webTitle: Brown keeps up child poverty drive

fields.headline: Brown keeps up child poverty drive
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will today set out the next stage of the government's strategy for taking 2m children out of poverty when he promises to quadruple the number of Sure-Start programmes and to create a network of children's funds to finance local community projects.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today set out the next stage of the government's strategy for taking 2m children out of poverty when he promises to quadruple the number of Sure-Start programmes and to create a network of children's funds to finance local community projects.

In an echo of what poverty campaigners call his "stubborn and persistent" drive to ease hardship among the elderly and the very young, the chancellor will also reveal that the poorest 20% of Britain's children have received almost half the total increase in Treasury support for children since 1997.

The Treasury-led programme, which is due to end the poverty of 1.2m children - a quarter of the 4m under-16s who are thought to live in poor households - will be extended into new areas and rescue a further 1m by 2010, Mr Brown will predict.

As with pension policy, ministers are targeting money at the poorest and Mr Brown will tell a Child Poverty Action Group (CPAG) conference that the poorest children will get £50 of public support next year - almost double the £28 they got in 1997.

Ministers have faced public anger and disappointment in the weeks since the budget: partly over the modest 75p increase in basic pensions; and partly because Mr Brown's children's tax credit is not due to come in until next year, whereas other family benefits, which it will replace, were abolished last month - creating a gap year.

In his CPAG speech in London, Mr Brown will seek to boost his credentials as a long-term anti-poverty campaigner. He will announce what amounts to an "alliance for children" between government and the voluntary sector, as well as the funding of 250 Sure-Start schemes by 2002. Currently there are 60 costing £450m.

That will enable poor communities - some as large as 15,000-strong, others as small as 500 people - to obtain extra services including special health visitors, play group help and teachers, packages worth up to £1,000 a head as ministers seek to emulate the success of the US Head Start programme which addressed deprivation early, among children up to four years olds.

Details of the regional children's funds will emerge during the multi-billion pound comprehensive spending review in July which is also due to restore high levels of funding for road programmes. But it will be used to meet special needs and will be done in conjunction with children's charities like the NSPCC. An inter-departmental group of ministers will monitor its progress.

 Gordon Brown came under criticism from Labour councillors defeated in the the recent elections last night when 78% of 150 ousted councillors said they lost their seats primarily because of anger over pensions, according to a straw poll carried out by the Times newspaper. Labour lost more than 500 seats in the elections.

Most of the councillors said that pensioners were furious at the modest rise the government offered in April and that voters showed their anger at the 75p increase in the state pension by staying at home on May 4.

webTitle: ITV defies flak over axed News at Ten

fields.headline: ITV defies flak over axed News at Ten
fields.trailText: ITV will tell television regulators this week that it has no intention of bringing back News at Ten, in defiance of mounting pressure to do so.
fields.body:
ITV will tell television regulators this week that it has no intention of bringing back News at Ten, in defiance of mounting pressure to do so.

In a report presented to a crucial meeting of the independent television commission on Thursday, the channel will not even propose the widely canvassed compromise solution of bringing forward the 11pm bulletin to 10.30pm.

Last night the veteran BBC broadcaster John Simpson joined calls for the return of the flagship bulletin axed last year to make room for drama and entertainment shows that gain higher ratings. But ITV chiefs said they would not be bounced into bringing it back.

Mr Simpson, accepting an award at the television Baftas for the BBC's coverage of the Kosovo conflict, said: "I should like very much to dedicate this award to the return of News at Ten to its proper place."

Later he added: "I have worked and lived for news for 34 years. The more news that people have about the world and the conditions that they live in and of what goes on around them [the better]. It is more important than ever.

"The idea that schedulers should shove News at Ten off, and say what matters is entertainment and ratings, is one of the most shameful things that has happened in my time in broadcasting. There is now the possibility that the people who shoved News at Ten so cavalierly aside will be forced to rethink."

The former News at Ten presenter Sir Alastair Burnet and two former ITN editors have submitted to the ITC a 39-point document outlining their concerns over the axing of News at Ten. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, last month called on the ITC to take a "robust approach" when considering ITV's performance over the past year.

ITV points out that audiences for programmes which replaced News at Ten are higher. It rejects claims that its programmes have fallen in quality. Sources point to ITC praise for the channel's output since News at Ten was axed.

ITV believes the commission has no legal right to force it to bring the bulletin back. Its decision not even to propose a compromise, taken at a meeting last Thursday, puts the ball back in the ITC's court. It will infuriate the commission's chairman, Sir Robin Biggam, who had hoped to be able to save face by accepting a compromise.

In its submission to the commission this week, ITV will point to recent successes in the late evening schedule and say it will invest even more in these sorts of programmes. Crucially, more investment will be made in the 10-11pm slot to boost ratings in the run-up to the 11pm news.

fields.headline: ICA to enact Jonestown massacre
fields.trailText: The Institute of Contemporary Arts in London is set to court controversy this summer by staging a re-enactment in a London park of the 1978 Jonestown massacre in which more than 900 followers of the Rev Jim Jones committed suicide in Guyana.
fields.body:
The Institute of Contemporary Arts in London is set to court controversy this summer by staging a re-enactment in a London park of the 1978 Jonestown massacre in which more than 900 followers of the Rev Jim Jones committed suicide in Guyana.

The project will launch later this month with a re-enactment of one of Jones's political and religious sermons from the mid-1970s, including a reconstruction of a "miracle healing" that was alleged to have taken place during the sermons.

The centrepiece will be a day-long event in July, when other elements of life under Jones will be reconstructed. The day will conclude with "White Nights", a re-enactment of the last few hours of the people's temple, culminating in the suicide and death scene at Jonestown.

Vivienne Gaskin, the ICA's director of live arts, said the aim was to demonstrate the power of cults and why people are attracted to them. "A significant part of the power of cults is their theatricality, where people are drawn in through theatrical means. The aim is to examine their power over ordinary people, and to show that the paths that lead to these extremes are not as far away from rational thinking as you might imagine."

Philip Dodd, director of the ICA, said yesterday: "From Uganda to the new right in America this is a very resonant subject. The reason I said we should do it was because this type of evangelical material is terribly powerful at the moment, and it is not going to go away."

But Ayman Akshar, director of the anti-cult campaigners, Triumph over London Cults, said: "I think on principle it is distasteful and disturbing to do something that glamorises or sanitises the image of someone who caused the death of so many. People do get attracted to join cults after seeing such images in films or in public displays."

The re-enactments are being created by Rob Dickinson, whose work has been widely exhibited in contemporary art galleries, but who is most famous for covertly creating crop circles.

The ICA is seeking a £7,000 grant from the London Arts Board for the re-enactment, which will involve several hundred participants, both professional actors and volunteers, who are being recruited through the internet and adverts in the Fortean Times.

fields.headline: Queen Mother 'exploited'
fields.trailText: The government has come under fire for its plans to charge businesses £500 for each guest they entertain at the parade to celebrate the Queen Mother's 100th birthday.
fields.body:
The government has come under fire for its plans to charge businesses £500 for each guest they entertain at the parade to celebrate the Queen Mother's 100th birthday.

The Conservative party attacked the defence secretary Geoff Hoon's decision to claw back some of the £400,000 cost of the July 19 pageant, saying that the public wanted the government to foot the entire bill.

The criticism followed a TV interview with Mr Hoon yesterday. When questioned about commercialising the parade, he told GMTV: "I don't know about logos but a number of individuals and a number of companies expressed the desire to be part of this marvellous celebration. And by doing so they will be reducing the cost to the public purse, and I am sure everyone would welcome that."

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said: "I think they would probably be taking a very different attitude if it were a piece of Cool Britannia. Because it is a piece of tradition and we are honouring a very long-established institution and an extremely well-loved figure, they are taking a rather cruder line."

The shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, said: "This appalling news highlights that this is a government that knows the price of everything and the value of nothing."

webTitle: Mugabe supporters invade Ian Smith's farm

fields.headline: Mugabe supporters invade Ian Smith's farm
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Dozens of angry supporters of President Robert Mugabe yesterday invaded the 6,000-acre cattle ranch of Zimbabwe's last white ruler, the stubborn and outspoken Ian Smith.
fields.body:
Dozens of angry supporters of President Robert Mugabe yesterday invaded the 6,000-acre cattle ranch of Zimbabwe's last white ruler, the stubborn and outspoken Ian Smith.

The occupation comes on the eve of a visit to Zimbabwe by the Commonwealth secretary-general Don McKinnon, who is expected to deliver a stern warning to Mr Mugabe about his continuing oppression of white farmers and the political opposition.

About 50 government supporters are now occupying Mr Smith's Gwenoro farm near the southern town of Shurugwe, 200 miles southeast of Harare.

Mr Smith, now 81, who led white-ruled Rhodesia throughout the 1960s and 1970s, played down the incident. He said he did not think squatters were targeting his farm because of his past opposition to Mr Mugabe. "No, they all love me. I've got more black friends than Mugabe at present."

He made light of the occupation. "It's just a few old timers from Shurugwe who are out of work," said Mr Smith from his Harare home. "I don't expect trouble. I've got a peaceful farm and there's no politics on the farm." But later in the day Mr Smith left for the farm, which is run by a manager.

Since Zimbabwe became independent in 1980, Mr Smith has lived peacefully in the country. Last month he suggested that he might run for parliament again to voice his opposition to Mr Mugabe's government and the recent collapse of law and order. Since February Mr Mugabe's supporters have invaded more than 1,200 white-owned farms, killed more than 20 opposition members, and beaten and tortured thousands of black opposition supporters.

Mr McKinnon arrives in Harare today as the violence shows no sign of abating.

Farmer John Weeks died in hospital yesterday after being shot when his farm, in the Beatrice area 40 miles south of Harare, was attacked on Thursday evening. Mr Weeks was shot a few miles away from where farmer Alan Dunn was bludgeoned to death by Mr Mugabe's supporters a week ago.

Mr Weeks' death brings to four the number of white farmers killed in the past six weeks. Sixteen black members of the opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), have been killed by government supporters during the same period.

Beatrice farmers say the area is teeming with militant veterans of the war against Rhodesian rule and other government supporters. Several white farmers have received death threats and hundreds of black farm labourers have been beaten for supporting the MDC.

The wave of violence is being promoted by Mr Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party in an effort to stamp out widespread support for the MDC before parliamentary elections, expected in July.

Mr McKinnon will see if the Commonwealth can field observers in the polls.

Opposition leaders and human rights activists say the government-sponsored violence against the MDC has already made free and fair polls impossible. "Thousands of Zimbabweans have been tortured by government agents, most in public settings which traumatises those that see the violence as well as those that experience it," said Tony Reeler, director of Amani Trust, which counsels victims of violence.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday warned Mr Mugabe against expelling whites from the country."It would be an enormous mistake for Zimbabwe to attempt to expel British citizens with resident qualifications because they provide the backbone for so much of the exports of Zimbabwe in the agricultural sector," he told BBC television.

His comments followed Zimbabwe's decision to order British nationals who have dual citizenship to surrender their Zimbabwean passports.

webTitle: Shayler will return to fight MI5 in court

fields.headline: Shayler will return to fight MI5 in court
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: David Shayler, the renegade MI5 officer now living in France, said yesterday that he will return to Britain to face criminal charges under the Official Secrets Act.
fields.body:
David Shayler, the renegade MI5 officer now living in France, said yesterday that he will return to Britain to face criminal charges under the Official Secrets Act.

He is expected to announce his decision at a demonstration outside the British embassy in Paris on Wednesday to mark the 1,000th day of what he calls his "political exile".

He has made no secret of his wish to return home ever since a Paris court released him from prison in 1998 following the British government's failed attempt to have him extradited, and he is known to have become frustrated by his effective status as a political refugee. But the trigger for his announcement is likely to be practical rather than emotional.

He is facing a charge of breaching the official secrets act - an act which provides no defence for serving or former members of the security and intelligence services. However, the European convention on human rights will become enforceable in English courts from October 2 and observers believe the act may breach the convention.

Over the past two years Shayler, MI5, and government lawyers have engaged in a lengthy bout of shadow boxing. Unenforceable court injunctions and media negotiations with government lawyers and Whitehall have led to allegations of malpractice by the security and intelligence agencies.

MI5 and MI6 reports recently posted on the internet have provided substance to Shayler's claims that MI6 knew about a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy, despite assertions by Robin Cook that the allegations were "pure fantasy".

Shayler has indicated that he would call the foreign secretary and the home secretary, Jack Straw, if he was brought to trial. He has already provided Mr Straw with the names of MI5 and MI6 officers who knew about the plot.

There is no doubt that publicity from a full Old Bailey criminal trial would not be welcome to the security and intelligence agencies. But it would be difficult for MI5 to back down and Shayler faces being held on remand for months awaiting trial.

John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty and Mr Shayler's lawyer, said yesterday: "It's been David's intention to face a trial for some time. The timing of this depends on discussions with the authorities. Certainly it is our intention to use the freedom of expression defence provided by the human rights act when it comes into force in October".

Shayler and the Mail on Sunday - which allegedly paid him £40,000 for the first disclosures he made in 1997 - also face a claim for damages in the civil courts. In a move which has widespread implications for the entire media, government lawyers claim all information supplied by Shayler about MI5 and MI6 is crown copyright and the media is bound by the same duty of confidence as any former crown servant. It would be sufficient, if the government gets its way, for it to claim that publication has caused "injury to the national interest".

Government lawyers are also intending to fight a court challenge by the Guardian and Observer against a ruling by an Old Bailey judge that the newspapers must hand over any notes or email they may possess relating to Shayler.

Mr Cook and Peter Hain, the foreign office minister, were horrified when they learned that the police special branch wanted to raid the newspapers' offices. MI5 has since tried to distance itself.

The police have also arrested and seized computer files of Julie Anne Davies, a student at Kingston university, in south west London, in connection with the Shayler case.

Shayler plans to climb a crucifix outside the British embassy in Paris, to deny betraying his country. He will say British people have a right to know about what he calls illegal actions taken in their name. "I signed the Official Secrets Act, not the unofficial secrets act," he says.

fields.headline: 'A neighbourhood was blown away'
fields.standfirst: 15 dead, 280 missing, as shell-shocked Dutch ask how could 100 tonnes of fireworks be stored in residential area
fields.trailText: Reeling from a thunderous explosion that tore their lives apart, hundreds of residents of this Dutch town were spending last night in emergency shelters and asking troubling questions about the disaster that befell them.
fields.body:
Reeling from a thunderous explosion that tore their lives apart, hundreds of residents of this Dutch town were spending last night in emergency shelters and asking troubling questions about the disaster that befell them.

Rescue teams searched all day under a blazing sun for survivors of Saturday's massive blast at a fireworks warehouse in the heart of a quiet suburb and adjusted the confirmed death toll to 15. But officials believe it will climb to at least 20.

Sixty people are in hospital, 11 in intensive care, and some 280 missing, among them a firefighter, though the figure is expected to fall as local people comply with requests to register with the authorities. More than 560 are injured.

"Arson could be a possibility," the town's mayor, Jan Mans, said as it was revealed that two other serious fires were reported in the town of 160,000 people last Friday and Wednesday.

There were unconfirmed reports of knocking sounds from beneath the still-smoking rubble last night. "If people are still under the ruins, or in cellars, the toll could rise again," one official said as the town hall confirmed that Enschede also has a fireworks factory - though in an industrial area. The factory was the scene of an angry demonstration yesterday.

Responding to the furore about the location of such a potentially dangerous installation, the prime minister, Wim Kok, announced an immediate investigation into the licensing of such premises.

It was unclear exactly how many warehouses were scattered around the Netherlands, since they are licensed by municipalities. However the Dutch news agency ANP said there were 11 depots, in addition to the two in Enschede.

The Dutch are fascinated with fireworks, spending hours in the streets on New Year's Eve setting off rockets, sparklers and firecrackers. Professional displays are common all year round.

In the tree-lined streets of the Roombeek neighbourhood, the epicentre of the blast, shards of glass and piles of debris carpeted the tree-lined streets in scenes more reminiscent of a war zone than a sleepy residential area.

Burned and flattened cars and mangled bicycles were skewed at crazy angles among lumps of concrete. Scores of neat semi-detached houses had their roofs blown off and blocks of flats had their windows shattered.

Tow trucks and hearses with drawn curtains were the only vehicles allowed past the main police roadblock outside the bingo hall on Oldenzaalsestraat. Yards away, workmen in overalls were fencing off the smouldering crater that marked the site of the SE fireworks depot.

As onlookers bicycled up to inspect the scene, angry residents complained they had not known that explosives were stored at the depot. "Lots of us had no idea it existed," said Boudewyn van Es. "Some thought it was a paper recycling plant. People are devastated."

Mr Kok, closely followed by Queen Beatrix, arrived at lunchtime to offer comfort to survivors. "It gets you by the throat... It's breathtaking being there, as if bombs had fallen on roofs".

"Its chaotic," said one Dutch journalist, while a BBC veteran was reminded of the aftermath of the 1988 Lockerbie disaster. Outside the town hall a satellite city sprouted overnight as the world's media descended on eastern Holland.

The disaster was the country's deadliest since October 1992, when an Israeli jumbo jet cargo plane crashed into an apartment block near Amsterdam, killing 43 people.

Residents spoke with horror and awe as they described the huge red fireball that sent a blastwave across Enschede at 3.30pm on Saturday.

"A whole neighbourhood was blown away," said Freek Tonis, who lives just down the street from the destroyed blocks. "It was like a warzone after the first explosion."

Amateur video showed a red-orange glow as the warehouse erupted, and then showers of fireworks shooting up in the sky. The blast was heard in nearby towns and across the German border.

The fire commander, Aaad Gross, said last night that crowds were watching the initial blaze for about half an hour before the blast occurred. "It was a standard procedure for a normal fire and turned into something else," he said.

It is believed that the fire spread to a storage area holding an estimated 100 tonnes of fireworks. A formal inquiry is due to begin today.

Witnesses said the explosion was so powerful that pieces of glass and cement were seen flying through the air several miles from the scene.

Many of the casualties were among people who had gathered on nearby streets unaware of the threat the fire posed to the neighbourhood, where Turkish migrants and other foreigners live side by side with their Dutch neighbours.

Warnings were issued about the danger of asbestos pollution from insulation material blown into the air from the roof of the nearby Grolsch brewery, but were withdrawn later.

Firecrews, ambulances and helicopters sped to the town from all over the Netherlands, and from Germany whose emergency help won lavish praise from the Dutch.

City officials insisted that the warehouse met normal safety standards and had been inspected and approved as recently as last Wednesday.

But there was concern that the authorities not been efficient enough in dealing with a recent spate of fires along the northern sector of the city's ring-road.

"I really think we have a problem with a pyromaniac," said an electrician, Heinz Focke, surveying broken glass littering his brother's office a few hundred yards from the blast. "And the police can't seem to do anything about it."

Mr Focke said that recent problems between Turks and Armenians in the usually peaceful university town might also be behind the recent fires. "We have an image of being tolerant in this country, but its not always like that," he said.

Mysterious blazes

Enschede has been hit by a series of fires in recent weeks:

 Last week there were two big fires at Arno furniture store, on Wednesday, followed by Hartmann Garden Furniture on Friday. In both cases police suspect arson

 Last month, the town was hit by a series of smaller fires all of which started at the same time each evening, 11pm. Police have arrested a suspect in connection with these

fields.headline: Retrial plan hijacked by Tories
fields.standfirst:
Hague steals initiative by calling for change to double jeopardy rule

Leader comment
fields.trailText: The Conservatives yesterday stepped up their new offensive on law and order when they unexpectedly endorsed plans to breach the "double jeopardy" rule and allow acquitted suspects to be tried a second time in exceptional circumstances.
fields.body:
The Conservatives yesterday stepped up their new offensive on law and order when they unexpectedly endorsed plans to breach the "double jeopardy" rule and allow acquitted suspects to be tried a second time in exceptional circumstances.

It prompted indignant Labour cries of "knee-jerk headline seeking", and of bandwagon populism, because - as shadow ministers admit - the Tory move follows a similar recommendation by the Macpherson committee which investigated the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence. It also anticipates an expected recommendation by the law commission, due next year.

When Sir William Macpherson made his proposal in February 1999, the then-shadow home secretary, Sir Norman Fowler, warned against the dangers of "legislating in anger" - a reference to the fact that three of the young men suspected of stabbing Lawrence in 1993 cannot face trial again because they were acquitted of murder in a private prosecution brought by the Lawrence family in 1996.

But the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, who trailed the shift on television yesterday ahead of William Hague's assault on the "liberal establishment" before the Police Federation on Thursday, refused to be apologetic.

"What of course people really mean when they say we are being populist is that we are responding to people's concerns," she said on GMTV. Stressing that only a few cases would be affected by the change in the rule, she added: "I am not here talking about massive numbers of retrials - heaven forbid."

Mr Hague plans to promise that a Tory government will stand for "more Pcs and less PC - as in politically correct. He is already claiming that his tough talk on law and order, as well as the asylum controversy, lies behind Labour's drop in the opinion polls this month. Both private Tory polling and a Gallup poll registered a 3% fall in support for Labour.

The Gallup poll for last Friday's Daily Telegraph still put Labour ahead, at 47% to 31%, twice the 43% to 35% lead recorded in ICM's private poll for the Tories, but both suggest an anti-government shift.

Paul Boateng, Jack Straw's Home Office deputy, complained: "William Hague's knee-jerk headline seeking is yet another example of his poor judgment. The government accepted the Macpherson report recommendation to consider this issue. "The law commission is giving very careful consideration to this issue. That is the right way to deal with this important and sensitive matter."

A bill is expected next year, but it will not be retrospective. That means that the three Lawrence suspects who were acquitted four years ago will not be caught by the new law.

As in several dramatic breakthroughs involving long unsolved cases, the most likely kind of substantial new evidence is expected to come from rapidly-expanding techniques for tracing DNA from clothing and other items.

The row prompted John Wadham, director of the leading civil rights group Liberty, to dismiss it as "macho" party politics. "The protection from double jeopardy is a fundamental part of our criminal justice system and we remove it at our peril," he said after Tory officials confirmed the policy shift. "Innocent people should not have to face one trial, be locked up for months at a time and then go through the whole thing again before they are finally acquitted."

But David Winnick, a Labour member of the Commons home affairs select committee, said that there was "undoubtedly an argument" for such a change, providing adequate safeguards were in place.

Ministers expect that the law commission will confirm the interim endorsement of the change which it made last year before it was put out to wider consultation. They point to the breach in the double jeopardy principle made by the Tories, with Labour support, in 1986 when the then home secretary, Michael Howard, permitted a second trial if jury tampering was later unearthed.

Mr Straw is said to have been anxious not to fall foul of the new Human Rights Act, which will soon make the European convention on human rights enforceable in UK courts. The law commission has reassured him on that point. In any case, Scottish judges, operating under their separate legal code, can already order fresh trials in special cases.

The commission has indicated that retrials should be ordered only when sentences of more than three years are likely, when "the interests of justice" would be served, and when evidence has come to hand that was not previously available.

fields.headline: Modern guy
fields.standfirst:
US profile praises Blair the family man

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: A smiling Tony Blair was pictured on yesterday's New York Times magazine, holding his infant child-to-be, an artist's impression of how the prime minister will look as a proud father, above the headline: Tony Blair, Modern Guy.
fields.body:
A smiling Tony Blair was pictured on yesterday's New York Times magazine, holding his infant child-to-be, an artist's impression of how the prime minister will look as a proud father, above the headline: Tony Blair, Modern Guy.

The portrait reflected a complimentary profile of Mr Blair as a new brand of world leader and caring family man.

The author, Warren Hoge, wrote: "There seem to be no embarrassments lurking in Blair's past or imminent eruptions of shoddy conduct in his present. For people who liked Clinton's promise but felt betrayed by his performance, Mr Blair might be their man."

He added that Mr Blair was "exercising his power in a personal manner more akin to an American president than a British prime minister".

With his pledge of solidarity with Mr Clinton during the impeachment crisis, and his call to arms over Kosovo, he had "attracted international attention as a reliable go-to guy with some unflinching acts at moments marked by hesitation in other western capitals".

But the greatest praise is reserved for Mr Blair's virtues as a husband and father. The article points out that his working day is organised to guarantee him time with Cherie and their three children.

In an interview, Mr Blair described his reaction when Cherie told him she was pregnant.

"I was here at the desk writing my party conference speech," he said. "And she came to me and said, 'I've got some news for you and it's going to be rather shocking about the family'.

"It was not a moment to forget, but I do a little because I was so shocked. Delighted of course, but really shocked, and I think I said 'You're joking' and she said, 'No, I'm not'."

Defending his decision not to take paternity leave, he said: "If people want their politicians to be honest, they have to know I cannot stop being prime minister.

"And it's usually my job to take care of things at night anyway. Cherie has many excellent qualities, but once she goes to sleep, it takes a minor nuclear explosion to wake her up."

webTitle: Pressure on Cook to spell out UK role

fields.headline: Pressure on Cook to spell out UK role
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive: what is happening in Sierra Leone?
fields.trailText: The arrival of a naval amphibious taskforce off the west African coast yesterday pointed to further British military involvement in Sierra Leone, despite adamant ministerial denials of "mission creep".
fields.body:
The arrival of a naval amphibious taskforce off the west African coast yesterday pointed to further British military involvement in Sierra Leone, despite adamant ministerial denials of "mission creep".

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who said that the expertise shown by the British troops in Sierra Leone had "reinforced respect for Britain around the world", insisted that they would not get involved in combat duties with the UN.

He said on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost: "We expect this to be over in a month. We want it to be over in a month, and we want to keep that deadline there as pressure on the UN to get their people there in a month.

"We don't want that timetable to slip... What we cannot do is contribute combat troops. That is not going to change," he said.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said the taskforce was a "precautionary measure".

Though he said he did not anticipate the presence of extra troops on the ground "at this stage", he said on BBC Radio 4's World This Weekend, "this is an extremely uncertain, dangerous environment and the deployment of the UK ships' potential reinforcements, should they become necessary, has given the UK commander much greater flexibility than ground forces allow."

A British military source was quoted by Reuters yesterday as saying: "There are no plans to bring facilities or men ashore but I don't think we have moved 1,000 men all the way just to let them sit out there."

Officials told the Guardian that the taskforce gave the "flexibility for other options".

The taskforce consists of the helicopter carrier HMS Ocean, with 600 Royal Marines and an artillery battery on board, the aircraft carrier HMS Illustrious, equipped with Sea Harriers and six landing craft, and the frigates Cumberland, Chatham, and Argyll.

It was becoming clear last night that the government was clinging to the hope that with the promised arrival of UN reinforcements - 1,400 troops from India, Jordan, and Bangladesh - Britain would not be dragged into an open-ended commitment.

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, demanded an inquiry into the government's handling of the crisis. Suggestions that Mr Cook pressed President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah into giving Revolutionary United Front leaders government posts and control of Sierra Leone's diamond mining region as part of last year's peace agreement had to be examined, he said.

The RUF's leader, Foday Sankoh, was responsible for the mutilations and killings attributed to his forces, Mr Maude said.

"To impose him as part of a new government is quite wrong, and it is precisely that that seems to have led to today's civil war."

The Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said: "It has now become clear that British forces are in for a much longer period in Sierra Leone than the Government has previously admitted. The precise nature of the political and military objective must be spelled out."

The UN force, whose mandate limits its troops to firing in self-defence, numbers 9,000.

webTitle: Trimble haggles on IRA arms dumps

fields.headline: Trimble haggles on IRA arms dumps
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, will today press weapons inspectors on how exactly they will verify IRA moves to put arms beyond use, aware his last-minute haggling and arm-twisting will determine the future political course of Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, will today press weapons inspectors on how exactly they will verify IRA moves to put arms beyond use, aware his last-minute haggling and arm-twisting will determine the future political course of Northern Ireland.

Mr Trimble will also seek reassurances from General John de Chastelain, head of the independent international commission on decommissioning, on whether IRA arms dumps will be sealed, and how. He wants to know if all dumps will be inspected before June next year, the new deadline the British and Irish governments have imposed.

Weapons inspectors Cyril Ramaphosa, ex-ANC secretary general, and Martti Ahtisaari, former Finnish president, arrive in Belfast today. There are hopes they may soon be allowed access to three substantial dumps, all believed to be in south-west Ireland.

Gen de Chastelain, who will oversee the work of the weapons inspectors, said of the IRA's move: "They've gone much further in their statement. They've said things they have not said before."

Confidence in the IRA move was underlined yesterday when Sinn Fein's chief negotiator Martin McGuinness said the inspections would go ahead "come what may". It was not dependent on the resumption of the devolved power-sharing administration.

On ITV's Jonathan Dimbleby programme, when he was asked whether the arms inspection process could proceed in the absence of a restored executive, Mr McGuinness said: "Everybody knows if the IRA make a statement, they will make it happen."

To Mr Dimbleby's response that this meant the process of inspections would go ahead "come what may", he replied: "Absolutely. I think it must."

Mr Trimble is expected to make his decision on Wednesday on whether to recommend to Saturday's meeting of the Ulster Unionist council that it backs a return to government with Sinn Fein a week today. He appears unlikely to go ahead unless he is confident of victory.

This week sees a battle for the soul of unionism, and will prove the most tumultuous in recent history. If Mr Trimble gambles and loses, his five-year leadership is almost certainly at an end. The Good Friday agreement will also be effectively dead.

Mr Trimble, who privately backs the IRA move, knows his chances of persuading the 858 council delegates depend on retaining the support of John Taylor, the deputy leader. He was initially strongly in favour, but has appeared increasingly lukewarm. Some pundits believe he can deliver about 8% of council votes.

As crucial to Mr Trimble will be the London-based PR guru, David Burnside, a long term ally. A pro-agreement Unionist, he now has serious reservations about it.

Some believe Mr Trimble made a critical error in failing to come out early last week strongly behind a return to government. The anti-agreement camp, some of which privately concedes there is an important shift in the IRA's position, was badly split, and one of its senior figures said they might never have recovered.

But anti-agreement Ulster Unionists are canvassing hard for the 60 votes in the middle third which will determine the outcome.

Mr Trimble, who looked as though he would commit early, would then have been able to cash in on a BBC Northern Ireland poll on Thursday. It said two thirds of Ulster Unionists were prepared to return to the executive on the basis of the IRA statement.

The council is more hardline, and the poll contained another worry for Mr Trimble. It showed Unionist opposition to the agreement up from 44% two years ago to 57%, indicating a last chance for the deal and that the end game is nigh.

Weapons inspectors Cyril Ramaphosa, ex-ANC secretary general, and Martti Ahtisaari, former Finnish president, arrive in Belfast today. There are hopes they may soon be allowed access to three substantial dumps, all believed to be in south-west Ireland. Gen de Chastelain, who will oversee the work of the weapons inspectors, said of the IRA's move: "They've gone much further in their statement. They've said things they have not said before." Confidence in the IRA move was underlined yesterday when Sinn Fein's chief negotiator Martin McGuinness said the inspections would go ahead "come what may". It was not dependent on the resumption of the devolved power-sharing administration. On ITV's Jonathan Dimbleby programme, when he was asked whether the arms inspection process could proceed in the absence of a restored executive, Mr McGuinness said: "Everybody knows if the IRA make a statement, they will make it happen." To Mr Dimbleby's response that this meant the process of inspections would go ahead "come what may", he replied: "Absolutely. I think it must." Mr Trimble is expected to make his decision on Wednesday on whether to recommend to Saturday's meeting of the Ulster Unionist council that it backs a return to government with Sinn Fein a week today. He appears unlikely to go ahead unless he is confident of victory. This week sees a battle for the soul of unionism, and will prove the most tumultuous in recent history. If Mr Trimble gambles and loses, his five-year leadership is almost certainly at an end. The Good Friday agreement will also be effectively dead. Mr Trimble, who privately backs the IRA move, knows his chances of persuading the 858 council delegates depend on retaining the support of John Taylor, the deputy leader. He was initially strongly in favour, but has appeared increasingly lukewarm. Some pundits believe he can deliver about 8% of council votes. As crucial to Mr Trimble will be the London-based PR guru, David Burnside, a long term ally. A pro-agreement Unionist, he now has serious reservations about it. Some believe Mr Trimble made a critical error in failing to come out early last week strongly behind a return to government. The anti-agreement camp, some of which privately concedes there is an important shift in the IRA's position, was badly split, and one of its senior figures said they might never have recovered. But anti-agreement Ulster Unionists are canvassing hard for the 60 votes in the middle third which will determine the outcome. Mr Trimble, who looked as though he would commit early, would then have been able to cash in on a BBC Northern Ireland poll on Thursday. It said two thirds of Ulster Unionists were prepared to return to the executive on the basis of the IRA statement. The council is more hardline, and the poll contained another worry for Mr Trimble. It showed Unionist opposition to the agreement up from 44% two years ago to 57%, indicating a last chance for the deal and that the end game is nigh.

webTitle: Granada to split and gear up to be key ITV player

fields.headline: Granada to split and gear up to be key ITV player
fields.trailText: Granada, the media and hospitality group, is understood to be in advanced talks to split itself in two and then merge its hotels and catering business with Compass Group, one of the world's largest catering firms.
fields.byline: Paul Murphy, Andrew Clark  and Jill Treanor
fields.body:
Granada, the media and hospitality group, is understood to be in advanced talks to split itself in two and then merge its hotels and catering business with Compass Group, one of the world's largest catering firms.

This £18bn shuffling of assets, affecting almost 300,000 staff worldwide, will reposition Granada, run by Gerry Robinson and Charles Allen, as a pure media group - leaving it ready to mount a takeover bid for either of its two main rival ITV broadcasters, United News & Media and Carlton Communications.

At the same time, Compass, taking in more than 400 hotels that were once part of the Forte group, will be expanded to become a business with catering and hotel interests in more than 80 countries.

Granada has already said it is "minded" to bid for one of its big ITV rivals, having been forced to show its hand by the planned merger of Carlton and United announced in November. As a result, the future ownership of the entire ITV network is being examined by the Competition Commission.

Under the codename Grasshopper, investment bankers have been working for several weeks, with a formal announcement planned for later this month.

Advisers to both companies refused to comment. In an attempt to keep the plan secret, the companies are understood to have developed a cover story that Granada and Compass are working on an internet venture to buy food supplies.

But as details of the talks began to leak last night, TheStreet.co.uk, the financial website, reported that all senior leave at Granada had been cancelled in order to manage what amounts to the most far-reaching restructuring of the group in its history.

The deal will be seen as a swansong for Mr Robinson, Granada's 52-year-old chairman, who after the takeover of Forte four years ago declared he wanted to complete one last multi-billion-pound transaction before retiring to his native Ireland when he reaches 55.

He has always been identified with the hospitality side of the business, and Mr Robinson led the original management buyout of the catering business from the Grand Metropolitan conglomerate in 1987. Also involved in the buyout was Compass's chairman, Francis Mackay, and this month's deal will reunite the pair. Their original purchase of Compass has been described as the most successful management buyout of all time.

Mr Allen was also at Compass and followed Mr Robinson to Granada after the latter was poached in 1991 to run what was then a struggling leisure group.

At the same time, the move will alarm Lord Hollick, the Labour peer at the helm of United, and Carlton chairman Michael Green.

Mr Robinson and Mr Allen have long argued that the ITV network needed just one owner if it were to compete against cable and satellite TV.

Such an industry structure would require fresh legislation, since currently no single business can command more than 15% of audience share or 25% of advertising revenue.

But the ITV prize amounts to almost £2bn in annual advertising revenues, and Granada's declaration in January that it was considering bidding for either United or Carlton was designed to wreck their own £8bn merger plans.

With Granada shorn of its hotel and catering interests, critics in the City and in industry will be less able to argue that taking over another media rival would produce an unwieldy group.

webTitle: Israel will keep South Lebanon militia armed

fields.headline: Israel will keep South Lebanon militia armed
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel will leave its proxy militia in south Lebanon a farewell gift of arms and equipment, the deputy defence minister, Efraim Sneh, said yesterday, increasing the prospect of fresh bloodshed after Israeli troops withdraw in the weeks ahead.
fields.body:
Israel will leave its proxy militia in south Lebanon a farewell gift of arms and equipment, the deputy defence minister, Efraim Sneh, said yesterday, increasing the prospect of fresh bloodshed after Israeli troops withdraw in the weeks ahead.

"As long as it is not safe for the South Lebanese Army, they are going to have to protect themselves in the Lebanese way," Mr Sneh said. "They will have the means to defend themselves."

If that is the case then, paradoxically, Israel's belated decision to respect UN resolution 425 and end its 22-year occupation of south Lebanon will lead to an increase in violence.

An armed, active SLA will reduce the UN's ability to deploy an expanded force in the nine-mile strip vacated by Israel. The UN had told Israel to disarm the SLA's 2,500 men as a condition for strengthening its forces in south Lebanon.

Israel's refusal to do so will leave its vacated "security zone" up for grabs come July, with Hizbullah guerrillas and perhaps even militant Palestinian groups attacking the settlements along Israel's northern border and drawing retribution on Lebanon. Neither Lebanon nor Syria, a patron of Hizbullah, is willing to guarantee that Hizbullah guerrillas will cease their attacks in the event of an Israeli withdrawal.

Mr Sneh said Israel would respond forcefully to any at tacks on its territory from Lebanon, and would not hesitate to attack Syrian targets in Lebanon, increasing the prospect of an all-out war.

Mr Sneh confirmed that preparations were going ahead for the July 7 deadline for the Israeli withdrawal.

Mr Sneh said: "Some preparations have been made on the Israeli side, and some on the Lebanese side. The question is what the reality will be after the pullout. Will it be a reality of ongoing fighting, or the reality of an agreement?"

The indications are that Syria and Lebanon are going to harry the departing forces to the end. On Saturday the Lebanese prime minister, Selim el-Hoss, demanded that Israeli forces should withdraw from an area known as Havat Shiva, making it difficult for Israel to claim that it has honoured the UN resolutions.

Hizbullah said yesterday it would seek government pardons for any member of the SLA who kills an Israeli soldier or an SLA officer.

 Israeli troops shot and wounded 15 Palestinians yesterday when demonstrators in the West Bank and Gaza Strip demanded the release of hundreds of Palestinians from Israeli jails, witnesses said.

The demonstrators, near an army camp in the Jewish settlement of Netzarim, were protesting against the detention of 1,650 Palestinians and commemorating the 52nd anniversary of what Palestinians call the nakba (great catastrophe) of Israel's creation.

webTitle: Computer to police EU driving offences

fields.headline: Computer to police EU driving offences
fields.trailText: Drivers who commit traffic offences anywhere on holiday in Europe may find themselves taken off the road under proposals to give foreign police instant computer access to United Kingdom driving licence records.
fields.body:
Drivers who commit traffic offences anywhere on holiday in Europe may find themselves taken off the road under proposals to give foreign police instant computer access to United Kingdom driving licence records.

A European computer system, developed by the Dutch and at present confined to tracing stolen vehicles, is soon to be expanded to include verification of licences - enabling authorities abroad to find out previous offences committed by the motorist.

The Irish Republic is going one stage further by introducing a "penalty points" system identical to that of the United Kingdom and allowing instant action by the Garda against motorists breaking the law.

The European-wide system would mean a UK driver caught speeding, for example, by foreign police could be banned from driving in that country if a licence check showed the driver was already on the verge of a points ban.

In the case of a tourist driving in the Republic, offences would lead to penalty points being imposed and those points being binding on the motorist's UK licence.

The computer system, the European car and driving licence information system or Eucaris, operates in Britain, Belgium, Germany, the Netherlands and Luxemburg, but is being expanded under bilateral agreements across the European Union.

Seven other member states are negotiating to be included and the Irish Republic is examining the conversion of its driver, vehicle and police files so it can be aligned with the system.

Last night the scheme was given a cautious welcome by the AA, saying it believed a European-wide system of traffic penalties was a good idea "in principle" but would be hard to put into practice".

Andrew Howard, the AA's head of road safety, said: "I think the principle we would be happy with, but we really want to see the nuts and bolts.

"For example, some countries don't ban you for a year for drink driving. If an Englishman is convicted over there, does that mean his disqualification becomes a year (because that is what he would get as an Englishman) or does he get a lesser ban?

"If a person from country X is prosecuted here, does it mean his penalty is diminished when he returns to his country? All those things will have to be worked out fairly first if this scheme is to work.

"We also have to watch out for anomalies where some countries rely very heavily on the statement given by the motorist at the time of the offence. While you may be OK if the offence is dealt solely by a fine system, but if you do not speak French and then have to go back to France to defend yourself, you could be in trouble."

Details of the latest moves have been obtained by the Guardian under the Irish freedom of information act following a meeting of the countries involved in the project in Coleraine last year.

The equivalent civil service policy papers would be banned by Jack Straw, the home secretary, for 30 years under Britain's draft freedom of information act now going through parliament.

The documents relate to a meeting between Lord Dubs, then a junior Northern Ireland minister, and his Irish counterpart, Noel Dempsey, in Dublin in December 1998. They reveal that the two governments, alarmed about the accident rates and drivers escaping convictions on both sides of the border, wanted much more cooperation.

webTitle: Doctors and nurses to be trained together to relax elitist divide

fields.headline: Doctors and nurses to be trained together to relax elitist divide
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Doctors will train alongside nurses and other health professionals in an attempt to end remoteness and elitism within the medical profession, under a radical scheme proposed for the NHS.
fields.body:
Doctors will train alongside nurses and other health professionals in an attempt to end remoteness and elitism within the medical profession, under a radical scheme proposed for the NHS.

The recommendation, from one of the modernisation action teams set up by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, is likely to be incorporated in the national plan for the NHS to be published in July.

It follows the revelation that one patient paid 22 visits to 12 different doctors but was told to go home and forget about his symptoms before he was diagnosed with tongue cancer.

The South Yorkshire businessman Steven Harley, 41, has now been advised that his cancer is inoperable.

Mike Richards, the cancer tsar, said improving communication skills for doctors was "of critical importance".

He said Mr Harley's case highlighted "the fact that communication is a two-way process. It is about listening as well as talking. We need to listen to what patients are saying. We need, when they are coming back on multiple occasions, to pay heed to that patient.

"I accept that, along with the rest of society, we are moving from paternalism to partnership. We may not be doing that as fast as society and patients want us to. What we have got to do is learn how to work in partnership with patients."

Judy Hargadon, chief executive of Barnet health authority, who is on the modernisation team looking at professional issues, said she would like to see a modular approach to training, which would benefit patients, professionals and the NHS by introducing more flexibility to the system.

Trainee doctors, nurses and therapists would take certain modules - such as communication skills, ethics and basic understanding of the human body - together.

It would help to break down barriers between different professionals, as well as assisting teamwork. "Groups would be better able to communicate with each other because they would have learned together," said Ms Hargadon.

There were other benefits. Medical training was rigid: doctors training exclusively as doctors, physiotherapists as physiotherapists, and so on. Anybody who wanted to change their role had to go back to the beginning.

A modular approach to training would allow a nurse or therapist later to become accredited to undertake certain aspects of another professional's role.

Mr Milburn, who has said that he wanted to end demarcation between health professionals, would be more than willing to take on board the team's thinking, but there is bound to be opposition to what Ms Hargadon said was lateral thinking - and others will see as diluting professionalism. Although nurse practitioners now work alongside GPs in some areas, there has long been a schism between the professions based on such factors as education, earning power and gender.

But Ms Hargadon believes the barriers are coming down. "There are wonderful examples of nurses and doctors working together incredibly well, much more than when I joined the NHS 20 years or so ago," she said.

In interviews with researchers, many health professionals complained about the rigidities of training.

"It causes some job dissatisfaction," said Ms Hargadon. "People are only interested in barriers and divides when they feel threatened by a change. This change offers so much for people."

webTitle: Thousands of mothers tell gun lobby: enough is enough

fields.headline: Thousands of mothers tell gun lobby: enough is enough
fields.standfirst: Gun violence in the US: special report
fields.trailText: Hundreds of thousands of American mothers descended on Washington and about 60 other US cities yesterday to voice their support for stricter gun laws, making one of the country's biggest demonstrations for many years.
fields.body:
Hundreds of thousands of American mothers descended on Washington and about 60 other US cities yesterday to voice their support for stricter gun laws, making one of the country's biggest demonstrations for many years.

The Million Mom March was focused on the capital, where a huge crowd of women, along with large numbers of men and children, gathered to mark Mothers' Day on the Mall, the green strip which leads to the Capitol building housing Congress.

At the other end, below the Washington Monument, about 2,000 people calling themselves the Armed Informed Mothers staged a counter-protest against gun control.

President Clinton threw his weight behind the Million Mom March, holding a morning reception on the lawn of the White House for the rally's leaders and the mothers of children killed by guns.

"One of the things your mother teaches you when you grow up is that an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure," he told the crowd. But he pointed out that a string of gun-control measures had been stalled in congress for more than a year by the opposition of the gun lobby.

Violent crime has been falling in the US for eight years, but the impact of firearms remains far higher than in other modern industrialised countries. Every year 32,000 Americans - including 12 children and teenagers each day - die from gunfire through murders, accidents and suicides.

Among the speakers at the gun-control rally in Washington were three women whose daughters died in the Dunblane massacre. Those murders triggered the Snowdrop Campaign, which eventually led to a ban on handguns in Britain.

Before the rally one of the Dunblane mothers, Alison Crozier, said she believed that the Million Mom campaign could ultimately outweigh the entrenched power of the gun lobby.

"There are more mums who want something done. We did it in Scotland, they can do it here if they just stand up and do something about it," she told the BBC.

The counter-rally may have been tiny by comparison, but the pro-gun demonstrators represent a powerful constituency. According to a survey published yesterday, 45% of US households own a gun, and one in four Americans has been threatened with a gun.

The gun-control lobbyists want child-proof trigger locks to be made compulsory, and a 72-hour "cooling-off periods" for would-be buyers at weekend gun shows. Their opponents say those restrictions are only the first step towards a total ban.

One of the Armed Informed Mothers coordinators, Debra Collins, said her life was saved 16 years ago when she used a gun to defend herself against her violent ex-husband.

"Thank God, my firearm was unencumbered by a trigger lock," she said.

Organisers of the Million Mom March hoped that the turnout nationally would top a million. The final figure was unclear yesterday afternoon, but May Leigh Blek, one of the movement's founders, said enough people had shown up to put gun control on the legislative agenda in congress.

She said: "I hope when legislators see so many mothers, it will give them the courage to do the right thing."

fields.trailText: British attempts to weld pro-government fighters in Sierra Leone into an effective force were set back yesterday when the army and militia turned on each other during a rebel assault on Masiaka, a town about 40 miles east of the capital.
fields.body:
British attempts to weld pro-government fighters in Sierra Leone into an effective force were set back yesterday when the army and militia turned on each other during a rebel assault on Masiaka, a town about 40 miles east of the capital.

Elsewhere the army and UN forces pushed back the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) as the British laid the ground for an assault on the diamond fields, which fund the rebels' war.

The UN said last night that 18 of the nearly 500 peacekeepers being held hostage by the RUF had been released near the Liberian border, including the only known British detainee. But it was not clear if the move heralded a mass release of the others.

The chief of Britain's defence staff, General Sir Charles Guthrie, arrived in Freetown yesterday to reiterate the government's line that its troops were not here to engage in combat against the RUF.

"It's absolutely clear why the British troops are here. They are here to evacuate our people, British passport holders," he said. "We are not part of the UN. We do not intend to be part of the UN."

But by Saturday there were so few Britons remaining in Freetown who wished to be evacuated that the only people to be flown to Senegal were a group of Senegalese.

Government forces held the town of Masiaka yesterday even through members of the army turned on their supposed allies, the Kamajor militia, during a rebel assault.

The battle was important because Masiaka was being reinforced as a launch pad for attacks deeper into RUF territory.

Asked about the problems in the government's forces, Gen Guthrie was non-committal.

"It's very easy for everybody to criticise. This is a very difficult task. What we are doing is very important indeed," the general said.

"It was always going to be difficult in Sierra Leone. It was never a quick fix. But the objectives remain the same. We want disarmament, prosperity, democracy and the military subject to political control."

The government continued to arrest RUF officials it accuses of plotting a coup accidentally foiled by the rebels themselves when they fired on an unarmed protest march a week ago, killing 19 people.

At the weekend the justice minister, Solomon Berewa, accused the RUF leader, Foday Sankoh, of planning a "very violent coup" in which leading government officials and supporters were to be executed.

More than 30 senior RUF leaders have been picked up at their homes and in hotels.

Mr Berewa said that the rebels had taken almost 500 peacekeepers hostage in order to paralyse the UN before the planned coup. Local newspapers have highlighted Mr Sankoh's derogatory comments about the UN at a press conference a fortnight ago as another indication of his intent.

"The UN is free to send 20,000 troops to Sierra Leone, but who would scare a pregnant women with a dead penis?" he said.

Mr Sankoh's whereabouts remain a mystery. He has not been seen publicly for a week. The Sierra Leone government, the UN and the British military all insist they have no reliable information of his whereabouts.

Brigadier David Richards, commander of British forces in the area, said yesterday that he did not believe Mr Sankoh had yet reasserted his authority over the RUF.

"He could be dead," he added.

The World Food Programme (WFP) said it was concerned about the fate of at least 65,000 displaced people trapped in rebel-held areas, who were reliant on food aid.

Its spokeswoman Aya Schneerson said there had been no deliveries to camps in parts of the north and centre of the country since the crisis erupted nearly two weeks ago.

"Our concerns are for the ones we can't reach and the fact that it's getting close to the planting season. If you have a crisis when the planting season starts that's not good in the long run," she said.

fields.headline: Blair rejects 'quick fix' for pound
fields.standfirst: Artificial devaluation would hit economic stability says prime minister, as TUC urges commitment to euro
fields.trailText: A defiant Tony Blair will tomorrow reject calls for the government to mastermind a devaluation of sterling to aid Britain's battered manufacturing sector. An artificial depreciation of the currency will cause economic instability and cost jobs, he will insist.
fields.body:
A defiant Tony Blair will tomorrow reject calls for the government to mastermind a devaluation of sterling to aid Britain's battered manufacturing sector. An artificial depreciation of the currency will cause economic instability and cost jobs, he will insist.

"We are not going to take any risks with stability," the prime minister will tell industrialists gathered for the Confederation of British Industry's annual dinner.

The Bank of England yesterday signalled support for the the tough Downing Street line when a senior official admitted the weak euro was one of the "winds that blow us off course".

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, admitted last week that the sterling-euro rate, which saw the pound rise to 3.28 marks after briefly dipping to 3.22, does not reflect the fundamental economic realities. But he and Mr Blair are determined not to concede any "quick fixes".

In the wake of Ford's decision to end 70 years of car production at Dagenham, and the protracted crisis at Rover, the prime minister intends to face down growing criticism of Labour's hardline economic strategy in front of the CBI.

Mr Blair will argue that an artificially induced devaluation, being promoted as exports to the eurozone are squeezed by the high pound, will amount to a reversion to the short-termism which has dogged industry for much of the post-war era and would jeopardise hard-won stability for the long term.

Unions, exporters and increasing numbers of MPs in manufacturing or marginal seats are increasingly worried about the strong pound - which ministers prefer to see as the consequence of a weak euro, beyond their direct influence. As the election looms such pressure will grow, MPs predicted yesterday.

John Monks, the usually diplomatic general secretary of the TUC, will go public about such disquiet today in a carefully coded speech in Belfast, where the Harland and Wolff yard was recently saved from closure.

While acknowledging the achievements of Labour since 1997, he will argue that Britain's "once in a lifetime" opportunity to rebuild the manufacturing base will be squandered unless the government takes action to bring down the level of sterling.

"Many industries have modernised and their workforces have delivered higher productivity, but they can't live with a currency that is over-valued by 30% against the euro," Mr Monks will say. He will urge short-term intervention in the currency markets and a commitment to join the single currency.

Some analysts have suggested diverting the whole £20bn expected from the sale of mobile phone wavelengths to buying euros.

That would help lower the pound if it was coupled with a declaration of intent to join - or hold the promised referendum - soon after the coming election, senior Labour MPs such as Giles Radice and Martin O'Neill are publicly saying.

Mr Blair and Mr Brown remain adamantly opposed to any action that would undermine the government's commitment to long-term stability. They argue that any steps to bring down the pound would lead either to higher interest rates or higher inflation, and perhaps both.

The deputy governor of the Bank of England, Mervyn King, backed the government yesterday, saying ministers would be wrong to ditch long-term stability in favour of a lower exchange rate.

"We have a tiller, but there are winds that blow us off course from time to time and there is no doubt that the weak euro leading to a strong pound has made life very difficult for part of the economy."

While conceding that the strong pound is hurting exporters, Mr King stressed that all businesses would suffer if the government abandoned its commitment to low inflation. "Stability must be the watchword of policy and that's how we are going to set monetary policy," Mr King said on GMTV.

Faced with regular charges that the membership of the bank's monetary policy committee is too heavily weighted against manufacturing experience, he said the committee considers the exchange rate when setting interest rates.

He specifically rejected demands to expand the committee's membership to include representatives of manufacturing "because it would then become a fight between different sectors of the economy".

webTitle: Foreign control of air traffic services now on the cards

fields.headline: Foreign control of air traffic services now on the cards
fields.trailText: The French and Germans could assume control of Britain's national air traffic service (Nats) in plans to be announced by the government this week.
fields.body:
The French and Germans could assume control of Britain's national air traffic service (Nats) in plans to be announced by the government this week.

The Department of the Environment confirmed yesterday that under European legislation it was open for a foreign company to bid for Nats, which will be partially privatised if the government's transport bill is approved by the House of Lords later this summer.

This means a key European supplier such as Thompson CSF, the French-run avionics company, or DFS, the German-owned state company, could bid for the £500m business and take a majority interest. The move amounts to a reversal of attitude away from the position adopted earlier this year by Nats and by ministers. Then it was made clear that the organisation was likely to end up in the hands of consortia, but that if there was a foreign element, it would only have a minority interest.

There have been second thoughts because European legislation does not allow for national governments to impose such restraints. Nats' original position was that a foreign company would only be allowed up to a 30% share.

Under the government's plans 51% of the business will be sold off, with the government maintaining a 46% share and staff 5%. The legislation, however, will allow for the government to reduce its share eventually to as little as 25%.

Following approval of the legislation by the Commons last week, after one of the biggest backbench rebellions of this parliament, the government is setting out detailed plans this week to complete the transfer of the business.

Ministers are confident that they can complete the legislative process in spite of probable opposition by the House of Lords. It was pointed out in Whitehall yesterday that the government would be able to veto any breaches of security or matters of national interest, which could arise if Nats was controlled by a foreign interest.

The government's method of protecting the national interest will be by means of the "golden share" principle.

This will be activated if it is believed that there has been a national security breach. But one senior air traffic controller yesterday said it could only do this after an offence had been committed. "This will be about as effective as shutting the front door behind a gang of robbers after they have ransacked your house. It is no protection at all, and the government knows it."

This has been one of the hardest battles the government has fought with MPs, some of whom are still concerned about the implications for national security thrown up by transfer of the business abroad.

Bernard Jenkin, shadow transport minister, said last night: "This ridiculous private-public partnership will not create a British company, but a foreign-owned subsidiary and that will not be in the national interest. Nats could finish up tied to a less satisfactory supplier, and there is also the risk of transferring control to a state-owned entity in another country."

The leadership of the air controllers' union, IPMS, is discussing the crisis at its annual conference in Torquay this week.

A spokesman said: "We will continue the fight to the House of Lords. Huge national security and safety implications are involved in this irrelevant and dangerous move, and we feel their lordships will look sympathetically on our opposition."

Because of pressure of parliamentary business, the transport bill may not get final approval until the autumn, although ministers are understood to want to press for the Lords to take a decision as soon as possible.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Telegraph
fields.body:
Sunday Telegraph

Boo.com is threatened with collapse after a last minute hitch in its $30m fund raising, the newspaper reported. One of Boo's two main investors - who was expected to inject funds last week - is said to have stalled, while the other, thought to be Frenchman Bernard Arnault, is only prepared to put up more cash if others match him.

AB Ports, which rejected a bid approach earlier this month from Nomura, is planning a series of property disposals worth up to £650m as part of its reorganisation. The sell-off should help the group underpin its share price and fend off bidders.

BAA is poised to win a key contract to run the services of Logan Airport in Boston, Massachusetts, as the latest success in its drive to become the leading airport operator in the US.

Sunday Business

Under a proposal that will see its valuation cut by up to 25% to £460m Yes Television, the video-on-demand broadcaster, is pressing ahead with its plan to float on the London stock exchange after it was forced to abandon its original intention to list last month.

The Doughty Hanson private equity group is the new front-runner to buy Rank Hovis McDougall from Tomkins for around £1.2bn.

Sunday Times

British Airways executives have told Barbara Cassani, chief executive of BA's low-cost offshoot Go, to temper her enthusiasm for a demerger or partial sale.

The Phoenix consortium, which last week bought Rover from BMW, is offering to sell up to 49% of the group to Japanese car maker Honda within three years. Nick Stephenson, Rover's engineering director, is understood to have held talks with Honda last week.

Tesco has suffered its first year-on-year fall in market share for three years, the newspaper said, citing a report by market research company Taylor Nelson Sofres. For the four weeks ending on April 30, TNS said Tesco had a 21.7% market share, a decline of 1.3% on the same period in 1999.

J Sainsbury slipped further with a market share of 17.1%, down almost 6%, and Asda, Morrisons and Safeway all increased market share.

Observer

Motor group Nissan is threatening to switch car production from Britain because of the strength of the pound. Nissan's Sunderland plant is the most efficient in Europe, but the company says without drastic cost cuts the next Micra will be built in France or Spain.

The Premier League may mimic the government's £22bn mobile telephone auction to maximise revenue for its television football rights. The 20 chairmen of the Premier League clubs would have to approve the idea, which could see broadcasters involved in competitive bidding.

Mail on Sunday

British Airways is in talks with KLM aimed at securing BA a stake in the Dutch flag carrier. The discussions centred initially on joint ticketing but are thought to have expanded to include BA as a strategic partner.

BT is planning to shed another 50,000 jobs in a large-scale reorganisation to be launched next month. The cuts will take the global workforce from 137,000 to about 90,000. Some cuts will be felt in Britain, but a proportion of the "lost" jobs will merely be moved outside BT.

The government may introduce laws to make it tougher for employers to close factories in the wake of Ford's decision to end car assembly at Dagenham. Trade secretary Stephen Byers is thought to be planning to force companies to consult seriously with workers when planning investment or closure.
