webTitle: New BBC political editor passes first hurdle as parties agree he is unbiased

fields.headline: New BBC political editor passes first hurdle as parties agree he is unbiased
fields.trailText: The man appointed to one of the hottest seats in British journalism last night surmounted his first important hurdle when the main political parties agreed that Andrew Marr is "straight" enough to become the BBC's new political editor.
fields.body:
The man appointed to one of the hottest seats in British journalism last night surmounted his first important hurdle when the main political parties agreed that Andrew Marr is "straight" enough to become the BBC's new political editor.

The columnist for the Observer and the Daily Express is a former writer and, briefly, editor of the Independent.

But, despite its recent skirmishes with the BBC, the Conservative leadership called the dogs off, at least for now. "We know Andrew. He is a distinguished journalist and we have no doubt he will continue the BBC tradition of unbiased reporting," said a party spokesman.

News that Robin Oakley, the BBC's political editor since 1992, is to step down a year earlier than expected, caught TV insiders by surprise. It is a sign that Greg Dyke's new regime is gearing up to fight for viewers during the coming general election - which Mr Oakley had intended to cover before his retirement at 60 - rather than a political signal.

It will leave a number of potential contenders feeling sore. John Sergeant, 55, Mr Oakley's deputy whom he beat for the top job, recently took over as political editor of ITN, though the BBC was in negotiation with Mr Marr before he left.

Well-regarded younger BBC political reporters like Mark Mardell, Nick Robinson and Huw Edwards - who reads the Six O'Clock News - will also have to wait longer for their chance at what is one of the most visible and relentless jobs in journalism which has again gone to a recruit from the national press.

Mr Oakley, who writes a racing column for the Spectator, also came from print journalism, as political editor of both the Daily Mail and the Times.

As Labour and the Liberal Democrats signalled their approval of Mr Marr, a Cambridge-educated wunderkind who has also worked for the Scotsman and the Economist - he is still only 40 - another Tory called him "very straight".

That epithet was applied during the long tenure in the post of John Cole, another man of the left who came to the BBC from the Observer and proved both popular with viewers and respected by politicians.

Mr Marr bracketed him and Mr Oakley together as reporters who could provide the independence of mind required by the BBC's charter obligations. "In each case they demonstrated that they were straight and impartial and they were trusted quickly. If I can do as well as them, I will be delighted, " he said on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost.

He also dismissed talk of "supposed New Labour sympathies", having voted for most parties, including the SNP and the Tories at various stages of his civic development.

It did not stop the former Tory chairman, Lord Tebbit, making a predictable attack. "The BBC is run by the Labour party and takes its orders from it, so this will make no difference," he said.

Some new BBC colleagues posed a different question: why would the cerebral Mr Marr, who has turned down a lucrative opening in internet journalism, want such a treadmill job when both devolution and closer European integration (both causes which the pre-BBC Marr backed) have undermined Westminster's place at the centre of events?

"Marr tries to bring a bit of hinterland to his writing - literature, the arts and a few jokes. He won't be able to do that so easily in a job where, fundamentally, what you do is read short and often rather dull pieces to camera," predicted one.

webTitle: It's the deal of Mackay's career

fields.headline: It's the deal of Mackay's career
fields.trailText: Less than a year after relinquishing the chief executive's position to become executive chairman, Francis Mackay appears to have pulled off the deal of his career.
fields.body:
Less than a year after relinquishing the chief executive's position to become executive chairman, Francis Mackay appears to have pulled off the deal of his career.

During his eight years as chief executive, he built Compass into a major FTSE 100 company through a series of big acquisitions which at one point caused anxiety among investors over the speed of growth.

The jitters about over-expansion seem to be firmly behind the Chertsey-based company, and its shares have enjoyed a meteoric rise, particularly in the last two months when they have gained more than £2.

Mr Mackay, 55, earned £4.5m last year through a combination of salary, bonuses and options - and he has Compass shares worth nearly £12m.

He has spent most of his life in the catering industry - his first senior position was as finance director of Global Group, the food manufacturer. He joined Compass in 1986 and led a management buyout with none other than Gerry Robinson - a partnership which now looks likely to be revived.

As well as being a keen golfer, with a handicap of nine, Mr Mackay lists his hobbies as opera and flying.

fields.headline: Granada faces new battle
fields.standfirst: Catering merger with Compass risks second monopoly inquiry
fields.trailText: The Granada conglomerate faces battles with competition regulators on two fronts if it pursues plans revealed today by the Guardian to merge its hospitality businesses with Compass, the catering group.
fields.body:
The Granada conglomerate faces battles with competition regulators on two fronts if it pursues plans revealed today by the Guardian to merge its hospitality businesses with Compass, the catering group.

The group's television arm is already embroiled in a inquiry by the competition commission into the ownership of the independent television network following its indication that it would bid for United News & Media and Carlton, two rivals in the throes of merging their businesses.

A move to spin off its hospitality arm - which ranges from Little Chef and Travelodge to the 400 hotels once owned by Forte - into Compass would run the risk of fresh conflict with the competition commission over the market power of the combined business in the UK.

However, the two companies - which on the food side would unite the world's largest supplier of vending machines with Britain's leading operator of roadside restaurants - are expected to argue that Compass, even though it may claim to be the world's largest contract caterer, still has only a 2.5% share of the £200bn international food market.

They are likely to point out that only a quarter of catering in Europe and the US has so far been contracted out to independent operators - the rest is done in-house - so although they are among the world's largest contractors, they say their share of the potential market is actually relatively small.

The companies - which have refused to comment on speculation about the deal - are expected to be forced to make announcements to the stock market this morning to confirm that their advisers, Schroders Salomon Smith Barney for Compass and Lazards for Granada, are working on the merger.

The bankers are thought to be two weeks away from thrashing out the final terms of the complicated deal - codenamed Grasshopper.

According to reports carried last night on the internet- based financial news service, TheStreet.co.uk, Gerry Robinson, the chairman of the Granada group, has been looking for a way out of the hotels and catering business for many months.

Mr Robinson was instrumental in creating Compass when in 1987 he led the management buy-out from its previous owner, the Grand Metropolitan group.

Crucial to the deal's success will be the attitude of French hotels group, Accor - which, at 4.5%, is Compass's largest shareholder. The structure of senior management of the combined catering organisation still has to be decided.

Michael Bailey, 46, who became chief executive of Compass a year ago, is likely to want a central role. Mr Robinson, 51, has indicated that he will be ready to retire within a year or two, but the position of Compass's executive chairman, Francis Mackay, is less clear. The deal is likely to include incentives for Compass executives to stay on.

Mr Mackay has been the driving force behind Compass's expansion - he presided over its withdrawal from health care in 1995 in order to focus solely on food and drinks.

If successful the transaction may involve the use of Compass's operations to supply Granada's hotels. Rival groups will be keeping close watch on the venture's progress.

fields.headline: Robinson spots tasty earner
fields.trailText: The days of the traditional staff canteen look to be numbered. Workers increasingly have a choice of in-house coffee bars, light meal counters or restaurants, offering a variety of branded foods and drinks.
fields.body:
The days of the traditional staff canteen look to be numbered. Workers increasingly have a choice of in-house coffee bars, light meal counters or restaurants, offering a variety of branded foods and drinks.

The reason, as with so many changes, is globalisation. As businesses develop internationally, they can cut costs and streamline operations by appointing a single catering contractor for all their sites.

Meanwhile, employees' expectations have risen. When they can buy a fast food meal in the high street for a couple of pounds, they are not likely to be impressed by stodgy canteen fare.

Compass has been taking advantage of this trend, building its turnover from £277m in 1988 to £4.8bn last year. Size matters: the bigger Compass gets, the better terms it can negotiate with its suppliers. This means it can tender for contracts at an increasingly competitive rate.

Contract catering is a sophisticated business, in which marketing is just as crucial as cooking.

Both Compass and Granada's catering business, Sutcliffe, use a range of techniques to improve their margins - for example persuading customers to pay more for premium and branded products such as espresso and caffè latte rather than a cup from an undistinguished urn.

Granada chairman, Gerry Robinson, reckons hotels could be fertile ground for similar arrangements. He has been experimenting with using Sutcliffe in the group's hotel chains - Posthouse, Le Meridien and Travelodge.

So far, the project has been confined to banqueting and conferences but it could well be extended to restaurant and bar meals.

In another attempt to make hotel restaurants more efficient, Granada recently invested £3m in a cook-chill operation, Circadia. This prepares meals which simply need reheating on demand.

By combining Granada's hotels, roadside and catering businesses with Compass, Mr Robinson can improve efficiency and profits.

At the same time, he leaves the rump of Granada focused on fast growing media activities which include a share in ONdigital and four ITV licences. The two sides of the group have little in common, and both should flourish independently.

The new hospitality group to be created by the deal will have a market capitalisation of more than £12bn. The hitch is that there are likely to be competition concerns - between them Granada, Compass and the French group Sodexho (which formerly traded in the UK as Gardner Merchant) control more than 70% of the UK catering industry.

A solution may involve a sell-off of part or all of Sutcliffe. Even so, there is a huge international opportunity.

Compass has just 2.5% of the world contract catering market, and wants to double this share. And if Granada can prove that contracting out hotel catering can work, others are sure to follow.

fields.headline: Non-science plus non-thinkers equals nonsense
fields.standfirst:
Peter Preston wonders why we have fallen prey to mobile phone fears

Mobile phone fears: special report
fields.trailText: It was a half-heard fragment from an American radio news show. "And then," said a man who turned out to be speaking for the US Department of Health, "there's the non- scientific European situation to bear in mind." Turn up the volume. They were talking genetically modified foods. They were talking Food and Drug Administration clearances. So they were talking, along the way, about quivering panic across the pond: non-thinkers consumed by non-science.
fields.body:
It was a half-heard fragment from an American radio news show. "And then," said a man who turned out to be speaking for the US Department of Health, "there's the non- scientific European situation to bear in mind." Turn up the volume. They were talking genetically modified foods. They were talking Food and Drug Administration clearances. So they were talking, along the way, about quivering panic across the pond: non-thinkers consumed by non-science.

There is no seething debate about GM foods in the land of Erin Brockovich. What the FDA certifies, the nation grows and eats. You can't smoke in the restaurants where they serve genetically modified dishes of the day. You can't, in one Californian county, wear perfume or cologne. But otherwise the perceived appliance of science rules. Which brings us, inescapably, to Sir William Stewart and mobile phones.

The British government's former chief medical officer (with high-level colleagues) has spent many months investigating the threat of the mobiles - everything from tumours to diarrhoea. But, try as he may, he can't find one. The "balance of evidence" shows "no adverse health effects" from the phones or their transmitter stations. No brain frying, no premature Alzheimer's: nothing. A scientific verdict which chimes precisely with World Health Organisation wisdom.

End of argument? We should be so lucky. Learned committees are supposed to advocate learned measures and Sir William's does its duty, rolling out exclusion zones, national databases and - of course - more research programmes in the accustomed fashion. Whitehall, flourishing action plans, duly performs its ritual dance. The response to an inquiry finding no present danger is almost exactly what you would have expected if the verdict had been greatly more menacing.

Even that draws no line under the affair. Stewart (a gravelled-voiced Scot with a touch of the Dr Finlays about him) says that if the threat he hasn't found does indeed exist then it might be worse for children - and therefore the widespread use of mobiles by kids should be discouraged by parents "making an informed choice". Would he buy a phone for his own grandchildren, aged two and four? No, he would not. Confusion reigns.

The trouble, of course, comes where the worlds of science and non-science meet. There are plenty of reasons why parents should worry about the 4m or more mobiles in the hands of under-18s. Reasons like paying the bill - or social stunting. (I was sitting in a cafe the other day watching, with fascination, four boys and four girls round a table: the boys were talking football, the girls - sitting back - were sending text messages to each other on their mobiles). There is obvious danger when you drive with one hand and answer a phone with the other. Transmission masts can mean aesthetic blight. But you don't need science to tell you that. Commonsense will do.

Here's another example of mission creep. We're alarmed about mobiles and health. We ask a team of eminent scientists to examine our fears. It finds them (insofar as science ever makes possible) to be groundless. Yet the process, both human and political, doesn't stop there. We can't take "no evident risk" for an answer. We always want more; and thus science itself turns into non-science, and there is no rational reassurance.

That is a very unsteady state to find yourself in. A land of mad cows and Frankenstein foods where hysteria rules and paranoia always lurks in the undergrowth: a land where nothing and nobody, no matter how expert, can be trusted. Thus is the shambles of BSE visited on genetic modification in terms of national angst, sealed in futility behind porous borders.

Pseudo-science, moreover, has a nasty habit of reaching into every walk of life and infecting every debate. Take (from the adjacent moral, rather than physical, pot of the moment) televised sex. There is a lot of it about. Even souls as hardy as Jonathan Freedland are alarmed. It won't be long, I guess, before Chris Smith turns his attention from News at Ten to Soft-Porn at Eleven and television's watchdogs chunter into action. More national rot.

Yet any suitably clinical look will reveal a rather different story. A fondness for eroticism - carved on the walls of Ancient Greece - is an enduring part of the human psyche. A market for it exists, and has always existed, everywhere in the world. In America, that market currently accounts for around $4bn a year. On television, some countries where cable is ubiquitous limit it to defined, easily accessible channels. Others - like France - let national channels carry prescribed doses of the hard stuff.

Britain's main regular outlet - Mr Kelvin Mackenzie's L!ve TV - went belly-up months ago. Not enough viewers or cash. But that left a footloose audience roaming the airwaves. Channel 5 has picked up a bit of it. Channel 4 has followed suit. What was spread thick in one area a couple of years ago is now spread more thinly across several. It will continue to be so until (a) a new or existing channel corners the porn market more determinedly or (b) until the market for tired documentaries about tired strippers wanes.

Put a team of media analysts and social scientists together and they would soon calm your fears. They would create a cool climate of contextualisation. But we seem to have lost the ability to summon such coolness or such trust. Tony Blair may have brought back royal commissions after a long absence; he hasn't managed to recreate an audience of a mind to listen to them.

Back to the mobile arena, where facts go even further. Do mobiles heat the brain? Yes, by one tenth as much as a spell of sunbathing. Drinking a cup of coffee or walking the dog would be just as perilous. You can compute the danger of dying in a road accident over a period of 70 years at far less than one in a hundred, but the risks here are too infinitesimal to be worth computing. There are risks; there are always risks. Living is a risky business which ends in death. Mankind is prey to sudden awful viruses, and vigilance is always necessary. Smoking does damage your health. Pesticides can poison the water.

But living is also a matter for reasonable inquiry, reasonable doubt and reasonable conclusions. When we call in the experts, we should expect no more than the best tools for risk assessment. Sir William Stewart gives us those tools. It would have been better if he'd stopped there, in brevity and prudent clarity. There's never (as the lofty guy from the US Health Department might say) been a better moment to start redrawing the lines between what science can do for us and what it can't. When there is nothing sensible to be done, it's best not to do it.

fields.headline: Royal confidant's indiscreet asides
fields.trailText: He appeared the very soul of discretion. But to his friends, the late Lord Goodman, royal confidant and fixer, could be gloriously indiscreet, casting withering asides on members of The Firm over bran and prunes at his apartments in Portland Place, London.
fields.body:
He appeared the very soul of discretion. But to his friends, the late Lord Goodman, royal confidant and fixer, could be gloriously indiscreet, casting withering asides on members of The Firm over bran and prunes at his apartments in Portland Place, London.

The Duchess of York, he reportedly said, "sleeps around" and once led dinner guests on an impromptu tour of the Queen's bedchamber in Buckingham Palace.

Prince Charles, he is said to have commented, "may not be the most appealing of individuals" and "doesn't appear to want to be king". Diana, Princess of Wales he found "scheming" and "quite wicked".

The reminiscences, recorded in a diary by a friend of Lord Goodman, the writer David Selbourne, were published yesterday in the Sunday Times. Buckingham Palace has declined to comment on them.

Goodman died in 1995 aged 81. Initially delighted with his role in royal circles, he is said to have become increasingly frustrated with the emotional turbulence in the House of Windsor.

He stopped dispensing legal advice to the Duchess of York, he told Selbourne, because he found her a "very foolish woman".

Once, while the monarch was away, he was among dinner guests at the palace. "When the meal was over and the guests were still at the table, [the duchess] asked us whether we should like to see the Queen's private apartments," he is reported to have said.

"I felt considerable unease at the proposal, thinking it was an improper suggestion to make in the Queen's absence, and upon a matter to which she would have been unlikely to have given her assent.

"Nevertheless, we appear to have set aside our anxieties on this score and accompanied her as she led the way to the Queen's private sanctum."

Goodman held an almost unrivalled place in the British establishment for many years. A distinguished lawyer, he rose to prominence under Harold Wilson but reportedly found him "chronically suspicious of plots and disloyalty" and to have an obsession about Roy Jenkins.

He described John Major, as "characterless" but saw promise in Michael Heseltine.

It was the breakdown of the marriage of the Prince and Princess of Wales, however, that tested his famed good nature. In July 1992 he told Selbourne he had been retained by Prince Charles after Andrew Morton's book on Diana was published. In the months that followed he tired of the trauma, commenting: "She hates him and he hates her."

Of the monarchy's survivial he reportedly said: "It will not survive long into the next century."

webTitle: West's pollution blamed for world disasters

fields.headline: West's pollution blamed for world disasters
fields.standfirst: Christian Aid says the growing number of climate-related calamities in poor countries are not 'natural' but the direct fault of rich nations
fields.trailText: Climate-related disasters, which kill thousands of people and cost millions in terms of providing aid to striken populations, are manmade and should no longer be termed natural disasters, according to a leading charity.
fields.body:
Climate-related disasters, which kill thousands of people and cost millions in terms of providing aid to striken populations, are manmade and should no longer be termed natural disasters, according to a leading charity.

In a report published today and entitled Unnatural Disasters, Christian Aid attacks rich nations such as Britain for condemning poor countries to an "ever increasing number of overwhelming humanitarian catastrophes".

Malcolm Rodgers, Christian's Aid's head of policy, said: "Nine of the past 11 disasters to which we have responded have been caused by extreme weather conditions. Country after country is being decimated by these so-called natural disasters.

"Christian Aid and other development agencies are caught in the middle, delivering relief aid. The terrible irony is that the poorest countries are suffering, and we believe this is because of pollution by the wealthiest."

The charity believes the problem is escalating and that by 2020 three-quarters of the world's population, mostly in poor countries, could be at risk from drought and flood. In those 20 years there could be as many as 245 climate-related catastrophes.

Droughts such as those in India and the Horn of Africa were caused by the creeping menace of global warming due to the continuing burning of fossil fuels, the report said.

In 1998 alone, environmental catastrophes created 25m refugees, more than the number affected by war; 300m people were affected by storm surges, torrential rain, landslips, mudslides and tidal waves; and 45 countries were striken with drought.

The warming helped mosquitoes to thrive in new areas, and malaria cases could rise by 50m to 80m a year. Lack of water would increasingly afflict 3bn people in India, Africa and the Middle East - nearly half the world's population. Sea level rises and increased storminess were putting 94m people at risk of flooding every year along the coastlines of India and south-east Asia.

The problems would cause mass migrations to cities, where the poor would live in ever larger shanty towns, vulnerable to disease, crime and prostitution.

Christian Aid believes that wealthy governments need to help developing countries to prepare for disasters, using funds for overseas development. These governments, including Britain, should think strategically about the way they spend aid money.

The report quoted Julian Salt, of the Loss Prevention Council, which advises the UK insurance industry: "If the world does not wake up to climate change and deal with its causes, then disasters will reach a point in the middle of the century when they are unmanageable. Prevention is cheaper than the cost of natural disasters." It urged richer countries to cut carbon dioxide emissions, which were the prime cause of the problem. Britain emitted 9.5 tonnes per person, compared with 0.7 tonnes in Honduras.

Munich Reinsurance, one of the world's largest insurance companies, said that the cost of climate-related disasters doubled every decade from $50bn (£30bn) in the 1960s, when there were 16 disasters, to nearly $400bn (£270bn) in the past 10 years, when there were 70.

Years of devastation

1998

Hurricane Mitch left 10,000 dead and more than 2m homeless in Nicaragua, Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador, with a bill of £3.1bn for the damage

Floods in Bangladesh affected 30m

Drought in Sudan affected 2.5m

1999

10,000 were killed or miss ing as a result of the cyclone in Orissa, eastern India. The cost of devastation was put at £745m

Giant mudslides in Venezuela left up to 20,000 dead

2000

Floods in Mozambique left 700 dead and 300,000 forced to flee from their homes. The disaster's cost was believed to be £625m

16m in the Horn of Africa, including those in Ethiopia and Sudan, face starvation after the failure of rains for the third year running

fields.headline: View from here
fields.trailText: Most newspapers have comics pages for good reason: they're popular - they are the first pages many readers turn to.
fields.body:
Most newspapers have comics pages for good reason: they're popular - they are the first pages many readers turn to.

Internet publications and websites often embrace comic strips as well, and the online world presents a promising marketplace. But most of tomorrow's internet comic strips won't look like those in newspapers. Instead of static images in black and white, comic strips online will be animated, interactive and colourful.

If you look around the web, you'll see the signs of what is to come. Trevor (www.comics.com/ comics/trevor/ab.html), an online-only strip by Australians Gerard Piper and John Lee, takes the size format of a typical newspaper strip. But its three panels are actually six. When viewing a Trevor strip with a web browser, put your mouse over a panel and it reveals a hidden panel.

Trevor is the only animated strip to have been picked up by United Media, the US syndicate that carries such comic heavyweights as Peanuts and Dilbert. The general manager of United Media's web group, Toby Sanders, sees Trevor as the tip of the iceberg. Her group's agenda for the coming year includes the cultivation of cartoonists who are producing interactive strips that could sell in the web publishing marketplace.

Sanders expects to see more animated strips using technology such as Flash, a content authoring program that artists use to build animations and interactive games; more cartoons where the user interacts; and cartoons that break out of the newspaper comic strip-size format.

One of the best things about cartooning on the web is the capacity for artists to get large. Captain Ribman (www.supercomics.com), which is syndicated for online and print use by Tribune Media Services, is in colour and takes up more than a full computer screen.

Captain Ribman, about a slothful superhero who interacts with celebrity "guest stars", is created by John Sprengelmeyer and Rich Davis. The duo is experimenting with Flash to create interactive and animated versions. Tribune Media Services creative director Fred Schecker says content buyers in the dot.com world are looking for interactivity to enliven their websites.

Web syndicator iSyndicate (www.isyndicate.com) sells the work of dozens of cartoonists to online publishers, but only a few have broken out of print format.

Jim Toomey, a cartoonist himself and a member of iSyndicate's international business development team, says that while dot.com companies do like interactive cartoons, what they want even more is relevance. He sees opportunity for cartoonists who have strips that appeal to a thin target audience. Whereas newspapers want strips that appeal to a broad audience and would spurn a comic about, say, life in a doctor's office, such a strip could be picked up by the many health sites on the web. "Niche cartoonists" probably won't become millionaires, but Toomey thinks many can make a living by selling to the web.

Toomey draws the comic strip Sherman's Lagoon, which is syndicated by King Features. It's a conventional strip that runs mostly in daily newspapers. Despite his second job as a web syndication expert, he's yet to take Sherman's Lagoon interactive. That's because of lack of time rather than interest, and Toomey says he does plan to add web elements to the strip. He also has a popular website for Sherman's Lagoon, which he plans to leverage.

One reason many cartoonists continue to draw static strips is that adding a layer of technology is a lot of work. Drawing a daily ink-on-paper comic is difficult enough; trying to do an animated comic on a daily basis would be impossible for a lone cartoonist. Humour illustrator Bob Staake says money is the big issue. Interactive comics take so much time to produce - and sometimes require the assistance of technology partners - that there may not be enough of a financial payoff to make them worth doing.

Nevertheless, digital cartooning creativity will come to market. Robert Duffy, of Universal New Media, says his syndicate is close to launching its first interactive cartoon, featuring short animations with sound. He sees a lot of incredibly creative digital work from cartoonists coming to Universal seeking syndication deals. While the most bleeding-edge digital comics have not yet made it to syndication, there are hundreds of independents combining creativity and technology to reshape the art of comics. "It's an incredibly exciting time to be a cartoonist," Duffy says.

Steve Outing is a Colorado-based columnist and analyst who also covers internet media trends for Editor & Publisher and Writer's Digest. He is also CEO and founder of Content Exchange (www.content-exchange.com). Email: steve@content-exchange.com

fields.headline: Let down by lawyers
fields.standfirst:
Corporate manslaughter prosecutions are deemed too difficult. Where's the justice for Paddington's victims?

Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: One of my most severely injured clients from the Paddington train crash is a US citizen. Still in hospital, he is fighting paralysis of the arms and legs caused by multiple trauma and burns. His wife rang me on the evening of last week's decision by the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, to bring no charges against those involved. She found it incomprehensible, describing it as an insult.
fields.body:
One of my most severely injured clients from the Paddington train crash is a US citizen. Still in hospital, he is fighting paralysis of the arms and legs caused by multiple trauma and burns. His wife rang me on the evening of last week's decision by the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, to bring no charges against those involved. She found it incomprehensible, describing it as an insult.

In America people get sent to prison, companies get put out of business and juries award massive punitive damages. But in the UK the most which usually happens is a fine for breaching safety regulations. In the earlier Southall rail crash, the £1.5m fine imposed on First Great Western was peanuts compared to their profits.

Moreover, not only are punitive damages not normally awarded, but where the person who dies is young and single, as were so many of those at Paddington, their damages claim may turn out to be worth next to nothing.

The directors of Go Ahead, which owns Thames Trains, were so unworried by the financial implications of the Paddington crash, that they have since paid £500,000 in dividends to two of their number. Railtrack announced record profits the month afterwards.

Paddington happened less than a month after the public inquiry into Southall started. As the Paddington hearings in turn now reveal, the general background of profit before safety is the same.

Thames Trains failed to install ATP, the best protection system, or to train drivers properly: Railtrack did nothing much about a signal passed at danger eight times and a track layout they knew was dangerous. Would there have been a spur to clean up their act had a previous Southall prosecution jailed a railway director?

Mr Calvert-Smith says corporate manslaughter prosecutions are too difficult to bring. But the problem may not be the law so much as the way in which he applies it. A TV documentary about Southall showed the DPP's senior prosecutor sitting round a table with a leading QC and discussing their plan to make cutting edge changes to the law. But lawyers representing the victims were not impressed. For it involved bringing corporate manslaughter charges against Great Western Trains without charging any individual director. We wrote warning that such a prosecution was bound to fail and would only cause meaningless delay. Our fears were justified. An Old Bailey judge threw out the charge and reaffirmed that a firm can only be found guilty of corporate manslaughter based on the guilt of at least one human manager.

The government became involved. The attorney general invoked a procedure to obtain a purely academic appeal court ruling, still seeking to enable a company to be prosecuted for manslaughter without the "difficulty" of prosecuting a senior manager or director. This also fell flat. The appeal court simply reiterated that the law remained the same.

Yet the "difficulty" may be spurious: on March 23 the high court ruled on another case - of 24-year-old Simon Jones, who died at Shoreham docks on his first day at work.

There Mr Calvert-Smith, advised by the same QC who advised on Southall, simply decided not to prosecute at all because, he said, there was no case against the manager identified as responsible for the safety system which led to Simon's death.

The court trenchantly said that completely the wrong legal test had been applied. The prosecutor should not be looking at the manager's state of mind or what he knew of events on the particular day or whether he was present when the death happened; it was necessary only to show that he was in charge of an unsafe system. Lord Justice Buxton said the DPP made a wholly wrong assumption that "the only test was the subjective culpability of (the individual manager) rather than objective liability for the dangerous system".

The DPP is now considering what to do (advised by a different QC). But bereaved Southall relatives were told it was impossible to prosecute a director of Great Western Trains responsible for safety because he personally had not authorised that particular train setting off with a safety system not working. If the correct test had been applied, he would undoubtedly have been prosecuted.

Mr Calvert-Smith now says he wants to see a new offence of "corporate killing" in which the company can be prosecuted regardless of the liability of any director.

This would mean legislation for what he tried to achieve over Southall; to all intents it may simply rename the current health and safety prosecutions to make them sound more severe, with the end result pretty much the same.

Clearly this whole area is seen as highly politically sensitive. The real decisions are being made by Gerry Norris, a policy unit special adviser to the prime minister. But however politically inconvenient it may be, those whose lives have been shattered on the altar of human greed would like a clear message sent to railway company directors: invest those profits in safety or prepare to sacrifice your liberty.

The author is a solicitor

webTitle: Now, if you've just joined us...

fields.headline: Now, if you've just joined us...
fields.standfirst: Radio bosses have finally realised the internet can help them too.  Maggie Brown  reveals how
fields.trailText: Radio bosses have finally realised the internet can help them too. Maggie Brown reveals how
fields.body:
In the past few months, the BBC's national radio networks have each appointed web managers for the first time, aware they've got some catching up to do. Radios 2, 3, 4 and 5 Live are preparing improved and better resourced sites and even Radio 4 will get its chance to relaunch with conviction in October.

With a beefed-up Radio 1 service scoring a six-fold increase in hits, the controllers of two other networks, James Moir at Radio 2 and Helen Boaden at Radio 4, have recognised that their online efforts have missed a trick. Producers are champing at the bit to match commercial radio's offerings, says online head Simon Nelson.

While you can chat online with the stars on Radio 1 or win a car or £20,000 online with Virgin Radio, an invitation to "email us with your questions and comments" is about as far as some speech programmes have tended to go. But the shift into directing Radio 4 listeners to websites is under way.

The move comes as the radio industry cheerily savours the heady fact that it could be a "net winner": radio may be the medium least likely to be hit by the growth in surfing, because radio listening is a complementary activity. You can listen to music, a phone-in or a play while doing DIY, or composing an email. Even though sound quality has yet to match the best radio reception (this is being worked on), you can access stations pretty simply over the web, too.

Virgin Radio, one of the first to webcast in 1996, now has more than 200,000 listeners accessing its services online. Just as breakfast audiences boomed when car-commuting increased in the 1970s - coinciding with the infancy of commercial radio in the UK - the hope now is that the rise of internet usage will produce a rise in radio listening at other "down" times outside office hours.

Jason Bryant, of talkSport, says this has already happened in the US. "Radio is a natural bedfellow of the dot.com user, and weekends and evenings are times of high usage. Radio allows you to listen and surf at the same time. At 11.30pm last night I was listening to a sports station in LA."

The subject stole the headlines last week when Rajar, the radio audience research company, began publishing regular information on how radio listeners (that's 90% of the population) use the internet, based on its 30,000-strong database.

It found that while one in three adults claimed some use of the web, however infrequent, radio users were slightly more likely to. But the really striking finding is that young men and upmarket households of under-44s are the most "techy". Some 11% of young men aged 15-24 listened to radio via the web, compared to 3.3% of the population overall. A quarter of 15-24 year old males had visited a radio website - Capital, Virgin and Chrysalis are seen as well advanced - compared with 14% of women in same age band and 8% generally.

Another finding was that while people do surf at work, more use it at home, when radio is a natural accompaniment. The figures are: home use 18.9%; work 10.5%; school/college 5.4%; cyber cafe 1%, and elsewhere 3.8%. But there are worrying public policy indications in the research, which Justin Sampson, managing director of the Radio Advertising Bureau, was quick to point out.

First, the stark social divide. Rajar found that 35.5% of well-heeled ABC1s accessed it at least once a week, compared with 13.6% of C2DEs. As Sampson says, this puts a question mark against the prime minister's goal of universal access within five years: "How can Tony Blair's vision of a wired-up society be achieved?"

One answer is that the most obvious entry barrier - the several hundred pounds required to set yourself up - will become less prohibitive as computer prices fall. Another lies in the falling cost of calls. Fear of large phone bills deters poorer households.

This is a factor identified by the radio sector as holding back broadcasting over the web: although some 3,500 radio stations worldwide webcast their services, listeners here are bound to ask why they should stack up call costs for nationally available services when they can get them free over the air. But this is where Nelson scents an opportunity for the public service BBC: he sees the 15m middle-aged listeners to Radio 2 and Radio 4 ("most of this audience are desperate to get involved") as potential "silver surfers".

Nelson says BBC radio staff face the prospect of swift re-training, to get radio producers used to adapting to the web. "I've found every producer seems to be screaming to get into this. We're trying to learn and build for the future, not just catch up." Of course there is an element of hype in all of this. With commercial radio networks achieving sky-high share prices, the dot.com link is a useful bit of extra spice. But the potential is real enough.

A survey by Ocean Consulting of the UK's media agencies published last week by Media Week confirmed their belief that radio had by far the most to gain from the internet, outstripping TV, magazines and newspapers. Radio is already an ally of isolated commuters stuck in jams. It is equally well suited to act as a friendly presence for isolated home workers, chained to a computer. And who knows how the online interactive dimension will start to change the character of the broadcast output?

John Ousby, head of online for Virgin Radio, says: "Radio production values are never going to die. A radio station is more than a collection of songs. But I think online will take the best of television, radio and the internet." Nelson says: "What I'd hate would be if the internet is ever seen as driving the content. But we're not going to turn our back on the ability to find out what the audience wants more of. Let's get it in perspective. The number of people tuning in in this way is still small. However, there are only 365 days in a year. Most broadcasters are trying to cram their output into too short a time. This offers the chance for lots more context and content. A chance to catch up on the Today programme all day."

fields.headline: Abolition of bailiffs 'overdue'
fields.trailText: Bailiffs regularly use threats of violence and prison against debtors, lie and cheat their way into homes, and charge excessive fees, the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux (Nacab) claims today.
fields.body:
Bailiffs regularly use threats of violence and prison against debtors, lie and cheat their way into homes, and charge excessive fees, the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux (Nacab) claims today.

Debtors were being plunged further into poverty by the largely unregulated debt collectors who were "an archaic relic of medieval times overdue for abolition" and "almost a law unto themselves".

There are few controls over what they do and how much they charge, no real protection for their victims, and powers established by laws dating from 1267 leave the system ripe for abuse, Nacab says.

Its report, based on evidence from 300 bureaux in England and Wales, says bailiffs regularly use threats of violence and prison to pressure people into paying lump sums they cannot afford, lie and cheat their way into homes, misrepresent their powers, take away essential goods, and impose fees that can increase the original debt many times over.

Cases highlighted include a man whose £12 parking fine escalated to £400 with costs and charges. The bailiffs removed the Motability scheme car he needed to get to hospital for kidney dialysis three times a week.

A woman was told by bailiffs they had the legal right to smash down her door with a sledgehammer, and a couple were threatened with prison by a bailiff who had "Pay or Die" tattooed on to his arm.

The report, published a month before the government receives a review on the subject, highlights the "wholly inadequate" regulation and archaic and complex legal framework. While bailiffs are supposed to hold certificates for claiming rent, road traffic penalties and council tax, the system is far from rigorous, and no certificates are needed to reclaim magistrates' fines, it says.

"Theoretically, these bailiffs are supposed to be independently monitored and controlled, but this doesn't happen," said Alison Green, its author. "Where no certificates are required, the bailiff is not subject to checks or regulations of any kind."

Statutes dating from 1267 also created a legal minefield and ensured bailiffs had the right to do things such as break into someone's home and assert the right to take goods.

They could effectively charge what they liked. "They are permitted to charge 'reasonable costs' for taking away goods. But there are no rules for what these are, and in practice people do not contest them since this involves going to the county court which costs more money," Ms Green said.

The report, Undue Distress, argues that there are fairer ways of recovering domestic debt, such as direct deductions from benefit. Calling for the system to be scrapped, it says the government's social exclusion unit should examine the issue of debt and debt enforcement.

David Harker, Nacab's chief executive, said: "It is high time we moved away from a system that relies on intimidation and confusion as its main tools to one that is sensitive to the situation of those who struggle on inadequate incomes."

webTitle: Third of sick days not due to ill health

fields.headline: Third of sick days not due to ill health
fields.trailText: More than a third of days taken off work through illness have nothing to do with ill health, a survey published today shows.
fields.body:
More than a third of days taken off work through illness have nothing to do with ill health, a survey published today shows.

The average worker takes three sick days off a year when they are perfectly healthy, at a cost of over £4bn to industry, according to the study by the Institute of Personnel and Development.

It found the most common reasons given for absenteeism through illness were minor complaints such as colds and headaches.

For non-manual workers, the second most cited reason was stress; for manual workers it was back pain.

On average, the annual cost of sick days is almost £500 for each employee, or at least £13bn to the British economy.

The study of almost 1,700 organisations, employing a total of just under 2m staff, said the main reasons given by employers for increases in sickness absence were changes in workforce morale and workload.

The average level of sickness absence was 4.1% of working time - the equivalent of 9.3 lost working days - with the highest levels in larger organisations, including the NHS.

About 90% of employers see sickness absence as "a significant or very significant" cost to their business.

Diane Sinclair, who carried out the survey, said: "Sickness absence costs the UK economy a vast amount each year.

"A conservative estimate is £485.60 for each employee each year. Organisations which have poor management, low morale and increased work pressures will see their employees take increasing amounts of time off as sick leave."

But a third of employers believe that the level of absenteeism in their organisations has decreased over the past two years, compared with a fifth who claim to have seen an increase.

Meanwhile, more than 90% of larger companies with a staff of over 2,000 have a written policy on sick days and 80% of respondents said they liked to interview workers on their return to work.

The priority that is being given to flexible working practices such as job-sharing, flexi-time and self-management was felt by a third of respondents to have been effective in reducing time off through sickness.

Ms Sinclair said: "With around one sick leave day in every three being taken for reasons other than illness, employers clearly need to focus on people management and development strategies in order to tackle absence.

"Direct approaches such as return-to-work interviews and proper record keeping are important.

"And more flexible, family-friendly policies are likely to be key to achieving this goal."

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: * It's official: the internet is a force for global peace and diplomacy. At the Industry Standard's Global Internet Summit on May 22-24 in Barcelona, hotly tipped as the "new media event of the year", the former Israeli PM and Nobel Peace Prize Laureate Shimon Perez will be closing the conference with a special address on "the digital divide - fostering economic growth and peace".
fields.body:
* It's official: the internet is a force for global peace and diplomacy. At the Industry Standard's Global Internet Summit on May 22-24 in Barcelona, hotly tipped as the "new media event of the year", the former Israeli PM and Nobel Peace Prize Laureate Shimon Perez will be closing the conference with a special address on "the digital divide - fostering economic growth and peace".

There will be presentations on global issues affecting the new economy from "visionaries, business executives and political leaders" such as Fabiola Arrendondo, Yahoo's head honcho, Ola Ahlvesson, former world kickboxing champ, and our very own new media babe Martha Lane Fox. Representing "the divide", Yosi Vardi, known as the father of the Islamic internet industry, will be speaking, and with representatives from subversive Chinese websites going head to head with the government-backed chinadotcom on the subject of "Is the Chinese government really censoring the internet and its entrepreneurs?", this could just explode into a cyber Seattle.

*One of the conference debates will be "Is the US really behind in the wireless race?" But the latest gossip from Silicon Alley suggests the yanks are catching up: two senior Microsoft managers, responsible for building MSN's mobile services, have just quit to create a new wireless internet company, VIair, with $8m backing. Oracle, the database giant which recently made its CEO Larry Ellison the richest man in the world, is also launching a corporate Wap service, OracleMobile.com; and AT&T cable co will be launching two Wap-enabled phones in June.

*Barely a week old and Vogue.com is already attracting some intriguing visitors to its forum. In among the blatant PR placements - such as "Yesterday, as I was buying my skincare provisions from Shiseido, I discovered this wonderful new fragrance . . ." and the "former Miss Universe finalist" searching for "stay-fresh" hair tips - is what appears to be a solicitation: "Before some days, I read a last issue in vogue by miranda soier [sawyer] with title 'women games'," writes the frighteningly literate ABC1 Anna. "It was write [written] that many women, espesially models r bisecsual, and i think this is not shame! so if u have an opinion like mine, and like women too, why don't u write me?" Could it be that the cheeky nipple-flashing publicity campaign is working too well? Editor Abigail Chisman confirms that since the campaign launch they have been inundated with requests for nipple posters and visitors to the site have doubled.

*Anyone suffering from New Media overheating should visit www.lostminute.com, a send-up of Martha and Brent's Lastminute.com. If that doesn't do the trick, try www.handanova.com, a hand-puppet virtual newscaster created by a mad American, who could become more popular than its namesake, PA's cyberbabe Ananova.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Commons turns off new voters
fields.body:
Commons turns off new voters

The experience of watching parliament on television has driven away young voters, research for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation shows.

Voters turning 18 this year were children when parliament was first broadcast in 1989 and many saw politics as nothing more than "the yah-boo of party politicking", said Clarissa White, co-author of the report Young People's Politics.

Troubled trust to lose chief

The chief executive of the Portsmouth hospital trust has taken early retirement.

The trust says the departure of Richard Bishop is not connected with controversies after a cancer patient discovered a junior doctor had written a "do not resuscitate" order on her notes and the decision to allow a 12-year-old cerebral palsy sufferer to "die with dignity" following a chest infection.

Call centre staff axed on screen

About 45 Vodafone workers were sacked by computer when a message flashed on screen: "Please log off your computer and clear your desk." On Friday the mobile phone firm announced it was to close five of its 13 call centres.

One former employee at the Aztec West centre, near Bristol, said: "People were looking at their screens when the message appeared. Five minutes later, we were called into a meeting and told that we no longer had jobs."

A spokesman said: "I don't think it was supposed to happen that way."

Radio 2 goes punk

Radio 2 is to broadcast two documentaries looking at the rise of punk music. A spokeswoman pointed out: "People who were at the vanguard of punk are now squarely in our target audience of over 35s."

No winner for £12m lottery

There was no winner of the £12m national lottery jackpot on Saturday. The numbers were 6, 30, 35, 42, 44, 45 and the bonus was 33.

Five people won the £250,000 on the Thunderball with numbers 4, 5, 16, 18 and 25. The Thunderball number was 8.

webTitle: Drama and comedy stars at TV 'Oscars'

fields.headline: Drama and comedy stars at TV 'Oscars'
fields.trailText: The dramatisation of the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence last night won a top award at the TV industry Oscars.
fields.body:
The dramatisation of the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence last night won a top award at the TV industry Oscars.

The Murder of Stephen Lawrence, which was accused by some critics of presenting the crime in a sensational way, won best single drama at the Baftas.

Producer Mark Redhead, with his colleague, Paul Greengrass, collected the award watched by Stephen's father, Neville, who was in the audience.

In other awards Graham Norton beat the Ali G creator, Sacha Baron Cohen, to win the Bafta for best entertainment performance.

Norton, who has just signed a lucrative deal to stay at Channel 4, beat comedians John Bird and John Fortune, and the veteran BBC chat show host Michael Parkinson.

The Royle Family, which missed out on a Golden Rose at the Montreux television festival earlier this week after the BBC entered an ineligible episode of the sitcom, restored the corporation's pride by scooping two awards - one for sitcom, and one for the comedy performance of its star Caroline Aherne. The award for best comedy programme was also won by the BBC for its series The League of Gentlemen.

ITV's A Touch of Frost won the Lew Grade audience award, voted by readers of the Radio Times, listeners to BBC Radio 2's Jonathan Ross show and viewers of GMTV.

Jeremy Paxman beat his Newsnight colleague Kirsty Wark to the Richard Dimbleby award for best presenter (factual, features and news). Thora Hird, 88, won best actress for the second year running for her role in Lost For Words. Best actor went to Michael Gambon for Wives and Daughters.

A special award was presented to the stars of the Avengers: Honor Blackman, Joanna Lumley, Diana Rigg and Linda Thorson, whom the academy believes have changed the perception of women on television.

Winners in full

Best actress Thora Hird, Lost for Words, ITV

Best actor Michael Gambon, Wives and Daughters, BBC1

Best entertainment performance Graham Norton, So Graham Norton, Channel 4

Best comedy performance Caroline Aherne, The Royle Family, BBC1

Single drama The Murder of Stephen Lawrence, Granada, ITV

Richard Dimbleby award for best presenter (factual, features and news) Jeremy Paxman, Newsnight, BBC2

Drama series The Cops, World Productions, BBC2

Drama serial Warriors, BBC Films, BBC1

Soap EastEnders, BBC1

Factual series or strand The Mayfair Set, BBC2

Documentary Divorce Iranian Style, 20th Century Vixen Productions, Channel 4

Features Blood on the Carpet, BBC2

Huw Wheldon award for best art programme or series This is Modern Art, Oxford Television Company, Channel 4

Sport Test cricket, Sunset and Vine Productions, Channel 4

News and Current Affairs Journalism The Kosovo Conflict, John Simpson and BBC News, BBC1

Innovation Walking with Dinosaurs, BBC1

Entertainment programme or series Robbei the Reindeer, BBC1

Situation comedy The Royle Family, BBC1

Comedy programme or series The League of Gentlemen, BBC2

Lew Grade audience award A Touch of Frost, ITV

Alan Clarke award for outstanding personal contribution to television Peter Kosminsky

Dennis Potter award Tony Marchant

Producer Mark Redhead, with his colleague, Paul Greengrass, collected the award watched by Stephen's father, Neville, who was in the audience. In other awards Graham Norton beat the Ali G creator, Sacha Baron Cohen, to win the Bafta for best entertainment performance. Norton, who has just signed a lucrative deal to stay at Channel 4, beat comedians John Bird and John Fortune, and the veteran BBC chat show host Michael Parkinson. The Royle Family, which missed out on a Golden Rose at the Montreux television festival earlier this week after the BBC entered an ineligible episode of the sitcom, restored the corporation's pride by scooping two awards - one for sitcom, and one for the comedy performance of its star Caroline Aherne. The award for best comedy programme was also won by the BBC for its series The League of Gentlemen. ITV's A Touch of Frost won the Lew Grade audience award, voted by readers of the Radio Times, listeners to BBC Radio 2's Jonathan Ross show and viewers of GMTV. Jeremy Paxman beat his Newsnight colleague Kirsty Wark to the Richard Dimbleby award for best presenter (factual, features and news). Thora Hird, 88, won best actress for the second year running for her role in Lost For Words. Best actor went to Michael Gambon for Wives and Daughters. A special award was presented to the stars of the Avengers: Honor Blackman, Joanna Lumley, Diana Rigg and Linda Thorson, whom the academy believes have changed the perception of women on television. fields.headline: Need to know
fields.standfirst: Gary Grant
fields.trailText:
Age?
26.
fields.body:
Age?
26.

Who is he?
Co-MD of Netronyx.com, an interactive web design and promotion agency going live next week. Previously did 3-D models for a company that designed shops.

What's the clever idea?
"The Ali G Flash promo - how you can use the internet for advertising. Basically, I did it on a Saturday afternoon for a bit of a laugh and emailed it to a few of my mates and places like FHM. People passed it on to friends and colleagues, and it spread around the whole country within about a fortnight. It was really nothing to do with Netronyx; we were setting Netronyx up. But due to the success of the promo, we had so much interest from the media, top record and television companies, including Channel 4, that we're setting up not just promotional advertising but also full websites - the whole package."

What's the thinking behind it?
"Basically, the internet as it stands is quite lifeless. Many of the sites are anyway. We're looking to make the internet more interactive, a lot more interesting, bring life to it - with interactive games, promotional work, advertising, quizzes, anything people can do."

How does it work?
"There's a piece of macromedia software called Flash that a lot of the latest web technologists are using, replacing the static old HTML software. People want to put a much more exciting, interactive image across, and Flash is ideal for that. So on the Ali G Flash promo there was a list of Ali G expressions, like "Boyaka" and "Westside" down the right of the screen and you get real samples each time you roll over them. There's also different loops of music: you click on each one to change the music. Ali G's speaking the words over the top of the music."

Possible shortcomings?
"The Ali G promo happened so quickly, it pushed us into the forefront before we had a chance to build up our portfolio, but we had so many leads, we're obviously using them. In the future, though, because we've got our company name we've got to be careful that we don't upset anyone, copyright-wise for instance."

What's next?
"Off the back of Ali G, we're doing mostly promotional stuff. It's really popular but doesn't demonstrate our talents to our full potential. But we've got some really good offers that are more than just promotional work, people that want us to produce more sites. Channel 4 want us on their list of preferred web developers, we're in the pipeline of doing a promo for a new Sky One television programme and a website for London Records to promote the Artful Dodgers' next single. We'll be producing websites for companies that want an exciting web presence."

fields.headline: Battle for the box
fields.standfirst: Internet access through TV is no longer a case of 'if' but 'when'. So who's going to cash in? And who'll be left behind?  Imogen O'Rorke  examines the big players vying over turf
fields.trailText: Internet access through TV is no longer a case of 'if' but 'when'. So who's going to cash in? And who'll be left behind? Imogen O'Rorke examines the big players vying over turf
fields.body:
Ever since the information started leaking out that Open, the Sky-owned interactive shopping TV channel, was actually proving a success, it has been hard to avoid Interactive television, iTV, or idTV. Not a week passes without some new announcement: first Granada Media Group, followed by cable comapny NTL, announced they will be offering internet access through TV, then YesTV goes for early flotation, and last week Carlton unveiled a new commerce-based service, Carlton Active, on the same day Open released its first user data.

The clash in Britain is not a head-to-head between the PC and the TV as it is in America (in the UK penetration of TVs is 97% whereas PC penetration is likely to drop off at 50%) but a pitched battle over which platforms will control the "dumb" grey box in the corner, which is growing less dumb by the day.

Media, telephone and cable companies and ISPs are all trying to exploit the potential of broadband - increased bandwidth which will allow extra services through TV such as internet access, enhanced television, television-commerce, programming and video-on-demand. There are three, potentially four, competing platforms: digital satellite (DST), digital cable, digital terrestrial (DTT) and ADSL or broadband through the phoneline; it is anyone's guess which one will dominate.

ONdigital, the DTT service, makes it sound perfectly simple. In five years, when the plug is pulled on analogue, Andrew Marre, head of communications, says there is "no question" that DTT will be supreme. "In the long run we are expecting DTT with free-to-air services in every house in the country."

Not all of them will be ONdigital users, of course. The subscription service shares the 24-year government granted DTT licence with the free to air channels BBC, ITV and C4 and with SDN, a commercial pay-per-view multiplex. Marre believes his satellite rival in the shape of Sky, and its service Open, has shot itself in the foot: "Open has a walled garden with 20 to 30 sites and therefore limited content providers. It has HSBC and Abbey National on board, for example, but what happens if you bank with Barclays?"

ONdigital has only around 600,000 subscribers, however, whereas Open's reach last month was 3.3m and its email through the television accounts alone are used by 750,000. They aim to increase this to 5m by the end of the year and increase penetration to one in four homes. But the latest news which really will have service providers salivating is that 10% of Open households have bought something through the service - far better figures than e-commerce through the PC.

"People are always trying to trash Open," says Ricardo Teller, Open's spokesman. "But we already have the advantage and ONdigital is desperate to get in." Open has a set top box which operates at 28.8 bits per second, whereas ONdigital's can only manage 2.2bps, making internet access painfully slow. DST can also physically cover more of the country and whole chunks of Europe.

In many ways, it is futile trying to compare the services at this early stage, though Carlton Active has launched by promoting the idea of the "internet on TV" to make it attractive to interactive advertisers.

The user experience in Open is not "the poor man's internet" according to Teller: "We do not believe people are looking for that through their TV screens - it is somewhere between the turn off box [the TV] and the turn on box [the PC]." It is essentially that of the shopping mall, where the customer is entertained constantly. They can play a computer game while waiting for the machine to compare prices on water beds and then, feeling peckish after all that virtual strolling, you can order a pizza.

"Right now, no company is even close to second to Open," says Teller. "It is impossible for the others to catch up because of our technological advantage. The real battle is between ONdigital and cable companies - by the time the cable companies get round to launching a serious product, it will be too late. So we are saying to them, 'Come on in, come on board.'"

Cable companies such as Telewest, Cable and Wireless, NTL and Kingston have invested billions in localised infrastructure, yet their brand visibility to consumers compared to their satellite and terrestrial rivals is low. Telewest, which went live in March, claims to reach 1.6m, yet only has around 140,000 subscribers; Cable and Wireless's service, still on trial in Manchester, is live in 100,000 homes; NTL still hasn't launched.

Potentially, the cable companies could provide the best packages by a long way, linking telecoms, TV and always-on, high speed internet: fully-integrated interactivity which DST and DTT cannot match. Having little experience of content provision, however, is a disadvantage and so cable companies are currently forging partnerships like mad. Telewest already has 150 content partners, whereas NTL can boast beeb.com and a couple of high street brands; it is currently bidding for football rights.

"If the goal is a full broadband experience, there are numerous technical reasons why cable is the best and second best is ADSL," says Evan Rudowski, of Excite Europe. Excite@Home - the world's largest broadband service provider, which aims to dominate home shopping across the globe and recently signed iTV deals with Microsoft, At&T, and Cox - chose cable and ADSL. "Anyone who doesn't believe cable is best is wrong." Until greater bandwidth is available through the phoneline, however, he believes the PC will remain the main platform for surfing and shopping.

The fourth and unknown platform is ADSL, already a threat to big players. With the roll-out of the new technology, the telecom companies are able to make alliances with platform and service providers such as Sky, YesTV and the ADSL video-on-demand service Diva. They can then take advantage of opportunities created by the unbundling of local networks in 2001 and compete against the broadcasting giants; many ISPs are already buying up ADSL technology.

Thomas Kressner, the CEO of Yes TV, which has been providing video-on-demand through BT, talks of "total TV" - integrated services including net access, email, and broadcast TV over ADSL. Yes TV has content deals with BBC, C4, Transworld and u>direct amongst others.

"We are no longer just a video-on-demand service," says a Yes spokesperson. "We are a digital service provider and intend to be a significant player in pay TV." In other words, it is pitting itself against the likes of ONdigital and Open. "People thought we were going to be a small supplier. Now we have rattled a few very big cages and they are trying to give us a good kicking while they can."

Of all the players in iTV, the BBC probably has most at stake. A year ago, BBC Online's commitment was to broadcasting on the net - video streamed news bulletins. But last month the department received an enormous cash influx and was renamed the BBC New Media department with an equal commitment to interactive TV and online services "as an illustration of the impending convergence".

The BBC's vision for "future TV" is uncompromising, and can be summed up as how to get EastEnders to the widest possible audience, across a platform that will let audiences join a chat group to discuss how cute young Matthew Rose is and what a rat Steve Owen is. Greg Dyke's policy is, like his predecessor John Birt's, to spread the BBC's presence as widely as possible and the corporation is currently negotiating access to all possible platforms, and partnerships across the digital board. There is no room for risk in a market that is about to fragment explosively.

BBC Online development executive editor, Jonathan Kingsbury confesses there is, "too much at stake" to sustain old rivalries with the likes of ITV (ONdigital's owners), and part-mergers and carriage deals can be expected. Beneath the bristling front-line bravado, off the record, this is what Open, ONdigital and the cable companies are also considering. It may just be as some analysts are predicting that no single platform will emerge triumphant.

fields.headline: Give temps a chance
fields.standfirst: Before you race out of the office door for a two-week break, spare a thought for the temp who will be taking on your job, says  Marley Obi
fields.trailText: Before you race out of the office door for a two-week break, spare a thought for the temp who will be taking on your job, says Marley Obi
fields.body:
It's a scenario most temps are all too familiar with. You accept a booking with an exhaustive list of skills and requirements - 60wpm typing, advanced Microsoft Office, one blue eye, one brown, fluency in Swahili - only to spend the next two weeks in the job filing your nails.

Either that or you find yourself lumbered with the chores no one can be bothered to do, from filing to fielding calls, while the rest of the team go off for a three-hour lunch. All this for a measly £7 an hour.

"There is nothing worse than trying to look busy when you have nothing to do, or arriving at a job only to discover no one has a clue what you are supposed to be doing," says Karen Lake, 37, a professional temp for seven years. This is not necessarily because there is nothing to do, she says, but because temps are not briefed properly as to what needs to be done and how to do it. As summer approaches and holidaying administrators are replaced by temps, companies should consider how best to use them, to ensure it is not a waste of their own or their temps' time.

Every office operates differently and even the most professional and hard-working of temps can't be expected to be a mind-reader. "A PA position is very much a one-to-one role, especially in blue-chip companies where senior managers work long hours," says Lake. "In that type of situation you need to know your boss's exact requirements, down to the fact that he likes coffee every half hour." The temp, it goes without saying, needs to be told what those requirements are.

Permanent staff must be forward thinking in how they manage their holiday cover. First, they should decide whether they actually need a temp. Sometimes a slight redistribution of the workload among the rest of the support staff is all that is required. If you do need a temp, a prioritised list of daily duties, as well as tasks that have to be completed during the booking, is crucial to ensuring the temp has a stockpile of work to get through.

Clear and concise handover notes and helpful colleagues make a temp's life significantly easier and more productive, as Lake discovered in one of her assignments. "It started off as a short-term booking working for London Underground but ended up lasting nine months. There was terrific support, everyone knew what they were meant to be doing, and there was always someone to go to for help. It worked perfectly."

Christine Brown, 24, who has been temping for more than a year, says many companies fail to use the skills of their temps, many of whom are over-qualified for the jobs they are covering. She blames lack of communication. "One of the worst jobs I've had was a booking which I was told would require a good all-rounder to do typing and filing, answer phones, and provide general admin support. But all I did was file documents for eight hours a day. They could have got a junior filing clerk for £6 an hour rather than paying me £9 an hour."

Helen Miller, director of the temporary division at Roc Recruitment, concedes that a lot of time and money can be saved by ensuring temps are properly matched to jobs. Her advice to office support staff or human resources managers is to remember that the temps are coming into a new environment. Introduce them around the office, make them feel welcome and comfortable - and set aside plenty of things for them to do.

'Does anyone know the password?'
* Ensure the agency knows what skills the temp will need - there is no point insisting on 60wpm when you hardly do any typing, but routinely have to download information from the internet.

* Leave a prioritised list of tasks that have to be completed in your absence so the temp knows exactly what is expected.

* Keep an up-to-date job description handy to give an overview of your role.

* Leave a list of your computer passwords and frequently used internal/external phone numbers.

* Ask a colleague to supervise and help the temp - that way there is someone to fill in anything you have overlooked.

* Leave copies of the company's fax and letter templates so that the temp can work within house style.

* Leave clear instructions about where everything is kept, from the petty cash box to your boss's favourite mug.

* Always agree working hours and lunch/break times so the temp is prepared if there is any overtime to be done.

webTitle: Card swaps deal out lesson in life at Pokemon fair

fields.headline: Card swaps deal out lesson in life at Pokemon fair
fields.standfirst: Stephen Harper narrowed his eyes as he delivered the bad news to his seven-year-old client. At 13 the Pokemon dealer had developed the stock market savvy of Gordon Gekko, combined with the eye for detail of an Antiques Roadshow expert.
fields.trailText: Stephen Harper narrowed his eyes as he delivered the bad news to his seven-year-old client. At 13 the Pokemon dealer had developed the stock market savvy of Gordon Gekko, combined with the eye for detail of an Antiques Roadshow expert.
fields.body:
"Sorry kid, it's a nice card and quite rare. But I'm afraid it's got a scratch, so that halves its value. It's no good to me."

Crestfallen, the pigtailed little girl said: "But it's only a tiny scratch." The dealer could only shrug: "That's business I'm afraid."

He surveyed the crowds jostling around his table and peering enviously at the extensive Pokemon portfolio displayed in front of him. Looking at his watch, he declared: "Anyone here want to do any deals? Make room for people with cards to swap, please."

For talent scouts searching for the next generation of city traders, a good place to start would have been the adrenalin-charged Pokemon trading fair yesterday at Epsom racecourse in Surrey. Around 600 were there to learn the game and, more importantly, to make a trade.

Pokemon started four years ago as a computer game in Japan, and has created an industry worth more than £6bn a year. More than 100m have been sold in Britain since they were launched last October, and the craze has spawned movie and other spin-offs.

Children willingly hand over £7 for one of the rarer characters in their efforts to collect all 151 cards.

With starter packs at £7.25, and booster packs of 11 random cards at £2.49, the hobby is not cheap. And, despite teaching children a keen business sense, the craze has led to incidents of violence. Police have reported children being attacked by other children, some with weapons, for their cards.

Yesterday's fair was organised by a Pokemon collector, Jonathan Hague, who owns one of the rarest cards, Picachu's birthday, with a £370 price tag. He said that, while the organised events were trouble free, the worst incident he had witnessed was at a recent fair at Ashford in Kent, where a boy was robbed of his entire card collection worth £2,000.

Another boy at yesterday's fair, John Rossiter, 12, had been beaten up by a group of older schoolboys who robbed him of his collection. But, said his father, the experience had not dampened his son's enthusiasm. "Sure, he was very shaken up and didn't want to go to school for a fortnight.
