fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText:
• ONLINE RECRUITMENT
Online recruitment services are springing up everywhere, but how do you choose between them? It is difficult for clients looking for staff, and for candidates looking for jobs, to assess these "e-cruiters" in the same way as they would a high street branch. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation is now working with key players in the industry to put together a code of practice. The aim is to produce a set of standards which will reassure users that their consultancy adheres to best business practice.
fields.body:
 ONLINE RECRUITMENT
Online recruitment services are springing up everywhere, but how do you choose between them? It is difficult for clients looking for staff, and for candidates looking for jobs, to assess these "e-cruiters" in the same way as they would a high street branch. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation is now working with key players in the industry to put together a code of practice. The aim is to produce a set of standards which will reassure users that their consultancy adheres to best business practice.

 TOP MARKS

Congrats to Patricia Sivewright who has been named LCCI Examinations Board Top Secretary. Sivewright is PA to a director at Redcar & Cleveland borough council. She won the award after gaining top marks in the examination board's private and executive secretary's diploma, one of the highest qualifications for senior secretaries, and shining in a test of her diplomacy, commercial awareness and confidence.

GOOD NEWS FOR SOFTWARE

The benefits of new software can be quickly forgotten if it is not compatible with existing data. This is particularly true for databases, where an upgrade can require hours of re-inputting. A new software program for PCs, ConvertIT, will transform data from a database to any other format, allowing you to drag information from one screen to another. You can download 250 functions from the website of developer iola or, if you can't face doing it yourself, iola will convert data for you. For more info, email enquiries@iola.co.uk.

 SLEEPING ROUGH

If you work in IT - and have some influence over your boss - the homeless charity NCH Action for Children wants to hear from you. In preparation for its annual Byte Night event, when IT bosses are encouraged to sleep out for the night to raise money for youth homelessness, it is inviting their right-hand men and women to a reception at Jury's hotel in Kensington on June 1. The MDs of Microsoft, Aonix and Computer Associates have signed up, so what about your boss? Email natalif@nchafc.org.uk, or call 020 7704 7013.

 EMAIL ETIQUETTE

Emails are now central to business, but many of us are still unsure of style for formal communication. Do you address an email with "Dear . . .", and is it right to end with "Yours sincerely"? A new book, Writing Business Emails (How To books, £5), gives the answers, and offers tips to keep you within the law. Author Jonathan Whelan also outlines pointers to ensure your emails are read. Call Plymbridge Distributors on 01752 202301 to order a copy.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

webTitle: Desktop icons No 19: The swivel chair

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 19: The swivel chair
fields.trailText: He may have written the American declaration of independence and established the Democratic party, but Thomas Jefferson was more than just a founding father of US politics. Like all good 18th-century statesmen, he was annoyingly talented at just about everything, fitting in the time to develop a new plough that was widely used for many years and introducing the threshing machine to America. When he got bored with agriculture he turned to the office - implausibly, it is Jefferson who is credited with inventing the swivel chair.
fields.body:
He may have written the American declaration of independence and established the Democratic party, but Thomas Jefferson was more than just a founding father of US politics. Like all good 18th-century statesmen, he was annoyingly talented at just about everything, fitting in the time to develop a new plough that was widely used for many years and introducing the threshing machine to America. When he got bored with agriculture he turned to the office - implausibly, it is Jefferson who is credited with inventing the swivel chair.

With Abraham Lincoln patenting a new buoyancy device for ships and even Al Gore claiming to have developed email, Bill Clinton must be feeling pretty inadequate as he approaches the end of his incumbency. But the Presidential posterior is probably grateful for Jefferson's innovation. Interminable policy meetings in the oval office are no doubt made a bit less tedious when you can spin round a couple of times when things get really dull.

Thanks to those nice people from the health and safety executive, most of us now sit in sprung seats with decent back supports and adjustable height. Certainly without pneumatic seats and articulating backs and ergonomic lumber support, most of us would be laid out flat with back ache for much of the year.

And yet, the office chair is often as good a measure as any of office hierarchy. You think you have a nice seat? Take a look at your boss's. Chances are it has bigger arms, a higher head-rest and more fancy reclining positions than yours. The ones in the boardroom are probably made of leather. Which rather gives the lie to Jefferson's assertion that all men are created equal.

fields.headline: Behind every star
fields.standfirst: If 'Madonna' finds her bra doesn't fit, or 'Robbie Williams' gets lost on the way to the wig-maker, they turn to Donna Longstaff.  Tom Twentyman  reports
fields.trailText: If 'Madonna' finds her bra doesn't fit, or 'Robbie Williams' gets lost on the way to the wig-maker, they turn to Donna Longstaff. Tom Twentyman reports
fields.body:
'If my work is challenging, I'm happy," says Donna Longstaff, production co-ordinator on ITV's celebrity impersonation show Stars in their Eyes. And with the live final looming on Saturday, the forthcoming week will certainly be a challenge. "This is a manic show at any time, but I'm already having sleepless nights."

The week will centre on making sure that things run as smoothly as possible. Meticulous planning is vital - Longstaff booked the hospitality catering and the dressing rooms, and confirmed the telephone voting lines, well in advance. She has a policy of triple-checking every detail, but it always pays to expect the unexpected. The ten winning soundalikes from the series heats are due to arrive at the Manchester studios of Granada TV at 10am on Wednesday, "and a delayed train can have a domino effect on our rehearsal schedules. I have to ensure that we're all kept informed about what's happening."

Organising the seating plan for the 200-strong audience is one of the biggest headaches. In theory, Longstaff will label each seat with the name of its occupant for the camera run-through on Thursday, but in reality it is unlikely to happen that way. Confirmations often don't arrive until hours before the show starts, and she anticipates having to revamp the document four or five times. On the night itself, she'll be in charge of a team of runners behind the scenes.

Longstaff, 27, took a private secretary's course at Rochdale college, and says that she had no designs on a career in TV. "I just wanted to be a PA, preferably in a big firm, that was all." Her two-week college placement was at Granada, and after graduating in 1990 she joined the company as a PA.

She became production co-ordinator in 1998, and is one of a handful whose entire year is spent on Stars in their Eyes. "I have to be incredibly good at prioritising, and thinking on my feet." Before the series airs, she arranges the tour in which the original 50 contestants are filmed at their home or workplace. "Setting it up is a logistical nightmare, so two crews travel the country in a sensible order, in a fortnight. It is a fine art, synchronising the places, the people, and their availability."

Longstaff tries to build up a relationship with those who take part, spending the three months in the run-up to their appearance "hand-holding in a way, by motivating, supporting and counselling them. By the time the studio segment is taped, we're usually great friends," she says. Which means that if they need help, the open-plan production office is the first port of call. Rather than using their real name, they'll identify themselves as the star they are going to be. "Whoever takes the call will shout across something like, 'Robbie Williams has got lost going to the wig-maker. He wants to know what to do,' or 'Madonna says her bra won't fit.' Things can get quite bizarre at times," she admits.

The rule is one version of a particular artist for each series. "At auditions, there might be two Celine Dions, for example, though one will have the edge. Our musical director can tell by listening to the key of the voice if the second person also sounds like someone else, and will ask if they fancy having a try." About a tenth of those who appear on the show will not be able to play their first-choice singer.

And should there be little possibility of their costume being used again, she will arrange for it to be sold to them. "However much an outfit cost to make, the most we would charge is £100. More often than not, it will be less than that." Almost everybody leaps at the chance to take home this memento. "The worst part is having to explain to anyone who can't buy theirs why they can't."

As for those who have walked through the famous dry ice archway in the past, many have been content simply to have appeared on TV, and have turned down offers to take it further. Others play the club circuit, or perform on cruise liners. "Last year's Chris de Burgh has just signed a deal to record five albums. He was a paint mixer in a factory, so he's done exceptionally well," says Longstaff.

"We regularly get thank you cards, telling us that coming on Stars in their Eyes was the most fantastic experience - better than their wedding day in some cases."

fields.headline: The low-down
fields.standfirst: Medical secretaries
fields.trailText: 'Every hospital is underpinned by secretarial support," says Dr Owen Epstein, a gastroenterologist at the Royal Free hospital in London. With every referral requiring a letter back and forth to the patient's GP, huge amounts of paperwork are generated. But the use of new voice recognition software in Dr Epstein's department has cut the time a letter takes to be processed from seven minutes to two.
fields.body:
'Every hospital is underpinned by secretarial support," says Dr Owen Epstein, a gastroenterologist at the Royal Free hospital in London. With every referral requiring a letter back and forth to the patient's GP, huge amounts of paperwork are generated. But the use of new voice recognition software in Dr Epstein's department has cut the time a letter takes to be processed from seven minutes to two.

Fully effective voice recognition packages are still elusive. Within the medical profession, pathologists have used another type of software with some success. But pathologists' reports are short and repetitive, which makes digital transcription easier. Consultants' letters are longer and more varied, and dictated in noisy offices rather than laboratory conditions. Dr Epstein found an error rate of up to 5% in even the best software.

The new package, CyberTranscriber, is a highly efficient voice recognition programme that, it is hoped, will change all that. Letters are dictated over the phone, as opposed to the stilted, slow speech that most voice recognition packages still require. But a high degree of accuracy is still attained only by proof-reading. From its Worcestershire headquarters, CyberTranscriber emails the transcript, together with the original voice file, to a remote proof-reader, who may be as far afield as India or the US. The corrected copy is emailed to the consultant's secretary, who cuts and pastes it into a standard letter. Turnaround is within 24 hours or even faster.

The service is not cheap - about 1p a word. But taking efficiency into account, costs are comparable to hiring a temp. Patients benefit too, because the faster the files move around a hospital, the faster the appointment system works.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: "My job is all about communication," says Sophie Jeffrey, who for the past two years has worked as press and PR officer for Isle of Wight tourism. "By phone, email, fax - it's all about getting information across."
fields.body:
"My job is all about communication," says Sophie Jeffrey, who for the past two years has worked as press and PR officer for Isle of Wight tourism. "By phone, email, fax - it's all about getting information across."

Jeffrey believes that the most important factor in communicating effectively is knowing why you are doing your job. "If you want to get your message across - whatever it is - it's essential to have a clear statement of intention in your head at all times. For me, it's to promote the Isle of Wight as a quality destination and support the tourism industry, and I keep that in mind whenever I'm dealing with someone."

One moment she may be talking to a journalist from a national newspaper, the next to a local hotelier. "It's important to deal with everyone in a similar way," she believes, "to return their calls immediately, answer queries or offer help. One of the most overlooked factors in effective communicating is listening - making sure you've really heard what they want and that you are responding to their needs."

A large part of Jeffrey's role is ensuring people know what is happening on the island, much of which is done through press releases. "When you're writing press releases you have to ensure everything is clear. There is an emphasis these days on using plain English, keeping things simple. It's also important to proof-read any document that is being sent out - if a release has mistakes or typing errors it creates a negative impression."

There is more to successful communicating than simply making a succession of points. "It's hugely important to have notes in front of you when you make a phone call so that you have all the information to hand, and know what points you need to make. But a call shouldn't be too formal - where possible it's good to try to form some sort of relationship with the person you're dealing with. If you are friendly and interested, people are far more receptive to what you have to say."

A good phone manner, she believes, can make all the difference. "I have been told that if you smile when you're on the phone people can sense it. Communicating is more than just passing on information. If you're upbeat and enthusiastic it tends to be infectious and people are generally more receptive to what you're saying."

But things don't always go perfectly, and it's important to deal with problems or criticisms in the right way. "If there is any negative feedback it's important to take it on board," says Jeffrey. "Getting defensive is pointless. You have to listen to what is said, think carefully about what sort of response to offer, and then come back with an explanation."

The least effective way to communicate, she believes, is to be negative. "Whether it's someone visiting the island, a local restaurant owner, or a TV crew wanting to come and film, I always tell them I can help. Even if I can't personally deal with their query, I can usually find someone who can, and that helps keep the lines of communication open. In my business I make it my policy never to say no."

webTitle: Pull over, fill up and start work

fields.headline: Pull over, fill up and start work
fields.standfirst: Dolly Dhingra  on the motorway service station where you can plug in your laptop, fax, photocopy - oh, and buy petrol
fields.trailText: Dolly Dhingra on the motorway service station where you can plug in your laptop, fax, photocopy - oh, and buy petrol
fields.body:
The motorway service station: a place to stretch your legs, get an overpriced but mediocre bite to eat, have a fag, fill up with petrol and find out if you are heading in the right direction. Not somewhere you would expect to find busy executives impeding your beeline to the toilets.

But it seems that we are doomed never to be able to escape the call of the office, even when on the move. If Granada road services and BT have their way, we'll soon be pulling over to do a couple of hours' work before refilling the car and heading off again. Earlier this month, they launched the first service station office at the Heston west-bound services on the M4. "Workspace" is being marketed as a "cutting-edge facility for executives on the move", for which read a colour-coordinated modern office in a petrol station.

Paul Kelly, brand development director of Granada services, had noticed that visitors to its facilities were increasingly using the restaurants as "touch down" areas - marketing babble for catching up on a bit of work. They were also casually recharging mobile phones at plug points throughout the buildings. "We wanted to redevelop the site and we realised that we had business-users trying to do paperwork and hold meetings in our restaurants while at the same time you would get a family at the next table with kids screaming and running around. The business people said that it was not the best place to work and the families were sick of business people taking up table space. The idea came out of the fact that these two different customers don't sit comfortably together."

There is a large potential customer base. More than 350m visits are made to UK's motorway service stations each year. The M4 is a strong business commuter corridor and Heston was considered ideal because of its prime location and proximity to both London and Heathrow airport. Jill McArdle of BDG McColl, which designed the office, says: "You see people in their cars using their mobile phones and their laptops - this is a sanctuary, with state-of-the- art facilities. Workspace legitimises time out in a professional place."

Work is being marketed in increasingly sophisticated ways. BDG McColl refers to Workspace as a concept, and to its company as "the concept architects". "The future is about workers being 'time editors', able to make more choices about how they spend their time. What they need is a place where they can create their own ambiance and their own pace." More than 100 further Workspaces are planned, which will be up and running within 18 months.

Located at the front of Heston ser vice station, and staffed by two assistants, is Zone 1, or the reception, where you can plug in a laptop at no cost. Printing, fax and photocopying facilities are offered at a fee. To enter Zone 2, the Workspace lounge, you have to buy a day card for £5. The lounge is carpeted, with modern furnishings in bright terracotta and pastel colours and walls in deep turquoise. It is a light and airy space.

"Women find motorway service areas very threatening," says McArdle. "They are very masculine, especially at night. We wanted to create somewhere where a woman alone would feel quite comfortable to work, relax."

A coffee bar stands in the middle. You even get a free cup of coffee for your fiver, plus use of the showers, complete with fluffy white towels, shower gel and shampoo. Opening hours are 7am to 8pm on weekdays only, and you can spend all day working on a personal laptop and mobile phone at no further cost. But staff are persistent in offering hospitality and one gets the feeling that malingerers might be discouraged. This is aimed strictly at those in transit.

Zone 3 includes hot desks, semi-private areas with screen and canopies allowing the use of PCs while others have plug-in points for laptops. Users are issued with a code number with which they can access land-line telephones. The final zone incorporates the only private areas: bookable meeting rooms designed to accommodate up to six people and including TVs, videos and videoconferencing facilities. Hire charges for meeting rooms are £10-£20 an hour.

A working lunch at your desk costs £6.99 and consists of a sandwich, crisps and a very basic salad of tomato and lettuce. Working breakfasts start at £5.99 and include a variety of pastries. Workspace-users are not charged for parking facilities and, at least at present, with few customers using the offices, it does feel like a haven. The hum of the M4 and the arcade games in the outside foyer are barely audible.

"I think it's going to take about six months until people realise exactly what they are being offered," says Kelly. By the end of the summer, 13 Workspaces will be open, dotted, along motorways throughout the UK; Granada hopes eventually to have one at each of its existing services. "It's not necessarily about immediate use," Kelly says. "People have to get used to the idea. It's also about persuading companies that this is a good facility to use"

Workspace also claims to be making a contribution to road safety. In a recent study by the RAC one in 12 drivers confessed to falling asleep at the wheel and 30% said that they had been excessively tired or stressed while driving. Both Granada and BDG McColl claim that the Workspace is not entirely about work but about leisure, snatching a bit of quality time during the mad dash to meetings. McArdle says, "It's not about just working - if you just want to get some headtime or relax and read the papers, then fine, this facility is available to you."

The only problem is likely to come the next time you decide to take time off to get away from it all. Pulling into a service station to check your voicemail could result in you having to put in a couple of hours in the motorway office. It seems there really is no escape from work these days.

fields.headline: Chain reaction
fields.standfirst: Property shows are like anything else - you get what you pay for. But Location, Location, Location, Channel 4's new house-buying series, lacks a real selling point. By  Mark Lawson
fields.trailText: Property shows are like anything else - you get what you pay for. But Location, Location, Location, Channel 4's new house-buying series, lacks a real selling point. By Mark Lawson
fields.body:
If you regard the television schedules as an estate agent's map - with each kind of programme representing a different location - then makeover shows would be the Islington or Notting Hill. Everyone has heard stories of the money you can make there if you just get on the ladder. But move fast.

Docu-soaps were yesterday's Islington and now you can't give stuff away there.

So it's appropriate that the latest expert intervention series features house-buying. With Changing Places renovating your house and Ground Force turning over your garden, Location, Location, Location this week enters the chain at an earlier stage and helps viewers to buy a house. Kirstie Alsopp and Phil Spencer - described as "professional property-hunters" - accept the challenge of finding a residence within the budget their guest has set. They have four days. The over-heated housing market - which is the reason this series is being screened - also makes this unusual among makeover programmes in that the guests fund the experiment themselves. In programme one, 28-year-old Kate, now resenting renting, has £100,000 to spend in London. The following week, the Williams family from Edinburgh have £270,000 to splash in Stirlingshire.

Although then-and-now formats are the current blue-chip commissions in television, this one is relatively risky. Estate agency is a widely disliked profession, and it is generally held that the worst possible dinner-party experience is enduring people's accounts of their suffering or success on the property market. Another gamble, of course, is that the programme begins with London, where people pay footballer prices for a cupboard. A national audience may feel appalled at Kate's largesse rather than, as the commentary invites, sympathetic to her financial limitations.

Whereas Changing Places and Ground Force are most compelling when the conversion plans are those that you would least like to copy, Location, Location, Location tries to push open doors and windows on knowledge.

Between the entertaining game-show segments - in which Kirstie and Phil rush their guest around possible properties - there are some website-like pop-up boxes of facts about surveys, planning permission, loft conversions and the usefulness of taking Polaroids of places you view. But, as a television property, the real problem with Location, Location, Location is its structural weakness. Although originally sold as improvement shows, programmes like this are relished by the audience as deterioration series. The success of the house and garden makeover shows largely depends on that final "Oh no!" moment when the client sees how their dreams have been misread. Stories about "victims" of the BBC's experts have become a standby of the middle-market press. But this is a double-standard, because what most of the audience wants is eye-popping horror at the results.

The problem with this new house-purchasing version is that it will finish either with frustration - if no suitable property is to be found - or with an "Oh yes!" yell as the bid is accepted. The first programme even closes on Grand Prix spraying of champagne. Neither emotion will match the excitement of seeing a home-owner at the moment when they discover that Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen has turned their semi-detached into a set from The Seventh Seal. The only potential "Oh no!" moments will come from gazumping.

A person's true story of their house purchase begins on walking through the door with the keys. Will there be a follow-up programme if the ecstatic dweller subsequently discovers subsidence or the sudden re-routing of the Channel Tunnel rail link past the door? It may be true to the creed of estate agents for the programme to walk away at the moment of purchase, but it sacrifices the drama.

Other worries make you reluctant to bet your house on this being a hit. In an age of weirdos - some of them strange men sitting alone at home watching TV - you feel a little uneasy about an opening programme which effectively gives the address of a young single woman.

And, rather as Crimewatch UK is a show made entirely on police terms, Location, Location, Location accepts the rhetoric of vendors and estate agents. Where some scepticism or regret about the hiking of house prices might seem journalistically required at the moment, the show stresses the importance of getting into the market as soon as possible and bidding high first time. Whenever Kate waits, she loses the house. "Another one we've missed," laments Phil. "I don't think we'll be seeing this on the market for five years."

So the paradox of a show designed to help the first-time buyer with limited funds is that its inevitable effect will be to raise asking prices in the parts of the country it visits. So, although it offers some impressive views of its subject, Location, Location, Location finally has, as they say, potential for improvement.

 Location, Location, Location, Wednesday, 8.30pm, Channel 4

fields.headline: A man's gotta do...
fields.trailText: Floggings, keel-haulings and a diet of worm-infested biscuits are what we normally associate with life in the Royal Navy 200 years ago. However, experts now think that being in the navy during the golden age of Nelson wasn't that bad after all. In fact, apart from obvious hazards like being dismembered by a French cannonball, being afloat with His Lordship was in many respects preferable to civilian low-life ashore.
fields.body:
Floggings, keel-haulings and a diet of worm-infested biscuits are what we normally associate with life in the Royal Navy 200 years ago. However, experts now think that being in the navy during the golden age of Nelson wasn't that bad after all. In fact, apart from obvious hazards like being dismembered by a French cannonball, being afloat with His Lordship was in many respects preferable to civilian low-life ashore.

The findings of various naval historians were reported in BBC2's History Zone film, Myths Of Nelson's Navy (Sat). Unwisely, it employed the device of pairing off reflections on Nelson's era with sequences filmed aboard the modern-day frigate HMS Grafton. Somehow, the Grafton could not help looking like a set for a navy recruitment film.

The historical revelations were far more interesting, not least the fact that while Nelson had recruiting problems too, the notorious press gangs were not the thuggish kidnapping teams of popular mythology. As the film pointed out, there wouldn't have been much point in dumping a random collection of clueless landlubbers on one of His Majesty's ships o' the line and then expecting them to perform like battle-hardened professionals. The navy needed experienced seaman, so the press gangs targeted merchant sailors.

The navy was of the utmost strategic importance, so its crews had to be kept healthy. Hence, a diet of fresh fruit and veg alongside salt beef and salt pork kept the Tars in fighting trim, while the comforts of home were often available to crew members in the shape of their wives, who were frequently on board during combat. But the major incentive for the grizzled seafarer was the lure of prize money. Some Spanish treasure ships boasted loot worth £50 million at today's prices, and Nelson, for whom patriotic pride came second only to the lure of the gold doubloon, never sailed without his personal prize agent. We might start viewing Nelson's column in a different, privatised light.

When The Magnificent Seven became a belated smash after its initial box office failure, everybody clamoured for the credit of having had the brilliant idea of turning Kurosawa's Seven Samurai into a cowboy movie. Yul Brynner planned to direct it. James Clavell wanted to write it. Anthony Quinn wanted to star in it.

In the end, John Sturges directed it, and Anthony Quinn sued Brynner for writing him out (Quinn lost). Walter Bernstein wrote the screenplay, but didn't get a billing because he got the hump when William Roberts was deemed worthy of a co-writing credit for his script-doctoring efforts.

All this and more was revealed in Guns For Hire: The Making Of The Magnificent Seven (C4, Sat), which managed to rise above its merely workmanlike construction and a truly appalling commentary ("filming in Mexico proved to be no fiesta") by winkling out some excellent anecdotes from the movie's cast and crew. With a bunch of stars-in-the-making all frantically trying to out-ride and out-shoot each other, the set was, as Steve McQueen's widow Niele put it, "fraught with testosterone". Much of it oozed from McQueen, and there was a hilarious compilation of scenes showing him upstaging his compadres with gratuitous facial expressions and brazen camera-grabbing tricks with his hat. Brynner warned him that if he didn't pack it in, he'd remove his own black stetson to reveal the show-stopping dome beneath.

Whether The Magnificent Seven was really the pivotal end-of-an-era Western that Lawrence Kasdan and John Carpenter tried to claim remains questionable - more of a rough and tumble horse-opera with a great soundtrack, I'd say. Still, Kurosawa had the grace to congratulate Sturges on making a darn fine movie.

I was rather enjoying Making Faces: Jerry Hall (C4, Sun), in which the long, tall Texan seemed funny ("from that picture in the Evening Standard, I must be part horse") and impossibly saintly towards the philandering Mick Jagger ("he's a really nice person"). A shame, therefore, that the film degenerated into an elaborate sales device for painter Paul Benney, who is Jerry's new best friend and is going to paint her entire family. It might be interesting to stretch the format a bit and set a pricklier challenge for the pampered portraitist. Alex Ferguson or Robert Mugabe, perhaps.

fields.headline: Bitter pill
fields.trailText: It's a big risk making a documentary about contraception. Just so many tempting metaphors for critics, even before they slide the cassette in. Programme should have been pulled out. It's a mis-conception. Presenter should have worn something over his head. Schedulers should have said "not tonight".
fields.body:
It's a big risk making a documentary about contraception. Just so many tempting metaphors for critics, even before they slide the cassette in. Programme should have been pulled out. It's a mis-conception. Presenter should have worn something over his head. Schedulers should have said "not tonight".

Unfortunately - and you can trust me, I've taken the precaution of watching it - Sex And Stopping: A History Of Contraception (Wednesday, 10.15pm, BBC1) merits all these remarks. Marking the birth control pill's 40th anniversary, it examines the history of attempts to enjoy sexual pleasure without a reminder nine months later.

The problem with contraception as a subject is that it has a cultural double life. It's both serious and funny. The condom is an objectively ridiculous garment, but may prevent us trampling each other to death as we fight for our share of the planet's last available air. And Sex And Stopping can never decide whether to snigger or instruct.

Presenter Nick Hancock - host of They Think It's All Over - claims to be investigating in preparation for the day he must tell his daughter about being careful, but this conceit is soon rolled up and thrown away in favour of an uncontrolled spurt of anecdotes focusing on the curious rather than the useful.

We learn of primitive Egyptian pessaries made from crocodile dung soaked in sour milk. Then we hear from those practising coitus reservatus, where ejaculation is willed to happen backwards. All of these will, of course, feature prominently when little Miss Hancock gets her chat.

Scheduled to follow the Uefa Cup Final, the film finally succumbs to laddishness completely as the presenter wincingly watches a vasectomy. Over-using the 90s device of showing old movie footage out of context, a silent movie sequence of a woman covering herself with a tarpaulin runs under mention of barrier methods. A film about preventing mistakes, Sex And Stopping is one.

webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: Desk Set | Gorky Park | Cube | Chungking Express
fields.body:
Desk Set (Walter Lang, 1957)
7pm, Carlton Cinema

A Hepburn-Tracy double-act enlivens this workaday comedy about a computer threatening jobs at a library. He's a prototype whizzkid installing the electronic brain, much to the chagrin of Hepburn the head librarian, a woman of formidable intelligence. You don't have to be a genius to work out the denouement.

9pm, 3am, Carlton Cinema

10pm, FilmFour

Wong Kar-Wei has already been compared to the young Jean-Luc Godard, and this shows just why - a frenetic, funny romantic comedy interweaving the adventures of two lovelorn Hong Kong cops. It's effectively a modern fairy tale, complete with touching love stories - particularly between policeman Tony Leung Chiu-Wai and wacky Faye Wang down at the local takeaway emporium - and an utterly dazzling portrait of the brash, tough city.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Inventors Imperfect | Nature
fields.body:
The final episode of Adam Hart-Davis's series Inventors Imperfect (11am, Radio 4) gently adjusts what we thought we knew about the invention of radio. History credits it, of course, to Guglielmo Marconi. But in 1889 Oliver Lodge and Alexander Muirhead registered an initial patent and, in 1894, built a working transmitter-receiver. But on June 2 1896, the Italian successfully patented "wireless telegraphy" - his modification of the Lodge-Muirhead system.

The abysmal state of British farming isn't just creating human misery. As Brett Westwood reports in Nature (9pm, Radio 4), it's having a dramatic impact on our native wildlife. European policy of subsidising intensive food production has destroyed one habitat after another. It's not only the loss of hedgerows but practices like shifting the planting cycle of cereals which are as disruptive. Elliot Morley, countryside minister, is among the interviewees.

webTitle: Easy pickings in a town called Sue

fields.headline: Easy pickings in a town called Sue
fields.standfirst: Should foreigners be able to use English libel laws against critics they can't easily pursue in other countries? The Berezovsky v Forbes case last week, says  Clare Dyer, suggests the issue needs to be reconsidered
fields.trailText: Should foreigners be able to use English libel laws against critics they can't easily pursue in other countries? The Berezovsky v Forbes case last week, says  Clare Dyer, suggests the issue needs to be reconsidered
fields.body:
Is he the godfather of the Kremlin? asks the headline. The original article, published in Forbes magazine in December 1996, might be hard to get your hands on. Only 1,915 copies were distributed in England, compared with 785,000 in America. But anyone who wants to see what it said about Boris Berezovsky, the richest man in Russia, can find out in a few clicks of a computer mouse. Just call up Forbes's website, search on Berezovsky, and it's on your screen.

Or at least it was last Friday, the day after the law lords gave the Russian tycoon and member of the Duma the go-ahead to sue for libel in the English courts. The ruling should send shock waves through the publishing industry worldwide. For it opens up for magazine and newspaper publishers around the world the risk of entanglement in expensive libel battles in England, not just over copies picked up on English newsstands, but over articles downloaded from websites in New York or Washington by computer users in England.

By a three to two majority, our highest court ruled that Berezovsky and an associate, who both live and work in Russia, can sue a US magazine in our courts over an article entirely concerned with their rise to power and business methods in Russia. As Lord Hoffmann, one of the two dissenters, put it, Berezovsky and his associate Nikolai Glouchkov, managing director of the Russian airline Aeroflot, "want English law, English judicial integrity and the international publicity which would attend success in an English libel action".

No doubt they do, but why should we hand it to them? As Mr Justice Popplewell explained in the High Court in October 1997, when he barred them from suing in England: "There is no English connection in the article. It is in an American magazine written in American style and is wholly connected with matters in Russia."

Forbes's editor and publisher could never have imagined when they ran the article that they could end up being sued for libel in the courts of a country wholly unconnected with the magazine, the subjects of the article, or the activities it describes. The magazine now has a global edition, but in 1996 the US edition was sold abroad in small numbers, mainly to expatriate American businessmen.

Forbes is produced in New York in a climate British journalists - operating under one of the world's most oppressive libel regimes - can hardly imagine. US journalists are protected by laws which enshrine free speech as a fundamental cornerstone of the constitution. Public figures can sue successfully only if they can prove the journalist either knew the story was false or wrote with reckless disregard as to its truth or falsity - a hurdle which makes it virtually impossible for well-known plaintiffs to win.

So the magazine had little to fear when it quoted an American businessman: "These guys are criminals on an outrageous scale. It's as if Lucky Luciano were chairman of the board of Chrysler." Or when it wrote: "Behind them lies a trail of corpses, uncollectable debts and competitors terrified for their lives" - the allegations, among others, over which the Russians are suing.

English law gives a right to sue for libel even if only a handful of copies are circulated in England. That rule, and libel laws which put the onus on the publisher of the story to prove it true, have made London a mecca for "forum-shoppers" - would-be litigants pondering which country's courts would give them the best outcome. Usually, there is simply no contest: London wins by a mile.

"London has become known as a town named Sue - a place where you can launder your reputation on the basis of a few sales in the UK of some overseas publication," writes London libel solicitor David Hooper (who happens to be Forbes's lawyer) in his new book Reputations Under Fire.

So Robert Maxwell used the English courts to sue the New Republic (135 subscribers in the UK, compared with 98,000 circulation in the US). Commander Martin Packard won £450,000 damages in 1987 against the Greek newspaper Eleftherotypia, of which only 40 copies were sold in England. And in 1997 a UK and Israeli citizen who had lived in London since 1985 was allowed to proceed with a libel action over two articles in an Israeli newspaper written in Hebrew in issues with circulations of 141 and 19 in England.

The Los Angeles-based tycoon, Armand Hammer, head of Occidental Petroleum, sued the UK publisher of a critical, US-written biography, which published only 3,000 copies, but not the American publishers, who produced a much bigger print run. Costs were said to exceed £1.5m before Hammer's death in 1990 aged 92 brought the action to an end.

Mr Justice Popplewell's ruling against Berezovsky and Glouchkov - along with two other recent decisions halting actions by US-based businessmen against Forbes and Dow Jones - was reckoned to mark a turning point. (One of the plaintiffs was Oscar Wyatt, whose stepson Steve's friendship with the Duchess of York boosted his claim to close business, family and social links with England.) But the Court of Appeal unanimously overturned Popplewell's decision.

The two Russians put in further evidence via claims by accountants and financiers in England that the article had raised doubts about the wisdom of getting involved with companies known to have links with Berezovsky or Glouchkov. The Appeal Court judges were persuaded that their connections with England were significant. Berezovsky's estranged wife and two children lived in London; his two daughters from a previous marriage had graduated from Cambridge University; he visited frequently on business. He had even known Prince Michael of Kent for four years and had visited him frequently in his home at Kensington Palace.

Forbes appealed and lost narrowly last Thursday when three law lords - Steyn, Nolan and Hobhouse - held that the Russians were entitled to use our courts to protect their reputations among business contacts in England. Lords Hoffmann and Hope came down strongly on the other side, but they were outnumbered.

Hoffmann pointed out that Berezovsky did not want to sue in either of the two more obvious places - Russia, where his activities took place, or the US, where the article was published - because he knew he would probably lose in the US, and he claimed success in the Russian courts might be put down to his "corrupt influence over the Russian judiciary".

In some respects, the English courts would be "admirably suitable" for the pair to vindicate their international reputations, said Hoffmann. "But that does not mean we should always put ourselves forward as the most appropriate forum in which any foreign publisher who has distributed copies in this country, or whose publications have been downloaded here from the internet, can be required to answer the complaint of any public figure with an international reputation, however little the dispute has to do with England."

Hope, also dissenting, pointed out that for all the Russians' assertions of their strong links with England, "it could be said that their position was really no different from that of the many thousands of businessmen and women from all over Europe and North America who are to be found in the executive lounges in our airports every week of the year as they travel to or from London".

Among the several ironies of the case is the fact that US courts regard our libel laws as so repugnant to their notions of free speech that they refuse to enforce our libel damages awards. So Berezovsky and Glouchkov can only hope to collect damages to the extent that Forbes has assets in the UK. Forbes has an office in London, which it might be well advised to close down pronto.

It seems there would be nothing then to stop the magazine ignoring the libel writ and letting the pair get judgment, which they would be entitled to do automatically if no defence was filed. The alternative would be weeks in the High Court trying to prove the truth of allegations for which any evidence would be in Russia.

The high hurdle defendants already face in proving what they said was true is much higher when witnesses and documents are abroad, making it hard to subpoena them. In this sort of case, the more truth there is in the allegations, the less likely it is that witnesses will want to testify.

Berezovsky said after the judgment: "I brought action in England in order to clear my name before a court where the truth or falsity of the allegations will be determined." But no one who knows the game believes that a libel court always determines the truth. A libel win could mean that the allegations were false; equally, it could mean that witnesses lied or that the defendants were not able to produce enough relevant evidence to prove the accusations. As the Jeffrey Archer and Jonathan Aitken cases showed, key witnesses may lie and their lies may be more convincing than the truth.

Of course Berezovsky and Glouchkov want "English law, English judicial integrity and the international publicity which would attend success in an English libel action". Russian newspapers have published scurrilous stories about them, but they have chosen not to sue there. Why should we let our courts and judges, paid for from our taxes, be used as a public relations vehicle to bolster the battered images of foreign businessmen?

fields.headline: Race dilemma for judges
fields.trailText: A few years ago a woman juror at Croydon Crown Court told the judge that her intense racial prejudice prevented her from reaching an unbiased verdict in the trial of a black defendant. The judge let her go home. But what should a judge do if he receives a note from one juror saying that some fellow jurors had made racist jokes and remarks?
fields.body:
A few years ago a woman juror at Croydon Crown Court told the judge that her intense racial prejudice prevented her from reaching an unbiased verdict in the trial of a black defendant. The judge let her go home. But what should a judge do if he receives a note from one juror saying that some fellow jurors had made racist jokes and remarks?

What he in fact did was to request (and receive) assurances from the jurors that they weren't racist and would reach an unbiased verdict. Not enough, said the European Court of Human Rights, ruling that an Asian defendant hadn't received an impartial trial; the judge should have discharged the jury and stopped the trial.

I'm a little apprehensive at this decision. I fear a flurry of informants squealing to judges that fellow jurors are racist, sexist, asleep, too stupid to understand the evidence, or otherwise objectionable or biased.

What's a judge to do? Investigate each allegation, thus breaching the secrecy of the jury room? Not allowed, and anyway impractical. Stop the trial and discharge the jury every time a complaint is made? Do nothing and wait for the defendant's inevitable, probably successful, application under human rights law that he didn't get a fair trial?

First A Civil Action, then The Insider, now Erin Brockovich; all of them films, based on real events, in which David, the ordinary man, woman or lawyer, confronts Goliath, the huge corporation. Two of the films involved the chemical poisoning of communities whose members - but for the Davids (lawyer John Travolta and paralegal Julia Roberts respectively) - would not have brought lawsuits and would have remained uncompensated for their suffering and deaths.

The Insider is different in that the David - the whistleblower revealing the secrets of the tobacco company he worked for - faced the opposition of two corporations: his old employers and, ultimately, the television network which let him down. What the films have in common is an unashamed anti-corporation stance. Big business is automatically unprincipled, untruthful and contrary to the well-being of ordinary people.

Yet what I missed was a sense of corporate ruthlessness and wickedness. The companies folded too easily; they were not villainous enough. Indeed, in Erin Brockovich, they're almost invisible, their nastiness limited to glowering looks in the courtroom and a mildly threatening phone call. Corporate evil in The Insider was portrayed by the tobacco boss, played by Michael Gambon stroking a cat, like Charles Gray in the Bond films.

The result, for me, was disappointment that the Davids - especially Brockovich - had it so easy. Lack of tension was caused not by the fact that we all knew who was going to win anyway, but that the struggle seemed so lacklustre. Bring back villainous corporations who will stop at nothing.

The recent popular Bring Your Daughter to Work day, a bonding occasion when mothers (and fathers) can impress (or embarrass) their offspring by showing them how they earn their living, wasn't of much help to one professional category - trial lawyers. Children under 14 aren't allowed into court; so those whose parents are advocates (or judges) weren't able to see them in brilliant action. I can understand why under-14s shouldn't be allowed to watch rape, murder or other sex 'n' gore trials; but why a blanket ban?

Why shouldn't a 13- or even 12 year-old sit in on the many non-sensitive cases, learning how our legal system works? It can always be left to the judge to exclude a child in a particular case, but the rule should be to allow them in, not keep them out.

I used to chortle, in a what-will-American-lawyers-think-of next sort of way;but I've just read a book which has made me laugh a little less patronisingly. Rattling the Cage, by Steven Wise (Profile Books), is a plea for some animals to be given legal rights, not just in the sense of being protected from man's cruelty, but active, positive rights, similar to those accorded to human beings.

The book is worth reading for its splendid historical outline of past relationships between animals and the law, not the least fascinating examples, in many societies, of animals prosecuted in the criminal courts. In mediaeval France, for instance, it was not uncommon for pigs to be convicted of murder; the sentence of death often accompanied by the judge's order that the pig's body should be left to hang in a public place, as a deterrent to other pigs.

Wise's book is sub-titled Towards Legal Rights For Animals, and he picks out chimpanzees and bonobo apes as being particularly worthy of being granted such rights. I am troubled by his reasoning. These animals, he argues, have as much intelligence, cognitive skills and autonomy as babies, small children or severely mentally handicapped adults. Those humans have rights; why not the cleverer "non-human animals"?

I'm tempted to give the informed, intellectual reply: "Because, that's why". The fact is, animals ain't people. But Wise has made me think. A little.

fields.headline: A balcony named desire
fields.standfirst: Six love stories collide in Michel Tremblay's new play. Canada's great playwright talks to  Elisabeth Mahoney
fields.trailText: Six love stories collide in Michel Tremblay's new play. Canada's great playwright talks to Elisabeth Mahoney
fields.body:
It sounds like a highly spurious PhD subject, or one of those how-did-they-fund-that? research studies at a university no one's ever heard of: the relationship between restaurant tables, political change and national identity. In fact, it's Quebec's most celebrated living writer, playwright Michel Tremblay, explaining how his hometown of Montreal has changed since he began writing more than 30 years ago.

So do the 11 characters in Tremblay's play Solemn Mass for a Full Moon in Summer, which opens the Barbican's Bite:00 festival this week, following the premiere of its new translation at Edinburgh's Traverse Theatre. As a play about love, Solemn Mass has far more emphasis on falling out than on falling in ("Well, I'm 57," Tremblay says with a laugh) and there are some terrifically bleak, honest moments about the cruelty, boredom and violence that can set in when love leaves. Yet somehow it feels redemptive at the end, when the cast have finished their 10-minute monologues and joined together as a chorus once more to sing, "Amen." "My generation of Quebecois were all raised in small houses with small rooms and windows. We renovated our houses but not our souls, and that's what the characters are doing. It's not, I hope, too late for us to do that."

A deeply personal play, Solemn Mass is in its own way as radical as the works Tremblay is best known for, the plays in which he put Montreal working-class speech - joual - onto the world stage. This elevation of the vernacular in plays such as Les Belles Soeurs brought a stigmatised language into the cultural mainstream. Though not as politically loaded, the new play brings into view all the details of love - the murky, dirty, despicable aspects of love - that are routinely left out of conversation, theatrical productions and certainly Catholic doctrine. Like all of Tremblay's best work, it is geographically and historically rooted, but also impressively universal.

What you may not recognise, if you're not familiar with Montreal and in particular Plateau Mont-Royal, the district where Tremblay sets his plays, are the balconies. Far more than a dramatic device to have all the characters in their own space but on stage at the same time, they are essential to the special quality of this drama. "You must go see," Tremblay urges, grabbing my map of the city. "They call this area Tremblayland!" Recently, he says, someone bought the house where he grew up. When word got round that the new owner planned to remove the front door, fans offered to buy it. That's how big Tremblay is round here.

I take a tour on foot through the landscape of Tremblay's youth - an overcrowded and brutal place by all accounts, though it has since been prettified - and see how every house has its balconies and wrought iron staircases. Garden furniture is in place, as are pot plants and homely touches like carpet on the stairs and fake grass on the floor. These extra rooms are both private and public, with sound and fury bound to carry from one to another. Suddenly, the balconies in the play make sense. As I turn into Rue Fabre, at the very heart of Tremblayland, church bells begin to ring out, deafeningly loudly. The idea of the mass being a structure through which the rest of your life might be held up, examined and measured makes sense too. I almost say a little prayer at this revelation but opt instead for a quick, quiet, "Amen."

 Solemn Mass for a Full Moon in Summer opens the Bite:00 festival at the Barbican , London EC1 (020-7638 8891), on Wednesday and runs till June 3.

fields.headline: Tower and the glory
fields.standfirst: The height of 7 South Dearborn in Chicago will be matched only by its beauty.  Jonathan Glancey salutes the next tallest building in the world
fields.trailText: The height of 7 South Dearborn in Chicago will be matched only by its beauty. Jonathan Glancey salutes the next tallest building in the world
fields.body:
It was the story of the cats and the lavatory that amused me and gave me the clearest idea yet of what living in an apartment in a real skyscraper must be like. Lynn Osmond, president of the Chicago Architecture Foundation, lives on the 45th floor of a downtown tower overlooking Lake Michigan on one side and Big John, the 100-floor John Hancock Centre and one of the tallest buildings in the world, on the other. Such is the swaying of her building during storms, she told me, that the water in the lavatory basin shifts from side to side. The cats sit fascinated on the porcelain rim, pawing the water as it sloshes about, and play there until the storm abates.

Osmond is never less than awed during electric storms as jagged forks of lightning stab into the twin red-and-white communications antennae that rise 350ft above the roof of this gloriously brutal 1,127ft skyscraper. And then there are the days when there is nothing to see outside because the 45th floor is in cloud. But what about those mornings when you look out of your bedroom window and find the clouds beneath you?

Still, this is chicken feed in the wonderful world of skyscraper living. If you can afford it, there are 90th floor apartments in Big John, offering views across Lake Michigan and the great wheat plains of Illinois as far as the eye can possibly see. In the Signature Room cocktail bar even higher up, dry martinis are shaken not stirred by the sheer force of the wind acting on the 46,000-ton steel structure of this architectural behemoth. But you ain't seen nothing yet. In the very heart of Chicago, work is about to begin on the tallest building in the world. Including its twin 450ft lightning-conducting digital communications antennae, 7 South Dearborn will be 2,000ft tall, with 108 floors.

Until it is completed in three or four years' time, the world's tallest building title will belong to the super-kitsch twin Petronas Towers (1,483ft) in Kuala Lumpur. They were designed by the New York architect Cesar Pelli, although William F Baker, structural engineering partner of Skidmore Owings and Merrill (SOM) had a hand in the development of this 88-storey condiment set. Baker is also the structural engineer of 7 South Dearborn, and SOM the designer of Big John and the Sears Tower in Chicago, which at 1,450ft held the tallest building title from 1974 until the Petronas Towers pipped it by 33ft in 1996.

Seven South Dearborn will be a genuinely mixed-use building, with shops and restaurants at street level, 11 floors of parking for 800 cars, 32 floors of offices, 40 floors of (cat-friendly) apartments and 13 floors of hi-tech communications gear. More than this, it promises to be as slender and appealing as the previous monsters - the World Trade Centre in New York, the Sears Tower and their kid brother, the Cesar Pelli-designed Canary Wharf tower in London - are bulky and dull.

This is because 7 South Dearborn is being designed to attract a new wave of hi-tech dot.com enterprises with highly paid staff who want a view over Lake Michigan in one direction and the infinitely receding wheat plain in the other: no one wants to moulder under fluorescent lighting beside the liftshaft, and the same applies to those renting the apartments, 80 or 90 storeys up. Furthermore, Baker's design is highly innovative: each floor will be cantilevered from a central concrete core, up which elevators and essential services will run. The structure is thus very light for a skyscraper, eschewing all those tens of thousands of tons of steel girders that have been the bones of high-rise buildings since they were born in Chicago some 110 years ago.

In effect, 7 South Dearborn is an exceptionally tall yacht's mast of a building, with floors strung out from it like sails. What could be more fitting for a skyscraper? The word was adopted from the terminology of sailing ships: the skyscraper was a ship's topmost sail.

Banks of floors will be divided by notched setbacks that will break up what would otherwise be the sheer, monumental nature of the stainless steel and aluminium tower and ensure that it looks as much like a communications mast as it does an office tower, shopping centre, place to eat and apartment block. And if anyone thinks a communications mast sounds a bit ugly, they have yet to see Norman Foster's superb, skyscraping communications tower in Barcelona.

After decades of bland skyscraper design worldwide, the beauty of 7 South Dearborn comes as both a surprise and a relief. For too long developers and their architects have viewed skyscrapers as highly ambitious rent-slabs, filing cabinets stacked as high into the sky as economics, egos and local planning laws have allowed. The last truly elegant skyscrapers were the Empire State Building of 1931 and the Chrysler Building of the year before. There have been some fascinating structural leviathans since - SOM's John Hancock Centre of 1969 and I M Pei's Bank of China, Hong Kong (1989) among them, but most have been banal and bullying.

If the building lacks anything, it is an innovation such as the sky gardens that Foster and Partners has created in the shaft of Commerzbank in Frankfurt, the tallest building in Europe. These occur at regular intervals, allowing sunlight and greenery into the tower. Commerzbank, however, is a corporate venture that was willing to sacrifice chunks of office space and invest heavily in financially unprofitable gardens; 7 South Dearborn, by contrast, has been built like most US skyscrapers by developers - in this case, European American Realty Ltd - in pursuit of a maximum return on capital invested.

There's one other thing missing from 7 South Dearborn: the wind-sway that keeps the cats so happy in Lynn Osmond's 45th-floor Chicago apartment. According to Baker, the concrete shaft should be far more stable than its skeletal steel predecessors. Miaow.

webTitle: From West Bank to West End

fields.headline: From West Bank to West End
fields.standfirst: Katharine Viner meets the Palestinian impresario shaking up images of Middle Eastern women
fields.trailText: Katharine Viner meets the Palestinian impresario shaking up images of Middle Eastern women
fields.body:
For those whose image of women in the Middle East is of chador-cloaked mutes walking behind their husbands, Raeda Ghazaleh might be something of a shock. At 27, she is spearheading a small theatrical revolution among Palestinians in the West Bank. Stephen Daldry, associate director of London's Royal Court, describes her as "a potent force for developing Palestinian playwrights, exceptional as a woman in her cultural context". Elyse Dodgson, head of the theatre's international department, says she has "conviction, determination, vision, respect". And the theatre she founded near Bethlehem is called "Inad", which means "stubborn".

It takes a lot to intimidate Raeda Ghazaleh. She was the first Palestinian to complete a degree at Israel's School of Visual Theatre. Did she find it difficult? "It wasn't easy for them to accept me," she says. "I was young, I was Palestinian, I didn't speak Hebrew. So I learned Hebrew."

She went to the college at the height of the intifada, when young Palestinians erupted in a sustained stone-throwing uprising against the Israeli occupation. Many were killed. Did she feel safe? "Nothing is safe and dying is easy in Palestine," she says. "But you get used to it."

She was chosen out of nowhere by the highflying Stephen Daldry to assist on his production of Rat in the Skull, a play about Ireland. Was she overawed? Well, on the Monday before the opening night, she told him she thought his ending was wrong. And he changed it.

She hasn't even been intimidated by the virtual absence of a theatrical tradition among Palestinian writers. "The war in Palestine took so much energy that it only left room for solitary writing, novels and poems," Ghazaleh says, "not for the group-work of theatre." So she made a wish-list of her favourite novelists or poets and went to see them all. "Imagine some guy writing alone in Hebron; he doesn't expect a young girl to come and persuade him to write for the stage. It's a shock for him," she laughs. Eventually she got together a group of eight writers, culminating in a week of readings at east Jerusalem's legendary Al-Kasaba theatre and, this week, two readings at the Royal Court.

Ghazaleh came to the attention of the Royal Court as part of its vibrant international programme - the very programme that produced David Hare's Via Dolorosa - when Daldry and Dodgson founded a Palestinian playwriting project. "We felt that, led by Raeda, this would be something new and different," Dodgson says.

And indeed it has been. For a start, neither of the plays being read this week is about politics. "People think Palestinians must want to write about politics all the time," Ghazaleh says. "But artists can see society in different ways. Our outer life is clear: we have the enemy and we know the situation. But now in Palestine we have to look to building our inner life; how we build inside ourselves. Our political situation is a part of who we are, but it is not the whole of us."

Ghazaleh grew up close to the theatre - her aunt was an actress - but her drive comes from her father. "He had to work as head of a hotel laundry, so he could not study. He always pushed his children, boys and girls the same, to have the education he so wanted for himself."

Her father also gave her the building for the Inad theatre company. How did she come up with the name? "It was the middle of the intifada and everything was hard, and we were feeling that nothing good was going to happen again. So we said, yes, let's call it Inad, to show that we are stubborn enough to continue."

She believes the intifada was a hopeful time because the Palestinians were fighting back. "Most of the time people now are very down," she says. "You don't see the hope in the eyes that you saw in the intifada. Everything since the beginning of the peace process has gone downhill. This peace process is just a joke." Hers is a young and widely-held belief rarely heard in the west.

But in that gloom there is, she says, a kind of salvation, a national maturity, in developing a homegrown theatrical tradition. "Art, but especially theatre, is a place to be free and open, to say things you can't say on the street or in the family. Society needs it when it tries to build itself. It is about freedom."

 International Playwrights is at the Royal Court until June 17. Tel 020-7565 5000 for details.

"Most of the time people now are very down," she says. "You don't see the hope in the eyes that you saw in the intifada. Everything since the beginning of the peace process has gone downhill. This peace process is just a joke." Hers is a young and widely-held belief rarely heard in the west. But in that gloom there is, she says, a kind of salvation, a national maturity, in developing a homegrown theatrical tradition. "Art, but especially theatre, is a place to be free and open, to say things you can't say on the street or in the family. Society needs it when it tries to build itself. It is about freedom."  International Playwrights is at the Royal Court until June 17. Tel 020-7565 5000 for details.

fields.headline: Married with kids
fields.standfirst: Young, free and single is fine these days. But what if you're a young woman who (whisper it) wants to settle down?  Emma Warren  reports
fields.trailText: Young, free and single is fine these days. But what if you're a young woman who (whisper it) wants to settle down?  Emma Warren  reports
fields.body:
Hearts And Bones, the BBC's funny-for-all-the-wrong-reasons rehash of This Life, unintentionally hit the spot last week. Amanda, the hard-living single girl with a plenitude of super-sharp put-downs at her disposal, was swapping complaints with the worry-faced Dervla Kirwan. Boringly-married Dervla thought single girl Amanda had a full-steam-ahead life of exciting men and all-night drinking, while her own domestic life at home with her husband and child was, well, the pits.

While the machinations of sub-standard TV dramas are best left to those Saturday nights in when you can't be bothered to find something less boring instead, it hit on a timely conundrum. It's a verifiable fact that many women are deferring the joy and pain of long-term relationships, marriage and children. The average age of first marriage and child continues to rise, to 27 and 29 respectively. But forgotten behind the Top Shop-draped figure of perma-girl emanating from every orifice of film, TV and mag-land are the women in their mid-20s who are electing to live their lives with - shock! - husbands and - horror! - children.

Jo Adams, of London research agency Flamingo, has conducted extensive studies into women's attitudes and is quick to debunk the myth. "A lot of women want to be a girl in their spare time, but the idea of a 30-year-old Eternal Girl wearing mini skirts and stilettos, drinking Lambrini and being empowered by that, is just not true," she avers. "People want to live that myth from time to time, but a lot of women are settling down, having babies and working quite hard."

Louise Sherwin, sales manager for a publishing company, who married at the relatively young age of 24, pulled her best puzzled face when asked about her choice. "Er, let me get this straight," she said. "You want to interview me about being normal?" She's got a point: the idea that empowerment would be found away from the confines of marriage got mangled to mean that the converse could provide neither equality nor independence.

"We're almost not meant to be doing this, having kids and getting married," says 26-year-old Kate Licence, a teacher and mother of four-month-old Jennie. "I'm the youngest mum I know and I almost feel that single friends look down on me for being at home." While we can ignore teeny marriages between plastic movie people in LA (stand up, Ryan Phillipe and Reese Witherspoon), everyone thought it was rather weird that a nice middle-class girl like Kate Winslet would get pregnant and married at only 24 (though note the non-response to pop star Richard Ashcroft's recent marriage and new baby).

Simone Baird, a 24-year-old Edinburgh-based journalist, who is getting married in the summer, agrees. "A lot of people were really shocked. I almost felt like I was letting my friends and family down by getting married young." The message has been coming across loud and clear: choose life, choose a TV, but don't choose marriage or kids. "There's a lot of pressure," Licence says. "Women of our generation have got to have gone to college, had a career, been around the world, had loads of relationships and then, only then, you're allowed to have a child."

I had a child when I was 25. Not old, not young. Judging by some people's reactions, you'd think I was barely out of my teens. The way men and women born in the 70s and 80s arrange our long-term living is clearly shifting and marriage is becoming one option among many. Illegitimacy is a non-issue: when was the last time you heard the word bastard used in its original context?

But while the choices are relatively new, there is bound to be confusion. And for the moment, that means marriage and kids among (mostly middle-class) twentysomethings is becoming almost unusual. "I think because of our parents' experience, women have thought we were going to be chained to the kitchen sink if we married," Baird says. "I've just realised that you can be independent and not compromised by being married or having a child. The girl out drinking all night with her lad friends is a myth and the idea that when you get married or have kids you're never going to see daylight again is a myth, too. They're fantasies, not people's lives. It's pick and mix, and choosing marriage doesn't mean choosing one lifestyle."

People choose to solve the love equation early for good reasons. It gave me structure and order - something a bit lacking before. Like Baird, who says she was "literally terrified of settling down and compromising myself", I felt that independence was just a physical state.

"I've now got a massive chunk of my life sorted," Licence admits, "and I can get on with a career without worrying about it. I just didn't want to put off the inevitable. This way, I can have a child, recover, and continue my career after."

She points to the recent coverage of Germaine Greer, who has expressed regrets about her childlessness. "Even people who've had it all wish they'd done it," she says. Adams reiterates the pull of what Julie Burchill calls the "Judas womb". "I hadn't expected to hear this, but the biological aspect is very powerful and it's particularly powerful in women of 28 or 29."

Of course it's not black and white. You don't choose between perma-girl and Top Shop or settling down and Dorothy Perkins. Says Adams: "Every woman has a part of them that's an eternal girl, with the exception of women who have had it knocked out of them by life experience. People are happy dipping in to it, but it's a choice not a character facet."

So back to Hearts And Bones. What of freedom-loving single girl Amanda? She hasn't had a boyfriend for two years and is so bored with going home alone that she considers going back to the office to do some paperwork. Lucky she doesn't exist, then.

webTitle: The first casualty of war movies

fields.headline: The first casualty of war movies
fields.standfirst: John Sutherland  on Hollywood history
fields.trailText: John Sutherland on Hollywood history
fields.body:
In October 1945 the Errol Flynn-starring film Objective Burma opened in London. It was of a piece with the movies that Flynn (Hollywood's most famous Robin Hood) had been making since 1939 - fantasies of daring war heroism.

In fact Flynn, a closet fascist, had spent the war years fending off statutory rape suits (he liked "jailbait" - young girls) and perfecting his ground shots (he was a good tennis player).

Objective Burma was shot in Palm Springs, where the pampered star complained bitterly that his trailer dressing room was less well air-conditioned than Bette Davis's.

The plot of Objective Burma is simple. A small band of American paratroops is dropped behind enemy lines in the jungle. Their mission? To destroy a Japanese radar station. They must succeed or the Allied invasion of Burma will fail.

In fact, no paratroops were ever dropped in Burma - least of all American. The campaign was won by the foot-slogging efforts of the British 14th (or "forgotten") Army.

The reaction in Britain to Objective Burma was furious. Questions were asked in the House. There were demonstrations outside cinemas. The film was withdrawn after a few days. Flynn himself was subjected to violent verbal and, occasionally, physical abuse. His name was still a proverbial term of contempt ("Errol Flynning it") in the British Army 15 years later, when I was a national serviceman. Perhaps it still is.

U-571 opened in US theatres on April 21 and has topped the box-office charts ever since. Its release coincided with the 25th anniversary of the fall of Saigon: an occasion for much American soul-searching and mournful militarism.

U-571 carries the motto "Heroes are ordinary people who do extraordinary things in extraordinary times". The film reminds Americans that they once fought a clean war. Also, perhaps, it distracts them from the fact that the unheroic Clinton, Gore and George W Bush did extraordinary things to avoid combat in Vietnam ("War? Ordinary people can do it for us").

The plot, devised by director Jonathan Mostow, echoes Objective Burma. A small band of American submariners is sent into enemy waters to capture an Enigma encryption device ("All this for a goddamn typewriter!" as one character exclaims). If they fail, the war will be lost.

The mission is achieved with much Errol Flynning - some of it preposterous, even to a landlubber's eyes. The half-dozen Americans stranded on U-571 instantly master the controls. They blow another German sub and a destroyer out of the water. Depth charge to left of them, depth charge to right of them, volley and thunder. They survive unscathed.

The film has yet to hit the British screen but there have already been complaints. The first capture of an Enigma at sea was the result of dogged work by HMS Aubretia and HMS Bulldog, who contrived to disable U-110 in May 1941 (six months before America entered the war). Kapitan Lemp ordered his men to abandon ship, then drowned attempting to get back to his vessel when he saw it was not sinking (it's been suspected that the Royal Navy killed Lemp). Lieutenant David Balme, Webley pistol in hand (he had never fired it in anger), ventured nervously into the U-boat and found "the greatest prize of the war", an Enigma machine complete with codebooks. There were no heroics. Just quiet courage.

There were two other captures of U-boats and their Enigmas, the last in 1944 by the US Navy. Both were bloodier affairs. But it is clear from the date of U-571's action ("spring 1942") that it is Balme's exploit which is the primary inspiration.

To soothe British sensibilities, the film has an on-screen dedication to "all the Allied sailors who captured Enigma machines". President Clinton has sent a mollifying message to the Yorkshire town of Horsforth, which raised the money to build HMS Aubretia.

Balme (now a lieutenant commander, retired) was taken on by Mostow as a "technical adviser". His name appears six minutes into the final credits, at some point after "hairdresser to Mr McConaughey". Since the star has a buzz cut throughout the film, neither the barber's nor Lt-Cdr Balme's expertise would seem to have been much drawn on.

U-571 is a good male-action film - as good as The Hunt for Red October, considerably less good than Das Boot. Do its historical distortions matter? Is this another indelible stain on the Cenotaph? Aw, c'mon - it's only a movie!
