fields.headline: Down town
fields.standfirst: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: The age of dissent
fields.body:
Rosemary thought she had found a new home just round the corner last week. We went to have a second look at it yesterday. The young couple upstairs clumped about above us, thundered down the stairs and slammed the door. Rosemary changed her mind. A quarter of a million pounds to live in an egg-box surrounded by noise nuisance. And to reach this poke-hole she'd have to pass her lovely old house twice a day on her way to the station.

Prices around here grow sillier by the week. At the end of Olivia's street there's a church. At least it used to be a church, then it was deconstructed and became a Hindu temple. Then speculators snapped it up, dumped all the statues, relics and holy items on the pavement, and put a large padlock on the door. The poor worshippers wept. They would have left if they'd been asked, but nobody asked them.

The neighbourhood was outraged. The Hindus had fitted in rather well. Now developers planned to convert the church into 20 luxury flats and penthouses. Two parking spaces would be available. Olivia and others checked dimensions, encroachment, light regulations and corruption, didn't like what they found and objected fiercely. "It will bring a better class of people to the area," said the Agent, annoying them even more.

This was Junction Road, a grunty, congested area blighted by poverty, crime, drug addiction and the Archway Tower, an ugly great stump where social security claimants wait in grim conditions, light years away from the possibility of a luxury flat or penthouse costing half a million. Locals were desperate for some dynamic community facilities to perk up their lives.

Planning permission was granted. Our council doesn't seem to have light regulations any more. At the planning meeting, Olivia met a worrying bunch of heavies and several people pretending to be local residents who admired the development. One raving enthusiast stood up and praised the Agent to the skies. "He's a genius! You're lucky to have him!"

"And where do you come from?" asked Olivia.

"Monte Carlo, Madam!" Olivia asked what interest he had in this area and discovered that he owned much of Junction Road. No wonder he can afford to live in Monte Carlo. Rosemary, however, will have to stick to lower Holloway.

fields.headline: Stone age survivor
fields.standfirst: Bill Wyman supports capital punishment, would like to have been a librarian and prefers talking about camera exhibitions to great gigs. Can this be the man who spent 31 years in the world's greatest rock'n'roll band?
fields.trailText: Bill Wyman supports capital punishment, would like to have been a librarian and prefers talking about camera exhibitions to great gigs. Can this be the man who spent 31 years in the world's greatest rock'n'roll band?
fields.body:
Bill Wyman, former bass player with the Rolling Stones, is a man with few affectations. (Very few expressions, too, but that's another matter.) He doesn't wear jewellery or fancy suits. "They told me to dress up for this. Well, I didn't." There's raggedy salt-and-pepper stubble above his upper lip.

And there are marks on his trouser legs where they've been turned down. He's 63, but he says he doesn't care about growing old. "It doesn't bother me, it doesn't bother me at all." So why does he dye his hair? "Of course I do," he says abruptly. But why? "I don't know, it just looks better." Wouldn't it look nicer if he left it to match his eyebrows? "No, no," he says, looking quite interested, for him. "My greyness is in patches. Mainly round the back." He ducks his head to demonstrate, waves his fag over the top. "And then there are other bits that aren't and it's sort of blotchy, that's the trouble. I'd end up like a dalmatian dog."

Wyman is a facts-and-figures man. Accuracy, that's what he likes. Dates. All his stuff is alphabeticised at home. And it drives him mad when people come up to him in the street and say, "'I remember you guys. I used to come and watch you at Eel Pie Island in 1961.' I say, 'No, you didn't. We didn't play until '62.'"

When I tell him that in my straw poll, more people associated him with Mandy Smith, his former teenage lover, than the Stones, he says: "That's because it happened in the 80s, it's in their minds. If you'd have asked people in 1969 they'd have said the Stones." But he hadn't dated a 13-year-old then. "Short-term memory," he interrupts grimly. "They do not believe you when you tell them."

If Wyman is a rock'n'roll animal, he's Eeyore, head down, disgruntled, never quite mucking in with Tigger and the rest. If Jagger was all mouth, and Richards all trousers, Wyman was all nose. He's the band's archivist. He's got 30 suitcases full of material in the attics of his house in Chelsea. ("Not suitcases. Trunks.") He was with the band for 31 years, from his audition in '62 (after his national service) to his departure in '93, but he was always, he says, "the odd one out". Jagger and Richards "didn't leave much room for anybody else to contribute. That was the frustration."

Rhythm Kings, his new 12-piece jazz and blues outfit, has a lineup including Georgie Fame and Peter Frampton. Wyman, who remains polite about the other Stones, whom he still sees from time to time, says of the new band: "There's never any arguments. No one being a prima donna or bossing it or showing off, or trying to take over." If he has one regret in life, it's that he didn't leave the Stones earlier. "But I had to stay for the money."

Was he an outsider because he didn't take drugs? "No, it was that I had other interests. Music was never my be-all and end-all, as it was for, say, Keith." He's been smoking, but he finishes his cigarette now, stubbing it out with a double twist. "When we were in Mexico City, for instance, and they were all hanging round the hotel, I was at the Museum of Mankind for the whole day, examining the stuff. No one else would come." "I see," I say. But he hasn't finished. "And when we were in New York, they had a big exhibition of old cameras from the 1800s, so I'd go there." Right. "And then when we were in New Zealand I went to the hot springs and all that." He pauses. It looks like he might have finished converting those infamous world tours into sightseeing achievements, but no. "And then when we were in Athens I went to all the old buildings, the old statues and temples and things. Same in Japan. And the others would be down the nightclubs."

Not that he missed out on the clubs altogether. There was a two-year period in the 60s when he logged the 278 women he slept with. "No. Well, yeah, one or two. Yeah." He laughs. "Huh, huh, huh."

You'd never know from talking to Wyman that he spent 31 years in the greatest rock'n'roll band in the world. Some of the time you just feel you're chatting to an old geezer on the bus. He votes Tory, will next time, too.

"Yeah, because I remember what Labour's all about. I remember having to leave the country in '71 because tax was at 90%. Never trust 'em. I vote Tory because that's where I come from." When asked what else he might have been, he says, "You know what Einstein said? A plumber. Maybe that, or a photographer or a librarian. Yeah, I'd like to have been a librarian." He believes in capital punishment. His favourite meal is lamb chops and mashed potato.

He talks a lot about money, and not having enough. "I'm not super-comfortable," he says, which seems rich coming from someone who owns a house in Chelsea, a villa in France and a moated manor in Suffolk. Perhaps the moat needs a lot of upkeep? "We've got live fish in there," he says proudly. "And wildfowl, ducks, geese. Of course we do."

Odd that the working-class boy from Sydenham still seems to have something to prove. Si Si, Je Suis un Rock Star, his solo single from the early 80s, he says, "was the most successful solo by any member of the Stones". Playing in a charity cricket match at the Oval, he was the third person ever to take a hat-trick there. He's not a grandfather yet. "The only Stone who isn't," he says with a chip of something.

But, of course (to use his favourite word: "Is it? Course it is." Big grin), he's not an old geezer at all. He's the father of three girls, "and to them I'm just Dad". He married his third wife, Suzanne Accosta, an actress and fashion designer, in 1993: "She gave up her career. I gave up my bad habits." He knows the names of the Teletubbies. He gives tips on communicating long-distance to toddlers: "I go, 'Di di di di, da da da' and she sings it back. You should try it."

You could also almost call him a new man these days, though he looks baffled when this is suggested. "New man? You mean like the shop? Do you know their sign? If you look at it upside down it still says New Man. It does. You should look."

His eldest daughter, Katie, is five. Mandy Smith was 13 when he met her. They dated for two years before the press got hold of it, split up, and married, briefly, when she was 18. I wondered what Wyman would think if Katie was to date a 57-year-old in eight years' time? "Won't happen," he says, "because my Katie won't start going to pubs and clubs and night habitats when she's 10 so when she's 14 she won't look like a 20-year-old. That's the difference."

Wyman is adept at moving swiftly on. "I want them to be as normal as possible. I never encouraged my son to be a drummer or guitarist. I let him do what he wanted. And he did really well. He got 10 O levels, two A levels, maths and chemistry. And a degree, with honours, in business studies. So he turned out his own person." Maths? I say, impressed. "Yeah, well, I'm good at maths, too," he says quickly.

Maybe that's the thing about Wyman - that whatever Stone was thrown at him, he was always his own person. These days, he says, he's happier than he's ever been. With the new band, with a project about the blues for TV, with the second volume of his autobiography, with his kids. Therapy helped. Is he still in it? "No. I only did it for six or seven visits. Just chatted to her for an hour each time. Felt a lot better afterwards. She said, 'Losses are quite big with you.' And I've had a lot. A lot when I wasn't there to deal with them, mourn, or what do you call it. Everyone dies, or things come to an end, when I'm not there. My grandma died when I was in the military. My dad died when I was on tour in Japan. My marriage to her ended when I was away." When he says "her" he points at me, presumably because I was the last person to mention Mandy Smith.

What about his mum? Is she still alive? "Oh yeah, she's full of bounce. A jolly old thing. She's as wide as she is tall. We're a pretty healthy family. My mum lost one tooth on an apple a few years ago and she's had one filling here" - he opens his mouth to indicate the spot - "and all the rest are her own teeth, and she's 83."

And what about him? "I've never been in hospital for anything except an appendix. Never had a major illness. No exercise. No dietary things, no vitaminy things. No special facial creams and all that garbage. I do all the wrong things and here I am."

We both look at him. I nod towards the turndown in his trousers. "Have you grown?" I ask. He replies, "Nah, that's the way they do them. Oh well, actually, no. What happened was I had these done by Boateng. I had about eight pairs done and I must have been wearing slippers, because when I got them back they were all, like, an inch too short. It was all right turning them down, but two pairs were corduroy and it shows, you see." We both study them again closely.

"Nah," he says, "I haven't grown."

fields.headline: Snake charmers
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Waxham, Norfolk
fields.body:
Waxham, Norfolk

It is one of my favourite wildlife spots each spring: a hedgeless field margin where the "thoughtless" farmer has dumped a great heap of unwanted corrugated iron. Probably the dismembered carcass of some unused shed, the metal is old and rusty and slowly decaying back into the earth. But pull these discarded sheets back and you lift the lid on a dark, secret world.

The undersurface of the metal is covered in clusters of large snails that have an almost luscious appearance like a bunch of crunchy, bronze-coloured grapes. The molluscs have taken advantage of the waste metal's warmer, dry micro-climate and gathered to hibernate. Since most of the light has been blotted out, the ground beneath is bare earth (except for the odd sickly yellow stem of a struggling weed) and perfect habitat for ants. The thin metal is good insulation in winter and quickly warms up with the first sunshine so that these essentially urban insects are soon reconstructing their summer colonies.

However, pride of place in the heap of metal goes to the adders that have chosen one south-facing sheet as the site for their hibernaculum. More than 20 snakes have been counted at the spot and it is virtually impossible to visit without finding at least one of them on location. My most recent visit produced a golden-coloured male with a bold, black zigzag down his spine, luxuriating in the warmth of his rusty home.

It is extraordinary how often wildlife takes advantage of human negligence, waste and industrial dereliction. Railway sidings and embankments, those great scars of the Victorian age, are now some of the best places left in the countryside to find flowers, while rubbish dumps and sewage farms are often equally good for birds.

It always strikes me as odd that some conservation organisations are obsessed with cleaning up the British countryside and complain when farmers leave buildings to go derelict or discard unwanted agricultural equipment. We should beware too much tidiness, lest we throw out some precious babies with all the dirty bathwater.

webTitle: Traffic goes or we do, villagers warn

fields.headline: Traffic goes or we do, villagers warn
fields.trailText: A fabled Italian village which has defied conquests, poverty, natural disasters and gravity, is in danger of being driven into oblivion by a new threat - traffic.
fields.body:
A fabled Italian village which has defied conquests, poverty, natural disasters and gravity, is in danger of being driven into oblivion by a new threat - traffic.

Within months Sassi di Matera, which clings to the side of a gorge gouged out by a torrent, could be uninhabited for the first time since the neolithic era. Locals, who set up emergency roadblocks for the day yesterday, have threatened to abandon the village's medieval streets and its 120 tiny cave churches unless something is done about the tourist cars and the lorries which are choking it to death.

"We are sick of living in an uninhabitable postcard," said Gianni Macina, vice-president of the village committee.

As a last resort the residents are threatening to block the Giro d'Italia cycle race, which started from Rome on Saturday and is heading for their mountain in Basilicata, between the toe and heel of Italy.

Only a cable-car and a traffic ban could save Sassi di Matera, Mr Macina says. Shopkeepers and residents echo his call. They say an increasing stream of traffic is shaking foundations, spewing dust and polluting the village. At 401m above sea level, the roar vibrates and echoes.

"We can't do it anymore," he said. "At night we don't sleep. In daytime we must collect all the rubbish ourselves because the street sweepers clean only the main street."

Residents are bitter after being encouraged by the state to keep alive the village, immortalised in Carlo Levi's novel Christ Stopped at Eboli as a symbol of southern communities' struggle to survive.

Recognised by the UN as a world heritage site, Sassi di Matera is a treasury of medieval frescoes and monuments, including a 12th-century cathedral and a 15th-century castle. Its tiny houses, packed together into steep, narrow streets and small squares, were hewn from the soft rock of the valley.

The village has a reputation for tenacity. It was devastated by the Franks, the Saracens, the Normans and various warlords before being subsumed into the Kingdom of Sicily, and then Italy.

fields.headline: Uefa
fields.body:
Age: 42.

Description: The European football competition where the winners are the losers.

Come again? The Uefa cup has traditionally been for teams that haven't won anything else.

So it's not the European Cup? No. The European Cup doesn't really exist any more, after evolving into the Champions League in 1992. It's the one that Manchester United won last year, and is by far the most prestigious.

Right, let's take this logically. The Champions League must be only for champions? Absolutely, only teams that won their domestic league. Oh, and those that came second. And sometimes third. Even fourth. In fact, this year's finalists, Valencia and Real Madrid, both failed to win the Spanish league.

OK. So who's the Uefa cup for? Arsenal are hoping to get their hands on it when they play Turkish team Galatasaray in Copenhagen in the final on Wednesday.

No, I meant who can enter? After merging last year with the Cup Winners' Cup, which had become hopelessly devalued, it's now, well, for winners and losers.

You've lost me again. The League Cup and FA Cup winners, and - in England - the fourth placed side in the league enter in the first round. And some teams who get knocked out of the early stages of the Champions League get another go by transferring across to the Uefa Cup. They are the winners who lose but get another chance of winning.

Blimey, Brian, I'm bamboozled, over me 'ead, son. Wossit all about then? It's all about money. Lots of teams get to play lots of matches and make lots of money from tickets and TV rights. Cynics say it's a conspiracy to introduce a European league for elite teams by stealth. Though the losers will still probably find something to play for. And the winners will find a way to sneak them in the back door.

Do say: It could be worse, we might have won the Autoglass Trophy.

Don't say: Champions of Europe. Kind of.

webTitle: Ghetto blaster: Shelter chief warns of housing divide

fields.headline: Ghetto blaster: Shelter chief warns of housing divide
fields.trailText: The housing charity Shelter warns today of the risk of new rich and poor ghettoes unless the government invests in affordable new homes to help the 700,000 households suffering from bad housing or homelessness in England.
fields.body:
The housing charity Shelter warns today of the risk of new rich and poor ghettoes unless the government invests in affordable new homes to help the 700,000 households suffering from bad housing or homelessness in England.

Shelter said that government spending on affordable housing is less than half what is necessary to cope with the housing misery facing hundreds of thousands of families and that an extra 85,000 households each year would be affected unless ministers agreed to higher investment.

The charity says that it has looked at various ways of increasing the number of affordable homes over the coming decade, but that even after generating extra revenue there was still a shortfall of £1.4bn that could only be met by public subsidy.

Chris Holmes, director of Shelter, said: "We are seeing thousands of people forced to endure inadequate housing conditions. A spiralling housing crisis can only be averted if the government resolves to invest in new affordable homes.

"The government has already set out policies which we believe can address many of the housing problems but these will only work if underpinned by building new affordable homes.

"Failing to do so will lead to growing polarisation between communities and ultimately create subsequent ghettoes of rich and poor for future generations," he added.

fields.headline: Wickes fights back
fields.trailText: DIY warehouse chain Wickes offered shareholders a £74m sweetener yesterday to reject the hostile bid from rival Focus Do It All. The payout is the equivalent of £1 a share and, said Wickes, would force the predator "to put up or shut up".
fields.body:
DIY warehouse chain Wickes offered shareholders a £74m sweetener yesterday to reject the hostile bid from rival Focus Do It All. The payout is the equivalent of £1 a share and, said Wickes, would force the predator "to put up or shut up".

Management fighting off the £285m offer tempted shareholders with a forecast of pre-interest and pre-tax profit for 2000 up to £28.5m - an increase of 33% on 1999.

Chief executive Bill Grimsey said the information in the latest circular to shareholders laid to rest the "sniping" by FDIA and shifted the argument back to the issue of value for shareholders. He said the company had £41m in the bank which would cover some of the shareholders' pay-out. He claimed the company was planning to hand cash back to shareholders but admitted: "the amount is a bit higher than we would have offered".

FDIA Finance, a subsidiary of Focus Do It All, made a cash bid for Wickes on March 30. It has claimed that Wickes's market position is under threat from Kingfisher's B&Q and Sainsbury's Homebase.

Mr Grimsey said yesterday: "FDIA is looking to short-change our shareholders with its ludicrously low bid. Clearly we can more than match the value of FDIA's offer".

Wickes said that like for like sales rose 8.6% in the five weeks to May 6 compared with the same period in 1999.

webTitle: Mining and metals co-op goes online

fields.headline: Mining and metals co-op goes online
fields.trailText: A $200bn (£132bn) online supply purchasing "co-op" launched yesterday involving 14 of the world's leading minerals and mining companies is expected to be floated by the middle of 2002. Top names involved in the so-called procurement platform include resources corporations Rio Tinto and Anglo American and the gemstone group De Beers.
fields.body:
A $200bn (£132bn) online supply purchasing "co-op" launched yesterday involving 14 of the world's leading minerals and mining companies is expected to be floated by the middle of 2002. Top names involved in the so-called procurement platform include resources corporations Rio Tinto and Anglo American and the gemstone group De Beers.

All the firms stressed that the internet venture - which allows groups to chose from a global range of mining equipment suppliers - is not an attempt to use their purchasing muscle to drive down prices.

Such a move would immediately fall foul of competition rules in Europe and the US.

The founders of the mining exchange represent more than 60% of the market capitalisation of the world's mining and metals industries, and include the largest producers of aluminium, copper, gold, platinum and iron ore.

The companies claim the website will mean greater pricing transparency among suppliers and bring speed and efficiency benefits.

But it is likely that an important motive is the slashing of the companies' $200bn annual supply bill. The partners aim to create a pool of suppliers allowing, for instance, a Chilean mining group to check local prices against those available internationally.

All 14 companies emphasised that the website will also open up the big mining houses to suppliers who may have felt excluded. The mining exchange follows similar succesful ventures in the aviation and oil and gas sectors.

Other big players backing the project include Australian mining group Broken Hill Proprietary, aluminium group Alcan and gold miner Barrick.

"This initiative will enhance the speed, efficiency and cost competitiveness in the mining and metals supply chain," said Leigh Clifford, Rio Tinto's chief executive.

The consortium said the exchange was not a first step in creating an internet-based market. But it is thought bankers are backing the venture with about £60m, and that the exchange will be floated in about two years.

This is the second shake-up in the industry in a week. On Wednesday the London Metal Exchange, centre of world metal dealing, announced plans to end its mutual status and become a limited company.
fields.bodyText: A $200bn (£132bn) online supply purchasing "co-op" launched yesterday involving 14 of the world's leading minerals and mining companies is expected to be floated by the middle of 2002. Top names involved in the so-called procurement platform include resources corporations Rio Tinto and Anglo American and the gemstone group De Beers. All the firms stressed that the internet venture - which allows groups to chose from a global range of mining equipment suppliers - is not an attempt to use their purchasing muscle to drive down prices. Such a move would immediately fall foul of competition rules in Europe and the US. The founders of the mining exchange represent more than 60% of the market capitalisation of the world's mining and metals industries, and include the largest producers of aluminium, copper, gold, platinum and iron ore. The companies claim the website will mean greater pricing transparency among suppliers and bring speed and efficiency benefits. But it is likely that an important motive is the slashing of the companies' $200bn annual supply bill. The partners aim to create a pool of suppliers allowing, for instance, a Chilean mining group to check local prices against those available internationally. All 14 companies emphasised that the website will also open up the big mining houses to suppliers who may have felt excluded. The mining exchange follows similar succesful ventures in the aviation and oil and gas sectors. Other big players backing the project include Australian mining group Broken Hill Proprietary, aluminium group Alcan and gold miner Barrick. "This initiative will enhance the speed, efficiency and cost competitiveness in the mining and metals supply chain," said Leigh Clifford, Rio Tinto's chief executive. fields.headline: On pedestals and plinths
fields.trailText: We wish the Queen Mother well as a centenarian (No snub to Queen Mother says BBC, May 13), but deplore the current establishment and media-generated hype about her contribution to public life, especially during the last war. The average London fire-fighter or air raid warden during the blitz did far more than she did, and at far greater personal risk, without having the lavish life-style she enjoys.
fields.body:
We wish the Queen Mother well as a centenarian (No snub to Queen Mother says BBC, May 13), but deplore the current establishment and media-generated hype about her contribution to public life, especially during the last war. The average London fire-fighter or air raid warden during the blitz did far more than she did, and at far greater personal risk, without having the lavish life-style she enjoys.

There is no stopping the drive to put the Queen Mother on a pedestal but we are sure that many more people share our view than the establishment chooses to believe. The commendable decision by BBC TV to downplay the broadcasting of the celebrations supports this assessment.
DH and Y Kedge
Sonning Common, Oxon y.kedge@lineone.net

 There's a plausible but ultimately indefensible argument for filling the plinth (Modern art wins battle of Trafalgar Square, May 13) with a statue to Wallis Simpson, because she (albeit unwittingly) gave us the valiant, dutiful king who supported us through the second world war. Less frivolously, let's honour the Queen Mother who supported him, or indeed the man himself, George VI.
John Race
Abingdon, Oxon

 With reference to the news from Trafalgar Square, will it be a case of "The Artist formerly known as Plinth"?
Alan Paterson
Cambridge

 Mr Hague states: "It is difficult to think of anyone in this country regarded with more warmth and enduring affection than the Queen Mother". Might I start the ball rolling... Ken Livingstone!
Gerry Bond
Reading
gerrybond@zetnet.co.uk

 I am shocked at the BBC's decision not to televise the parade to mark the Queen Mother's 100th birthday. I am now deprived of the pleasure of turning it off!
Brian Fitzgerald
Buckhurst Hill, Essex
BFitzg6306@aol.com

fields.headline: Watch the real birdie - inflation
fields.trailText: Mervyn King is a gent. When answering questions about monetary policy he does so with wit and intelligence. However, even the mildest of men has something that really riles them, and for Mervyn it is the suggestion that the Bank's monetary policy committee is divided into hawks and doves. Mervyn cuts up rough at this point.
fields.body:
Mervyn King is a gent. When answering questions about monetary policy he does so with wit and intelligence. However, even the mildest of men has something that really riles them, and for Mervyn it is the suggestion that the Bank's monetary policy committee is divided into hawks and doves. Mervyn cuts up rough at this point.

The Bank's deputy governor has a point. The MPC is focused on one thing and one thing only - hitting the government's 2.5% inflation target - and as such it is quite wrong to discriminate between hardliners and softies. But while "hawks and doves" has become a lazy shorthand, it is clear that there are serious and healthy disagreements on the MPC about how the economy works.

The nub of the matter is this. Does the increase in average earnings growth and the strength of domestic demand mean that Britain is about to lapse into its bad old ways? Or is the really striking feature of the economy not that inflation is so high but that it is so low?

Pound not the full story
After more than eight years of sustained growth, unemployment is at a 20-year low, yet inflation excluding mortgage interest payments has been below its target for more than a year. Partly, of course, this is due to the overvalued pound, which has made imports cheaper. But it is far from the whole story. As the Bank of England revealed in last week's inflation report, domestically-generated inflation has been steady at around 3% since 1998, so the fears that big City bonuses and rising house prices in London and the south-east would send inflation spiralling out of control seem to be wide of the mark.

It is a similar story in the US. To be sure, the economy is steaming ahead and the tightness of the labour market is allowing workers to push up real wages, but competitive pressures mean that companies - even after the longest period of expansion in America's history - simply cannot make price increases stick. There are cyclical factors pushing inflation up, but there are structural factors dragging it down. Global deflation remains a threat, despite the recovery since the autumn of 1998.

To understand that this is so, you need look no further than the world's second biggest economy, Japan. There, the economy has yet to recover from the collapse of an asset bubble in the late 80s and deflationary pressures are powerful. It is entirely possible that Japan could experience a 1930s-style slump.

For the time being, there seems little prospect of Britain going the same way. With earnings growth at 6%, the Bank is worried about cost-push inflation, but whether these misgivings are justified or not remains to be been. It is unlikely that earnings are really growing at an underlying annual rate of 6%, and official data is unlikely to be picking up real improvements in productivity. It is notoriously difficult to estimate productivity in the service sector.

Price pressures are strong in some sectors of the economy, but they are very weak in others. Inflation goes up when demand exceeds supply, but there is no reason to believe that this is what is currently happening. Business investment has risen sharply as a proportion of GDP in recent years and stands at around 14%, double its level in the 60s and higher even than in the US. Higher investment means extra capacity, which should mean lower not higher prices.

The latest EU survey showed capacity utilisation in the UK running at 82%, below its 15-year average. Investment has been particularly strong in retailing, with stocks running at high levels and shops under pressure to discount to keep sales volumes up. Meanwhile, manufacturing is starting to feel the impact of sterling's strength, making it well-nigh impossible to pass on cost increases to customers.

The MPC knows all this. It knows more about the economy than is probably good for it. But while there is unanimity about the need to hit the inflation target, there is a big debate about the transmission mechanism between activity in the real economy and inflation, and about how much attention should be given to movements in asset prices when setting interest rates.

Pay more attention
A paper co-written by one of the MPC's members, Sushil Wadhwani, brings this debate into view. Asset Prices and Central Bank Policy (Cecchetti, Genberg, Lipsk and Wadhwani, CEPR) argues that if policymakers paid more heed to fluctuations in equity prices or exchange rates when making decisions they would reduce the fluctuations in both inflation and output.

The authors note: "Although asset price misalignments are difficult to measure, this should not be a reason to ignore them. We argue that there are situations where we can claim to spot misalignments and suggest measures to deal with them."

The study falls short of calling for an explicit exchange rate target, but does say that failure to give proper weight to the level of sterling - and misplaced expectation that it is about to fall - has meant interest rates have been systematically pegged too high in recent years.

"Comparisons of these exchange-rate forecasts during the past four years with the subsequent outturns reveal persistent errors in the same direction, which may have led policymakers to set interest rates at too high a level."

Industry would no doubt say three cheers to all that. But it will be interesting to see whether Mr Wadhwani's thinking is incorporated into the Bank's decision-making processes, because there are some on the MPC who are suspicious of this line of argument. The Bank's chief economist, John Vickers, wrote of the dangers last year of trying to hit more than one target, arguing that asset prices were already incorporated in the Bank's decision-making process. Some MPC members believe globalisation, the opening of new markets and the fading of the effects of the oil shocks of the 70s will have a far bigger impact on inflation than do others.

So here's an idea. Let's stop talking about hawks and doves and take a leaf out of Peter Mandelson's book and re-classify the MPC according to whether or not they believe that life has moved on from the dark days of the 70s.

It will be assumed that there is unanimity about the need to achieve low inflation - just as all members of the Labour Party believe in social justice -but those who feel that the battles from the 70s and 80s need to be refought will be called Old Bank, while those who want to move with the times and be tough on inflation and on the causes of inflation will be called New Bank. Now how does that sound to you, Mervyn?

fields.headline: Fleeting stardom for Hatfield
fields.trailText: The former British Aerospace factory at Hatfield in Hertfordshire, once home to 8,000 engineering workers, is being sold off bit by bit. A glance through the perimeter fence on the south of the site reveals small groups of unlikely looking buildings rapidly taking shape.
fields.body:
The former British Aerospace factory at Hatfield in Hertfordshire, once home to 8,000 engineering workers, is being sold off bit by bit. A glance through the perimeter fence on the south of the site reveals small groups of unlikely looking buildings rapidly taking shape.

These wooden mock-ups of wartime cities are the set for Steven Spielberg's follow-up to Saving Private Ryan. The latest Star Wars movie was shot at the nearby Leavesden studios - another former aerospace factory. Is this confirmation of the government's thesis that newer knowledge-based and cultural industries compensate for jobs lost in traditional employment?

In Los Angeles, entertainment-related jobs have soared to an estimated 800,000 in 1999. Employment in aerospace has fallen from 138,200 to 59,800 over the past decade while the number of jobs infilm and television production has grown from 75,800 to 136,000 over the same period.

Entertainment is the dominant employer in the area, but even Hollywood is having to come to terms with effects of globalisation.

We received an email last week from a Hollywood script supervisor. "Freelance work has been very slow all year," she wrote, "probably due to the many productions that shoot out of town - and many crew people I know who have worked the bigger shows, are not working, or are taking low-pay short shows'.

This message has been confirmed many times in our interviews with Los Angeles-based film and television workers: shooting "out of town" is having a real effect on their ability to make a living in the entertainment industry. In Hollywood they call it "runaway" production.

It is happening not because the location cannot be reproduced in the LA area, but because producers know they can cut costs by filming in countries such as Canada, Australia and Mexico.

Film production is labour intensive and labour makes up 85% of its costs. However, marketing and distribution account for two thirds of the total cost of delivering the product to the consumer.

Both production and marketing costs are rising rapidly, so production companies are reducing output and concentrating their efforts on fewer, more bankable, films.

According to industry estimates the number of US films in production at the end of 1998 was 13% lower than at the same time in 1996 and there are 10% fewer in the pre-production phase.

Nevertheless, it is the flight of the remaining production from LA which is gaining most attention. During our research into employment patterns in the US film industry several reasons were put forward for Canada's success in attracting the majority of this work - equivalent to as many as 23,500 full-time entertainment jobs.

It is close to the US, shares a language and can provide experienced technicians who are paid up to 35% less than their US neighbours. Active promotion of the country as a location by government agencies, combined with generous federal and provincial government tax incentives for both domestic and foreign productions, provide another reason.

Reduced union influence and the weakness of the Canadian dollar against the US dollar complete the picture - combining to produce a significant lowering of costs.

Many hope that the LA experience - a declining aerospace industry giving way to a growing entertainment industry - can be reproduced here.

The Department for Culture, Media and Sport recently announced the launch of the Film Council. This is a new unitary body that, it is claimed, will develop further the film industry in the UK.

There are, however, only two sizeable US-backed projects going into production in the UK at the moment: Spielberg at Hatfield and the Harry Potter film at Leavesden. But George Lucas has decided to shoot the next two films in the Star Wars series in Australia, an increasingly popular, cheap and well-equipped destination for large US productions.

Given that the production phase of film-making is so mobile, the lack of tax incentives from the UK government and the strength of sterling may act as a powerful disincentive for producers to come here.

There are good reasons why the UK will not become a major beneficiary of US runaway productions. While the UK can boast a mature industry, capable of providing high quality film workers and a shared language, other countries have greater advantages.

To the south of Los Angeles is Mexico, a country with a young film industry but with the advantage of low cost, non-unionised crew.

Where high quality is required Canada has an industry at the same broad level of development as the UK, but with a number of advantages.

These include its close proximity to the US, a weaker currency - and an aggressively protectionist government which offers a range of incentives that can significantly cut the real cost of making movies.

Ironically, as Spielberg's latest production draws to an end Hatfield will become home to another growing knowledge industry. The University of Hertfordshire plans to build its new business school on the site.

Dr Keith Randle and Nigel Culkin are members of the Film Industry Research Group (FIRG@herts.ac.uk) at the University of Hertfordshire Business School.

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.trailText:
Why are the IMF and the World Bank under attack?

Protesters argue that their policies have made poverty in the developing world worse rather than better. The two are also under fire from the right. A US commission, headed by the monetarist economist Alan Meltzer has recommended that the Fund should pull out of long-term development lending and instead concentrate on fighting financial crises, such as the one that ripped through Asia in 1997; it also says the Bank should stop lending to middle income countries which have access to global financial markets.
fields.body:
Why are the IMF and the World Bank under attack?
Protesters argue that their policies have made poverty in the developing world worse rather than better. The two are also under fire from the right. A US commission, headed by the monetarist economist Alan Meltzer has recommended that the Fund should pull out of long-term development lending and instead concentrate on fighting financial crises, such as the one that ripped through Asia in 1997; it also says the Bank should stop lending to middle income countries which have access to global financial markets.

Is there a case for abolishing them?

Few serious development experts think that the world would be better off without them. The two were set up more than 50 years ago, to make sure there was no repeat of the great slump of the 1930s. Global markets don't always work properly - as the Asian financial crisis showed - even if not everyone agrees with the conditions the Fund imposes in exchange for its lending.

What about the suggestions for reform?
The US Treasury wants the IMF to concentrate on emergency lending, but while Horst Köhler, the Fund's new head agrees it should focus on crisis management, he doesn't favour radical changes to its mandate or closing down the poverty reduction and growth facility, its long-term lending arm. Some people want the PRGF moved to the Bank which has more expertise in development issues.

fields.headline: Call off the hounds
fields.trailText: Your latest report (Cook and Jay backed hunt lobby, May 12) on the machinations surrounding the Committee of Inquiry into Hunting with Dogs can only reinforce long-held doubts about the purpose of this exercise.
fields.body:
Your latest report (Cook and Jay backed hunt lobby, May 12) on the machinations surrounding the Committee of Inquiry into Hunting with Dogs can only reinforce long-held doubts about the purpose of this exercise.

Would it be very unkind to suggest that, after years in the political wilderness, the experience of mixing at last with the (largely pro-hunting) "establishment" has become more important than listening to the views of MPs and, not least, the majority of the electorate?

The many people who voted Labour in 1997, some for the first time, because they believed that the party offered more "animal friendly" policies will not be deceived again, and will not easily forgive a government which promised so much on various aspects of animal welfare and has so far delivered so little.
Diana Wilson
Chairman, Conservative Anti-Hunt Council

fields.headline: Criminal politics
fields.standfirst: Replace rhetoric with a serious debate
fields.trailText: William Hague wants to end the centuries-old rule barring the retrial of defendants who have been acquitted. Is this a continuation of their populist agenda? Of course. This is the third element of their three-card trick - race, tax and now crime.
fields.body:
William Hague wants to end the centuries-old rule barring the retrial of defendants who have been acquitted. His new policy will be unveiled before the Police Federation on Thursday, but the main proposals were revealed at the weekend through leaks and a television interview by the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe.

Is this a continuation of their populist agenda? Of course. This is the third element of their three-card trick - race, tax and now crime. Ms Widdecombe accused the government of failing to respond to public concern over law and order. Yesterday's Sunday Express might have been written by Conservative Central Office: "In a move that will seize the crime initiative from the government, the Conservative leader will promise new Tory laws to put acquitted defendants back in the dock if police find new evidence against them." In a week in which Gallup has shown the Tories ahead of Labour in dealing with law and order, the Conservatives are clearly hellbent on consolidating this rare poll lead. It could not have occurred at a more opportune time for them: recorded crime has begun to rise for the first time for six years.

There is a lot to debate but no indication that the Tories want a serious dialogue. Even ending the "double jeopardy" rule would benefit from a proper airing. It is not Mr Hague who first proposed this move but the Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence. The proposal was referred by ministers to the law commission which, in a consultative paper six months ago, came out in favour of amending the rule in exceptional cases. The benefits of the rule are obvious: protecting defendants from unfair repeated trials; encouraging police and prosecutors to be diligent from the beginning rather than lazily waiting for a later stage; and ensuring some finality to the prosecution process.

But the rule already has its exceptions - retrials are possible where either jury nobbling or witness intimidation has taken place. The commissioners have set out tough criteria before any retrial would be allowed: new evidence which was "substantially stronger" and could not have been obtained before the first trial; only serious offences punishable by at least three years; a strong likelihood of conviction. All retrials would require the permission of the high court plus the right of appeal to the court of appeal. The commission appear to have struck a fair balance, but ministers are right to await their final report. Miscarriages of justice occur not just with wrongful convictions but wrongful acquittals too. But the Tories are being asinine in claiming authorship and even sillier in criticising Labour for delay. What is at stake are fundamental rights.

The biggest threat to civil rights is not the end of double jeopardy, but a nervous Labour government intent on maintaining a macho posture. Labour has produced an intelligent evidence-based crime reduction strategy. It is "tough on the causes" as well as on crime - investing in programmes ranging from pre-school projects to better anti-burglary devices for pensioners and the poor.

Yet ministers are still reluctant to engage the public. They should have prepared them for the rise in crime - a rise anticipated by researchers with the increase in the most criminal age group (males aged 16 to 25) and a burgeoning economy producing more stealable goods. Ministers should resist the macho rhetoric and remember what happened to Michael Howard. No one was more populist yet he ended up so unpopular, even the Tories had to hide him in the last election.

webTitle: Missing pieces in the jigsaw of Aids treatment

fields.headline: Missing pieces in the jigsaw of Aids treatment
fields.trailText: The news that pharmaceutical companies are reducing their costs and helping to ensure that their drugs become more affordable (Boost for Aids fight, May 12) is a good step, but it is only one part of the jigsaw.
fields.body:
The news that pharmaceutical companies are reducing their costs and helping to ensure that their drugs become more affordable (Boost for Aids fight, May 12) is a good step, but it is only one part of the jigsaw.

If these treatments are to be of real benefit there also needs to be access to quality medical and other health care support - and stronger political leadership to deal with the stigma and denial which presents significant barriers to prevention and care efforts.
Derek Bodell
Chief executive, National Aids Trust

 Bringing down the cost of Aids drugs for Africa will not work unless combined with an intensive programme of education and support at community level, informing people of the dangers of HIV/Aids and how to protect themselves, and offering help to children orphaned in the pandemic. In Kenya, where 350 people die every day from Aids-related complications, Plan has found that community involvement to increase understanding of HIV/Aids and how it is spread is helping to reduce the stigma surrounding the disease. It is also empowering communities to care for the orphans HIV/Aids is leaving behind.

Community education is vital if children in countries like Kenya are to face a more optimistic future. Since many Kenyans will be unable to afford even the cheaper drugs, it is also our best weapon in fighting the spread of the disease.
Marie Staunton
Chief executive, Plan International

 While welcoming the decision to cut the cost of HIV treatments to developing countries, this is the first step in a long-term solution. Elementary needs such as access to adequate food, clean water and a well structured and funded health care system must be in place for the full benefits of this price-cut to have any real impact. Even at reduced prices, few developing countries will be able to afford to provide the drugs to everyone who needs them.
Nick Partridge
Chief executive, Terrence Higgins Trust

 Still missing from the equation is access to cheaper basic medicines that can substantially improve the quality of life for those suffering from HIV/Aids and related illnesses. Simple treatments such as antibiotics and painkillers could go a long way in enabling people with Aids to live healthier and more economically active lives if they were available. In sub-Saharan Africa, HIV/Aids is killing development and this could be the most important link to social and economic recovery.

Africa clearly has the greatest need, but all developing countries should have the right to the same opportunities for confronting this epidemic. The people with whom 2,000 VSO volunteers share their skills all over the world see the impacts of this disease on their colleagues and neighbours every day. UNaids and the pharmaceutical industry should extend their good will to looking for sustainable solutions for all Aids sufferers.
Mark Goldring
Chief executive, Voluntary Service Overseas

fields.headline: It's great at the Tate
fields.trailText: I have just visited Tate Modern. How wonderful to have such a place where the whole family can go and experience modern art. It was great seeing families with pushchairs; there was no hassle taking the family from six weeks onwards. Everyone can enjoy the art experience together, without having to worry who is going to baby-sit.
fields.body:
I have just visited Tate Modern. How wonderful to have such a place where the whole family can go and experience modern art. It was great seeing families with pushchairs; there was no hassle taking the family from six weeks onwards. Everyone can enjoy the art experience together, without having to worry who is going to baby-sit.

The only other institution in London that welcomes whole families including babies is the Globe. Try taking the whole family to a child's production like Honk at the National Theatre - babies are banned.

This is the complete art form that the family want to access. Tate Modern has made modern art accessible to everyone. Excellent.
Ann Evans
Mickfield, Suffolk
a.m.evans@btinternet.com

 As organiser of the "witty protests" outside the Tate Modern's celebrity opening bash, I would like to correct your description of us as "disgruntled arts students" (Sushi, champers and snarls, May 12).

We are a group of artists, art college lecturers and academics. Our protest is at the shallow and facile nature of contemporary art fashions, which, far from being cutting-edge, have overlooked key discoveries about perception and creativity, and mislead society by recycling in visual form the flawed assumptions and values of capitalism and commercialism.

Art is not a simplistic entertainment or spectacle for gawpers, nor mystification for the muddled, nor a fashion accessory for celebs and plutocrats. Look out for us at further art events.
David Rodway
Action to Transform Art and Culture

fields.headline: PR takes a bow
fields.standfirst:
Suddenly fair votes look more attractive

Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: For more than a year after its publication, Lord Jenkins's 1998 essay on electoral reform languished. That formidable political artist had produced a plan as readable as it was do-able. But it was not just Tony Blair's vacillation that put it out of sight and out of mind. Proportional representation (PR) had too little bearing, it seemed, on decisions affecting public welfare. Then came devolution.
fields.body:
For more than a year after its publication, Lord Jenkins's 1998 essay on electoral reform languished. That formidable political artist had produced a plan as readable as it was do-able. But it was not just Tony Blair's vacillation that put it out of sight and out of mind. Proportional representation (PR) had too little bearing, it seemed, on decisions affecting public welfare. Then came devolution.

In the past 12 months PR, in fact Lord Jenkins's preferred marriage of territorial representation and top-up lists, has been tried and found flavoursome. People can handle it. In Scotland, Northern Ireland, Wales and London electors have confronted PR's allegedly intractable forms. As a result working administrations have been formed, ministers appointed and - compared with Westminster (not exactly the acme of fair, open and honest governance) - the public business carried on. To judge the various assemblies is to judge the attempt to make representation fairer.

Of course it is early days. But there in Scotland's new parliament last week, standing in for Donald Dewar as first minister, was Liberal Democrat leader Jim Wallace - showing that PR can produce civilised, reasonably effective inter-party administration. Will those words come to be applied to London with its double cohabitation between mayor and assembly and, within the assembly, between political rivals? Paul Murphy, Welsh secretary, said on Friday that because PR had sacrificed "stability" in Cardiff - for which presumably read Taffia hegemony - few would favour it for Westminster.

His was a warning shot as manifesto-writing season approaches - it needs to be read along with Robin Cook's equally vehement conclusion in the other direction. Meanwhile, first-past-the-posters have lost their trump card, the overwhelming results of the 1997 Westminster election. It is time to revisit the Ashdown-Blair rhetoric of the summer of 1997: PR could deliver a Commons that better reflected voters' preferences and delivered progressive, left-liberal government. Paul Whiteley's 1999 survey of Labour activists showed a majority favour reform. Some big unions - flexing their muscles in the run up to the national policy forum taking place in a month or so - are dead against. It is time to hark again to the oracle. Now we have dense experience against which to measure Lord Jenkins's prescriptions.

fields.headline: Heavenly bodies
fields.trailText: As a Guardian reader since 1984, I've come to accept that every so often (ie whenever he has a new book out) your paper gets ever so slightly, shall we say, enthusiastic about Martin Amis. But even with this in mind, the past week has been overdoing it a bit.
fields.body:
As a Guardian reader since 1984, I've come to accept that every so often (ie whenever he has a new book out) your paper gets ever so slightly, shall we say, enthusiastic about Martin Amis. But even with this in mind, the past week has been overdoing it a bit. There are those of us who have no interest whatsoever in Amis, his books, his father, his teeth, his girlfriends, his preferred choice of socks or anything else about him.
David Lee
Gillingham, Kent david.lee11418@freeserve.co.uk

 Just in case anyone should imagine that the "quotations" attributed by Martin Amis to Samuel Beckett (G2, May 9) were in fact written by him, it should be made clear that they were not. (It is to be hoped that the above sentence is not so ugly as to attract Mr Amis's disapproval.)
Terence Killeen
Dublin
TKILLE@irish-times.ie

 I was amused to read in your review of Pluto: The Renewer (May 13) that Gustav Holst had not considered writing a piece in honour of the eponymous planet. I expect this was because, at the time he composed the Planets Suite, Pluto had yet to be discovered: this did not take place until 1930, and Holst was writing during the first world war.
Justin Harwood Moss
Bristol
justin@moss53.freeserve.co.uk

 Congratulations on Sarah Hall's article (Eat, drink and yell your head off, May 13) on the din people are nowadays expected to endure when dining out. I recommend to your readers that whenever booking a table or a hotel room, they ask if muzak is to be inflicted on them as part of the service, and if so, cancel immediately explaining why. It is only if there is a commercial loss involved that this nuisance will diminish.
M Simms
London

webTitle: Ecstasy use could lead to brain risk

fields.headline: Ecstasy use could lead to brain risk
fields.trailText: Ecstasy users could permanently damage the mechanism in their brain responsible for learning and thinking quickly, research revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Ecstasy users could permanently damage the mechanism in their brain responsible for learning and thinking quickly, research revealed yesterday.

Former users who had not taken ecstasy for six months were equally affected.

Michelle Wareing, who led the study, said: "We are talking about a brain mechanism that is involved in learning new tasks. Ecstasy users, therefore, may not pick up things so quickly.

"As soon as there is a bit of pressure, that is when they are going to have problems. So it could affect performance at work, or in exams."

Ms Wareing and colleagues at the centre for studies in the social sciences at Edge Hill College, in Ormskirk, Lancashire, put 30 men and women aged 18 to 25 through two tests.

Most of those with experience of ecstasy had taken the drug once or twice a week.

One test involved speaking aloud a randomly chosen consonant when a bleep was heard. Pressure was applied by increasing the frequency of the bleeps from four to two seconds, and then to one. Both current and previous ecstasy users found the task difficult, performing significantly worse than non-users. For two previous users, the experience was so unpleasant they were not asked to do the test at the one-second rate.

For the other test, participants were asked to compare rows of letters. Half the rows were the same, and in half just one of the letters was different. The volunteers had to classify as many rows as possible as "the same" or "different" in the space of 30 seconds. Again, non-users outperformed the two ecstasy user groups.

In both animals and humans ecstasy has been shown to destroy nerve endings in the brain responsible for producing the important message transmitter chemical serotonin.

fields.headline: Cornish Eden to open early
fields.trailText: Britain's own Garden of Eden, taking shape in a disused clay pit, opens to the public tomorrow - 11 months before it is due to be completed.
fields.body:
Britain's own Garden of Eden, taking shape in a disused clay pit, opens to the public tomorrow - 11 months before it is due to be completed.

Interest in the £74m Eden project (above) near St Austell, Cornwall, has been so great that managers have decided to open early to show the work in progress.

A train will transport visitors around the 34-acre site, which houses what is believed to be the world's biggest greenhouse. The kilometre-long structure features huge biomes covering an area equal to 12 soccer pitches. Its hexagonal steel panels will be covered with triple-glazed foil.

A humid tropics biome, 50m high, will house trees and plants from the Amazon, Africa and Malaysia, including rubber, coconuts and rice. A warm temperate biome will have plants and trees from the Mediterranean climate, including oranges, olives and grape vines.

Outside will be interlocking terraces, featuring plants that have helped to shape man's development, including wheat and sunflowers.

The project is backed by a £37m millennium commission grant.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Japan's former PM dies
Keizo Obuchi, the prime minister who oversaw the biggest public spending binge in Japan's history, died in a Tokyo hospital yesterday. He was 62.
fields.body:
Japan's former PM dies
Keizo Obuchi, the prime minister who oversaw the biggest public spending binge in Japan's history, died in a Tokyo hospital yesterday. He was 62.

Obuchi had been in a coma for six weeks after suffering a stroke believed to have been caused by overwork.

His successor, Yoshiro Mori, led a long list of statesmen praising him.
Jonathan Watts, Tokyo

Nine killed as block collapses
A five-storey residential building collapsed in central Cairo before dawn yesterday, killing at least nine people, officials said.

Rescuers said two survivors had been found, but added that the death toll was expected to rise.

The newspaper Al-Ahram said 25 people left the block on Saturday when cracks appeared in the masonry. The city council had told the landlord to repair the building.
AP, Cairo

Manila police under attack
A rocket-propelled grenade exploded 50 metres from the Philippine police chief's home in Manila yesterday.

The blast came as negotiators seeking the release of 21 hostages flew to Manila to present the captors' demands to President Joseph Estrada.

webTitle: Putin redraws the map of Russia

fields.headline: Putin redraws the map of Russia
fields.standfirst:
Plans to put the Kremlin back in control face resistance in Bashkortostan

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin acted at the weekend to reverse a decade of fragmentation in Russia and reassert the Kremlin's control of its 89 regions and republics.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin acted at the weekend to reverse a decade of fragmentation in Russia and reassert the Kremlin's control of its 89 regions and republics.

In his first substantive policy move, he ordered Russia divided into seven zones under specially appointed administrators, in an attempt to bypass the dozens of provincial governors who run their territories as personal fiefdoms.

The decree opened a Kremlin campaign to claw back power from the regions, heralding an eventual showdown with the elected governors, who have exploited the political vacuum of the past decade to build their empires.

But in the land of Babai (Granddad), as President Murtaza Rakhimov of Bashkortostan is known, the ruling elite is contemptuous of Moscow's ambitions.

Mr Putin's writ does not run in Bashkortostan.

"The Russian has always been imperialist. That's the mentality - imperial, unitarist, and statist, always trying to centralise. Putin is very much in that tradition," says Mansur Ayupov, an aide to Mr Rakhimov and one of the intellectuals behind the surge of Bashkir nationalism in the 1990s.

Since 1993 Mr Rakhimov has ruled Bashkortostan, in the Urals 900 miles west of Moscow, with an iron fist. He controls everything that moves, showering patronage on those he favours.

In the "country" of 4.5m, Mr Rakhimov has a loyal police force of 40,000. There are no independent media. The opposition publishes its newspapers in neighbouring regions and smuggles them in, risking arrest. A Bashkir holding company run by the president's son controls the oil industry in Ufa, the polluted capital, which was the Soviet Union's main oil refining centre.

Mr Rakhimov appoints his own judges and prosecutors, regardless of Russian federal law. He even controls the regional branch of the FSB, the successor to the KGB, which Mr Putin once headed.

"Rakhimov's is a tough authoritarian regime, even totalitarian, like in the Soviet era," says Sergei Fufaev of the Federalism Institute in Moscow.

"Putin says he wants to strengthen the Russian state. Bashkortostan is one of many tests for him."

From Kaliningrad on Russia's western tip to Vladivostok in the far east, Mr Putin faces the same dilemma. Russia's federal dispensation is a mess. Mr Putin says his policy is to establish "a single legal and economic space in Russia". It is estimated that there are more than 20,000 regional legal acts that flout the Russian constitution and federal laws.

The war in Chechnya is the most extreme example of Moscow's inability to tame its unruly provinces, and of its brutal response to separatism. Bashkortostan may be insubordinate, but it cannot separate because it is in the heart of the Russian land mass, unlike Chechnya, on the southern edge.

"We've never said we're independent," says Mr Ayupov. "In no document. That's the difference with Chechnya."

But Bashkortostan has its own constitution, declaring it a "sovereign state within the Russian federation". It has a "bilateral" treaty with Moscow ostensibly regulating relations between them. It reserves the right to make diplomatic deals with other states.

"It's absurd," says Marat Ramazanov, a leader of the big Tatar community in Ufa. "This is not federalism. It's feudalism. Moscow allows Rakhimov to do what he likes and in return he promises to deliver when the Kremlin needs him."

Mr Rakhimov does indeed deliver when it suits him. His powers of patronage in a patriarchal culture enables him to mobilise the popular vote. In the March presidential election, Bashkortostan voted 62% for Mr Putin, well above the national average.

Mr Rakhimov expects to be repaid. But last week Mr Putin ordered Bashkortostan to rewrite its constitution, to make it conform with Russia's basic law. Granddad is playing for time, hoping that Mr Putin will be ground down by office.

Among the constitutional articles Russia objects to is the stipulation that the Bashkir president must speak the Bashkir language, effectively disqualifying four out of five citizens. Bashkortostan is only 20% Bashkir, a Turkic people; ethnic Russians account for 40% and Tatars almost 30%. Ufa is 10% Bashkir.

"This is historically Bashkir land, changed by Russia's colonial policies," Mr Ayupov says.

"It's not our fault that we're now a minority here. This was 60% Bashkir 120 years ago. We face assimilation or disappearance."

Anatoly Dubovsky, an ethnic Russian political leader in Ufa, disagrees. "The Russian constitution has got to be the basis for all of the country. Rakhimov is using the courts, the laws, the language, and citizenship to try to separate from the centre. This process has gone too far. Chechnya is the logical outcome."

Ten years ago Boris Yeltsin told the Bashkirs and the rest of the regions:" Take as much sovereignty as you can swallow." The Bashkirs and the others drank deep from the cup of sovereignty, proffered by Mr Yeltsin in his effort to destroy Mikhail Gorbachev and sink the Soviet Union.

Mr Yeltsin's legacy to Mr Putin is a weak centre ringed by farflung outposts of neo-feudal power and lawlessness. Mr Putin claims he will put Bashkortostan, and everywhere else, to rights.

"Even the liberals here expect steps from Putin," says Igor Rabinovich, an Ufa opposition activist. "But they don't really believe he will be able to change things. It's gone too far in 10 years."

Rival set to win at polls

Vladimir Putin's native city, St Petersburg, was poised to deliver the first electoral setback to the Russian president yesterday by awarding his enemy Vladimir Yakovlev a second term as governor of Russia's second city, writes Ian Traynor.

In the first test of voter opinion since Mr Putin was elected on March 26, Mr Yakovlev was tipped to take up to 60% of the ballot, despite the rampant crime in St Petersburg and Mr Putin's hostility to the incumbent, whom he regards as an unprincipled traitor.

Mr Putin's decree establishing a Kremlin-controlled territorial dispensation across Russia is aimed at curbing the powers enjoyed by regional potentates like Mr Yakovlev. But Mr Putin was forced to back down in the 1996 mayoral contest with Mr Yakovlev.

fields.headline: Censure for MTV over swearing
fields.trailText: A four letter outburst from the Boyzone singer Shane Lynch yesterday led to television chiefs being censured.
fields.body:
A four letter outburst from the Boyzone singer Shane Lynch yesterday led to television chiefs being censured.

The Irish star's foul language came during an awards show on the music channel MTV, one of several pop shows which broke broadcasting rules, the Independent Television Commission has ruled.

Although there were no complaints about the singer's remarks, ITC staff monitoring the show spotted the comments during a programme which was likely to have a family audience.

As well as Lynch's comments, singers Iggy Pop and Marilyn Manson uttered swear words in a show which began before the watershed.

The ITC ruled the show, broadcast on November 8, broke the programme code.

It also ruled against MTV after the channel screened George Michael's controversial Roxanne video, which featured real-life prostitutes and some nudity, during the day. A video for Lenny Kravitz's track Black Velveteen also showed raunchy scenes.

The ITC said: "The sexual images in both videos were unsuitable for any daytime transmission."

Channel 4 was also criticised for an edition of its Top Ten series which looked at one hit wonders. The Doctor from Doctor And The Medics used strong language which two viewers complained about.

fields.headline: Joy Shelton
fields.standfirst: Heroine of morale-boosting wartime movies and devoted wife of radio's PC49
fields.trailText: The career of actress Joy Shelton, who has died aged 77, was all stops and starts. In the 1940s, she was groomed for stardom by the Gainsborough film studio, but then dropped. Picked up by BBC radio, she was for six years a household name as the fiancée, and later the wife, of that reassuring model policeman, PC 49, in the crime series of that name.
fields.body:
The career of actress Joy Shelton, who has died aged 77, was all stops and starts. In the 1940s, she was groomed for stardom by the Gainsborough film studio, but then dropped. Picked up by BBC radio, she was for six years a household name as the fiancée, and later the wife, of that reassuring model policeman, PC 49, in the crime series of that name. But her marriage to character actor Sydney Tafler took precedence, and she faded from the public eye, reappearing only after their three children had grown up.

She continued acting into the 1990s, when she was stopped again, this time by illness. But it is hard to imagine that a steadier career, or more conventional stardom, would have brought the contentment she found with her family, an adopted religion, and life outside the theatre.

Born in London, Shelton was destined for the stage from the days of her appearance in a school nativity play. She was only 16 when she won a scholarship to the Rada, and 18 when she made her stage debut in Brighton. Shortly afterwards, she claimed, she engineered a romance with the young radio actor Tafler by demanding him as her leading man in Antony And Anna, at London's Q theatre.

They married in 1941, despite the fact that Tafler was Jewish and Shelton was not. She later converted, becoming, said her actor son Jonathan, "the model of a Jewish mother".

Strikingly beautiful, with lustrous hair and expressive eyes, Shelton was discovered by Gainsborough and given a starring role in her first film, Millions Like Us (1943), one of the many morale-boosters that celebrated British working-class spunk during the second world war. She was charming and unaffected as one of the daughters of old Moore Marriott, formerly comedian Will Hay's stooge.

Shelton was then given her best-known film part, as the wife torn between "Honest Joe" husband John Mills and rotten cad Stewart Granger, in Waterloo Road (1944). She provided a decent and heart breaking role model for many British war widows, and it remains unaccountable that her only other Gainsborough movie was a weak Arthur Askey comedy, Bees In Paradise (1944), in which she was billed eighth as a dusky maiden on a south seas island. Singer Anne Shelton (no relation and no actress) took star billing.

Joy continued to have success on the London stage, notably in Ever Since Paradise, at the New theatre in 1947, but is still remembered for her partnership with Brian Reece as PC 49, a hero copper who predated Dixon Of Dock Green. The couple appeared together on radio from 1947 to 1953, and in a 1951 film, A Case For PC 49. This, however, was a second feature, as were many of Shelton's later films. Her last screen appearance was as Alec Guinness's wife in HMS Defiant in 1962.

"Her greatest pleasure," says Jonathan of his mother, "was when she and Sydney [Tafler] could work together." They did so several times, finally in a tour of Barefoot In The Park shortly before his death in 1979. Shelton never fully recovered from the loss, but was far from reclusive, working for the cerebral palsy charity that became Scope, teaching children at the Ravenscourt theatre school, and taking occasional acting roles, her last in the television serialisation of The Darling Buds Of May in 1991.

Only emphysema prevented Shelton making the most of her considerable gifts as a performer and ganze macher, someone who can organise everything. The day before her death, her doctor and his students stayed for two hours at her bedside, enchanted by her stories. She was as charming as she had been in her first film, which had pointed the way her life would go. She was not just a star; she was just like us.

Shelton is survived by her three children and four grandchildren.

Joy Shelton, actress, born June 3 1922; died January 28 2000

fields.headline: Dolphin in cleaned up Mersey
fields.trailText: After a multi-million pound clean up campaign, the river Mersey is coming back to life, with up to 50 species of fish and, its latest visitor, a dolphin.
fields.body:
After a multi-million pound clean up campaign, the river Mersey is coming back to life, with up to 50 species of fish and, its latest visitor, a dolphin.

Fifteen years ago the Mersey was devoid of life, condemned as one of Europe's most polluted waterways and a victim of Liverpool's industrial past.

But the river is now teaming with salmon, sea bass, sea trout, cod, whiting and, for the first time in living memory, a 5ft long dolphin, sighted swimming alongside a passenger ferry.

A spokesman for Mersey inshore rescue said the creature was thought to be a bottlenose dolphin.

"It must have followed a boat in from the Irish sea and stayed to look for food," he said. "It stayed for around 24 hours and we are hoping to get a return visit soon."

webTitle: Battered SPD wins crucial regional poll

fields.headline: Battered SPD wins crucial regional poll
fields.trailText: The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, survived a key test of public opinion last night, but it left support for his Social Democrats eroded and a new question mark over their alliance with the Greens.
fields.body:
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, survived a key test of public opinion last night, but it left support for his Social Democrats eroded and a new question mark over their alliance with the Greens.

Yesterday's regional election in North Rhine-Westphalia - home to one in five Germans - had been widely seen as a referendum on the "Red-Green" coalition which took power nationally two years ago. The region has been run by such an alliance since 1995.

Early projections showed support for Mr Schröder's SPD slipping by 3-4%. The fall was almost certainly due in part to yesterday's unseasonably hot weather, which was expected to work against the left.

It was a better outcome than the chancellor had any reason to expect in the autumn, when his government's business-friendly programme came under fierce attack from the left. But that was before the Christian Democrat(CDU) opposition was plunged into crisis by the scandal over covert funding under its former leader Helmut Kohl.

Last night's results made it uncomfortably clear that the SPD had failed to make any lasting capital out of the affair.

The CDU was forecast to repeat its 1995 tally - an encouraging result for its new leader, Angela Merkel.

"We were able to match the results from the last vote in a difficult political situation," said its candidate for the regional premiership, Jürgen Rüttgers. "We can be proud of that."

The most striking changes affected the smaller parties. The Greens were predicted to lose almost a third of the votes they gained at the last poll in North Rhine-Westphalia in 1995. Support for the liberal Free Democrats was predicted to soar. Early projections gave them almost 10% of the vote, compared with well under 5% last time.

The outcome raised the question whether the re-elected regional premier, Wolfgang Clement of the SPD, might not swap coalition partners. Clearly, the Greens will now have less room for manoeuvre, regionally and nationally.

The results appeared to reflect dissatisfaction with the Greens' policies and public bickering. Taken with the drop in support for the SPD, it may also signal a key change in voter attitudes in the region.

Once Germany's industrial powerhouse, North Rhine-Westphalia is now trying to shape a new future as home for "TMT" (telecommunications-media-technology) businesses. The change is thought to have weakened voter loyalties and until a few days ago the polls showed that up to a quarter of the electorate undecided.

fields.headline: Briton murdered in China
fields.trailText: Police in China were yesterday investigating the murder of a British woman found stabbed to death while backpacking.
fields.body:
Police in China were yesterday investigating the murder of a British woman found stabbed to death while backpacking.

The Foreign Office said Shirine Harburn's body was found on Paomao mountain in the province of Sichuan.

A spokesman said: "The Chinese police are investigating. Reports state she was stabbed 12 times with a small craft knife. The knife was found near her body. It appears she was stabbed and her body was moved, but there is no evidence of sexual assault."

The spokesman said her body was found by a tourist on May 11. She was last seen at 9am on May 9 at the foot of a hill in the region by someone selling tickets.

He added: "It seems she was heading out to do some walking, carrying a day pack. She was wearing relatively light clothing. There was a search after she was reported missing."

Ms Harburn, 30, of West Sussex, was travelling with her boyfriend, Colin Horsfield. No one has been arrested in connection with the murder.
