webTitle: French strike dries up cash flow

fields.headline: French strike dries up cash flow
fields.trailText: With thousands of cash dispensers shut and many shops accepting only cheque or credit card payments, France began running out of ready money yesterday as a national strike by armoured van guards entered its sixth day.
fields.body:
With thousands of cash dispensers shut and many shops accepting only cheque or credit card payments, France began running out of ready money yesterday as a national strike by armoured van guards entered its sixth day.

Talks between union leaders and employers broke down on Saturday night after the country's two leading security van firms, Brink's and Ardial, refused to meet the guards' demand for higher basic salaries, monthly danger money and greater on-the-job security.

The French Banking Association estimated that around 40% of France's 33,000 cash machines were empty, and warned that banks would introduce a strict £100 ceiling on over-the-counter withdrawals unless supplies resumed soon.

Retailers faced a different problem. Sitting on nearly a week's worth of uncollected takings and unwilling for security reasons to accept any more of the cash still circulating, big groups such as the Carrefour supermarket chain and the Fnac book and record shops slashed the standard £10 lower limit for credit card payments to £5 or even £1.

The strike by 4,000 guards follows a recent increase in violent attacks on armoured vans. Last week several hundred guards attended the funeral of a colleague shot dead during a robbery in Grenoble. A day later, an attack on a van in Nanterre, west of Paris, left three more badly wounded.

In the past six months three guards have been killed and a dozen injured in 10 attacks. The robbers are using increasingly dangerous and sophisticated methods: in Marseille in December, masked assailants fled with £1.4m after firing a shoulder-launched missile at a security van.

"We're just not prepared to carry on getting killed for such a miserable reward," a union organiser, René Baralys, said, pointing out that newly recruited guards take home less than £600 a month.

Mr Baralys, 52, survived having a gun held to his head during a two-hour hostage-taking and a machine-gun attack in Marseille in which two colleagues died. In Nice in 1995, a dynamite attack on his van paralysed a colleague from the waist down.

"It used to be that all we had to worry about was small-time yobs," he said.

"But these days it's organised, large-scale gangs. They have Kalashnikovs, rocket-launchers and dynamite. They can easily walk away with more than £2m for a single hold-up."

The guards are demanding an extra £150 a month danger money, more efficient bullet-proof jackets, better reinforced vans, and official recognition of their profession as dangerous - which would entitle them to earlier retirement and other benefits.

The security firms say that the business is not profitable and that the guards' demands would cost them £10m a year.

"We understand and sympathise with their complaints," said Jean-Michel Haury of Brink's.

"But if we're going to meet their demands, the government and our clients will have to help."

fields.headline: Wanted: a new Beveridge
fields.trailText: The government mistakenly seems to believe - and tries to persuade others - that the basic pension is a handout designed only for poor people and says it is wasted on the rich. That is why it will not increase it to decency levels at which pensioners do not have to apply for means-tested benefits such as the guaranteed minimum, which many refuse to do.
fields.body:
The government mistakenly seems to believe - and tries to persuade others - that the basic pension is a handout designed only for poor people and says it is wasted on the rich. That is why it will not increase it to decency levels at which pensioners do not have to apply for means-tested benefits such as the guaranteed minimum, which many refuse to do.

What everyone seems to forget is that the National Insurance pension is precisely that - a contributory pension which virtually everyone, rich and poor, has paid for through their working careers and to which all of them are entitled when they retire, whatever other sources of income they may have.

Beveridge's intention was that it should be sufficient to live on by itself, though it never has been and still isn't, as the Family Budget Unit's recent research shows. However, the government has no minimum income standard by which to assess the adequacy of the pension. That remains the problem.

As in the 1940s, state income maintenance practice in the UK has again become completely incoherent, unprincipled, ineffective and inefficient. It is time this "reforming" government found its Beveridge to review the overall situation and plan for a system which meets modern human rights and decency standards. Changes in lifetime careers and gendered working roles have undermined some of his assumptions, but not the necessity of a basic pension, sufficient to live on decently, to which everyone, poor, middling and rich alike, is entitled without having to apply for state charity.
Prof John Veit Wilson
University of Newcastle upon Tyne

 Polly Toynbee asks (Bowing to the power of pensioners, May 10) why no word from the pensioners who have had an increase of £20 a week from the government's latest budget. The answer is quite simple - no pensioner has had such an increase. Nearly all of the new provisions don't take place until April 2001. The winter fuel payment of £150 per household (not per pensioner) won't be doled out until mid-winter, the free TV licence for over 75s doesn't start until November, in fact all most of us have had is the 75p per week.
DM Elliot
Battle, East Sussex

 The enormous wealth generated in our society is not, in the main, produced by the labour of the present work force. Today's wealth is produced primarily by the investment of vast amounts of capital, in industrial plants and in financial services. This capital was accumulated by my generation of pensioners and those before us, through our insurance contributions and our savings, but even more from the surplus value of our labour.

So we don't want welfare targeted to the most needy. We just want our fair share. And that can only be calculated by linking pensions to current incomes, including fat-cat share handouts and other fringe benefits.
Brian Cordingley
Saddleworth, Lancs
briancordingley@ compuserve.com

 Why not: increase the basic state pension to say £200 a week - enough for an old person to live with dignity; stop all the present "add-ons" and save the cost of their administration; create a new income tax system for the over-65s with bands and progressive rates to claw back the whole of this increase from those like myself who do not need it?
AF Bennett
Chichester

fields.headline: John Emery
fields.standfirst: Medical pioneer whose work cut the toll of cot deaths
fields.trailText: Professor John Emery, who has died aged 84, was a distinguished paediatric pathologist and one of this country's leading authorities on unexpected death in infancy, or cot death.
fields.body:
Professor John Emery, who has died aged 84, was a distinguished paediatric pathologist and one of this country's leading authorities on unexpected death in infancy, or cot death.

The first son of a village schoolmaster at Aylburton, Gloucestershire, on the edge of the Forest of Dean, he was educated at Lydney grammar school, qualified at Bristol University in 1939, and soon began his career in children's medicine at Bristol children's hospital. After the hospital was damaged by wartime bombing, he was in charge for a while when it was evacuated to Weston-Super-Mare.

At that time, trainee paediatricians spent a year in pathology - regrettably this is no longer the case - and Emery became pathologist in charge of the evacuated hospital laboratories of the Bristol university teaching hospitals. In 1947, he was appointed consultant pathologist to the Sheffield children's hospital, where he was to remain for the rest of his professional life. He was appointed professor associate by the University of Sheffield in 1972 and retired as emeritus professor in 1980.

In his early work at Sheffield, Emery published prolifically on lung development in infancy, malformations, spina bifida, children's tumours and tuberculosis. Perhaps motivated by the loss of one of his own children at an early age, he focused his attention on sudden, unexpected death in infancy.

Writing in 1989, he said: "As infant mortality diminished in the first half of this century, more attention was given to those babies dying unexpectedly and with less florid disease. The skills required to study such deaths had not, however, been developed, and the result was that diagnoses ranged from pneumonitis to suffocation. The latter label led to parents being interrogated by the police and to social stigma. In 1969, a group in Seattle, believing that all of these were natural deaths, recommended that they should be registered as the sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)."

Emery, however, described the label as a seductive diagnosis, which excused all concerned from any defect in care, diagnosis and treatment. He regarded SIDS not as a single entity, but as the result of many different causes. He reported that after meticulous postmortem examination and detailed confidential inquiry, only 17% of deaths diagnosed as SIDS remained completely unexplained.

Unlike those pathologists who remain glued to their microscopes, Emery instigated measures in the community to reduce the toll of cot deaths. An early member of the Foundation for the Study of Infant Deaths, he became director of the Coni (Care of Next Infant) programme.

By identifying babies at risk, establishing a selectively intensive health-visitor programme and responding promptly to those early symptoms which may presage cot death in vulnerable babies, Emery and his colleagues in Sheffield achieved a substantial fall in the infant death rate in the city.

He travelled and lectured widely. At the invitation of the White House, he carried out a survey in 1975 of the cot death bereavement community service in seven US states. In 1986, he made a study of the primary childcare services in New Zealand for the minister of health and the Plunket Society of New Zealand. This was followed by a national research survey, which produced information leading to the back-to-sleep campaign that halved cot deaths in New Zealand.

Emery consistently argued that paediatric pathology was a discipline distinct from its adult counterpart. As a founder member of the Paediatric Pathology Society, the International Paediatric Pathology Association (IPPA) and several other learned societies, he promoted international debate and research. He was keen to attract and train bright recruits, organising with Johannes Huber the first five annual advanced international training courses in paediatric pathology on behalf of the IPPA.

Emery had a sparkling intellect, a roguish wit and an artist's eye and hand. At a scientific meeting, he might be seen busily sketching the speaker, an activity which in no way impaired his ability to ask the penetrating question. A gifted orator, he had the ability to hold an international audience spellbound, as he did at the end of a long meeting to honour his own 80th birthday, when he spoke about occupational disease in neolithic man.

In Sheffield, he had been president of the Fine Arts Society, the Literary and Poetry Society and the Sheffield Museum Society. His interests in history, decorated cast iron, prehistoric art and art symbolism were shared with his beloved wife, Mytts.

To his colleagues, Emery was the father of paediatric pathology in the UK. To his friends, he was a gentle, witty and knowledgeable raconteur. He received many academic honours, including an honorary degree from the University of Sheffield in 1999.

Emery died in the house in Aylburton where he had been born. Though he and Mytts escaped a fire, he returned to the house in a typically courageous attempt to try to save their Airedale terrier. He is survived by his wife, four sons, two daughters and 15 grandchildren.

fields.headline: Keizo Obuchi
fields.standfirst: Japanese machine politician and would-be economic reformer
fields.trailText: Keizo Obuchi, who has died aged 62, of complications from a stroke, was the kind of Japanese politician about whom western commentators scratch their heads and wonder how he ever made it to high office. He was totally lacking in charisma, a poor public speaker and unimpressive in appearance.
fields.body:
Keizo Obuchi, who has died aged 62, of complications from a stroke, was the kind of Japanese politician about whom western commentators scratch their heads and wonder how he ever made it to high office. He was totally lacking in charisma, a poor public speaker and unimpressive in appearance. When people described him as "ordinary" and "plodding", he did not wholly disagree, and when the American media likened him to cold pizza, he confined himself to the mild-mannered response that pizza can be heated up.

With so much demonstrably not in his favour, how was it that Obuchi became leader of the most successful political party (in terms of years in office) in any postwar democracy, and prime minister of the country with the largest economy in the world after the US? The answers lie in his good fortune in possessing so many of the attributes which an effective politician needs in Japan, and against which the shortcomings mentioned above pale into insignificance.

First, he was lucky enough to be born a male, in a political system where, typically, his first cabinet, in July 1998, contained the usual solitary token female. Second, he was fortunate enough to have a politician for a father, whose support network he could inherit. Third, he was affable, a good listener and so practised in consensus-building that it seemed like second nature. Fourth, he could hide his considerable abilities behind a mask of ordinariness and, hence, put people at their ease.

Obuchi was born in rural Gunma prefecture, a heartland of conservative politics in Japan. In 1958, he entered Waseda, a top private university in Tokyo, majoring in English literature. While there, he kept fit by taking aikido classes, and practised oratory in the speech club - though his later career removed all traces of these pursuits.

After graduation in 1962, Obuchi was inclined to stay on at Waseda and take a higher degree in politics, but dropped out after a few months and went abroad to travel. In later life, he often recalled meeting Robert Kennedy on the American leg of his round-the-world trip, and claimed that this inspired him to become a politician. This was probably a rationalisation of a career choice that social pressures and family expectations made virtually unavoidable.

Obuchi returned to Japan in September 1963, and went straight into an election campaign in the Gunma third constituency. Although two formidable Liberal Democratic party politicians, Yasuhiro Nakasone and Takeo Fukuda (both of whom went on to become prime minister) were in the contest, the multi-member system allowed Obuchi to be elected along side his seniors - he once described himself as "a noodle shop between two skyscrapers". At 26, he became the youngest representative in the lower house of the Japanese national assembly.

From then on, Obuchi's progress was impeccably conventional. The multi-member constituency system meant that he had to join a different LDP faction to Nakasone's and Fukuda's. The faction he ended up in was that of Kakuei Tanaka, who continued as godfather of the LDP even after being convicted in 1983 for his part in the Lockheed scandal. Tanaka's faction remained the largest and most powerful group within the LDP throughout successive changes of leadership, first to Noboru Takeshita and then to Obuchi himself.

In addition to working his way up in his faction, Obuchi met all the other requirements of a rising LDP politician. Consistent delivery of material benefits to his constituency meant that he was returned in 12 successive elections, and he occupied, in turn, all the key positions which together serve as apprenticeship for the top job. These included chief cabinet secretary in 1987, party secretary-general in 1991 and minister of foreign affairs in 1997.

Obuchi's turn eventually came in July 1998, when Ryutaro Hashimoto resigned after taking responsibility for the LDP's poor performance in the upper house election. Among the general public, Obuchi was the least popular candidate for the LDP presidency, but with the votes of the third largest faction, led by Kiichi Miyazawa, to add to his own support, the result was not in doubt. Obuchi repaid Miyazawa with the finance ministry, and the make-up of his cabinet dutifully reflected the factional balance within the party, his own faction and Miyazawa's getting five posts each.

In a sense, Obuchi wrote his own political obituary when he declared, in his first policy speech, that he was determined to set the Japanese economy on the path to recovery - this was the yardstick by which he invited judgment. Twenty months and two enormous emergency economic packages later, the economy remains on its knees, unemployment is higher than ever and government indebtedness stands at 125% of GDP.

None of this should be put down to Obuchi's inadequacy. He was a superlative practitioner of politics Japanese-style, and had considerable personal charm. But the qualities that brought him the top job ensured that he would be a link in a chain, not someone to sever the chain that binds Japan.

He and his wife Chizuko had a son and two daughters.

But the qualities that brought him the top job ensured that he would be a link in a chain, not someone to sever the chain that binds Japan. He and his wife Chizuko had a son and two daughters. Keizo Obuchi, politician, born June 25 1937; died May 14 2000

fields.headline: Derek Allhusen
fields.trailText: Major Derek Allhusen, who has died aged 86, will be remembered for his part in the run of British equestrian successes in the 1950s and 1960s, most notably for leading the national team to a gold medal in the three-day event at the 1968 Olympic games in Mexico, where he also took the individual silver.
fields.body:
Major Derek Allhusen, who has died aged 86, will be remembered for his part in the run of British equestrian successes in the 1950s and 1960s, most notably for leading the national team to a gold medal in the three-day event at the 1968 Olympic games in Mexico, where he also took the individual silver.

He was then aged 54, and riding Lochinvar. A sudden storm dramatically changed conditions for the cross-country test, the key phase of the contest and a severe test of endurance. One horse drowned in the flooded ditch and a rider, a non-swimmer, was in trouble before being rescued. Conditions were also hazardous in the final section of jumping in the arena, when Britain was one of only two nations to complete with all four horses.

Allhusen was also a member of the victorious British squads in the European championships of 1957, 1967 and 1969. He had the unusual distinction of also representing Britain in the pentathlon at the 1948 winter Olympics in St Moritz.

Allhusen was educated at Eton, Chillon College, in Montreux, and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he read history. He only started riding at 18, having become interested in winter sports while recovering from illness in Switzerland.

He was commissioned into the 9th Queen's Royal Lancers in 1935, and during the second world war served in north Africa, Italy and France, where he was wounded. In 1944, while attached to the United States army, he was awarded the US silver star.

Out of the services in 1949, he farmed extensively at Claxton, Norfolk. He began eventing in 1955. After retiring from competitive riding, he continued to play an important part in equestrian matters. For the 1972 Olympics, he loaned his horse, Laurieston, to Richard Meade, who won both team and individual gold medals. He was president of the British Horse Society in 1987-88 and involved in related activities, such as the Riding for the Disabled group. He was appointed CVO in 1984.

One of his sons predeceased him. He is survived by his wife Claudia, a son and a daughter.

Derek Swithin Allhusen, horseman, born January 9 1914; died April 24 2000

fields.headline: Wimbledon lose heart and status
fields.trailText: Southampton 2 - 0 Wimbledon David Lacey witnessed the Premiership's most enduring fairy tale reach a dark denouement worthy of the brothers Grimm.
fields.body:
So we'll no more go a'wombling, at least not in the Premiership for the moment, and maybe not for some time to come. The manner of Wimbledon's relegation here yesterday did not suggest a swift return. The players voted on a motion of confidence in themselves and lost.

Given 75 minutes to respond to the news that Bradford were leading Liverpool at Valley Parade, Wimbledon began to fade once Wayne Bridge's free-kick put Southampton ahead early in the second half and all but disappeared after Marian Pahars had added a second 11 minutes from the end.

Thus the Premiership's most enduring fairy tale has reached a dark denouement worthy of the brothers Grimm. Elected to the Football League in 1977 and promoted to the old First Division nine years later, Wimbledon were living proof that given team spirit and consistency, plus more than a few able players, a small club could survive among the big spenders.

It was when Wimbledon began to splash out themselves that the waters started to close over them. The truth is that mere millions could not replace the special character of the side that had consistently challenged those above them, reaching its zenith in the 1988 FA Cup final victory over an outstanding Liverpool side.

Those days are long gone. Wimbledon's decline towards the Nationwide League set in last season following the heart attack which eventually ended Joe Kinnear's tenure as manager. The team lost nine of their last 11 league matches and have now won only seven out of 49.

Yesterday was Wimbledon's 10th successive away defeat in the Premiership and indeed they lost like a losing team. Briefly optimistic at the start, it did not take much for the fatalism to set in.

Presumably not much time will be wasted with recriminations since Wimbledon got those out of the way when they sacked Egil Olsen. Terry Burton, who expects to be appointed full-time manager by the club's Norwegian owners, did his best to suggest that relegation was a little local difficulty, but he may find the practical demands of regaining a Premiership place quickly somewhat daunting.

It was not the end, he insisted. "This is the beginning of how we want the club to be run in the future, with healthy football habits all the time, week in, week out. One bubble bursts and you have to blow another one."

Tricky things, bubbles. Ask West Ham. The principal question for Wimbledon during the close season will concern not only who they will buy but how many of their present players will want to stay.

"No player will leave unless it is right for the club and the supporters," Burton said, but the likes of Carl Cort, who has already attracted the eyes of several Premiership clubs, may not be around in August.

At times yesterday the combination of Cort's quick reactions near goal and the persistence of Marcus Gayle suggested that Wimbledon might yet save a cause which began to appear lost the moment Bradford scored. Throughout the game, however, Wimbledon's football was a parody of the fast-breaking, quick-crossing style which had served them so well in better days. The suspension of John Hartson, after his sending-off at Bradford, deprived them of a strong figure to hold the attack together.

Southampton announced their intent as early as the first minute, when Pahars saw a shot beaten out by Neil Sullivan. From then on their superior passing dominated large areas of the match.

Pahars's readiness to run at defenders increasingly unsettled Wimbledon and 11 minutes into the second half the Latvian was brought down by Alan Kimble near the penalty arc. Up stepped the 19-year-old Bridge to score his first goal for Southampton with a free-kick driven in off the underside of the bar.

From then on Wimbledon were looking to Liverpool for salvation. Their hopes of saving themselves vanished in the 79th minute when two successive shots from Trond Ander sen were blocked, the second rebounding to Pahars who sprinted three-quarters of the length of the pitch before turning past Dean Blackwell and shooting low past Sullivan.

"We didn't send Wimbledon down, Bradford did," said Southampton's manager Glenn Hoddle. The truth is that Wimbledon have sent themselves down and may still have a considerable way to fall.

webTitle: United cash in on Villa's distraction

fields.headline: United cash in on Villa's distraction
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 0 - 1 Man Utd
fields.body:
An under-strength Manchester United line-up suggested that Aston Villa's hopes of a meaningful warm-up for the FA Cup final were most likely to be provided by the May sunshine.

But despite the absence of several players, either injured or rested for Euro 2000, Teddy Sheringham's goal ensured a familiar result for United and an unfamiliar one for Villa.

This was only Villa's second Premiership defeat in 21 matches and their manager John Gregory was in downbeat mood. "I think some of the players were preoccupied with next Saturday," he said.

"That's been the case for the past six weeks since we won the semi-final against Bolton. It hasn't been easy, as anyone who has been involved in an FA Cup final will tell you."

For Wembley it is reasonable to assume that the goalkeeper David James and midfielder Ian Taylor will be the two alterations made to the Villa XI that started yesterday.

It was not the first time this season that Sir Alex Ferguson has sent an under-strength team to Villa Park. An even more inexperienced and youthful line-up lost there in the Worthington Cup in October.

This time the absences in the United line-up meant a half each for the youngsters Danny Higginbottom and Ronnie Wallwork while others played in unfamiliar positions. The central midfield duo comprised Phil Neville and Dwight Yorke, who was predictably booed by the home contingent who have not forgiven him for defecting to Old Trafford last season.

Despite the low-key performance Villa had their chances. Benito Carbone swept Paul Merson's low, left-wing cross just wide of the post in the first half and Dion Dublin had a header cleared off the line by Phil Neville in the second. But by then Sheringham, taking advantage when Jordi Cruyff's right-wing cross bounced off Ugo Ehiogu, had converted his sixth goal of the season.

Dublin almost rescued the game in the closing seconds with a rasping shot that Raimond van der Gouw tipped over and then with a header that hit the bar.

Had that gone in it would have prevented United establishing a Premiership record of 11 successive victories. But it would have been a minor omission from the catalogue of records set by Ferguson's team.

Their points tally is a record for the Premiership, their goals total of 97 the best in the top flight for almost 40 years and the margin of points between them and second-placed Arsenal also sets a new standard.

In terms of trophies, though, compared to last this season has been one of under-achievement, something Ferguson already seems determined to put right. "I think we are quite capable of doing just as well next season," he said.

"We've proved we can retain the championship this season and are convinced we can do so again. It will be interesting to see who Arsenal, Chelsea, Liverpool and Leeds buy in the summer to challenge us."

webTitle: Spurs flatter but Graham is not deceived

fields.headline: Spurs flatter but Graham is not deceived
fields.standfirst: Lively victory over Sunderland fails to hide Tottenham's season of disappointment
fields.trailText: Tottenham 3 - 1 Sunderland
fields.byline: Vivek Chaudhary at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
For a change the final whistle was greeted with cheers from Spurs fans rather than the jeers that have echoed around the ground at many games this season.

Yet the glorious sunshine and the party atmosphere did little to disguise the disappointment of Tottenham's campaign.

George Graham admitted as much after the game as he prepared for a summer holiday that will be followed by a major rebuilding job.

"Of course I am a little disappointed," he said. "In the second half of the season we really dropped off and we had a bad time. But there are a lot of good things happening at this club and we are optimistic for next season."

By contrast, Sunderland will look back with satisfaction on their first season back in the top flight, despite this defeat. Peter Reid's task appears much less daunting than that facing his north London counterpart.

There was no lacklustre end-of-season feel to this game despite the fact that both teams were playing only for honour.

As well as the four goals there was a red card for Alex Rae, who hit out at David Ginola and will now miss the start of next season on suspension, plus bitter disappointment for Steffen Iversen.

Graham said after the match that the Norway striker, who was substituted at half-time, would miss Euro 2000 because of a recurrence of a leg injury.

Tottenham once again demonstrated their capacity for valuing commercialism above tradition as they opted to wear next season's new away kit in an attempt to boost sales.

This no doubt pleased the Spurs chairman Alan Sugar, who had something else to smile about when his team took the lead after 11 minutes from a Darren Anderton penalty. It was a controversial spot kick, given that Paul Butler appeared to have brought down Chris Armstrong just outside the Sunderland box.

The visitors felt hard done by and continued pressing forward. They were justifiably rewarded nine minutes later when Chris Makin surged past a flat-footed Ledley King, who was making his full Tottenham debut, and then slotted the ball home.

With the heat increasing and noise levels rising, both teams set about each other as if they had something crucial to play for.

"The lads could have just gone out there and strolled around," said Graham. "Considering there was not a lot at stake it was a very good, entertaining game. The crowd was really up for it."

Spurs managed to edge ahead midway through the second half when Tim Sherwood, making a return from injury, was able to get on to the end of a Sol Campbell header and tuck the ball away.

The Sunderland marksman Kevin Phillips had an unusually quiet game and was well shackled all afternoon by the impressive Chris Perry.

It was left to the Spurs full- back Stephen Carr to steal the prize for goal of the day .

With the visitors searching for an equaliser, Spurs managed to hit them on the break and Carr beat off two challenges to lob the ball into Thomas Sorensen's top right hand corner. It was a spectacular finish to mark a spectacular season for the Irish defender.

webTitle: Knight remedy no cure for ills

fields.headline: Knight remedy no cure for ills
fields.standfirst: England should have looked to the future and welcomed back Thorpe
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey feels that England should have looked to the future and welcomed back Thorpe.
fields.body:
Competition for places is a fine and dandy thing, a staple in the process of ensuring that players maximise their ability at the highest level. But in selecting a form player, Nick Knight, rather than someone with a proven record for this week's first test against Zimbabwe the England selectors could well be creating a rod for their own backs.

When Michael Vaughan cracked the knuckle of his left hand 11 days ago, while making a century for Yorkshire against Derbyshire, he must have been mortified - as a contracted player who was pretty much guaranteed a place for the first test - to know he would miss out when he had only just established himself in the side.

He may also have entertained a bitter if fleeting thought along the lines of the old WC Fields adage about suckers seldom getting an even break. If the fates continue to conspire against him (and he lost out in the winter for a while when he broke a finger, so he and they are not exactly courting) it may be some time before he reclaims his place.

Knight, his replacement, has played 12 tests since his debut in 1995 but only one of them - against South Africa at Old Trafford two years ago, again as a replacement - in the past three years.

At test level, as distinct from one-day internationals in which he is indispensable, Knight has proved a modest player, much in the manner of the Australian Michael Bevan. There was a hundred that promised much at Headingley against Pakistan in 1996, when he batted at No6 rather than opening, and four half-centuries besides, but the end product is a modest average of 27.85.

Technique rather than temperament, which is excellent, has been and remains his problem. Knight's one-day strengths - panache, hitting over the top, using the angles square of the wicket on the off side - are weaknesses against test bowlers who have done their homework and have the skill to apply the lessons.

He is 30 now and, for all that some reports like to suggest otherwise, there is little evidence that his basic instincts are changing. However, here he is back in the side rather than Graham Thorpe, who may be lacking confidence and is clearly paying for complacency and opting out of touring last winter, but is case-hardened in test cricket nonetheless.

The scenario is that Knight will get runs against Zimbabwe's moderate attack to earn some leeway and, unless the selectors back their original judgment and return to Vaughan when he is fit - or indeed Thorpe when his penance is done and he starts to make runs - Knight will retain his place for the summer.

Vaughan can do nothing but curse his luck. Thorpe, though, is a different matter. The England captain Nasser Hussain came up through the system with him and is a close friend, a huge admirer and, one suspects, would have wanted him back as soon as possible. He may well have been outvoted. But one can bet Hussain understands the dangers in selecting one player over another simply because one of them is currently scoring more.

It may seem harsh on Knight but, as Hussain has pointed out time and again, England have been too nice for too long and too democratic with it. "If we bring in someone against Zimbabwe we want someone who will also do well against West Indies," Hussain said yesterday.

He might add Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Australia to that list. The last thing England needs is a technically deficient player established in the side when the big boys arrive.

fields.headline: Hollioake deal almost pays off
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 417 & 17-0 dec.
Kent 115-2 dec and 255-8
Match drawn
fields.trailText: Surrey 417 & 17-0 dec Kent 115-2 dec and 255-8 Match drawn
fields.body:
It caught the umpires on the hop, and the scorers too. Expecting to see Rahul Dravid and Alan Wells emerge yesterday morning to continue their batting practice, instead they saw them sprinting out as part of the fielding side.

After the two captains, Adam Hollioake and Matthew Fleming, struck a deal over the corn flakes, Kent declared at their overnight deficit of 302 and Mark Butcher took guard.

Robert Key, unusually, took the new ball. He is employed by Kent to open the batting and, bowling like a granny in the garden, he laid out a buffet for Butcher, who duly helped himself. A four, two sixes over mid-wicket and a single achieved the required equation and Kent were set 320 to win from a minimum of 93 overs.

After a washed-out Thursday followed by two meandering days, this was a welcome enterprise. The crowd had the prospect of a real contest rather than a mere outdoor net.

When Kent slipped to 45 for four it seemed that only the wristy brilliance of Dravid stood between Surrey and a successful gamble. But the Indian found a stout ally in Mark Ealham and a stand that began as a repair job grew in confidence and stature.

Alex Tudor probed Dravid with a series of bouncer-yorker combinations, Martin Bicknell's seaming accuracy was always threatening and Ealham often looked all at sea against the leg-spin of Ian Salisbury, but survived beyond tea.

Dravid, who followed up his 182 against Zimbabwe earlier this month with a cultured 44 not out here on Saturday, has taken to English conditions like a duck to water. His dismissal just before tea - top-edging a pull off Bicknell - was an aberration.

fields.headline: Joke has Warne thin
fields.trailText: Shane Warne's insistence that he would like to use his season at Hampshire to improve his batting skills is fast becoming the county scene's standing joke. Warne has yet to score a run in four championship innings and lasted only two balls at Headingley yesterday before the all- rounder Gavin Hamilton had him caught in the gully.
fields.body:
Shane Warne's insistence that he would like to use his season at Hampshire to improve his batting skills is fast becoming the county scene's standing joke. Warne has yet to score a run in four championship innings and lasted only two balls at Headingley yesterday before the all- rounder Gavin Hamilton had him caught in the gully.

Yorkshire needed less than two hours to claim the last six Hampshire wickets, the win putting them second behind the First Division leaders Lancashire. Hamilton also had a maiden championship century to celebrate. "It was a great relief," he said. "I've been close but, when you are batting at No8, it is easy to run out of partners."

 Leicestershire's first championship victory of the season was a tighter affair, beating Somerset by six wickets at Grace Road with only six overs remaining. Darren Maddy's occasional medium pace conjured up the wickets of Peter Bowler and Keith Parsons at a critical juncture, leaving Leicestershire a target of 122 in 36 overs.

 Nottinghamshire's woes are continuing to pile up. On top of an innings defeat by Northamptonshire yesterday, there are now doubts about their Pakistan paceman Shoaib Akhtar, who has bowled only 10 overs on the current West Indies tour because of a groin injury. Pakistan officials were forced to deny reports yesterday that he is about to quit the tour.

 Gloucestershire's No9 Jamie Averis held out for two hours for 25 not out in Cardiff as Glamorgan fell one wicket short of victory.

webTitle: Adams gets into Constant hot water

fields.headline: Adams gets into Constant hot water
fields.standfirst:
Sussex 224 & 277 Warwickshire 548-7 dec.
Warwickshire won by an innings and 47 runs
fields.trailText: Sussex 224 & 277 Warwickshire 548-7 dec. Warwickshire won by an innings and 47 runs
fields.body:
Not much is going right for Chris Adams these days. Unceremoniously abandoned by England's selectors after an unflattering tour of South Africa, and with his Sussex side lying at the foot of the Second Division, the embattled right-hander has landed himself in hot water by confronting the umpire David Constant off the field to question him about a decision.

With Sussex struggling to make the 324 runs needed to make Warwickshire bat again at Hove, Constant adjudged Adams leg-before for 23 off the left-arm spinner Ashley Giles' last ball before tea on Saturday evening. The Sussex captain was not impressed and later made two trips to the umpires' room to let the former test official know about it.

"We make a match report after every game and I think we can safely say he will get a mention in dispatches," Constant, who stood in 36 test matches, said yesterday.

"The first time he came to see me he wasn't happy with the decision. He just came in and said he wanted to make it clear how he felt. Then he came to apologise after play and I accepted his apology."

Sussex's general manager Dave Gilbert rushed to Adams' defence, claiming that he was "not a malicious or spiteful sort of bloke. He is very well respected around the circuit and it just appears at the moment that the tiniest incident seems to be magnified".

Giles had apparently told Adams during the tea interval that the ball which dismissed him appeared to be missing leg stump. Adams had also felt the gods were frowning on him in the first innings when he was given out leg-before to Alan Richardson for 70.

"He probably reacted in a way which was regrettable," Gilbert admitted, "but he has apologised and from what I'm hearing that is the end of it."

Yesterday's final day lasted only 80 minutes as Warwickshire wrapped up Sussex's last four wickets to secure victory by an innings and 47 runs.

Neil Smith started the procession, enticing Will House to pop up a catch to Dougie Brown at silly point on the third ball of the day. The Warwickshire captain then ousted the seamer Jason Lewry, for a career-best 39, and the wicket-keeper Shaun Humphries.

It fell to Ed Giddins, celebrating a well-deserved test recall, to finish off the one-sided affair, scattering James Kirtley's stumps with a swift yorker. No question about that dismissal, then.

webTitle: Tears of joy after rearguard fight in Valley of rejoicing

fields.headline: Tears of joy after rearguard fight in Valley of rejoicing
fields.trailText: Dave Pendleton: It has been a rearguard action from day one. The tension-racked 1-0 victory at Middlesbrough on the opening day of the season was but a precursor for the long months ahead.
fields.body:
There were tears at Valley Parade - tears of absolute joy as the pitch filled with dancing fans and on the terraces embraces were exchanged. There was also euphoria, relief and even disbelief.

With tears streaming down my face I punched the air in triumph. And what a triumph it is. City's season was summed up yesterday by the way bodies were thrown time and again into the path of Michael Owen's shots. It has been a rearguard action from day one. The tension-racked 1-0 victory at Middlesbrough on the opening day of the season was but a harbinger of the long months ahead.

Despite the financial gulf between City and most of the Premiership, this squad of unglamorous battlers threw themselves into the task with a will that at times surprised even their own supporters. In fact the main plank of City's survival has been home form, with only five defeats there all season and the Valley Parade pressure cooker claiming many notable scalps - none more important than Liverpool's.

You could almost touch the tension yesterday. At times it was crushing. David Wetherall sparked general insanity among the claret-and-amber hordes when his thumping header put the Bantams one up.

But still tension ruled. On the stroke of half-time a fortunate deflection put Owen clean through. As Valley Parade held its breath, Matt Clarke raced out to push the England striker wide. Owen's shot beat the keeper, but there was City's sole foreigner, Gunnar Halle, to clear off the line to wild acclaim.

And still there was another twist. A near miss at the Dell was misinterpreted as a goal and the roars rolled around the ground. It was not until the interval that the error was realised.

The second period brought a Liverpool onslaught. City defenders went into tackles like madmen. The news of Southampton's first goal echoed around the ground. At first there was a reluctance to accept the news. But as confirmation came through, the roars thundered. The pressure was unrelenting. But when Southampton's second was announced, the party began.

Isaiah Rankin could have made it go with a swing, but his audacious chip went wide. Three minutes of injury time was met with a cry of anguish, even though a draw would do now. A false dawn saw fans pouring on to the pitch. But the release wasn't long coming and once again the pitch was engulfed by a tide of claret and amber. But don't mention next season; we simply don't care.

Dave Pendleton is editor of The City Gent, a Bradford fanzine

webTitle: Lazio win Serie A as Juve sink in deluge

fields.headline: Lazio win Serie A as Juve sink in deluge
fields.trailText: Lazio clinched the Italian title in dramatic fashion yesterday as torrential rain forced the suspension at half-time of Juventus's match at Perugia.
fields.body:
Lazio clinched the Italian title in dramatic fashion yesterday as torrential rain forced the suspension at half-time of Juventus's match at Perugia.

When that game resumed after an hour Perugia's Massimiliano Cappioli scored inside four minutes. It stayed 1-0 and Juventus, who had Gianluca Zambrotta sent off, saw their title hopes sink.

Lazio's 3-0 win over Reggina in Rome, after a pitch invasion by home fans halted play for 10 minutes, carried them a point clear of Juventus to clinch their second scudetto in 100 years.

"I never thought it would be this beautiful," said Sven Goran Eriksson, Lazio's manager. "The other titles I won elsewhere in Europe cannot compare to this."

A resumption in the Juventus game had looked unlikely as huge puddles formed on the pitch. But, when the sun did reappear, the referee Pierluigi Collina decided the surface was playable even though the players' every step raised large splashes. "The match was all above board," said the Juventus coach Carlo Ancelotti.

Milan, who finished third, go into the Champions League while Inter and Parma must play off for the final berth.

Deportivo La Coruna will win the Spanish league next weekend if they pick up a point at home to Espanyol. Barce-lona, who face Celta Vigo, trail by three points after both leaders' games finished 0-0.

In France Monaco are champions by seven points and Paris St-Germain runners-up, with Lyon taking the third Champions League place.

Bayer Leverkusen need a point next Saturday to be sure of taking the German title from Bayern Munich, who trail by three points. Hamburg are third and the final Champions League berth lies between 1860 Munich and Hertha Berlin.

webTitle: Fowler future in doubt after Anfield row

fields.headline: Fowler future in doubt after Anfield row
fields.trailText: Robbie Fowler's chances of making the England squad for Euro 2000 suffered a further blow yesterday when he was left out of Liverpool's final game of the season after a disagreement with his club's coaching staff.
fields.body:
Robbie Fowler's chances of making the England squad for Euro 2000 after missing most of the season through injury suffered a further blow yesterday when he was left out of Liverpool's final game of the season against Bradford City after a disagreement with his club's coaching staff.

While Fowler seems certain to be named in Kevin Keegan's 28-man squad for the forthcoming friendly internationals against Brazil and Ukraine, Gérard Houllier was this morning facing up to the first genuine crisis of his reign at Liverpool when he ponders what future, if any, the striker has at Anfield.

Fowler was omitted from the squad which travelled to west Yorkshire for fitness reasons, according to Houllier, after what was diplomatically described as a "difference of opinion" with senior members of Liverpool's coaching staff.

"There was no bust-up," Houllier said. "He couldn't play a full game so I decided not to even put him on the bench - although he will play on Tuesday in a testimonial game. He hasn't been playing regularly for the last eight months and you can't just come back in."

When Fowler's qualities as a goalscorer are laid alongside the significance of the fixture, such an argument is difficult to believe, especially considering the apparent disagreement over the striker's substitution during last weekend's 0-0 draw against Southampton at Anfield. Liverpool ended the season without a goal in their last five games.

After being withdrawn on the hour Fowler made little attempt to hide his displeasure and it is believed he called into question the wisdom of his manager's decision during a training session at lunch-time on Friday.

He was anxious to play in yesterday's game in the hope of convincing Keegan that he is fit enough to be considered for Euro 2000.

Houllier must now decide whether Fowler's latest indiscretion is the act of a player still frustrated by a long period of recurring injury or the petulant behaviour of a young man forever railing at authority.

If Houllier, a strict disciplinarian, should decide that Fowler is again shaping up to become a disruptive force, he may decide to cut his losses and sell him forthwith, which would spark an intense early-summer auction.

Last season, after Fowler had been heavily censured by both his club and the sport's authorities for his notorious line-sniffing incident during a Merseyside derby against Everton, Houllier warned that, if he stepped out of line one more time, he would be off-loaded in the interests of internal club discipline.

fields.headline: Chapple claims his fifth Trophy
fields.trailText: Kettering 2 - 3 Kingstonian
fields.body:
Geoff Chapple celebrated his fifth FA Trophy final victory as manager when Kingstonian came from behind to beat Kettering at Wembley.

Chapple won three finals with Woking in the 90s and this was Kingstonian's second successive Trophy win. They made it hard for themselves, though, falling 2-1 behind after taking the lead. Eddie Akuamoah's second goal of the afternoon pulled Kingstonian level before the former France international Amara Simba got the winner with 15 minutes remaining.

"It was the hardest of my five finals because it was the first one in which we had gone behind," Chapple said, "and it was the most special for me because it was the last final to be played at Wembley as we know it."

Akuamoah had given Kingstonian a half-time lead before Kettering's captain Colin Bowden and a penalty from Craig Norman put Peter Morris's side ahead. Despite playing seven games in the final fortnight of the season, Kingstonian finished the stronger to claim the win.

Akuamoah, Kingstonian's longest-serving player with more than 300 appearances, said: "It didn't sink in until all the players jumped on me but the second goal was more special because it brought us back into the game."

 England's women secured a place in the play-offs for Euro 2001 after beating Switzerland 1-0. Sue Smith got the only goal in the 55th minute of the second leg of their group two qualifying game. England must beat the undefeated group leaders Norway on June 4 to have any chance of automatic qualification.

fields.headline: Back trouble looms for Keegan
fields.standfirst: England's squad for warm-ups likely to lack defensive balance
fields.trailText: David Lacey fears that England's squad for the warm-up games are likely to lack defensive balance.
fields.body:
England will not be burdened by overwhelming public optimism four weeks from today when they meet Portugal in Eindhoven in their opening game of the 2000 European Championship. The hit-and-miss nature of their qualification under first Glenn Hoddle and then Kevin Keegan has seen to that.

Reaching the quarter-finals from a group which also includes Germany and Romania would be no small feat for an England side that contains some solid building bricks and one or two useful breeze blocks but is short on mortar. A better idea of the task will be revealed today, when Keegan announces the party of 28 from which he will select his squad of 22 after warm-ups at Wembley against Brazil on Saturday week and Ukraine four days later.

Few national coaches are ever able to strike an ideal balance in selections for major tournaments. At any time a country will always be stronger in some positions than others. Yet it is hard to remember a period when the contrast facing an England coach was so stark.

Keegan is well off for strikers, reasonably well provided for at centre-back and has sound options in goal. David Beckham and Paul Scholes give him quality both on the right wing and in central midfield.

Defensively, however, the midfield gives cause for concern. Does Paul Ince still have the legs which covered so much ground at Wembley in 1996? Has a 33-year-old Dennis Wise the speed, in addition to his passing ability, to protect England's central defenders?

At least Keegan still has a choice here and, with Liverpool's Steven Gerrard, 20 at the end of the month, the most likely newcomer, he will have room to manoeuvre in midfield. Even the problem on the left has eased, with Jason Wilcox a natural on that side and Steve McManaman a renewed possibility after his recent Champions League performances for Real Madrid.

It is in the full-back positions where Keegan faces his greatest difficulty. With Graeme le Saux unfit he has no natural left-back and, if rumours about not taking Gary Neville prove correct, he will be without a right-back of international stature unless Lee Dixon is dusted down once more.

The situation is becoming horribly reminiscent of England's ill-fated excursion to the 1992 championship when Graham Taylor arrived in Sweden without a right-back, having lost both Dixon and his replacement, Gary Stevens, to injuries and the team as a whole suffered from its lack of defensive balance.

For Euro 2000 the fear is that, should Keegan take only Phil Neville, who can play in either full-back position but not both at the same time, he will be forced to use three defenders with a five-man midfield. While players, not systems, win or lose most matches it was Hoddle's faith in a 3-5-2 formation which helped throw England off course in the 1998 World Cup, when Romania exploited uncertainties at the back to win in Toulouse.

Either that or Keegan could ask Martin Keown, Sol Campbell, Rio Ferdinand, Kieron Dyer or even Gerrard to fill in at right-back. But such a move would invite trouble. At this level, in the modern game, the full-back positions demand specialists not bit-players and Le Saux is still the only English footballer who remotely resembles a natural wing-back.

Asking Beckham, Wilcox or McManaman to double up in defence in a 3-5-2 system would leave England short in both defence and attack. It did not work when Hoddle asked Darren Anderton to go deeper during France 98. Dixon, even at 36, would do a better job in what, for him, is a natural role.

webTitle: 'Today, May 14, has been a disaster for Wimbledon'

fields.headline: 'Today, May 14, has been a disaster for Wimbledon'
fields.trailText: Wimbledon's colourful 14-year stay in the top flight came to an end yesterday but the manager Terry Burton promised that the club would bounce back.
fields.body:
Wimbledon's colourful 14-year stay in the top flight came to an end yesterday but the manager Terry Burton promised that the club would bounce back.

The Dons' limp 2-0 defeat at Southampton displayed little of the Crazy Gang's famed - or notorious - fighting spirit as Bradford's win over Liverpool saw the south London club join Watford and Sheffield Wednesday in the drop to the First Division.

"There's three things you can do when you fail: that's admit it, learn from it, don't repeat it," said Burton, who took over from Egil Olsen two weeks ago.

"We have a responsibility to those supporters and this club to work and work and work until they are back in the Premiership.

"When one bubble bursts you have to blow another one," he added.

With the goalkeeper Neil Sullivan out of contract and several other players having indicated they want to move, speculation is rife that there will be an exodus. But Burton insisted: "The players who are under contract cannot and will not leave unless it is right for the club."

Wimbledon's Norwegian owners have been accused of failing to understand the underdog spirit of a club which lacks its own ground and is poorly supported. Relegation could cost £8m.

Dave Bassett, who took Wimbledon from the old Fourth Division to the top flight, felt the Dons had paid the price of upheaval.

Bassett, now manager of Barnsley, said: "When the club changes ownership and managers there is always upheaval. You look for scapegoats, and the players have to take some responsibility, as does Egil Olsen to some extent. The owners have to, too, as things have been left in limbo.

"But whatever the reasons, today, May 14, has been a disaster for them."

fields.headline: Wigan banking on Barlow's return
fields.trailText: Millwall 0 - 0 Wigan
fields.byline: Adam Sills at the New Den
fields.body:
Millwall and Wigan will no doubt be busy fine-tuning their preparations for Wednesday's second leg this morning, with set-piece routines, tactics and formations rigorously practised. It would perhaps save everybody's time and effort, though, if the coaches gathered their players 12 yards from goal and told them to pick their spot.

Inseparable in three matches this season, if ever a tie was destined to end in a penalty shoot-out this is it. "There's nothing between the sides," said both managers after this frantic but unfulfilling match in which neither side created many clear openings. And while Wigan were marginally happier with the draw, history suggests it could be a long night at the JJB stadium.

Wigan's inability to turn their 17 draws in the league - including two against Millwall - into victories was a major factor in their failure to earn automatic promotion, despite a run of 24 games unbeaten at the start of the season.

And when the sides met at Wembley in the Auto Windscreens Shield final last April only a hotly disputed last-minute goal from Wigan's Paul Rogers separated them.

A crucial factor on Wednesday could be the return of Wigan's top scorer Stuart Barlow. Not risked on Saturday after a six-week absence following an ankle operation, Barlow declared that he was "really hopeful" of playing in the second leg.

He has 22 goals already and his absence was one of the main reasons for Wigan's dismal end to the season when they managed only two wins in nine games.

In fact Saturday was the first time this season that the New Den has hosted a goalless draw but it never looked like finishing any other way. The Millwall striker Paul Moody came closest to breaking the deadlock with a header on 35 minutes that was cleared off the line by Darren Sheridan, while Simon Haworth flashed a header narrowly wide for Wigan with 20 minutes to go.

"It was helter-skelter, 100 miles per hour stuff," said the Wigan manager John Benson, "but there weren't too many heart-stopping moments for either side.

"The pressure was on Millwall to try to create chances, but now the tables have turned and the pressure is on us to create and score goals, so I don't think we have done the hard part yet."

Millwall's joint manager Alan McLeary said he hoped his side would enjoy more space away from home and, having twice experienced play-off defeats as a Millwall player in 1991 and 1994, he will be desperate to make it third time lucky.

Only one thing is certain about this showdown. Penalties will definitely be practised today.

webTitle: Shearer hits 300 as Wenger rests his case

fields.headline: Shearer hits 300 as Wenger rests his case
fields.trailText: Newcastle 4 - 2 Arsenal
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James' Park
fields.body:
It was mission accomplished here for Alan Shearer and Arsène Wenger. The Newcastle striker scored the 300th senior goal of his career and made it 30 for the season, while Arsenal got through their last game before Wednesday's Uefa Cup final without picking up any injuries.

Not that there was a serious risk of disruption to the visitors' preparation for their match with Galatasaray. Nine of those likely to start in Copenhagen were rested and the manager was not unduly concerned that the Premiership runners-up, in a game which could have no impact on that placing, had provided Newcastle with a straightforward victory.

However there was some significance in a winning end to the season for the hosts, who this summer must generate enough interest to sell an extra 16,000 tickets to fill their extended stadium. And Shearer was eager to reach his personal landmark before heading to Euro 2000 with England.

He made it to 300 with Newcastle's second goal, a typically explosive free-kick through an unconvincing Arsenal wall which parted obligingly. It has taken Shearer a little over 12 seasons to get to his triple century, a formidable record for a striker who has had serious injury problems.

Bobby Robson led the tributes. "It's a phenomenal feat," said the man who has worked with forwards such as Ronaldo, Romario and Gary Lineker. "He's up there with them, he's in that cluster," the Newcastle manager added.

Shearer commented: "I'm a very proud man. When I set out at Southampton I never dreamed I would score 300. To do it at the age of 29 makes me happy. It was a sweet strike, as sweet as I've ever hit. I would put it in my top 10."

Oddly enough Arsenal were also the opponents when Shearer headed in the first goal of his career, for Southampton. He finished with a hat-trick on that day at the Dell back in 1988; yesterday a second goal would have brought him to another personal milestone, 200 in the league.

Gary Speed did score a couple, though, to take his total to 13, his best-ever return for a season. In the first instance the midfielder made a typically forceful run to meet Shearer's overhead pass with a first-time shot in the sixth minute.

Arsenal levelled it within 45 seconds, however, when Davor Suker, eager for a goal in what is likely to be his final appearance for the club, had to settle for setting up Kanu, who lobbed Shay Given. The visitors also responded to Shearer's goal when Stefan Malz held off Warren Barton to score stylishly in the 53rd minute, but Newcastle took charge with two goals in five minutes.

Speed was given ample space to head in Nol Solano's corner in the 59th minute before Andy Griffin, playing his first game since being injured in last season's FA Cup final, steered in the fourth.

"It was a good opportunity to give a run to some of our young players. I can foresee some of them challenging for first-team places next season," said Wenger, who gave debuts to Ashley Cole and Rhys Weston.

 Steve Clarke, the former Chelsea defender and Ruud Gullit's first signing when he took over in August 1998, is to step down from his post as senior coach at Newcastle. Peter Beardsley is expected to be offered a job as a youth coach.

fields.headline: Immaculate emptiness
fields.standfirst:
Emerson Quartet
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.trailText: It has become a convention to tackle a cycle of Shostakovich's 15 string quartets chronologically, so that his increasing command of the form and the way in which he appropriated it to his personal, expressive ends is traced step by step. That is the approach the Emerson Quartet is taking in its survey, shared between the Wigmore Hall, (for the first three of the five programmes), and the Barbican Centre.
fields.body:
It has become a convention to tackle a cycle of Shostakovich's 15 string quartets chronologically, so that his increasing command of the form and the way in which he appropriated it to his personal, expressive ends is traced step by step. That is the approach the Emerson Quartet is taking in its survey, shared between the Wigmore Hall, (for the first three of the five programmes), and the Barbican Centre.

But beginning with the first two quartets makes the opening concert rather underwhelming, for both are very cautious essays, not only in comparison with their later siblings, but with the orchestral works that Shostakovich was composing at the same time - the First was produced in 1938 immediately after the Fifth Symphony; the Second Quartet in 1944, after the Eighth. The return to a blameless world seems like an attempt to recapture childhood innocence, but those who are disinclined to take anything Shostakovich wrote at face value inevitably look for coded messages in those folk-tinged melodies.

Unfortunately searching for anguished subtexts is not what the Emerson's approach is all about. They play the music immaculately but never really extract the maximum expressive mileage: there were countless occasions on Friday when more involvement would have produced more intensity. The two quartets were followed here by the Piano Quintet, composed between them; the pianist was Joseph Kalichstein, more interventionist than his colleagues but also sometimes rather splashy in his figuration, yet the engagement missing earlier was certainly welcome. The best in the series, musically and one hopes interpretatively, must still be to come.

Further concerts tonight and Wednesday (Wigmore Hall), Friday and Sunday (Barbican)

webTitle: Whitbread poised to sell breweries for up to £400m

fields.headline: Whitbread poised to sell breweries for up to £400m
fields.trailText: Whitbread is on the brink of agreeing the sale of its brewing operations to Interbrew, the Belgian owner of the Stella Artois lager brand, for between £300m and £400m.
fields.body:
Whitbread is on the brink of agreeing the sale of its brewing operations to Interbrew, the Belgian owner of the Stella Artois lager brand, for between £300m and £400m.

Insiders say a deal is imminent to end Whitbread's 250-year involvement in the beer making industry.

Unless a last minute hitch emerges, the disposal of Whitbread's brewing operation could be announced some time this week.

The move is part of a strategic review by Whitbread's chief executive, David Thomas - who has watched the company's shares fall by half during the last year.

Mr Thomas wants to concentrate on faster growing operations, such as health clubs and budget hotels.

Whitbread is Britain's third largest brewer after Scottish & Newcastle and Bass.

The sale will include breweries in Manchester, Salmesbury in Lancashire and Magor in Wales, along with two regional distribution centres and 17 satellite sites, employing a total of 4,500 people.

The bulk of Whitbread's production is of Heineken and Stella Artois - which it brews under licence for the European brand owners.

The company also produces Boddingtons, Murphys, Wadworth 6X and a variety of beers designed to serve smaller niche markets.

Mr Thomas hinted at a sale of the brewing operation during Whitbread's annual results briefing some two weeks ago, when he said that consolidation in the brewing industry "could well create an opportunity for us to add value for Whitbread shareholders".

Among the other potential buyers rumoured to be interested were Heineken and a management buyout team, led by the Whitbread Beer Company's managing director, Miles Templeman.

However, sources close to the negotiations for the brewing operation's sale confirmed yesterday that Interbrew had emerged as "the leading contender", and that hopes were high regarding a swift conclusion to the talks.

A Whitbread spokesman declined to comment, but the group is likely to be keen for a smooth resolution after failing in its last strategic move - an attempt to buy Allied Domecq's pub estate last year.

Following the transaction attention is likely to shift to Bass - which is also keen to exit the brewing industry.

Bass wants to concentrate on hotels and on its branded bar chains, which indclude All Bar One and Edwards. Heineken, Carlsberg-Tetley and South African Breweries have been mooted as possible purchasers of the Bass breweries.

fields.headline: Spanglish supremo
fields.standfirst:
Ricky Martin
Earl's Court, London
****
fields.trailText: On album, the former Enrique Morales gives every impression of being just another lantern-jawed bit of robopop trouser, albeit one with an exotic Latin twist. But on stage, who'd have thought that the purveyor of salsa-lite smashes such as Livin' La Vida Loca would redeem himself so fluently? The Martin live experience combines elements of Robbie Williams, Liberace and Carmen Miranda, emphatically distancing him from sleepwalkers such as Boyzone. Two hours in his entertainingly vain company (typically, one video opens with a lengthy close-up of his own eyes) has a Michael Jacksonian effect - you don't want to like him, but can't help it.
fields.body:
On album, the former Enrique Morales gives every impression of being just another lantern-jawed bit of robopop trouser, albeit one with an exotic Latin twist. But on stage, who'd have thought that the purveyor of salsa-lite smashes such as Livin' La Vida Loca would redeem himself so fluently? The Martin live experience combines elements of Robbie Williams, Liberace and Carmen Miranda, emphatically distancing him from sleepwalkers such as Boyzone. Two hours in his entertainingly vain company (typically, one video opens with a lengthy close-up of his own eyes) has a Michael Jacksonian effect - you don't want to like him, but can't help it.

His first UK show rivalled Wacko's for visual bedazzlement. It's a huge operation, incorporating Pink Floydesque lights, filmic special effects and, at the end, a metal capsule that whisks Martin up and away to his reward. The opening Livin' La Vida Loca kicks off with a leather-rumped Martin acting out the "crazy life" lyric in a Cadillac that rises out of the floor, one of a dozen such set pieces.

Things move briskly, with interludes for homilies of the "Live for today, because tomorrow doesn't exist" sort, but it properly takes off in the salsa-clad second half. If Martin has more to offer musically than his competitors, it's because he grew up steeped in ebullient Puerto Rican rhythms, which he reproduces with a fantastic band and, shockingly, no backing tapes. The brass and percussion sections are old-school Latinos who gyrate through the Spanglish silliness of Shake Your Bon-Bon as cheerfully as they do the more authentic stuff. They steal the show so comprehensively that Martin becomes peripheral, though he obviously doesn't think so.

It goes to show that you never can tell. What threatened to be a corporate-pop ego-fest turns into a fine time. Who knows what Boyzone could do with a decent backing band?
***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

Things move briskly, with interludes for homilies of the "Live for today, because tomorrow doesn't exist" sort, but it properly takes off in the salsa-clad second half. If Martin has more to offer musically than his competitors, it's because he grew up steeped in ebullient Puerto Rican rhythms, which he reproduces with a fantastic band and, shockingly, no backing tapes. The brass and percussion sections are old-school Latinos who gyrate through the Spanglish silliness of Shake Your Bon-Bon as cheerfully as they do the more authentic stuff. They steal the show so comprehensively that Martin becomes peripheral, though he obviously doesn't think so. It goes to show that you never can tell. What threatened to be a corporate-pop ego-fest turns into a fine time. Who knows what Boyzone could do with a decent backing band? ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Funds 'must alter mindset'
fields.trailText: Bolstering investment in venture capital, a central aim of the government in boosting productivity, would require a radical change in the "mindset" of pension fund managers, according to industry research published today.
fields.body:
Bolstering investment in venture capital, a central aim of the government in boosting productivity, would require a radical change in the "mindset" of pension fund managers, according to industry research published today.

Merrill Lynch Mercury, the country's biggest pension fund manager, believes greater support for venture capital from big institutional investors would require them to extend investment horizons to 10 years from three, and at the same demand an overhaul of the way the performance of pension funds is measured.

The stark conclusions of the Merrill Lynch Mercury report come as the government begins its investigation into whether City investors are driven by "systemic herd behaviour" which prevents them funding new industries as well as the "old" economy.

The investigation is led by Paul Myners, head of fund management group Gartmore and the chairman of Guardian Media Group, and is an important part of the chancellor Gordon Brown's aim to improve productivity in the economy.

It also follows the hard hitting inquiry by Don Cruickshank - now chairman of the stock exchange - into competition among the banks.

The Cruickshank review has led to a full-scale competition inquiry into the way in which banks treat small and medium sized businesses.

The Myners inquiry, which will be formally launched this week, is expected to analyse the way big investors inject finance into small business and will look at how pension fund trustees - who ultimately take the main decisions about the money in the funds - are chosen and what incentives they have.

Mr Brown wants to establish why it is that the country's pension funds put only 0.5% of their assets into venture capital. The US figure is closer to 5%, and in Britain venture capitalists receive only 13% of their backing from UK investors but 37% from overseas.

According to Peter Stanyer, head of strategic asset management at Merrill Lynch Mercury, pension fund trustees are interested in investing in the private equity market. That prompted the publication today of the report into private equity investment - broadly speaking venture capital - which disputes the standard premise that venture capital investment is too volatile for pension funds.

"The real risk is getting tied up for 10 years," said Mr Stanyer, who explained that pension fund trustees tend to review management of their funds every three years. That also suggests that the quarterly measurement of pension fund performance would also have to be altered, particularly as private equity investments may not show much return in the early years.

Pension funds investing in private equity should diversify investments, Mr Stanyer said. They should chose fund management firms to spread risk.

The government's decision to start a review at the same time at which pension funds themselves were scrunitising the private equity market was, Mr Stanyer said, a symptom of the fact that it is "a live issue".

webTitle: Halifax offers mortgage decision in one minute

fields.headline: Halifax offers mortgage decision in one minute
fields.trailText: Halifax will start offering more than 10,000 mortgage brokers and millions of potential homebuyers an online decision for a home loan within 60 seconds today.
fields.body:
Halifax will start offering more than 10,000 mortgage brokers and millions of potential homebuyers an online decision for a home loan within 60 seconds today.

The former building society, which sold a record £17.8bn of mortgages last year, will also enable customers to track the progress of mortgage applications on the internet.

The bank is developing two internet products, Halifax Online and Intelligent Finance; The latter had 5,000 applications last Monday for its new accounts which are being launched in June.

Halifax claims its online mortgage promise, launched today, is a first among mortgage lenders, but a tracking service is already offered by some brokers, including the largest, John Charcol.

The Halifax tracking system available in the summer, will enable customers and brokers to see when the bank has received the valuation report, confirmation of the customer's salary and whether the mortgage has been offered.

The Halifax move is the latest development in a race by the leading financial services companies to enhance their internet offerings.

Abbey National has also pledged to speed up the process of home buying with a similar on-line offering which it has spent £5m developing.
