fields.headline: In praise of free speech
fields.standfirst: Now that the conference season is in full swing, Judi James urges you to make the most of it
fields.trailText: As the conference season gets under way I'll wager a pound to a penny that your mantelpiece is as awash with invites as Scarlet O'Hara's was at the start of Gone With the Wind.
fields.body:
As the conference season gets under way I'll wager a pound to a penny that your mantelpiece is as awash with invites as Scarlet O'Hara's was at the start of Gone With the Wind.

Don't let the thought of skulking at the back row in some hotel room full of windbags put you off: no matter how dull the topic under discussion, conferences can mean good fun for everyone - apart from the speakers - so get along to as many as your attention span and training budget will allow.

Selection process

When picking your programme, always veer towards the driest-sounding subjects. There is a mathematical equation attached to conferences that goes something like:

Most boring topic = best venue (often abroad) + biggest 'apres-ski' bar binges

Event planners tend to know when they've been put in charge of a turkey and are only too aware they need to compensate attendees with a stonking good lunch and lots of free booze. Scintillating speakers tend to go hand-in-hand with stewed tea in vacuum flasks, a plate of soggy biscuits and a note on the programme saying delegates are free to go off and do their own thing at lunchtime.

Star guests

Alternatively you might like to forgo the smoked salmon starter and champagne on ice and head instead for the celebrity speaker. Many conferences sport one of these, with a view to getting bums on seats. Most have no conceivable connection with or knowledge of the subject under discussion, which tends to make them very good value for money, providing a gleam of light entertainment in among the business-related dross.

Any celebrity - however minuscule their fame - will be worth hearing, even if only to report back to the office how much shorter/fatter/more drunk/bewigged they are in real life.

There is also plenty of fun potential in watching once-famous faces being forced to enthuse wildly about subjects like dispatch notices, photocopier paper dispensers and hands-free vending packs.

Standing room only

Choose your seat carefully at any conference you attend and always be aware of your overall objectives. Are you there to: a) learn something? b) participate? c) heckle speakers? d) stuff your face? e) tackle your long-running battle with insomnia?

If your answer is 'a' you need to stay around the middle rows. If it's 'b' or 'c' you will have to head for the front, preferably in the seat slap-bang opposite the speaker. If you opted for 'd' then make sure you are next to the aisle and the nearest exit to the buffet. If it's 'e' then you'd best hang out close to the back and in a corner, preferably nowhere near the visual aid equipment or mikes.

Syndicate success

Some conferences split into syndicates in between the main lectures. You will often be asked to select your preferred topics in advance. It is vital to commit to nothing at this point, unless one particular speaker is known to you as a bit of a star. Make a mark under a few of the boxes, but make the mark virtually unintelligible. This will leave your options open. Take a quick look in the syndicate room in advance and feel free to change your mind at the last minute. Alarm bells should ring if you catch the speaker doing any or all of the following:

1. gibbering with fear
2. going through a pile of notes as thick as a telephone directory
3. unpacking anything that smacks of audience participation, like building block kits or jigsaws
4. getting drunk

Herd mentality

Always avoid the herd-a-nerd aspect of some of the larger conferences. This is where they check you in, badge you, and store your brains along with your coat. Play the game according to the rules while actually in the conference or you may miss out on essential moments, like when to break for the loo, but otherwise remember to become a drop-out. Never wear your badge in the street, like some of the sadder cases, and always dispose of the delegates' folder pack/canvas shoulder bag/baseball cap the moment you pass a litter bin.

Doing the room

Networking is one of the most useful byproducts of any conference. This is the place to press the flesh, make friends, get a new job, sell your flat or even meet a new partner. Never shy away in a dingy corner during breaks in the proceedings - get out there and get a new life.

webTitle: Phillips and goal-a-game Henry lead my team of season

fields.headline: Phillips and goal-a-game Henry lead my team of season
fields.trailText: When managers and coaches are attempting to build successful teams, they usually start from the back. In selecting my Premiership team of the year, however, I prefer to start from the front.
fields.body:
When managers and coaches are attempting to build successful teams, they usually start from the back. In selecting my Premiership team of the year, however, I prefer to start from the front, with Sunderland's Kevin Phillips and Arsenal's Thierry Henry. There aren't many back four men - particularly full-backs or wing-backs - who spring to mind as having had exceptional seasons so the focus begins up front.

The obvious reason for my selection of Phillips and Henry is that they have scored more goals than even Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole at Manchester United. Phillips has become only the third player to get 30 Premiership goals in a season while Henry, who joined Arsenal as a winger last summer and was only switched to the central striking role in November, has scored 26.

Henry's part in helping Arsenal to this season's Uefa Cup final and next season's Champions League is reflected by a superb recent record of at least one goal in each of his last 10 matches. Phillips has had to struggle to get where is he today, having been released by Southampton as a boy - when he was a right-back - and dropping into non-league football before getting another chance at Watford. This shows in his enthusiasm and his determination to make the most of his career.

There's no doubt a lot of promising youngsters can get too much success and praise too early. Phillips is a good example of the benefits of not having been 'spoilt'. In terms of attitude, I cannot think of a striker who has produced a better performance than he did in Sunderland's match at Coventry. He reminded me of Ian Rush, who was noted not just for the goals he scored for Liverpoool and Wales but for his work rate off the ball.

Whenever Liverpool lost possession deep in the opposing half, he was usually the player who would start their effort to get it back. He was probably the striker who best epitomised that old football concept of 'defending from the front'.

In that department, Phillips was no less prominent against us - even when we were 3-0 ahead. It was largely down to his example that Sunderland made it 3-2 (he deservedly scored their first goal), and came close to salvaging a point.

Technically, the great things about him are that he has what we call exceptionally 'quick feet', and can adjust himself into good shooting positions as expertly as anyone. Quite apart from being able to hit them in from both inside and outside the box, he is not bad in the air, either, for someone of his height.

Henry, who could never be described as anything but a top-class player when he operated on the wing, seems to be even better as a central striker. The irony, of course, is that he has appeared a more natural scorer than any of the men who filled the central striking roles in France's 1998 World Cup-winning team.

His pace is frightening, and for that reason alone, it is easy to appreciate why Arsenal's manager, Arsene Wenger, felt he would be an ideal replacement for Nicolas Anelka. Interestingly, Wenger has recently gone on record as saying that he considers Henry to be even quicker than Anelka and that other speed merchant, Marc Overmars, over 40 yards.

The big advantage of having someone like that in England is that opposing teams get quite neurotic about leaving too much space behind their defence. It forces them to think twice about pushing up and squeezing the play. That teams facing Arsenal tend to defend 10-15 yards deeper than they would against other sides means that the Gunners get greater scope to strike an effective rhythm in their build-up play.

Of all the other players I have chosen, I guess that the one that might create the most surprise is Marcel Desailly. He himself has been quoted as saying that he has not been entirely happy in the Premiership; and I have to admit that if I could have my pick of any of France's World Cup defenders, I would have to bypass both Desailly and his Chelsea colleague Frank Leboeuf in favour of Parma's Lillian Thuram. Who knows, if the rumours are true, he might be playing in the Premiership next season.

But Desailly has been a tremendous asset to Chelsea in the Champions League. Bearing in mind my earlier thoughts about it not having been a vintage season for defenders generally, in trying to put all the players who have impressed me into a team shape, I have had to plump for a back three rather than a back four. My team, in a 3-4-1-2 system:

Gordon Strachan's team of the season

Nigel Martyn (Leeds) Jaap Stam (Manchester United) Sammi Hyypia (Liverpool) Marcel Desailly (Chelsea) David Beckham (Manchester United) Roy Keane (Manchester United) Patrick Vieira (Arsenal) Harry Kewell (Leeds) Paul Scholes (Manchester United) Thierry Henry (Arsenal) Kevin Phillips (Sunderland)

webTitle: Olé for Spain while we are left with a load of bull

fields.headline: Olé for Spain while we are left with a load of bull
fields.trailText: There is very little of interest in today's games. The Premiership is in danger of becoming as boring as its Scottish equivalent
fields.body:
Today may be the official end of the Premiership season but in truth it ended before it even started, as no one really doubted Manchester United would once again walk away with the title.

Arsène Wenger maintains that the League bosses did everything they could to make sure Manchester United had no fixture congestion, which may be sour grapes on his part but, given the crass decision over the FA Cup, he does have a point. Giving United the chance to have a winter break in Rio and make millions at the same time was undoubtedly the worst decision the FA have made in years. It was partly because the Cup was devalued by the holders' absence that the competition became a non-event, confirmed when the FA decided to hold both semi- finals at Wembley.

It was claimed that this was because Wembley was about to be knocked down, but in reality it was to make more money. Football fans aren't that stupid and voted with their feet, ensuring that for the first time in living memory neither game was a sell-out.

The only interest in today's games is whether it will be Wimbledon or Bradford going down and who will get the third Champions League slot. The Premiership is in danger of becoming as boring as its Scottish equivalent where this year has been the same as the last dozen bar one. How Rangers must long for some real competition.

Not many weeks ago there was widespread talk of the Premiership being the best league in the world as Manchester United, Chelsea, Leeds and Arsenal looked capable of providing two all-English European finals. The fact that Spain at the time still had three teams left in the Champions League went almost unnoticed as we all sniggered at the demise of the Italians. Now we have an all-Spanish Champions League final.

Not only do we now have the first European Cup contested by two teams from the same country - but the Spanish League title race is still wide open. Kevin Keegan called the Spanish league 'Attack, attack, attack, my kind of football' and anyone who has followed the Spanish matches on Sky will testify to the level of excitement.

Barcelona and Real Madrid don't dominate like Manchester United here. In fact if you look at all the big European leagues none has yet been decided. In Germany Bayern Munich may have had a good run in the Champions League but are in danger of finishing behind Leverkusen. In Portugal Sporting Lisbon are just one point ahead of Porto.

The final stages of the Italian league have not just been back-page news but have made the front too. While many English fans believe the establishment favour Manchester United, in Italy there is a wide belief that there is a conspiracy to favour Juventus. Anyone watching the Channel 4 Serie A game last weekend between Juve and Parma would believe that to be true. The ref disallowed a perfectly good Parma equaliser that, had it stood, would have meant Juve and Lazio going into the last game of the season level on points rather than Juve being two ahead. The furious Lazio chairman said, 'Serie A is losing credibility and it is time to take action for the good of the game.' Paolo Di Canio put it a bit more bluntly when he said, 'Italian football has an illness eating away at its heart. I almost feel ashamed of being Italian.' Even so, the last day of the season today promises to be a good deal more exciting than in England, so it's Channel 4 rather than Sky that the discerning armchair fan will tune into.

Let's hope for something more competitive next season.

Let's hope for something more competitive next season.

webTitle: Hospitals to receive cash rewards for cutting waiting lists

fields.headline: Hospitals to receive cash rewards for cutting waiting lists
fields.trailText: The government is to introduce performance-related pay for hospitals in an attempt to raise standards in the NHS.
fields.body:
The government is to introduce performance-related pay for hospitals in an attempt to raise standards in the NHS.

Under plans being drawn up by the Department of Health, top performing hospitals will receive significant cash rewards for reducing waiting times and cutting the number of cancelled operations. Ministers are considering forcing hospitals to publish how they perform in a prospectus, which will also include information on cleanliness and quality of food.

So far, £60 million has been allocated to the performance pay scheme, but officials say that is just 'dipping a toe in the water'. A further £10m is to be announced this week to encourage hospitals to combat heart disease. This is the first time the Department of Health has distributed money solely on the basis of performance targets.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn has been particularly concerned that under-performing hospitals have virtually no incentive to catch up with better ones. Studies show that two hospitals in the same area with the same level of funding can have radically different levels of efficiency. The new measures are part of the National Plan to modernise the NHS, which will be announced in July. The National Plan - made in consultation with doctors and the public - is aimed at getting the best out of the rise in health spending announced recently by Chancellor Gordon Brown.

Officials have already drawn up the criteria for the cash top-ups. They include: inpatient and outpatient waiting times; being fully prepared for winter; number of cancelled operations; delayed discharges; number of trolley waits in accident and emergency; and whether they have implemented a sound financial management system.

The £10m to be announced this week will reward 22 projects solely on the basis of good performance at improving prevention and treatment of heart disease. Those winning the money include an electronic heart disease register for tracking people at risk, rapid-access chest pain clinics, as well as food co-ops that provide cheap vegetables in impoverished neighbourhoods, and a cooking club to encourage healthy eating.

Performance-related pay for hospitals will be backed by the new Commission for Health Improvement - described by Tony Blair as an Ofsted for the health service - which wills end teams of inspectors into hospitals. Those that do well will get the cash payments, while those that are failing could have teams of managers sent in.

Officials see the new hospital prospectuses as a way to help local people pressure their hospitals into better performance. The Department of Health has no plans to publish league tables for hospitals as the Department for Education and Employment does for schools, but information enabling others to do so will be publicly available.

In a speech to the Royal College of Surgeons on Thursday, Milburn will stress how he sees the approach as essential for improving standards. He is expected to say: 'It is neither fair on taxpayers or patients that too often good performance and bad performance sit side by side in the NHS.'

fields.headline: Explain... Gazza and Joondalup
fields.trailText: The biggest news of the week was almost Gazza's on-loan transfer to the Western Australia Soccer League side Joondalup city. It would hardly have been the most glamorous move of a career that has taken in the likes of Lazio, Rangers and Spurs, but it would have had its advantages.
fields.body:
The biggest news of the week was almost Gazza's on-loan transfer to the Western Australia Soccer League side Joondalup city. It would hardly have been the most glamorous move of a career that has taken in the likes of Lazio, Rangers and Spurs, but it would have had its advantages.

Joondalup, an aboriginal name which translates as 'place of glistening water', is a suburb of Perth, on Australia's west coast, and it is known for its large British expatriate population. The team's manager, Paul Simmons, was born and bred in Tyneside, which may explain his eagerness to tell the world about Gazza's imminent arrival 'We are towards the end of negotiations,' he said. 'How big is this for Australian soccer?'

'It would be a huge boost for Australian soccer,' says George Pendrigh, editor of British Soccer Week, a Perth-based magazine sold in newsagents across Australia, New Zealand and Singapore. 'I'm not sure if it'll happen, but this is a lovely part of the world and I'm sure that he would enjoy his time here.'

I'm sure he would. Perth not only boasts some of the best fishing around (Gascoigne is a renowned angler), but there's also the Swan Valley wine-growing region and mile upon mile of beautiful beach. And while the area might not be world renowned for its football, it's good enough to attract soccer academies run by Southampton and West Ham, which would share Gascoigne's home stadium, the Arena Joondalup.

Perhaps it's about time that, having creamed off much of Australia's best talent, we send them some of our own. Although it's less certain if Gazza still qualifies. And it's less certain still that he'll be going. 'I couldn't believe what I was hearing,' said Bryan Robson when he heard the 'news', 'I have never even heard of them.' He has now, but maybe that was the point.

fields.trailText:
King Kanoute in £12m switch
West Ham have beaten Chelsea in the race for Frederic Kanoute - by offering Marc-Vivien Foe in part-exchange. 'We've done a deal', says Harry Redknapp.
fields.body:
King Kanoute in £12m switch
West Ham have beaten Chelsea in the race for Frederic Kanoute - by offering Marc-Vivien Foe in part-exchange. 'We've done a deal', says Harry Redknapp.

Turks swoop for £8m flop Sutton
Turkish giants Fenerbahce have lined-up a shock £8m move for Chris Sutton: they plan to link him with £1.5m-rated Chelsea team-mate Gianfranco Zola.

Celtic go for curbs and Kinnear
Celtic are set to move for Charlton's Alan Curbishley or Joe Kinnear after managerial first choice Guus Hiddink demanded a £20m transfer budget.

And the rest...

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Swap seats for summer in slammer
fields.body:
Swap seats for summer in slammer

Touts and holders of black market Euro 2000 tickets face fines of 100,000 euros and up to three years in jail, organisers warned this week. Individual tickets, sent to fans in Britain last week, are identified by the holder's name: police have warned that rigorous identity checks should prevent any ticket transfer. 'Do not buy tickets on the black market and do not sell your ticket,' they warn. 'Those who do, risk fines and jail terms of six months to three years.' Some 97 percent of the 1.2m available tickets for the 31 games have already been sold, with the remainder set to be assigned in the next few weeks. So for everyone who landed seats for Slovenia v Norway in last year's ticket lottery and had been hoping to sell them on - enjoy the game.

Hague 'listens with interest'
Fat Les may have won the vote to record England's official Euro 2000 song, but one of the rejected artists isn't giving up. Billy Arthur's ' An English Millennium Anthem ' was spurned by the FA in favour of the Jerusalem remix - but Arthur believes his song remains a candidate for a new 'motivating, unifying English National Anthem'. So far he has sent copies to William Hague, Tony Adams, the England squad, national radio stations, and to us. Adams sent back a signed photo, Hague a Tory compliment slip, claiming he had 'listened with interest' - but Arthur won't stop until the CD makes it big. He's set up a website at www.billyarthur.com , and we've got three copies to give away: send your details to the address below.

Escort fillies chase horses
A flock of high-class escort girls have taken to targeting wealthy race-goers at Chester after exhausting the football-fan market. The ladies from La Femme Escort Agency handed out flyers to binocular-carrying punters at the three-day meeting last week. John O'Brien, the agency boss, said the Liverpool-based firm had a history of attending big sporting events: 'We already target big football matches and did a lot of business during Euro 96. But this is the first time we've hit the races so we'll have to wait and see what kind of a response we get.' Mr O'Brien denied the girls were lowering the tone. 'They are very up market ladies and they weren't asked to stop.'

New Italian shirts: 'Great for the ladies'
Italy have launched a brand new strip for Euro 2000 - a skintight outfit designed to prevent shirt-pulling by opponents, and, say the makers, to 'appeal to young ladies'. The high-collared azure blue outfit, made from lycra, allows players to reach the ball even when their shirts are being tugged. 'It also makes it easier for referees to see when a shirt is being pulled,' says designed Marco Boglione. The commercial clincher, though, is the unisex appeal. 'Our shirt stretches to accommodate all the curves of the body,' says Boglione, 'making it perfect for the ladies. We also studied the idea of making skintight shorts too, but in the end decided against it.' The shirt will make it's debut in the U21 game against England later this month.

Brooklyn.com set to clean up
Just days after Brooklyn Beckham's debut walk-about at Old Trafford, a Norwegian fan has set up the youngster's first tribute website - part of an online rush to cash in on the toddler's image. 'Brooklyn Pictures' has inspired a wave of punters to snap up Brooklyn-related domain names in the hope that companies negotiating to pay £8m for the rights to Beckham senior's image will also be keen on owning junior's online identity. According to John Holmes, head of SFX entertainment who represent the Beckham's online, 'Brooklyn hasn't played any part in our negotiations so far, but no doubt he will at some point.' Brooklynbeckham.co.uk and brooklyn-beckham.com are already taken - other permutations are in big demand.

Competition: see the FA Cup final
Win a top day out at next Saturday's FA Cup final courtesy of sponsors AXA by answering this, as-ever, simple question. Which of the following dietary supplements have not been taken by FA Cup finalists on the night before a final? a) nerve powder b) monkey gland powder c) steak, egg and rum cocktail. Send your answer to Axa competition, Observer Sport, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. The prize includes £100 travelling money for two people.

fields.headline: Wembley is just the beginning
fields.standfirst: George Boateng tells  Marie-José Kleef  why he believes Aston Villa are on the verge of becoming one of Europe's top teams
fields.trailText: George Boateng tells Marie-José Kleef why he believes Aston Villa are on the verge of becoming one of Europe's top teams
fields.body:
At least one Villa player is confident about next week's FA Cup final. 'The pressure lies with Chelsea. It will be very special,' he says. But George Boateng believes his club will have bigger fish to fry in the future. He dares to suggest that Aston Villa will be competing in the Champions League within two years.

Boateng is all smiles and laughter at Villa's training ground despite the pre-Wembley trials and tribulations. Why the confidence? It could be that Villa's manager, John Gregory, is taking him seriously.

With all his clubs, it has taken Boateng time to convince the coach that he is a central midfielder. At Villa, for the first time in his career the 24-year-old Dutchman feels completely at ease. The energetic ball-winner and fiery tackler has earned the privilege to operate in his favourite position, feels respected by the management and loved by the fans. Boateng was born in Ghana, lived in Accra with his mother until he was 10 and then moved to Holland to join his father, who lived near Rotterdam. He made his debut in Feyenoord's elite at 16, but it took another two years before he was a regular. In 1997 he left for Coventry to develop himself in a central midfield position.

'The Feyenoord manager fielded me wherever he needed someone. I had suddenly made a name for myself as a defender,' says the former Dutch Under-21 captain. 'But I believed I would have a lot more to offer in midfield. I saw my friend and team-mate Giovanni van Bronckhorst grow in that position and I thought I could do the same.'

Halfway through the 97-98 season he had had offers from Udinese and Deportivo La Coruna, but he chose relegation candidates Coventry because of manager Gordon Strachan. 'This great former player convinced me when he said he needed midfielders and gave me his word that I would play there.' The £250,000 Coventry paid for the youngster immediately proved a bargain - an inspired performance made him man of the match in his debut against Liverpool and later when he guided the team away from relegation danger.

'Finally I could show what I had had in mind all those years. I even started to surprise myself. When I saw myself on television I thought I was watching someone else. I had always known my worth to a team hugely depended on spirit and agility. I had never been one to dribble past three or four players to score a spectacular goal, but I even started doing that. The reason was my growing confidence and the trust that the manager put in me.'

That things turned ugly just a year later still bewilders Boateng, just as it does Stra chan, who has a different version of events. 'My relationship with Strachan had always been good. But around the time of the transfer to Aston Villa and after it all changed. I know the Coventry chairman was playing a clever game, but I was very disappointed in Strachan when he played along.

'I had been unhappy for some time when I told Strachan that I did not want to leave Coventry, but that I would like the chance to talk to other clubs if they would come for me,' says Boateng. 'Strachan had always told me that the team did not play the way he wanted when I was not in a central position, but as soon as Gary McAllister came back from his injury, Strachan dumped me wide on the right.'

In Coventry's 4-2 win at Villa Park last year Boateng impressed Gregory with a stunning performance and two goals. When Gregory officially enquired about him, he was turned down.

Soon after Coventry reported Aston Villa to the FA for making an illegal approach and accused former team-mate Dion Dublin of acting as a double agent to tempt Boateng. 'That hurt me the most. Dion is a good friend and he had done no such thing. I got a phone call from Strachan that I was allowed to talk to Aston Villa. They wanted to sell me. They needed the money to buy new players. But because I was a fans' favourite they needed someone else to take the blame.'

Boateng has now put matters behind him. 'My wife convinced me that I should give him a call to thank him for all he did for me at Coventry and I swallowed my anger and did. But if he ever comes to manage a top team and he wants to buy me, I would have to think twice.'

After his £4.5 million move to Aston Villa Boateng again did not immediately get the position he craved. But since his move to central midfield he has unmistakably been a key player in Villa's league and Cup success.

'My dream had always been to play in Italy or Spain, but that dream is fading because I feel at home in England. Aston Villa have the ambition and the players to get further than sixth in the table. Of all players only Benito Carbone is doubtful, the rest will stay. When you add the experience of Luc Nilis and maybe one or two other top players [he suggests compatriots Pierre van Hooijdonk and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink], we can make it to the Champions League. We could have done it this year if we had not had that winless streak in which we almost lost our manager in October.

'The chairman is very ambitious and wants to expand Villa Park, the manager got us through that rough period and the players are a tight-knit group. There are no rotten apples here. We are all moving in the same direction, have got nothing to hide and therefore nothing to lie about. I think I could very easily get used to that.'

fields.headline: A 2,000-mile train trek to Anna
fields.standfirst: Filming Channel 4's current adaptation of  Anna Karenina in Helsinki posed a few problems for director and non-flyer  David Blair  - just how would he travel all the way there from Scotland? (Putting the train inside a ferry from Hamburg helped...)
fields.trailText: Filming Channel 4's current adaptation of Anna Karenina in Helsinki posed a few problems for director and non-flyer David Blair - just how would he travel all the way there from Scotland? (Putting the train inside a ferry from Hamburg helped...)
fields.body:
I don't go on planes. I haven't been on one for 10 years and would be quite happy to see out the next decade in a similar fashion. So, when I accepted the job of directing Anna Karenina for Channel 4, to be filmed entirely on location in Poland and Finland, I knew that getting there would be part of the challenge.

If you'd asked me then how to travel from my home in Dumfriesshire to Helsinki solely by public transport, or, indeed, if it was even possible, I wouldn't have had a clue. Expecting an argument about the perceived eccentricities of my travel arrangements - why the hell should I fly? Dennis Bergkamp doesn't; neither does the hero of TV's The A-Team, B.A. Baracus ('I ain't goin' on no damn plane, fool!') - I was reluctant to completely commit to the job.

'Charlie,' I said to the producer, as we sat discussing the contract. 'Look, there's something we need to talk about...' He cut me off immediately. 'You're leaving on the 12 o'clock from Waterloo. You arrive in Warsaw at 9am the next morning. Your tickets are booked.' So, that was it; no more excuses. I was on my way.

Though we filmed the vast majority of Anna Karenina in Poland, February brought an unexpected thaw to Warsaw and the need to change to a colder location. The -20 C that we'd been told to expect never materialised, and it was simply not cold enough to shoot one vital scene involving two of the main characters, Levin and Kitty, meeting on an ice rink in the street.

The producers decided to move us to Finland. The temperatures were due to be between -3 and -10 ; cold enough for our purposes. We scheduled in two days filming in Helsinki. My flightless journey there would begin at my Scottish home very early on a Monday morning and end 2,000 miles later in the Finnish capital on Wednesday, in time to film the next day. I'm told it took even longer to book. Lisa, my assistant, used seven different travel agents over four days.

It's a 16-mile car journey from my home in Tynron to the railway station in Dumfries. From there, I made my way to Carlisle and then on to London, where I was due to catch the Eurostar from Waterloo to Brussels. It was great to know that all the arrangements had been made for me; that my route was mapped out and that all my tickets were booked and paid for. I could just sit back, relax and enjoy the jour ney. What a job! Remind me to direct more big-budget lavish costume dramas.

From Brussels, my trajectory would take me into and across Germany, to Denmark, on through Sweden and then, finally, across the Baltic Sea to Finland. Some of my changeover times between trains were very tight; only 12 minutes in Brussels and 14 minutes in Cologne. In fact, the train I was meant to get from Cologne to Hamburg was running 25 minutes late, which meant I would have missed my connection at the other end. A nice German lady spotted me scouring the timetable in a bewildered search. She very kindly pointed me in the direction of another train that would actually get me to Hamburg 40 minutes earlier. I found it on the other side of the station.

An amazing beast, the Metropolitan was an exclusive train catering for businessmen. A quarter of each carriage was an office and, once I'd paid my supplement of 30 marks (about £9.20) to ensure a place, I really felt as though I should take my shoes off; it was so clean and comfortable. You wouldn't get this sort of service on the Dumfries to Carlisle route, I can tell you.

Settled into my luxurious surroundings, I was free to admire the stunning sight of Cologne cathedral rising up in front of me at the end of the platform. I think that, of all the many staggering things I saw along a very interesting journey, this is the one that will stay with me most. There is something quite surprising about the way in which this amazing piece of religious architecture looks as though it has just been plonked at the end of a railway platform. For a moment you wonder which, like the chicken and egg, came first: the cathedral or the platform?

Other memories stand out almost dream-like from that long journey across Germany; a collage of feelings and sights garnered through the windows of moving trains. In Düsseldorf, I looked out of the window and saw what seemed to be a block of flats with big square windows and, by the bottom left-hand corner of each window, a number drawn in white paint. Behind the windows, I could just make out rows of women, clad in scanty underwear; prostitutes in a high-rise brothel. Quite a different take on sexual politics from that in Anna Karenina .

One overriding impression I gained as the trains passed through Dortmund, Düsseldorf, Cologne and then on through Bremen, Essen and Duisburg to Hamburg, is that the world has been taken over by McDonald's. That universal yellow 'M' hung in each of these cities, normally close to the stations - one of the first things any traveller would see on arrival. Warsaw too, had one. And I was greeted, upon my return to Dumfries, by a brand new 'M' hanging above a brand new restaurant, like some evil talisman. Nowhere is safe.

I learnt just how thorough the Germans are about their Customs points. No one ever asked to see my passport in Denmark or Sweden, but on entering and leaving Germany I was given the full treatment: roused from sleep by torchlight in my face, a big burly man standing over me, demanding to see my passport. I felt I was in some Steve McQueen movie.

As I moved from country to country, I started to realise just how convenient the euro could be. By the time I got to Helsinki, my pockets were full of Belgian francs, marks, Danish kroner, Swedish krona and Finnish markka. The coins get everywhere, like sand. I'm still finding them, weeks later.

The Metropolitan arrived in Hamburg at about 7.30pm on the Monday. The next leg was across the sea to Copenhagen. Not quite knowing what would happen at this point, I was surprised when the train ran straight on to the boat. There was a long echo throughout the hold of the ship as we hooked onto couplings and then, that was it. Passengers are free to get off and go to one of the ship's many bars and restaurants, or just stay on the train. Looking at the huge tethered locomotive, rolling in the opposite direction to the ship as the water got choppier, I was quite glad I had chosen to get off. The idea of getting seasick on a train was just a bit too surreal for me.

I stayed over in Copenhagen that night. It is a beautiful city, and I could have happily stayed longer, but my thoughts were on arriving for the shoot, so early next morning, I boarded a catamaran for the 45-minute ride to Malmo in Sweden. A lot of people commute from Malmo, which is a fairly small fishing town, over the water to the Danish capital. I was quite struck by the idea of commuting from one country to another, with a different language and different customs. Then I thought about travelling from Dumfries to London, and realised that I do exactly the same.

In Malmo, I boarded a train for Stockholm, whence I would pick up the boat that would take me on the final leg of my journey, across the frozen Baltic to Helsinki. I could feel it getting colder, the further north I went. Everywhere I looked in Sweden, I saw tree felling and realised what an important part wood plays in the lives of Swedes. All along the four-and-a-half-hour journey I kept looking up from the script I was working on to see more lumberjacks.

At about 5.30pm that day, I left Stockholm on board the Silja Princess, a gargantuan passenger ferry, dwarfing any boat I had ever been on. It takes more than two hours to clear all the little inlets around Stockholm; they are, apparently, incredibly tricky waters to negotiate and the going is slow. This is one of the busiest strips of water anywhere in Europe; ships leave Stockholm at intervals of between 12 and 15 minutes, and I was told that 12 major ferries full of people arrive in Helsinki every day.

The Finns, I discovered, are paranoid about drugs. They had no problem with traffickers until they joined the European Union, but now a lot of drugs are flowing into the country, and their Customs are ultra-strict. We ran into problems with them on the way back. The production team were stopped and searched, and a roll of film we had shot was opened by a suspicious officer. Exposed to the light, it was ruined. We lost a lot of shots that had captured the feel of the location.

The ship was so comfortable I felt I could have stayed on her for days. The contents of my cabin's mini-bar were all free of charge. I won't go into the carnage that followed this discovery, but, suffice to say it was a quite hungover Scotsman who woke early next morning to witness the approach into Helsinki. I think my hangover helped to make this incredible experience all the more visceral. On the horizon, I could see another massive ferry, looking almost as though it had been painted onto some beautiful white canvas.

As the alcohol drained out of my system in the freezing morning air, I was filled by a sheer joy to be alive and here, looking out at light glinting off the ice as we cut our path through it. Just hours earlier, smaller ice-breaker boats had been literally cutting through it, making a safe channel for our passage. In Scotland, I'm used to ponds freezing, but to think of the whole Baltic Sea becoming an icy mass was almost beyond my comprehension. It's quite incredible to be in a place where something so seemingly spectacular is the norm. In London, it only takes some heavy rain to bring everything to a grinding halt. Here I was in a part of the world where a foot of snow made no difference to public transport and a whole sea freezing was an everyday occurrence.

The Silja Princess arrived in Helsinki on the Wednesday morning, almost exactly 48 hours after I'd left Tynron. It had been cold in Scotland when I said goodbye to my wife and kids, but that was nothing compared with the temperatures we experienced in Finland. I think the Scots and English have different psychological approaches when it comes to the cold. We have to deal with it so much more and, living out in the Dumfriesshire countryside, I'd say I was pretty hardened to it.

I didn't suffer too much in Helsinki, but there was one night when I had to turn back from a planned walk, actually in pain from the sheer cold. I think the Finns and the Scots do have quite a bit in common; I even found that Helsinki reminded me of Glasgow in certain ways. The stone work and architectural design of many of the buildings are not dissimilar. I often think when I walk through Glasgow that the architecture at the back of buildings is even more interesting than that at the front. You've got to scout round, down the alleys, to see it. I found I was doing the same in Helsinki.

The Finns, like the Scots, enjoy a drink. In fact, the Finnish people seem obsessed with alcohol. It's not only that they drink a lot of it, it also seems to be their main topic of conversation. The ships around Helsinki are full of Finns stocking up on duty-free booze. Some boats don't even land anywhere, they just leave Finnish waters, skirt around for a bit and return to discharge their cargoes of people clinging to trolleys packed full of vodka, wine and beer.

I was viewed as something of a circus act by the people I met in Helsinki. I was the Scotsman who'd travelled all the way to their country by train because he didn't like flying. It wasn't long before I was lured into a good old Scots versus Finns drinking contest, though only once we'd finished filming, I have to state. Mika Karttunen, from the Finnish production crew, took me to a Helsinki nightclub just to get me completely wasted on as many different types of vodka as possible. I lost track of the types of drink that passed my lips that night: treacle-flavoured vodka, strawberry-flavoured vodka, orange-flavoured vodka, perhaps even vodka- flavoured vodka. I can't remember. What I do remember is Mika's father-in-law, a very dapper man who sported a monocle, smuggling out his own brogues to his son-in-law who, although otherwise equally immaculately dressed, was being refused entry because of his trainers. Another surreal moment from an incredible week.

I was exhausted by the time I left Helsinki on the Friday night on the 2,000-mile journey back to London, where I would start editing the film we had shot. All this travelling felt quite in the spirit of the film, really. Anna, Vronsky, Levin, Kitty and company would have had to endure days of travel on trains between Moscow and St Petersburg, and I doubt they would have had a free mini bar to get them through it. Cheers. Here's to not flying.

webTitle: Racing is a sure bet for families

fields.headline: Racing is a sure bet for families
fields.standfirst: Andy McSmith knows nothing about horses and his daughters know even less, but they still had a grand day out
fields.trailText: Andy McSmith knows nothing about horses and his daughters know even less, but they still had a grand day out
fields.body:
You have to be careful what you write as a journalist. A careless sentence can land you in court or, in my case, in the members' enclosure at Sandown Park racecourse.

It came about because of a throwaway sentence in a piece I wrote for Escape about the pleasures of visiting Egham, on the western edge of London, and being able to walk along the banks of the Thames. I said that for those who like more expensive pleasures, there were also several racecourses in the vicinity.

I have to be honest and say I had no idea whether going to the races was expensive, cheap, or somewhere in between. My knowledge of life alongside the track was restricted to a scene from My Fair Lady and a Marx Brothers' film. I suppose I expected an enclosure full of men in pork pie hats and tweed jackets, carrying expensive binoculars, and women dressed like Christine Hamilton. Any children who wandered in by mistake would, I imagined, be in severe danger of being served up for lunch.

However, United Racecourses, which owns most of the big London tracks, is in the middle of a drive to try to project racing as a cheap, accessible and family-friendly day out. That is why their publicity people called me out of the blue, and why I turned out on a Saturday morning, with my wife and two young daughters, at Sandown Park, near Esher, Surrey. It was the day of the Whitbread Cup, a big event in the racing calendar. The Queen Mum was there.

There is a strange rhythm to watching the races. It is not at all like football, though for short bursts, as the horses are heading for the winning line, the spectators become like soccer fans, shouting at their nags to hurry along. After these flashes of intense excitement, all goes calm suddenly, and the terraces empty as everyone crowds into the cafés or queues to collect their winnings.

Shouting at your horse to hurry along is an aspect of racegoing with which we are culturally familiar, because of the famous line in which Eliza Doolittle uttered the word 'arse', and nudged back the frontier of theatre censorship. But it is pointless. Neither horse nor jockey can possibly distinguish the shouts of their supporters from anyone else's. In the main race, when the winner was far enough out in front to be jumping fences alone, it is possible that the jockey could tell that the applause was for him alone, and that he was encouraged - and the rest of the pack discouraged by it - but I doubt it. Generally, all the noise can do is egg on all the runners indiscriminately.

There was one amiable exception to this rule. When a horse lagged spectacularly far behind, there would be an ironic round of applause as it ambled by. Then the jockey would certainly know that this was for him, but whether it helped, I could not say.

I don't know to what extent our girls, aged eight and six, could be said to have been exposed to the pleasures and pitfalls of gambling that day. They certainly had a good time, because we opted for a family-friendly system of picking winners, which I would not commend to anyone who wants to get rich. Basically, the girls looked at the list of runners and picked out the name which appealed most to them. They called it 'voting' for a horse.

You will not be astonished to know that by this democratic means, we blew all our complimentary vouchers on losers. But because the vouchers were given to us by Juliet, the racecourse company's public relations officer, it was their money if we lost, and ours if we won. Losing was the only decent thing to do. However, by the time our vouchers had run out and we took to betting with real money, we had picked up on the fact that there is enough useful information in the official guide to steer you away from foolish bets. I'm half ashamed to admit that we left carrying more money than we had brought with us, so our day was just about cost free.

Unfortunately, most people cannot go in as guests of the PR department, and therefore must part with some money. Nonetheless, it need not be as hard on the pocket as you might expect. Entrance is free for children under 16, so the only money you have to pay is the entrance fee for adults, which can be as low as £5 a head. Once inside, the refreshments are not cheap. The ice creams, for example, were £1.50 each. But you are not obliged to buy: you can bring your own picnic if you like.

The courses make a point of welcoming families with children. Three days in the Sandown Park calendar are designated family days, with clowns, jugglers, free pony rides, face painters and a roving jazz band. They have half a dozen such days at nearby Kempton Park. At all race meetings at both tracks, there is a free crèche for children under five, run by qualified staff. Although the day we were there was not a children's day, it was rounded off by a free rock concert. Despite the fact that there were two stag parties in progress, by my count, only two revellers had to be carried out for being objectionably legless. Not like a football crowd at all.

I don't know to what extent our girls, aged eight and six, could be said to have been exposed to the pleasures and pitfalls of gambling that day. They certainly had a good time, because we opted for a family-friendly system of picking winners, which I would not commend to anyone who wants to get rich. Basically, the girls looked at the list of runners and picked out the name which appealed most to them. They called it 'voting' for a horse. You will not be astonished to know that by this democratic means, we blew all our complimentary vouchers on losers. But because the vouchers were given to us by Juliet, the racecourse company's public relations officer, it was their money if we lost, and ours if we won. Losing was the only decent thing to do. However, by the time our vouchers had run out and we took to betting with real money, we had picked up on the fact that there is enough useful information in the official guide to steer you away from foolish bets. I'm half ashamed to admit that we left carrying more money than we had brought with us, so our day was just about cost free. Unfortunately, most people cannot go in as guests of the PR department, and therefore must part with some money. Nonetheless, it need not be as hard on the pocket as you might expect. Entrance is free for children under 16, so the only money you have to pay is the entrance fee for adults, which can be as low as £5 a head. Once inside, the refreshments are not cheap. The ice creams, for example, were £1.50 each. But you are not obliged to buy: you can bring your own picnic if you like. The courses make a point of welcoming families with children. Three days in the Sandown Park calendar are designated family days, with clowns, jugglers, free pony rides, face painters and a roving jazz band. They have half a dozen such days at nearby Kempton Park. At all race meetings at both tracks, there is a free crèche for children under five, run by qualified staff. Although the day we were there was not a children's day, it was rounded off by a free rock concert. Despite the fact that there were two stag parties in progress, by my count, only two revellers had to be carried out for being objectionably legless. Not like a football crowd at all.

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst: Dries Aabouz, Head Concierge:     American Hotel, Amsterdam
fields.trailText:
Any celebrity guests?
We have lots of people from the music world, such as David Bowie, Tina Turner and Eric Clapton. Take That stayed many times and were very funny. We also get many artists and actors. Although Amsterdam is not so big, it is a very cosmopolitan city.
fields.body:
Any celebrity guests?
We have lots of people from the music world, such as David Bowie, Tina Turner and Eric Clapton. Take That stayed many times and were very funny. We also get many artists and actors. Although Amsterdam is not so big, it is a very cosmopolitan city.

Any unusual requests?
I have been a concierge here for 11 years and of course there have been strange requests during that time. But we are always very private. Our work is to make our guests feel happy, so I have to care about everything.

What about a night out?
There is a very good restaurant at the American Hotel, and our sister hotel, the Amstel, has a Michelin starred restaurant, La Rive, which is one of the best in Holland. It is in a nice location, overlooking a canal, and the menu is French cuisine. However, the American Hotel is probably the best place for breakfast. It really depends what guests want, because there is food from all over the world here: Indonesian, African, Italian, Japanese. The Nightwatch bar is very famous, and there are lots of cafes and bars around Rembrandtplein and Leidseplein.

What about sightseeing?
I recommend visiting some of the bigger museums, such as the Van Gogh, Rembrandt and Anne Frank museums. The markets are also interesting: there is a good antiques market in Waterlooplein. We have four main canals in Amsterdam, with many boats, which are always popular with tourists, but if you want a little more privacy we can make a reservation for a water taxi, which seats up to eight people, so you can explore the canals with your own guide. The most beautiful canal is Prisengracht, which is named after William of Orange. It is not too far from the hotel, and the best residential areas are around this canal. Also, if Leidseplein is too busy, try the area around Concertgebouw, which is much quieter and is the place to go for classical music concerts. Holland is famous for flowers and this is the best time of year to see them. There are more than 500 types of tulip at the Keukenhof flower park. The gardens are about one hour from Amsterdam and are open for the next two months. All along the way there are spectacular fields of tulips.

What happens on Queen's Day?
Queen's Day was the weekend before last and everyone comes to Amsterdam for a very big party to celebrate Queen Beatrix's birthday. It is a hell of a day, but unfortunately I had to go to London to see my brother.

American Hotel: 00 31 20 556 3205

La Rive: 00 31 20 622 6060

Keukenhof Flower Gardens: 00 31 252 46 5555

fields.headline: Elysées come, Elysées go...
fields.standfirst: Desmond Balmer  checks into  a mansion  and finds that  timeshares have been given a welcome makeover
fields.trailText: Desmond Balmer checks into a mansion and finds that timeshares have been given a welcome makeover
fields.body:
The Rue de Berri is typical of the streets that radiate off the Arc de Triomphe end of the Champs-Elysées. There are a couple of smart hotels, a scattering of designer clothes stores and some small bar/brasseries. Inevitably, the street bears some of the scars of international branding: a Chicago Pizza Pie Factory stands across the street from a Firkin pub. But what could be more French than the turn-of-the-century mansion on the corner of the Rue d'Artois with its art nouveau styling? Look again, for this is the Paris Residence, part of a new wave of timeshare development that originated in Edinburgh.

This is timeshare, but not as you know it. The Paris Residence is being converted into 33 self-contained suites supported by all the usual hotel facilities with a concierge and a 24-hour room service menu. It was the ideal venue for my outing last weekend with my three sons aged 19, 23 and 25. When I ran out of steam, I could retreat to my classic suite - a living space larger than the average hotel bedroom decorated in period style with high ceilings and large traditional windows with wrought-iron balconies - while they continued to play in their grand suite with its separate living room and a bathroom large enough to hold a party (which it probably did).

We had billed this as our stag weekend (mine as it happens) but it was really a rite of passage, a chance to spend time together after five testing, but rewarding, years since their mother died. And where better to spend this time than in Paris? The Residence may have Edinburgh influences (and English was the lingua franca ) but we intended to celebrate in French style. When manager Kevin Gunn told us that the cheapest beer in Paris was to be found in the Bowler pub just around the corner, we smiled knowingly. This was not for us. Of course, after several beers in a streetside cafe and a Vietnamese meal we ended up in the Bowler, though I compromised by ordering a calvados.

I was first to leave the Bowler in the early hours and wasn't surprised when the boys were slow to start on the Saturday morning. This turned to our advantage for after a late breakfast (or rather an early lunch) in a square opposite the Bourse we were able to walk straight into the Pompidou Centre (there were lengthy queues when we left in mid-afternoon). We were entertained by the post-1960 work on the fourth floor and engaged by the scale of the collection on the fifth (from 1905 to 1960) where there seemed to be a Picasso at every turn.

Just as exciting were the views on every side of the city of light shimmering in the haze of a spring heatwave. The Sacré Coeur drew us like a magnet to Montmartre where the streets were crowded and the portrait painters were busy as usual making their subjects look years younger. A cut down a sidestreet to the Métro at Pigalle led to an interesting encounter with a flamboyant transvestite: we fled back to the Champs-Elysées where we stopped in a small bar for refreshment. We were the only customers, but the landlord secured a second round when he switched the television to show live coverage of Munster overcoming Toulouse in rugby's Heineken Cup semi-final.

As we passed the Bowler on our way back to change for the evening, we realised it was just 4.45pm at home, that special moment of the week when the football results flood in. The televi sion was tuned to Gillette Soccer Saturday on Sky. The boys sat with their pints of Heineken watching the dramas unfold. Watford might be going down to the first division but they secured a draw at Middlesbrough. It gave them particular pleasure when Luton were pegged back by a 90th-minute equaliser. I watched them with a surge of affection knowing how this inherited ritual continues to puzzle any woman who has known us well.

Now we switched to a full-bodied French flavour, with a little help from a friend - regular Escape writer John Brunton, who has the knack of finding those bars and restaurants locals prefer to keep to themselves. He recommended L'Ebauchoir, a bistro in the back streets of Aligre in the Bastille area, with tiled floors, wooden tables and an informal but electric atmosphere. We sat at an alcove table, underneath a vast, colourful mural. The menus, chalked on giant blackboards handed round the tables, were on the face of it traditional - carré d'agneau, jus aux thyme; confit de canard maison; veal and lots of fish. But the flavours were subtle with variations such as calves' liver with coriander and honey.

There was a great buzz as extended families as well as the smart-but-casual set tucked into their food. The pleasures of the table seem always to be heightened in Paris. Even with an indulgent bottle of Gevrey Chambertin, the bill for three courses each came to just 874 francs (£83). On Sunday morning we returned to the Bastille to follow up another recommendation by visiting the Marche D'Aligre, a jam-packed fruit, vegetable and flea-market. Crates were stacked outside the Baron Rouge bar to form tables where those in the know enjoyed glasses of wine from the barrel and plates of crevettes and cold meat. Our verdict was unanimous: 'John Brunton rocks.'

Eurostar seemed to speed us too quickly away from Paris, yet the value of the train and tunnel combination is that the journey connects you with the changing landscapes of France and England in a real timescale: in fact, just what the weekend had done for our lives together.

 A flexible week's timeshare for a classic suite at the Paris Residence costs from 97,250 francs (£9,260) plus 8,898 francs (£850) in taxes and fees while a grand suite starts at 122,500 francs (£11,670) plus 10,287 (£980). This buys seven nights a year for 20 years which can be taken outside new year, Easter and major sporting events. There is an annual maintenance fee of 2,950 francs (£280 ) for a classic suite and 3,450 francs (£330) for a grand suite. Details from 0131 226 3380.The week can be exchanged from a choice of 3,000 worldwide resorts through RCI.

 Eurostar (0990 186 186) return fares from £69.

 L'Ebauchoir: 00 331 43 42 49 31. Bookings essential.

 60 per cent of owners swap for another resort
 British ownership doubled in the past 10 years

webTitle: The star of the season: Renee Zellweger

fields.headline: The star of the season: Renee Zellweger
fields.trailText: 'I'm the dork that got lucky' says Renee Zellweger. So what is it about the star of Nurse Betty, Me Myself and Irene, and the forthcoming Bridget Jones
fields.body:
Renee Zellweger had a slow start in movies but with a starring role in the Farrelly Brothers' Me, Myself & Irene , everything's going fine now. The film is a safe bet for the biggest comedy of the summer. And she's going out with her co-star Jim Carrey.

But until recently people seemed to have trouble remembering who she was. First, there's her name. Agents used to tell her to change it. 'I think it's great. I mean, Schwarzenegger - what's that? How are you going to complain about Zellweger?'

And then there's the fact that although people sort of recognise her, they often think she's singer-songwriter turned actress Jewel. Or Chasing Amy star Joey Lauren Adams.

Jerry Maguire almost changed all that, when she was chosen to play Tom Cruise's love interest in the 1996 hit.

'She's a Billy Wilder-style heroine. She cries when she could be laughing, and laughs when she could be crying,' said director Cameron Crowe.

Yet it has taken her four years to make another hit movie. But with the title role in Neil LaBute's Nurse Betty coming up later in the year, followed by Bridget Jones - which should be a hit if her English accent holds up - the 31-year-old from Katy, Texas, seems to have it made. Not that she is too carried away. In her own assessment: 'I'm the dork that got lucky.'

fields.headline: Rome with a view
fields.standfirst: Ridley Scott's exhilarating and ferocious Gladiator brings the epic back to life
fields.trailText: Gladiator is at once gloomy and exciting, oppressive and exhilarating, though at times the plot is somewhat puzzling, says Philip French.
fields.body:
Britain is a nation that for centuries has dispatched its violently inclined citizens to do their dirty work abroad, in the colonies or, more recently, in Hollywood. Ridley Scott, one of our most gifted directors of commercials and a most impressive exponent of screen violence, has yet to make a movie set in this country.

No one could accuse him of being squeamish and his directorial debut in 1977, The Duellists, featured a succession of brutally painful sabre fights between two French officers in the Napoleonic Wars. The extraterrestrial monster leaping from John Hurt's stomach in Alien is among the most shocking moments in movie history, and now in Gladiator, Scott's best film since Thelma and Louise, he's revived the bloodiest of action genres.

Roman history was the chief topic of the Italian epics before the First World War, while Mussolini encouraged another wave of such pictures in the Thirties to celebrate his own imperial ambitions. Meanwhile, Hollywood got in on the act with the silent Ben-Hur of 1924.

The need to meet the challenge of TV with spectacular entertainments and bigger screens brought about a revival of the costume epic in the Fifties, with new film versions of the Victorian novels Quo Vadis? and Ben-Hur, and pictures based on more recent books such as The Robe and Barabbas, many shot at what became known as Hollywood-on-the-Tiber.

They usually contrasted Roman decadence with Christian spirituality, though for all their piety the selling point was brutal combat in the arena rather than prayers in the catacombs.

In April 1964, the month Anthony Mann's The Fall of the Roman Empire premiered in London, there also opened with less fanfare five dubbed Italian epics of the sort known in Italy as 'peplums' (named for the short tunics the heroes wore) and elsewhere as sword and sandal sagas, among them Caesar the Conqueror, Battles of the Gladiators and Gladiators Seven.

But the glut of such movies and the catastrophic box-office failure of the prestigious, all-star Fall of the Roman Empire brought the cycle to a sudden end. Since then, Christians have been thrown to the lions and Roman legionnaires have marched into battle only for laughs, as in the Asterix comedies and Monty Python's Life of Brian.

So here's Ridley Scott in deadly earnest bringing us the most ferocious picture of its kind since Richard Fleischer's Barabbas. But there is no reference to Christianity in Gladiator. It's about the undoing and attempted restoration of civilised values and covers the very events treated in The Fall of the Roman Empire - the death of the stoic Emperor Marcus Aurelius in AD 180, his failed attempt to appoint a worthy successor and the disastrous 13-year rule of his corrupt son, Commodus, from which point Gibbon charts the imperial decline.

Like Scott, Anthony Mann was a great visual stylist and a master of screen violence. But in The Fall of the Roman Empire, he tried to be too tasteful: before the first blood is shed, there's 45 stately minutes of fancy dialogue between the emperor and his Greek counsellor and beautifully composed shots of a spectacular gathering of regional leaders.

Scott doesn't make this mistake. His picture starts with the Roman army on a muddy battlefield near the Danube, straining like greyhounds in the slips to be unleashed on the howling barbarian hordes by their heroic Spanish-born general, Maximus (Russell Crowe). 'What we do in life echoes in eternity,' he tells his troops, establishing the film's principal theme of confronting death and destiny.

Suddenly, flaming arrows fly through the air, catapults unleash balls of fire that explode above the enemy. The centurions advance accompanied by the cavalry and a hand-to-hand battle ensues, with Maximus in the vanguard. The rapid editing gives way to slow motion and an elegiac soundtrack. This is a final costly victory for tired, tested men and a knock-out overture.

When the battle is over, the effete Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) arrives in a Roman equivalent of a movie star's trailer. 'Have I missed the battle?' he asks his father. 'You have missed the war,' says Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris, who has an uncanny resemblance to Alec Guinness in Mann's picture).

The functional dialogue is pared down and rarely lapses into old-fashioned Hollywood historic or high-flown Christopher Fry poetic. Marcus wants Maximus, a fictitious character, to succeed him and make Rome a republic again. But Commodus kills his ailing father, sentences Maximus to death for treason and becomes Caesar.

From then on, the film pits the decent, civic warrior against the libertine villain, the man who, in Gibbon's words, had 'an aversion to whatever was rational or liberal, and a fond attachment to the amusements of the populace: the sports of the circus and amphitheatre, the combats of gladiators and the hunting of wild beasts'.

After turning the tables on his executioners, Maximus embarks on a long voyage home that is like a cross between the travels of Ulysses after the fall of Troy and the travails of Spartacus as slave and enforced gladiator. It is a journey of revenge that brings him from the dusty eastern fringes of the empire back to a Rome corrupted by Commodus.

The movie is at once gloomy and exciting, oppressive and exhilarating, though at times the plot is somewhat puzzling. Its Rome is as grand as that of past movies, but a harder, harsher place, and the succession of battles in the arena are electrifyingly staged, imaginatively varied and increasingly ferocious. Enthralling and appalling, the gladiatorial combat appeals to much that is primitive and atavistic in us, but we experience it through a true hero who has lost everything except his dignity and his will to survive.

There are attractive performances from Oliver Reed (as an ex-gladiator turned arena impresario), Derek Jacobi (happily back in a toga as an honest senator 25 years after I Claudius) and the statuesque Djimon Hounsou as the hero's resigned African friend.

But the movie is dominated by Russell Crowe's towering Maximus, a man of intelligence, probity and Roman virtue. He's the most virile presence in a film of this kind since Richard Burton commanded the widescreen in The Robe, in 1953. Following on from L.A. Confidential and The Insider, Crowe confirms his position as one of the best star character actors around.

When I read that Ridley Scott's next subject was to be Hannibal I naturally supposed that he was going to celebrate Rome's most formidable enemy, whose defeat is bloodily restaged at the Colosseum in Gladiator like an ancient version of a video game. The hero of his next film, however, is Hannibal Lecter, who'd feel very much at home as Commodus's dinner guest.

So here's Ridley Scott in deadly earnest bringing us the most ferocious picture of its kind since Richard Fleischer's Barabbas. But there is no reference to Christianity in Gladiator. It's about the undoing and attempted restoration of civilised values and covers the very events treated in The Fall of the Roman Empire - the death of the stoic Emperor Marcus Aurelius in AD 180, his failed attempt to appoint a worthy successor and the disastrous 13-year rule of his corrupt son, Commodus, from which point Gibbon charts the imperial decline. Like Scott, Anthony Mann was a great visual stylist and a master of screen violence. But in The Fall of the Roman Empire, he tried to be too tasteful: before the first blood is shed, there's 45 stately minutes of fancy dialogue between the emperor and his Greek counsellor and beautifully composed shots of a spectacular gathering of regional leaders. Scott doesn't make this mistake. His picture starts with the Roman army on a muddy battlefield near the Danube, straining like greyhounds in the slips to be unleashed on the howling barbarian hordes by their heroic Spanish-born general, Maximus (Russell Crowe). 'What we do in life echoes in eternity,' he tells his troops, establishing the film's principal theme of confronting death and destiny. Suddenly, flaming arrows fly through the air, catapults unleash balls of fire that explode above the enemy. The centurions advance accompanied by the cavalry and a hand-to-hand battle ensues, with Maximus in the vanguard. The rapid editing gives way to slow motion and an elegiac soundtrack. This is a final costly victory for tired, tested men and a knock-out overture. When the battle is over, the effete Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) arrives in a Roman equivalent of a movie star's trailer. 'Have I missed the battle?' he asks his father. 'You have missed the war,' says Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris, who has an uncanny resemblance to Alec Guinness in Mann's picture). The functional dialogue is pared down and rarely lapses into old-fashioned Hollywood historic or high-flown Christopher Fry poetic. Marcus wants Maximus, a fictitious character, to succeed him and make Rome a republic again. But Commodus kills his ailing father, sentences Maximus to death for treason and becomes Caesar. From then on, the film pits the decent, civic warrior against the libertine villain, the man who, in Gibbon's words, had 'an aversion to whatever was rational or liberal, and a fond attachment to the amusements of the populace: the sports of the circus and amphitheatre, the combats of gladiators and the hunting of wild beasts'. After turning the tables on his executioners, Maximus embarks on a long voyage home that is like a cross between the travels of Ulysses after the fall of Troy and the travails of Spartacus as slave and enforced gladiator. It is a journey of revenge that brings him from the dusty eastern fringes of the empire back to a Rome corrupted by Commodus. The movie is at once gloomy and exciting, oppressive and exhilarating, though at times the plot is somewhat puzzling. Its Rome is as grand as that of past movies, but a harder, harsher place, and the succession of battles in the arena are electrifyingly staged, imaginatively varied and increasingly ferocious. Enthralling and appalling, the gladiatorial combat appeals to much that is primitive and atavistic in us, but we experience it through a true hero who has lost everything except his dignity and his will to survive. There are attractive performances from Oliver Reed (as an ex-gladiator turned arena impresario), Derek Jacobi (happily back in a toga as an honest senator 25 years after I Claudius) and the statuesque Djimon Hounsou as the hero's resigned African friend. But the movie is dominated by Russell Crowe's towering Maximus, a man of intelligence, probity and Roman virtue. He's the most virile presence in a film of this kind since Richard Burton commanded the widescreen in The Robe, in 1953. Following on from L.A. Confidential and The Insider, Crowe confirms his position as one of the best star character actors around. When I read that Ridley Scott's next subject was to be Hannibal I naturally supposed that he was going to celebrate Rome's most formidable enemy, whose defeat is bloodily restaged at the Colosseum in Gladiator like an ancient version of a video game. The hero of his next film, however, is Hannibal Lecter, who'd feel very much at home as Commodus's dinner guest.

fields.headline: Summer 2000 preview
fields.standfirst: The Observer's guide to this summer's biggest movies
fields.trailText: THE VIRGIN SUICIDES
fields.body:
THE VIRGIN SUICIDES

Stars: James Woods, Kathleen Turner, Kristen Dunst, Josh Harnett
The pitch:: The not-so Wonder Years
The story:: The parents of five teenage Catholic girls forbid romance with tragic consequences. Director Sofia Coppola proves she's more than just Daddy's girl with this impressive debut.
The prospects:: Boosted by positive reviews stateside and a well-received festival screenings, The Virgin Suicides should emerge as one of the best indie films of the year.
(Released on Thursday)

RULES OF ENGAGEMENT (pictured)

Stars: Samuel L. Jackson, Tommy Lee Jones, Guy Pearce
The pitch:: A Few Good Men need Courage Under Fire.
The story:: A taut military courtroom drama/thriller. Jackson's colonel is accused of breaking warfare rules by killing civilians, so he enlists his Vietnam buddy-now-lawyer Jones to prepare his defence.
The prospects:: The partnership of two veteran scene-stealers is inspired casting, though this genre has been much seen in recent years.
(Released on 26 May)

SWEET AND LOWDOWN

Stars: Sean Penn, Samantha Morton, Uma Thurman
The pitch:: All that Jazz meets Bullets Over Broadway.
The story:: Woody Allen's biopic of fictional Thirties jazz guitarist (Penn) who is talented but self-destructive. The film focuses on his rollercoaster career and long-suffering girlfriend played by Morton.
The prospects:: Pretty good. A light-hearted meditation on the nature of creativity is spiced by Allen's trademark barbs and witticisms.
(Released on 9 June)

CHICKEN RUN

Stars: The voices of Mel Gibson, Julia Sawalha, Miranda Richardson, Timothy Spall, Jane Horrocks
The pitch:: The Great Escape meets Animal Farm.
The story:: This animated comedy from the creators of Wallace and Gromit is set on an authoritarian battery farm from where the resident hens plan to escape. Their hopes are boosted by the arrival of an American rooster (Gibson) whose confidence is infectious.
The prospects:: Aardman Animations have spent the past three years working on their first feature film and its quaint charm conforms to a tried and tested formula.
(Released on 30 June)

MISSION: IMPOSSIBLE 2

Stars: Tom Cruise, Thandie Newton, Anthony Hopkins, Dougray Scott, Ving Rhames
The pitch:: More thrills and spills than the first one - and this time a plot, too.
The story:: An audacious terrorist tries to hold the world to ransom with a deadly virus. The franchise takes a OO7 twist as Cruise gets a high-powered girlfriend (Newton) and faces a charismatic foe (Scott). The introduction of director John Woo offers the prospect of balletic set pieces.
The prospects:: Woo should inject a sense of style and spectacle to ensure it's better than the first one. Critical acclaim may prove elusive again, but that's unlikely to affect box-office success.
(Released on 7 July)

THE PATRIOT

The stars: Mel Gibson, Heath Ledger, Joely Richardson, Chris Cooper
The pitch:: Braveheart goes West. The story:: Set during the American Revolution. Gibson plays a war hero whose family idyll is shattered when his son is captured. This $80m epic has an intriguing pedigree: written by Robert Rodat ( Saving Private Ryan ) and directed by Roland Emmerich ( Godzilla, Independence Day ).
The prospects:: Mel Gibson earned $25m for playing a character with shades of Mad Max .
(Released on 14 July)

HIGH FIDELITY

Stars: John Cusack, Iben Hjejle
The pitch:: The end of The Rock 'n' Roll years.
The story:: Based on Nick Hornby's best seller, but relocated to Chicago. Cusack stars as the thirtysomething slacker who lavishes attention on his massive vinyl collection rather than commitment on his discontented girlfriend (Hjejle).
The prospects:: Faithful to the novel, High Fidelity is a fine example of textured and whimsical Hollywood entertainment.
(Released on 21 July)

THE PERFECT STORM

Stars: George Clooney, Mark Wahlberg, Karen Allen
The pitch:: The War of the Waves
The story:: Based on Sebastian Junger's non-fiction best seller about the crew of a fishing boat as it battles against the ferocious elements.
The prospects:: An atypical summer offering, but director Wolfgang Petersen has talked up the huge special effects.
(Released on 28 July)

GONE IN 60 SECONDS
Stars: Nicolas Cage, Angelina Jolie, Giovanni Ribisi, Vinnie Jones
The pitch:: On the Road and on the lam.
The story:: Remake of the 1974 B-movie. A car thief (Cage) plans to retire after stealing 50 cars in one day aided by his crew. Unfortunately, other crims have their eyes on the motors.
The prospects:: This big-budget action thriller reunites producer Jerry Bruckheimer and star Cage following their big hits The Rock and Con Air . Enough said, really.
(Released on 4 August)

TITAN AE

Stars: The voices of Matt Damon, Bill Pullman, Drew Barrymore
The pitch:: Stars Wars meets Ferris Bueller's Day Off.
The story:: Animated adventure sci-fi about a teenage boy (Damon) who must save the human race from extinction by aliens. It's a dark fantasy aimed at the teen audience and inspired by moody comic books
The prospects:: Fifteen writers worked on the script at different times so there should be a few good lines.
(Released on 18 August)

X-MEN

Stars: Patrick Stewart, Ian McKellen, Halle Berry, Anna Paquin
The pitch:: Supermen and Superwomen
The story:: Based on the adventures of America's favourite comic book heroes, X-Men is a futuristic fight between good and evil.
The prospects:: Internet hype has made this one of the most anticipated films of the season despite a lack of A-list names. After Apt Pupil , director Bryan Singer needs a hit.
(Released on 18 August)

ME, MYSELF AND IRENE

Stars: Jim Carrey, Renee Zellweger
The pitch:: There's Something About Schizophrenia
The story:: Another funfest from the Farrelly Brothers. Carrey's unassuming state trooper has a split personality, both of whom fall in love with Irene (Zellweger).
The prospects:: The Farrellys' comedy instincts seldom fail and with Carrey on board in non-dramatic role, Me, Myself and Irene looks like a sure bet.
(Released late summer)

SHAFT

Stars: Samuel L. Jackson, Vanessa Redgrave, Jeffrey Wright
The pitch:: Return of the (Leather) Mac.
The story:: Jackson is not Shaft but his nephew and this is not a remake but an update - okay? You know what to expect: a new take on the Seventies blaxploitation classic.
The prospects:: The concept feels right, if unadventurous.
(Released late summer)
