webTitle: Susan Lynch's portrayal of James Joyce's wife

fields.headline: Susan Lynch's portrayal of James Joyce's wife
fields.trailText: As far as Ewan McGregor was concerned, Susan Lynch had to play Nora Barnacle, James Joyce's muse and wife. Although McGregor and Lynch hit it off during their first screen test, it was five years before cameras actually starting rolling on Nora, the story of the literary couple's tempestuous relationship. The film got stuck in development, better-known actresses were proposed, but McGregor, a partner in the film's production company Natural Nylon, held firm.
fields.body:
As far as Ewan McGregor was concerned, Susan Lynch had to play Nora Barnacle, James Joyce's muse and wife. Although McGregor and Lynch hit it off during their first screen test, it was five years before cameras actually starting rolling on Nora, the story of the literary couple's tempestuous relationship. The film got stuck in development, better-known actresses were proposed, but McGregor, a partner in the film's production company Natural Nylon, held firm.

Lynch repaid his faith with a captivating performance that anchors the film. For the 28-year-old Irish-born actress the role of the proud, flame-haired hotel chambermaid who fell for one of the titans of twentieth-century literature held obvious appeal. 'She was unconventional, very complex, very anarchic,' she says. 'I was quite shocked when I found out they were so ahead of their time. They met in 1904 and didn't marry until 1934, which was considered scandalous.'

Now James Joyce purists angry at the strong language and sexual frankness have attacked Nora, but Lynch is unimpressed. 'During his own lifetime he was reviled by many as a pornographer in exile,' she bristles. 'It's a fact he cursed a lot in his letters. This wasn't a conscious decision made by actors and directors to make the characters say "fuck" a lot.'

Playing the role clearly touched Lynch. She read Nora's biography twice and visited her birthplace in Galway although, 'there is something creepy about real people, you feel like you're stalking in their tracks'. And since making Nora last year, she has kept her naturally black hair red. 'I tried to go back to normal but I feel like a red-haired person now.'

Born in Newry, Lynch was spotted by her present agent in a local amateur production before she went to drama school. They kept in touch during the course. When Lynch graduated from The Central School of Speech and Drama at the start of the Nineties, she didn't have to scratch around for work.

Her television career began with a humdinger of a role: half of a psychotic Bonnie and Clyde partnership in the second Cracker episode. 'It was a dream part but afterwards I got offered lots of girls with guns.' Until recently, though, she wasn't offered many Irish roles. She was obviously eager to play Nora, a rare big screen female Irish protagonist, but enjoys employing an English accent. 'I'm always more comfortable doing different accents,' she explains. 'It makes you feel slightly different and it adds to the character.'

She did play the Irish love interest in last year's surprise hit Waking Ned, a role which raised her international profile, following a series of supporting roles in TV dramas such as Ivanhoe and Amongst Women. Next, she stars opposite Rachel Weisz in Creatures, a Scottish female buddy movie and soon jets off to Prague for From Hell, a Jack the Ripper thriller starring Johnny Depp. In it she plays an alcoholic prostitute.

Directed by the Hughes brothers (Menace II Society), From Hell is her first major Hollywood project, but she remains modest about future plans. 'Saying "Do you want to go to Hollywood?" is like asking a novelist if they want to win the Booker Prize. It's not about the glory. I wouldn't say I was that ambitious.'

Five things you should know about Susan Lynch

1 Her father is Irish and her mother is Italian. She speaks both English and Italian fluently.

2 After playing a serial killer in Cracker, she recalls, 'people kept screaming at me on the street'.

3 She recently directed a play for the amateur dramatic society in her hometown.

4 At drama school she won Kenneth Branagh's Renaissance Award as Most Promising Student.

5 She had the title role in a four-part ITV gangster series called Dangerous Lady.

webTitle: BBC braced for row over new political editor

fields.headline: BBC braced for row over new political editor
fields.trailText: The BBC was bracing itself for a political row last night after it announced that one of New Labour's closest associates is to become its political editor.
fields.body:
The BBC was bracing itself for a political row last night after it announced that one of New Labour's closest associates is to become its political editor.

Andrew Marr, a columnist for The Observer and a former editor of the Independent, was offered the post after BBC executives decided that current political editor Robin Oakley should retire early.

Marr, who will take over in the summer, is close to senior officials in Downing Street and makes no secret of his New Labour credentials. He is well-liked by the Prime Minister and his official spokesman, Alastair Campbell.

Lord Tebbit, the former Tory party chairman and a robust critic of the BBC, said: 'The BBC is run by the Labour Party and takes its orders from it. So this will make no difference. It is a thoroughly unreliable broadcasting organisation.'

BBC executives pointed out that Marr was a highly respected journalist who could be trusted to be impartial. Marr himself has given strong assurances that he will 'bend over backwards' to give every side a fair hearing.

It was made clear last night that the Conservatives would initially view Marr as a man 'they can do business with'.

'We will be watching very closely but we will see how things work out before we say anything,' said a Tory source.

Last night Michael Ancram, the Tory party chairman, was diplomatic in his response. 'Andrew Marr is a political journalist of stature and we look forward to a constructive engagement and dialogue,' he said.

Oakley is thought to be disappointed, but said he could see 'the logic' of the situation. 'Although I would have liked to have covered the [general] election, the BBC have decided they would like the whole period - through the election and the next parliament - to be covered by my successor.

'I can see the logic of that and so I have decided to pursue other interests.'

fields.headline: Day four/five: 'The star system sucks'
fields.standfirst: Nick Nolte was joined by Uma Thurman in his condemnation of Hollywood's dehumanising star system, plus, reports  Fiachra Gibbons, Ali G booyaka-sha, and an unlikely collaboration in the shape of Madonna and Peter Greenaway
fields.trailText: Nick Nolte was joined by Uma Thurman in his condemnation of Hollywood's dehumanising star system, plus, reports Fiachra Gibbons, Ali G booyaka-sha, and an unlikely collaboration in the shape of Madonna and Peter Greenaway
fields.body:
The actor Nick Nolte - one of Hollywood's most bankable stars of the past two decades - yesterday laid into the star system which he claimed is killing creativity and turning actors into products.

"The star system sucks," he declared to applause from journalists at the Cannes Film Festival. "Hollywood has boiled itself down to four male leads, and they have to be in all the big movies. I didn't want to be a part of that anymore, that's why I am doing my own thing now. The major studios pick the star first with no thought for material. It shouldn't be like that."

But the real surprise was that Uma Thurman, Nolte's co-star in the new Merchant Ivory film The Golden Bowl, and one of today's biggest box-office draws, joined in the attack by saying that actors wanted to be set more challenges than having to squeeze in a "rubber Batman costume".

Ms Thurman made her name in Quentin Tarantino's Pulp Fiction before starring in a string of blockbusters including Batman & Robin and Gattaca. She was also in the disastrous big-screen version of The Avengers, where her figure-hugging leather catsuit was its only real selling point.

Nolte, who made his name in 48 Hours, said something had to be done to stop the accountants who run the studios. "These smiling fellows come to you and push millions of dollars across the table at you. So what do you do? But you soon find yourself in a pretty limited position. The actor actually dies. It is a tricky kind of dance you have to do to not be a product."

"There always been a rebel in me that stopped that happening to me," he said. "But it's a big problem. How does the artist wrest back control of what you do, we have got to find a way because the independents are just as bad," he declared.

Nolte revealed he and the actress Neve Campbell were doing their next film, Investigating Sex, for nothing because they were so won over by the script about sexual experimentation among the surrealists in the 1920s. "All the actors have done the same. If it makes money we'll take a cut. That is one way of making better films."

Thurman was equally heartfelt. "Not a lot of people are fighting the good fight to make real dramas that do not have endings that tie up in a neat bow so they can send the audiences out happy after they have spent their eight bucks. Actors need to know they are playing real people, especially when we are in the middle of getting into a rubber batman costume."

She praised London-based Merchant Ivory for taking on Henry James' Golden Bowl - a surprise hit with critics - despite its reputation for being his most difficult novel. "James Ivory and Ismail Merchant are unique in that they have stood by their own taste and made stories about people, and I think this is why this film works so well. I don't want people to stop making movies like this, there is a need to tell stories in an intricate and sophisticated way."

Nolte did not name Mel Gibson, Bruce Willis, Harrison Ford and George Clooney, the current Hollywood 'big four', but he didn't need to.

Ironically, George Clooney, the youngest of the ageing Hollywood four, is in Cannes too and starring in another film in the main competition. He plays a convict on the run from a southern chain gang in the Cohen brothers' crowd-pleasing comedy, O Brother, Where Art Thou? fields.bodyText: The actor Nick Nolte - one of Hollywood's most bankable stars of the past two decades - yesterday laid into the star system which he claimed is killing creativity and turning actors into products. "The star system sucks," he declared to applause from journalists at the Cannes Film Festival. "Hollywood has boiled itself down to four male leads, and they have to be in all the big movies. I didn't want to be a part of that anymore, that's why I am doing my own thing now. The major studios pick the star first with no thought for material. It shouldn't be like that." But the real surprise was that Uma Thurman, Nolte's co-star in the new Merchant Ivory film The Golden Bowl, and one of today's biggest box-office draws, joined in the attack by saying that actors wanted to be set more challenges than having to squeeze in a "rubber Batman costume". Ms Thurman made her name in Quentin Tarantino's Pulp Fiction before starring in a string of blockbusters including Batman & Robin and Gattaca. She was also in the disastrous big-screen version of The Avengers, where her figure-hugging leather catsuit was its only real selling point. Nolte, who made his name in 48 Hours, said something had to be done to stop the accountants who run the studios. "These smiling fellows come to you and push millions of dollars across the table at you. So what do you do? But you soon find yourself in a pretty limited position. The actor actually dies. It is a tricky kind of dance you have to do to not be a product." "There always been a rebel in me that stopped that happening to me," he said. "But it's a big problem. How does the artist wrest back control of what you do, we have got to find a way because the independents are just as bad," he declared. "All the actors have done the same. If it makes money we'll take a cut. That is one way of making better films." Thurman was equally heartfelt. fields.headline: Comment: Jacob's cracker
fields.standfirst: The festival opened this week with the usual sacrificial turkey
fields.trailText: The festival opened this week with the usual sacrificial turkey
fields.body:
For some years now, it has been the policy of the Cannes Film Festival to choose a big, bad movie to be shown out of competition at the gala opening, presumably so that everything seen thereafter will look good. The sacrificial turkey chosen for the fifty-third Festival was Vatel, a costume epic starring Uma Thurman which centres on a visit made by Louis XIV to the château of the Prince de Condé in 1671. This costly French production was made in English by a British director of no great distinction, Roland Joffe, and its one French star, Gérard Depardieu, speaking in his thickest accent, is surrounded by British actors, including Julian Sands as the king.

I arrived in Cannes too late for the press screening, but everyone without exception assured me that it was an unmitigated disaster. David Stratton, the kindly critic of Variety, wrote that 'wit, style and emotional involvement are notable by their absence'. The skies wept in sympathy as the VIP guests made their way up the red-carpeted steps of the Palais de Festival, among them Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, though Sir Tom Stoppard, who wrote the English adaptation of Vatel, chose to celebrate the award of his OM elsewhere.

Things improved radically the following day when Gilles Jacob, who'll be moving up next year to become president of the festival after 23 years as its director, pulled off a characteristically sly piece of programming. Both the first movie in competition, Ken Loach's Bread and Roses, and the first film in the non-competitive section known as 'Un Certain Regard', Rodrigo Garcia's Things You Can Tell Just By Looking at Her, featured the distinguished Mexican-American actress Elpidia Carrillo.

In Loach's film, his first to be made in the States, Carillo plays Rosa, a Hispanic housewife who has struggled for years to support her family back in Mexico City while caring for her children and sick husband in Los Angeles, often resorting to prostitution. Then her rebellious young sister (Pilar Padilla) arrives in the US as a wetback and rapidly starts rocking the boat through her involvement with Justice for Janitors, a movement to unionise the ill-paid office cleaners of Los Angeles, most of them immigrants, and all working without security, sick benefits or vacations. This simple, hard-hitting movie about social injustice is an attack on the capitalist system in the prosperous city that supports the film industry, and it exposes the way the system divides those it exploits.

A major point is made in Bread and Roses about the invisibility and anonymity of the blue-collar Hispanics to the middle-class Americans they serve. In Things You Can Tell Just By Looking At Her, the accomplished directorial debut of the American-educated son of novelist Gabriel Garcìa Màrquez, Elpidia Carrillo plays Carmen, a 40-year-old Hispanic, living alone, who has committed suicide after destroying most of the evidence of her life. She never speaks and on the face of it she's a marginal figure in a portmanteau movie of five tales of women living in LA's San Fernando Valley, a film reminiscent of Short Cuts and Magnolia.

To a woman detective (Amy Brenneman) living with her blind sister (Cameron Diaz), Carmen is the subject of a routine police inquiry. To the other women - a doctor (Glenn Close), a bank manager (Holly Hunter), a divorcée (Kathy Bates), a girl (Calista Flockhart) caring for her dying lesbian lover - Carmen is someone unnoticed as they cope with their own crises. But in these interlocked stories of loneliness and dependency she exposes the absence of a true sense of community.

There's been the usual negative talk during the opening days about Cannes being snubbed by Hollywood, the absence of old-time glamour, the Palme d'Or being box-office poison, about the Venice and Sundance Festivals taking over the lead. People have been saying these things for a quarter of a century, but they keep coming back.

fields.headline: Serbian lawyers defy the regime
fields.standfirst:
Judges show solidarity with young radicals in Milosevic's home town

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Leading lawyers in the home town of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic have resigned rather than handle a highly political case involving a clash between members of the radical Serbian youth movement Otpor and bodyguards of the President's son, Marko.
fields.body:
Leading lawyers in the home town of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic have resigned rather than handle a highly political case involving a clash between members of the radical Serbian youth movement Otpor and bodyguards of the President's son, Marko.

The fight between three activists of Otpor, which means Resistance, and three bodyguards from Marko's Madonna disco led the opposition to call a rally in Pozarevac last week, which in turn sparked a clampdown on journalists and anti-regime activists. Opposition politicians have called a big rally in Belgrade for tomorrow.

But the incident is creating a judicial crisis at the heart of the regime: the homestead of the ruling family. At the end of last week, the public prosecutor due to work on the Otpor case, Jovo Stanojevic, resigned. A press conference at which he was to explain why was first postponed, then cancelled.

Other lawyers in Pozarevac have gone: investigating judge and deputy district attorney Djordje Rankovic was relieved of his duties after admitting that he had joined last week's opposition protest in the town over the Otpor case.

Three of his colleagues said that they were also there and a respected investigating judge, Bosko Papovic, has refused to preside over the controversial case and is seeking early retirement.

The fracas at the heart of the case began after a young Otpor activist from Pozarevac was allegedly threatened by bodyguards of Marko Milosevic. He says they accused him of painting Otpor graffiti in the town and ordered him to leave Otpor and bring them proof that he had quit.

When the bodyguards came on him again, two other Otpor activists were watching. Fearing for his life, they became involved in a fight that left one on the floor in a pool of blood with a serious head wound and another with eye injuries. A local lawyer, who apparently tried to intervene, was also hurt. The two injured Otpor men and the lawyer were then arrested and, despite their injuries, face possible charges of attempted murder.

The fight's significance lies in its participants and its location. The bodyguards are closely linked to Marko and his best friend, Zoran Ivanovic, known as Zoki Rolex. Pozarevac, a town of 70,000, is where Milosevic grew up and he still has a home there. He met his wife and ally, Mirjana Markovic, at the local school. Their son Marko owns not only the Madonna disco but also a leisure park - Bambiland - a coffee bar and cyber-café.

The childhood friends of Slobodan and Mirjana have been key figures in the Milosevic regime. Among them are Interior Minister Vlajko Stoiljkov, film director Ljubisa Ristic, and Zika Petrovic, the head of Yugoslav airlines who was recently assassinated.

'That place is sacred territory for Milosevic,' said Vukasin Petrovic, a key member of Otpor.

Otpor has grown rapidly in the last year. Many say the regime is scared of it.

The resignations in the judiciary in Pozarevac have gained support from several leading legal figures in Serbia. Slobodan Vucetic, former judge of the Serbian constitutional court, ousted from his position in February, said: 'It's courageous for an investigative judge to refuse to obey political orders.'

He said the regime may find prosecutors and judges who will obey political orders on the case, but added: 'If the regime pursues this route, then it's possible that this could create a second wave of prosecutors and judges to resign.'

But Professor Jovica Trkulja, who is currently suspended from his job at Belgrade University's faculty of law, said the Pozarevac resignations did not mark the start of a collapse in the judicial system.

However, he added: 'The consequences of the events in the town will be very important and massive - even if the beginning was just a single act - because now it is obvious that the regime is using aggressive oppression and it is clear who in the opposition is ready for change.'

webTitle: It was only a typo, but it meant £1,000 more to pay

fields.headline: It was only a typo, but it meant £1,000 more to pay
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: I borrowed £10,000 from Lombard North Central in May 1995 at a variable rate of 1.31 per cent a month for about five years. Last December, I was given a settlement figure of £2,629. I reckoned this should have been £1,642.
fields.body:
I borrowed £10,000 from Lombard North Central in May 1995 at a variable rate of 1.31 per cent a month for about five years. Last December, I was given a settlement figure of £2,629. I reckoned this should have been £1,642.

A detailed statement showed that the rate applied was 1.47 per cent a month, and indicated that one payment by cheque, in 1996, was not included. I want to settle this account quickly, since each month costs me an extra £20 in interest using my figures, or £40 using theirs.

GS, Accrington

Lombard North Central, now First National Tricity Finance, is owned by Abbey National, which has checked the figures again and agrees that you are right.

At the outset, someone typed in the wrong interest rate so, instead of 1.31 per cent a month (an annual percentage rate of 16.9 per cent) you have been charged 1.47 per cent, or 18.8 per cent a year for five years. During that time, the interest rate changed only once - to go up to 20.9 per cent. But instead of raising your repayments, the lender extended the term, which is why you still owe money after making 60 monthly payments. So instead of insisting that you owe £1,756, Abbey agrees it should be £756.

You have since made another repayment and Abbey is waiving interest on two instalments, so the amount now needed to pay off the loan is £483. Someone from Abbey is contacting you to discuss compensation for the costs and inconvenience Lombard 's mistake has caused you.

Inheritance tax: Spouse's house?

I understand that a wife has a legal right to 50 per cent of the value of the property, even though the deeds may be in the husband's name. So, if I died before my wife, would she have to pay inheritance tax based on the total valuation of the property, or only on my half? Or must I get the deeds changed to reflect

ownership?

SK, Romsey

Your understanding is not quite right. A wife is likely to be given half the house in divorce proceedings, but she does not have a legal right to a particular share. Even if she did, the Inland Revenue would not accept your conclusion that you should be taxed only on your half. That, however, is academic because she would not have to pay tax on inheriting the house anyway: there is no tax on gifts between spouses.

You do not have to get the deeds changed for your wife to inherit the whole house, but you should make your intentions clear in your will. If you died without making one, part of your estate might go to other relatives, including part of the house's value.

Card confusion: Less than capital

In January, I sent a cheque to pay my Capital One credit card account and, as instructed, wrote my address on the back. I was then unable to use the card for my pharmacy business, and the card firm eventually found that the money had bee

ted to my

account.

They said they had to ask my wife's permission to take back the money. What if they had credited the account of someone I did not know? I was told repeatedly that about £16 interest, accrued during the delay, would be credited to me but I have heard nothing.

RG, Woodford Green

Capital One says you should not have been told that your address was an acceptable alternative to writing the account number on the back of your cheque.

It admits that an operator then failed to check your initials before sending the payment to your wife. It claims your wife was 'informed' of the error, rather than requested to return the money so, if it had gone to a stranger, there would have been no difficulty recovering it. The company is sending you £25 to cover the interest you were wrongly charged and a goodwill payment, although Capital One warns this will take a little time to work through the system.

Solicitor's delay: $40,000 blocked

My brother died in 1979 and his estate passed to me. In April 1999, I received a letter from Fidelity in the US, stating that he had about $40,000 in its Capital Fund there. Nothing had been heard from my solicitor since May 1980 (the solicitor died), so the account, was being

erred to t

doned prop

<

account.

Through my current solicitor I was asked for a sworn statement, which I forwarded. I have made several phone calls to Fidelity in Boston without success. I have contacted my new solicitor several times and stressed the urgency for action, but with no satisfaction.

AT, Accrington

The logjam appears to be with your solicitor. Fidelity says there is just one piece of information it still needs before releasing the money: a transfer death certificate. Once this arrives, you will have a cheque within a week.

Fidelity has phoned and written to your solicitor several times, asking for the certificate, but heard nothing. Keep nagging your solicitor.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Save on holiday cash | Friends become more responsible | Discover a long, long trip | Holiday pocket money
fields.body:
Save on holiday cash

If shopping for foreign currency is a more serious issue for you than a last-minute dash to the bank on the way to the airport, a pre-holiday season survey by financial database Moneyfacts could help you.

It found that commission varies from 0.25 per cent at Northern Ireland's First Trust Bank to 2 per cent at Abbey National, Barclays, HSBC, NatWest and North ern Rock. Customers buying larger sums may find it cheaper to pay a flat fee; Thomas Cook and American Express charge £2 per currency. Commission on sterling traveller's cheques ranges from 1 per cent at American Express to 2 per cent at Thomas Cook. Some organisations charge handling fees rather than commission, ranging from £3.50 at Nationwide to £7.50 at Newcastle building society.

Friends become more responsible

The insurer that pioneered ethical investment in the UK, Friends Provident, is to expand this idea by applying a new 'social responsibility policy' to its funds. The ethical funds will be run as before, maintaining specific ethical criteria, excluding some companies and including others. But through its other funds, Friends will 'engage' with firms that its other funds invest in to encourage protection of the environment, and to promote human rights and fair labour policies.

Discover a long, long trip

Travel insurer Club Direct now offers cover for journeys of more than a year under its Discovery policy for backpackers and other long-term travellers. There are two versions: one offers comprehensive cover, and a second excluding baggage and cash. Both include £10 million of medical cover. The premiums are £279 and £199 a year respectively. Tel: 0800 074 4556.

Away bonus for children

British children receive more than six times their weekly pocket money when they go on holiday abroad, says a survey by Walt Disney Travel. The average for those aged from seven to 16 is £30 a week, compared with £4.75 at home. Girls receive £5 more than boys. Scottish parents are the most generous, giving an average of £36, while children in South East England get the least, at £25.

Planning for security

Mencap, the charity, is running seminars on financial planning for parents and relatives of children with learning disabilities. The aim is to help plan for the support of their children after parents die. The first seminar will be in north Warwickshire on 20 May. Others will follow in Cambridge, Hertfordshire and Essex. Tel: 0500 243 444.

It found that commission varies from 0.25 per cent at Northern Ireland's First Trust Bank to 2 per cent at Abbey National, Barclays, HSBC, NatWest and North ern Rock. Customers buying larger sums may find it cheaper to pay a flat fee; Thomas Cook and American Express charge £2 per currency. Commission on sterling traveller's cheques ranges from 1 per cent at American Express to 2 per cent at Thomas Cook. Some organisations charge handling fees rather than commission, ranging from £3.50 at Nationwide to £7.50 at Newcastle building society. Friends become more responsible The insurer that pioneered ethical investment in the UK, Friends Provident, is to expand this idea by applying a new 'social responsibility policy' to its funds. The ethical funds will be run as before, maintaining specific ethical criteria, excluding some companies and including others. But through its other funds, Friends will 'engage' with firms that its other funds invest in to encourage protection of the environment, and to promote human rights and fair labour policies. Discover a long, long trip Travel insurer Club Direct now offers cover for journeys of more than a year under its Discovery policy for backpackers and other long-term travellers. There are two versions: one offers comprehensive cover, and a second excluding baggage and cash. Both include £10 million of medical cover. The premiums are £279 and £199 a year respectively. Tel: 0800 074 4556. Away bonus for children British children receive more than six times their weekly pocket money when they go on holiday abroad, says a survey by Walt Disney Travel. The average for those aged from seven to 16 is £30 a week, compared with £4.75 at home. Girls receive £5 more than boys. Scottish parents are the most generous, giving an average of £36, while children in South East England get the least, at £25. Planning for security Mencap, the charity, is running seminars on financial planning for parents and relatives of children with learning disabilities. The aim is to help plan for the support of their children after parents die. The first seminar will be in north Warwickshire on 20 May. Others will follow in Cambridge, Hertfordshire and Essex. Tel: 0500 243 444.

webTitle: On the market:  Framlington New Leaders Fund

fields.headline: On the market:  Framlington New Leaders Fund
fields.trailText: Framlington New Leaders Fund
fields.body:
Framlington New Leaders Fund

Contact:
0845 702 3138, or on the Internet at www.framlington.co.uk/newleaders.

Aim:
To produce capital growth through investment in seven key sectors: leisure, healthcare, financial services, Internet, media, technology and telecommunications.

Bells & whistles:
New Leaders is designed to be a core holding for investors with UK-biased portfolios looking for broadly based international exposure. Neil Birrell, the fund's lead manager, says: 'We don't believe that there is such a thing as the "new economy", rather there is a single and increasingly dynamic global economy. This dynamism is driven by the seven key sectors, and within these, we will look for high growth businesses which are thriving across two or three continents, and are able to deliver exceptional returns.'

How it works:
Birrell will draw on advice from six of Framlington's specialist sector fund managers to choose between 50 and 70 companies. The portfolio will be split between firms that are already world leaders (and will continue to be so), and those that the team believes will reach that level. The companies included are likely to have a minimum market capitalisation of about £3 billion, sufficient to take them into the FTSE 100. Examples are Pfizer, News Corp, Intel and Disney.

Minimum:
£1,000 for lump sums, or £50 a month.

Charges:
Initial 5.25 per cent per cent (1 per cent off until 31 May), and a 1.5 per cent annual management fee.

Tax:
Available as mini- or maxi-Isa to produce tax-free capital growth.

Risk:
Medium.

Should you invest?
Patrick Connolly of Bath independent financial adviser Chartwell is not impressed. 'Marketing-wise it is very innovative. But Framlington is doing something every other fund manager has been doing for years now - picking the sectors they think will do well and choosing the big stocks from those sectors that they expect to perform. It isn't anything new.' However, Michael Aaron, of Milton Keynes independent financial adviser David Aaron Partnership, likes the fund. He says it draws on the experience Framlington has built up in running specialist funds to develop a less speculative global fund suitable for medium-risk, long-term investors.

Points out of 10:
Connolly 5, Aaron 8.

webTitle: Surf through  the wave of cyber-crime

fields.headline: Surf through  the wave of cyber-crime
fields.standfirst: Colin Frier  on how not to fall victim to  Internet fraud
fields.trailText: Colin Frier on how not to fall victim to Internet fraud
fields.body:
How ironic that Bill Gates, the person most associated with the personal computer, should reportedly have had his credit card details stolen by a teenage hacker. If it can happen to the world's greatest geek, what hope for the rest of us?

And the havoc created by the Love Bug virus provides a further reminder of the fallibility of electronic information systems.

Chris Potter, who works for PriceWaterhouse Cooper advising organisations on how to secure e-business, says that where Gates and the US go, Britain is sure to follow.

And with UK levels of Internet crime 12 to 18 months behind those in the US, he says: 'All the drivers are towards increasing cyber-crime.'

The US-based Computer Security Institute's latest survey shows that the threat from computer crime is continuing unabated, with 35 per cent of respondents reporting between two and five attacks on their e-commerce sites in the past 12 months.

And in January, shock waves reverberated around the computer world when CD Universe, an e-commerce retailer, admitted that customers' credit card data could have been compromised, after a 19-year-old Russian hacker 'Maxim' posted 25,000 stolen card numbers on the Web.

Potter says he hears a couple of stories a month about breaches of Internet security in the UK, some involving household names.

One is BT, whose security was breached in April when a few smart alecs found they could access customers' names, addresses, telephone numbers and email addresses.

A BT spokesman said the problem was caused by human error, and less than 1,000 customers had been affected.

BT is not the only UK company to give its customers cause for concern. The Halifax suspended online share-dealing in November after customers found they could access other people's personal details. And last May, there was a security scare at the Internet bank, Egg.

So if the security of some of the UK's best known and largest companies has been compromised, shouldn't we be concerned?

Potter admits that there is no such thing as 100 per cent security. And given that fewer than half of US organisations surveyed would report computer crime even if required to do so by law, Potter says: 'What you see is only the tip of the iceberg.' But he adds that by following sensible precautions, the risks can be greatly reduced.

It is important to know who you are dealing with, he says. 'When I shop on the Internet, I am careful where I buy and who I buy from.'

The Office of Fair Trading warns people to check the company's geographical and website addresses. This will stop details being pirated by those who have set up websites with names similar to well known companies'.

'You have some extra protection if you buy with a credit card,' says the OFT. This applies particularly when an item costs more than £100, even if you only pay a deposit: you can claim against the card company should there be a breach of contract with the retailer.

The OFT advises customers to, 'look for traders with an encryption facility to scramble card details'. However, not all encryption offers the same security. Potter says the minimum encryption necessary for transferring confidential information is Secure Socket Layer, which brings up a padlock symbol on the screen. 'But even this is not a universal panacea,' he warns.

In the laboratory, he says, it has been possible to intercept data on the Internet, siphon it off and break the encryption code. To counter this possibility, people should take account of the sort of items they are buying when judging whether encryption is sufficient. For low-value items, he says, a little encryption is 'better than none'. For more expensive transactions, he says, people should look for the highest possible level.

The OFT says: 'Check whether the company has a privacy statement giving details of its information handling practices. This will indicate the uses they make of the information about you, and says something about the security they apply to this information.'

Helena Sims of the Data Protection Registry, adds that since the 1998 Data Protection Act came into force in March, organisations have 'a requirement to keep secure information they collect on individuals'.

Her office receives complaints from people unhappy that their details have been made available to others. Most concern smaller retailers and pure e-commerce businesses, and are caused by companies, 'storing personal information on the website rather than elsewhere'.

And as with cyber-crime, it's a problem that looks set to grow. But no matter how sophisticated the security systems, Potter says that, as with the breaking of the Enigma encryption machine during the Second World War, 'it is the human element which is often the weakest link'.

fields.headline: Perpetual in motion
fields.standfirst: Uncertainty grows as investment house admits it has been holding talks about selling up, reports  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: More than 750,000 Perpetual investors are wondering how they will be affected following the news that the investment firm is negotiating its sale to another financial institution. Perpetual, which has £11.5 billion under management, admitted last week that it was in discussions with another party, believed to be US investment giant Amvescap.
fields.body:
More than 750,000 Perpetual investors are wondering how they will be affected following the news that the investment firm is negotiating its sale to another financial institution. Perpetual, which has £11.5 billion under management, admitted last week that it was in discussions with another party, believed to be US investment giant Amvescap.

The announcement increases the uncertainty felt by many investors after a stream of takeovers and mergers. Already this year Gartmore has been bought by the US insurer Nationwide Mutual, while Dresdner and Deutsche announced their merger but fell out over the terms. Such mergers can cause considerable disruption for fund managers, resulting in a decline in performance.

Perpetual is the last independently owned investment house in the UK, and a favourite with independent financial advisers and investors. But over the past two years, the performance of its flagship UK funds has slumped. So should investors now move their investments to other fund managers?

Amvescap bought UK investment firm Invesco in 1997, and GT last year, and has just completed the amalgamation of their onshore unit trusts. The performance of Invesco funds has improved considerably since the takeover, and its range of funds has been strengthened by the addition of GT, which had well regarded funds in the Far East and Japan.

There is considerable overlap between the Perpetual and Invesco fund ranges - both companies run European, Far Eastern, Japanese, UK Income, UK Growth, UK Smaller Companies, US and fixed-interest funds - and a merger of the two companies would be sure to result in many of these funds being combined.

Ian Millward of Bath independent financial adviser Chase de Vere believes investors with units and shares in Perpetual funds should sit tight. 'Perpetual may be allowed complete autonomy in its operations, which would be good news, or it may be merged with Invesco, in which case it is the coming together of two good investment houses.'

Jason Hollands of London independent financial adviser Best Investment agrees that investors should not sell yet, but believes the two houses make an uncomfortable fit. 'Already some of the flagship funds [on both sides] are of considerable size and it wouldn't be in the interests of either unit holders nor the management company to create unwieldy dinosaurs,' he says.

Invesco's European Growth fund is worth £2.82bn; if this were merged with Perpetual's £743 million European Growth fund, it would create a monster of more than £3bn - the biggest unit trust run in the UK to date.

Hollands also points out that many of Perpetual's key fund managers have substantial wealth tied up in Perpetual shares - a move designed to encourage them to remain with the firm. But he wonders whether these managers are likely to stay if Perpetual is absorbed into a bigger group and their shares are bought out.

Michael Usher at London independent financial adviser Brooks Macdonald believes a merger with Invesco could improve performance for Perpetual investors. He recommends that people with moderately sized investments in Perpetual Income and High Income should retain their units, but those who have accumulated large investments in comparison with the rest of their portfolio should consider selling part of their holdings now.

fields.headline: Webwatch
fields.trailText: The pace of development in internet banking is picking up rapidly. Halifax has launched Intelligent Finance (IF), which promises a radical approach to money management as well the latest technology. IF, headed by Jim Spowart, who took Direct Line into the savings market and Standard Life into mortgages, is applying for a patent on the software used in its product.
fields.body:
The pace of development in internet banking is picking up rapidly. Halifax has launched Intelligent Finance (IF), which promises a radical approach to money management as well the latest technology. IF, headed by Jim Spowart, who took Direct Line into the savings market and Standard Life into mortgages, is applying for a patent on the software used in its product.

The service will be available from July, and aims to cut borrowing costs and maximise returns on savings not only by offering competitive rates, but by offsetting savings against borrowings. IF will deduct any savings balance you have from borrowings, such as mortgages and credit cards, charging interest only on the balance. One innovation is that it will be possible to have a zero per cent mortgage. Those whose savings outstrip a mortgage - as may be the case with older customers - will be charged nothing for their borrowing.

The account is billed as an internet product, but it will also be possible to operate it by telephone and by the new wap technology mobile phones. Free Internet-compatible wap phones are on offer to the first 150,000 customers who agree to have their salaries credited to the accounts. To register for IF call 0845 609 4343, or visit the website.

Abbey National is offering its existing banking and savings products on the Internet, with a few bells and whistles added. For example, it will allow customers who want to transfer their current account from another bank to Abbey to request the service online; Abbey will switch all the direct debits and standing orders. You can register at Abbey branches, cash machines or by calling 0845 765 4321. Still to come from Abbey however, is Cahoot, a separate Internet bank account promising to 'target a new customer segment'.

Sharedealers can buy and sell shares at the flat rate of £10 from tomorrow through online execution-only service iDealing. The company plans to maintain low charges by keeping overheads to a minimum. This means that while other sharedealing services are fighting to offer the most comprehensive content packages on their sites, iDealing provides a stripped-down service with links to other sources of information, although it does include portfolio analysis.

It is starting with just 12 employees - a fact that may alarm sharedealers who have experienced delays and system failures with other, better staffed online services. But Foster Bowman, managing director of iDealing, says his staff will easily cope with up to 15,000 dealing accounts. iDealing offers real-time transactions on a nominee account basis. In addition to the £10 flat fee, customers must pay a quarterly account charge of £5. A minimum of £500 is required to open an account.

Charles Schwab is offering a saving of up to 40 per cent to online traders after reorganising its dealing structure. Minimum commission for Net trading is now £12.

DLJdirect , another online broker, will refund stamp duty on UK share trades - 0.5 per cent per trade - for all new customers for a month from opening an account.

E*Trade is offering a commission-free trading day on 26 May. You must register by 20 May.

Business and investment information service Hemington Scott is offering UK company information free to all users until the end of June. This service, Business Plus, normally costs £10 a month plus VAT.

Such is the diversity of Internet business that it is even possible to visit a site specially for motorcycle insurance. Bennetts, a specialist in this type of cover, is offering to quote the best rate from 15 insurers through its new site, which also has an online payment facility.

webTitle: Seller's information packs - do they lack real punch?

fields.headline: Seller's information packs - do they lack real punch?
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley on a mixed reception for the scheme for speeding up property buying
fields.trailText: Government plans for a homeseller's information pack, designed to cut the time it takes to sell your home, are facing strong criticism. Solicitors and estate agents involved in a pilot scheme report that the pack is expensive to produce and unlikely to reduce the period between acceptance of an offer and completion.
fields.body:
Government plans for a homeseller's information pack, designed to cut the time it takes to sell your home, are facing strong criticism. Solicitors and estate agents involved in a pilot scheme report that the pack is expensive to produce and unlikely to reduce the period between acceptance of an offer and completion.

The pack aims to speed up house sales and reduce gazumping (sellers accepting a higher bid after agreeing a lower one) and gazundering (the buyer offering a lower-than-agreed price just before exchange). The pack - to be prepared by a seller's solicitor before the property is put on the market - includes all the information a buyer needs to make an informed decision. Once the buyer's solicitor has approved the information, contracts can be exchanged without all the delays normally caused by searches, surveys and solicitors' correspondence.

So far 179 homesellers have agreed to take part in the pilot, which has been running in Bristol since January. Of these, 60 have received offers on their properties, 31 have exchanged and 11 have reached completion. The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, which is running the pilot, claims that early results indicate that the pack has helped to accelerate property sales, enabling a 'smooth, seamless, stress-free process, where problems are known about earlier, helping buyers and sellers to agree a realistic final selling price'.

However, several estate agents and solicitors involved in the scheme are not impressed. Robert Pain of estate agent Allen & Harris says he has found it diffi cult to persuade sellers to take part. 'Increasing numbers of people like to look for a property before they put theirs on the market, and if they've found one they like, they want to start selling theirs straight away, not wait up to two weeks while a pack is put together.'

He is concerned that the time-savings experienced during the pilot will not be achieved once the scheme becomes mandatory. The DETR reports that one seller in the pilot scheme took just 12 days to complete on his property after accepting an offer, and even the longest transaction has taken 47 days, comparing well with the average 56 days for a normal sale. But Pain points out that these results are due largely to the fact that Bristol City Council had earmarked pilot scheme local searches for special attention, pushing them through in 48 hours. Searches for normal sales take up to four weeks.

Mike Rendell of solicitor Convey Direct adds: 'Ninety per cent of cases involve chains, and here the seller's pack is irrelevant. No one can complete until everyone in the chain is ready.'

He questions the cost of producing a pack. The DETR quotes an approximate cost of £450, but Rendell says it is more likely to cost between £600 and £700. This cost could increase if a property takes a long time to sell, as local searches expire after three months and the seller would have to renew them.

The survey, which costs about £350, is the most interesting part of the pack for the buyer. However, the survey does not include the valuation required by all lenders, so buyers requiring a mortgage will still have to pay for one (about £150). Currently only 20 per cent of buyers order a homebuyer's report - the equivalent of the survey in the seller's pack. The rest rely on their lender's valuation report, a more superficial survey.

However, not all involved with the pilot are critical. Anna Maggs of estate agent Maggs & Allen says the pack has speeded up sales: 'It's fabulous for us because as soon as we start marketing, we've got everything we need to go ahead with a sale.'

Even Rendell admits the pack has cut the need for time-consuming correspon dence between buyer's and seller's solicitors, but he adds: 'If it's a good thing to be transparent, the seller's pack achieves that. But if you are saying this is going to prevent gazumping, that's absolute rubbish.'

So far 179 homesellers have agreed to take part in the pilot, which has been running in Bristol since January. Of these, 60 have received offers on their properties, 31 have exchanged and 11 have reached completion. The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, which is running the pilot, claims that early results indicate that the pack has helped to accelerate property sales, enabling a 'smooth, seamless, stress-free process, where problems are known about earlier, helping buyers and sellers to agree a realistic final selling price'. However, several estate agents and solicitors involved in the scheme are not impressed. Robert Pain of estate agent Allen & Harris says he has found it diffi cult to persuade sellers to take part. 'Increasing numbers of people like to look for a property before they put theirs on the market, and if they've found one they like, they want to start selling theirs straight away, not wait up to two weeks while a pack is put together.' He is concerned that the time-savings experienced during the pilot will not be achieved once the scheme becomes mandatory. The DETR reports that one seller in the pilot scheme took just 12 days to complete on his property after accepting an offer, and even the longest transaction has taken 47 days, comparing well with the average 56 days for a normal sale. But Pain points out that these results are due largely to the fact that Bristol City Council had earmarked pilot scheme local searches for special attention, pushing them through in 48 hours. Searches for normal sales take up to four weeks. Mike Rendell of solicitor Convey Direct adds: 'Ninety per cent of cases involve chains, and here the seller's pack is irrelevant. No one can complete until everyone in the chain is ready.' He questions the cost of producing a pack. The DETR quotes an approximate cost of £450, but Rendell says it is more likely to cost between £600 and £700. This cost could increase if a property takes a long time to sell, as local searches expire after three months and the seller would have to renew them. The survey, which costs about £350, is the most interesting part of the pack for the buyer. However, the survey does not include the valuation required by all lenders, so buyers requiring a mortgage will still have to pay for one (about £150). Currently only 20 per cent of buyers order a homebuyer's report - the equivalent of the survey in the seller's pack. The rest rely on their lender's valuation report, a more superficial survey. However, not all involved with the pilot are critical. Anna Maggs of estate agent Maggs & Allen says the pack has speeded up sales: 'It's fabulous for us because as soon as we start marketing, we've got everything we need to go ahead with a sale.' Even Rendell admits the pack has cut the need for time-consuming correspon dence between buyer's and seller's solicitors, but he adds: 'If it's a good thing to be transparent, the seller's pack achieves that. But if you are saying this is going to prevent gazumping, that's absolute rubbish.'

webTitle: How can I pass on what I've inherited?

fields.headline: How can I pass on what I've inherited?
fields.standfirst: Rosemary Ison has had some good fortune but, she tells  Margaret Dibben, feels out of her depth on investing
fields.trailText: Rosemary Ison trained as a childrenswear designer and now works part-time in her local community mental health team. Her husband Jeremy, 52, is a teacher. They have never had money to spare and have never been able to afford Tessas, Peps or Isas. Until now.
fields.body:
Rosemary Ison trained as a childrenswear designer and now works part-time in her local community mental health team. Her husband Jeremy, 52, is a teacher. They have never had money to spare and have never been able to afford Tessas, Peps or Isas. Until now.

She says: 'Our joint income just pays for the basics and perhaps a holiday every two years.' She has £900 in an emergency fund for unexpected bills. For this, she saves about £65 a month but admits: 'The money never accumulates because we are always dipping into it.'

An inheritance has changed her fortunes, but she does not know what to do with the money, and is unsure as to how much risk to take with investments because, she explains: 'I don't take risks because I have never had the chance.'

Rosemary has inherited, with her sister, a half share in a house worth about £260,000. The house is currently let on a six-month lease until August. The rent is £900 a month which, after management fees, the sisters share. In August they have to decide whether to continue letting the house or sell it. Also in the summer, she and Jeremy will inherit around £40,000 each.

Her one clear ambition is to see her children through university without them accumulating large debts. Paul is starting a four-year MSc course in September; Sarah finishes A levels next July and is planning a four-year zoology course. Each has £4,000 earmarked for university costs but, says Rosemary: 'I would like them to keep this money for a house deposit in the future.'

She wants to know how to use her new wealth to pay for their education and wonders if it is worth buying each child a property to save them the cost of renting. For herself, her only concern is her pension - she started contributing relatively late in life.

Rosemary joined the NHS pension scheme in June and has transferred to it £9,000 from her Equitable Life Personal Pension. She has 15 months' worth of local government pension, which is frozen. The Isons have no mortgage and their only debt is a car loan which costs £207 a month for another two years. They spend £70 a month on three endowment policies from Equitable Life and Co-operative Insurance; these will mature over the next few years.

 Adviser 1: Stephen Wise

Mrs Ison should consider selling the inherited house. It is impossible to predict whether a mixture of cash, fixed-interest and equity-based investments will outperform property, but this does offer greater diversification. Mrs Ison's half share after costs will be about £126,800 which, in a building society, could produce a net income of £6,080 a year.

They need at least £40,000 to fund four years' university fees for two children, but purchasing property for student lets has become so popular that it attracts investors as well as parents, which has pushed up the price of smaller properties and reduced the rental yield.

For lower-risk investing, I suggest putting £20,000 in a managed portfolio of zero-dividend preference shares. Zeros pay a fixed return at the end of a set period. Because they have a fixed redemption date and a known (but not guaranteed) value at redemption, they are useful for education fees, although a managed portfolio of zeros has no fixed redemption date and you pay an annual management charge of 1 per cent plus VAT. I would recommend a specialist firm such as BFS Investments.

Moving up the risk scale, I suggest a managed fund within an investment bond such as the AIG Guaranteed Quarterly Stockmarket Bond.

Mrs and Mr Ison should take out an Isa this year and set aside enough for one next year as well. I suggest a well-diversified international unit trust such as the Fidelity Managed International Fund.

Stephen Wise works for Ashcombe Financial Services of Haslemere.

 Adviser 2: Carolyn Corless

Rent from the inherited property produces income at less than 4 per cent a year before tax which is not particularly attractive. Selling it will release capital which Mrs Ison could invest for income and long-term growth. For short-term needs, postal accounts pay at least 6 per cent gross: £10,000 provides a comfortable emergency fund; £15,000 should cover two years' university costs; £5,000 buys holidays or a new car. She could repay the £5,000 car loan but should first check the settlement figure to decide if the cost is worthwhile.

When the endowment policies mature, she could invest up to £15,000 in investment trust zeros to meet university costs. I suggest Gartmore Shared Equity Junior, redeeming in two years' time at 9.2 per cent a year gross, and Aberdeen Preferred Income, producing 8.8 per cent for three years. She should consider with-profits bonds (Prudential and CGU Life) for income and long term growth: £50,000 provides £2,500 a year. Although slightly higher risk, UK equity income funds such as Dresdner RCM UK Equity Income and Newton Higher Income should provide good long-term returns.

Mr Ison should use some of his inheritance to buy added years in the Teachers' Pension Scheme. He will have about 34 years' service by age 60, so there is considerable scope to boost his pension, which generally represents good value for money.

 Carolyn Corless works for Bideford-based chartered accountant Sully & Co.

Advice is for guidance only.

fields.headline: Questions
fields.trailText: Tax returns - who needs them and who gets them? How many are sent out?
fields.body:
Tax returns - who needs them and who gets them? How many are sent out?

None of us wants them, but 9 million of us receive them every year, and this year's batch - to collect tax for the 1999/00 financial year - have just been posted. Returns go to anyone whom the Revenue believes has not paid all their tax through the PAYE system. Mainly, this means those who have received investment income not taxed at source, higher-rate taxpayers who have not paid extra tax due on bank and building society accounts or dividends, the self- employed, those with freelance income or income from part-time work, business partners and company directors. But it is your responsibility to ask for a return if you haven't received one and think you owe tax.

I've had one but don't owe any tax. What now?

Contact your tax office. The telephone number should be on the form.

When do I have to send it back?

If you hate forms or are numerically challenged, 30 September is the date to shoot for. Get the form in by then, and the Inland Revenue will do the calculations for you, and send a bill later. But you must still provide all the information needed. Start assembling everything you need now, and you may get the chore done by the time you go on holiday.

What if I miss that date?

The Revenue may still be able to do the calculations for you, but it won't guarantee this. If it does not get the job done and you end up owing tax as a result, you will pay interest. Strictly speaking, forms sent in after 30 September are expected to include the calculation - by you - of the tax owed. For employees, another advantage of meeting the deadline is that if you owe less than £1,000 for the last tax year, you can have it deducted in monthly instalments from next year's pay packet.

When is the final deadline?

It is 31 January 2001. If you miss that date you will be fined £100, or the amount of tax you owe, if that is less.

What information do I need to fill in the form?

Statements of interest paid on bank and savings accounts; dividends on investments not held inside a Pep or an Isa; and P60s. Banks and building societies are sending out statements of interest now, showing the gross and net amounts and tax paid, so don't assume those windowed envelopes are more junk mail.

Where can I get more information?

Ring the Revenue helpline - 0845 9000 444. Or if you think any of the form is missing, ring 0845 9000 404. Or visit its website at www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk/sa. From the end of this month you should be able to download a return from the site. And if you file your return over the Internet this year and pay by debit card or bank electronic transfer, you will get £10 off your bill. Use the site above to register for electronic filing.

Maria Scott

webTitle: Dabble in Energy and you could get a nasty shock

fields.headline: Dabble in Energy and you could get a nasty shock
fields.trailText: British Energy, like many of our traditional companies, likes to complain that its shares have suffered from investors' love affair with the new economy. But last week's results from the nuclear power company showed just why investors should be so desperate to buy into high-growth companies.
fields.body:
British Energy, like many of our traditional companies, likes to complain that its shares have suffered from investors' love affair with the new economy. But last week's results from the nuclear power company showed just why investors should be so desperate to buy into high-growth companies.

It is not just that British Energy's profits and earnings fell by 19 and 15 per cent respectively. It is not even the 50 per cent cut in the dividend, although income is about the only thing many old economy companies have going for them. It is what that cut tells investors about how British Energy sees its future. And if it believes its business can only afford to pay out half what it used to, the prospects look bleak.

British Energy's key problem is that it has no control over the price of electricity - it just takes the price set by the arcane arrangements of the pool pricing mechanism. And this has collapsed: the average price achieved in the year to March fell by 7 per cent, but the fall in the fourth quarter was even more severe.

The looming review of the pricing mechanism - NETA, or New Electricity Trading Arrangements - makes it impossible to predict whether, let alone when, that will recover. Few customers are prepared to sign contracts beyond the expected review date in the autumn, and those that have been signed are at around 15 per cent below the current pool price.

British Energy was also hit by problems: these caused the shutdown of two of its key power stations, Dungeness and Heysham. That cut its output by 9 per cent and reduced its utilisation to a meagre 74 per cent, compared with a theoretical maximum of 85 per cent-plus. Dungeness is now back in operation and Heysham will be completely operational by the autumn. But its profits will still be suffering from the shutdowns in the current year.

A cut in capacity is particularly serious for a nuclear generator, as most of its costs are fixed and have to be paid whether the plants are operating or not. It is doing its best with the variable costs: slicing them by 7 per cent last year and promising further cuts this year. But the 19 per cent fall in profit before tax, to £241m for the year to March, shows just how little British Energy can control the impact of the electricity market on its figures. That is underlined by the warning from Nigel Hawkins, utilities analyst at Williams de Broe, that the result this year could range from a profit of £350m to a loss of £60m. The first figure is based on similar prices and output to last year's; the second on a 15 per cent fall in prices and a 9 per cent fall in output. The directors will presumably have done similar calculations before they decided to slash the dividend.

Investors are right not to rate British Energy as a technology stock. Estimates such as those from Hawkins suggest it is far riskier than the average dot.com. Until there is more clarity over pool prices, the shares should be avoided.

High price of success
It seems investors are prepared to pay any price to get into the few retail companies with decent growth prospects. Matalan and N Brown both produced excellent results last week, but the share prices of both have now gone beyond realistic levels.

Matalan's progress continues to astonish. Like-for-like sales rose 21 per cent in the year to 26 February, and since then growth has accelerated to 31 per cent. Combined with the contribution from new store openings, profits have soared from £22.7m to £54.1m, although the latter figure was for 60 weeks rather than 53.

With large swathes of the country still to get the Matalan experience, the group has plenty of scope for growth by opening new stores. It is also toying with the idea of using the information gathered from its database of customers - who have to pay £1 in exchange for membership - to sell other products, such as financial services. There must be a question as to why it needs to do this when it is enjoying such excellent growth from its core retail business, but at least it does not seem to be distracting management's attention from the key challenge of getting the retail offer right.

N Brown also ran true to form, increasing both profits and sales by around 10 per cent in the year to February: a notable achievement when all other retailers are struggling.

It has been doing that for years, yet its shares never enjoyed the rating they deserved. What has excited investors now is Zendor.com, its newly launched e-fulfilment business (which, translated, means that it is selling its expertise in warehousing, delivery, credit checking and other logistics to Internet retailers). That is an interesting service: N Brown has already signed up four customers. But it is too early to judge how successful Internet retailing will be, let alone who will profit from running it.

N Brown's shares trade on a multiple of about 23 times its expected earnings for the current year, while Matalan is priced at a stratospheric 35 times forecast profits. That leaves little room for growth, and plenty of risk of disappointments. Nice companies, shame about the share price.

Still worth banking on
There is something about the Internet that encourages even the most focused of companies to believe they can sell anything. Even LloydsTSB, justly famous for its early realisation that high street banks should stick to their core business, suddenly thinks it can also be travel agent, theatre booking agency and restaurant critic.

Its evolve.com Internet banking service offers all this, tailored to its customers' wishes. And this, it thinks, should help it net a quarter of those who chose to bank solely on the Web by 2003.

Fortunately, it also believes that only a minority will want to bank solely on the Internet, and is devoting most of its energies to keeping customers who want to use both hi-tech and conventional services. Here its plans look sensible, albeit no different to those of any of its rivals. And it must still be odds-on that those of us who are banking on the Internet in 10 years time will largely be doing so through the websites of the existing high street banks.

The market, however, remains concerned that its Internet investment - £150m this year and further unspecified figures thereafter - is stepping up just as competition from the Web is pushing margins on the rest of the business lower. That is justified. But the collapse in its shares - they have fallen by 40 per cent since last year's peak - discounts too much bad news. The patient investor should tuck them away.

webTitle: A casket and two obsequies to go, please

fields.headline: A casket and two obsequies to go, please
fields.standfirst: Thomas Lynch ranges over subjects from fishing to Bible studies in his new collection of essays, Bodies at Motion and at Rest
fields.trailText: Thomas Lynch ranges over subjects from fishing to Bible studies in his new collection of essays, Bodies at Motion and at Rest
fields.body:
Bodies in Motion and at Rest
Thomas Lynch
Jonathan Cape £10, pp238

Thomas Lynch is a poet and he is an undertaker. Like his father and grandfather before him, he buries his townspeople, perhaps a couple of hundred a year. He lays them out on the slab, washes them, dresses them, folds their hands on their breasts, stitches up their anuses, closes their eyes. He puts them under the ground with rituals. He comforts the living.

For him, the word 'undertaking' has great resonance. As a child, he imagined the word literally - a taking under (though why not underputting? he wondered). As he grew older, he realised that undertaking was for the living: 'An undertaker was someone who stood with the living confronted with death and pledged to do whatever could be done with it.'

Then finally, undertaking became not something done for the living but something done by them: 'Undertakings,' he writes in an earlier collection, The Undertaking, 'are the things we do to vest the lives we lead against the cold, the meaningless, the void, the noisome blather and blinding dark. It is the voice we give to pain, to love and desire. Anger and courage, the words we shape into song and prayer.'

It is, says Lynch, a pledge and a promise. Reading such words, it no longer seems surprising that an undertaker should be a poet, for Lynch the poet is an undertaker all along.

In his final essay of this new collection, he makes the same lyrical connections between the words he writes and the trade he practises. Though many view an undertaker/poet like they would a cop who sings opera or a wrestler turned governor (and because it makes good copy, he charges accordingly, 'like a dancing bear'), here, he says, is the 'quiet, little truth of the matter. Requiems and prosodies, sonnets and obsequies, poems and funerals - they are all the same... an effort at meaning and metaphor, an exercise in symbol and ritualised speech, the heightened acoustics of language raised against what is reckoned unspeakable - faith and heartbreak, desire and pain, love and grief'.

Or as his hero Seamus Heaney says more succinctly, less self-indulgently: 'Poetry is what we do to break bread with the dead.'

Thomas Lynch is a romantic, in love with the sound of the words that he makes; besotted with the comparisons between poetry and funerals, the undertakings of life and the undertakings of death, between sex and death.

He remembers the first poem he ever heard; the first body he ever saw; the first woman he kissed. He was once an alcoholic, he tells us, and there is in this collection, soaked in reminiscence and that 'heightened acoustic of language', a sense of addiction to sorrow, melancholy, joy, to the nostalgic tales of fateful sexual encounters, and to the sense of himself as an undertaker/poet, lying awake at night while the woman he loves sleeps beside him, and the rain falls on the window, and maybe a candle flickers, and he a sleepless man, half his hard, mistake-laden life behind him, brimful of misty verse.

In The Undertaking, the essays were linked and they were all about the practicalities and metaphysics of his trade, and, as such, they were, if a bit early-Yeatsian in their romantic intensity, somehow irresistible in their unflinching details. Most of us fear death. We peek at death through our fingers, like children; we have to look and we can't. 'I'm not scared of dying,' said Woody Allen. 'I just don't want to be there when it happens.'

But Lynch is there for us, giving us details of what a dead body looks like, feels like, what it smells like, how the flesh congeals, how the relatives weep or turn away from bodies that may be, he says in this new book, 'skinny with Aids, green with liver failure, or bulbous with renal failure... and who'd want to see someone they love like this? Whatever way they got like this. Dead.' The unimaginable becomes commonplace. He sees death for us, reports back from a front line we haven't reached yet, but know we will.

By this collection, however, the subject has been mostly exhausted. Lynch has already written out his obvious subject, and in its place ruminates on all manner of other subjects: the womb, abortion, his ex-wife's bad behaviour, Bible studies, soft porn, fatherhood, his loathed cat, fishing, standing on the seashore, making packed lunches, the way he wrote a particular poem, other poets, his children.

Which is fine, but not what we want from him. We want the post mortem on mystery. His method is freewheeling and associative, letting words and metaphors ratchet him round to unexpected connections, usually coming back at the end to a contemplation of death.

But the most successful pieces in the book are still about his trade. He writes about Jessica Mitford, author of The American Way of Death, whom Lynch, though a friend of hers, accuses of focusing on costs and mechanics so she wouldn't have to think about what death actually means.

Indeed, Lynch fastens on to the word 'cost' throughout the book. 'Do the maths' is one of his favourite phrases, as is 'difficult maths' - adding up the sums for the casket, the funeral, the burial; adding up the costs of a life; getting and spending.

He writes about his son becoming a fully-blown, down-in-the-gutter alcoholic at a horribly early age, (a condition passed down from father to son, burying sorrows in the bottle; seeking oblivion, finding early heaven and hell in whisky and rum). He writes about undertaking chains and the quick-fix burial (Funerals-R-Us, he calls them, or McFunerals).

Best of all, he writes about caskets, and the whole way of selling a burial and marketing a death. After all, you can't enlarge the market like you can for bagels or poetry books. There's only one death for each potential customer's life: 'Do the maths.'

And, in his lovely, facile style that makes us a tad anxious about authenticity, he writes about authentic grief versus the Princess Diana grief. 'The therapy of spectacle', he calls this. 'Our humanity is dulled by mega-doses, like too much pornography dulls real sex... too much information dulls the truth.' Maybe, he says, if we were better at wakes and funerals ('those ancient parlour games we used to play for keeps'), we would have less 'free-floating, unattached heartache'.

In these patchy, repetitive, alluring essays, Lynch calls for us to be 'open to grief: deregulated, unplanned, unruly, potentially embarrassing grief'.
