webTitle: Fatima secret 'foresaw attempt on Pope's life'

fields.headline: Fatima secret 'foresaw attempt on Pope's life'
fields.standfirst: Emma Daly  joins half a million pilgrims in Portugal to hear the third part of the Virgin's 1917 message revealed
fields.trailText: Pope John Paul II used an emotional ceremony at the shrine of Fatima - where he beatified two of the three shepherd children who said they saw visions of the Virgin Mary in 1917 - to reveal the Church's best-kept secret: the third message from the vision of Our Lady at Fatima. The Vatican says it predicted the attempt on his life in 1981.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II used an emotional ceremony at the shrine of Fatima - where he beatified two of the three shepherd children who said they saw visions of the Virgin Mary in 1917 - to reveal the Church's best-kept secret: the third message from the vision of Our Lady at Fatima. The Vatican says it predicted the attempt on his life in 1981.

Once the Pope had beatified Jacinta and Francisco Martos before an ecstatic congregation of perhaps half a million worshippers, his Secretary of State, Cardinal Angelo Sodano, revealed that the third part of the Virgin's message included a vision of the 1981 attack on the Pope by Mehmet Ali Agca. It had been concealed by the Vatican for more than 50 years.

The text, which contains a prophetic vision was written by Sister Lucia de Jesus dos Santos, the third witness to the apparitions and the only survivor.

'According to the interpretation of the "little shepherds", which was also recently confirmed by Sister Lucia, the "bishop clothed in white" who prays for all the faithful is the Pope,' Cardinal Sodano said to applause from the congregation.

'As he makes his way with great effort towards the Cross amid the corpses of those who were martyred (bishops, priests, men and women religious and many lay persons) he too falls to the ground, apparently dead, under a burst of gunfire.'

This revelation helps to explain the Pope's conviction that Our Lady of Fatima saved his life in an attack that took place on the 65th anniversary of the first apparition at Fatima. The Pope believed that 'a motherly hand which guided the bullet's path' delivered him 'from the threshold of death' the cardinal continued.

Asked why the Vatican had not increased protection around the pontiff because of the message, Joaquín Navarro-Valls, the papal spokesman, replied: 'It was only known by the Pope, not by the police.'

This underlines why the pontiff was so determined to visit Fatima, ignoring the advice of officials, who feared that the pilgrimage would prove too much a strain for the Pope after his gruelling and high-profile trips this year to Israel, Egypt and Jordan.

'He was quite insistent', said a Vatican source. 'Once he had made up his mind there was no stopping him.'

Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from across the globe gathered yesterday at the Catholic shrine for the beatification, and many had wondered if the pontiff might reveal the 'third secret' - which had been widely feared to contain an apocalyptic vision. Those gathered in the huge precinct leading to the basilica cheered, wept and tossed rose petals into the papal path as John Paul arrived in his white 'Popemobile', flanked by security men.

In animated form for such a ceremony he feels to be deeply personal, the Pope waved to the crowd and smiled, before entering the basilica for a private meeting with Sister Lucia, close to the marble tombs of her celebrated young cousins, now Blessed Jacinta and Blessed Francisco Martos. Setting a precedent for the Church, which has never before beatified children who have not died as martyrs, the Pope proclaimed Blessed Jacinta and Blessed Francisco as new role models for Christian youth.

Packed worshippers cried out 'Long live the Pope' and cheered as the Portuguese and Vatican flags were pulled down from the basilica's façade to reveal photographs of the children, their expressions solemn, even anxious.

The Pope is well-known for his devotion to the Virgin Mary. It is, says Gerard O'Connell of the Tablet, a leading Catholic journal, 'the thing that goes back to his childhood, it's the constant thread of his own spirituality'. Shortly after his arrival on Friday evening to applause from more than 150,000 people in the congregation, many of whom were preparing to camp out overnight to ensure a good spot for yesterday's Mass, the Pope offered his ring to Our Lady of Fatima, placing it at the foot of a statue whose crown bears the bullet that wounded him in 1981.

Jacinta was only seven at the time of the apparitions, but died two years later, shortly after her elder brother, Francisco.

According to the story told by Sister Lucia's memoirs, the three children saw the Virgin appear six times during 1917, as they pastured sheep in a hollow on the family's farm. 'We beheld a Lady, all dressed in white. She was more brilliant than the sun,' the nun wrote. The vision appeared six times and promised to perform a miracle 'for all to see and believe'. She urged the children to make sacrifices for God, and told Jacinta and Francisco they would soon leave for Heaven, and Lucia would stay on Earth for longer.

On 13 October, a crowd of 70,000 joined the children and reported seeing the sun, harmless to the naked eye, spin on its axis and zigzag across the sky. The children had decided not to reveal the Virgin's words, but Lucia, persuaded by the Church, agreed to publish the first two 'secrets' of Fatima.

These include a vision of hell 'which horrified us and made us tremble with fear', the end of the First World War and the prediction of a second, as well as a call for the conversion of Russia.

In Sister Lucia's account, the Virgin concluded, 'in Portugal, the dogma of the faith will always be preserved... Do not tell this to anybody.' This referred to the remaining secret of Fatima, revealed by Sister Lucia only to the five Popes who have reigned in her time.

'I've been expecting it, because I think with this Pope it's the time for it,' said one English pilgrim who gave her name as Ann, and said that she visits Fatima every year.

'I was expecting him to reveal it today, he's obviously so close to dying. He's the one to bring us all to the consciousness of what Christianity is all about, to go back to the originals.' The Pope has ordered the Vatican to prepare for publication the full text with 'appropriate commentary', the cardinal said, warning that the vision was not of 'photographic clarity' but must be interpreted 'in a symbolic key'.

'The vision of Fatima concerns above all the war waged by atheist systems against the Church and Christians, and it describes the immense suffering endured by the witnesses to the faith in the last century of the second millennium,' the cardinal added.

It is a message that must have resonated strongly with a Pope so famous for his anti-communist crusade.

How a prophecy became history

1917 At Fatima the Virgin appears to Jacinta Marto, her brother, Francisco, and their cousin, Lucia dos Santos, on the 13th day of each month from May to October and reveals three secrets, including a vision of hell and the outbreak of the Second World War.

1941 Sister Lucia dos Santos, the only survivor of the child visionaries, begins writing her memoirs but will not reveal the last part, the 'Third Secret of Fatima'.

1981 A former Trappist monk hijacks an Aer Lingus plane, threatening to blow it up unless the Third Secret is revealed.

In Rome, Pope John Paul II is shot and almost killed by Mehmet Ali Agca, a Turk. The Pope believes the Madonna of Fatima saved his life. He has the bullet welded into the crown of the Virgin in Fatima.

fields.headline: Doomsday on the Tokyo tube
fields.standfirst: On 20 March 1995 the Aum cult launched a sarin gas attack on Tokyo's subway. Twelve people died, thousands were injured and Japan was left traumatised. Here, for the first time, survivors describe how their lives changed forever on that fateful day
fields.trailText: On 20 March 1995 the Aum cult launched a sarin gas attack on Tokyo's subway. Twelve people died, thousands were injured and Japan was left traumatised. Here, for the first time, survivors describe how their lives changed forever on that fateful day
fields.body:
Leafing through a magazine one afternoon, I found myself looking at the letters page. One of the letters caught my attention. It was from a woman whose husband had lost his job because of the Tokyo gas attack. A subway commuter, he had been unfortunate enough to be on his way to work in one of the carriages in which the sarin gas was released. He passed out and was taken to hospital. But even after several days' recuperation, the after-effects lingered on, and he couldn't get himself back into the working routine. At first, he was tolerated, but as time went on his boss and colleagues began to make snide remarks. Unable to bear the atmosphere any longer, he resigned.

The letter shocked me. Here were people who still carried serious psychological scars. As if it weren't enough to be the victim of purely random violence, the man had suffered 'secondary victimisation' (everyday corporate violence of the most pervasive kind). Why could nobody do anything about it? I grew curious to learn more and decided to interview the survivors of the attack.

The degree of suffering inflicted by the sarin attack varied considerably from person to person. Some escaped with little actual harm, those less fortunate died or are still undergoing therapy for serious health problems. I had a hunch that we needed to see a true picture of all the survivors, severely traumatised or not, in order to better grasp the whole incident. But first you must imagine...

The date is Monday 20 March, 1995. It is a beautiful clear spring morning. You get up at the normal time, wash, dress, breakfast, and head for the subway station. You board the train, crowded as usual. Nothing out of the ordinary. It promises to be a perfectly run-of-the-mill day. Until five men in disguise poke at the floor of the carriage with the sharpened tips of their umbrellas, puncturing some plastic bags filled with a strange liquid...

Kiyoka Izumi (26)

Works in the PR department of a foreign airline company

I never get ill, but on the morning of 20 March I wasn't feeling well. I caught the train to work anyway. I stood at the front next to the driver's compartment, holding the handrail. Then, when I took a deep breath, I got this sudden pain. It was like I'd been shot or something, all of a sudden my breathing completely stopped. I'd never felt so bad. It was that intense.

When the train got to my stop I began to feel really sick. So instead of going straight out, I thought I'd better go to the toilet first. As I was passing the stationmaster's office, I saw three station attendants just lying there. I was at a loss. What was going on? When I came out of the station 10 minutes later they had been brought up and were laid on the ground, spoons stuck in their mouths as a precaution against them choking on their tongues. About six other station staff sat there on the flower beds holding their heads and crying. I didn't have a clue what was happening. I thought they were grieving for their colleagues.

TV Tokyo cameramen were filming the whole scene. I ran after the film crew, saying: 'Now's not the time for that! If you've got transport, take these people to the hospital!' The driver conferred with his crew and said, 'All right, fine.'

We managed to lift Mr Takahashi, the station attendant who later died, into the back, along with another assistant. The driver pleaded with me, 'Miss, you come along with us', but there were still lots of others being brought above ground and someone had to look after them, so I stayed behind. There was a girl nearby, crying and trembling. I tried to comfort her until the ambulance came. One man was foaming at the mouth. I had no idea humans could foam like that.

When I got to the office, my boss had seen me on TV, and everyone was asking 'Ms Izumi, are you really okay?'After a while a message came from Personnel: 'If you start to feel ill report to hospital immediately.' So they put me in an ambulance. I had this terrible asthmatic cough, and a high fever of over 40 C [104 F]. I was completely immobilised. As I lay there, the television showed Mr Takahashi lying dead with a spoon in his mouth. I couldn't bear to watch it.

Minoru Miyata (54)

Chauffeur for TV Tokyo

When we got to the station everybody was screaming their heads off. Ikida, the cameraman was shooting the whole scene. That's when somebody spoke up: 'How about instead of filming us, you help take one or two people to hospital?' So me and the crew talk it over. 'What the hell are we going to do?' 'It'll look bad if we don't take them.'

In the car we had assistant stationmaster Takahashi, who died, and another guy, not as bad. We ran all the red lights; went the wrong way down one-way streets. We were desperate; I knew it was life-or-death.

When we got to the hospital they couldn't cope. It was 9.30, over an hour since the gas attack. And yet the hospital didn't know what had happened. That night I learned Takahashi had died, which made me so sad. To think that someone you'd transported didn't make it.

Toshiaki Toyoda (52)

Station attendant

I was on monitor duty that day for the Chiyoda Line, and two colleagues died while I was responsible. Two men who ate in the same canteen as me. To tell the truth, I'd rather not remember it... That day at about 7.40am, I handed over to Okazawa saying: 'Everything's in order.' Pretty soon, though, Okazawa came by, picked up the intercom and said: 'There was an explosion or something at Tsukiji Station, so they've stopped the train.'

Next came a phone call from Central Office: 'Suspicious item sighted on board. Please verify.' When I got to Train A725K I noticed there were spots all over the platform, almost like paraffin or something. And around the base of a pillar were seven or eight big wads of newspaper. Takahashi was on the platform - he'd been trying to mop up the stuff.

I crouched down, picked up the bundles of newspaper up and put them in a plastic bag that Okazawa held open for me. We carried the bags back to the office staffroom. Takahashi stayed on the platform cleaning. I was trembling all over by then. I tried to check the train timetable, but couldn't read the numbers. Just then word came in that Takahashi had collapsed on the platform. I was in no shape to go and help. I tried to call in to Head Office, but my voice wouldn't come. All the time those bundles of sarin-soaked newspapers were right there at my feet.

I went to wash my face. Nose running, eyes watering, not a pretty sight. Have to make myself a bit more presentable, I thought. I stripped off my jacket and washed my face at the sink. I always take off my uniform when I wash so as not to get it wet. Sheer habit. Only later did I find out that this was a good thing, because it was soaked with sarin. Same goes for washing my face.

Just then I started foaming at the mouth. I went faint and collapsed. After that I don't remember a thing.

It was 11 the next morning before I came to, and found out Takahashi and Hishinuma, another colleague, had died. That night I couldn't get to sleep. I'd been spared. After that came the anger. I was irritable, irrational, got upset at everything. It was clearly some sort of hyper-excited condition. I feel a lot more relaxed now, but this rage sometimes flares up over nothing. I have no physical symptoms, but psychologically there's this burden. I've got to get rid of it somehow.

Mitsuteru Izutsu (38)

Shrimp import buyer for a major trading house

I didn't notice anything out of the ordinary until I got off the train. A lot of people coughing, but that was all. I just went to the office. The TV is always on so we can keep up with the exchange rates. When I saw the news report I didn't think for a moment it was the train I'd taken, but slowly I started to feel ill. Everyone said I should go to hospital.

There were a few other sarin victims there and they'd set up a production line to test blood pressure and the like. They still didn't have any antidote, but I was put on a drip for an hour and a half, then I was told to go home and come back tomorrow. They didn't do any tests at all.

The next day was a holiday, so I just lay down and rested. Everything still seemed dark, and I had no energy. Couldn't sleep much at night. I was scared that if I went to sleep I might never wake up again.

I live alone now, but at the time I had a family. A wife and kids. The day after the gas attack, I asked my wife for a divorce. We hadn't been on the best of terms for quite a while. Still, even after all I'd been through, she would barely speak to me. I phoned home from the office to tell her what had happened, but I got almost no reaction from her. Perhaps she couldn't really grasp the situation. But even so, well... I knew then that we'd come to a turning point. I came straight out with it and said I wanted a divorce.

Perhaps if this sarin thing hadn't happened, I wouldn't have said anything. It was a shock to the system and at the same time a kind of trigger.

Kenji Ohashi(41)

Car dealer married with three children

As soon as I got on the train, I noticed two people in odd postures behind me. A man hunched over in his seat, nearly falling off, and a huddled woman, head down and sort of curled up. And then there was this really strange smell. At first I thought there must be some drunk who's thrown up making the place stink.

But I got a seat, so I was prepared to put up with a little smell. I soon fell asleep, so when I suddenly heard the announcement 'This station is Nakano-sakaue', I snapped awake, jumped up and left the train.

Everything was dim. The lights on the platform were faint. My throat was parched and I was coughing. I went to the water-cooler and gargled. My nose was running and my legs were shaky. I sat down. My lungs were wheezing like I was running a marathon. I was afraid if I lost consciousness I'd be done for.

I was taken by police van to Nakano General Hospital. They put me on an IV straight away but we were still wearing our sarin-saturated clothes. Soon the hospital staff were complaining of eye trouble, too.

I was in hospital for 12 days: vicious headaches the whole time. No pain-killer worked. I was in agony. The headaches would come in waves all day. They finally discharged me on 31 March and I took a month off work to recuperate at home. First thing in the morning my head would hurt. It was like a killer hangover.

I took off all of April, then after the early May holidays I started back on the job. I know I overdid it. Every day it felt like I had some massive weight crushing my skull. One day in August it took me three hours to get to work. I had to stop off all along the route and rest until the pain subsided.

I went to see a psychologist at St Luke's Hospital and he said I had post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Since then I've been relieved of my managerial responsibilities and only work 8.30am to 3pm. I feel very isolated. I still have headaches all day.

There have been times I've contemplated suicide. I almost think I'd be better off dead. If I'd lost an arm, or was reduced to a vegetable, people could probably sympathise more. If only I'd died then, how much easier it would have been. But when I think of my family, I have to go on...

Tatsuo Akashi (37)

Elder brother of critically injured 'Shizuko Akashi' who was reduced to a vegetative condition by the attack and remains in hospital.

I had taken the company car to see a client, when a call came in from the office. I was to contact my mother urgently. 'We had a call from the police,' she said. 'Shizuko was injured in the subway and taken to hospital. Go quickly!'

I reached the hospital around noon. The reception was filled with victims. All of them were on drips or getting examined. The doctors weren't much help. All they told me that day was: 'She inhaled a virulent chemical similar to a pesticide.'

I waited for two hours and then got to see her just briefly. She was dressed in a hospital gown and lying in bed getting artificial dialysis. She was on several drips. Her eyes were closed. According to the nurse she was in a 'sleeping state'. I reached out to touch her but the doctor held me back; I wasn't wearing gloves.

She'd been having convulsions since they brought her in. Her face, to be crude, looked more dead than asleep. She had an oxygen mask over her mouth, and she was expressionless. The device that measured her heartbeat hardly flickered, just an occasional blip. I could hardly bear to look at her.

That evening our parents, my wife and kids all came to the hospital. The kids were too small to understand the situation, but seeing them let me get some feelings out. 'Something horrible's happened to Auntie Shizuko ...' I started crying. My kids were upset; they'd never seen me cry before. They tried to comfort me, 'Daddy, Daddy, don't cry!' - and then we were all crying.

A few days later, we were shown an X-ray of her head and were told: 'The brain's swollen.' They said there was virtually no chance of further recovery. In other words, while she wasn't a 'vegetable', she would probably remain bedridden for the rest of her life. Unable to sit up, unable to speak, barely aware of anything.

Since then, she's had therapy and progressed to the point where she can move her right hand. It's still not easy for her to speak, but she seems to understand most of what we're saying. This year she's been able to laugh. I'll say, 'Who farted?' and she'll answer 'Brother' but whether or not she knows what a 'brother' is is another matter. Most of her memory has disappeared.

I go the hospital every other day. It's 11pm by the time I get home. Sundays the whole family goes. My wife's the one I feel sorry for: if she hadn't married me, she wouldn't have to put up with all this. And the kids, too.

The night before the attack, the family was saying over dinner 'My, how lucky we are. All together, having a good time' ... a modest share of happiness. Destroyed the very next day by those idiots. They stole what little joy we had.

(Tatsuo Akashi is not his real name.)

Hiroshige Sugazaki (58)

Insurance executive

As soon as the train door opened that morning I turned right and got a seat. I looked up to see this man sitting directly to my left wearing a leather coat. 'This guy stinks,' I thought and I stared him right in the eye. He just stared back at me with this 'You-got-a-problem, mister?' look.

Then I saw something about the size of a notebook lying at the feet of the second person on my right. A plastic pack with something spilling out of it. Soon there's nobody left at the back of the carriage. Everyone's moved to the front, saying, 'It stinks! It stinks!'

By then my head was spinning. I thought to myself 'I really must be anaemic today.' I decided to get off and rest for a while, maybe let two or three trains go by. But when I tried to stand I couldn't get up. My legs had gone. I grabbed the handstrap and sort of dangled from it.

I moved from strap to strap until I reached the pole near the door. I grabbed it and just slid down to the floor. They ran a photo of me in the tabloids, so I could see later what happened. I was seen on television, too, lying like that on the carriage floor. I was flat out for at least half an hour. Then the station attendants carried me away.

I came to in hospital three days later. I had no awareness of time passing at all. No awareness is paradise.

Around that time one of my daughters was pregnant. I'd been anxious about it. It would be my first grandchild. Well, apparently my sister-in-law came in and said to me: 'What if you never see your grandchild's face?' Until then I'd shown absolutely no reaction to anything anyone had said, but this I heard and suddenly regained consciousness. My grandson was born in September, and thanks to him I came back to life.

I probably shouldn't say this, but all the nurses were beautiful! I even said so to my wife. For some time after I came around, I was convinced everyone in the world had turned beautiful on me [laughs].

I found nights at the hospital frightening, though. Lying in bed, I'd brush up against the frame of the bed and I'd feel like a cold, damp hand was about to drag me into the darkness. I was sure there was a dead person in the ward whispering 'Come with me! This way, this way...'

Back at home it was the same thing. Whenever I stepped on to a tatami mat, whenever I touched anything cold, those fears resurfaced. Even when I took a bath I couldn't do it alone, I was too scared. My wife had to scrub my back. 'Stay with me until I get out,' I told her. 'I don't want to be the last to leave' [laughs].

Some of the victims are afraid to take the subway, even now. I was scared at first, too. I went back to work on 10 May, and from that very first day I took the exact same 7.15 Hibiya Line train that had been targeted in the gas attack. I even made sure I sat in the same carriage - the same seat. At that moment I felt a bit queasy, but having got it over and done with, my spirits lifted. That wiped the slate clean.

Yoshiko Wada (31)

Widow of Eiji Wada. She was pregnant when her husband died. A daughter, Asuka, was born not long afterwards.

I met my husband skiing. This was in February, 1991. We saw each other a lot after that. Every week, and if possible at weekends, too. It really seemed we were made for each other. Like it was fate or something. We were married in June the following year.

We hardly ever quarrelled. I was irritable while I was pregnant. I'd get at him for the most trivial things but he just took it all in his stride. He was such a kind person. He seemed to get even kinder before he died. If he got home from work and the cooking had gone wrong he'd just say, 'It's all right, I'll get a take-away.' And when I had morning sickness and could only eat sandwiches and grapefruit jelly, he'd always buy them for me on the way home from work.

The day before 20 March we went shopping together. Something he'd ordinarily never do. We went to buy baby clothes and nappies, stuff like that. The next morning he said to me, 'If anything ever happens to me, you know you have to hang on in there and fight.' It was as though he had some kind of premonition.

He left the house around 7.30. I pottered about a bit before settling down to watch the Morning Wide Show. Across the TV screen they ran subtitles - 'Such-and-such happened at Tsukiji Station' - but I didn't worry because I thought he commuted by the Marunouchi Line. At 9.30 a call came from the company saying, 'He seems to have got mixed up in this mess. We'll call back later.' Then 10 minutes later, it was, 'He's been taken to Nakajima Hospital. We'll fax you the details so you can get in touch directly.' So I rang them up, but they were in total confusion. 'We can't even keep track of who's here,' they said, and hung up. So all I could do was be patient and wait.

It was just before 10 when the call came: 'It looks pretty bad, come to the hospital as quickly as possible.' I was getting ready to leave when they rang again with the message: 'He just died.'

I took a taxi to the hospital but by the time I got there the body had been transferred to the central police station in Nihonbashi. I took another taxi. The driver had the news on and they were reading out the names of the deceased. I heard my husband's name. I thought, 'I can't be sure until I see his face. I won't cry until I know for sure' ... I just hoped against hope.

They were examining the body, so it was 1.30 before I got to see him in the morgue. They'd laid him out completely naked and covered with a white sheet. 'Don't touch him,' they told me. 'Don't go too near.' If I touched him the sarin would penetrate my skin. But I'd already touched him. He was still warm. There were bloodied bite marks on his lips. Scabs, as if he'd bitten down really hard. And on his ears and nose, too, crusted, where he'd bled. His eyes were shut. I couldn't stay very long because it was 'dangerous'. I was in there less than a minute. 'Why did he have to die?' I said. 'Why did he leave me here?' And I broke down.

The body was transferred to Tokyo University Medical Department where, the next day, I bid him a final farewell. They didn't let me touch him then either, nor my mother-in-law. We could only look. I couldn't believe they'd left him overnight in such a lonely place.

The only good thing now is Asuka. Some little gesture, some food she likes will remind me of him. I'm always telling Asuka, 'Dada was like this.' When Asuka asks, 'Where's Dada?' I point to the photo on the altar and say, 'Dada, Dada.' She says 'Nighty-night' to the photo before going to sleep. It makes me want to cry.

I'm thinking of teaching Asuka to ski. My husband always said he would. I'll wear my husband's gear and teach her. We wore the same size. I think I'll start next season. It's what he would have wanted.

The Aum Shinrikyo Cult

The trial of the Aum Shinrikyo cult members accused of the subway attack began nearly four years ago, after their sarin gas factory was discovered outside Tokyo. One received a death sentence last year and three have been sentenced to indefinite hard labour. The other six, including part-blind guru Shoko Asahara are still in court. The cult continues to thrive. It now has about 2,000 members and earned £30 million last year from its shops selling cut-price computers.

fields.bodyText: Leafing through a magazine one afternoon, I found myself looking at the letters page. One of the letters caught my attention. It was from a woman whose husband had lost his job because of the Tokyo gas attack. A subway commuter, he had been unfortunate enough to be on his way to work in one of the carriages in which the sarin gas was released. He passed out and was taken to hospital. But even after several days' recuperation, the after-effects lingered on, and he couldn't get himself back into the working routine. At first, he was tolerated, but as time went on his boss and colleagues began to make snide remarks. Unable to bear the atmosphere any longer, he resigned. The letter shocked me. Here were people who still carried serious psychological scars. As if it weren't enough to be the victim of purely random violence, the man had suffered 'secondary victimisation' (everyday corporate violence of the most pervasive kind). Why could nobody do anything about it? I grew curious to learn more and decided to interview the survivors of the attack. The degree of suffering inflicted by the sarin attack varied considerably from person to person. Some escaped with little actual harm, those less fortunate died or are still undergoing therapy for serious health problems. I had a hunch that we needed to see a true picture of all the survivors, severely traumatised or not, in order to better grasp the whole incident. But first you must imagine... The date is Monday 20 March, 1995. It is a beautiful clear spring morning. You get up at the normal time, wash, dress, breakfast, and head for the subway station. You board the train, crowded as usual. Nothing out of the ordinary. It promises to be a perfectly run-of-the-mill day. Until five men in disguise poke at the floor of the carriage with the sharpened tips of their umbrellas, puncturing some plastic bags filled with a strange liquid... I stood at the front next to the driver's compartment, holding the handrail. Then, when I took a deep breath, I got this sudden pain. It was like I'd been shot or something, all of a sudden my breathing completely stopped. I'd never felt so bad. It was that intense. When the train got to my stop I began to feel really sick. So instead of going straight out, I thought I'd better go to the toilet first. As I was passing the stationmaster's office, I saw three station attendants just lying there. I was at a loss. What was going on? When I came out of the station 10 minutes later they had been brought up and were laid on the ground, spoons stuck in their mouths as a precaution against them choking on their tongues. About six other station staff sat there on the flower beds holding their heads and crying. I didn't have a clue what was happening. I thought they were grieving for their colleagues. TV Tokyo cameramen were filming the whole scene. I ran after the film crew, saying: 'Now's not the time for that! If you've got transport, take these people to the hospital!' The driver conferred with his crew and said, 'All right, fine.' We managed to lift Mr Takahashi, the station attendant who later died, into the back, along with another assistant. The driver pleaded with me, 'Miss, you come along with us', but there were still lots of others being brought above ground and someone had to look after them, so I stayed behind. There was a girl nearby, crying and trembling. I tried to comfort her until the ambulance came. One man was foaming at the mouth. I had no idea humans could foam like that. When I got to the office, my boss had seen me on TV, and everyone was asking 'Ms Izumi, are you really okay?'After a while a message came from Personnel: 'If you start to feel ill report to hospital immediately.' So they put me in an ambulance. I had this terrible asthmatic cough, and a high fever of over 40 C [104 F]. I was completely immobilised. As I lay there, the television showed Mr Takahashi lying dead with a spoon in his mouth. I couldn't bear to watch it. That's when somebody spoke up: 'How about instead of filming us, you help take one or two people to hospital?' So me and the crew talk it over. 'What the hell are we going to do?' 'It'll look bad if we don't take them.' In the car we had assistant stationmaster Takahashi, who died, and another guy, not as bad. We ran all the red lights; went the wrong way down one-way streets. We were desperate; I knew it was life-or-death. When we got to the hospital they couldn't cope. It was 9.30, over an hour since the gas attack. And yet the hospital didn't know what had happened. That night I learned Takahashi had died, which made me so sad. To think that someone you'd transported didn't make it. Toshiaki Toyoda (52) Station attendant I was on monitor duty that day for the Chiyoda Line, and two colleagues died while I was responsible. Two men who ate in the same canteen as me. To tell the truth, I'd rather not remember it... That day at about 7.40am, I handed over to Okazawa saying: 'Everything's in order.' Pretty soon, though, Okazawa came by, picked up the intercom and said: 'There was an explosion or something at Tsukiji Station, so they've stopped the train.' Have to make myself a bit more presentable, I thought. I stripped off my jacket and washed my face at the sink. I always take off my uniform when I wash so as not to get it wet. Sheer habit. And when I had morning sickness and could only eat sandwiches and grapefruit jelly, he'd always buy them for me on the way home from work. The day before 20 March we went shopping together. Something he'd ordinarily never do. We went to buy baby clothes and nappies, stuff like that. The next morning he said to me, 'If anything ever happens to me, you know you have to hang on in there and fight.' It was as though he had some kind of premonition. He left the house around 7.30. I pottered about a bit before settling down to watch the Morning Wide Show. Across the TV screen they ran subtitles - 'Such-and-such happened at Tsukiji Station' - but I didn't worry because I thought he commuted by the Marunouchi Line. At 9.30 a call came from the company saying, 'He seems to have got mixed up in this mess. We'll call back later.' Then 10 minutes later, it was, 'He's been taken to Nakajima Hospital. We'll fax you the details so you can get in touch directly.' So I rang them up, but they were in total confusion. 'We can't even keep track of who's here,' they said, and hung up. So all I could do was be patient and wait. It was just before 10 when the call came: 'It looks pretty bad, come to the hospital as quickly as possible.' I was getting ready to leave when they rang again with the message: 'He just died.' I took a taxi to the hospital but by the time I got there the body had been transferred to the central police station in Nihonbashi. I took another taxi. The driver had the news on and they were reading out the names of the deceased. I heard my husband's name. I thought, 'I can't be sure until I see his face. I won't cry until I know for sure' ... I just hoped against hope. They were examining the body, so it was 1.30 before I got to see him in the morgue. They'd laid him out completely naked and covered with a white sheet. 'Don't touch him,' they told me. 'Don't go too near.' If I touched him the sarin would penetrate my skin. But I'd already touched him. He was still warm. There were bloodied bite marks on his lips. Scabs, as if he'd bitten down really hard. And on his ears and nose, too, crusted, where he'd bled. His eyes were shut. I couldn't stay very long because it was 'dangerous'. I was in there less than a minute. 'Why did he have to die?' I said. 'Why did he leave me here?' And I broke down. The body was transferred to Tokyo University Medical Department where, the next day, I bid him a final farewell. They didn't let me touch him then either, nor my mother-in-law. We could only look. I couldn't believe they'd left him overnight in such a lonely place. The only good thing now is Asuka. Some little gesture, some food she likes will remind me of him. I'm always telling Asuka, 'Dada was like this.' When Asuka asks, 'Where's Dada?' I point to the photo on the altar and say, 'Dada, Dada.' She says 'Nighty-night' to the photo before going to sleep. It makes me want to cry. I'm thinking of teaching Asuka to ski. My husband always said he would. I'll wear my husband's gear and teach her. We wore the same size. I think I'll start next season. It's what he would have wanted. The Aum Shinrikyo Cult The trial of the Aum Shinrikyo cult members accused of the subway attack began nearly four years ago, after their sarin gas factory was discovered outside Tokyo. One received a death sentence last year and three have been sentenced to indefinite hard labour. The other six, including part-blind guru Shoko Asahara are still in court. The cult continues to thrive. It now has about 2,000 members and earned £30 million last year from its shops selling cut-price computers.  This is an extract from Underground by Haruki Murukami (Harvill £20). fields.headline: Control freaks
fields.standfirst: The rules governing appellation contrôlée wines are no guarantee of a decent bottle
fields.trailText: The rules governing appellation contrôlée wines are no guarantee of a decent bottle
fields.body:
Travelling on the Eurostar recently, I was handed a menu. 'All of our wines are from appellation contrôlée areas,' it informed me. Big deal, I thought. Some of the world's worst wines are produced in delimited areas, and not just in France. In the last week, I've had bottles of Chianti, Rioja and Hock that should have been poured straight into the European wine lake.

In France, you only have to look at the rubbish that's sold as Bordeaux, Muscadet, Beaujolais and Champagne to question the validity of appellations. That said, I'm pleased to see that the authorities in Bordeaux have started to do something about their region's sorry image by rejecting 30 per cent of the samples submitted by producers from the 1999 vintage. The failure rate is usually six per cent.

Appellations do not, and never have, been a mark of quality. There are bad and good wines produced in appellation areas, just as there are in every wine region in the world. Appellations are supposed to be a guarantee of origin, but there's so much cheating going on in Europe these days that you can never be sure.

So what's the point of appellations? As far as the consumer is concerned, none whatsoever. Appellations have two main functions: as a marketing tool and as a way of protecting producers' interests. Mediocre winemakers can hide behind a famous appellation name - Clos du Vougeot springs to mind - and sell their wines to gullible label drinkers.

The worst thing about appellations is that they stifle innovation. The people who police them are the paperclip brigade of the wine trade. 'You can't plant those varieties here,' they say. 'You can't blend this with that.' Their grounds for favouring one set of grape varieties over another are often tenuous at best.

It took a wholesale revolt against the appellation rules in Tuscany (with some of the best producers selling their wines as vini da tavola) to get Cabernet Sauvignon admitted to the list of permitted varieties and to allow wineries to make wines entirely from the Sangiovese grape. When these super-Tuscan reds reached prices that were far higher than the very best Chianti Classico, the authorities had to act, even in Italy.

Despite such a precedent (and the success of New World countries that allow producers to make what they want, where they want), the jobsworth tendency is still alive and prosecuting. In the Languedoc, Jean-Louis Denois, of the Domaine de l'Aigle, has been fined for planting a few rows of Riesling and Gewürztraminer in the cool climate area of Limoux, and ordered to pull them out.

Meanwhile, in the Alentejo, Cortes de Cima has run into trouble with the Comissão Regional for producing a wine made from Syrah, a grape that has a great future in Portugal, but which is not authorised locally. The owners tried calling their wine 'Chiraz' and 'Hary's' (Syrah backwards), but had to settle for Incógnito. The wine has sold out in Portugal, but has enraged traditionalists who want to see it banned.

If the Old World wants to compete with the New World (and the competition is getting fiercer by the vintage), it's time it stopped fighting with one arm bound behind its collective back.

fields.headline: Asparagus tips
fields.standfirst: Some food is too good to be eaten with a knife and fork - these delicate spears make perfect finger food
fields.trailText: Nigel Slater: Some food is too good to be eaten with a knife and fork - these delicate spears make perfect finger food
fields.body:
I didn't see it at first, that short, purple spear poking through the sodden soil. I had to crouch, my knees wobbling, my gumboots sinking deeper and deeper into the Evesham mud to get a proper look. Then I spotted a second close by, then another and then a group of three, all pointing skywards through the bare, dark soil. I would need to pick the entire field if there was to be asparagus for tea. It was only late morning, but the day's cutting was already done. Asparagus waits for no one.

But there was asparagus for tea, even so early in the short six-week season, and we ate it in the local style, that is, with melted butter and thin brown bread. None of your chargrilled with sauce Maltaise here. Twelve spears apiece, and a feast in the true sense of the word. No knives and forks, just gingham napkins and much sucking of fingers. I wiped the butter from my chin with the back of my hand.

That is what asparagus should be about. If you are using cutlery, then you are not really eating. You are just playing with your food - just like we were always told not to. This is a vegetable to revel in. The six weeks of the British asparagus season are soon over, and I cannot see why we shouldn't gorge ourselves.

The older I get, the more I like Asparagus officinalis. At first, in early May, I will dip the spears into nothing more sophisticated than melted butter. I am not sure you really need an egg-and-butter sauce such as Hollandaise with it, but that is what I invariably make. Sometimes it curdles, sometimes it doesn't. As the season whizzes by, I am happier to gild the lily, though that may mean little more than wrapping a piece of thin, air-dried ham such as St Daniele around each spear.

If and when I do get fancy, then my asparagus will end up in something that contains dairy products of some sort - in a crumbly tart, perhaps, or in a risotto I finish with butter and grated cheese. I have tried taking the dairy-free route with this vegetable, and it loses all point.

This is something to eat as soon as you get it home. A night in the fridge will do your bundle no favours at all. Like the older varieties of sweetcorn, asparagus toughens and loses its sweetness by the hour, but it will be fine on its short journey from Worcestershire or Norfolk. Dry ends, so often hidden by the packer's paper, are difficult to spot, but matter much less than withered spears or open flowers. The fresher it is, the tighter the points will be.

I will not agree with those who say that it is unrealistic, xenophobic even, only to eat certain foods in their natural season. I don't care how quickly a bundle of asparagus is flown to us from the Far East, I have never found it compares with locally grown spears in terms of taste or succulence. But there is more to it than timing. To me, eating this particular ingredient out of season just feels wrong. There is something as uncomfortable about eating asparagus in January as there is in watching Wimbledon in November.

I do think how and when you eat something is as important as what you eat. If I am to get a meal well and truly right, and why else bother to cook, then the whole experience - the when, the what and the where, if you like - must be considered, too. There is more to a meal than the food on the plate. Yes, of course, I buy the occasional punnet of Chilean blueberries to brighten up a winter fruit salad (they are good with passion fruit and mango), and I don't feel so bad about Spanish strawberries in February, either. But there is something about those shrink-wrapped trays of Guatemalan asparagus that makes my heart sink.

I have come across some truly ridiculous methods for cooking asparagus, but any method you choose must protect the delicate spears. I have cooked them in a heap in a large pan of boiling water with only the loss of one tender point, but even that is one too many. There is success to be had in laying your treasure in a deep frying pan full of water, the points resting on the side of the pan, but you end up having to make a daft foil hat for them and scalding yourself into the bargain.

Last week, I bought a fine bunch of early Lincolnshire asparagus and wondered if steaming might be a good way to get them to the table in one piece. My longest oval pan is a good size for long, thin vegetables but has no steamer attachment, so I swaddled them in a clean tea towel and tied the ends to the handles. They took a little longer than usual because the lid no longer fitted tight to the pan, but the method seemed appropriate for such valuable cargo and I ended up with perfect spears, tender, succulent and intact, and ate them with nothing but melted butter and brown bread. Evesham might have thought well of me.

Asparagus and mint tart

Serves 6

for the pastry

90g butter

150g plain flour

an egg yolk

very little water

for the filling

12 medium-thick spears of asparagus

1 medium carton (284ml) double cream

2 eggs

12 largish mint leaves

3 tbsps grated pecorino or Parmesan

Cut the butter into small chunks and rub it into the flour with your fingertips until it resembles coarse fresh breadcrumbs. Mix in the egg yolk and enough water to make a firm dough. You will find you may need about a tablespoon or even less.

Roll the dough out to fit a 22cm tart tin (life will be easier when you come to cut the tart if you have a loose-bottomed tin), pressing the pastry right into the corners. Prick the pastry with a fork, then refrigerate it for a good 20 minutes. Don't be tempted to miss out this step - the chilling will stop the pastry from shrinking in the oven.

Bake at 200°C/gas mark 6 for 12-15 minutes until the pastry is pale biscuit-coloured and dry to the touch. Bring a large pan of water to the boil, drop in the asparagus and let it simmer for 7 or 8 minutes or so, until it is quite tender. It will receive more cooking later, but you want it to be thoroughly soft after its time in the oven, and its texture will barely alter under the custard.

Put the cream in a jug or bowl and beat in the eggs gently with a fork. Roughly tear up the mint and add that to the cream with a seasoning of salt and black pepper. Slice the asparagus into short lengths, removing any tough ends.

Scatter the asparagus over the partly baked pastry case, then pour in the cream and egg mixture, and scatter the cheese over the surface. Bake, with the oven temperature lowered to 180°C/ gas mark 4, until the filling is golden and set (about 40 minutes). Serve warm.

Roast asparagus

There is no joy in undercooked asparagus. It must be soft and juicy, otherwise it loses much of its magic. Baking the spears in a foil parcel in the oven will suit those who don't like messing around with steam, and keeps the asparagus succulent. Serves 2.

450g thin spears of asparagus

2 tbsps light, mild, olive oil

the juice of 1 lemon

Place the asparagus on a large sheet of kitchen foil. Drizzle over the oil and lemon juice and then scatter over a seasoning of salt. Bring the edges of the foil up and seal them tightly (you want the asparagus to cook in its own steam). Bake for 15-20 minutes at 180°C/gas mark 4 or until the spears are tender.

Warm asparagus with melted cheese

The cheese should melt easily. I have used Taleggio, Brie, Camembert and a Pavé d'Affinois with great success. I cannot see why a mild, oozing Gorgonzola would not work either. I am not usually someone who bothers with 'starters', but this would make an elegant start to a more formal dinner. Serves 2.

12 spears of asparagus, thick and juicy

150g soft, ripe cheese

Cook the asparagus in boiling, lightly salted water till it is tender enough to bend. Lift the spears out with a draining spoon and lower them into a shallow baking dish.

Remove the crust and slice the cheese thinly, then lay it over the asparagus. Place under a hot grill till the cheese melts. Eat immediately.

Baked asparagus with pancetta

Serves 2

Boil a bundle of asparagus until it is just tender. Drain it carefully, then lay the spears in a shallow baking dish. Heat the oven to 200°C/gas mark 6.

Melt a generous slice of butter in a shallow pan and fry a handful of diced pancetta, or mildly smoked bacon, until its fat is golden. Tip it and the butter over the asparagus then sprinkle with a little grated Parmesan and bake for 10 minutes till the cheese has melted.

 Nigel Slater's Real Food is now out in paperback (Fourth Estate, £12.99)

fields.headline: An Englishman abroad
fields.standfirst: Richard Neat made his name in London, now he's stealing the limelight in Cannes. By Jay Rayner
fields.trailText: Richard Neat made his name in London, now he's stealing the limelight in Cannes. By Jay Rayner
fields.body:
Richard Neat does not like talking about the food he cooks. That's fine; everybody else will do it for him. At the Cannes Film Festival this week, his 45-cover restaurant, on the seafront opposite the Palais des Festivals, is the only place guaranteed to a be at full capacity for every performance. It's been like this since it opened last summer. In February, the Michelin Guide awarded both Neat the restaurant and Neat the chef a single Michelin star. He was the first Englishman working in France ever to manage such a thing.

This is the sort of stuff he is more than happy to talk about, even if he feels the 'successful English chef in France' tale is getting a bit worn. But he loves the fact that, as he puts it, his 'star is in the ascendancy in London' by mere virtue of his not being there; that when he took over the restaurant, he upset local trade by getting rid of all the Frenchmen in the kitchen and replacing them with English chefs.

Then again, he's known for the grand gesture. After working with Raymond Blanc, Joel Robouchon in Paris and Marco Pierre White (whom he says he 'hates with a passion' - he calls him 'the unwashed chef'), Neat made his name at Pied à Terre in London. He picked up his first Michelin star shortly after opening. A little later, he won a second. On the same day it was announced, he quit. He'd had enough, he said. He and his wife Sophie were going travelling in India. Few could understand how a young chef, right at the top of his profession, could quit while so far ahead.

He didn't bother to explain. After two years in New Delhi, he simply reappeared on the French Riviera. 'The restaurant in Cannes was always part of the plan,' says Neat, now aged 33. He wanted to be able to spend his downtime on the beach. He wanted somewhere nice to walk his beloved boxer dog. Cannes just made sense. But as to analysing the food he serves there, he won't play. At the end of an extraordinary dinner, I am presented with dessert. By then, Neat has left the kitchen and is sitting at my table, dressed in sweats, the first of his many post-service cigarettes clutched between his long fingers. As each of the seven - count them, seven - other courses arrived, I had been treated to florid descriptions by the waiters: a coulis of this, a velouté of the other. But now, as chef is at table, they defer; the dish is simply placed before me. I ask Neat for a description. He leans forward, sniffs and says, 'Bit of white chocolate, some mousse, a few raspberries.' And then he takes another drag on his fag. 'It's the new dessert,' he says. 'Only tried it myself this evening.' His pastry chef designed it, but he was happy enough with the result to let it out of his kitchen.

This reluctance to talk food may be down to a general reticence born of precise Englishness. He grew up in a Forces family, and says many chefs have that sort of background. ('All top chefs are right-wingers,' he says at one point, with a toothy grin. 'We're all rampant capitalists, too. Can we charge 30 quid for the turbot? No, make it 36 quid. That sort of thing.') In this kind of world, it's about doing rather than saying. Partly, I think, he feels there are few who know enough about this level of cooking with whom he can have a proper conversation. But I also think he's simply content for the cooking to speak for itself.

And boy, is it articulate. It should be said that this meal was not eaten under the usual conditions of The Observer restaurant review. Which is to say I didn't go there anonymously and the paper didn't cough up. But with cooking of this calibre, it was hardly likely to cloud my judgment. If anything, the one Michelin star is misleading. This is at least a notch up from that, but the Michelin organisation was never likely to bestow the full accolade on a chef just seven months after opening - and certainly not on an English one.

I began with an amuse-gueule of rillettes of red mullet on an almond and prune sauce. Rillettes of fish are usually made with butter. Here, Neat used goose fat. It was rich without being cloying, and the gentle sweetness of the sauce firmly anchored it. Next came a tian of dense brown crabmeat wrapped in skate wing on a refreshing cucumber velouté. The third course was Neat's signature dish, and the only one to have followed him from Pied à Terre: escargots rolled in a light chicken mousse and dusted in chopped morels on a wild mushroom sauce. It was a dark and meaty combination and fully deserving of the praise it has received whenever it has turned up on one of Neat's menus.

And onwards we rolled, each course a measured few forkfuls all designed to make this parade manageable. The crab was followed by a second fish course: pan-fried sea bass on a dark and salty bouillabaise reduction. Next came melting sweetbreads wrapped in parma ham on a bed of polenta and wild mushrooms.

All these were served with a big flowery Gewürtztraminer from the Hugel winery in Alsace, chosen by sommelier Bruno Asselin. There was cheese served with port, a tiny thimble of crème brûlée followed by a chocolate and raspberry dessert with a glass of Beaumes de Venise. Listed like this, it looks obscene, and in a way it probably is. But this is Neat's tasting menu, and in the measurement of portions and the contrasting of ingredients, it does boast a real kind of art.

Despite the turbot crack, his food is also not fiendishly expensive. There is a three-course dinner menu at around £27 and even the carte would keep things pegged back around the £40 a head mark for the food, which for cooking of this calibre is not extortionate. You can pay that and more for disappointing style-over-content exercises in any of London's new restaurants.

Soon Neat intends to take them on, too. He is returning to London later this year to open a new brasserie. He will spend two days a week in Britain, the rest in Cannes. 'I'm restless,' he says. 'And I have two guys in my kitchen here who will soon be ready to run their own places. It would be better if I had them working for me for a while in the new place rather than leaving the company.' He won't say much about the new place except that, compared to Neat in Cannes, it will be 'rough and ready'.

He knows that starting the London operation will mean the end of the tight family he has created in France. 'I'll probably never work in such a good, professional and fun environment ever again,' he says, almost wistfully. He is, it seems, in the fortunate position of having the time of his life and knowing it. Happily, the pleasure he is having is showing up in exactly the right place: on the plate.

fields.headline: See how they grow
fields.standfirst: Their perfect packets make buying seeds a pleasure - even if you never get round to sowing them
fields.trailText: Their perfect packets make buying seeds a pleasure - even if you never get round to sowing them
fields.body:
So much of gardening is bound up in ritual. Every garden has its own liturgy. The seasons impose a rhythmic observance of custom that in turn becomes customised by every gardener. One of my own favourite gardening rituals is the annual laying out of seeds that we have ordered by mail, shuffling the packs on to the kitchen table to create an embryonic map of the garden. We pretend that it is an important 'job' - that it needs to be done sometime in January so that we can plan and organise the pattern of seed sowing.

Utter nonsense of course. We do it because it makes us feel good, and all those packets of flat paper envelopes look good. When the game is done they go back into the box and the seed is sown as randomly and impulsively as horticultural sense will allow. But the ritual pleasure of relishing the packets themselves never wanes. I discovered this long before I ever sowed a seed. Nearly 40 years ago I marched unannounced into the cottage of some neighbours - as we all seemed to do in those days - to find them standing back, silently admiring their seed delivery spread out on the table like a feast. I did not know what the individual seeds were - although with hindsight I'm sure they would nearly all have been vegetables and very ordinary ones at that - but I could tell the table was almost glowing with richness and promise.

Thinking back on it, they had probably poured over the catalogue for weeks, despite the fact that they bought exactly the same, year after year. That spread of packets represented real investment and expectation. They would hardly have starved if all the harvests failed, but the quality of their lives would have been inferior. Those packets were precious.

One of the ironies of this is that very few seeds are remotely precious. Most plants produce the things effortlessly, in huge quantities, for free. This raw material needs no working by expensive machinery, no human skill to make it useful.

In practice we buy the packet as much as the seeds inside it. It acts as both marketing device and container. A poster or television advertising campaign for seeds would be stupid - they are a poster campaign in themselves. You can chart cultural and aesthetic values through the changing designs on seed packets - from the surrealy garish or the coyly kitsch with their promise of flowers as wholesome as apple pie, to the brown-paper plain of the organic movement. You can even collect antique seed packets - the Richter Gallery (www.sover.net/~oldlabel) sells pre-First World War packets on the net.

Seeds are the perfect candidate for mail order. They take up hardly any space, will store for years, cost practically nothing to produce and have a steady source of supply. They are very light and therefore cheap to deliver, and they are unlikely to be damaged in transit. There is huge profit to be made from them.

However, the vast majority - some 90 per cent - of all seeds are sold retail. One of the side effects of these huge profit margins is that the larger seed companies wage fierce discount wars to get retailers to stock their range and give it pride of place. It is on the shelves that seed packets, rather than the seeds themselves, come into their own. They stack and rack perfectly. Nothing influences sales more than the picture on the front of the packet. Seed packets are like book covers. We browse and buy on visual whim: shoppers looking for a tray of petunias will see a packet of lettuce seed, buy it and in the process pick up half a dozen other packets as well. Most will never get sown. Seed companies, like mustard manufacturers, happily make money from their product being wasted.

Thompson & Morgan told me that changing the photograph on the packet can transform sales overnight. But printing good-quality colour pictures is expensive - much more expensive, and only viable on huge runs. Inevitably this counts against the small, specialist producer. But niche marketing is probably the future of seed selling. Every producer is now packaging mixtures of seed, either in the same packet or as a set of packets, be it for a herb garden, summer salad, hanging basket or spring windowbox. For the most part, each 'collection' (pass the sick bag) has an artful but unstylish photo. The result is probably very popular and successful but it has all the style of a 1950s girdle ad.

Sarah Raven's Cutting Garden - a small producer of specialist seeds - has turned this on its head by using transparent packets, so you can see the seeds inside, and colour-coded, stylishly printed labels with one picture per group of seeds. The result is glamorous and up-market. Chase Organics sells all the seeds in The Organic Gardening Catalogue in brown-paper bags with green (geddit?) lettering. Predictable, but certainly clear branding.

Despite all the efforts put into the packets, more and more people are buying their bedding plants in trays from a garden centre for hundreds of times what it would cost to grow them from seed. But we are a rich society. We can afford it. The fact is that most people with a garden would not dream of growing anything from seed. But in my view, sowing a few seeds is probably the most significant shift from doing the garden to becoming 'a gardener'. At a stroke you are going beyond the kick of instant gratification and bringing time into the equation: and time always makes gardening so much more interesting than any kind of quick fix.

webTitle: Got a dream? Then keep reinvesting

fields.headline: Got a dream? Then keep reinvesting
fields.trailText: We buy shares to make our money grow. We want to be wealthy in our retirement, perhaps even buy a yacht and sail round the world. If we invest our cash in something that actually increases in value, rather than just lying around in a deposit account, our dreams may come closer to reality.
fields.body:
We buy shares to make our money grow. We want to be wealthy in our retirement, perhaps even buy a yacht and sail round the world. If we invest our cash in something that actually increases in value, rather than just lying around in a deposit account, our dreams may come closer to reality.

What few people realise, however, is that real growth in equities comes not from capital growth but from reinvesting the dividends. If you spend the income from your share portfolio, you could find yourself falling well short of achieving your dreams.

Consider the following example of two trusts, each established with £1 at the start of the century, quoted in The Millennium Book: A Century of Investment Returns , an analysis of investment performance published by broker ABN Amro and the London Business School. The first trust paid out all its income, the second used it to buy more shares. By the end of the century, the spendthrift fund had accumulated £161, a return about three times the rate of inflation and enough to buy perhaps a small rowing boat.

But the trust that re-invested all its dividends had amassed £16,946, enough for at least a second-hand yacht. The same holds true over shorter periods. Barclays Capital's annual Gilt/Equity study shows that £100 invested at the end of 1990 had grown to £244 by the end of the decade. Re-investing dividends increases that to £334: a 14.4 per cent annual return, compared with 9.4 per cent if dividends are taken away.

The reason is simple: compound interest. We all see it with our mortgage payments, where an apparently reasonable interest rate adds up to the need to repay three or four times the value of the loan over 25 years. With investments, the compounding works in our favour. Many investors already realise that. Foreign & Colonial, for example, estimates that 90 per cent of regular savers with its flagship trust reinvest their income. But what about those who hold shares directly? Some companies give shareholders the option of taking their dividends as shares, but this is by no means universal. Collecting interim and final dividends from all direct investments and using the lump sum to buy shares once a year would help push up returns, but few people will be that organised.

There are, however, signs that dividends are becoming a less important component of investment returns. Barclays Capital, for example, estimates that the contribu tion has fallen from 5.5 per cent in 1989 to 2.6 per cent in 1999. That is hardly surprising given that some of the fastest-growing technology companies do not pay dividends - Microsoft, for example, has never provided shareholders with income.

But it is also due to demographics. We are all getting older and saving more for retirement. That is pushing up demand for equities, and therefore prices, faster than companies are increasing their dividends. That will ultimately reverse - if only because we will retire and want to cash in our shares.

In the meantime, those who want to get the most out of their shares should keep reinvesting the dividends.

webTitle: How Bill Gates wooed the love bug

fields.headline: How Bill Gates wooed the love bug
fields.trailText: 'We know no spectacle so ridiculous,' wrote Macaulay, 'as the British public in one of its periodical fits of morality.' One wonders what he would have made of the 'love bug' infection which, for a brief period recently, apparently threatened the very fabric of civilisation as we know it.
fields.body:
'We know no spectacle so ridiculous,' wrote Macaulay, 'as the British public in one of its periodical fits of morality.' One wonders what he would have made of the 'love bug' infection which, for a brief period recently, apparently threatened the very fabric of civilisation as we know it.

Journalists who two years ago thought email was a form of body armour have been speculating learnedly on the fiendish minds and unfathomable motives of virus writers. All this heat, however, generated little light. And one or two intriguing aspects of the story went oddly unreported.

The bug was variously described as a 'virus' or a 'worm', as if the two concepts were synonymous. Yet the computing fraternity has hitherto regarded them as distinct species. According to Eric Raymond's New Hacker's Dictionary, for example, a virus is a program that searches out other programs and infects them, so that when they are executed - that is, run - the embedded virus is executed, too, thereby propagating itself.

'Unlike a worm,' Raymond says, 'a virus cannot infect other computers without assistance. It is propagated by vectors such as humans trading programs with their friends'. A worm, in contrast, is 'a program that propagates itself over a network, reproducing itself as it goes'.

So was the love bug a virus or a worm? The CERT software co-ordination center at Carnegie-Mellon University, normally considered the definitive authority on these matters, was careful to describe it as a worm. Yet it is clear that the infection was disseminated like a virus, by humans engaging in what Dr. Johnson would call epistolary intercourse.

What went unreported was the fact that the only systems affected were, according to CERT, 'systems running Microsoft Windows with Windows Scripting Host enabled'. When the worm executes, reported CERT, 'it attempts to send copies of itself, using Microsoft Outlook, to all the entries in all the address books'.

We have been here before. Readers of this column will remember the Melissa email virus, which likewise displayed an inordinate affection for Microsoft Outlook. What the love bug demonstrates is that, in computing as in agriculture, monoculture is more vulnerable than biodiversity. Or, as Scott Rosenberg put it in Salon, 'using Outlook is like hanging a sign on your back that reads: "Please mess with my computer".'

Actually, the problem is not just with Outlook but with the entire Windows architecture. The Microsoft philosophy is to create a completely integrated system in which all the components - Word, Excel, Powerpoint, Internet Explorer - are seamlessly interconnected. Bill Gates says this is to make life easier for consumers by giving them one-shop computing without having to worry about the details. The US government says it's his scheme for taking over the world.

Whatever the interpretation, the effect of the Windows architecture is the same: it creates a system on your computer which is vulnerable to attack because if an intruder program can infect any component, it can easily subvert the others.

In an odd way, therefore, the love bug problem and the Microsoft anti-trust case are linked. In an extended whinge in Time magazine, Gates railed against the Department of Justice's 'profound hostility' to Microsoft's efforts to 'make products that work well with one another'.

Later in the same piece he argued that the company should not be broken up because 'updates to Windows and Office technologies that could, for example, protect against attacks such as the love bug virus would also be much harder for computer users to obtain'.

In other words: Microsoft should be allowed to sell systemically vulnerable software systems because that makes it easier to get fixes when their vulnerabilities are exposed.

I've always thought Gates would go mad in the end. It seems he's shaping up nicely.

John.Naughton@observer.co.uk

Later in the same piece he argued that the company should not be broken up because 'updates to Windows and Office technologies that could, for example, protect against attacks such as the love bug virus would also be much harder for computer users to obtain'. In other words: Microsoft should be allowed to sell systemically vulnerable software systems because that makes it easier to get fixes when their vulnerabilities are exposed. I've always thought Gates would go mad in the end. It seems he's shaping up nicely. John.Naughton@observer.co.uk  www.briefhistory.com/footnotes

webTitle: As you spin, so shall you reap

fields.headline: As you spin, so shall you reap
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair should drop his obsession with explaining what he is trying to do, and just get on with doing it
fields.trailText: The people are disgruntled with their Government, but not half as annoyed as the Prime Minister is with the people. An irritable buzz has crept into the discourse between leader and nation. Tony Blair frowns at us with frustration. Why doesn't Britain get it?
fields.body:
The people are disgruntled with their Government, but not half as annoyed as the Prime Minister is with the people. An irritable buzz has crept into the discourse between leader and nation. Tony Blair frowns at us with frustration. Why doesn't Britain get it? Why does he have to explain his project to us yet again? Why isn't the country displaying more appreciation for the many wonderful gifts showered upon it by New Labour? Well, sod the lot of you. The Great Helmsman will 'stay focussed' and drive forward 'come fair weather or foul'.

The obvious answer to Mr Blair's consternation about the country's wilful ingratitude is that even he isn't immune from the voters' eternal reflex to give their governors a kick in the ballots at mid-term. But that is not good enough for the Prime Minister. The reason he supplies is that the fine work of New Labour is being blackened by the 'forces of cynicism'. These shadowy subversives obviously serve duty as an alibi for his recent electoral battering, but it is more than an excuse. Anyone who has spent any private time with Tony Blair comes away with the clear impression of a man who is genuinely confounded that he is still failing to get across what he calls his 'mission'. The Prime Minister complains that they pay more respect to the Third Way in South Korea than we do in Britain. He is not to be consoled with the thought that it is ever the fate of prophets not to be honoured in their own homelands, and especially not, in his case, in their heartlands.

So this week he and his senior cohorts will have another crack at dinning the Big Idea into our heads. On successive days, in a relaunch which the Government will be most keen not to call a relaunch, the Chancellor, Prime Minister and Home Secretary will be offering mission statements.

The oddity is this. I can think of no Prime Minister in history who has devoted more words to explaining the purpose of his Government. Most leaders are content to get on with governing. Mr Blair wants my job, too. He offers a running political commentary on his own administration. My filing cabinet bulges with speeches by Mr Blair exploring his Project. And yet - about this he is quite right - it remains opaque to much of the electorate.

Tony Blair is brilliantly fluent, but strangely inarticulate. This is not such a paradox as it seems. I think, rather, it is an explanation. The Government is not getting his mission across because it so relentlessly over-communicates the message.

What can we say, using unexcitable language, that we know about New Labour from experience of it as a Government? It has avoided the economic disaster that has struck every previous Labour Cabinet, and many Tory Cabinets. It has succeeded, where all previous progressive governments failed, in devolving to Scotland and Wales, and removing most of the hereditary peers. It has guided Northern Ireland into the most peaceful period since the beginning of the Troubles. It has been mildly redistributive from rich to poor. It has some illiberal features. It has not done anything spectacularly stupid or ruinous. As governments go, that is a well above-average score. To describe his record in those flattering, but prosaic terms, is not enough for Tony Blair. At various times, he has told us that his ambition is to create 'The Decent Society', 'An Age of Achievement', 'The Giving Age', 'The Radical Century', 'A Twenty- first Century Model Nation', 'Beacon To The World', and - the runt of this oratorical litter - 'A Young Country'.

Unsurprisingly, the voters are a bit bemused. The contents of the package have been obscured by all these over-blown labels. New Labour suffers from rhetorical and presentational diarrhoea. An endless discharge of initiatives, announcements, speeches, signed articles, and roadshows spews from the machine to assail the senses of the voters. The obsession with over-hyping even the most modest progress as 'radical' or 'revolutionary' has ironically served to mask the Government's real achievements. The media and the voters discount everything for spin.

That is what the Government itself has tutored us to do. The most infamous example is the phoney £40 billion for education and health manufactured by Gordon Brown two years ago. I still have not established to my satisfaction whether the Chancellor was merely trying to fool the country or whether this was mainly designed to bamboozle the Prime Minister into believing that they were spending a lot more on schools and hospitals than they actually were. I will let you know when I have completed my inquiries. As a result of that - a major strategic blunder - the media and the public now treat any spending announcements, even the genuine ones, as suspect. The forces of cynicism have been encouraged by the Government's own fiddling of figures and regurgitation of the same money umpteen times. No one knows anymore what can be taken at face value and what is bogus, what is meat and what is candyfloss.

A depressing classic of New Labour's fixation with image is the Health Secretary's groan-inducing declaration that the NHS is to get a new 'logo' - so Nineties - and the Government will spend £500,000 on a consultative exercise to find out what patients want from the health service. Alan Milburn calls it a 'once in a life-time chance' to have your say. Providing, of course, that your life-time is not cut short by the inadequacies of the health service. I do not have access to a mega focus group, but instinct tells me that the last thing the majority of patients want money spending on is a new badge for the health service. The Government has now embarked on a four-year programme of real and massive investment in the health service. Then it goes and spoils it with this sort of silliness. Who on earth did they expect to impress by recruiting Sir Richard Branson to offer advice on the efficiency of the NHS? I suppose Sir Rich knows something about waiting lists: he calls them train timetables. But, come on, is there a more tired gimmick than the bearded balloonist?

A shrewd Cabinet Minister suggests that what the voters would most like to hear from New Labour is 'a period of silence'. They should cease the frenetic boasting in favour of a stretch of quietly competent governing. He then went on to admit that he himself had made no less than six speeches in as many days.

New Labour is chemically incapable of dropping the hype for fear that it will leave a noise vacuum which will be filled by its opponents and critics.

The greatest victim of the spin cycle is its progenitor. In the flesh, Tony Blair is an engaging, serious and strategic politician. Beneath the crud of verbiage that has accumulated around his Government, he has been consistently clear about what he wants to do. He is refreshingly unpompous and open to argument for a Prime Minister, rounded and grounded, as close to a human being as you are ever likely to find in that office. Yet, where the Tories tried and failed, New Labour itself has succeeded in weaving the impression that the Prime Minister is a fake, a hologram, a confection. There are people who will not be budged from the belief that the name of his fourth child will be selected by a focus group. It is New Labour's perverse achievement to have turned Tony into a Phoney. No wonder he's so perplexed.
