fields.headline: Flying into cyberspace
fields.trailText: Alliances between the world's largest airlines are flourishing in cyberspace.
fields.body:
Alliances between the world's largest airlines are flourishing in cyberspace.

The European airlines' online travel agency, led by BA, Lufthansa, and Air France, will offer a range of published fares for flights to, from and within Europe.

Seven smaller airlines, including British Midland, are also involved, alongside hotel and car rental companies. McKinsey, the management consultancy, will run the project.

The Boston Consulting Group is running a similar project for the big four US airlines, American, Continental, Delta and Northwestern. The site, codename T2, is slated for launch within the next two months.

Airline groups have also collaborated on online 'business-to-business' deals to buy supplies. In an effort to allay fears about a lack of competition, the projects will be run 'at arm's length'.

The European scheme will, say the airlines involved, be an independent online travel agency, with no exchange of marketing information. The site will sell only at published fares, rather than the negotiated and last-minute ones offered by the likes of lastminute.com and ebookers.

Any further cooperation, either in the type of fare or in terms of sharing marketing information, would invite the attention of competition authorities. The American Society of Travel Agents is suing over the US scheme.

The European project, due for launch by the end of the year, does not worry Dinesh Dhamija, head of ebookers.com, Europe's largest online agent. 'We have first-mover advantage, a strong brand and a presence in 11 countries,' he says.

fields.headline: A pleasure cruise from hell
fields.trailText: We are up in Leeds for the twice-yearly Novelty Sleeping Arrangement Olympics at my parents-in-law's house, which involves my wife and me drawing straws to decide which one of us will be kicked in the testicles all night by our three-year-old while the other spends the small hours slithering about on an inflatable vinyl mattress last utilised on It's a Knockout in 1971 to hinder the progress of leisure-industry professionals from Milton Keynes dressed as giant penguins trying to get from A to B carrying buckets of tartare sauce.
fields.body:
We are up in Leeds for the twice-yearly Novelty Sleeping Arrangement Olympics at my parents-in-law's house, which involves my wife and me drawing straws to decide which one of us will be kicked in the testicles all night by our three-year-old while the other spends the small hours slithering about on an inflatable vinyl mattress last utilised on It's a Knockout in 1971 to hinder the progress of leisure-industry professionals from Milton Keynes dressed as giant penguins trying to get from A to B carrying buckets of tartare sauce. Needless to say, the next day we are well fatigued, and it's not even as if we can catch up on our sleep what with the racket of the kids thrilling to the opportunity of going berserk in someone else's house and the steam hissing out of grandpa's ears, not to mention (though I might as well) my wife's mother, who has so entirely run out of walls to be driven up that by teatime she is reduced to tutting into a megaphone fashioned from The Daily Telegraph.

Next morning, we leave the older generation contentedly smoking their heads off in their matching orthopaedic recliners and drive off up the A61 to Knaresborough, which is world-famous for Mother Shipton, an old hag who was born in a cave and was almost burnt at the stake by Cardinal Wolsey for prophesying the dissolution of the monasteries and the Great Plague and for all I know the casual misuse of the apostrophe in pub menu's. Lucky for her, Wolsey was himself less generously endowed in the way of knowing what was going to happen next and indeed had barely had time to buy a packet of firelighters when he was captured by the King's men and charged with treason for making the Inland Revenue unpopular and being so useless at putting a good word in with the Pope for Henry VIII, who merely wanted to marry the new woman in his life before he had quite got round to remembering to kill the old one!

The eldest takes a sudden interest. 'So she's the one married to that doctor who murdered all those women?'

'No, no,' says my wife, 'Ship- ton not Ship- man. He was from Lancashire.'

Knaresborough is a beautiful place, though it does get slightly defiled on a warm day by people like us turning up, clogging the streets and eating all the ice cream and crisps. We park the car and take the bluebell path to the petrifying well, which has a washing line strung across it with hats and gloves and teddy bears that have been magically turned to stone by the running water, which has amazing powers. The children are entranced until the guide starts going into detail about aquifers and the position of calcium carbonate in the league table of interesting minerals. 'It's unique,' he adds, as though creating a lump of rock out of a handbag were some kind of marketable invention. I mean, maybe if they could do it the other way round

Still, very interesting, I'm sure. We go to the cave where Mother Shipton was born in 1488, and the children get to put their hands in the wishing well and give it their best for world peace (or possibly rare Pokémon cards) before being forced to climb the hill to the castle overlooking the craggy gorge and handsome Victorian viaduct and river dotted with people crashing into each other in boats. 'Hey, cool! Dad, can we go out on a boat?'

'Of course we can!' says my wife, who knows full well I would rather have my ears cut off than travel by water in the pursuance of nothing more urgent than amusement.

'What if we fall in?' wails the nine-year-old.

'Yes, what if we fall in?' I repeat. My wife gives me a much-needed poke in the ribs with her captain's telescope and 20 minutes later, we're going round in circles, her rowing, me at the back trying to steer with three children wedged between my legs, the eldest at the front loudly picking holes in my knowledge of left and right. At last, we're zigzagging up the river, and though I do seem to get more than my fair share of earache every time my wife gets her hair snagged in the branches of overhanging trees, or when the little ones suddenly decide to test Archimedes's principle of not leaping to one side of a boat to examine a floating leaf, I have to admit, at no time do we officially sink. Which is odd I don't remember making a wish.

Titanic videos to phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Hooray for Hollywood
fields.standfirst: William Goldman, who wrote the best book about the silver screen, has gone one better with Which Lie Did I Tell?
fields.trailText: William Goldman, who wrote the best book about the silver screen, has gone one better with Which Lie Did I Tell?
fields.body:
Which Lie Did I Tell? More Adventures in the Screen Trade
William Goldman
Bloomsbury £16.99, pp486
Buy it at BOL

Here's the story so far. William Goldman is the author of, for my money, the single best book about Hollywood, Adventures in the Screen Trade. First published here in 1983, it is a book I've given away so often that I am now reduced to a sad, coffee-stained and broken-backed paperback edition bearing the now-forgotten Futura imprint. The volume under review has a helpful subtitle, which tells us that Goldman has written a sequel, a genre that he pungently characterises as the work of 'whores'.

Having unburdened himself of this obiter dicta, I guess Goldman then decided that if it ain't broke, don't fix it, and settled down for a profitable session in American literature's red-light district. Fans of 'Adventures' will be relieved to hear that Which Lie Did I Tell?, the dirty sister, is easily the equal of its more chaste and fairer sibling.

Once again, Goldman takes us backstage at the dream factory and then, like an ancient mariner on Sunset Boulevard, buttonholes the reader with a succession of wicked anecdotes, irreverent asides and behind-the-scenes scuttlebut interspersed with enough nearly actionable gossip to keep a reasonably diligent midtown lawyer in profitable work from Cannes to Christmas. Rather more than 'Adventures' it provides an informal (and, boy, is Goldman informal, or what?) masterclass in screenwriting, with learned references from Chinatown to North by Northwest.

This is hardly surprising. In case you didn't know, and by way of further explanation, Goldman is also the author of Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid , Marathon Man and The Princess Bride, three of the most successful Hollywood films of the past 50 years. So when he's telling you what he knows about movies and storytelling, you are getting it from the front end of the horse. If you want the other stuff, what Goldman calls 'Hollywood horseshit', you have only to read Robert McKee, the author of Story, possibly the silliest and most pretentious book about filmmaking ever published.

Goldman, by contrast, knows the enchanting mystery of 'story' inside out, though he's far too savvy to claim that a successful piece of cinematic storytelling is anything but the happy conjunction of chance, good luck and good instincts. As he writes, in words that should be pinned up in the seminar rooms of creative writing schools around the world: 'I am, alas, a totally instinctive writer, with - please believe this - next to no idea [sic] of what I'm doing.'

It's this refreshing understanding of the supreme difficulty of natural good storytelling that gives his book such assurance and authority. He is also funny and perceptive about 'just how fragile movies are, how even the greatest successes run, at least for a while, neck and neck with failure.'

Goldman is supremely quotable. Famous in the business for the arresting turn of phrase, he's come up with a harvest of new zingers, though not one mot quite so juste as his immortal 'nobody knows anything', a phrase that will probably be chiselled into his gravestone. Goldman is also wise. 'An original screenplay? Nothing to it, really. Just come up with a new and fresh and different story that builds logically to a satisfying and surprising conclusion... Do you know how hard that is?'

And so on and so on. Even if you think fiction is what happens to ball-bearings and that the basic appeal of movies is, as Pauline Kael once said, 'Kiss Kiss Bang Bang', what Goldman has to say is of real consequence. Stripped of the 'Hollywood horseshit' this book simply addresses that profound and age-old question: What do people do round the campfire at night? (Answer: spin yarns).

The other reason why Goldman holds our attention, and it's related to the first, is that having decided to pay a visit to the bordello, he gives the reader a very high class of pillowtalk. If you want to know what the producer yelled at Richard Attenborough during the over-budget shooting of A Bridge Too Far; or what Michael Douglas said to Val Kilmer; or how Billy Crystal inspired that brilliant pay-off line ("I'll have what she's having") to the famous orgasm scene in Nora Ephron's When Harry Met Sally; or the latest on Gwyneth or Cate, then this is a book no movie buff should fail to beg, borrow or steal.

As well as telling us about how his own films got made (excellent chapters on Misery, Maverick and Absolute Power) and about his famous movie-making friends and adversaries, Goldman lets slip quite a bit about himself, and it's all revealing. He is, for example, frank in his admiration of his dead brother Jim, the author of Follies and The Lion in Winter. Jim, apparently, was 'the one who was programmed to succeed'. Compared to his brother, Goldman thought himself, he says, to be 'a fraud'.

He went into film because he felt unworthy to be a novelist. 'In my heart,' he writes sadly, 'I'm a novelist who happens to write screenplays.' Goldman may not be much of a novelist. Who, outside America, has ever heard of, let alone actually read, Your Turn to Curtsey, My Turn to Bow (1958) or No Way to Treat a Lady (1964) or The Color of Light (1984)? What his fiction writing has taught him, however, is that if you get the tone right, almost anything goes. The triumph of Adventures in the Screen Trade and Which Lie Did I Tell? is the triumph of tone.

By creating, on the page, the voice of a seen-it-all, been-there-done-that veteran, a salty but star-struck barfly who's watched the human comedy unfolding on the sound stages of Universal, Warner Bros and MGM, he has created the perfect vehicle for what is, of course, a deep and lifelong love-affair with the city of silver dreams.
fields.bodyText: Which Lie Did I Tell? More Adventures in the Screen Trade William Goldman Bloomsbury £16.99, pp486 Buy it at BOL Here's the story so far. William Goldman is the author of, for my money, the single best book about Hollywood, Adventures in the Screen Trade. First published here in 1983, it is a book I've given away so often that I am now reduced to a sad, coffee-stained and broken-backed paperback edition bearing the now-forgotten Futura imprint. The volume under review has a helpful subtitle, which tells us that Goldman has written a sequel, a genre that he pungently characterises as the work of 'whores'. Having unburdened himself of this obiter dicta, I guess Goldman then decided that if it ain't broke, don't fix it, and settled down for a profitable session in American literature's red-light district. Fans of 'Adventures' will be relieved to hear that Which Lie Did I Tell?, the dirty sister, is easily the equal of its more chaste and fairer sibling. Once again, Goldman takes us backstage at the dream factory and then, like an ancient mariner on Sunset Boulevard, buttonholes the reader with a succession of wicked anecdotes, irreverent asides and behind-the-scenes scuttlebut interspersed with enough nearly actionable gossip to keep a reasonably diligent midtown lawyer in profitable work from Cannes to Christmas. Rather more than 'Adventures' it provides an informal (and, boy, is Goldman informal, or what?) masterclass in screenwriting, with learned references from Chinatown to North by Northwest. This is hardly surprising. In case you didn't know, and by way of further explanation, Goldman is also the author of Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid , Marathon Man and The Princess Bride, three of the most successful Hollywood films of the past 50 years. So when he's telling you what he knows about movies and storytelling, you are getting it from the front end of the horse. If you want the other stuff, what Goldman calls 'Hollywood horseshit', you have only to read Robert McKee, the author of Story, possibly the silliest and most pretentious book about filmmaking ever published. Goldman, by contrast, knows the enchanting mystery of 'story' inside out, though he's far too savvy to claim that a successful piece of cinematic storytelling is anything but the happy conjunction of chance, good luck and good instincts. As he writes, in words that should be pinned up in the seminar rooms of creative writing schools around the world: 'I am, alas, a totally instinctive writer, with - please believe this - next to no idea [sic] of what I'm doing.' It's this refreshing understanding of the supreme difficulty of natural good storytelling that gives his book such assurance and authority. He is also funny and perceptive about 'just how fragile movies are, how even the greatest successes run, at least for a while, neck and neck with failure.' Goldman is supremely quotable. Famous in the business for the arresting turn of phrase, he's come up with a harvest of new zingers, though not one mot quite so juste as his immortal 'nobody knows anything', a phrase that will probably be chiselled into his gravestone. Goldman is also wise. 'An original screenplay? Nothing to it, really. Just come up with a new and fresh and different story that builds logically to a satisfying and surprising conclusion... Do you know how hard that is?' And so on and so on. Even if you think fiction is what happens to ball-bearings and that the basic appeal of movies is, as Pauline Kael once said, 'Kiss Kiss Bang Bang', what Goldman has to say is of real consequence. Stripped of the 'Hollywood horseshit' this book simply addresses that profound and age-old question: What do people do round the campfire at night? (Answer: spin yarns). The other reason why Goldman holds our attention, and it's related to the first, is that having decided to pay a visit to the bordello, he gives the reader a very high class of pillowtalk. If you want to know what the producer yelled at Richard Attenborough during the over-budget shooting of A Bridge Too Far; or what Michael Douglas said to Val Kilmer; or how Billy Crystal inspired that brilliant pay-off line ("I'll have what she's having") to the famous orgasm scene in Nora Ephron's When Harry Met Sally; or the latest on Gwyneth or Cate, then this is a book no movie buff should fail to beg, borrow or steal. As well as telling us about how his own films got made (excellent chapters on Misery, Maverick and Absolute Power) and about his famous movie-making friends and adversaries, Goldman lets slip quite a bit about himself, and it's all revealing. He is, for example, frank in his admiration of his dead brother Jim, the author of Follies and The Lion in Winter. Jim, apparently, was 'the one who was programmed to succeed'. Compared to his brother, Goldman thought himself, he says, to be 'a fraud'. He went into film because he felt unworthy to be a novelist. 'In my heart,' he writes sadly, 'I'm a novelist who happens to write screenplays.' Goldman may not be much of a novelist. Who, outside America, has ever heard of, let alone actually read, Your Turn to Curtsey, My Turn to Bow (1958) or No Way to Treat a Lady (1964) or The Color of Light (1984)? What his fiction writing has taught him, however, is that if you get the tone right, almost anything goes. The triumph of Adventures in the Screen Trade and Which Lie Did I Tell? is the triumph of tone. By creating, on the page, the voice of a seen-it-all, been-there-done-that veteran, a salty but star-struck barfly who's watched the human comedy unfolding on the sound stages of Universal, Warner Bros and MGM, he has created the perfect vehicle for what is, of course, a deep and lifelong love-affair with the city of silver dreams.

fields.headline: Mrs Blair's Diary
fields.standfirst: Small, pink, wrinkly ... must stop thinking of Hague
fields.trailText: Small, pink, wrinkly ... must stop thinking of Hague
fields.body:
Monday: Not sure how well these Indian neck-massages are working. The idea, as all the papers have been busy pointing out, in pieces generally headlined 'Share the wonder of this gentle Indian magic' and sandwiched between two pages headlined 'Hague strikes right note with Send Back Dirty Wogs call' - anyway, the idea is that you end up for a while in a land of comfy woozy stupor, robbed of the need for cogent thought processes, rather like reading Anthony Giddens, or waking up to find you are Brian Souter. But it doesn't seem to be working on Tony, no matter how hard I knead. As soon as I've got one knot soothed, another pops ... boing ... as he remembers something else horrible. That crawling phone call to Ken. Ping . Hague preening at having proved that the average bigoted English voter is even stupider than the average bigoted Scottish multi-millionaire (if a little less likely, facially, to curdle sunlight) ... thwang , pop . Never mind: in a week or so he'll be able to take a little time off himself, and leave all the cares and worries to Gordon and John.

Spreeng , twacka , crick , shnap .

Tuesday: At least we're keeping our promises, proceeding with our far-sighted plan to turn over air traffic control from quiet people called things like Bill and Pete who want to, basically, keep people alive in the air, to people called things like Horace and Jasper Greed, who want to, um, make obscene amounts of money. Marvellous. I wonder if we could at least insist on something like the Chinese did over Y2K: the people who buy the ATC have to run it from 32,000 feet, flying 24 hours a day. I think we might see some promises being kept ...

Wednesday: Mollified a little, I must say, by the performances of Charles Kennedy. Why haven't we heard more of him? A good and principled man, everything fine I remember about this party; we should use him more.

Oops. Just checked with Tony. How was I to know? When did you last time read anything about the Lib Dems?

Thursday: Being the size of an elephant, I find myself reluctantly missing the party of the year. But I'm sure Paxo will have another birthday ...

Friday: Just 12 days to go till little Zachariah bursts forth. Longing for it ... but it seems so long since I've been exposed to it all: the shocking baldness, the whining, the little wrinkled face, the preening self-obsession ... but what a relief, a contrast, to current public life. Papers full of pictures of Hague, Livingstone, Souter, Bragg. Be so lovely to get away from all that for a while.

fields.headline: Adams 'assassin' targeted by UDA
fields.trailText: The loyalist who shot Gerry Adams lives in fear of being murdered by former paramilitary comrades.
fields.body:
The loyalist who shot Gerry Adams lives in fear of being murdered by former paramilitary comrades.

An Ulster Defence Association member, John 'Grug' Gregg became a loyalist hero in 1984 for attempting to murder the Sinn Fein president. But now he faces the prospect of being shot by UDA colleagues from west Belfast.

According to loyalist and security sources, Gregg has provoked anger in 'B' company of the UDA's west Belfast brigade over the shooting of three loyalists from the Woodvale area. Gregg's east Antrim UDA brigade shot all three men in two separate attacks in Belfast last weekend. But the trio, who included released UDA prisoner Geordie King, are popular inside the organisation and friends have vowed revenge.

The row between Gregg's UDA brigade and the Woodvale section centres on a dispute over proceeds from a drinking club the group controls in west Belfast.

The row highlights the disparate, federal nature of the UDA, where rival brigades vie for supremacy and argue over territory and finance.

The three Woodvale men were shot after two visited Gregg's home several weeks ago, complaining about a UDA 'punishment' shooting in the Rathcoole area of the city. Gregg objected to the Woodvale men's presence at his home and later complained to the UDA's west Belfast brigadier. He claimed their visit broke the standing orders of the UDA's supreme body, the Inner Council, that no individual member should threaten any of the organisation's brigadiers. While Gregg is still held in high esteem in certain UDA areas for trying to kill Adams, the UDA in Woodvale wants revenge. One of the victims is a brother of a senior UDA figure in west Belfast who has been in jail for terrorist offences.

Gregg came close to killing Adams on 14 April 1984, when his UDA unit drew up alongside a car Adams was in. The loyalists fired up to 20 shots at Adams, hitting him four times. The West Belfast MP would have died if he had not been treated at the nearby Royal Victoria Hospital.

webTitle: Orangemen failed to expel sex offender

fields.headline: Orangemen failed to expel sex offender
fields.trailText: The Orange Order failed to expel a convicted sex offender who became the first person in Northern Ireland banned from loitering near schools.
fields.body:
The Orange Order failed to expel a convicted sex offender who became the first person in Northern Ireland banned from loitering near schools.

James McGivern, 57, of Lime Grove in Lurgan, appeared in court last Monday where he was ordered to avoid schools, parks, playgrounds and teenage discos after complaints from parents in the Craigavon area.

McGivern, who has two convictions for sex offences in the early Nineties, belongs to an Orange Lodge in Portadown and is a member of Ian Paisley's Free Presbyterian church there. He belongs to Orange lodge LOL 352 - the Derrykeevin Temperance Lodge - whose members are teetotal on religious grounds.

According to the Orange Order rulebook a member can be expelled if found guilty of 'conduct unbecoming of an Orangeman'. Despite convictions dating back a decade, McGivern remained a member of LOL 352, attending protests at Drumcree.

RUC officers convinced the court to ban McGivern from schools, parks, playgrounds and other places where children played. He can be arrested if seen near such places. The court agreed that McGivern was 'posing a renewed threat to the community'. This was the first time the police were granted powers under the 1997 Sex Offenders Order to restrict movements of a convicted sex offender in Northern Ireland.

The order was imposed for five years after parents of a nine-year-old girl alleged McGivern approached her as she left school in Lurgan.

webTitle: Mandelson in move to quell flags dispute

fields.headline: Mandelson in move to quell flags dispute
fields.trailText: In a clear concession to David Trimble, the British Government moved yesterday to prevent Sinn Fein Ministers in a new power-sharing Executive banning Union flags from public buildings.
fields.body:
In a clear concession to David Trimble, the British Government moved yesterday to prevent Sinn Fein Ministers in a new power-sharing Executive banning Union flags from public buildings.

Legislation will be introduced next week in Parliament enabling Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, to overrule any Minister in the Belfast administration who tried to stop the flag flying above government offices.

While Mandelson's move partially calms unionist fears, it is unlikely that Trimble will wrest any major concessions over the Patten report on the RUC's future. The Ulster Unionist leader wants the RUC's name incorporated in the force's new title - the Police Service of Northern Ireland - but the Irish government, the SDLP and Sinn Fein have successfully fought off attempts to water down the Patten report.

Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams has warned that any tampering with the Patten report could undermine last weekend's IRA initiative.

Trimble is seeking changes in the Patten report before Saturday's crucial meeting of the Ulster Unionist Council at which 860 delegates will vote to accept the IRA's offer of arms being put beyond use and the independent verification of their weapons dumps.

An Ulster Unionist spokesman said the legislation on flags was 'better than nothing' but held dangers.

One of the aspects of the 72 days of power-sharing which angered unionists the most was the decision by Sinn Fein Education Minister Martin McGuinness and Health Minister Bairbre de Brun to order the Union flag removed from their ministerial buildings.

'It's fair to say that the Union flag would be safe under Mandelson whom we trust, but what if Mo Mowlam had still been in place? Could we have trusted her to take our side if Sinn Fein Ministers wanted to tear down the flag over Stormont buildings? It will depend in the end on the personality in the post of Secretary of State,' the UUP spokesman said.

A spokesman for the Northern Ireland Office said the new powers to intervene in the flags dispute were a 'last resort'. He said: 'We would prefer if the parties at the Assembly sorted these issues out for themselves. But at the end of the day if they cannot do so, then we have reserve powers to intervene.'

The NIO spokesman stressed that Mandelson stood by his statement to the House of Commons in January when he pledged that the Patten report would be implemented in full.

Unionists opposed to the Good Friday Agreement are predicting that Trimble will win the vote next Saturday and that a new Executive will be formed by 22 May.

webTitle: Women aim to overturn rule by gun

fields.headline: Women aim to overturn rule by gun
fields.standfirst: Washington march will put more pressure on Bush as debate rages over the tide of firearms violence
fields.trailText: Daisy Bartisson will be there today, amid the 'Million Mom March' on the Mall in Washington, to protest her rage and comfortless sorrow against America's violent world of guns.
fields.body:
Daisy Bartisson will be there today, amid the 'Million Mom March' on the Mall in Washington, to protest her rage and comfortless sorrow against America's violent world of guns.

She had just fixed the pram straps around her three-year-old son Everton when her life was suddenly condemned to what she now calls 'sadness for me always'. The pram was parked outside a cheque-cashing and money-transfer corner store on the poor outskirts of Chester, Pennsylvania, and Bartisson had turned away for a moment to pick up her shopping when the shooting ripped through the hot afternoon air on 23 May last year.

The firing came from the doorway of the cheque-cashing store. Seven shots, Bartisson says, though the police say four. They were one too many. The one that ricocheted off a wall hit Everton in the side and punctured his lung. The little boy died after five days in intensive care. Another bullet scratched Bartisson's thigh; 'if only it had gone right through me instead of through my baby,' she says. A man called Byfield - a 'crackhead', she says - was convicted and is serving 18 years for second-degree murder.

'I will be going to Washington with my church, the First Ebenezer Baptist Church of Chester' Bartisson said on Friday. 'We are 15 of us going in a bus and I am not the only momma in my exact same situation who is going from this congregation.' A neighbour, Wilma Seddon, lost her nine-year-old daughter in a shootout at a filling station in Philadelphia 13 years ago.

Also at the march will be Mindy Finkelstein, a counsellor at a Jewish children's day camp in Los Angeles, who was playing with the children at the moment when a neo-Nazi with the Aryan Nations party strolled in and sprayed the place with bullets. Mindy was hit twice in the leg; another woman and three children were also hurt.

Colleen Smith from Houston will also be there. Colleen's daughter Brandy, 18, was walking with two friends near a shopping mall last May when a man demanded her car keys. When he pulled a gun, they ran; a shot rang out and hit Brandy in the head.

The demonstrators at the 'Million Mom March' in Washington DC will make a new kind of history; the rally will be a Peace March for the year 2000; peace on every street of every town in America. In addition to the gathering on the Mall, there will be simultaneous rallies in more than 60 other US cities.

The march will be hard for even the mighty National Rifle Association to counter, while 80 Americans - including a dozen children - continue to die from gunshots every day. 'The Vietnam War,' says Wendi Kaplan, Virginia co-ordinator for the march, 'ended when a Mom said we're not going to send our sons any more. I think we are at that point.'

Impatience with gun violence in America is distinctly female - 72 per cent of women want stricter control over guns as compared to only 22 per cent of men. Women have been to the fore of every campaign, spurred by such shoot ings as Columbine School and Granada Hills. Not that the march is a spontaneous outburst. Behind it is a slick media campaign that deploys the latest techniques.

The march takes place on America's Mother's Day, but the timing is far more highly charged than that. It comes at a critical moment in the country's gun crisis. Guns have become the sharpest area of debate between the two candidates in the coming presidential election, Al Gore and George W. Bush.

Bush has always been a good friend to the gun lobby; but even his campaign has balked at a claim by the NRA's vice-president, Kayne Robinson, that Bush would offer it a presidency 'where we work out of their office'.

Today's march has specific aims which will become straight challenges to Bush: it demands that any US government requires all handgun owners to be licensed and requires safety locks on all handguns and 'cooling-off' periods and background checks on any person who buys a gun 'intended only for killing or injuring humans', i.e. not a sporting gun.

The issue of safety locks lay at the core of a recent duel over guns, which only emboldened the gun industry. Faced with the prospect of massive lawsuits, British-owned Smith & Wesson broke ranks with its colleagues and agreed with the administration to unilaterally enforced controls.

The NRA and US-based firms such as Glock elected first to continue defying the states and local authorities, and then to suspend negotiations and bank on a Bush presidency. The gun lobby believes Bush will implement nationwide what he has done in Texas: backing laws that protect gunmakers from writs by local authorities. Gore has said he will remove any such restraints on the towns, cities and states.

Meanwhile, Governor Bush, to whom the women's vote is pivotal and whose election message is primarily directed at women, was left scrambling to distance himself from his friends in the NRA, saying that 'I will make the decisions'.

The other tidal wave atop which today's protest will soar is the increasingly tragic aftermath of the Columbine school massacre last spring. Last weekend a second child survivor of the massacre committed suicide: Greg Barnes, who had watched his basketball coach bleed to death on the classroom floor, hanged himself in the family garage.

He had become a star athlete, and had recently given an interview to Sports Illustrated magazine, saying that he had been in the 'midst of mayhem' during the massacre, in which Dylan Klebold and Eric Harris killed 13 of their classmates.

Last weekend a second child survivor of the massacre committed suicide: Greg Barnes, who had watched his basketball coach bleed to death on the classroom floor, hanged himself in the family garage. He had become a star athlete, and had recently given an interview to Sports Illustrated magazine, saying that he had been in the 'midst of mayhem' during the massacre, in which Dylan Klebold and Eric Harris killed 13 of their classmates.

fields.headline: French 'traitor' in Net fightback
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: A senior French army officer arrested and accused of passing top-secret documents to the Serbs with details of Nato's planned air strikes in Kosovo has turned to the Internet to clear his name.
fields.body:
A senior French army officer arrested and accused of passing top-secret documents to the Serbs with details of Nato's planned air strikes in Kosovo has turned to the Internet to clear his name.

Major Pierre-Henri Bunel, who retired early from military service last year after several months in jail, insists he did not betray France, Nato or his comrades, and says he was the victim of sordid manipulation. He also provides what appears to be documentary evidence that the Bosnian Muslim government of Alija Izetbegovic was harbouring Iranian terrorists well after the date agreed in the Dayton accords for the withdrawal of foreign troops from former Yugoslavia.

'I passed documents on to get certain key messages across,' he writes on http: //site.voila.fr/pierre_bunel. 'They were that France would take part in the conflict [in Kosovo], that the five principal Nato countries had agreed to strike Yugoslavia, and that if Milosevic did not withdraw his troops the carnage would be terrible.'

Bunel, a distinguished intelligence officer who had been awarded the Légion d'honneur, was attached to France's Nato delegation in Brussels in mid-1996. He served as head of personal staff to the delegation's senior military adviser, General Pierre Wiroth, and had access to much classified Nato information.

When he was arrested in October 1998, it was alleged that in four meetings between July and October of that year he gave substantial quantities of sensitive information, including operational orders, flight plans and target lists, to a colonel in Serbian army intelligence, Jovan Milanovic.

'I admit passing on information classified "secret" to a Serb agent,' Bunel says on his site. 'But this was confidential information, not top secret: top secret in Nato is classified "Cosmic". I never passed on flight plans or operational orders.' He acted because 'it is nonsensical to undertake a military action if it does not correspond to a political solution'.

On another website, http://site.voila.fr/rensops he publishes photographs of what he says was a UN-sponsored mission in February 1996 to arrest Iranian terrorists still operating illegally on ex-Yugoslav territory in support of Izetbegovic.

webTitle: How Dyke won a political coup

fields.headline: How Dyke won a political coup
fields.standfirst: Kamal Ahmed  on why the BBC changed its front man for Westminster coverage
fields.trailText: Driving from central London to the jumble of buildings that make up the headquarters of the BBC in White City, you might be forgiven for missing a smart hotel nestling in the tree-lined streets of Holland Park. It's called the Halcyon and its not overly catchy slogan is, 'Peaceful, private, elegant'.
fields.body:
Driving from central London to the jumble of buildings that make up the headquarters of the BBC in White City, you might be forgiven for missing a smart hotel nestling in the tree-lined streets of Holland Park. It's called the Halcyon and its not overly catchy slogan is, 'Peaceful, private, elegant'.

Private is the operative word for the legions of television executives who tramp through its doors every lunchtime to discuss the latest plots and manoeuvres, coups d'état and wicked wheezes that are the lifeblood of Britain's media scene.

Last month any casual observer would have been intrigued by a breakfast party that arrived for a very private discussion. On one side of the table were two of the most powerful men in the BBC - Greg Dyke, the director-general, and Tony Hall, head of news and current affairs.

On the other was Andrew Marr, former editor of the Independent , author, broadcaster, columnist for this newspaper and one of the country's foremost liberal-left voices. Over the toast and marmalade the three got down to business. Hall and Dyke wanted to talk to Marr about one of the most powerful jobs in political journalism, and therefore one of the most influential jobs in politics. The BBC wanted Marr to be its political editor.

Marr already knew what was afoot. He had been approached about it by Mark Damazar, the BBC's head of political programming. Marr had mulled it over - the long hours, the days away from his wife and young children, the harsh spotlight he will work in - and decided to accept.

'It's not the kind of job you get offered twice,' he told friends.

Dyke and Hall were delighted, but knew there would be trouble ahead. They would have to ease out Robin Oakley, former political editor of the Times, who took over as political editor at the BBC in 1992. Oakley is well known as a Conservative sympathiser, Marr is a friend to many in the New Labour project. The Tories, surely, would cry foul and add the Marr appointment to their long litany of complaints about 'BBC bias'.

Oakley, who had wanted to see out the next general election and then retire gracefully, was called to a meeting last week and told by Damazar that the plans were changing. Marr had to be appointed now, or the BBC risked losing him to a new e-commerce venture.Oakley, who is 59, decided to allow the corporation to buy him out. It was agreed that his employers would not say that Oakley had been sacked, but that his 'retirement had been brought forward'.

On the question of Marr's New Labour credentials, Dyke has told colleagues that he cannot be expected to make staffing decisions on the basis of what the response of political parties might be. Hall and Damazar have said Marr is one of the most thoughtful and provocative political journalists in Britain, and the only person they wanted for the job. Marr's intellect will enable him to be equally robust with both the Tories and Labour.

That is the line, but the BBC knows that Marr could offer the Tories another stick with which to beat the corporation. Political rows always make the BBC nervous. It is now fighting a rearguard action over a decision not to give live coverage to a pageant to mark the Queen Mother's 100th birthday in July.

William Hague used the row to attack the BBC again. 'It would be a great shame if the British people were denied the opportunity to watch live on television all the official events marking her 100th birthday,' he said.

The Tory leader was also making the wider political point that the Conservatives think the BBC is biased against them. The appointment of Marr, despite the fact that Amanda Platell, head of Tory media relations, considers him a friend and was managing editor at the Independent when Marr was there, will not ease their concerns.

'The party will kick up about this,' said a senior Conservative source.

'You would have to be blind and deaf to not believe, if you are a Conservative, that we do not get a fair crack of the whip. Many are sick of New Labour's media friends being brought in to the BBC by the back door.' The Conservatives will be watching Marr 'very carefully', the source said.

Marr has given powerful assurances about his impartiality. 'The BBC has a duty which I totally understand,' he said. He pointed out that John Cole, Oakley's predecessor, was a well-known Labour supporter and that neither Cole nor Oakley had been criticised for their allegiances.

The issue of the BBC's independence is a fraught one. When Dyke, himself a Labour supporter, was appointed last year, Hague said it revealed Labour's influence over the BBC.

Three weeks ago battle was again rejoined when Michael Ancram, the Conservative Party chairman, attacked the corporation for failing to invite a Tory to appear on an edition of Question Time , the first time in the programme's 21-year history.

Ancram said the bias 'appears to have got worse over the last few months. I will be writing in the strongest terms to Mr Dyke asking him to explain why this appears to have got worse in terms of tone and content since he took over.'

Dyke agreed that Question Time had been a mistake and apologised.It was his second apology this year. The first was in response to a Conservative complaint about an episode of the Archers in which leading characters praised a speech by Tony Blair about farming.

A few days after the Question Time row, it was revealed that Panorama was investigating links between the far Right and the Conservative Party, a subject which was also being looked into by Labour.

Tory sources saw another BBC 'stitch-up', fuelled by Labour's agenda.

Add to this the move of Lance Price, the former BBC political man, to Downing Street's press department last year, and constant accusations of pro-European BBC bias, and the Tories feel they have a good case.

But, the BBC points out that it also has a raft of complaint letters from Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's spokesman, and the Labour Party itself.

Campbell and party general secretary Margaret McDonagh were incensed by a series of Panorama programmes earlier this year on Labour's spin machine and the gerrymandering that led to Frank Dobson's selection as the official Labour candidate to be Mayor of London.

Protests flow regularly into the BBC from the Left.

'For every claim that we are biased against the Tories comes a claim that we are biased against Labour,' said a BBC executive. 'We must be doing something right.'

webTitle: Britain's only mission is to protect imperilled humanity

fields.headline: Britain's only mission is to protect imperilled humanity
fields.standfirst: Richard Dowden on Britain's 'pretence of closeness' with its former colony
fields.trailText: They seem a long way from home, those British soldiers digging fox holes in the red gravel earth on the road to Freetown. But look at the names of the places they are defending: Aberdeen is their base, they are deployed at Hastings and Waterloo. They are defending Regent Road, the Prince of Wales School, St George's Cathedral and Victoria Park.
fields.body:
They seem a long way from home, those British soldiers digging fox holes in the red gravel earth on the road to Freetown. But look at the names of the places they are defending: Aberdeen is their base, they are deployed at Hastings and Waterloo. They are defending Regent Road, the Prince of Wales School, St George's Cathedral and Victoria Park.

Is this some bad TV sci-fi in which a suburb of Bournemouth has floated away and attached itself to Africa and Britain has to defend? Freetown sometimes feels like that. It was Britain's biggest naval base in the South Atlantic for centuries, the headquarters of the anti-slavery patrol. It was last used as a fuelling depot in the Falklands war. The ties with Britain are long and deep, felt strongly by Sierra Leoneans. That, however, is not why British troops are there.

Are they there to keep Africa at bay? Freetown's hinterland was always a worry. In the late 19th century the British authorities proposed building a rampart across the peninsula to keep out malaria. And there was always a threat of a native uprising. Up country were the Leopard Men, secret societies that indulged in murder and cannibalism. The British civilising mission never quite suppressed them. But no, this is not some imperial replay.

Are the troops there to protect some vital British interest? The once-rich diamond areas are now commercially ruined by freelance diggers. We no longer need the naval base. Sadly, Sierra Leoneans have nothing to induce Britain to send troops there except their imperilled humanity.

Sierra Leone became independent 40 years ago, so Britain should have no direct responsibility. There should have been a normal robust relationship between equals. Britain's only responsibility, as the Western country with the strongest diplomatic links, should have been to keep Sierra Leone connected to the rest of the world. Instead, imperial guilt and bad aid created a dysfunctional relationship, like that between an absent-minded parent and a delinquent child.

There was a pretence of closeness. Money was sent, but no one cared how it was spent. Britain fitfully helped prop up corrupt governments and nearly sent troops five years ago. Its fitful attention was typified by the Sandline affair. When the government was overthrown in 1997, Sandline, a British security company, tried to provide weapons to help restore the exiled government. But it fell foul of a badly drafted United Nations arms embargo on Sierra Leone intended only to apply to the rebel junta. While Sierra Leoneans were going through their armageddon, the British Government was worrying about which bureaucratic papers had been seen by which diplomats.

Now Britain finds itself with the only effective troops to defend the elected government and the people of Freetown from one of the nastiest movements to emerge from Africa in recent years. Perhaps we will look back in 20 years at this footage of British troops digging into African soil and smile ruefully - the world's last attempt to save Africa from itself. There will be a moving memorial to the men of the 1st Battalion, The Parachute Regiment, who died defending a piece of worthless soil one called Sierra Leone, a Rorke's Drift 100 years on that failed. Then we will be watching horrific scenes of fighting and starvation amid the smashed ruins of Johannesburg and Lagos and Nairobi.

Maybe. Recent interventions in Somalia, Rwanda and Angola have failed. Talk of an African economic revival a few years ago was wrong. Thabo Mbeki's African Renaissance? A good idea, but death looks more likely than birth at the moment. This week an American-led UN mission failed to secure peace between Ethiopia and Eritrea; in Congo, Rwanda and Uganda, old allies have started a new war; while Zimbabwe seems headed for self-destruction. It is not hard to conclude that Africa is going to hell and then walk away.

Yet we can't. Freetown is as much part of the world as Bournemouth. If Britain left Sierra Leone now and the people of Freetown were butchered the UN might as well close down and the world accept that it is two, not one. The line is drawn on that red gravel road from Aberdeen. That is why the paratroopers are there. Other countries should be sending their troops to join them.

 Richard Dowden is Africa Correspondent of the Economist.

webTitle: Rebel chief planned British diamond scam

fields.headline: Rebel chief planned British diamond scam
fields.trailText: Foday Sankoh, the brutal rebel leader in Sierra Leone, was planning to tempt at least two London-based diamond companies to play key roles in his vast illegal gem-dealing network, documents released by the west African state's government have revealed.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal,  Freetown,  and Jason Burke
fields.body:
Foday Sankoh, the brutal rebel leader in Sierra Leone, was planning to tempt at least two London-based diamond companies to play key roles in his vast illegal gem-dealing network, documents released by the west African state's government have revealed.

The documents, seized from Sankoh's ransacked home in the capital, Freetown, have prompted an official investigation, Sierra Leone's Justice Minister and Attorney General, Solomon Berewa, said at a press conference yesterday.

Berewa also accused the rebel, who fled from Freetown on Monday after guards at his house killed 19 unarmed demonstrators during an anti-rebel protest, of plotting to stage a coup this week. Sankoh is now being hunted by the British-led combined force of United Nations and Sierra Leonean troops who are preparing to take the war into the rebel Revolutionary United Front heartland.

Under last year's peace agreement, Sankoh was appointed chairman of the National Resources Commission, a post which gave him direct influence over Sierra Leone's lucrative diamond trade but did not confer the right to award mining concessions. However, Sankoh abused the position to set up his own diamond deals, including illegal mining and smuggling of gems.

The government claims Sankoh exchanged letters with two London-based British companies which they named as Rocstone International in Mayfair and a firm run by a dealer called I.S.I. Weinberger in Hatton Garden. Berewa said they included an invitation to both companies to visit Sierra Leone 'to finalise details' of an unstated agreement.

One of the letters to Weinberger, dated 12 April 2000, then invited the company to pay an amount of $5,000 (£3,270) 'to cover consultancy before your arrival'.

There is nothing in the letters to suggest that the British dealers knew Sankoh was attempting to lure them into what, according to the Sierra Leone government, was an illegal activity. There is no evidence of any wrong-doing.

Unlike Angolan diamonds those from Sierra Leone are not covered by any sanctions. The Observer was unable last night to contact Weinberger or the directors of Rocstone. Both, however, are listed at Companies House.

Sankoh kept a record of the rebels' illegal diamond digging in several exercise books, each marked 'RUF Mining Unit'. Just one of the books, covering a single mine from August to January, lists the recovery of 2,134 'pieces of diamond' with a total of 347 carats.

A letter written in September to Sankoh by his deputy and chief rival, Sam Bockerie, mentions selling diamonds to buy weapons.

'There is no doubt that diamonds were fuelling this war,' said Berewa. 'He was obsessed with money. He was obsessed with power and because of that he was prepared to do anything and everything.'

webTitle: Prince's pet village gets seal of approval

fields.headline: Prince's pet village gets seal of approval
fields.trailText: Prince Charles's much criticised village development of Poundbury in Dorset will receive a surprising boost tomorrow when a Government report holds it up as a shining example of the 'anti-Brookside' style of architecture it wants to encourage.
fields.body:
Prince Charles's much criticised village development of Poundbury in Dorset will receive a surprising boost tomorrow when a Government report holds it up as a shining example of the 'anti-Brookside' style of architecture it wants to encourage.

The report by officials at the Department of the Environment, Transport and Regions will say the village on the outskirts of Dorchester gives people a real sense of community.

'I've seen the past and it works,' said Francis Golding, an architectural consultant and one of the authors of the report. 'OK, so it's retro but it is a development that has been given real attention.'

Poundbury has been at the centre of a bitter debate about how to build new housing since it was launched on a sceptical public in the mid-Nineties.

The prince, who has put his name to the development of new homes and an enterprise centre, said he wanted to see a departure from the 'terrible' architecture of most modern housing and that Poundbury would be in sharp contrast to the Sixties idea of stuffing people in tower blocks.

The development has split the architectural community. Many described it as a pastiche of a non-existent 'village past' and pointed out that it was built on a greenfield site rather than on a site of urban decay, which environmentalists say is better use of scarce land resources.

Although the first residents who moved in were optimistic that they could create a new community, the development was attacked last year for having no shops, post office, village hall, pub or church.

The council estate which sits behind Poundbury is fenced off, creating, critics say, an 'us and them' environment, and the five-storey retirement home in the centre of the village has been attacked for dominating the skyline for miles around.

The report, which will be launched by Environment Minister Nick Raynsford, will say that although Poundbury has its drawbacks it is a development where thought has been given to how the buildings work together and what people who live there think.

Other developments which will be praised include the Glasgow development at Glasgow Green, the Caspar buildings in Birmingham, the Piggeries in Frome, Somerset, and the Seven Dials development in London's Covent Garden.

'We want to get away from the "cul-de-sac" culture where new developments are built around roads that don't go anywhere,' Golding said, citing myriad examples of executive housing estates that use architecture styles now dismissed as 'Tudorbethan', an ugly mixture of faux Tudor and Elizabethan styles which look the same whether they are built on the outskirts of Edinburgh or Brighton.

'Builders say that these are the type of houses that people want, but I have seen little evidence of that,' said Ian Ritchie, an architect and member of the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment, which is backing the report.

Maxwell Hutchinson, an architect and former president of the Royal Institute of Architecture, said he was surprised by the conservatism implied by the report's backing of Poundbury. 'There has been a growing consensus that new building should be on brownfield sites like Greenwich and not on greenfield sites like Poundbury,' he said.

He said that support for the prince's pet project flies in the face of recent developments which had revealed 'a renaissance in the British attitude to architecture. The reaction to the new Tate Modern shows that.'

Peter Bryant, a former civil servant and president of the Poundbury Residents Association, said he was delighted at the news. 'This is a vindication of everything that we have said in defence of Poundbury over the past few years. We have had so much adverse criticism in the past, but people like living here because of the pleasant housing.

'There is no question of sameness at all. Anyone who comes here can see that. We have a mixed population and quality housing which is all individual. That is the whole ethos of the place.

'People like living here and it will improve still further when the shops being built become operational and the pub and the Market Hall are finished.'

fields.headline: Mugabe to seize whites' passports
fields.trailText: White farmers in Zimbabwe who have not formally given up being British will be stripped of their Zimbabwean citizenship and must surrender their passports, President Robert Mugabe ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
White farmers in Zimbabwe who have not formally given up being British will be stripped of their Zimbabwean citizenship and must surrender their passports, President Robert Mugabe ruled yesterday.

Mugabe will force the tens of thousands of people involved to obey the letter of his country's law, which makes dual nationality illegal, said the state-owned Herald newspaper.

Instead of having the rights of full citizens, those stripped of their Zimbabwean citizenship will be merely resident British nationals.

The move - which some observers interpreted as a possible precursor to mass expulsions of the farmers - appeared to catch the British Government off guard.

The ruling was widely viewed as a manoeuvre to prevent thousands of whites from voting in a general election due by August.

In London one Foreign Office source said: 'We have insisted that Mr Mugabe should stay within the rule of law. This is a difficult issue because it clearly is the law in Zimbabwe, and we are cautious about walking into a trap.'

The decision puts further pressure on the besieged farming community, despite apparently conciliatory talks they held with Mugabe last Friday. The new regulation removing the rights of citizenship could also be a first step towards expulsion of the British minority, estimated at about 20,000 to 30,000. It also would intimidate the entire white minority, estimated to be about 70,000.

Human rights lawyer David Coltart said the new move was designed to 'disenfranchise white voters and to make some people ineligible to stand in the election'.

Coltart, who is tipped to win a seat as a candidate for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, added: 'I have renounced my British citizenship under British law, and therefore they cannot take my Zimbabwean citizenship away from me.'

webTitle: US planned one big nuclear blast for mankind

fields.headline: US planned one big nuclear blast for mankind
fields.trailText: The US Air Force developed a top-secret plan to detonate a nuclear bomb on the moon as a display of military might at the height of the Cold War.
fields.body:
The US Air Force developed a top-secret plan to detonate a nuclear bomb on the moon as a display of military might at the height of the Cold War.

In an exclusive interview with The Observer, Dr Leonard Reiffel, 73, the physicist who fronted the project in the late Fifties at the US military-backed Armour Research Foundation, revealed America's extraordinary lunar plan.

'It was clear the main aim of the proposed detonation was a PR exercise and a show of one-upmanship. The Air Force wanted a mushroom cloud so large it would be visible on earth,' he said yesterday. 'The US was lagging behind in the space race.'

'The explosion would obviously be best on the dark side of the moon and the theory was that if the bomb exploded on the edge of the moon, the mushroom cloud would be illuminated by the sun.' The bomb would have been at least as large as the one used on Hiroshima at the end of World War II.

'I made it clear at the time there would be a huge cost to science of destroying a pristine lunar environment, but the US Air Force were mainly concerned about how the nuclear explosion would play on earth,' said Reiffel.

Although he believes the blast would have had little environmental impact on Earth, its crater may have ruined the face of the 'man in the moon'.

Reiffel would not reveal how the explosion would have taken place. But he confirmed it was 'certainly technically feasible' and that at the time an intercontinental ballistic nuclear missile would have been capable of hitting a target on the moon with an accuracy of within two miles.

Reiffel was approached by senior US Air Force officers in 1958, who asked him to 'fast-track' a project to investigate the visibility and effects of a nuclear explosion on the moon. The top-secret Project A119, was entitled 'A Study of Lunar Research Flights'.

'Had the project been made public there would have been an outcry,' said Reiffel.

Many Cold War documents are still classified in the US, but details of Project A119 emerged after a biography of celebrated US scientist and astronomer Carl Sagan was published there last year.

Sagan, who died in 1996, was famous for popularising science in the US and pioneering the study of potential life on other planets. At the Armour Foundation in Chicago - now called the Illinois Institute of Technology Research - he was hired by Reiffel to undertake mathematical modelling on the expansion of an exploding dust cloud in the space around the moon. This was key to calculating the visibility of such a cloud from the Earth.

At the time scientists still believed there might be microbial life on the moon and Sagan had suggested a nuclear explosion might be used to detect organisms.

Despite the highly classified nature of the work, Sagan's biographer, Keay Davidson, discovered that he had disclosed details of it when he applied for the prestigious Miller Institute graduate fellowship to Berkeley.

Yet, until today, the full nature of Project A119 has never been revealed. Friends of Sagan believe he never would have wilfully revealed classified information, but Reiffel has come forward to put the 'historical record straight'.

Reiffel continued: 'It was well known that the existence of this project was top secret. Had Sagan wanted to make any disclosures to any party, as his boss at the time, I would have had to take forward any such request and Air Force permission would have been extremely unlikely in those very tense times.'

In a letter to the science magazine Nature, Reiffel said: 'Fortunately for the future of lunar science, a one or two horse race to detonate a nuclear explosion never occurred. But in my opinion Sagan breached security in March, 1959.'

Reiffel produced eight reports between May 1958 and January 1959 on the feasibility of the plan, all of which were destroyed in 1987 by the foundation. Reiffel would not discuss details of these reports, believing they were still classified, but it was clear the conclusion was that the explosion would have been visible from Earth

He does not know why the plans were scrapped, but said: 'Thankfully, the thinking changed. I am horrified that such a gesture to sway public opinion was ever considered.'

Dr David Lowry, a British nuclear historian, said: 'It is obscene. To think that the first contact human beings would have had with another world would have been to explode a nuclear bomb. Had they gone ahead, we would never have had the romantic image of Neil Armstrong taking "one giant step for mankind".'

Lowry believes Project A119 has relevance today with the US proposing a missile defence system in space. He said: 'The US has always wanted to militarise space and some of the fanciful ideas currently being put forward will seem as incredible as the idea of nuking the moon in the Fifties seems today.'

A Pentagon spokesman would not confirm or deny the plans.

 antony.barnett@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Africa's deadly trade in diamonds
fields.standfirst: How Western arms dealers, corrupt warlords and our hunger for jewels have brought misery to millions
fields.trailText: How Western arms dealers, corrupt warlords and our hunger for jewels have brought misery to millions
fields.byline: Jason Burke in London, Chris McGreal in Sierra Leone, Ed Vulliamy in New York and Nick Paton Walsh in Antwerp
fields.body:
On a hot, humid day three years ago the rebels hacked off Jonah Dumbuya's right arm and his ears.

The 23-year-old teacher was walking through the bush near his village when he was surrounded by armed men and forced to the ground. After their work, the rebels gave the him a letter to take to the government asking for a new arm.

'If you want to know the value of a diamond in Sierra Leone you should take all the arms and legs they chopped off and put them on one side, and all the diamonds dug up over the past 10 years and put them on the other, and then you divide one into the other. That is the value of a diamond in Sierra Leone,' said Dumbuya.

He may not know it, but he is a tiny and bloody link in a huge and complex chain that links cities from New York and London to Tel Aviv and Johannesburg; that links the richest countries of the world with the very poorest, that links warehouses full of Kalashnikov rifles in Eastern Europe with huts full of maimed children in tropical jungles; that links the gleaming gems on the ring fingers of half the world's brides with blood and sweat and pain. They are gems fuelling half a continent's wars.

The trail starts in places like the dusty town of Catoca in Angola, or in the jungles around the war-scarred city of Kisangani in the Congo. Catoca is a huge industrial site where 1,000 workers and huge earthmovers sift yellow, arid dust. It is guarded by heavily armed paramilitary troops.

Around Kisangani the scene is different. Deep in the fetid rainforest, half-naked men work around the clock with sieves and a shovels in the hope that they will be lucky just this once and that their lives will change. Usually they find just a $20 stone which, if not stolen by local bandits or ill-disciplined Congolese troops, might buy them enough food to give them the strength to go on digging.

For all its immense variety the African diamond trade is a slick, well-run business. From the bottom - the myriad workers slaving under the hot sun - to the consumers on the high streets of London, the stones move efficiently along well-worked routes. First, in the case of the small mines, the miner will sell his gem to a local dealer. The dealer will have split the haul with the local military commander, who will pass his stash on to his seniors. After taking a little for themselves - they pass the growing hoard on towards the top.

With armies of up to 35,000 troops, spread over hundreds of thousands of square diamond-rich miles, huge quantities of diamonds amass quickly. Local warlords - or governments - typically sell concessions for the bigger mines, and the concession-owners then feed the gems on to the world market.

Either way, the amounts involved are huge. Jonas Savimbi, who leads the Unita guerrilla movement in Angola, has spent an estimated £2 billion on supplies for his rag-tag army in the last 10 years. Diamonds have allowed him to convert a motley group of ill-trained fighters into one of the best armed irregular forces in the world, capable of fighting a war that has cost 500,000 lives.

The poor African state of Liberia has, according to a US State Department report, sent out at least £200 million worth of diamonds a year, though it has no real gem reserves of its own. Almost all the diamonds were from Sierra Leone, and were collected by troops loyal to Foday Sankoh, the rebel Revolutionary United Front leader whose troops look set to confront the British Army within days.

The sheer wealth involved explains why Sankoh is willing to take such risks to prevent United Nations troops entering the key diamond producing areas in the East of the country.

US State Department sources estimate that between 10 and 15 per cent of the global diamond trade - worth between $5bn and $7bn a year - is made up of smuggled and illicit stones. That sort of money buys a lot of AK47s.

Though men like Sankoh and Savimbi are the key figures, a host of minor players have essential roles. Dozens of different African countries are involved, both directly in the trade and in the conflict it provokes. Some, such as Blaise Compaore, the President of Burkina Faso, and Charles Taylor, the leader of Liberia, help by facilitating the transfer of diamonds from 'conflict' countries to circumvent many of the controls placed on the trade by the UN, other regulators and the big diamond companies such as De Beers. Others help fuel the trade by providing military support to warlords in return for packets of stones or permission to mine, such as the governments of Sudan, Zimbabwe, Rwanda, Burundi and Uganda.

Zimbabwe's involvement is particularly murky. Critics of President Robert Mugabe's regime in Zimbabwe accuse the elderly autocrat of committing 11,000 of his country's troops to the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo in return for vastly lucrative concessions on its diamond fields.

Zimbabwe's economy suffers enormously, hundreds of its soldiers are being killed and Mugabe and senior army officers are getting richer.

But the system would fall apart without the shadowy group of western middlemen who set up the deals, fly the diamonds to the main dealing markets in the West and supply the weapons that the Africans so desperately want. It would also collapse without commercial agreements that keep diamond prices high.

A recent UN report into the failure of the sanctions imposed to stop the trading of stones from Angola lists a score of men such as Victor Bout, a Russian former KGB agent who runs an airfreight service out of Dubai, and the De Decker brothers, two South African businessmen alleged to have funnelled weapons into - and gems out of - half the countries along the continent's west coast.

Another key figure named is a Dutch national called Jacobus Witteveen. According to the researchers he has procured arms for Unita and owns his own Antwerp-based diamond firm.

The Observer has also learnt that at least two British-based companies are involved in the trade, and that a number of mercenary organisations with UK links have been drawn into the shadowy world of smuggled diamonds. There are even some British mercenaries who are reported to have trained the rebels in Sierra Leone.

The UN report's findings are confirmed by US State Department and Central Intelligence Agency sources. It reveals that almost all the weapons being flown into Africa come from Eastern Europe. Most are from Bulgaria, though increasing quantities are now sourced in the Ukraine. Everything from tank parts and multiple rocket launchers to handguns and bayonets are flown in, often with trainers. The Sierra Leone rebels are reported to have former Soviet surface-to-air missiles. At the height of the Angolan war, 22 Ilyushin transport aircraft were landing on a single airstrip each night. Without such arms supplies, war on the scale seen now in Africa would be impossible.

The consequences of the rush for the diamonds - and the bloody fighting that it provokes - are obvious. 'Even the Cold War superpowers did not allow the wholesale ripping up of the economy, the use of children as soldiers and attacks on relief groups,' says Herbert Rowe, political scientist and Africa specialist at Georgetown University in Washington.

As for Sierra Leone, the UN report blames diamonds for 'destabilising the country for the better part of three decades, stealing its patrimony and robbing an entire generation of children, putting the country dead last in the UN's human development index'.

The key to the whole system that drives the diamond wars is found, however, not in a stinking bush war bunker but in one of Europe's most well-heeled cities.

Two thirds of the world's diamond trade is dealt through the Belgian port of Antwerp. It is there that, campaigners allege, the blood-stained stones from African conflicts are laundered clean and sent out to be worn on the fingers of lovers around the world.

On Antwerp's sunny, tree-lined Pelikanstraat, amorous couples wander, gawping at the baubles on display in the shop windows. The real business, however, is done on the grey functional walkway round the corner called the Hovenierstraat. Here diamonds, both rough and polished, are dealt wholesale to the tune of $20bn a year.

The street is overshadowed by a series of huge office blocks: the five main diamond exchanges. For years, when the warlords of Africa placed their packets of rough diamonds into the sweaty hands of their arms dealer's gem experts, it was to the cramped rooms behind these doors that the gems were brought to be evaluated and sold. A culture of turning a blind eye to a stone's provenance gave the city an ugly reputation as the world's leading gem-laundering centre.

The Antwerp trade's governing body, the Diamond High Council (HRD), says business is now reformed. Youri Steverlynck, a spokesperson, maintained that the body has imposed tough new rules. The latest regulation, introduced late last year, means that independent experts check that no diamonds have been imported or exported without documents proving the gems are not from war zones, he said.

But the reform has its limits. It was not hard for The Observer to find a buyer for seven, one carat rough diamonds that 'were from Sierra Leone and had no papers'. After two hours of making calls, a dealer agreed to take our stones for $5,000.

The cash was to be paid in notes with non-consecutive serial numbers, the deal was to be completed at 3pm the following day in the company's Hovenierstraat office. Once the rough diamonds were polished, it would be almost impossible to tell where they had been mined.

One young diamond polisher, Kollon S, was not surprised. 'People here don't care where [rough diamonds] come from,' he said. 'Money, mines and the right people are all there together in Africa. You can send in the UN, but they can't control it. It's a small world, your name matters and everyone trusts each other to keep quiet.'

The UN report is uncompromising. It describes Antwerp as a 'diamond smugglers' dream', where 'even over the most overt cases of questionable behaviour, little is done'.

A few thousand miles to the South, however, there is movement on the issue. A disparate alliance is gradually forming to force change.

Three weeks ago, key American diplomatic and development staff stationed in Sierra Leone called a meeting. Around a table the suited officials sat opposite a number of key mining figures and half a dozen rival military commanders, including rebel leader Sankoh and representatives of the government. Outside the central African sun beat down. Inside the atmosphere was tense.

It was an acrimonious few hours. One American source said the RUF was 'intransigent' over control of the mining areas and the sort of distribution of profits that was envisaged by the peace agreement last year. Finally, an exasperated UN commander is reported to have said the peacekeeping force would attempt to seize back control of the country's mining areas before the end of July. Now that operation has begun, under the leadership of the British Army.

The fact that the Americans called the crucial meeting - even if it ended badly - shows that curbing the trade's excesses is finally being seriously discussed in the western corridors of power.

State Department officials say the American administration is likely to propose a global marketing system in which diamond sales must be accompanied by documents declaring their source and destination. The aim would be a multilateral treaty signed by African nations and overseen by the US.

Diplomatic pressure is being brought to bear on Belgium, and a close eye is being kept on the burgeoning diamond markets of Tel Aviv and Kiev. The Foreign Office has been lobbying quietly for reform.

Other factors may help too. New mines in Canada are threatening to undercut prices. Synthetic diamonds are eating into the market, and a new fake called Moissanite looks exactly like the real thing and is affecting sales of real gems. The age of diamonds may be over.

In Africa too, the movement is gathering pace. Last Friday experts at a meeting of the African Diamond Technical Forum, chaired by South African Minister of Minerals and Energy Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, urged governments on the continent to create an environment for the fair and transparent trading of diamonds in order to prevent smuggling.

The participants, including representatives from the governments of the US, Britain, Belgium and from non-governmental organisations, urged the diamond industry to contribute towards the development 'of the communities and countries in which they derive their wealth', though they agreed that it was fundamentally up to Africans themselves to act.

No one expects change to come swiftly, however, and no one doubts that for Jonah Dumbuya and the ordinary people of Sierra Leone, it is now far too late. 'We used to talk of this country as rich because of the diamonds,' said Dumbuya.

'It was a good thing. It was a glamorous thing - a country with diamonds. Even people who had nothing to do with diamonds would paint them on the signs for their shops and call them Diamond Restaurant, or Diamond Clothes Shop. But they don't do that any more because diamonds have become a nightmare.'
