fields.headline: The last action heroes
fields.trailText: My grandfather died before I was born, while still a relatively young man, of a heart attack, in his bed. My grandmother woke up, leaned over to offer tea, and there he lay, dead. Then again, she always maintained that the boy she married never returned from Dunkirk. Her dashing Jack The Lad came back from war a ghost of his former self. His hands shook, his nerves were shot. My mother remembers an extreme gentleness, and a morbid fear of loud noises - balloons were banned at birthday parties. In all, the war killed his friends, broke his spirit, and probably shortened his life by years if not decades. I think that merits a poppy or two, don't you?
fields.body:
My grandfather died before I was born, while still a relatively young man, of a heart attack, in his bed. My grandmother woke up, leaned over to offer tea, and there he lay, dead. Then again, she always maintained that the boy she married never returned from Dunkirk. Her dashing Jack The Lad came back from war a ghost of his former self. His hands shook, his nerves were shot. My mother remembers an extreme gentleness, and a morbid fear of loud noises - balloons were banned at birthday parties. In all, the war killed his friends, broke his spirit, and probably shortened his life by years if not decades. I think that merits a poppy or two, don't you?

Paper flowers and sentimental news coverage once a year, don't add up to much, but they could be more than future generations could hope for. You'd have to be insane, or a politician chasing votes, not to hate and fear war. However, the fact remains that organised bloodshed seems to dignify an era like nothing else. Had my grandparents lived, they might have been surprised to find themselves part of what is, in effect, the last generation of credible pensioners - the final wave of old people that society can be half-bothered to care about and honour. My grandparents might also have been enraged by all the hypocrisy. We might ignore and despise the elderly as a matter of course - raising their pensions in insulting pennies, letting them freeze to death in winter, and scribbling 'Do Not Resuscitate' on their medical notes - but that doesn't mean we don't enjoy a good blub on Remembrance Sunday.

You could see all this in the reaction to the May Day protests. The anger at the images of the graffiti-daubed Cenotaph. The disgust at the vision of the statue of Winston Churchill with a turf mohawk. Student beer is a terrible thing, to be sure, but there didn't seem to be much lasting harm done. Personally, I couldn't help laughing at the mohawk prank. The Cenotaph, though, was a different matter - but what do you expect from toff teenage anarchists, doubtless descended from breadroll-throwing 80s Hoorays? Even the former soldier who defaced the Churchill statue was keen to distance himself from the vandalism at the Cenotaph. It's one thing to dribble red paint over wartime premiers, quite another to mess with the Unknown Soldier, who was doubtless an alright geezer even an anti-capitalist could quite imagine sharing a pint with.

We seem to get choked up about our Blitz-elderly the same way we get teary eyed about the 1966 World Cup win. Scanning the media, what happened on May Day was variously: 'A disgrace to the memory of those who died for their country'; 'An affront to a generation who fought for democracy'; 'A shameful indictment of our changing times'. This present generation of war-literate pensioners obviously represents something special, historic, and romantic to the public. Usually, old people matter so little, politicians are too busy chasing the sexy 'yoof vote' to bother to suck up to them. This situation only seems to change when there's a righteously patriotic editorial or photo opportunity to be had. Then, old soldiers and dears are wheeled out to shake their heads sorrowfully for the benefit of the cameras, before being spirited away to be ignored until next time they are needed.

fields.headline: Devaluation is our EU right
fields.trailText: Some years ago the powers that be (or were) at the Financial Times decided that, considering the paper's reputation, the range of letters from readers was rather narrow. Indeed, for a time it seemed that the FT only had two letter writers: H.Meulen of Wimbledon and W.Grey of Finchley.
fields.body:
Some years ago the powers that be (or were) at the Financial Times decided that, considering the paper's reputation, the range of letters from readers was rather narrow. Indeed, for a time it seemed that the FT only had two letter writers: H.Meulen of Wimbledon and W.Grey of Finchley.

The decision to 'do something' about the letters page took years to bear fruit. The final straw was the day the paper printed a letter from one O.Emminger, with a Frankfurt address but no reference to the fact that the writer was the president of the Bundesbank.

The FT's letters have since become an important forum, and last week there was one from the City economist Malcolm Levitt, which ought to put the cat among the pigeons. Levitt, an expert on the single currency, reminds us that under the Maastricht Treaty all member states of the European Union (and that still includes, believe it or not, the UK) are required to treat their exchange rates as a matter of common interest. The aim was to avoid 'competitive devaluation'.

No prizes are given for guessing which country the proviso was especially aimed at. The fear was that the UK, with its 'opt-out' from monetary union, might devalue. Potential offenders were warned they could not expect the benefit of 'unfettered exports'.

Well, here we are, with one of those classic overvaluations, and the boot is on the other foot. Levitt says: 'It is now time for the euro-zone governments to be reminded of the damage that the persistent and even increasing under-valuation of the euro against sterling is doing to the manufacturing sector of the UK economy.' He argues that the UK would be within its rights to introduce 'measures to redress the current distortion in the relative prices of euro-zone and UK manufactures'.

Although he does not specify which measures might be taken, the obvious route would be to alleviate the tax burden on manufacturing via lower National Insurance (NI) contributions or an abatement of VAT on energy use. Such measures would be emergency ones. They would probably have to be offset by higher consumer taxes to have a neutral impact on demand.

There is a precedent in the 'Burns-Middleton hypothesis' of 1981, when the Treasury considered action on NI to alleviate the burden of the high pound. In the end the balance of monetary and fiscal policy was altered, the Thatcher government changed its view that it was powerless to influence the value of sterling, and the pound came down. So the proposal remained a hypothesis.

Whether the Levitt proposal will remain a hypothesis remains to be seen. It was significant last week that Chancellor Gordon Brown, having asserted his belief in 'a stable and competitive pound' as the currency became increasingly unstable and increasingly uncompetitive, finally admitted in a lecture that the sterling-euro rate 'cannot be justified by any view of long-term, economic fundamentals'.

That, plus the market's sudden belief that UK interest rates might have peaked, produced a small relapse in the pound's value last week. But when the markets also reflected on Bank deputy governor Mervyn King's warning of 'turbulence ahead' if there is indeed a 'descent of sterling against the euro to a more comfortable altitude', views about interest rates were revised again.

Earlier this month the Bank Governor, Eddie George, told the House of Lords' Peston Committee: 'In effect what we have been doing is compensating for the dampening impact of the weak euro on domestic inflation and the prospect for domestic inflation by encouraging the growth in domestic demand.' Think about it.

At his press conference to launch the May 'Inflation Report' King gave the impression he was relaxed about earnings. I am surprised. The 6 per cent earnings figures look disturbing to me. But in any case, King warned: 'If the exchange rate were to return to a more sustainable level, then final domestic demand growth would have to fall to prevent excess pressure on capacity and rising inflation'. Unless there is a marked slowdown, or a sudden desire on Brown's part to raise consumer taxes, that means higher interest rates.

Giles Radice, the chairman of the Commons Treasury Committee, sees joining the euro as protection from an excessive fall in the pound, as well as from the madness of the current overvaluation. In a pamphlet for the European Movement ( The Case for the Euro ) he urges 'a firm government statement of its intention to join the single currency early in the next parliament, provided the economic circumstances are right' as a way of inducing the market to get the pound down.

Well, at least most people are now getting the message. But there are still some around, including Michael Portillo and the Prime Minister, who do not seem to understand that the traditionally strong deutschmark was the consequence of good economic performance, not the cause of it. The Bundesbank was always very careful to avoid an overvalued currency.

webTitle: Central banks are the new rock 'n roll

fields.headline: Central banks are the new rock 'n roll
fields.trailText: Are Central Banks the new rock 'n roll? The world is after all agog, nay on the edge of its seat, awaiting the Fed's Open Market Committee meeting this week.
fields.body:
Are Central Banks the new rock 'n roll? The world is after all agog, nay on the edge of its seat, awaiting the Fed's Open Market Committee meeting this week.

Forget Tate Modern, the hot ticket is Alan Greenspan's pronouncement on interest rates. While Greenspan is the Madonna of monetary policy - he only has to show up for an occasion to be an event - our own Bank of England is a bit more Oasis; sneering and scowling, shuffling and looking at their shoes, insistent that hitting the inflation target is their only responsibility and shocking those who would encourage intervention to weaken the pound against the euro by putting two fingers up to them.

Then there is the Plastique Bertrand - Wim Duisenberg at the European Central Bank - with his own weak euro problems and crazy punk rock hair.

Central bankers from the 'Group of Ten' industrialised countries met last weekend to throw television sets into swimming pools and discuss international exchange rates in Basle.

Like rock stars, central bankers don't do much. They rarely get out of bed for less than a 25 basis point cut or rise in interest rates, but every wiggle of their eyebrows or suggestive shrug of their shoulders can send the markets into a frenzy of teenage excitement.

And, like rock stars, there is always a fair amount of bitching and whingeing from commentators about what kind of examples central bankers set.

In the UK and Europe the debate has centred round whether central banks have a duty to bale out the euro, while in the US, and as a wider point, whether central banks should take any notice of the stock market fluctuations.

The answer to the first conundrum, intervention, is for the moment 'no' though Duisenberg is reserving his right to step into the market at any point. The issue of soaring share prices - or alternatively crashing markets - is a more interesting subject for debate.

A recent quartet of influential economists meeting in Geneva, all of them au fait with central bank policy-making, drew the conclusion that the economic outlook of individual countries would be improved if central banks took into account sharply rising stock markets or indeed real estate or property prices.

The bottom line is that a massive hike in house prices, or a spike in share prices, is inflation-in-waiting, and therefore should be pivotal to any central bank's inflation control policy. In other words instead of strutting, pouting and singing ballads about 'irrational exuberance', Greenspan should get off his butt and do something about it.

In a wider sense all banks with responsibility for keeping inflation rates stable will always have an eye on asset values, without them necessarily being the deciding indicators for a rise or fall.

The interesting point about the quartet of economists and their thinking is that had the Fed applied the share and house price test then it is reckoned that the interest rate at the end of last year would have been around 7.25 per cent - two points higher than it was.

Greenspan will probably take only a cursory interest in the markets when he decides what to do with rates this week - and the likelihood is of a .25 per cent rather than a full .5 per cent rise.

Central banks are after all only the new rock 'n roll because of their association with exceptionally strong economies such as the continuing US economic miracle and the sustained recovery in the UK.

Success at controlling inflation has perhaps persuaded us to think that central bankers are the right route to correcting all economic ills, whereas in fact they would be better off sticking to their greatest hits rather than striving for that difficult second album. Because even if central banks ignore markets they are totally comfortable in the knowledge that markets would never ignore them.

fields.headline: A brand from the ashes
fields.standfirst:
Phoenix must breathe new life into an old name, argues Simon Caulkin
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Phoenix must breathe new life into an old name, argues Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
If new Rover is to succeed, it will need better management than it has ever had. That should not be difficult - the German episode is just the culmination of an unbroken sequence of management failures since the Fifties.

But, in another sense, it's a tall order. The external conditions in which the company operates have never been tougher, and the stakes are rising all the time. 'It's on life support now,' says Professor Kumar Bhattacharyya, head of Warwick University's Warwick Manufacturing Group.

But not all Rover's management problems are strictly of its own making. Some graphically illustrate the precarious position of manufacturing companies caught between indifferent governments and an unfriendly financial system.

The Thatcher government's sale of Rover to BAe in 1988 was cynical. The aerospace company then sold the company on under the nose of its alliance partner Honda to an unsuspecting BMW, having neatly relieved it of some of its best Japanese-trained management talent.

Now Rover faces more revolving doors, as UK personnel replace the existing BMW team. Despite the long-term record, recruitment is unlikely to be a problem, industry analysts believe. UK motor industry management in general has improved, thanks largely to the Japanese influence and outfits such as the Warwick Manufacturing Group.

'My guess is that in the wave of euphoria it won't be hard to bring together some of the old team that was swept away by BMW,' says Professor Dan Jones, head of the Lean Enterprise Group at Cardiff Business School. 'Of course, the old group didn't disappear without reason; whether it is the right one now is a good question.'

In the short term the Towers team does have a couple of things going for it, however. The first is unprecedented co-operation from the workforce - 'an extraordinary turnaround from the days of Red Robbo two decades ago,' notes Jones, who believes that the TGWU, and Tony Woodley in particular, deserve more credit for the Phoenix deal than they have yet received.

The second plus is that, unlike BMW, the new management is under no illusion about how bad the situation really is. 'Managing is no problem if you have skilled managers, top-quality cars and the best modern plant,' says Bhattacharyya. 'When you're far from the best, you have to use a witches' brew and hope some of it will work. The problem for BMW at Rover was that it couldn't press A and get B. It couldn't manage chaos.'

The issue for the incoming team is the reverse. It can probably handle the short-term ducking and diving - the big question is how it gets to the sunny uplands of a settled product and market strategy 18 months to two years on.

The first of the immediate management priorities, say industry analysts, is to shift fields of unsold cars at almost any price - anything to get the cash coming in and prevent stocks from building up.

There's no mystery about selling cars, Bhattacharyya says. There are no bad cars any more, but a lot of average ones. The lesson of Rover's doubled sales figures last month is that people will buy average vehicles - but not at a premium they no longer deserve.

Rover's current sales drive improves morale and buys time, but is unsustainable in the long term because the cars are being sold below cost. So the group's second priority is to cut out any remaining fat at Longbridge to lower the cost base and make itself more attractive to a stronger partner. Here, unfortunately, the company can exert little leverage, since overcapacity in the industry is endemic, and Jones says Longbridge is 'a hellhole - given the choice you wouldn't start from there'.

Even Honda, which appears remarkably well disposed towards its former partner given the previous snub, will be no soft touch. It is a commercial organisation after all - and, while the UK company gained much-needed knowhow, it reportedly received little financial return from the previous collaboration.

Assuming the deal is finally done - there remain plenty of details to finalise, warns Jones - perhaps Rover's biggest management challenge will be to prevent short-term survival measures such as cost-cutting and squeezing assets from sabotaging the medium-term need to invest in the brand.

Most glaringly, BMW seemed as paralysed by Rover's brand shrinkage and halting product strategy as every other post-war management and, as it stands, Rover only has the resources to tweak the current range.

'The 75 is a bank manager's car,' says Jones. 'But there soon won't be any bank managers left - the Internet has seen to that.' So who is Rover to sell to?

Resurrecting the Rover brand is vital; compared with this, streamlining Longbridge is child's play. If Phoenix can pull that off, it really will deserve its name.

webTitle: Pylon the power, s'il vous plat

fields.headline: Pylon the power, s'il vous plat
fields.standfirst: Lack of electricity and water fracture the idyll at  Natalie Sutton's  French home. Was someone economical with the vérité?
fields.trailText: I felt a strange sensation just below my solar plexus as we drove over the hill and I caught my first glimpse of the little stone-walled French hamlet we had bought two months previously.
fields.body:
I felt a strange sensation just below my solar plexus as we drove over the hill and I caught my first glimpse of the little stone-walled French hamlet we had bought two months previously.

It was mainly a ridiculous sense of relief that it was still there and that, tucked away in its clearing in the forest, with a view of distant mountains, it was as beautiful as I remembered. I also felt a hint of panic when I thought of all the things we needed to do to it over the next four days.

The problem with setting up a secondary home is that there is always so much to do and never enough time. With the effort and cost of snatching a few days in France, organisation and time management need to border on the military, - and organisation has never been one of my strengths.

The sun was setting as we eventually jolted to a stop, dragging a trailer piled high with two precariously tied beds and a couple of mattresses. We had tried to persuade the furniture shop to deliver, but were turned down. It wasn't so much the distance or inaccessibility of the hamlet that deterred them, but the fact that we wanted all the stuff immediately.

Added to the imminent loss of sunlight, the journey from down in the valley had been given a slight edge by the way in which French drivers insist on tailgating in their rush to overtake. Surely, a sight akin to a Bedouin's picnic swaying around from the back of a rusty old Jeep would caution them to follow from a safer distance? Apparently not.

Self-assembly furniture is, it seems, a universal enigma - following the inadequate instructions is hard enough in daylight; try doing it in the half-dark.

Not surprisingly, we spent the first night on a mattress on the floor. The candlelight and a roaring log fire made it all quite romantic - not least because it hid the fact that we were sleeping among mouse droppings, bat poo and dead flies collected over the two years the place had lain empty.

I fully recognise, now, that I may have come across as rather smug in the first couple of instalments of this diary. As is often the case, pride comes before a fall. For example, the previous owner had assured us that the plumbing, albeit basic, was fully functional, and I distinctly remember him giving us a running commentary about the quality of the water from our spring rivalling Evian.

In theory, the guided tour we were given to the various pipes and how they connected to the water pump seemed straightforward. In practice, it was quite a different matter. The little pump, operated by the generator, had about as much power as an electric toothbrush, yet it has to suck a substantial flow of water from the spring and push it 30 yards up a hill to the reserve tank above.

The idea is that water then has enough pressure to flow down again to various outlets in the two main houses. Air bubbles prevented progress for a while, but suddenly we could hear water gurgling and feel the pipe going cold. The weather was mild, but the the spring water was icy.

The reserve tank filled very slowly from the pathetic trickle which the pump was able to produce at full capacity. When the tank was about a tenth full, we opened the sluice and ran down to the house to admire, we hoped, a steady jet of clear, mountain water coming from the tap in the kitchen. There was none. A tap outside delivered a healthy spurt of water. In five seconds, most of the supply we had struggled to collect was happily watering the grass.

We hurriedly switched off the tap, and found that the flow was splashing out of cracked and broken pipes in the bathroom, temporarily creating an indoor swimming pool.

Until a plumber can be lured up to the back of beyond, it's back to freezing my fingers off while filling cans from the cold spring.

Sadly, the previous owner was also economical with the truth about the sanitation. I suppose we were rather stupid not to have asked for proof of all his claims, but when we spoke to him we had already paid our deposit on the property, so lying would have been unnecessary.

Anyway, waste is not flushed away (admittedly this would be difficult in itself, given the water situation) and discarded to a place of no consequence half way down the mountain. It actually comes up for air about 2ft away from the front door. That'll be another job for the plumber, so it's best not to use the facilities yet.

We're hoping that the longed-for electricity, which would ease many other problems, could actually be on its way. The EDF (Electricité de France) is planning where to place the pylons. Thankfully, these will be wooden, environmentally and aesthetically friendly telegraph poles, rather than metal monstrosities.

Slight confusion arose when EDF asked us to produce a certificate, signed by a registered electrician, to prove that the hamlet was correctly wired up - which clearly it isn't.

For now, the shaky generator powers one pulsating lightbulb. The single flex leading to the bulb hardly constitutes a full circuit and, with a full complement of exposed wires, is probably about as safe as a hairdryer in a bathtub.

Our electrician cannot do his job without an existing supply of electricity.

Luckily for us, Monsieur l'Electricien and Monsieur EDF know each other, and have decided to install a temporary electric cable while work is in progress. After that will come some suitable wiring.

I've only just returned to Britain, and it's already time to start thinking about the next jaunt. Planning a trip is no longer a case of booking travel, ordering currency and checking passports. It also means organising electricians, plumbers, removal men and builders, and booking appointments with mayor plus mechanic and customs man.

I had visions of lazy holidays snoozing in the Southern sunshine. Maybe one day.

fields.headline: Surrey bask in net practice
fields.trailText: Surrey v Kent
fields.body:
A game going nowhere fast, barring declarations or a dramatic collapse this morning, has at least afforded the champions a degree of much-needed batting practice. Having scraped past Yorkshire into the Benson & Hedges semi-final on Tuesday, Surrey took full advantage of the first flush of summer in posting 417 before Kent embarked on their own quest for batting points.

A fair gathering basked in the sunshine at England's oldest Test match ground, which is scheduled for an £18m face-lift to include a new grandstand alongside the Pavilion, and a belated comprehensive refurbishment at the Vauxhall End. An 'interactive museum' will also be incorporated, allowing cus tomers the opportunity of an over or two at WG or the chance to face Harold Larwood in his pomp. Good enough reason, then, for staying in the bar on rainy days.

Great things are expected this term of Rahul Dravid, Kent's Indian Test batsman, and a big hundred against the Zimbabweans last week has only heightened anticipation. Ed Smith offered another early opportunity, pulling the replacement ball, a long hop from Martin Bicknell, down square leg's throat. Dravid then had to draw on all the nuances of a pure, refined technique to withstand a searching early examination by Alex Tudor.

Robert Kee kept him company in a torpid passage before tea, managing just 19 runs in 26 overs, as Kent made heavy weather of their reply. Surrey rang the changes in a bid to dislodge the pair and Ian Salisbury, the fourth change leg spinner, eventually claimed Key in his first over, thanks to a low catch at slip by Ben Hollioake from a defensive push.

Surrey, looking to extend an overnight 278 for 6 after the first day wash-out, resumed in warm sunshine in the morning but were in no particular hurry themselves on a placid pitch. Bicknell's enduring qualities with the new ball have overshadowed his batting ability, and the 31-year-old seamer would no doubt have kept half an eye cocked towards Ceefax for England's first Test squad.

Adam Hollioake, the captain, long since relinquished interest in such matters and is now charged solely with keeping the champions ahead of the pack. A year ago at Tunbridge Wells, Surrey despatched Kent by an innings and 28 runs and moved to the championship summit, a position protected zealously to the end. Things have been less equable this time around, with defeat already against unfancied Durham, and this match so far has served as little more than an extended net.

Kent's threadbare attack was fully compliant again as Surrey added 131 in the first session. It is rank bad luck, of course, to have Dean Headley out with a long-term back injury, Julian Thompson, the Good Doctor, laid low by a second operation on a knee tendon, and now Martin McCague sidelined after having spurs on a heel bone trimmed.

Mark Ealham has shouldered some of the extra burden admirably, and Hollioake was bemused by a classic outswinger which pitched leg stump and hit the top of off. Salisbury, however, is no mug with the willow either, and Matthew Fleming, the Kent captain, was soon scratching his pate and surveying the options with a critical air. The wisdom of granting Surrey first use of such an unresponsive track may also have crossed his mind as the hosts moved past 400.

Dravid was not engaged for his off-spinning but Fleming pressed him into service again and was immediately rewarded with Bicknell's scalp, only his second first class wicket, held ankle-high at mid-off by David Masters, for an enterprising 73 in a shade under three hours. Salisbury, too, completed a pleasant half century before falling lbw to Martin Saggers first ball after lunch, then Rupesh Amin was run out.

fields.headline: Careless talk...
fields.trailText: Last week's publication of the Stewart report on mobile-phone safety will have helped allay the public's worst fears over these devices. However, its refusal to give a complete clean bill of health to the technology has left lingering doubts. Are mobile phones completely safe or do they pose dangers, even on a limited scale? Stewart finds no persuasive evidence to support the latter notion, but refuses to support the former.
fields.body:
Last week's publication of the Stewart report on mobile-phone safety will have helped allay the public's worst fears over these devices. However, its refusal to give a complete clean bill of health to the technology has left lingering doubts. Are mobile phones completely safe or do they pose dangers, even on a limited scale? Stewart finds no persuasive evidence to support the latter notion, but refuses to support the former.

The trouble lies not with Stewart's caution, but with some people's lust for certainty, an urge that science is simply not structured to assuage. Scientists draw inferences from available evidence and then expect their colleagues to try to disprove their ideas. Surviving notions are then temporarily accepted as working hypotheses. By contrast, pressure groups demand absolute assurances about the safety of food, phones and the environment, an expectation with unhappy consequences. During the BSE crisis, some researchers proclaimed beef was safe, statements that looked unfortunate with the first appearance of cases of new-variant CJD. Once burned, scientists then refused to give similar clearances to GM foods, a critical factor, it is said by some, in the disastrous public reception of this technology.

One could argue just as easily that gene engineering was acceptable to the public when the technology was used to make medicines that helped the sick, but was rejected when employed in food and crop production - because it looked as if only farmers and big business would benefit. In other words, the public can assess the risks and benefits of a given science quite easily when it wants to. Indeed, it is arrogant to assume otherwise.

Most people will therefore respond calmly to Stewart's report. Sales will not slump, though this will have more to do with our thirst to talk than with the public's powers to assess scientific pronouncements. We should not underestimate this latter ability, just the same.

fields.headline: SingalongaKant
fields.trailText: At a cinema near you they may one day be showing Dickie 'luvvie' Attenborough's account of the existentialist triangle of Simone de Beauvoir, Jean Paul Sartre and Nelson Egren. His casting ambitions include Juliette Binoche as Simone, Geoffrey (Shine) Rush as Sartre and George Clooney as the American Egren who de Beauvoir has credited as the agent of her first orgasm.
fields.body:
At a cinema near you they may one day be showing Dickie 'luvvie' Attenborough's account of the existentialist triangle of Simone de Beauvoir, Jean Paul Sartre and Nelson Egren. His casting ambitions include Juliette Binoche as Simone, Geoffrey (Shine) Rush as Sartre and George Clooney as the American Egren who de Beauvoir has credited as the agent of her first orgasm.

Marvellous. We hope he filches Sartre's filmic title Being and Nothingness. And, when he's finished with that, we've got more philosophical projects for him. The Critique of Pure Reason from dry old Immanuel Kant is surely due the Hollywood treatment, with Ralph Fiennes breathing passion into the categorical imperative, while a title like Fear and Trembling is pure box office even if Soren Kierkegaard himself was a few premises short of a logical conclusion. And what about René's Story ('He thought therefore he was!') which could trace Descartes' journey from frigid France to liberal Netherlands where his several illegitimate children led him to ponder the meaning of existence.

But the film we really can't wait to see is The Undecidability Theorem, a title as pregnant with menace as The Ipcress File. This would unfold the central paradox of Kurt Gödel's life and death. Woody Allen could play the troubled logician who, believing he was being poisoned, starved himself to death. Profound, or what?

fields.headline: So farewell to all that...
fields.standfirst: You've read the football writers every week. Now Observer Sport's club-by-club fanzine survey gives the supporters' views on the Premiership season, with a fun-factor rating
fields.trailText: You've read the football writers every week. Now Observer Sport's club-by-club fanzine survey gives the supporters' views on the Premiership season, with a fun-factor rating.
fields.body:
Arsenal

Ian Trevett: Highbury High

Whatever the result on Wednesday, the Uefa Cup saved our season. After the Wembley disasters in the Champions League, confidence was rock bottom and it cost us points. With only two goals Henry was no Anelka and with Vieira still suspended, Highbury was a gloomy place. The Uefa Cup brought back the fun and proved we could live with the best in Europe, especially the 5-1 thrashing of Spanish leaders Deportivo. Henry - the fanzine's player of the year - caught fire, Vieira added maturity to his game, and Tony Adams returned more dominant than ever. Next season we won't give United such a big start!

Fun factor (marks out of 10): 6 (but 0 for the Champions League and 9 for the Uefa Cup).

Aston Villa

Dave Woodhall: Heroes and Villains

A decent start, with results looking good even if performances weren't. A catastrophic run which left John Gregory a match away from the sack, even if the newly self-styled 'Delightful' Doug Ellis won't admit it. Then just one league defeat since early December and a place in the Cup Final. With a regular goalscorer this strangest of seasons could have ended with Champions League qualification. Instead, it's either FA Cup immortality or Intertoto mediocrity. Goerge Boateng added steel to midfield, Paul Merson was the best midfielder in the country post-Christmas. But for all-round consistency, my Player of the Year is David James.

Fun factor (with the FA Cup): 10 (and if we lose at Wembley) 6

Bradford City

John Watmough: City Gent

It has been a roller-coaster. We knew at the start that we faced enormous difficulties to stay up. But if anyone had offered us a chance of staying up going into the last game of the season, most fans would have taken that last August. It's just a shame that things have swung around because two successive wins against Sunderland and Wimbledon meant our fate was in our own hands - last week's results took it away from us again. Liverpool today? Of course it's possible to beat them but we know how tough it will be. Goalkeeper Matt Clarke has been terrific as has young defender Andrew O'Brien and Dean Windass but my own Player of the Year choice would be David Wetherall, a great signing from Leeds. If we go down ,we all want to come back.

Fun factor: 6

Chelsea

Mark Wheeler: Chelsea Independent

Many Chelsea fans are unsure whether this has been a good season or not. We could give you a more definite answer after the FA Cup Final. Some feel that fifth in the league is disappointing after finishing third last season, but in reaching the quarter-finals of the Champions League (at the first attempt) Chelsea have broken new ground. League performances against the relegation fodder have been infuriating but the 5-0 triumph over Manchester United was splendid compensation. Albert Ferrer and Gustavo Poyet have been superb but top man this season is undoubtedly Dennis Wise.

Fun factor: 8 (rising to 9 if we win the FA Cup).

Coventry City

Paul Wheeler: Peeping Tom

At times it has seemed as though Gordon Strachan was building and stocking his own ark as he only seems interested in collecting pairs of players. We have two Moroccans, two from Peru, a brace of Scottish internationals, we had two Swedes, and he even signed up two of his sons , and a couple of pensioners. It was a tale of two seasons on the pitch. At home we were Champions League contenders; away, relegation certainties. Only Watford can stop us achieving a whole season without an away win. The new arrivals made an immediate impact, none more so than Robbie Keane who exploded on the scene with a rush of goals, and Hadji and Chippo brought a touch of Moroccan gold on and off the pitch. Perhaps the greatest honours should go to Steve Ogrizovich who retired after his 601st appearance. Because of him we are still in a position to attract the international stars.

Fun factor : Home 9, Away 1.

Derby County

William Wilkinson: Ramsnet

A season which began with manager Smith stating he had his 'strongest squad ever' finished with relief as we narrowly escaped relegation. Smith was right, the squad was strong, but through no fault of his own it had been left to go stagnant across the summer. The perennial underachievers were out in force with Lars Bohinen, Mikkel Beck, Dean Sturridge and Deon Burton being the main culprits. Player of the season Mart Poom was a rock throughout and captain Darryl Powell along with Craig Burley and Georgi Kinkladze stood out. The performance against Bradford away was inspirational and the emergence of Christie leaves hope for next season. Fresh blood and a new drive will see us come good next term. Who knows, maybe we'll have Furetes fully equipped with a passport by then

Fun Factor: 5

Everton

Mark Staniford: Speke from the Harbour

It's a sad reflection of the current state of the club when being safe from relegation six weeks before the end of season is seen as progress. However what should not be overlooked is the increase in the quality of the football that we have seen this season. Eyebrows were raised at the recruitment of Richard Gough, Mark Pembridge and Joe-Max Moore but not one of them have let the Blues down. Admittedly we would like to be looking at higher calibre players but the money is just not there. Bargain buy of the season was Stephen Hughes from Arsenal and Player of the Year, Richard Gough.

Fun factor: 7

Leeds United

Eric Carlile: Leeds United Supporters' Club

A successful season with the side again qualifying for Europe and reaching the Uefa Cup semi-finals. Several players were introduced and their experience gained this time will make us even stronger in the future. David O'Leary, in his first full season as manager, did a great job and will surely strengthen the side for next season while full houses at most home games demonstrate the fans' faith in the side. Harry Kewell is our player of the year and we're looking forward to even more success next term when hopefully we win at least one trophy. Fun? With respect we must take the Turkish tragedy completely out of talk about fun but it has been, otherwise, an enjoyable campaign.

Fun factor: 8.

Leicester City

Gary Silk: The Fox

Another season of ridiculous over-achievement. When you think about how much we've spent - or not spent - it's remarkable. £3 million for Darren Eadie was a huge deal for us. We also had a real midwinter injury crisis and then, even when Heskey went, we won at Southampton, Liverpool and Newcastle to show that Leicester still hard fire in their bellies when others were coasting towards summer. We go into the last weekend eighth in the table and that is fantastic for a club of our size. Then there is the matter of winning the League Cup and qualifying for Europe and all the while there was more politics off the field than you can shake a stick at. We were more confident of holding on to Martin O'Neill than last season when Leeds were after him. Heroes? I'd look no further than Matt Elliott and Gerry Taggart. Elliott, as a makeshift striker, was amazing - our player of the year. Losing Heskey was disappointing but Collymore is a more skilful replacement.

Fun factor: 10.

Liverpool

John Pearman: Red All Over

Like many Liverpool fans, if someone had told me at the start of the season that come the last day we would have a chance of finishing third, I would have taken it. We've achieved a lot despite having enough injuries to fill a couple of episodes of Casualty and we've seen some memorable goals and shared some memorable moments. The goals that Paddy Berger has scored should have ensured that MOTD gave him his own goal of the season competition. The premier signing of the season must surely be Sami Hyypia. But for the Koppites the man of the season has been Grard Houllier who, along with Phil Thompson, has given Liverpool fans hope for the future and have given us back our prideÉ at times the Kop sounded like it used to in days of yore.

Fun Factor: 9.

Manchester United

Andy Mitten: United We Stand

1999/2000 in a nutshell: another great season of fine attacking football only tempered by not defending the FA Cup and the defeat by Real Madrid. Red-shirted heroes: Ryan Giggs, Roy Keane, Jaap Stam, David Beckham - our world-class quartet. Could do better: Mickael Silvestre - rarely has a player made the difficult stuff look easy and, unfortunately, vice versa - like this one. Player of the year - Keane for another absolutely massive contribution to the United cause. 'We won the league in second gear,' sing Old Trafford's red hordes nonchalantly, but nothing can ever compare with last season's Treble.

Fun Factor: 8

Middlesbrough

Robert Nichols: Fly Me To The Moon

Expectations were high but then the slump set in and we went crashing down the league and out of the cups to lower league opposition. Player of the year - Paul Ince, and I must mention young player of the year Andy Campbell, a super home-grown striker. It has been a bit of a slog soÉ

fields.headline: Knickers to war
fields.trailText: Germaine Greer's article on lingerie (Review, last week) reminded me of my Women's Auxiliary Air Force 'issue' of underwear with our uniforms during World War II. They inspired, in both sexes, horror and amusement and, especially when worn by a big-busted woman like myself. They were certainly passion-killers. They should be exhibited in the Imperial War Museum - as an incentive to keep the peace!

fields.headline: Knight ready for big day
fields.trailText: Will Buckley talks to Nick Knight, waiting for the call after being consigned to the periphery as a one-day specialist since 1997.
fields.body:
At the age of 30, the time has come for Nick Knight to fulfil his potential. Yesterday he was given his first chance for two years to build on a Test career which started promisingly and then went awry. There was a time when Knight, an aggressive left-hand batsman and accomplished fielder, seemed predestined to be one of the chosen few selected for the Test team as a matter of course. Between July 1996 and February 1997 he played eight Tests in a row and averaged 34.07 before breaking a finger. Since then, just one Test against South Africa at Manchester, 11 and one, and then consigned to the periphery as a one-day specialist considered not good enough to make England's dismal World Cup team.

'I'm hoping to get the call,' he said at a dank Hove on Thursday evening sitting in the players' common-room - lounge is too flash a word - and watching his team-mates lark around with a rugby ball while coach Bob Woolmer looked on. 'I was disappointed with the one-off Test against South Africa. If I get a chance I must make it count,' says Knight.

The reason he has been offered it is a encouraging start to the season. 'The pleasing thing is that when you're not among the original contracted players you have to score as many as you can to get in,' he says. 'I've gone out and got a weight of runs. The double hundred [against Glamorgan] doesn't make a season but it was a good time to get it.'

Despite being excluded from the contracted dozen, he believes in the concept: 'It's the way forward. It must be a good thing to get a team together so they can progress together. The aim, obviously, is to get into the dozen next time.'

Being left out has been something of a constant during his career. He started at Essex but had an in-and-out time. 'It was difficult. You'd be in, out, back in and then out again. I was desperate to be involved but when Goochie came back from Test duty he would naturally come back in.'

In 1995, Warwickshire offered more certainty. 'We saw a cricketer with a lot of potential,' says Dermot Reeve, the Warwickshire captain at the time. 'He picks the ball up early, he's a good athlete and a very good fielder. We thought he'd be a good acquisition for the team and he proved to be. Nick wasn't entirely happy at the time and felt he'd be a better cricketer with us.'

In Knight's first season Warwickshire won three trophies, in his second two trophies and Knight was instrumental to their success. 'Since I started at Warwickshire I've averaged 50,' he says. 'That's not too bad. I like to think I've done my piece.'

He carried over his Warwickshire form to the England one-day team. Opening the batting on his debut against Pakistan, he charged down the wicket at Wasim Akram during his first over. Over that weekend, he made two centuries. His swashbuckling style was suited to the times. The Sri Lankans had improvised the idea of pinch-hitting to take maximum advantage of the fielding restrictions in place during the first 15 overs. Knight was the only Englishman who could launch an innings the Jayasuriya way. By hurtling down the wicket and pummelling the ball over a fast bowler's head he not only gave his side momentum, but also irritated the hell out of big men used to seeing batsmen cower rather than charge.

Only a year and a half ago David Lloyd, when asked how much Knight meant to the team, compared his absence to the Australians missing Steve Waugh or the Sri Lankans doing without Aravinda De Silva. Four months later, after a dodgy trip to Sharjah and a meagre start to the season, he was dropped from the side. England opted to open with Alec Stewart and Nasser Hussain and were out of the tournament before Dave Stewart's World Cup single was in the shops.

'It was a real low point,' says Knight. 'A massive disappointment. But ultimately you have to remember that you're a member of the squad. You can't mope around. If someone wants a drink or a few throw-downs then you do it.'

The disappointments may have made him mentally stronger. He's certainly an improved batsman. 'I'm a better player now than when I joined Warwickshire. I'm a much more complete player. Experience has given me a better understanding of the game and lots of batsmen have improved after they've reached 30.'

In the past, there has been a suspicion that Knight is vulnerable to the ball swinging into him, a flaw common to left-handers. But there is no evidence of this as he survives the final session up against spirited Sussex bowling led by Robin 'Tucker' Martin-Jenkins. It has to be said that an overcast Hove can have a deadening effect. There are few spectators present and over half of them are suddenly deprived of a view of proceedings when a barman, apropos of nothing, and without a word of warning slams down his aluminium shutter. Men holding pints stand and stare at sheet metal, it takes them a while to realise they might be missing the action. Welcome to Division Two.

'It will be a big disappointment if we're still in Division Two next year,' says Knight. 'But I don't think there's much difference between the divi sions at the moment. People don't say he scored runs in Division Two so they don't count. In time the better sides will stay up and the best players will play against the best more regularly. With the best batsmen facing the best bowlers the rate of improvement will be much quicker.'

He's a fan of the restructuring and the new pitches. 'Last season lots of games were lasting one and a half days, two days, two and a half days. This year seems better. Good pitches help me. As long as you have good, even bounce that's all you need.'

I mention the 'C' word. Knight admits to being surprised at Cronje's behaviour. Behind us Bob Woolmer does an impersonation of a man looking flabbergasted while juggling too many balls in the air.

Knight made his Test debut against the West Indies and didn't have the happiest of times. He was hit on the helmet by a full-toss from Courtney Walsh, hit on the head while fielding at short-leg and broke his finger. If he does well against Zimbabwe he will have the chance to exact his revenge.

Being left out has been something of a constant during his career. He started at Essex but had an in-and-out time. 'It was difficult. You'd be in, out, back in and then out again. I was desperate to be involved but when Goochie came back from Test duty he would naturally come back in.' In 1995, Warwickshire offered more certainty. 'We saw a cricketer with a lot of potential,' says Dermot Reeve, the Warwickshire captain at the time. 'He picks the ball up early, he's a good athlete and a very good fielder. We thought he'd be a good acquisition for the team and he proved to be. Nick wasn't entirely happy at the time and felt he'd be a better cricketer with us.' In Knight's first season Warwickshire won three trophies, in his second two trophies and Knight was instrumental to their success. 'Since I started at Warwickshire I've averaged 50,' he says. 'That's not too bad. I like to think I've done my piece.' He carried over his Warwickshire form to the England one-day team. Opening the batting on his debut against Pakistan, he charged down the wicket at Wasim Akram during his first over. Over that weekend, he made two centuries. His swashbuckling style was suited to the times. The Sri Lankans had improvised the idea of pinch-hitting to take maximum advantage of the fielding restrictions in place during the first 15 overs. Knight was the only Englishman who could launch an innings the Jayasuriya way. By hurtling down the wicket and pummelling the ball over a fast bowler's head he not only gave his side momentum, but also irritated the hell out of big men used to seeing batsmen cower rather than charge. Only a year and a half ago David Lloyd, when asked how much Knight meant to the team, compared his absence to the Australians missing Steve Waugh or the Sri Lankans doing without Aravinda De Silva. Four months later, after a dodgy trip to Sharjah and a meagre start to the season, he was dropped from the side. England opted to open with Alec Stewart and Nasser Hussain and were out of the tournament before Dave Stewart's World Cup single was in the shops. 'It was a real low point,' says Knight. 'A massive disappointment. But ultimately you have to remember that you're a member of the squad. You can't mope around. If someone wants a drink or a few throw-downs then you do it.' The disappointments may have made him mentally stronger. He's certainly an improved batsman. 'I'm a better player now than when I joined Warwickshire. I'm a much more complete player. Experience has given me a better understanding of the game and lots of batsmen have improved after they've reached 30.' In the past, there has been a suspicion that Knight is vulnerable to the ball swinging into him, a flaw common to left-handers. But there is no evidence of this as he survives the final session up against spirited Sussex bowling led by Robin 'Tucker' Martin-Jenkins. It has to be said that an overcast Hove can have a deadening effect. There are few spectators present and over half of them are suddenly deprived of a view of proceedings when a barman, apropos of nothing, and without a word of warning slams down his aluminium shutter. Men holding pints stand and stare at sheet metal, it takes them a while to realise they might be missing the action. Welcome to Division Two. 'It will be a big disappointment if we're still in Division Two next year,' says Knight. 'But I don't think there's much difference between the divi sions at the moment. People don't say he scored runs in Division Two so they don't count. In time the better sides will stay up and the best players will play against the best more regularly. With the best batsmen facing the best bowlers the rate of improvement will be much quicker.' He's a fan of the restructuring and the new pitches. 'Last season lots of games were lasting one and a half days, two days, two and a half days. This year seems better. Good pitches help me. As long as you have good, even bounce that's all you need.' I mention the 'C' word. Knight admits to being surprised at Cronje's behaviour. Behind us Bob Woolmer does an impersonation of a man looking flabbergasted while juggling too many balls in the air. Knight made his Test debut against the West Indies and didn't have the happiest of times. He was hit on the helmet by a full-toss from Courtney Walsh, hit on the head while fielding at short-leg and broke his finger. If he does well against Zimbabwe he will have the chance to exact his revenge. Batting Test matches 12 Innings: 21 Runs: 585 Average: 27.85 One-day Intls 53 Innings: 53 Runs: 1923 Average: 40.66

fields.headline: Lehmann looks a cut above
fields.standfirst: More misery for Warne as injury-struck Hampshire are humbled by an in-form Yorkshire batsman
fields.trailText: Yorkshire v Hampshire
fields.body:
We came to Leeds to witness a tubby, gregarious Australian, much lauded in his own country, deftly asserting his superiority over workaday English county professionals - and we were not disappointed. But the Aussie in question was Darren Lehmann, not Shane Warne.

Lehmann was a class above his English colleagues (though not his Scottish one - Gavin Hamilton was also superb) as he steered Yorkshire to a position of total dominance over a hapless Hampshire side. He hit a masterful 85 on a typically tricky Headingley pitch, playing very straight and very late. There was no brute force; just wonderful watchful placement, deflecting the good ones into the gaps, cracking the bad ones to the boundary.

One or two of those bad ones were delivered by his compatriot Warne, who is currently confronted with one of the sternest tests of his cricketing career. Warne has found himself playing for a team that can't score runs (neither has he after three first-class visits to the crease); he's playing on pitches which make the trooper, Peter Hartley, a far more formidable proposition than the world's greatest leg-spinner, and bowling to a young keeper who has only been converted from an opening batsman because of an injury mini-crisis at Hampshire.

Being Warne he's still competing furiously, still encouraging his new mates, but it must be a struggle. When playing for Australia, he has rarely had to bowl when the deficit is in excess of 200. He had to yesterday. The root of Hampshire's problems stems from the loss of confidence of their batsmen, though they are also handicapped by the continued absence of their other expensive winter acquisition, Alan Mullally. They were bowled out cheaply by Caddick on a flat pitch at Southampton last week; on Tuesday they were tumbled out for 69 in the B&H at Cardiff, where the ball refuses to bounce above knee high. Thence to treacherous Headingley, where they were bundled out for 101 on Friday. Top score: Extras, 23.

No surprise then that Warne was not required until 12.40 and by then Hampshire were already in the mire. Hartley, back on his own stamping, ground, had caused the home batsmen a few problems early on. According to new coach Jimmy Cook he has been Hampshire's outstanding bowler this year, a fine achievement for a 40-year-old, but also something of an indictment of the others. It's reassuring that someone whose training regime still involves a few fags and pints can excel at such an advanced age.

When Yorkshire resumed on 144 for four Hartley soon had Wood caught behind. Fellows departed lbw to Mascarenhas, but Lehmann now found a boisterous ally in England's forgotten man, Gavin Hamilton. Hamilton was more forthright and more chancy than his partner in a 111-run union. He cracked the ball to the boundary; Lehmann, so much more adept on these Headingley pitches than last year's Aussie, Greg Blewett, guided the ball there after watching it right onto the middle of his bat.

Warne might have dismissed Hamilton several times. Once the Scot came down the wicket, missed a leg-break which passed between bat and pad, then passed between the gloves of Kenway behind the stumps. Hamilton promptly whacked the next ball to the square leg boundary. Later Warne tossed in an unusual number of googlies, unread by Hamilton or Kenway. Again the batsman was stranded outside his crease; again he survived. Soon Warne at first slip could be seen embracing and consoling the young makeshift keeper, an indication that he hasn't fallen out of love with county cricket just yet.

After lunch Lehmann cracked a square cut straight into the hands of Laney at point, bringing in James Middlebrook, who was soon to become Warne's second first-class victim of the season by edging a classic leg-break to slip. Enter Gough and the prospect of an enticing duel. Gough managed one hugely satisfying clunk over the mid-wicket boundary but otherwise played Warne with unusual discretion.

In the meantime Hamilton, unrecognisable from the forlorn figure who dutifully ferried drinks around Southern Africa this winter, became ever more assured in his strokeplay. He drove straight and through the covers as if this was a batsman's paradise; he even managed to uppercut Hartley for six to third man. The next ball was cracked square for four, which took him to his maiden first-class century. So much for the nervous nineties. He was finally bowled by a low bouncing leg-break when Yorkshire were one short of a fifth batting point, enabling Warne to register his first two-wicket haul in county cricket.

webTitle: Revealed: How to lose a match

fields.headline: Revealed: How to lose a match
fields.trailText: Deliberate run-outs of team-mates, the intentional bowling of wides, byes and easy-to-hit bouncers, slowing down the run rate, and bizarre adjustments to the batting order have all been used to 'throw' matches, according to the Pakistan investigation into match-fixing.
fields.body:
Deliberate run-outs of team-mates, the intentional bowling of wides, byes and easy-to-hit bouncers, slowing down the run rate, and bizarre adjustments to the batting order are some of the methods cricketers have used to 'throw' matches, according to the investigation into match-fixing carried out by a judge in Pakistan.

The Observer has seen depositions to Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum, whose report is keenly awaited by the International Cricket Council. The leaked excerpts appear to confirm that match-fixing has been prevalent among Pakistan sides since 1994, and do not tally with the assessment of the chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board, Lieutenant General Tauqir Zia, that 'there has been no planned match-fixing found during the inquiry'.

There are tales of dressing-room fights prompted by arguments over bookies' money, of players declining to name names to the authorities because they feared for the safety of their families, and of the harassment of those players who declined to get involved. One senior figure, giving evidence in October 1998, said that there were only four Pakistan players 'whom I consider absolutely clean'. Another player, who cannot be named for legal reasons, says of another year, 'I can't disclose the names of the main culprits, though as a matter of fact the entire team is involved in match-fixing and betting except one player.'

Another player, now retired, recalls the 1994 tour of New Zealand by Pakistan and the final one-day international. He says that he was told 'we have to lose the match' as a deal had been struck. He goes on: 'I was offered thousands of dollars. I told him [a member of the team] I would think about it. There were also four or five other players and it was obvious that they must also have been offered money.' The next morning he was reprimanded when he took a catch and it was reiterated to him that 'we have to lose this match'. He had decided not to be party to match-fixing.

In that game, won by New Zealand by seven wickets, it is alleged that intentional wides were bowled. 'There was a threat of the match being washed out due to rain, which led the bowlers to bowl deliberately in a way that the scoring rate could be accelerated,' claims a player. He also alleges that two deliveries were deliberately bowled so wide that both resulted in four byes.

A prominent Pakistan official also says: 'I was absolutely sure that match-fixing and betting was going on in the Pakistan team.' He then outlines the problem of gaining concrete evidence from a certain player, who had verbally indicated that he had been asked by the twelfth man not to play well. 'I asked him to make the statement in writing. He promised to come over to me and do the needful. Later on he informed me that he could not do the needful as promised because his brother was threatened by dire consequences... if he delivered the statement in writing.'

Another leading Pakistani figure explains how, in 1994, 'I went to the Board... and said that stern action should be taken against the culprits even though other players might subsequently lose matches. In my opinion expediency came in the way of the administrators in imposing some punishment as at that time the Pakistan team was very strong and they did not want to disrupt it.' He confirmed the story of a paceman being paid by one of his colleagues to bowl badly.

A bookmaker says that 'most of the matches played by Pakistan and other teams are fixed' and reveals that two players 'had received $100,000 from me on behalf of someone for fixing a match in Sri Lanka. The amount was paid so that Pakistan should lose, which they did.'

Among the allegations there are instances of in-form batsmen being asked to retire hurt, of a stand-in captain being chastised for conjuring two quick wickets and of dressing-room fights on the notorious tour to South Africa and Zimbabwe in 1994-95. These are stories that are simultaneously riveting and infinitely depressing. Assuming these excerpts are in the ICC's version of the Qayyum Report there is a strong possibility that two Pakistan cricketers will be banned for life. If they are absent some serious questions may need to be asked of the Pakistan Cricket Board.

webTitle: Singalong Olonga tunes up for Lord's

fields.headline: Singalong Olonga tunes up for Lord's
fields.trailText: Jon Henderson talks to the affable and accessible Henry Olonga about music, art and the beginnings of his cricket career.
fields.body:
After more than a century, WG Grace is about to lose the distinction of having paraded the the most dramatic head of hair in a Lord's Test match. But the dreadlocked Zimbabwean Henry Olonga will leave unscathed WG's reputation as probably the most irascible cricketer to play at HQ.

It is hard not to make assumptions about a shock-haired fast bowler. In Olonga's case, though, you would almost certainly be wide of the mark. In fact I even found his easy charm and lack of menace a little disappointing. Take, for example, the explanation for how he keeps those dangling tresses a distinctive coppery colour: 'I bleach them with a home colouring kit that you can buy at any pharmacy.' Absentee doctor that he was, WG, you suspect, only went near a pharmacy in search of some substance with which to spike a rival fast bowler's refreshment.

But it would be wrong to give the impression that the affable, accessible Olonga, who has a confidence in his ability that even WG would have admired, is without an interesting hinterland. Quite the contrary.

Although numerous descriptions of him as an opera singer are fanciful, he did reveal a considerable singing talent at school, which he has had only limited opportunity to develop, but which he intends to exploit once his cricketing days are done. 'I have no extensive experience of singing since I left school,' he says, 'but I have developed my skill.' And how has he done that? 'Oh, singing in the shower,' he adds gleefully. 'I have improved immensely and it's mainly through listening to other musicians.' His taste is eclectic. He names R'n' B singers Eric Benet and Brian McKnight and, on the classical side, Andrea Bocelli and Roberto Alagna as among those he likes to copy.

He has not decided which direction he hopes his singing career will take, but he thinks he will probably move into the pop scene, preferably as a solo artist. 'The easiest thing to do is get a bunch of five guys who can hold a note, gather some really good songwriters together, get a nice beat - and you've got the newest pop sensation. Boy bands are easy to form and they're wonderful, but I think I can offer more than that.'

He is also artistic. 'Music is something I picked up,' he says. 'It wasn't a talent I knew I possessed. I just took it up and tried to do certain things and people said, "Hey, you sound good. Why don't you pursue it?" But art was always something I knew I could do from a young age; so I draw, I paint - oils, water-colours, pastels, you name it. I've always had an interest in it and always will have, but I wouldn't take it up as a career.'

And then there's his athletic prowess, beyond anything most cricketers possess. As a 16-year-old, he long-jumped 7.11 metres, ran a 10.6sec for the 100 metres and, as a senior, threw the javelin more than 60 metres. 'I could easily have pursued a career in athletics.'

But he chose cricket, and it is after fielding practice at Essex's Chelmsford ground last week that we sit and chat. He talks openly, except when I ask him how he feels about the situation in Zimbabwe - a banned topic, it turns out. Even so he is unable to resist saying something: 'I can't comment on the political side of things, but, if that's your question, I'll give you a simple answer: I feel tense, worried and not happy. But I think there are some positive things that will come out of it. I'll leave it at that.'

He also talks with a slightly mannered accent, the result possibly of being privately educated in Zimbabwe where he has lived for most of his 23 years, having been born in the Zambian capital, Lusaka, where his mother was a nurse and his father a doctor. Early on, the family moved to Kenya, but when his parents split up soon after that, his mother, a Zimbabwean, went to live in Bulawayo, which has been his home town since.

He became a cricketer at school, where he says his progress was steady rather than spectacular, although he remembers an eight-wicket haul against Brighton College, traditionally one of the stronger English school sides, when they visited in 1994. After school, he advanced rapidly, and in 1995 became the first black player to represent Zimbabwe after being picked for the opening Test against Pakistan. It proved a chastening experience.

On the third morning, Olonga was called for throwing by the home umpire Ian Robinson - England's Mervyn Kitchen was at the other end - and his future was put in doubt. 'I was a freshman, just out of school, keen to impress, wanting to bowl fast,' he says. 'Initially, it hit me with a sense of disbelief - shock, I suppose - and I guess at the time I had my various conspiracy theories. But when I eventually saw the videotape, I thought, "Well, OK, maybe there is a problem".'

Olonga reacted determinedly, travelling to Dennis Lillee's bowling academy in Madras the following month. 'Lillee was very supportive. He said, "You've got a problem - but don't worry, we'll sort it out." He felt I had a mixed action, somewhere between Sean Pollock, who's one of the better side-on bowlers, and Lance Klusener, who's totally chest-on, and not only would this make me prone to injury, but would account for my throwing the ball.

'He sensed that I was a natural front-on bowler who had been told to bowl side-on, and so he got me bowling chest-on. I've changed again slightly since then, but I'm still pretty much a chest-on bowler.'

With his new action, Olonga regained his place in the Zimbabwean side and has given some notable performances, including the four second-innings wickets that helped bowl Pakistan to defeat in the Test in Peshawar in November 1998, the three wickets in the penultimate over that gained a three-run win over India in last year's World Cup, and his six for 19 in a one-day international against England in Cape Town last January, which 'surpassed anything I expected I could do'.

And he thinks upsetting England again at Lord's is not beyond the team's capacity: 'We're becoming more and more efficient at getting into strong, winning positions, so I wouldn't rule out a Zimbabwean win.' That would be something to sing in the shower about.

But when I eventually saw the videotape, I thought, "Well, OK, maybe there is a problem".' Olonga reacted determinedly, travelling to Dennis Lillee's bowling academy in Madras the following month. 'Lillee was very supportive. He said, "You've got a problem - but don't worry, we'll sort it out." He felt I had a mixed action, somewhere between Sean Pollock, who's one of the better side-on bowlers, and Lance Klusener, who's totally chest-on, and not only would this make me prone to injury, but would account for my throwing the ball. 'He sensed that I was a natural front-on bowler who had been told to bowl side-on, and so he got me bowling chest-on. I've changed again slightly since then, but I'm still pretty much a chest-on bowler.' With his new action, Olonga regained his place in the Zimbabwean side and has given some notable performances, including the four second-innings wickets that helped bowl Pakistan to defeat in the Test in Peshawar in November 1998, the three wickets in the penultimate over that gained a three-run win over India in last year's World Cup, and his six for 19 in a one-day international against England in Cape Town last January, which 'surpassed anything I expected I could do'. And he thinks upsetting England again at Lord's is not beyond the team's capacity: 'We're becoming more and more efficient at getting into strong, winning positions, so I wouldn't rule out a Zimbabwean win.' webTitle: Prison is no cure for addicts

fields.headline: Prison is no cure for addicts
fields.trailText: It is encouraging that Nick Cohen reminds readers that Ruth Wyner and John Brock still languish in prison despite having committed no crime (Comment, last week). Cohen stresses the importance of safe disposal of needles, but it is also essential that injectors come to services they trust, for support.
fields.body:
It is encouraging that Nick Cohen reminds readers that Ruth Wyner and John Brock still languish in prison despite having committed no crime (Comment, last week). Cohen stresses the importance of safe disposal of needles, but it is also essential that injectors come to services they trust, for support.

Britain had an approach that kept HIV among drug users at one of the lowest levels in the world. There is a new global epidemic of Hepatitis C, a highly infectious, dangerous blood-transmitted virus, and already more than 600,000 people in the UK are infected.

The Department of Health denies the severity of the epidemic. After Wintercomfort, doors at treatment agencies are slamming. And the Government's policy for persistent addicts is prison, the setting where Hep C is most readily spread.

Lorraine Hewitt
South London and Maudsley NHS Trust
London SW9

fields.headline: Jolly dodger
fields.trailText: I seem to recall that, during the latter stages of the Major administration, whenever there were council or municipal elections and the Tories lost hundreds of seats, jolly Johnnie Prescott was to be seen time and again on all TV channels. Smiling broadly he happily explained, with absolute clarity and irrefutable logic, that the results meant the country was fed up with the Government and that the sooner the Prime Minister resigned the better.

fields.headline: Identifying a Spanish practice
fields.trailText: Readers of my piece about editing Kingsley Amis's letters (Review, last week) might like to know the meaning of the term 'watcher in Spanish', which I myself was unable to identify
fields.body:
Readers of my piece about editing Kingsley Amis's letters (Review, last week) might like to know the meaning of the term 'watcher in Spanish', which I myself was unable to identify. It comes from chapter two of Christopher Isherwood's 1938 novel Lions and Shadows , when Christopher and his friend Chalmers (Edward Upward) are Cambridge undergraduates: 'The Watcher in Spanish was the latest of our conceits. The phrase came, I believe, from a line in a poem about: "The watcher in Spanish cape ..." He appeared to us, we said, at moments when our behaviour was particularly insincere ... He made no gesture, never spoke. His mere presence was a sufficient reminder and a warning.' The phrase is thus analogous to 'inner audience' and 'reader over my shoulder', with which Amis groups it.


Zachary Leader
London EC1

webTitle: Who really suffers, men or women?

fields.headline: Who really suffers, men or women?
fields.trailText: I can only plead for the research cited in your report on 'moaning men' (News, last week) to be closely examined by other researchers to see if there is error in it, because if this kind of thinking catches on, men's health, which is already seriously neglected, will become even more so.
fields.body:
I can only plead for the research cited in your report on 'moaning men' (News, last week) to be closely examined by other researchers to see if there is error in it, because if this kind of thinking catches on, men's health, which is already seriously neglected, will become even more so.

Researchers in the past claimed that men wouldn't go to the doctors until the problem they were suffering from was so advanced that they were forced to go. This often resulted in men dying from diseases that could have been cured if they had been treated earlier. This reluctance of men to visit the doctor was claimed to be due to their 'macho' attitudes. (They were to blame for their own deaths.) In fact, a more likely reason for men not visiting the doctors was that often in the past it meant a loss of a day's pay. Furthermore, they may have preferred not to know about some condition that may to require them to take an easier but lower-paid job. As in many other areas of life, men's reluctance to visit their doctor could therefore be explained by the overriding drive in most men to protect their wife and children even from a reduction of income represented by the loss of a pay.

If men do make more of a fuss over their illnesses than women,(which I don't believe they do), then this would be justified by the fact that all the major diseases kill more men than women, and kill them younger. For instance, the vast majority of sudden deaths from heart disease under the age of 65 affect men.

Approximately 10 per cent of men will die from prostate cancer. About the same number of women die from breast cancer. A report I saw recently claimed that the Government gave £47,000 for research into prostate cancer and £8 million for research into breast cancer. It is claimed that prostate cancer is a disease of old age. Maybe so. Nevertheless, benign prostate disease affects 50 per cent of men aged 50. There's not even a meaningful education programme for benign prostate disease.

Men's suicide rate is four times that of women. They suffer more from alcoholism. They suffer more homelessness by far, which also leads to ill health.

Brian Abbott
Cork
Ireland

Thousands of women have a hysterectomy every year. For most of us this major and traumatic operation has been preceded by years of misery which we have been conditioned to put up with 'because it is our lot'. If the same number, one in six, of the male population had to face major surgery putting them out of action and effectively removing them from the workforce for weeks, the situation would be preoccupying the tabloids, attracting funding for major research programmes and taken seriously by politicians of all persuasions. Because it is women, we just suffer in silence

Dr Mary Joannou
Cambridge

fields.headline: Bombs away
fields.trailText: Further to article on mine clearing, DSL won fairly a Department for International Development-funded tender for landmine clearance in Kosovo. The tender was open to both non-governmental organisations and commercial companies.
fields.body:
Further to article on mine clearing, DSL won fairly a Department for International Development-funded tender for landmine clearance in Kosovo. The tender was open to both non-governmental organisations and commercial companies.

DSL is not in the business of supplying mercenaries, and never has been. DSL is a legitimate, successful and highly professional security risk management company whose clients number international corporations, diplomatic missions, including US and UK embassies, multilateral agencies and NGOs. DSL has been providing landmine clearance and other humanitarian services for aid agencies around the world since 1992.

Does the UK Working Group on Landmines and the Campaign Against the Arms Trade have a problem with commercial de-mining businesses per se ? If so, it is a peculiar stance: professional landmine clearance companies can field the technical and management expertise to deliver high standards of safety, quality and cost-effective use of donor funding. That is why the majority of de-mining work is carried out not by NGOs but sub-contracted to companies like DSL.


Nigel Woof
DSL/Armor Group
London
