webTitle: Sharp-dressed man ends up in rags

fields.headline: Sharp-dressed man ends up in rags
fields.trailText: There are Chelsea fans who, as this long long season finally draws to a close are, quite frankly, finding it very hard to stay awake.
fields.body:
Chelsea's game of the season might have been on Wednesday week in Paris in the final of the Champions League. It might have been at Highbury last Sunday with the Premiership being decided or, at the very least, a Champions League place established. Instead, it is at Wembley next Sunday when they will attempt to win a Uefa place and, by the by, the FA Cup.

New Chelsea fans won't be too concerned as they've already written out the cheques for next season's inflation-busting tickets. There are fans of longer standing who remember the '94 Final when Chelsea turned up at Wembley with a team which relied on Mark 'There's Only One Steeno' Stein for goals and Gavin 'The Rev' Peacock for inspiration. What a difference six years have made.

There have been disappointments, but any year in which you beat United 5-0 and go three up against Barcelona is an annus mirabilis.

Perhaps so, but United finished over 20 points ahead and Barcelona won. And there are other Chelsea fans who, as this long long season finally draws to a close are, quite frankly, finding it very hard to stay awake. They are exhausted by expectation. Dog-tired at having to listen to big talk and watch little defeats. Shattered by the draining experience of being a part of Vialli's huge gamble going horribly wrong.

For make no mistake, Vialli, the best-dressed man ever to lead out a team at Wembley, has taken a huge punt and is on the point of scrunching up the betting slip.

The team Luca built was founded on old legs and never likely to last beyond this season. Among the regulars only Flo, Morris and Babayaro would qualify for a Club 18-30 holiday and the last two would probably be turned away at the airport.

It is a one-season team on the point of disbandment with the players not going to Italy or Spain but Turkey and France and, in Di Matteo's case, Celtic. When it finally dawned that Sutton wasn't working, his replacement, Weah, was paraded as 'World Footballer of the Year makes obvious choice and joins Chelsea'. In fact, 'the Big Librarian' couldn't believe he'd found anyone prepared to throw so much good money after bad. And on arriving announced he preferred to play with... Sutton.

There's no coming back from that. It's time to rip up the team sheet and start all over again.

fields.headline: Hick climbs the run chart
fields.trailText: Graeme Hick moved up to fifteenth place on the all-time list of century makers with an unbeaten 115 from 106 balls in Worcestershire's seven-wicket win against Middlesex at New Road.
fields.body:
Graeme Hick moved up to fifteenth place on the all-time list of century makers with an unbeaten 115 from 106 balls in Worcestershire's seven-wicket win against Middlesex at New Road.

The England batsman's 109th hundred in first-class cricket took him clear of former Pakistan star Zaheer Abbas and his next target are two of Wisden's five cricketers of the Twentieth century.

West Indies legend Sir Viv Richards is only five ahead and the peerless Australian Sir Donald Bradman, on 117, could come within range by next year.

Hick's latest masterpiece was a suitable way of celebrating conformation of his latest recall to Test cricket for this week's first Test with Zimbabwe at Lord's.

Hick said: 'After I had been out there for 10 or 15 minutes things fell into place and I felt good for the rest of the innings.'

Worcestershire began the third day at 50 for one, needing a further 111 for their first Championship win in the new Second Division, but this was no formality on a troublesome pitch.

There was an early set-back when Elliott Wilson, himself a century-maker in the first innings, was caught at first slip off Richard Johnson without adding to his overnight 19.

Hick's response was clinical. He rose onto his toes to force Angus Fraser through cover for two fours and soon afterwards he pulled the England seamer for two more boundaries.

Hick's century was posted in 102 balls before Vikram Solanki, who was the junior partner in a 97-run partnership with Hick, shuffled off, a second victim at first slip for Justin Langer to give Fraser a match return of five for 59.

Middlesex called up off-spinner Paul Weekes and the match was over in three blows.

Hick then marched off with 88 of his runs in boundaries, 19 fours and two sixes in an unbeaten 115, and a healthy aggregate of 195 for two dismissals in his three Championship innings this season.

webTitle: Labour U-turn sparks revolt over Chief Whip

fields.headline: Labour U-turn sparks revolt over Chief Whip
fields.trailText: The Labour Chief Whip at Holyrood, Tom McCabe, is facing a revolt from furious backbenchers who blame him for a series of last-minute policy changes. MSPs say they can no longer trust him after what they see as an inept U-turn last week on Section 28.
fields.body:
The Labour Chief Whip at Holyrood, Tom McCabe, is facing a revolt from furious backbenchers who blame him for a series of last-minute policy changes. MSPs say they can no longer trust him after what they see as an inept U-turn last week on Section 28.

The Scottish Executive capitulated to pressure and announced that sex education guidance for teachers would be given statutory backing - after months when Ministers had dismissed this as 'stupid and opportunistic'.

Backbenchers, who first learnt of the policy reversal from the media, say the episode is the latest in a year-long list of surprise changes of policy and a general lack of information about the Executive's intentions.

'This is another instance when McCabe has dropped us in it,' one Labour MSP told the Observer . Backbenchers already blame McCabe for last month's fiasco when rebellious MSPs eventually forced the Executive to drop their opposition to Scottish Socialist Party MSP Tommy Sheridan's Bill calling for abolition of warrant sales. Last week McCabe further damaged his standing with a suggestion, aided by the SNP's Mike Russell, that the number of Holyrood committees might be cut.

Senior Ministers have dismissed the criticism as unfair. One described McCabe as 'the best friend backbenchers have'. In some ways this is a clash between Old and New Labour. McCabe is the archetypal Old Labour fixer and, as former head of South Lanarkshire council, is well versed in the arts of persuasion.

The council's Labour group used to have 'pre-meetings' before each committee met to ensure the desired conclusion was reached. His Cabinet colleague, Finance Minister Jack McConnell, has a similar approach. Both men were stung by the warrant sales vote a fortnight ago, when Labour MSPs refused to obey McCabe's whip and derail Sheridan's call for the system to abolished.

As fixers, however, they have been painfully aware of the growing pressure from socially conservative party members in the West of Scotland for the Section 28 policy to be watered down. Muslims and Christians were muttering about de-selecting sitting MSPs unless concessions were made.

The moves began a week last Thursday when Tom McCabe contacted the SNP's Russell, requesting a meeting. That much was normal: the two men represent their parties on the Bureau, which decides the Parliament's business. What was unusual was McCabe's request for Nicola Sturgeon, the SNP's education spokeswoman, to attend. Party spokespeople never attend Bureau meetings, but Sam Galbraith, the Education Minister, was also there.

The SNP members were told that Labour wanted to do a deal on Section 28, and table an amendment along the lines the Nationalists had been suggesting for months.

Russell and Sturgeon agreed to help, and McCabe and Galbraith went off to draft the new wording. The Nationalists were cock-a-hoop.

The following Monday Sturgeon read the proposed amendment, and pledged SNP support. McCabe sold it to the Tuesday Executive meeting as a compromise that would ensure a landslide vote for abolishing Section 28.

Labour's coalition partners, the Liberal Democrats, reluctantly backed it, too. They felt they should be supportive while their leader, Jim Wallace, was acting First Minister during Donald Dewar's illness.

The Labour group lacked even the luxury of discussing the matter beforehand. The party's MSPs were never warned of the change by their party. The group includes many political novices who, as they gain experience, are less willing to change positions to suit the Executive.

But, as last week showed, they are often the last to know what is going on.

webTitle: Juve's top official branded by critics

fields.headline: Juve's top official branded by critics
fields.standfirst: General manager Luciano Moggi under fire in latest scandal, reports  Simon Evans
fields.trailText: The stench enveloping Italian football in the wake of Juventus's controversial victory over Parma has prompted an investigation into events before and after the game by Turin's public magistratel, reports Simon Evans.
fields.body:
The stench enveloping Italian football in the wake of Juventus's controversial victory over Parma has prompted an investigation into events before and after the game by Turin's public magistrate.

Since Fabio Cannavaro's last-minute header for Parma was inexplicably disallowed by referee Massimo De Santis, giving Juve a 1-0 win last Sunday, Italy has been swept by an extraordinary tidal wave of anti-Juve sentiment. There have been death threats against the referee's family, violent street protests in Rome and the president of the Italian FA has said he may look to bring in foreign match officials next season.

No one has made an outright claim that Juve have broken any law, but it has been a close-run thing. And one of their top men, general manager Luciano Moggi, is the target for vitriolic criticism because of the power he allegedly wields over Italian football. More of him later.

Juve should claim their 26th Serie A title in today's last round with a win at Perugia but if there is an ounce of sense left in Italian football their celebrations will be muted.

The feelings are strongest in Rome, where Lazio are left two points behind the Turin club thanks to referee De Santis's decision. Midweek street protests are forecast to continue today with two major events - the Giro d'Italia cycle race and the Italian Open tennis finals - braced for violence. Lazio are hosting Reggina just a few hundred yards from the Foro Italico tennis complex.

One of the leaders of Lazio's hard-line 'ultras' fans, Fabio Piscitelli, said today's demonstrations would include a 'funeral' of Italian soccer, with a real coffin in Rome's Piazzale Flaminio. Fans will then enter the stadium for Lazio's match 15 minutes late.

Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti claimed: 'This championship is losing credibility. I can't invest millions in this club and then find we are in this unclear situation.'

Had the goal stood, and the game ended in a 1-1 draw, Lazio and Juve would have gone into today's games level on points and with a title play-off almost certain (goal difference is not a factor in Serie A ). 'Sorry, but this is a scandal' was the front-page headline in Rome's Corriere dello Sport the day after the match, probably the mildest comment on its pages this week.

Within half an hour of the game ending De Santis had explained his decision to annul Cannavaro's goal to a reporter. He claimed to have blown the whistle before the Parma defender headed the ball goalwards, having spotted some pushing as Marcio Amoroso's corner came over. When Cannavaro himself appeared in front of the press, his reaction was the same as in the moments after the whistle blew - he was just laughing.

Television replays clearly showed he had whistled after Cannavaro connected with the ball - and that there was no foul to be seen. From early Sunday evening to past midnight on Monday there are shows that contain nothing other than action replays of controversial incidents, scrutinised by a panel of journalists. Not one of the judges in these self-styled 'courts of calcio' was able to find a reason why the goal was disallowed.

It is not the first time Juventus are in sight of a title that few but their own fans feel they deserve. In Florence they still rage over the 1982 season when Fiorentina were pipped to the title by Juve on the final day thanks to dubious refereeing which favoured Juve and punished Fiorentina.

More recently, during what Italians call 'the season of poison' two years ago, Juve were neck and neck with Inter. Juve won 1-0 at Empoli, who were denied an equaliser when the ball clearly crossed the line. A week later Juve beat Inter 1-0 at the Delle Alpi but Inter had a clear penalty turned down, leaving their president, Massimo Moratti, claiming Juventus have a psychological grip over referees.

'Referees don't do this on purpose; it's a habit. They are afraid of hurting Juventus. It is the rule not the exception,' said Moratti at the time.

The veteran Lazio striker Roberto Mancini went closest to suggesting foul play when he claimed the last nine championships had been rigged. 'The last fair championship was won in 1991 by Sampdoria. Since then Juventus and Milan have shared the titles between them and have never fought each other for the championship.'

Such sentiments are not hard to find in Italy.

'These accusations, which have no proof attached to them and which continue to be hurled at the club, are intolerable,' says Juventus club secretary Antonio Giraudo, the only man at the club who has been allowed to speak in public since Sunday.

'In no other foreign country is one episode seen as more important while all others are forgotten. No one accuses Real Madrid, Barcelona, Ajax, Manchester United or Bayern of having won by foul play.'

Fair comment. But why is there always an air of suspicion around Juventus whenever a mistake is made in their favour? The most com mon explanation is Moratti's argument that referees are conditioned to be afraid of Juventus and their decisions reflect that fear. Others hint at the power of Juve's owners the Agnelli family, owners of the Fiat group and Italy's unofficial royal family.

But some suggest darker forces. The Roma president Franco Sensi, the most outspoken critic of northern domination of Italian football, points the finger firmly at the Juventus general manager Luciano Moggi. He said: 'Why do the Rome teams find it difficult to win the title? Ask Moggi. It will be this way until Moggi isn't against us. It is not enough to invest millions to win.'

Moggi is officially in charge of Juventus's transfer policy and the general management of team affairs. In reality his role at Juventus and in Italian football is far greater. After 20 years working for the state railway company, he began his career in football as a youth scout for Juventus and worked his way up the ladder with spells in administration at Roma, Torino and Napoli before returning to Juve in his current role. He is known as the 'king of the transfer market' and together with his son Alessandro, one of the leading players' agents in Italy, is reported to have 250 players within his sphere.

When lower division Italian clubs gather in a Milan hotel twice a year to trade players, Moggi is one of the few representatives of a Serie A club to bother turning out, wheeling and dealing, and building his links with club officials from Serie B and C . A recent report claimed Moggi's network included at least 18 lower division clubs as well as five 'friendly' clubs in Serie A .

Before he moved to Juventus he worked at Torino with Luciano Nizzola and helped Nizzola to be elected president of the Italian FA in 1996. When that link was raised this week, Nizzola flew off the handle. 'We are just friends. When we meet we don't even talk about football,' he replied. But to many, Nizzola is seen as Moggi's man.

Some believe he has the power to end careers. Former Fiorentina coach Giancarlo De Sisti believes that he has been out of work for eight years because of Moggi: 'I had some conflicts with the president of the club. He was a friend of Moggi's.'

Di Sisti then criticised Moggi in the press. 'I can't prove anything but I haven't found work since then,' he says.

Such power is reminiscent of the late Italo Allodi, who was considered the most potent man in Italian football three decades ago. Allodi, frequently accused of match- rigging but never found guilty, recruited Moggi at Juventus. Like Moggi, Allodi, who worked for Inter before moving to Juventus, had a wide network of allies that spread far beyond his own club. Like Moggi, Allodi was the man people blamed when something suspicious happened with referees. And like Moggi, Allodi appeared to revel in his shadowy reputation.

Moggi does little to discourage the mystique that surrounds him. Asked if Italian football was suffering because of suspicions that his power and influence was too great he replied with a Chinese proverb: 'If your shoe is unlaced, watch out when you bend down to lace it in a field of melons. Those that see you could misunderstand you.' That's cleared it all up then.

fields.headline: Aussie tests on 'Paine's skull'
fields.trailText: Did the mortal remains of eighteenth-century radical Tom Paine end up in Australia? DNA identification of a skull which turned up in the late Eighties may solve the historical riddle once and for all. A report in the first edition of the BBC's new  History magazine will reveal that a professor at Sydney University, who claims to be a descendant of the political thinker, believes Paine's skull ended up in Sydney.
fields.body:
Did the mortal remains of eighteenth-century radical Tom Paine end up in Australia? DNA identification of a skull which turned up in the late Eighties may solve the historical riddle once and for all. A report in the first edition of the BBC's new History magazine will reveal that a professor at Sydney University, who claims to be a descendant of the political thinker, believes Paine's skull ended up in Sydney.

Paine, who wrote The Rights of Man , was born in Thetford, Norfolk, and lived in Lewes in East Sussex but, after time spent in Europe, he died in 1809 on a farm in New Rochelle, America.

And there his remains would have stayed if another influential British political theorist, William Cobbett, had not travelled to his graveside 10 years later with the purpose of digging up Paine's remains and bringing them back to England, where they would be reburied with due ceremony and marked with a monument.

The plan came to nothing and the body went missing. Historians believe the skull may then have fallen into the hands of an Australian antiquarian who was visiting London and took the gruesome booty back home.

Stored in a leather pouch and marked with the copperplate inscription Thos Paine, the skull was bought at a Sydney auction in 1988 by John Burgess, an academic from New South Wales who is convinced that he is a a descendant. Burgess and his wife, Hazel, have spent the past few years visiting sites related to the life of Paine in both England and the United States - the latter a name coined by Paine.

Burgess believes that Paine, a republican who helped to shape the course of both the French and American revolutions, is an ancestor although there is no official record that he ever fathered a child. A tradition has persisted that in 1797 Paine's lover, Marguerite de Bonneville, gave birth to his child. Burgess hopes his colleagues at Sydney University will be able to establish the identity of the skull as well as determining whether he is a direct descendant. He also believes the new process will break ground in molecular genealogy research.

DNA has already been extracted from the skull by Tom Loy, best known for his work on the ice-man recently discovered in the Alps.

webTitle: The Cup Final made for history

fields.headline: The Cup Final made for history
fields.standfirst: Paul Wilson  on a key day for football under the twin towers
fields.trailText: For the first time in ages it looks like being an open contest between two sides who have not won anything else all season and would be grateful for the glory of a Wembley triumph.
fields.body:
With a bit of luck, the first FA Cup final of the third millennium might come to be remembered for more than just the absence of Manchester United.

For the first time in ages, for a start, it looks like being an open contest between two sides who have not won anything else all season and would be grateful for the glory of a Wembley triumph as well as its passage to Europe. Chelsea and Aston Villa are side by side at the top end of the table, separated by just four points, and it is genuinely difficult to guess who will win on the day. On paper Chelsea appear to possess the class and experience to outplay Villa, but these days you never quite know which Chelsea will turn up. Villa, in their first FA Cup final for 43 years and fully conversant with how much these occasions mean to supporters, could easily be the more motivated.

Which brings us neatly to the other reason why the 2000 FA Cup final might go down in history. It may come to be regarded as the high-water mark, the text book reference point in the debate about foreign players in the English game, especially if Villa happen to win.

There is a neat symmetry about these two teams contesting the definitive English football fixture at the soon to be demolished Wembley. Just over a year ago Villa were making a stand as the last English team in the Premiership, and although George Boateng and Benito Carbone have since been added to the mix they still field a higher quotient of native players than most of their rivals. Chelsea, you will recall, this season became the first club to field a wholly foreign side in a Premiership fixture, an alarm call to English football if you like but an experiment, surely, which not even Gianluca Vialli will be repeating now that Didier Deschamps and Frank Leboeuf are looking longingly at Champions League opportunities on offer elsewhere. 'There is nothing wrong with signing English players, I will be looking to sign more in the future,' Vialli said in one of the season's most memorable quotes. 'They speak the language and they know what to expect at places like Everton and Sheffield Wednesday.'

Vialli himself has picked up the language admirably, despite appearing to have enrolled by mistake on Sybil Fawlty's correspondence course in the bleedin' obvious. Practically anyone who has watched more than 10 minutes of Match of the Day could have told him that the collection of talented but cosseted players he was assembling at such expense would blow up over the course of an English season, but Vialli affects a mild surprise at the under-achievement of finishing outside the top three. It makes you wonder how much longer Chelsea will continue to back his judgment in other areas. A return to Sampdoria is being suggested for the near future, in which case it will be interesting to see whether Vialli deems it necessary to justify the wisdom of signing Italian players.

Where Vialli is going to begin looking for his English players is another question. Paying £10 million for Chris Sutton was considered a bold move at the time, but so was the Ancient Mariner's shooting of the albatross. There are fewer and fewer big money transfers of English players between English clubs going through each year, and if Chelsea are going to start scouring the lower leagues or developing their own talent then they no longer need a manager like Vialli.

Like Ruud Gullit before him, Vialli's big advantage to Chelsea has been his continental contacts and his standing in the international game. Employ a highly respected, hugely popular figurehead like that and in no time at all you've got a team full of World Cup winners and Champions League regulars. Fine if you can afford it, not so fine if your best players want to opt out of the domestic treadmill and only play in the glamour fixtures. Even worse if they don't manage to win the glamour fixtures, so that there are none to look forward to next season.

The English season was already too much of a tread mill - too many clubs, too many games, at least one too many cup competitions - before the expanded Champions League made life almost intolerable for leading sides. It is difficult to keep going, as even Manchester United discovered this year, and one can readily understand foreign players used to a less stressful existence not fancying a trip to Sunderland on a wet Wednesday night. Probably not many of Aston Villa's players are up for every game of the season either.

Chelsea now seem to be admitting what they should have known from the start, that you can't bypass the Premiership and take a short cut to the Champions League. The fact that leading continental players are exploiting their post-Bosman freedoms to move around Europe and play Champions League football every year does not mean clubs can do the same. Perhaps Chelsea were never going to win the Champions League with their team of elderly cast-offs, but one could hardly say the same of Barcelona, who threw everything at Europe and lasted just one round longer. Clubs gambling on Champions League revenue and success is arguably the most insidious effect of allowing two or three teams per country to enter each year. The old system, whereby you had to win your league to get in, at least kept everyone on the straight and narrow.

Apart from the considerable risk of failure and financial overstretch, the trouble with English teams gearing up for Europe at the expense of the Premiership is that it is unfair on the paying customers. Yes, the fans enjoy adventures in Europe, but no, they don't see why they should have to put up with second rate stuff on Saturdays for the privilege. Even the patience of Manchester United fans is wearing thin when they travel such a long way and pay good money to see watered down sides in less demanding Premiership fixtures, but the one thing you can say about Sir Alex Fergu son's rotational system is that he makes it work. United do not take many risks or drop many points in the Premiership, and though the club accountants might put up with it, their manager would not be a happy man if his team were champions of Europe but not of their own backyard.

The bottom line is that the English fan buys his season ticket, first and foremost, to see his team do well in the English league. If foreign players can help towards that objective, welcome aboard. If they cannot, if they find it easier to express themselves in the Champions League or find the Premiership too violent, what is the point in paying a king's ransom for them? Especially if they are going to tout themselves to other clubs in Cup final week, as Messrs Deschamps and Leboeuf have been doing. That undignified spectacle alone will have most neutrals rooting for Villa on Saturday, and should John Gregory's side manage to strike a blow for the solid values of coaching and commitment over the blue flag of cosmopolitan convenience, English football might never be quite the same again.

Yes, the fans enjoy adventures in Europe, but no, they don't see why they should have to put up with second rate stuff on Saturdays for the privilege. Even the patience of Manchester United fans is wearing thin when they travel such a long way and pay good money to see watered down sides in less demanding Premiership fixtures, but the one thing you can say about Sir Alex Fergu son's rotational system is that he makes it work. United do not take many risks or drop many points in the Premiership, and though the club accountants might put up with it, their manager would not be a happy man if his team were champions of Europe but not of their own backyard. The bottom line is that the English fan buys his season ticket, first and foremost, to see his team do well in the English league. If foreign players can help towards that objective, welcome aboard. If they cannot, if they find it easier to express themselves in the Champions League or find the Premiership too violent, what is the point in paying a king's ransom for them? Especially if they are going to tout themselves to other clubs in Cup final week, as Messrs Deschamps and Leboeuf have been doing. That undignified spectacle alone will have most neutrals rooting for Villa on Saturday, and should John Gregory's side manage to strike a blow for the solid values of coaching and commitment over the blue flag of cosmopolitan convenience, English football might never be quite the same again. webTitle: Archbishop's angst as big-spending Seville pair suffer

fields.headline: Archbishop's angst as big-spending Seville pair suffer
fields.trailText: Forget the Spanish teams fighting for the Champions League - the bottom of Spain's premier division is much more fun, says Simon Kuper.
fields.body:
Forget the Spanish teams fighting for the Champions League - the bottom of Spain's premier division is much more fun. Take the match at Sevilla a fortnight ago, when the home side, already relegated, faced Oviedo. The visitors were themselves fighting relegation, and it just so happened that their chief rivals were Betis, the other team in Seville.

Fans of Sevilla despise Betis. So in the days before the game Sevilla players were told by neighbours and friends to lose against Oviedo, in order to send Betis down. 'If we beat Oviedo, the fans will kill us,' concluded the Sevilla midfielder Francisco Lama.

Sevilla lost. They went 3-0 down, each away goal being applauded by the home fans, then came back to 2-3, and finally, to avoid an accidental equaliser, whiled away time by pushing the ball around at the halfway line. A league commission acquitted Sevilla of a fix, saying that there was no evidence. Sevilla had made basic defensive errors, but then they usually did.

It was hard for Betis to be angry. Three years before, urged on by their fans, Betis had themselves deliberately lost a home match to Gijon to send Sevilla down. Lama says: 'Football is like life: what goes around comes around.'

Now Betis seem set to go down with Sevilla. 'How is this possible?' asked Seville's archbishop, Carlos Amigo. 'It's terrible because sporting issues directly involve people in the city's daily life, and affect a lot of people.'

Indeed, Betis and Sevilla are very popular clubs. Each has the support and spending power of, say, Arsenal or Spurs. The Betis attack fea tures the Brazilian Denilson (bought for £23 million), Alfonso and Finidi George. Yet neither Betis nor Sevilla is as big as the third Spanish side for the drop.

Atletico Madrid have been in the top division since 1934, won the Spanish double only four years ago, and have a squad packed with internationals.

When Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink joined them from Leeds last summer for £12 million, he said: 'They have brought in a very good coach in Claudio Ranieri, they have spent a lot on players, they are going for a Champions League place, and they wanted me.'

Hasselbaink has scored 24 league goals, but everything else has gone wrong, down to a plague of pigeons who pecked the grass in the stadium and damaged the pitch.

Ranieri is long gone, and prosecutors are demanding that Jesus Gil y Gil, Atletico's crazed owner, be jailed for 34 years, banned from public office for 121 years (some think it should be longer), and pay a £7 million fine for fraud. Gil is suspected of making £35 million disappear. It's a good thing he took out insurance against relegation, or Atletico could really be in trouble.

There are many men like Gil in the Spanish game: Caudillos, or leaders, who run their clubs as if they were fascist states. Most Caudillos made their money in property, usually under the rule of General Franco, their role model.

The most prominent Caudillos are the property magnates Josep Lluis Nunez, president of Barcelona, and Lorenzo Sanz, who runs Real Madrid. But they get everywhere: Manuel Ruiz de Lopera, the property magnate who owns Betis, has named the club's ground the Ruiz de Lopera stadium.

The Caudillo way of running a football club is not what they teach you at Harvard Business School. Firstly, they enjoy incurring debts entirely out of proportion to expected income. Atletico are the second most indebted club in Madrid. First is Real Madrid, who owe well over £100 million, and often make players wait months for their salary.

Secondly Caudillos love buying centre-forwards. Gil signed Hasselbaink, Betis spent so much on strikers that they left themselves with a defence worthy of Chester City, while Sanz paid £24 million for Nicolas Anelka even though John Toshack, the then Real manager, had asked for a keeper and a centre-back. The Caudillo fetish for centre-forwards is the equivalent of Franco's urge to build concrete monuments all over the country instead of feeding people.

The other Caudillo habit is sacking managers. Gil at Atletico and Ruiz de Lopera at Betis average about one sacking every three months, while Sanz at Real is not far behind. He fired Jupp Heynckes after the Champions League triumph in 1998, and this year Vicente del Bosque could suffer the same fate.

Plainly, being a Caudillo doesn't work. The most successful Spanish club of recent times are Barcelona, where Nunez has suppressed his Caudillo instincts and used just three managers in 12 years. At Valencia, president Pedro Cortés has bought good defenders, stuck by coach Héctor Cúper after some early defeats, and now finds his club in the Champions League final.

But Caudillos have more fun.

fields.headline: Let us travel
fields.trailText: Jeremy Harding (Comment extra, last week) puts a human face to illegal immigration and gives voice to thousands of people in desperate situations. As a Turkish Cypriot I am often faced with visa rejections from European Union and other countries, even as a tourist. Denying any human being the experience of the historical, cultural and linguistic wealth of this world is not just and should not be justified on political grounds.

fields.headline: Football on Channel 4? Sweet FA
fields.trailText: Jon Henderson on Channel 4's desertion of the football scene after the broadcaster's last-minute withdrawal from the TV bidding process.
fields.body:
The Football Association have suffered a blow to their hopes of getting some live international football on terrestrial television with Channel 4's last-minute withdrawal from the bidding process.

The FA, who are keen that not all the live rights to international matches should go to subscription television, were expecting Channel 4 to put in a vigorous bid.

But Channel 4, who were indeed poised to come in with a substantial offer after working on the details of one for months, got an acute attack of frostbite when it came to making a final decision. 'In the end, the money was just too much for them,' one insider said.

With Channel 5 lining up a bid for live Football League coverage, the BBC looking after their pennies so they can save Match of the Day for a grateful nation and ITV being plentifully supplied through the Champions League, Channel 4's deserting the scene leaves live international football at the mercy of pay television, however much the FA may want to offer some of it to a free-to-air broadcaster.

But the FA remain upbeat about the sale of their rights, which also include the FA Cup and women's football. One source described the response, after last week's deadline for bids, as very good.

Channel 4'3 desertion of the football scene contrasts with their commitment to cricket following their excellent, award-winning first season in 1999.

They seriously considered recalling Geoff Boycott to the television commentary box, starting with Thursday's first Test against Zimbabwe. 'We talked about going back to Geoffrey, but felt the whole emphasis of our coverage was moving the thing forward,' said a spokesman. 'He's a great commentator, there's no question of that, but we felt it would be a backward step.' Instead they have gone for Michael Slater, the Australian batsman with an English heritage, who is described by those who have seen him on Australia's Channel 9 as 'a natural'.

On the production side, Channel 4 will concentrate on improving last season's innovations, notably the already legendary Snickometer and the Red Zone, the device for judging lbw decisions.

The Snickometer, exported to Australia, India and Sharjah with huge success, is now fully digitised, which means it can be used far more quickly than in its debut season.

This column really goes through the hoops to keep you up-to-date with the TV scene. Last Thursday it was off to The Escape nightclub in downtown Amsterdam for the launch of Eurosport's Euro 2000 coverage.

The venue was not quite as incongruous as it might seem, with Eurosport's round-the-clock coverage of this summer's tournament going to include a post-midnight NightClub slot for the continent's football-nut insomniacs.

A feature of the NightClub will be viewers exchanging opinions through Eurosport's website and even choosing the content of the programme, including which matches should be rerun.

It is an enterprising effort by the pan-European satellite operation, which cannot hope to compete with most national broadcasters when it comes to live match coverage.

webTitle: Bradford hopeful as Fowler is dropped

fields.headline: Bradford hopeful as Fowler is dropped
fields.trailText: David Hills previews today's Premiership matches.
fields.body:
Bradford manager Paul Jewell was cheered last night by the news that Liverpool have dropped striker Robbie Fowler ahead of today's crucial match at Bradford. Gérard Houllier's decision, a surprise to Anfield insiders, has prompted fresh speculation of a £12m summer move for Fowler to Old Trafford.

Both sides need to win a game that has become the focus of today's Premiership's finale. Liverpool are chasing Champions League qualification, while Bradford's result must be better than Wimbledon's at Southampton if they are to survive. 'If I get two hours' sleep these days I feel guilty,' says Paul Jewell. 'But you just have to cope. The players all know what's at stake.'

Jewell could be without Peter Beagrie and Wayne Jacobs, while Michael Owen, Dietmar Hamann and Steven Gerrard return for Liverpool.

Wimbledon, on the back of eight defeats and a draw in the last nine games, could be playing for their future: relegation, it emerged last night, could have implications for their prospects of remaining tenants at Selhurst Park. If they don't win - and they are without the suspended John Hartson - Bradford only need a point. Carl Cort, recalled by the England U21s yesterday, should lead the line. Both games will be televised simultaneously by Sky.

Elsewhere, Darren Fletcher's hopes of becoming Manchester United's youngest debutant for 44 years have been dashed by red tape. Fletcher - at 16 years and 103 days - would have been the youngest since David Gaskell, who played as a substitute in the 1956 Charity Shield at the age of 16 years, 19 days. However, schoolboy status means Fletcher won't now be among the United kids on show at Villa Park. Several first-team regulars will also be missing as United look to break the Premiership points record. Roy Keane, Gary Neville, Mark Bosnich and Andy Cole are all injured, Nicky Butt is suspended and David Beckham is shopping in California.

Arsenal are also set for a reshuffle: Arsène Wenger plans to use Paolo Vernazza and Stefan Malz, and rest Emmanuel Petit away at Newcastle.

Coventry, meanwhile, are looking for their first away win of the season at Watford.

webTitle: Whitehall kept watch on fortune-tellers of war

fields.headline: Whitehall kept watch on fortune-tellers of war
fields.trailText: As the moon approaches Saturn, your love life will face a period of turmoil and your career prospects will suffer a severe a setback. Money worries come to the fore as enemies appear to prosper at your expense. Oh, and Germany will invade Greece.
fields.body:
As the moon approaches Saturn, your love life will face a period of turmoil and your career prospects will suffer a severe a setback. Money worries come to the fore as enemies appear to prosper at your expense. Oh, and Germany will invade Greece.

Ministers in Winston Churchill's War Cabinet were so worried about the impact on public morale of newspaper astrologers that they considered outlawing them. Such portents could be desperately worrying for the wife of a soldier on the front line during the Second World War, they believed.

Their concerns are revealed in declassified government documents from the Public Records Office. Minutes of the War Cabinet's Civil Defence Committee, dated 7 January 1942 and titled 'Astrology and the Press', state: 'The Financial Secretary to the Treasury [Viscount Crookshank] expressed concern at the popularity of contributions by so-called astrologers writing in the Press and particularly in the Sunday Press.

'He believed that the illusions disseminated in this way had a harmful effect on public morale and on the war effort. He suggested strong action should be taken to put a stop to this form of journalism.'

Following discussion it was pointed out that the 'popularity of these contributors depended not on the general level of accuracy which they maintained but on the one or two sensational instances in which their forecasts have been verified by events'.

The committee came under the control of Peter Mandelson's grandfather, Herbert Morrison, who was Home Secretary and Minister for Home Security during the war.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Information was asked to prepare a report on the effect 'of this form of journalism on the public mind'.

The minutes, unearthed by historian Dr A. D. Harvey, conclude: 'It would be of interest also if the figures could be given showing the percentage of instances in which the forecasts of the various prophets had been justified by events.'

Just over two weeks later, the Ministry of Information responded. The Parliamentary Secretary stated that an extensive investigation was carried out in July 1941. According to this report, about two-thirds of the adult population read astrological columns, although only four out of 10 gave them any credence. At most, 'one in 10, and probably of a neurotic type, make astrology a major interest in their lives and allow it to play some part in forming their conduct'.

The report found no evidence that the more fantastic advice such as 'that the public should shelter in hollows in the ground instead of air-raid shelters' was ever followed.

The report published a table of the four best-known Sunday astrologers and whether or not their predictions had proved correct on various issues, including the outbreak of war, the invasion of Norway, the collapse of France and the British offensive in Libya. Nearly all the astrologers correctly predicted the last. The most accurate was R. H. Naylor of the Sunday Express, who sprang to fame by correctly predicting the 1937 Hindenburg airship explosion. He predicted the German invasions of Norway, Greece and Crete. Sir Arthur 'Bomber' Harris is believed to have taken his advice before launching bombing missions over Germany.

The Great Lyndoe of The People and Petulengro of the Sunday Chronicle both predicted Germany's invasion of Russia, but none of the famed astrologers predicted the outbreak of war.

Nick Campian, a former astrologer at the Daily Mail who is an astrological historian, says these documents prove how seriously astrology was taken during the war. 'It was widely thought that Hitler used astrology, and the British Army used Hungarian astrologist Louis de Wohl to give them advice.'

The Ministry of Information report concluded: 'It would appear, therefore, that the astrologers have a considerable amusement value, but otherwise exert very little influence on the public, except in the case of neurotic individuals, for whom they supply a relatively harmless prop.'

fields.headline: 'Incompetent' murder case police accused
fields.standfirst: Officers named in Internet campaign for justice over graveyard stabbing of teen mother, writes  Tony Thompson
fields.trailText: Campaigners are using fly posters and the Internet in an attempt to secure justice for the family of a teenager brutally murdered nearly four years ago.
fields.body:
Campaigners are using fly posters and the Internet in an attempt to secure justice for the family of a teenager brutally murdered nearly four years ago.

Katrina Taylor, 19, was found stabbed to death in a Brighton graveyard in July 1996. Despite two Crown Court trials, no one has been found guilty of her murder. Campaigners believe this is a result of the failure of the local force to investigate the crime properly and are demanding a full investigation by the Police Complaints Authority. They have distributed a list of Sussex officers who are accused of varying degrees of incompetence, from allegedly failing to take statements from key witnesses to not responding to tips about the whereabouts of the accused.

Taylor herself had taken part in a police murder reconstruction in 1986 posing as nine-year-old 'Babe in the Wood' Nicola Fellows, who had been strangled in a Brighton park. Ten years on she was struggling to bring up her baby daughter and fund her heroin habit. In May 1996 she acted as a lookout to a break-in at a flat owned by Neshia Williams, a petty criminal and girlfriend of a drug dealer.

When the intruders tried to steal the washing machine they accidentally flooded the house and set fire to the furniture. Williams began tracking down who was responsible, along with her brother, Simon, her boyfriend Trevor Smith and his flatmate Fergal Scollan. One of the intruders was beaten and stabbed in the leg with a screwdriver.

Taylor was spotted one afternoon outside a hotel by Simon Williams. In the run-up to the subsequent court case the manageress gave a statement saying Williams had dragged the screaming Taylor into his car, but in court she said Taylor had gone willingly - one of a number of conflicting reports. Taylor was taken to a flat where later that evening, Neshia Williams, Scollan and Smith all arrived to see her.

At 11.15pm, screaming was heard in the graveyard of a nearby church. Katrina's body was found the next morning. She had been stabbed five times in the chest, two of the wounds puncturing her heart. According to the pathologist's report, she had been held from behind and stabbed from the front by one or two people.

The four suspects were rounded up and gave a series of interviews to police which, they later admitted in court, were mostly lies. In July 1997, the four appeared at Lewes Crown Court charged with murder. Neshia and Simon Williams claimed Taylor had left the flat late that evening with Scollan and Smith. One campaigner said: 'We will not stop until someone has been found responsible for this murder. We want the police to be fully accountable for their actions in this case.'

The campaigners have drawn parallels with another Brighton murder in which Sussex police have been accused of failing to investigate properly. The family of Jay Abatan, a black accountant murdered outside a nightclub last year, joined forces with local MP Peter Bottomley last week to fight for justice.

Bottomley, MP for Eltham at the time of Stephen Lawrence's death, is keen to ensure the case is investigated thoroughly. 'It was at a similar stage in the proceedings after Lawrence's death that I became unhappy about the police investigation. I didn't ask for an inquiry early enough. webTitle: Cheap labour in race for jobs

fields.headline: Cheap labour in race for jobs
fields.standfirst: Overseas workers scramble to fill British healthcare and teaching posts
fields.trailText: Crippling levels of vacancies in hospitals, schools and local authorities have led to an urgent worldwide recruitment drive for cheap overseas workers.
fields.byline: by Anthony Browne and Martin Bright
fields.body:
Crippling levels of vacancies in hospitals, schools and local authorities have led to an urgent worldwide recruitment drive for cheap overseas workers.

Public sector managers have been forced to scour the world for nurses, teachers and social workers because wages are now too low to recruit locally. Critics have accused the Government of accepting a quick fix rather than seeking a long-term solution to recruitment problems.

The weekly tally of foreign nurses applying to register in Britain has risen from 70 five years ago to 1,000 now - three times the number of British nurses applying for registration. Stuart Skyte, spokesman for the UK regulator for nurses, said: 'It is not an exaggeration to say there's been an explosion in applications from nurses from abroad.'

Supply teaching agencies in London say that during some parts of the year 70 per cent of teachers on their books are from overseas. Severe shortages of social workers mean local authorities - particularly in the South-East - are having to advertise in South Africa, Scandinavia and other EU countries.

The proportion of nurses from overseas who are registering has been steadily rising. Five years ago, 12 per cent of registrations were from overseas, and in the year to March 1999 this rose to 28 per cent. Since then, the numbers have escalated dramatically. 'It's been really building up since the middle of last year,' said Skyte.

Britain's largest international nursing recruitment agency, Worldwide Healthcare Exchange Limited, estimates that the number of nurses recruited from the Philippines has risen by almost 400 per cent in the past year. In recent weeks, two new companies have been set up specifically to bring Filipino nurses to the UK.

The Royal College of Nurses welcomes overseas nurses, but a spokesman added: 'It's taking a very short-term view. In the long term, we need to make nursing a more attractive career and to encourage more people to stay in the profession.'

Professor Tim Hatton of the University of Essex, an expert in the economics of migration, condemned government policy: 'There are plenty of qualified nurses in Britain; there is just a shortage of people prepared to work as a nurse at the wages being offered. That's no basis to run a modern National Health Service.'

Hospitals from all over Britain are sending managers on regular recruiting trips overseas. Last week three hospitals which had previously managed to fill nursing posts locally started recruit ing overseas from the EU, Eastern Europe, Africa and the Far East. However, most hospitals have stopped recruiting from South Africa after the government there complained to the Department of Health that Britain was stealing their expensively trained nurses.

In teaching, the recruitment problem is approaching crisis proportions. In London there is a severe shortage of deputy heads in primary schools, as teachers in their early 20s are pushed out of the city by rising house prices.

Chris King, education director of the Timeplan agency, said: 'This is part of a huge paradigm shift in professional work. London would fall apart without people from overseas.' He said there had been a sharp rise in the number of South Africans coming: 'Since the Mandela era, it's been like taking the cork out of the bottle.'

Ministers are known to be concerned about the quality of graduates going into the profession and the shortage of secondary teachers in key areas such as languages and science. Graham Lane, education spokesman for the Association of Local Government said: 'The most serious problem the Government face is that 25-30 year olds are leaving the profession and not coming back.'

According to Terry Gorman, President of the Society of Chief Personnel Officers, whose members recruit in the public sector, there is a severe shortage of social workers and an increasing number of qualified South Africans, Scandinavians and Belgians are being brought to Britain.

Gorman backed Tony Blair's concern that people were retiring too early when they could be filling jobs in shortage areas. 'The biggest issue is the ageing population,' he said. 'We are letting people go too early.'

A survey of 50-55 year olds who had taken early retirement commissioned by Gorman's organisation found that 48 per cent would consider coming back to work and 41 per cent had not wanted to go in the first place.

John Philpott, director of the Employment Policy Institute, said: 'There are a lot of older people not in work who might have the right skills.'

fields.headline: Risk from mobile masts was 'hidden'
fields.standfirst: Mobile phone fears: special report
fields.trailText: Vital evidence of harmful effects on children from transmitter masts was kept from the expert group which last week reported on mobile phone safety.
fields.body:
Vital evidence of harmful effects on children from transmitter masts was kept from the expert group which last week reported on mobile phone safety.

The independent panel asked the government agency acting as its secretariat, the National Radiological Protection Board (NRPB), for copies of a study on schoolchildren living near a radio mast in Latvia. They were told that the research was unpublished and unobtainable, which they recorded in their final report.

But The Observer has learnt that the research, published in an international scientific journal in 1996, was peer reviewed by other scientists and has been easily obtained by ordinary members of the public who gave evidence during the expert group's investigation.

First published in Dutch journal The Science of the Total Environment, the study by the Latvian Academy of Sciences examined the impact of a military radio transmitter on local schoolchildren, comparing them with a control group.

The research, which studied nearly 1,000 children aged 9 to 18, found that 'memory and attention were significantly impaired in all children living in front of the Skrunda station'.

Dr Hilary Kennedy, a biologist and chairperson of Northern Ireland Families against Telecommunications Transmitter Towers (NIFATT), said: 'The nature of the radiation from both installations is pulsed. It is pulse radiation which now gives most cause for concern.'

The Independent Expert Group on Mobile Phones acknowledged that pulse radiation, used in the digital signals of most modern mobile phones, needs more research.

Most of the scientific evidence reviewed by the independent panel related to old analogue signals. 'I believe that the NRPB has misled Sir William Stewart's committee,' said NIFATT's secretary, Margaret Dean. 'By withholding the findings of this important study I also believe the NRPB is guilty of a gross disservice to the general public.'

Two of the expert group broke ranks this weekend to condemn the NRPB's failure to advise Ministers or the public properly. The panel glossed over its views on the agency last week. But the two lay panel members, John Fellows, outgoing president of Edinburgh University Students' Union, and Marie-Noëlle Barton, national manager of Women into Science and Engineering Campaign, brought in to represent ordinary people, say NRPB heads were sly and insensitive.

'It became quite clear that if the NRPB had been doing its job properly there would have been no need for our committee,' said Fellows. The panel was told by the Department of Trade and Industry's observer that the NRPB refused a year ago to measure how much energy from the phone is absorbed by body tissue - the Specific Energy Absorption Rate (SAR) - despite an offer of a six-figure sum to do so.

One of the group's main recommendations is that handsets display SAR so consumers can choose phones which emit lower levels. Barton, the only woman in the 12-member group, said: 'People just want to know whether phones are safe or not, yes or no. People are confused and scared by jargon.

'Most queries the NRPB receives are about mobile phones and base stations but they spend a tiny fraction of their budget on this research. I used to use my phone for a 45-minute taxi ride because I thought that was efficient use of my time. Now I will not use it for more than two minutes.'

sarah.ryle@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Olympic athletes pack oxygen tents to clinch victory

fields.headline: Olympic athletes pack oxygen tents to clinch victory
fields.trailText: Athletes hoping to win gold at this summer's Olympic Games will bring more than running vests and spikes. The medal-hungry will also take the latest gizmo to enhance performance: an altitude tent.
fields.body:
Athletes hoping to win gold at this summer's Olympic Games will bring more than running vests and spikes. The medal-hungry will also take the latest gizmo to enhance performance: an altitude tent.

Competitors climb in, zip up, turn on the oxygen supply and sleep through their training, theoretically gaining the lungs of Sherpa Tensing while slumbering.

The tent is all the rage with those whose events require superhuman stamina, such as cyclists, swimmers and distance runners who all rely heavily on breathing power.

It is also popular with triathletes, who make an Olympic debut this September. Simon Lessing, triple world triathlon champion and one of Britain's few medal contenders in Sydney, is an enthusiast. Leading Australian triathletes Greg Welsh and Michelle Jones, are also banking on the tent to help them in their quest for glory.

But the tent is causing Olympic controversy. Jacques Rogge, vice-president of the International Olympic Committee and a member of its medical commission, has condemned the device as an unfair aid. But Australian Olympic Committee president John Coates says there is nothing to stop athletes using the tent and reaping benefits.

It restricts oxygen to the person inside, simulating altitudes up to 14,500 feet. The body manufactures red blood corpuscles to absorb thinner air. Back at sea-level, 'value-added blood' soaks up oxygen like a sponge to give a vital edge.

Altitude training has been a vital part of top athletic training since the Olympics in Mexico City in 1968, the first at such high altitude. Kip Keino from Kenya showed the value of being born in rarefied air by running the legs off the 1,500m world record-holder, Jim Ryan of the United States.

Since then, Africans have dominated distance running. The rest of the world believes the altitude tent may help them catch up.

It is the latest in a long line of attempts to steal a march on competitors. Sydney will also see the controversial new 'shark suit', a swimming costume designed for extra speed.

At the winter Olympics in Nagano in 1998, there was uproar when the Dutch speed skating team turned up with tiny zigzag stripes on their shins and foreheads which reduced wind resistance. They stormed the medals tables.

Trying to gain an edge is as old as sport itself. But until recently, most methods involved taking something. In ancient Greece, it was brandy, wine, and magic mushrooms. These days, six-day cyclists sniff cocaine and heroin for endurance. The French and Belgians experimented with ether-coated sugar, while the English took pure oxygen, strychnine, heroin and cocaine with brandy.

webTitle: Scientist seeks quake-spotting gene in animals

fields.headline: Scientist seeks quake-spotting gene in animals
fields.trailText: Birds began to flit from tree to tree, dogs howled, and cats scratched and mewed. These antics were spotted by scientists who had come to Haicheng in China's Liao-ning province to study local earth tremors which they thought might presage a major quake. The animals' behaviour so alarmed the researchers, they had the city evacuated.
fields.body:
Birds began to flit from tree to tree, dogs howled, and cats scratched and mewed. These antics were spotted by scientists who had come to Haicheng in China's Liao-ning province to study local earth tremors which they thought might presage a major quake. The animals' behaviour so alarmed the researchers, they had the city evacuated.

A couple of days later, a major quake destroyed Haicheng. Thanks to the scientists, and to the city's animals, only a few citizens died.

This success - in 1975 - convinced seismologists they had discovered how to forecast earthquakes: by combining geological knowledge with observations of animals.

Then, a year later, a shock of 7.9 on the Richter scale devastated neighbouring Tangshan, killing 650,000 people. No one predicted this catastrophe, and geologists were forced very quickly to abandon their claims to have developed seismic powers.

Since then scientists have concentrated on studying geological forces in a bid to regain this lost predictive prowess. However, a Tokyo researcher has now begun a new approach by revolutionising studies of animals which he believes still hold the secret to anticipating geological disasters.

Professor Mitsuaki Ota, of Azabu University in Tokyo, intends to find 'an earthquake gene', a piece of DNA which could account for animals' odd behaviour before major shocks. Ota has begun by studying reports of pets that acted oddly - whining, fluttering or generally behaving peculiarly - before the 1995 quake that devastated the Japanese city of Kobe. From these pets he has then selected the 60 top prescient creatures and taken blood and tissue samples from them.

He has also gathered a control group of several hundred Kobe cats, dogs and budgies, pets who singularly failed to spot that a major earthquake was about to destroy their city. Armed with these two groups, Ota now intends to compare the genomes of successful and unsuccessful pet predictors. In particular, he will be seeking out genes that may be responsible for the synthesis and reception of dopamines, one of the most important of the brain's chemical transmitters. It may play a key role in animals' pre-quake behaviour, he believes.

'There is no doubt among many researchers that animals can exhibit strange behaviour before certain natural phenomena, but the mechanism has not been discovered,' says Ota in the current issue of Science .

Ota's ideas are unusual, but strike a chord with most geologists. 'There are all sorts of reports of animals acting oddly before earthquakes,' said Dr Alice Walker of the British Geological Survey in Edinburgh.

'However, these have never been studied properly. Different animals react in different ways to an irritant. It is a matter of temperament which could be very difficult to study.'

Scientists currently put forward two main explanations to account for animals' reactions to forthcoming shocks. 'Either they are picking up static electricity that is caused by rocks rubbing together, or they are reacting to rising levels of electromagnetic radiation,' said Dr Bill McGuire, of the Benfield Greig hazard research centre at University College London.

How an animal could spot such forces remains to be seen. Nevertheless, if Ota is successful, and manages to pinpoint a promising breed of animal, a group could be kept under constant observation and their behaviour used in combination with geological studies to forecast quakes.

Immediate prospects of generating a population of predictive pets by selective breeding are not too high, however. Ota has found that most of the pets that acted oddly before the Kobe quake have a major biological flaw: they have been neutered.

webTitle: Go family-friendly, firms told, as bill for 'sick note fibs' hits £4bn

fields.headline: Go family-friendly, firms told, as bill for 'sick note fibs' hits £4bn
fields.trailText: A third of all sick leave is taken by workers who are not really ill, the first major employers' survey has revealed.
fields.body:
A third of all sick leave is taken by workers who are not really ill, the first major employers' survey has revealed.

Malingerers cost companies more than £4 billion every year, according to the Institute of Personnel and Development.

Staff who call in sick may simply be sick of work or dodging off to catch their child in the school play or because the childminder has not turned up.

Worries about absence levels - which have now reached an average nine days a year per worker, at a cost of £500 - are now the biggest reason why personnel managers contact the institute's helpline.

'It is what we call a hot topic,' said Diane Sinclair, an adviser in employment relations. But she says that bosses are at fault in many cases for failing to trust staff who need time off for genuine family reasons. 'In some cases they are forcing people to tell fibs,' said Sinclair.

Just one in four of the 1,684 companies in the survey, who employ between them two million people, operate family-friendly policies and fewer than one in three are flexible about working hours. But nearly half the organisations restrict sick pay.

The biggest single innovation is the 'return to work interview', in which bosses question staff who have taken even one day off for illness. In theory these interviews are supposed to help managers understand underlying reasons for absence, such as stress or low morale.

Asda, the supermarket chain, introduced return to work interviews a year ago. 'It is not a rap on the knuckles,' said spokeswoman Zaria Pinchbeck. 'It's an opportunity for colleagues to explain why they were off. We can then get to the bottom of the issues.

'That is how the shift swap scheme began. Colleagues understand that we can't deliver the lowest prices if we are not efficient on costs and absence is a cost. We have found absence has come down because of the culture change.'

The institute survey shows that not all employers take that approach. 'More people are wielding the stick than are waving the carrot,' said Sinclair. 'If you can wave a carrot, you can recruit and retain people. If you treat people like grown-ups they will act like grown-ups.'

Falling unemployment means that good workers are scarce and they can command better conditions. The institute believes the companies should be creative to motivate and keep staff. 'It is all about high trust relationships,' said Sinclair. 'This generation has learnt that there is no such thing as a job for life and that loyalty is a one-way street, so they are prepared to demand more in return for their own commitment.'

Multinational companies are introducing concierge schemes, ranging from collecting children from school to doing household chores. One London-based advertising company has introduced 'duvet days', allowing two days' paid leave each year for staff who wake up with a hangover and cannot face crawling out of bed.

At Asda, the new range of leave schemes includes a school starter programme, giving parents half a day off on their child's first day at school.

Shift swapping means that parents are able to attend school plays or cater for illness.

A new 'Benidorm and Carers' scheme was devised to cater for the over-50s. It's intended to keep older workers who want to head for sunnier climes in the winter or who have relatives to look after.

They can take three months' leave, unpaid, each year without losing pension or other entitlements and with a guaranteed job to return to.

Women, who make up 44 per cent of the workforce, have a higher level of absence than men. Sinclair believes this is because women are still seen as the primary carers in families and are expected to deal with childcare emergencies.

Sick leave is half the average nine days in companies with 100 or fewer workers. It is lowest in South-East England and highest in the Midlands, the North-West and Wales.

webTitle: From killing fields to football fields

fields.headline: From killing fields to football fields
fields.standfirst: Denis Campbell reports on the first asylum-seeker from Kosovo to find a new life in the English Third Division
fields.trailText: Denis Campbell reports on the first asylum-seeker from Kosovo to find a new life in the English Third Division.
fields.body:
When Naim Uka arrived in Britain hidden in the back of a lorry, he was just another refugee fleeing the ethnic cleansing in his native Kosovo. All he had with him was some money, several T-shirts and a pair of football boots.

Now the stowaway has swapped the killing fields of former Yugoslavia for the football fields of Britain by becoming the country's first asylum-seeker turned professional soccer player. The teenager, who makes his debut on Tuesday, is tipped to become a major star.

Uka, 18, had to leave Kosovo after his parents and brother disappeared, neighbours were murdered and the family home was blown up during a bloody Serb offensive in 1998. After two months on the run to avoid Serb killers, he fled, joining a dozen others in the back of a truck, eventually reaching south Wales.

Today he is preparing to make his first appearance for Leyton Orient of the Third Division in a post-season charity match against West Ham.

It will be Uka's first chance to display the mesmerising ball skills which encouraged Partizan, the biggest team in Albania, to sign him at the age of 15.

It was during his stay in Albania that the Balkan war engulfed Kosovo. In the summer of 1998, Serb fighters razed buildings to the ground and murdered hundreds of people. The area where the Uka family lived, suffered some of the worst attacks.

When the young footballer returned from Partizan's training camp one day in September 1998, a scene of total devastation greeted him. He found his home ablaze, no sign of his relatives and bodies everywhere. There was no one left to ask if they had seen his mother, father or brother. Survivors of the massacre had escaped to the mountains.

Naim was just 16. He was appalled at the horror, but relieved that he could not find his relatives among the bodies lying near his former home. Like the others left alive, he headed for the hills.

He slept where he could, did not eat for up to three days at a time and had to avoid the constant threat of Serb snipers. A search for his family yielded nothing. After two months he crossed the border into Macedonia, found a lorry heading for Britain and climbed in.

Five days and five nights later, Uka arrived in south Wales with no passport. The others in the truck - men and women who like him had paid Dm5,000 (about £1,500) each to a Macedonian fixer - were in the same situation.

'One woman had given her six-month-old baby sleeping tablets to make sure it didn't cry, so that we wouldn't be discovered,' recalls Uka.

He headed straight for the Home Office refugee centre in Croydon, where he was fingerprinted, issued with identity papers, given £60 in food vouchers to last a fortnight and sent to a hostel.

Its 60 residents were all fellow asylum-seekers - Romanians and Nigerians, but mainly other Kosovans - who slept four to a room.

For the first six months, he was banned from working. And when he did get a work permit, no one would employ him. 'No one wants to give work to an asylum seeker,' says Uka.

Only football stopped him dying of boredom. The youngster trained on his own in the yard and played four-a-side every day with some compatriots in a nearby park. The hostel manager, impressed with the Kosovan's ball skills, called the Football Association. They alerted Richard Cody, a players' agent, who took Uka under his wing.

At an Orient trial for young hopefuls, Uka stood out because of his clothing - green beach shorts, one red sock and one blue - but then caught the eye because of his obvious talent. Now he has a two-year contract.

'The things Naim can do with a ball are unbelievable,' enthuses Orient assistant manager Paul Clark. 'Judged on individual skill and technique, there's no better player his age in the country. He's adjusting to English football, which is quicker and much more physical than he's used to.'

Uka feels incredibly lucky to have been given a chance to make his mark as the first Kosovan in British football.

'I owe it all to this man,' says the teenager firmly, pointing at Cody. 'He and his wife Jenny and their daughters, Claire and Kristy, have become like my new father, mother and sisters.'

Home is now with the Cody family in Hornchurch, Essex, rather than a hostel. But what of his real family? Although Uka is resigned to the likelihood that they are dead, he is not giving up hope.

'The Red Cross are trying to find them for me through their tracing service for families separated because of war. Maybe my parents have moved to another country. Maybe they are in Macedonia. I don't know.'

webTitle: Tate curator in attack on arts

fields.headline: Tate curator in attack on arts
fields.standfirst: Labour accused of populism and social engineering
fields.trailText: Britain is basking in the glory of the opening of Tate Modern. But key names in the art world are lining up to deliver a broadside against the Government's arts policy.
fields.body:
Britain is basking in the glory of the opening of Tate Modern. But key names in the art world are lining up to deliver a broadside against the Government's arts policy.

Famous painters, writers, sculptors and arts administrators, including a curator of the new Tate, are scrambling to contribute to a book that will attack New Labour's 'patronising populism'.

The book - so far known only as The Publication - will be edited by Baroness Warnock and the acclaimed installation artist Mark Wallinger. It will argue that Labour is undermining the artistic life of Britain, not enhancing it.

'There is too much emphasis now on the make-up of the audience, rather than on the art,' said the creator of the Angel of the North, Antony Gormley, expressing support for the ideas behind the project to The Observer . 'This Government sees art as a tool of social engineering. We must speak out and not be shrinking violets.'

The collection of 'provocative' essays and illustrations will be published this autumn by the independent arts group The Peer. Its target will be Labour's emphasis on populism and 'access'.

'There is too much enforced consensus now,' said Ingrid Swenson, who runs The Peer from a small office in east London. 'The Dome is really the symbol of how this can go wrong. It had no agenda and no integrity from the start. Chris Smith, the Culture Secretary, is always laying emphasis on the idea of "access", but lots of people do feel excluded and our book will reflect that.'

It will include essays from cultural theorist Andrew Benjamin, and from artists Craigie Horsfield and Julian Opie.

Others, including the sculptor and co-designer of the Millennium Bridge, Sir Anthony Caro, and Gormley, have expressed interest. The group is funded by the Sainsburys' Charitable Trust and one of its four trustees is Andrew Brighton, curator of public events at Tate Modern. Although Brighton's work for The Peer does not represent the views of the Tate, he is forthright about mistakes in arts policy.

'We have lost the idea that arts institutions should be able to pursue their own agenda,' he said. 'The arts are now talked about in terms of their economic or social effect, rather than allowed to stand on their own terms.

'The Government is concerned that the audiences for art should reflect the whole population, rather than allowing there is a specific arts community - just as there is a specific football community. There seems to be a fear of plurality too, and good art often comes from plurality.'

Brighton is not alone. Norman Rosenthal, the man behind the 1997 Sensation exhibition at the Royal Academy, has criticised the messy British populism that led to what he regards as the creative failure of the Dome. 'It is a nightmare,' he told The Observer . 'There is not an idea in it.'

Another curator of a leading national gallery indicated private support for a more independent arts community, and complained of centralist conformism. 'It is interesting that I do not feel able to speak out publicly, while in the 1970s and 1960s subsidised creative directors like Sir Peter Hall were free to express their criticisms.'

Charles Saumarez Smith, director of the National Portrait Gallery, believes it unfair to blame the Government for the Dome, a fait accompli when it took power. He does, though, have reservations about New Labour's attitude to the arts.

Outside the new Tate gallery launch party on Thursday night others excluded from the bright world of Lottery-funded restaurants and cafés made their opposition felt.

Chloe Ruthven brought a group of homeless people from Piccadilly Circus to the gallery. Each was asked to collect celebrity signatures as part of a piece of conceptual protest art and paid £20 for the work by sponsors.
