fields.headline: From palette to palate
fields.trailText: The rash of new lottery-funded galleries concentrated in the capital will provide open access to all art lovers in search of a meal this summer - as long as they have a good income.
fields.body:
The rash of new lottery-funded galleries concentrated in the capital will provide open access to all art lovers in search of a meal this summer - as long as they have a good income.

The fancy menus may not be accessible to the regular lottery ticket buyer in Penzance or Skipton, but it is planned that they become a steady source of income for the subsidised galleries.

The National Portrait Gallery

Head chef Kerwyn Browne

View Previously unseen vista, with an astonishing silhouette of Nelson's column against a backdrop of Westminster and the London Eye.

Typical dish Shin of beef with broad bean consommé at £5.95, followed by grilled tuna with bacon, salsa verde and dandelion leaves at £12.50

Open? For a week on a preview basis.

Booked up yet? No. The restaurant will not be open on Saturday evenings for a month but Thursdays or Fridays are still available.

By the way The gallery itself houses Britain's reorganised display of paintings, sculptures and photographs representing eminent historical and contemporary figures. See The Darnley Portrait of Elizabeth I or try the new Internet research room.

The Wallace Collection

Head chef Stephen Bull is designing the menu for the new courtyard restaurant, Cafe Bagatelle, named after the French chateau of the art collector Sir Richard Wallace. The concept has been put together by the team that brought a restaurant to the Museé d'Orsay in Paris.

View The pale rose stucco of the old inner courtyard has been renovated and covered with a glass atrium. A French fountain plays in the centre.

Typical dish British Modern cuisine. Three courses cost around £32 at Bull's other establishments.

Open? Not yet. The Prince of Wales is pencilled to reopen the collection on 22 June, date of the Collection's centenary.

Booked up yet? No. As well as tired Bond Street shoppers, clientele may well include the collection's trustees Sir Elton John and Vivienne Westwood.

By the way The Wallace Collection in Manchester Square, behind Selfridges, has long been a semi-secret. Enjoy an encounter with Frans Hals's The Laughing Cavalier or Fragonard's The Swing.

Tate Modern

Head chef Lloyd Hardwicke

View Best by a mile. The intended view of St Paul's Cathedral is now dramatically revealed again. You can also look down on the Richard Rogers/Anthony Caro Millennium Bridge - due for completion in late June.

Typical dish Substantial salads and pasta, and fish and chips with mushy peas at £7.50.

Open? Yes. Both the lower, riverbank level cafe and the panoramic restaurant on the seventh floor are now open. And you don't have to pay to come inside.

Booked up yet? Next Saturday night is booked, but beyond that, plenty of openings.

By the way Tate Modern generously displays many of the century's most dazzling gems

Dulwich Picture Gallery

Head chef Mark Morgan. The franchise is owned by Digby Trout

View A sunny garden from inside a brick, glass and bronze pavilion. Taking tea at the gallery was always quoted as being as close to paradise as England could get.

Typical dish Smoked haddock fish balls on skewer, pocket pitta bread filled with salad, tarragon mayonnaise at £8.25.

Open? The Queen will open the gallery on 25 May

Booked up? Taking bookings from next week

By the way Houses Cornelis Bol's grand view of London. Other gems include Poussin, Raphael, and Rubens' Aeneas with the Arms of Mezentius.

Somerset House

Head chef Eric Guilbert, but run by Oliver Peyton, creator of the Coast and The Atlantic Bar & Grill

View Stunning vistas across the Thames from the North Bank, marred only by the National Theatre. Covered courtyard with fountain.

Typical dish Regional French classics

Open? The Queen Mother will open Somerset House officially on 25 May. The cheaper River Cafe Terrace and Admiralty Delicatessen, selling sandwiches and salads, wll open at the same time. The Admiralty restaurant opens mid-June

Booked up yet? Not yet taking bookings.

By the Way Once the home of the nation's register of births, deaths and marriages, the building now houses the Gilbert Collection. It was put together by Sir Arthur Gilbert and is a treasure trove of gold, silver and mosaics. Galleries of the Courtauld Institute have also been extended.

webTitle: New blood clots alert over HRT

fields.headline: New blood clots alert over HRT
fields.standfirst: Many doctors fail to warn patients of menopause drug danger, report says
fields.trailText: Taking hormone replacement therapy to counter the effects of the menopause makes women three times as likely to suffer from potentially fatal blood clots, according to new evidence .
fields.body:
Taking hormone replacement therapy to counter the effects of the menopause makes women three times as likely to suffer from potentially fatal blood clots, according to new evidence .

The clots can form in the women's legs, disabling them, or can travel into the lungs, possibly causing death. The study, reported last week in the American Annals of Internal Medicine , is one of the most alarming pieces of research to show HRT as a looming public health disaster.

About a quarter of British women aged between 50 and 64 - about 1.3 million - use HRT to overcome the negative effects of the menopause. A recent US study caused international alarm by showing women on HRT are more prone to get strokes or heart attacks. There is concern that a large number of women are being handicapped for life as a result of HRT, which is also thought to lead to gall bladder and liver disease, and even cancer.

The latest study - based on clinical trials over four years - suggests about 5,000 British women a year will get blood clots as a result of HRT. The report's author, Dr Deborah Grady, of the University of California, concluded: 'About one in every 263 women treated with HRT will experience a blood clot each year because of the hormonal treatment. Women with leg fractures, cancer or hospitalisation for surgery were more likely to develop a blood clot than were women without these conditions.'

The study says 'women and their doctors should consider the potential side effect of blood clots when considering the risks and benefits of hormone replacement therapy after menopause'. Many doctors prescribe HRT drugs without checking patients or monitoring their progress.

Because of ignorance about the side-effects of HRT, symptoms are often dismissed as neuroses or unrelated to the HRT drugs prescribed. Drugs companies were not obliged to include information leaflets with the medicines until European Union regulations came into operation last year. There had previously been a proliferation of marketing hype and a climate of false security. Many women feel rejuvenated after taking HRT, although it is also often prescribed to reduce the risk of heart disease.

Critics say the medical claims for HRT are based on anecdotal, and sometimes conflicting, evidence. HRT has not been licenced in the UK or the US as a drug for the heart.

Dr Ellen Grant, founder of Doctors Against the Abuse of Sex Hormones (Dash), said: 'The hormone trials in the Seventies and Eighties were completely misleading. Selection and exclusion tactics led to erroneous nonsense that heart attacks were reduced when in fact the original studies in the Sixties showed an increase in venous thrombosis and arterial disease as well as hormone-related cancer and liver disease. Properly controlled studies worldwide at the time showed an increase in migraine and strokes and blood clots, but other large-scale studies mud died the waters and conned people into believing these drugs are far safer than they really are. It is far safer for women to take nutritional supplements which can be monitored by chemical tests.'

There is concern that oestrogen implants - a common form of HRT for women who have had hysterectomies - can result in oestrogen addiction, causing mood swings, sickness and exhaustion. Oestrogen addiction was recently highlighted by the case of Pat Mitchell, the first woman to receive compensation - an undisclosed five-figure sum - after a four-and-a-half year battle against Worcester Health Authority. While oestrogen levels rarely exceed 50 in women without uterus or ovaries, Mitchell's reached 4,000 after 18 implants over six years, leaving her with chronic health problems.

Mitchell said: 'The whole experience has left me more prone to infection and I get tired easily. I would give all the money back to be able to do the things I used to do.'

Another victim of oestrogen addiction had suffered fibroids and cysts before her womb was removed, followed by the prescription of HRT. 'Soon I was not only having implants, but "top ups" of HRT tablets and patches to carry me through to my next medical appointment,' she said. 'I had seven implants in 14 months and my levels of oestrogen had become dangerously high.' It took her four years to recover, while she suffered withdrawal symptoms of oestrogen overdose.

A third victim had taken HRT tablets for three days when she suffered a stroke. Her GP had prescribed HRT because she felt tired and depressed and suffered sweats at night. He made no inquiry about her family history. After three days she was paralysed. Four years later she can barely walk or string a sentence together.

The long-term consequences of HRT drugs will not be known for at least 10 years with the results of the Wisdom trial in the UK, which will recruit 22,000 women to find out if HRT lowers the risk of diseases.

There is concern that its effects could be similar to those of the contraceptive pill, which contains similar hormones, and has been studied for 40 years. While the dosages of the pill have been reduced to improve safety, HRT drugs can be up to 40 times more potent.

Prof William Inman, senior medical officer for the Committee on Safety of Drugs, traced the deaths of 385 women who had thrombosis or heart attacks after taking oral contraceptives. Eight years later, after examining the deaths of all women under 50 who had suffered heart attacks in England and Wales, he found a fivefold increase of fatal heart attacks of women over 40 who had taken the pill.

020 7251 6580.

fields.headline: Largin' it at Tate Modern
fields.trailText: The most overused word, in the many thousands of words written by those previewing Tate Modern over the past few weeks, has not been 'small',  writes Euan Ferguson. 'Pygmy' pops up terribly seldom, as does 'bijou'. No, we are all agreed on one thing: it's big. Very, very big. It is, most commonly, 'breathtaking'; it is also 'momentous'; we are 'staggered and stunned and silenced by its frigid beauty'. In one article the writer, lost for suitably Brobdingnagian adjectives, began, with a sweet, refreshing helplessness: 'God, the size of it ...'
fields.body:
The most overused word, in the many thousands of words written by those previewing Tate Modern over the past few weeks, has not been 'small', writes Euan Ferguson. 'Pygmy' pops up terribly seldom, as does 'bijou'. No, we are all agreed on one thing: it's big. Very, very big. It is, most commonly, 'breathtaking'; it is also 'momentous'; we are 'staggered and stunned and silenced by its frigid beauty'. In one article the writer, lost for suitably Brobdingnagian adjectives, began, with a sweet, refreshing helplessness: 'God, the size of it ...'

Most critics agreed last week that Tate Modern is also very, very good. Gripes are tiny. Some even fretted over the dropping of the definite article from the title, but this was just a momentary cavil before the eulogies. The most general criticisms, tellingly, are not of Tate Modern but of the Dome; the gallery is hailed as the apex of modern thinking, the tent its nadir. As the Independent pointed out, Tate Modern (and the Eye) 'are not frauds upon the public, but gifts to them'.

There's not enough good early twentieth-century stuff, critics agree - but all blame lies in the past. Similarly, the layout has come in for much discussion, the curators having famously opted for a themed rather than chronological approach, but the verdict, from about 40 articles so far, is warmly for Serota's approach.

But there were, of course, reasoned criticisms. What would we do without Brian Sewell, who kicked off with a reluctant admiration for the building before a quick swipe at Louise Bourgeois ('demented old bag') and a confident prediction that 'within 20 years the building will be massively reconstructed to make use of the wasted space ... the displays will seem so shallow and capricious that they will be replaced by the despised chronologies'.

webTitle: Airmen sue RAF over torture class

fields.headline: Airmen sue RAF over torture class
fields.trailText: The top-secret RAF course that teaches downed pilots to cope with intensive interrogation faces a legal challenge under European Human Rights laws which take effect in Britain later this year.
fields.body:
The top-secret RAF course that teaches downed pilots to cope with intensive interrogation faces a legal challenge under European Human Rights laws which take effect in Britain later this year.

The Conduct After Capture course will have to be radically modified - or halted - if legal actions brought by airmen are successful. Some participants have found it 'traumatic and disturbing'.

During a week at a centre at St Mawgan in Cornwall, pilots and navigators face intensive interrogation and sleep deprivation, and are denied food and water. The course is covered by the Official Secrets Act, and crew are told to deny its existence.

Five officers, including two Tornado pilots, hope to use provisions in the European Convention on Human Rights - to be incorporated into British law on 2 October - to brand the course 'degrading and inhuman'. One pulled out of the course and has been told that unless he retakes it his flying career will be over.

The course was introduced after the Gulf war of 1991, when several British airmen shot down by the Iraqis were tortured. John Nichol, then a Tornado pilot, was badly beaten by his captors. He said yesterday that he refused to take the new CAC course - compulsory for all aircrew. 'There is a valid debate over whether you can teach anyone what they need to know to cope with an experience that extreme,' he said.

Previous attempts to appeal to the courts have failed. 'There are numerous allegations of the instructors going well over the top,' said one solicitor representing the airmen. 'Some of the men have found the course deeply traumatic and disturbing.'

Fierce arguments have filled Internet chatrooms used by British military pilots. Some accuse those bringing the cases of being weak, but others are supportive.

The case raises wider issues. Nichol said: 'This is about the military being told it is no longer possible to stamp on the rights of its people. Senior officers have never been aware of this. They are being dragged kicking and screaming into the twenty-first century.'

webTitle: Calm surface of abortion debate hides deep divisions

fields.headline: Calm surface of abortion debate hides deep divisions
fields.trailText: 'There has always been the option of going to Britain with all our problems - from unmarried mothers to emigration.' The words are those of Professor Anthony Clare, medical director of St Patrick's Hospital in Dublin, and the interviewer in Radio 4's  In the Psychiatrist's Chair .
fields.body:
'There has always been the option of going to Britain with all our problems - from unmarried mothers to emigration.' The words are those of Professor Anthony Clare, medical director of St Patrick's Hospital in Dublin, and the interviewer in Radio 4's In the Psychiatrist's Chair .

Clare has been giving evidence to an all-party parliamentary committee holding public hearings on the Irish government's Green Paper on abortion.

Abortion is prohibited, but 5,000 Irish women a year travel to Britain to have them. That number is rising. It is this situation which the government has promised to address, either by holding a constitutional referendum on the issue, or by legislating to allow for abortion in strictly controlled circumstances.

Abortion has been a bitterly divisive issue in Irish politics for 20 years and, as Clare reminded the legislators, it would be extremely foolish to think that 'the steam has gone out of it'.

That is one reason why the government has gone to such pains to promote civilised debate. Nobody wants a repeat of the bitter divisions of l983, when a constitutional amendment pledging 'to protect the right to life of the unborn child' was put to referendum and carried by an overwhelming majority.

In 1992 the whole situation was once more thrown into confusion when the Supreme Court ruled that a teenage girl, pregnant as the result of rape, should be allowed to travel to Britain to have an abortion, because her threat of suicide constituted a serious risk to her life.

In theory, this decision meant that it should be possible to perform abortions in Irish hospitals, in similar circumstances. That hasn't happened. One eminent obstetrician told the all-party committee medical practice was unaffected by the ruling.

But the public hearings have shown how far the debate has moved, at least within the Irish medical profession. It is now generally accepted, even by doctors opposed to any relaxation in the law, that pregnancies are terminated in Irish hospitals when the mother is at risk.

A difficulty arises in deciding whether such cases constitute abortion or not. Professor John Bonnar, Chairman of the Institute of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, argues the procedures involved, while destroying the foetus, are not abortions because this is not the primary, deliberate intention.

Some of his colleagues disagree. One obstetrician told the committee he believed an outright constitutional ban on abortion would lead, sooner or later, to a situation where a woman's life would be at risk and the doctor would have to decide whether or not to break the law.

There are other agonising choices facing doctors and patients. A leading paediatrician raised the question of how a doctor should advise a couple who have learnt that their baby may be born severely handicapped. He cited the incidence of cystic fibrosis in Ireland, which is the highest in the world. There are couples who have two or three children suffering this tragic condition. In other countries termination of a second pregnancy would be the norm but this is not possible in Ireland. Instead, the couple have to decide whether to go to Britain.

For most Irish women these arguments, while genuinely difficult, fail to address the real problem. The overwhelming majority of those who fly to Liverpool or London do so for more mundane reasons. Their method of contraception has failed, they lack social and emotional support, or cannot face bringing up a baby on their own.

The London-based British Pregnancy Advisory Service, used by many Irish women, has presented a submission urging the Irish government to provide abortion facilities in their own country. It says: 'The women who come to us are not amoral, feckless or degenerate. They are normal women who have considered their position carefully and know that they must live with the consequences.'

Many Irish women would like to see the government face this challenge. But they are not holding their breath.

fields.headline: Family crisis? Call  mother-in-law
fields.standfirst: Bill Clinton's mother-in-law will look after him if his wife wins New York. Tony Blair's is moving into Number 10 to babysit.  Maureen Freely  on the modern rise of an ancient force
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton's mother-in-law will look after him if his wife wins New York. Tony Blair's is moving into Number 10 to babysit.  Maureen Freely  on the modern rise of an ancient force
fields.body:
It's never easy to be a lame duck, especially if, like Bill Clinton, you're watching your wife's political career take off at the same time. It may be true that he's proud of her. But her success has both private and public implications for him. From now on, Hillary is going to be just too busy to hold his hand.

This is a big problem, one he shares with many other men in his generation. They can no longer go home to their wives for emotional support when they need it, because they are most probably out at work.

Luckily for Clinton and his ilk, many of these wives were raised by stay-at-home mothers who retain old-fashioned ideas about maternal duty.

Take, for example, Hillary's mother, Dorothy Rodham, famous for being fiercely protective of her daughter, not a bit amused by the Lewinsky saga. But if her daughter wins the electoral race in New York, she will be taking Bill into her condo in Little Rock, Arkansas. He plans to stay there, he says, for a couple of years, while she reigns.

Similarly, the Blairs have resolved their upcoming childcare problems after the upset over Ros Marks, their former nanny who tried to sell her story. How relieved they must have been when Cherie's mother offered to move in and babysit. It pleased the public, too. What a good idea, everyone said, to keep it all in the family. It is not, however, anything new. The Invaluable Mother-in-Law is a media staple.

Noel Gallagher's mother-in-law made tabloid headlines when she saved her granddaughter's life after the 18-month-old stopped breathing. Not long after that, we had George Best's mother-in-law showing a brave face to reporters asking about the football star's health. 'He's got a stomach upset,' she said loyally. 'He's fine, really.' Then came the cancellation of Anna Kournikova's alleged engagement to hockey star Pavel Bure, allegedly because he baulked at having Mrs Kournikova Snr as a mother-in-law. This prompted columnists to write about how much power mothers-in-law have over the popular imagination. They went on to prove their own point by making a huge flap about Robin Cook's mother, when (after siding with his first wife Margaret during the divorce) she shocked onlookers by chatting with Gaynor at a party.

There was another flurry of comment when Terri Apter published a study about tensions between married couples and their mothers. Then the mother-in-law joke had a revival when Italian lawyer Paola Mescoli Davoli started a Mother-in-Law School. Intrusive or disapproving mothers-in-law are cited in 40 per cent of Italy's divorce cases. The only way forward, said Davoli, was to make them use their power more carefully. In Britain, mothers-in-law are getting attention not because they are causing problems, but because people are starting to see how useful they are.

One of the fondest hopes of Jack Straw and his Ministerial Group on the Family is that grandparents can be encouraged to play a larger role in rearing their grandchildren. Then the nation's children would be safe and sound while New Labour pushes their mothers into work.

According to the Family Policy Studies Centre, grandparents are the main providers of childcare after parents. More than half of mothers and fathers over 50 help their adult children. Grandparents become more involved after family breakdown, but here there is a catch. According to a 1999 study by Geoff Dench and Katrina Thomson, grandfathers feel marginalised if their children divorce. They complained that they had too little time with grandchildren. Grandmothers said they had too much.

No government should assume that there is a huge pool of grandparents eager to do childcare. Juliet Mountford of the FPSC says many grandparents feel they deserve time off. They want to travel, take up new hobbies and relax. There is very little research in this country on how grandparents feel about the new roles government is planning for them. Policy-makers 'tend not to take the grandparents' point of view,' says Mountford. Instead they use them to 'fill a gap'.

The Family Policy group hopes a number of studies will stop this. Meantime it may be useful to look at the US, where census figures say the number of grandmothers involved in childcare has increased by 41 per cent since 1992. Other statistics identify 1.4 million children whose 'functional' parents are now their grandparents. This is largely an inner-city problem, as more women have been obliged to take over the care of grandchildren after their own children succumb to drug addiction or Aids, family breakdown or the need to find work.

Childcare stress is affecting health to such a degree that geriatric parental stress is well under way to becoming a syndrome. Five years ago there wasn't one organisation offering grandparent carers advice and support. Now there are more than 600. There has been a parallel rise in training programmes. Some concentrate on helping grandmothers update their skills. For example, many have trouble helping with homework, because education has changed so much since their day, and they find modern discipline methods perplexing. The most common question, says one grandparent educator, is 'What do you mean they don't spank any more?'

Grandparent carers have grown rather militant. The American Association of Retired Persons, with its 30 million members, is a force to be reckoned with. When it brought a test-case about grandparents' visitation rights to the Supreme Court earlier this year, it was one of dozens filed.

According to David D Meyer, professor of law at the University of Chicago, the attention this case has received underlines the need for a new definition of the word 'family'. The social reality of modern families was changing dramatically, he said, but our ways of understanding them had not kept pace.

Many people in the UK family policy sector share his view. A few months ago, the FSPC published a briefing criticising the Government for being too fixated on childcare, and failing to see the link between childcare and eldercare. It makes little sense to bring grandmothers into the picture as carers of children, while failing to remember that these same women sooner or later will need to be looked after themselves.

Traditionally, elderly mothers and mothers-in-law are looked after by daughters and daughters-in-law. But, as we have already noted, these paragons are no longer necessarily at home all day. And the rise in the divorce rate could mean a drastic drop in the number of daughters-in-law who are available at all. As the population ages, family friendly policy is going to be as much about helping employees take care of their elderly relatives as it will be about childcare.

Joanna Foster, chair of the women's network the National Work-Life Forum, believes that this larger understanding of family policy is already current in the business world. For example, the 'work/life question' was considered a marginal women's issue at BT until the Forum did a survey revealing that a huge number of the male employees had caring responsibilities, for older relatives as well as with children. Once it became official, it became easier to talk about.

The same thing happened at a German car manufacturer that may or may not be BMW, after the boss talked of having to leave work at six twice a week because his wife was ill. If an issue touches the people at the very top, she says, this has a dramatic effect both on the culture of a business and its policies. This may even explain why the FPSC is so keen on the older generation question lately. According to its director, Ceridwen Roberts, 75 per cent of its staff had eldercare problems last year. 'It does concentrate the mind,' Roberts said.

So far, however, it has failed to concentrate the top minds in government. This Tuesday, at a conference in connection with National Work/Life Balance Week, a speaker from the Department of Trade and Industry was roundly criticised by the audience for focusing only on families with young children, and failing to address the care problems of the older generation.

No doubt Gale Booth will be doing her best to correct this oversight once she's moved into her Downing Street granny flat. She is known to have no qualms about telling Tony what she thinks of his politics. She is particularly vocal on pensioners' rights.

Her very important son-in-law is said not to mind at all. He has already declared that he hopes she will continue to live with them, even after the childcare crisis is over. fields.bodyText: It's never easy to be a lame duck, especially if, like Bill Clinton, you're watching your wife's political career take off at the same time. It may be true that he's proud of her. But her success has both private and public implications for him. From now on, Hillary is going to be just too busy to hold his hand. This is a big problem, one he shares with many other men in his generation. They can no longer go home to their wives for emotional support when they need it, because they are most probably out at work. Luckily for Clinton and his ilk, many of these wives were raised by stay-at-home mothers who retain old-fashioned ideas about maternal duty. Take, for example, Hillary's mother, Dorothy Rodham, famous for being fiercely protective of her daughter, not a bit amused by the Lewinsky saga. But if her daughter wins the electoral race in New York, she will be taking Bill into her condo in Little Rock, Arkansas. He plans to stay there, he says, for a couple of years, while she reigns. Similarly, the Blairs have resolved their upcoming childcare problems after the upset over Ros Marks, their former nanny who tried to sell her story. How relieved they must have been when Cherie's mother offered to move in and babysit. It pleased the public, too. What a good idea, everyone said, to keep it all in the family. It is not, however, anything new. The Invaluable Mother-in-Law is a media staple. Noel Gallagher's mother-in-law made tabloid headlines when she saved her granddaughter's life after the 18-month-old stopped breathing. Not long after that, we had George Best's mother-in-law showing a brave face to reporters asking about the football star's health. 'He's got a stomach upset,' she said loyally. 'He's fine, really.' Then came the cancellation of Anna Kournikova's alleged engagement to hockey star Pavel Bure, allegedly because he baulked at having Mrs Kournikova Snr as a mother-in-law. This prompted columnists to write about how much power mothers-in-law have over the popular imagination. They went on to prove their own point by making a huge flap about Robin Cook's mother, when (after siding with his first wife Margaret during the divorce) she shocked onlookers by chatting with Gaynor at a party. There was another flurry of comment when Terri Apter published a study about tensions between married couples and their mothers. Then the mother-in-law joke had a revival when Italian lawyer Paola Mescoli Davoli started a Mother-in-Law School. Intrusive or disapproving mothers-in-law are cited in 40 per cent of Italy's divorce cases. The only way forward, said Davoli, was to make them use their power more carefully. In Britain, mothers-in-law are getting attention not because they are causing problems, but because people are starting to see how useful they are. One of the fondest hopes of Jack Straw and his Ministerial Group on the Family is that grandparents can be encouraged to play a larger role in rearing their grandchildren. Then the nation's children would be safe and sound while New Labour pushes their mothers into work. According to the Family Policy Studies Centre, grandparents are the main providers of childcare after parents. More than half of mothers and fathers over 50 help their adult children. Grandparents become more involved after family breakdown, but here there is a catch. According to a 1999 study by Geoff Dench and Katrina Thomson, grandfathers feel marginalised if their children divorce. They complained that they had too little time with grandchildren. Grandmothers said they had too much. No government should assume that there is a huge pool of grandparents eager to do childcare. Juliet Mountford of the FPSC says many grandparents feel they deserve time off. They want to travel, take up new hobbies and relax. There is very little research in this country on how grandparents feel about the new roles government is planning for them. Policy-makers 'tend not to take the grandparents' point of view,' says Mountford. Instead they use them to 'fill a gap'. The Family Policy group hopes a number of studies will stop this. Meantime it may be useful to look at the US, where census figures say the number of grandmothers involved in childcare has increased by 41 per cent since 1992. Other statistics identify 1.4 million children whose 'functional' parents are now their grandparents. This is largely an inner-city problem, as more women have been obliged to take over the care of grandchildren after their own children succumb to drug addiction or Aids, family breakdown or the need to find work. Childcare stress is affecting health to such a degree that geriatric parental stress is well under way to becoming a syndrome. Five years ago there wasn't one organisation offering grandparent carers advice and support. Now there are more than 600. There has been a parallel rise in training programmes. Some concentrate on helping grandmothers update their skills. For example, many have trouble helping with homework, because education has changed so much since their day, and they find modern discipline methods perplexing. The most common question, says one grandparent educator, is 'What do you mean they don't spank any more?' Grandparent carers have grown rather militant. The American Association of Retired Persons, with its 30 million members, is a force to be reckoned with. When it brought a test-case about grandparents' visitation rights to the Supreme Court earlier this year, it was one of dozens filed. According to David D Meyer, professor of law at the University of Chicago, the attention this case has received underlines the need for a new definition of the word 'family'. The social reality of modern families was changing dramatically, he said, but our ways of understanding them had not kept pace. Many people in the UK family policy sector share his view. A few months ago, the FSPC published a briefing criticising the Government for being too fixated on childcare, and failing to see the link between childcare and eldercare. It makes little sense to bring grandmothers into the picture as carers of children, while failing to remember that these same women sooner or later will need to be looked after themselves. Traditionally, elderly mothers and mothers-in-law are looked after by daughters and daughters-in-law. But, as we have already noted, these paragons are no longer necessarily at home all day. And the rise in the divorce rate could mean a drastic drop in the number of daughters-in-law who are available at all. As the population ages, family friendly policy is going to be as much about helping employees take care of their elderly relatives as it will be about childcare. Joanna Foster, chair of the women's network the National Work-Life Forum, believes that this larger understanding of family policy is already current in the business world. For example, the 'work/life question' was considered a marginal women's issue at BT until the Forum did a survey revealing that a huge number of the male employees had caring responsibilities, for older relatives as well as with children. Once it became official, it became easier to talk about. The same thing happened at a German car manufacturer that may or may not be BMW, after the boss talked of having to leave work at six twice a week because his wife was ill. If an issue touches the people at the very top, she says, this has a dramatic effect both on the culture of a business and its policies. This may even explain why the FPSC is so keen on the older generation question lately. According to its director, Ceridwen Roberts, 75 per cent of its staff had eldercare problems last year. 'It does concentrate the mind,' Roberts said. So far, however, it has failed to concentrate the top minds in government. webTitle: 'Mommie and Clyde' blaze  trail of deceit and death lies leads to murder

fields.headline: 'Mommie and Clyde' blaze  trail of deceit and death lies leads to murder
fields.standfirst: They conned their way across the US. But the people they duped had a habit of vanishing without trace , reports  Ed Vulliamy  in New York
fields.trailText: Sante Kimes and her son Kenny stepped out of the Manhattan Hilton Hotel for the evening after the July the Fourth Independence Day celebrations in 1998, towards their smart Lincoln Town Car limousine parked in a nearby garage.
fields.body:
Sante Kimes and her son Kenny stepped out of the Manhattan Hilton Hotel for the evening after the July the Fourth Independence Day celebrations in 1998, towards their smart Lincoln Town Car limousine parked in a nearby garage.

They thought they were stepping into a new and luxuriant life as owners of a mansion on the Upper East Side, the deeds for which they had just procured. But suddenly they were handcuffed by FBI and NYPD officers who appeared out of nowhere. Kenny, soiled himself in fear.

The police thought they were arresting 'Manny Guerrero' and his mother Sandy, wanted because the cheque which paid for the car in Utah had bounced. They were charged with theft. 'Manny' asked the officers if this really was about a car. If it was, he joked, he'd buy them all a drink when he got out.

That night, the detective on the Lincoln case was watching the TV news. He saw pictures of a mother and son - Sante and Kenny Kimes - wanted over the disappearance that same day of a wealthy widow, Irene Silverman, famous socialite and owner of a Beaux Arts mansion on East 65th Street. The officer started; he had just booked both mother and son into his cell block.

This weekend, Sante Kimes, aged 64, and her 24-year-old son are at different prisons in New York, waiting for Judge Rena Uviller to direct the jury tomorrow in the most flamboyant and bizarre murder case America has seen since O.J. Simpson - the murder of Irene Silverman.

As the prosecution finished its summing-up at the end of the three-month trial last week, Kenny - a handsome man with chisel jaw and swept-back hair, now wild-eyed and nervous - kept having to leave the courtroom under escort. A detective in the case leaned forward to whisper: 'Say what? Now Kenny is shitting himself - literally.'

It is an ignominious conclusion to the mystery, mayhem and murder that Sante and Kenny Kimes are accused of wreaking across America, a mother-and-son Bonnie & Clyde team - 'Mommie and Clyde' they have been called - rumoured also to be lovers.

It is an intriguing case. For the first time ever in a Manhattan murder trial history there are no witnesses, no forensic evidence and no body. There is only a stockpile of damning circumstantial evidence, and the fact that people have a habit of disappearing after last being seen with Sante and Kenny Kimes.

Irene Silverman was bid goodnight in her home by two guests with whom she had dined on Independence Day evening. She was the daughter of a seamstress and had been a ballet dancer when she married the millionaire broker Sam Silverman, and although he died in 1980, she had not lost her love of life. But she was careful to protect it, only venturing out with friends or handsome male escorts.

Silverman hardly needed the mansion to herself, and let out apartments. Number 1B had been rented to a man she disliked enormously and was planning to evict - the dapper but reticent 'Manny Guerrin', who had paid a $6,000 deposit in cash and produced no references. His real name was Kenny Kimes.

According to the prosecution, Kimes and his mother seized 'that little old lady' outside the door of apartment 1B, dragged her inside, doped her with the 'date-rape' drug Flunitrapezepam, strangled her, wrapped her in a large black duffle bag, loaded the body into the boot of their car and dumped it on their way to meeting the man who was to manage the apartment, which they had just bought at a knock-down price with deeds bearing Silverman's forged signature. According to Kenny Kimes, mouthing the words in court for all to see 'it was suicide'.

'What New York has on trial is a monster,' one of Sante Kimes's own relatives told Vanity Fair recently. She is indeed a scary woman. Her skin is like polished porcelain. She dresses elegantly. Between rounds of evidence, she picks out members of the press and public and fixes them with a cold, sharp stare from her jet-black eyes, deep-set beneath broad-brush black eyebrows, before then offering a friendly wave.

Sante Kimes plagued the Vanity Fair writer with hysterical calls about her love for her son and corruption and violence by the authorities - to the horror of her lawyer.

But tapes which were played in court - and which Kimes herself had recorded - reveal a different woman. The jury heard telephone conversations Kimes held with Silverman - in which she tried to lure her alleged victim to Las Vegas by posing as a company rep offering a free trip. On these, Kimes is silken, and unfazed by Silverman's suspicions.

No one is certain who Sante Kimes is or where she comes from (she says her father was a Holy Man from India), only guesses by the authorities and journalists.

She appears to have been born in Oklahoma, daughter of Rattan and Mary Singhrs, an Indian and an Irish immigrant. Mr Singhrs left his wife and child when the girl was two and her mother became a prostitute in Los Angeles. Sante was probably a victim of sexual abuse and was given up for adoption aged 10.

She set out to climb the social ladder through crime and social scheming, and married Kenneth Kimes, a millionaire member of Washington political circles during the administration of President Gerald Ford, with whom the couple were once photographed.

They were convicted of kidnapping Mexican girls and forcing them to work in 1985. According to a recent book by the New York Daily News crime writer, Kenny demanded sex from the girls when he was aged 10.

But it was after Kenneth Kimes died in 1994, leaving his wife nothing, that her life of serious crime alongside Kenny began in earnest.

In 1998, police in Los Angeles wanted to interrogate Sante and Kenny Kimes in connection with the shooting in May 1998 of a businessman, David Kadzin, whom they had tried to involve in a property scam. But they had vanished again.

There were no grounds on which to detain Sante and Kenny Kimes's over the Kadzin murder, but the LAPD did have something useful: the cheque with which the couple had bought the tinted-windowed Lincoln Town Car in Cedar City, Utah, had bounced, and the police immediately put out an alert.

On the day that Irene Silverman disappeared, the NYPD just happened to find the 'Guerreros' after the appearance of the Kimes's on television. They searched their car.

There they found the ingredients of the Kimes's plan for a new life: a Glock 9mm handgun, a packet of hypodermic syringes, stocks of the 'date-rape' sedative which is 10 times more potent than valium and documents belonging to Silverman - including the forged deeds to her mansion. The prosecution also claims that 14 spiral-bound notebooks, containing lists of weapons and titles of videos about fraud as well as plans of Silverman's building and her Social Security number, are enough to prove intent to murder. The defence, however, says the notebooks are forgeries or may have been altered by police.

No one has proved that mother and son are lovers. But the couple's chauffeur, Jose Alvarez, did testify during the trial that Sante and Kenny Kimes slept in the same bed (he also said he overheard them discuss dumping a body).

During an interview on 60 Minutes, sensuality between them was there for all to see. 'I think [my mother] is a beautiful person,' swooned Kenny. 'Spiritually and intellectually. And physically.'

Judge Rena Uviller had been due to direct the jury on Friday, but she postponed her task until tomorrow. She said that she didn't want to trouble the jurors' minds over this weekend - 'what with Mothers Day [which falls today in the US], which I'm sure some of you will want to celebrate'.

webTitle: Rebels' advance brings Tamil homeland closer

fields.headline: Rebels' advance brings Tamil homeland closer
fields.standfirst:
Demoralised army faces defeat in Jaffna, reports Luke Harding in Colombo

Sri Lankan government website
Tamil Eelam
fields.trailText: Sri Lanka's rebel Tamil Tigers were last night poised to make a final assault on a rambling colonial building at the heart of Jaffna, which has come to symbolise the town's twisting fortunes.
fields.body:
Sri Lanka's rebel Tamil Tigers were last night poised to make a final assault on a rambling colonial building at the heart of Jaffna, which has come to symbolise the town's twisting fortunes.

The Tigers said they were preparing for a final push on Jaffna's administrative headquarters from positions less than a mile away. As thousands of residents fled, fighting continued in the northern outskirts.

Last Wednesday, after five months of holding their position. rebels attacked from across a lagoon a few hundred yards away from the forward observation posts of Sri Lanka's demoralised government army.

At 3am that morning - 36 hours after the Sri Lankan government rejected the Tigers' offer of a temporary ceasefire - 400 élite Tiger troops started crossing from the other side of the lagoon, bringing with them the ferocious weaponry which is enabling them to dominate Sri Lanka's 17-year-old civil war: multi-barrel rocket launchers, heavy artillery and mortars.

The rebels mounted an audacious assault on Jaffna itself, the town they lost in 1995. 'It was a classic pincer movement,' one analyst said. Using devastating mortar fire, the Tigers advanced up both the Ariyalai and Tanankillapu peninsulas, capturing a strategic bridge 3km from central Jaffna. Thousands of government troops further east were cut off. The battle for Jaffna had begun.

In Colombo, Sri Lanka's capital, the military high command said their troops had temporarily readjusted their positions and were now repulsing the enemy. In fact, they were retreating. Although about 40,000 troops had been stationed in Jaffna to guard against a final rebel assault, few wanted to fight.

Many had been on the frontline for three months and were tired. 'The Tigers are highly motivated and extremely well trained. The army, by contrast, is undersupplied, badly prepared and lacking in self-belief,' one military observer said.

In Jaffna itself, a curfew was imposed, as shellfire rang out across the town. About 500,000 civilians spent Thursday sheltering in their homes and offices. 'There is a lot of tension. We can hear the shellfire. But it is unclear where it is coming from,' one aid worker in Jaffna said.

The Ministry of Information, meanwhile, was doing its best to keep the bad news from ordinary Sri Lankans. The BBC's Sinhala and Tamil services were pulled off the air. All live broadcasts and interviews were banned.

As the Tigers secured the main road leading from the east into the outskirts of Jaffna, the military lifted its curfew. On Friday morning, a procession of cars, vans and bicycles could be observed fleeing for the suburbs to the west. The rebels urged residents to get out, using Voice of Tiger radio, their most effective propaganda tool.

Twelve Tiger fighters, who had been living as civilians for several months, made a premature attempt to seize Jaffna's symbolic administrative centre and were killed. Sri Lankan airforce jets launched a belated attack on rebel positions across the lagoon.

Most observers now expect the centre of Jaffna to fall within days. In a statement from its London headquarters, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) claimed they were ready for the final push. 'Heavily armed Tamil Tiger troop formations who have moved in large numbers from LTTE bases in the Vanni [to the south] into the Jaffna theatre of war are gearing up for the decisive battle,' it declared.

The advancing Tigers may yet encounter fiercer resistance than expected, however. Sri Lanka's government under President Chandrika Kumaratunga says it has no plans to evacuate the troops from Jaffna. Sri Lanka's reluctant army has little choice now but to confront the enemy.

If he recaptures Jaffna, the Tigers' leader Velupillai Prabhakaran is expected to return to the negotiating table with a vastly strengthened hand. Prabhakaran has virtually established a de facto Tamil homeland in Sri Lanka's north and east.

webTitle: Islamists prepare for violent last stand in Iran

fields.headline: Islamists prepare for violent last stand in Iran
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: 'For God's sake tell me, is Islam a religion of violence or not?' begged a reader of  Musharekat , mouthpiece of the reformist forces led by the brother of President Khatami of Iran. Most Iranian clergymen, he said, seemed to support the opinions of the country's conservative establishment that, to the devout Muslim, divine commands authorising violence in defence of faith overrule the laws of the state.
fields.body:
'For God's sake tell me, is Islam a religion of violence or not?' begged a reader of Musharekat , mouthpiece of the reformist forces led by the brother of President Khatami of Iran. Most Iranian clergymen, he said, seemed to support the opinions of the country's conservative establishment that, to the devout Muslim, divine commands authorising violence in defence of faith overrule the laws of the state.

Not so, said Musharekat . Days later it was shut down.

The question goes to the heart of the Islamist controversy: is Islam, in its fundamentalist, political form, compatible with democracy? And if it takes power by democratic means, will it ever give it up by the same?

Nowhere could this controversy be more definitively settled than in Iran. The Islamic republic may not have arisen democratically, but it was an expression of popular will. But, like the Shah, the republic, or rather the reactionary clique of mullahs who run it, has become deeply unpopular. That was the verdict of February's general elections.

But the rejoicing was premature. It has become clear the conservatives never intended to cede power, not even to the moderate Islamists of the Khatami school, let alone the secularists. Moreover, they are ideologically and organisationally ready for anti-democratic violence, coercion and intimidation.

webTitle: Panties police go on nudist patrol

fields.headline: Panties police go on nudist patrol
fields.trailText: Sunbathers on Germany's Baltic coast are to be closely watched by nudity monitors enforcing rules that nudists stay on their own beaches and that visitors to nudist beaches take their clothes off. Dubbed 'Höschen-Polizei' - or panties police - by locals, the watchdogs are the idea of Paul Bolle, spa director at Göhren beach resort on the island of Rügen.
fields.body:
Sunbathers on Germany's Baltic coast are to be closely watched by nudity monitors enforcing rules that nudists stay on their own beaches and that visitors to nudist beaches take their clothes off. Dubbed 'Höschen-Polizei' - or panties police - by locals, the watchdogs are the idea of Paul Bolle, spa director at Göhren beach resort on the island of Rügen.

'They will approach people very politely and ask them to stay on their own side of the beach. If someone is wearing clothes on the nudist beach, they will be told to take them off or go elsewhere,' he said.

Bolle's panties police are the latest twist in a battle for Germany's beaches that has been growing since the fall of the Berlin Wall. As Westerners flock to the unspoilt Baltic beaches in the former East Germany, many encounter more of their eastern neighbours than they expected.

'They are much more prudish than the Easterners,' said Anna-Margarete Kraetschell, a family therapist based in the east of Berlin. Although Germany's Baltic coast boasts 68 nudist beaches, a growing number of Easterners are flouting the rules to flaunt themselves on the so-called 'Textilstrände', where bathing costumes are obligatory. Nude bathers face a fine of up to £3,000 for straying off their reservations but nobody has ever been prosecuted for the offence.

Even in Göhren, Bolle predicts his monitors will take an easy-going approach - not least because they have no authority to enforce the nudity rules.

Before reunification, the communist regime in East Germany took an uncharacteristically relaxed view of nudism. 'Nude bathing was one of the few freedoms we had,' said easterner and nude bather Susanne Schulze.

Denis Staunton writes for the 'Irish Times'

fields.headline: The 'other women' who  haunt Hillary
fields.standfirst: Ed Vulliamy on the New York senatorial election trail sees an odd couple: the Mayor playing Hamlet in 'To Run or Not to Run' and the First Lady still having her old problems with infidelity
fields.trailText: Ed Vulliamy on the New York senatorial election trail sees an odd couple: the Mayor playing Hamlet in 'To Run or Not to Run' and the First Lady still having her old problems with infidelity
fields.body:
To keep up, Hillary Clinton now needs to get cancer, ditch Bill, find herself a new beau and have a past affair with a close aide exposed, preferably by her husband at a tearful press conference. That would be a mirror-image of Rudy Giuliani's month, a continuation of the symmetrical tango between the egos of the First Lady and the Mayor of New York who would - most voters agree - make the perfect couple.

Giuliani is playing Hamlet - To Run or Not to Run; to continue in what was already a supercharged election or bow out gracefully, nurse his cancer and luxuriate in the vortex of love that envelops himself and Judi Nathan.

But what also remains unclear is whether the most dramatic month in Giuliani's life is a bane or blessing for Hillary, as the best election of the year twists into something between grand and soap opera and vividly recalls that other domestic drama she lived through more painfully than anyone.

The fallout from Mayor Giuliani's whirlwind affair could leave Hillary facing an opponent energised by love and testosterone, with a cancer sympathy vote enhanced by the properties of a mortal human that had hitherto eluded him but are essential to victory.

Or it could mean an opponent whose moral deportment has dismayed his conservative and Catholic constituencies and whose lack of commitment to the fight deflates his hitherto unswerving crusade for the citizenry of New York. Or, indeed, to her having no serious opponent at all, cruising to victory without doing much.

Whichever turns out to be the case, what is it about Hillary and the men in her life, whether she is married to them or fighting an election against them? Bill and Rudy now appear as soul brothers: they find other women, they brave the flak and, in the case of her husband, they survive it all.

The people did not care about Monica Lewinsky and the polls indicate that, for all the pundits' hand-wringing, they do not care about Giuliani's squeeze either. On Thursday, 77 per cent of voters said his affair was 'a private matter that has no effect on politics' - even more than the 65 per cent of Americans who stayed loyal to President Clinton throughout the Lewinsky scandal.

Both Hillary and the Republicans are in the same fix. On the one hand, after spending her annus horribilis standing by her man throughout his affair with Monica, Hillary can hardly score moral points off Giuliani's with Ms Nathan which is, moreover, less grubby and more serious than her husband's with the intern.

Similarly, Rudy's Republicans, having hounded and impeached President Clinton all that time, would find it hard to dismiss the Mayor's affair as harmless slap-and-tickle on the sidelines of politics.

Like the voters, the right-wing punditry is consistent: Peggy Noonan of the Wall Street Journal emerged as Hillary's baiter-in-chief with her didactic book The Case Against Hillary Clinton. But on Friday, Noonan, a former speechwriter for Ronald Reagan, led the charge, arguing that Rudy must go.

She echoes others: John Podhoretz in Rupert Murdoch's New York Post and a number of Rudy's own aides. Ironically but consistently, only the liberal New York Times - hardly a minnow - sees in Giuliani a man 'fighting back'.

This is the moment of Rudy and his women, a labyrinth comprising his wife, lover, former lover and, by no means least, his political rival.

On the eve of this breathtaking month, Hillary was ahead of Giuliani in the polls for the first time - no mean achievement against a man credited with having rescued New York from being an ungovernable, crime-infested miasma in 1993 to the breezy global capital it is now. It should have been no contest - but that was Rudy's doing, nor hers.

Then came news of Rudy's cancer, which presented Hillary with a political problem. Her aides argued the diagnosis would win her rival a surge of sympathy and should mute the ad hominem flavour of her campaign lexicon. Damn it, Giuliani even had the same cancer strain as that other heroic champion in town, New York Yankees' manager Joe Torre.

If Hillary's difficulty over a series of early blunders in town had been due to heartlessness in the pursuit of ambition, this was time to ease off. And that is more than ever the feeling in Hillary's election camp this weekend. The events have brought about an undeclared shift in tactics; the almost daily attacks have ceased.

Aides say that Mrs Clinton must for once let her rival steal the headlines and 'shut the spigot' on anti-Giuliani rhetoric. Aides are scurrying to re-cast this week's state Democratic convention in Albany as a low-voltage affair.

'They are making the news,' said one senior adviser. 'If we make news now, you can bet it's the wrong kind of news'. And another: 'This is the time when you can make mistakes. It's easy to make a slip of language on Rudy.'

The First Lady herself urged that 'out of respect, we should just leave [Rudy and Donna Hanover] alone to do what's best for them,' to anchor Katie Couric before a 'town meeting' audience of 60 at the Rockefeller Centre on Friday.

But the events still present Hillary with a major difficulty. In the symmetry of the mirror-image love triangle, Monica Lewinsky's opposite number is the upright nurse Judi Nathan - a comparison less than flattering to the Clinton ménage.

Much more seriously, Hillary's own opposite is the righteously indignant Donna Hanover. And for all Hillary's political DNA, she is no Donna, whose foursquare performance over her husband's infidelity casts into sharp relief Hillary's biggest problem with women voters in the polls: the perception that she rides Bill Clinton's coat-tails with slavish loyalty and that her blind ambition leaves her trampled by her husband.

Hillary has not been through the hoop of fire Donna has just leapt through. She has not left Bill. By contrast, not only is Donna refusing to stand by her man, there are no signs she is going to let him off the hook. Confronted by humiliation, Hanover's instincts paralleled Hillary's for a while but have now broken the banks and exposed Hillary's cold weakness.

On Wednesday evening Donna made a passionate declaration unimaginable from Hillary - the equivalent of her dumping Bill over Monica and then invoking the pain of an affair with a 'home town girl' without actually mentioning the name Gennifer Flowers. Donna talked about her husband's affair with one of his 'staff', and in New York that translates as Chrystine Lategano.

Until Donna's remarks last week, allegations of Giuliani's affair with Lategano had been what gamblers call a 'push' no bets paid, every body gets their wager back. They were made and denied but never proved. Now, for all Ms Lategano's denials, Donna herself seems ready to convict her own husband of the Clinton line: 'I did not have sexual relations with that woman.'

Through Hillary's prism, Lategano is Flowers, and she does have Gennifer's steely ruthlessness. But here Giuliani looks the fool: Lategano's appointment as his press secretary and subsequent promotion to communications director was the equivalent to Bill Clinton making Gennifer chief White House spokeswoman.

Giuliani was reported to have hired Lategano after, at her first interview in 1993, she impressed him with a firm grip on New York Yankees baseball trivia.

'She's a real Yankees fan,' boasted Giuliani, introducing her to the public, 'and I can usually tell the difference.' The pinnacle of Lategano's previous career in the private sector was shoe-store sales clerk.

There was one coda to the week's events that could not but raise a smile across every taproom in New York, and reminded voters why only a fool would dismiss Rudy if he does choose to continue against Hillary Clinton. And that was a word of sympathy for the Mayor from the rake whom Americans are realising they will miss terribly.

President Clinton said: 'I wish him and his wife and children well. We should want some space for all of them, out of the glare of publicity, to work their family issues out.'

fields.headline: Test can pinpoint autism 'at birth'
fields.trailText: Scientists have pinpointed a set of chemicals which could identify newborn babies at high risk of developing autism. It is the first time that a clear biological marker for the condition has been identified.
fields.body:
Scientists have pinpointed a set of chemicals which could identify newborn babies at high risk of developing autism. It is the first time that a clear biological marker for the condition has been identified.

The development has caused considerable excitement among doctors and scientists, for it raises the prospect of treating potential patients, virtually from birth.

'This is a very important piece of research,' said Dr Simon Baron-Cohen, co-director of the Autism Research Centre at Cambridge University. 'For the first time, scientists have managed to find factors - at birth - in those that go on to develop the condition.'

Autism is a psychological disorder with a wide spectrum of severity, ranging from mild versions to full-blown Classic Infantile Autism. Symptoms include an inability to communicate, abnormal self absorption and eccentric behavioural characteristics such as an obsession with ordering and sorting things. Boys account for 80 per cent of cases.

Diagnoses are rising, though it is not known if this is due to an increase in numbers of patients or to the improving sensitivities of tests. However, children are often not diagnosed as having autism until they are about four or five - when they have already missed out on crucial years of treatment which typically involves special education and teaching.

'The earlier the diagnosis, the better chance a child has of improving his or her language development and social skills,' said Dr Fiona Scott, Baron-Cohen's Cambridge colleague.

Dr Judith Grether and colleagues at the California Birth Defects Monitoring Programme analysed blood taken from babies born in the state between 1983 and 1985. This sampling is standard, and is carried out to test for the genetic disease phenylketonuria (PKU).

But unlike other states or countries, California does not destroy its baby blood, and has created a vast library of samples. The group used 249 of these for its research, re-testing the blood of children who had subsequently developed autism, as well as re-testing the blood of a standard control group that was unaffected by the condition.

The results astonished the researchers. Of the autistic children, 96.9 per cent had elevated levels of four proteins - chemicals called neuropeptides - that act as chemical messengers in the brain and which are normally associated with cerebral development. None of the control children had elevated levels of these proteins.

'We never expected such clear-cut results,' says Dr Grether. 'We are now looking to replicate those results in a much larger trial, comparing 5,000 autistic children with several thousand control children.'

The team presented their work last week at a meeting of the American Academy of Neurology in San Diego and are now preparing a paper which is to be 'fast-track reviewed' for a leading scientific journal. They remain cautious, but agree their findings 'could be the start of something truly exciting'.

The study is also expected to stimulate considerable debate at next weekend's major international conference, Autism Europe, being held in Glasgow at the end of the Autism Awareness Week to be launched tomorrow across Britain.

If validated, the research suggests it may one day be possible to carry out routine tests for autism in the same way that newborn babies are tested for PKU and thalassemia. But Baron-Cohen warned: 'No test is foolproof. If it exaggerates numbers of cases, then parents will go through a lot of unnecessary anxiety and children will be given unnecessary treatment. But equally we do not know how many cases might be missed by such a test.'

On the other hand, the research also raises the prospect of biomedical interventions for countering autism, which now affects around one in 100 children in Britain. 'If we know that certain neuropeptides are harmful at elevated levels, we could think of altering children's diet while they are babies in a bid to reduce the production of these chemicals in the body,' said Dr Paul Shattock, director of the Autism Research Centre at Sunderland University. 'However, we have had false hopes raised before. More work is needed on this study.'

webTitle: Britain still has a duty to Africa

fields.headline: Britain still has a duty to Africa
fields.trailText: History casts a long shadow, never more so than over Africa. Britain had the largest of the European empires in this troubled continent and, as it slides into chaos, it is Britain that is inevitably at the centre of the disastrous relationship between the two continents. Mr Mugabe's unilateral withdrawal yesterday of dual passport rights from white farmers holding British passports is but the latest manifestation of a crisis that was already serious enough even as Sierra Leone totters on the point of collapse. Mugabe has underlined what was already clear as barbaric rebels descended on Sierra Leone's Freetown. Whether or not we like it, Britain is compelled to engage with the explosive cocktail of poverty, tribalism, resentment and despotism that defines contemporary Africa.
fields.body:
History casts a long shadow, never more so than over Africa. Britain had the largest of the European empires in this troubled continent and, as it slides into chaos, it is Britain that is inevitably at the centre of the disastrous relationship between the two continents. Mr Mugabe's unilateral withdrawal yesterday of dual passport rights from white farmers holding British passports is but the latest manifestation of a crisis that was already serious enough even as Sierra Leone totters on the point of collapse. Mugabe has underlined what was already clear as barbaric rebels descended on Sierra Leone's Freetown. Whether or not we like it, Britain is compelled to engage with the explosive cocktail of poverty, tribalism, resentment and despotism that defines contemporary Africa.

The Conservatives have been quick to criticise the Government's response in Sierra Leone. Britain should keep out, they say. If the United Nations cannot handle events, then so be it. No more the White Man's Burden; no more humanitarian interventions. British soldiers and sailors should not bail them out.

But over Zimbabwe, the Conservatives take a different tack. Any intervention is contemplated to protect the interests of white farmers. Every looting, beating and murder is reported in depth. If there is a mass exit from Zimbabwe, there will be as intense pressure to welcome Zimbabwe's whites as there has been to deter asylum-seekers.

The hypocrisy of the position is unsustainable. Britain was right to send troops to Sierra Leone. The written thanks of the UN Secretary General Kofi Annan are testimony to the importance of what we have done. A vital respite has been won while underequipped and undermanned UN forces are replenished. Britain is thus morally equipped to make a calibrated intervention in Zimbabwe, if any is needed. We act to preserve black and white lives alike from despotism, through whatever means we judge most effective.

The more open question is what to do about attacking the roots of the crises throughout Africa. The West needs to revisit the idea of constructing stabilisation funds to support world commodity prices, a form of aid that directly helps Africa without clumsy, direct economic programmes that have failed so frequently. A rapid deployment force needs to be constructed, with a critical mass of well-trained Western soldiers capable of intervening to support UN mandates.

That is for the medium term. In the here and now, we have to act and the Government deserves full support for what it has done in Sierra Leone and what it may have to do in Zimbabwe.

webTitle: At least 20 killed in huge explosion at Dutch fireworks warehouse

fields.headline: At least 20 killed in huge explosion at Dutch fireworks warehouse
fields.trailText: A disaster area was declared in the Dutch town of Enschede last night after an explosion in a fireworks warehouse killed at least 20 people and left 100 wounded.
fields.body:
A disaster area was declared in the Dutch town of Enschede last night after an explosion in a fireworks warehouse killed at least 20 people and left 100 wounded.

Amateur film footage showed a huge fireball rising over Enschede. Dozens of secondary explosions rocked the town.

The mayor said last night: 'This is truly a calamity.' Ten firefighters were missing, he said, but it was not clear whether they were included in the figure of 20 dead.

The explosions rocked heavily populated parts of Enschede, 85 miles east of Amsterdam.

Fire crews were called in from nearby Germany and casualties were ferried to hospitals in other Dutch cities as Enschede struggled to cope . A local air force base was also being used to treat the wounded.

The explosion was felt in neighbouring towns, blew out windows across Enschede and set fire to the city's Grolsch brewery.

'We heard a huge explosion and then we thought, we're finished,' an unidentified eyewitness told RTL-4 television station. 'We had no idea what was happening. All we knew was there was no place to escape.'

'I was sitting in a cafe and all of a sudden there was a huge explosion. Beer glasses shattered, window panes were blown out and people were hit by slabs of concrete," said a teenager.

A statement issued by the municipality said the explosion was the result of a fire that broke out at the SE fireworks warehouse during the afternoon. The cause of the fire was not immediately known but it followed a spell of unseasonably warm and exceptionally dry weather, with temperatures in the upper 20s.

fields.headline: Young Lions lose their bite
fields.trailText: Joint manager and expecting father Keith Stevens has booked his wife into hospital to be induced a week before the play-off final, to avoid any needless distractions from Wembley. Having watched his young Millwall charges fail to take charge of a match they dominated, maybe his planning was premature.
fields.byline: Amy Lawrence at The New Den
fields.body:
Joint manager and expecting father Keith Stevens has booked his wife into hospital to be induced a week before the play-off final, to avoid any needless distractions from Wembley. Having watched his young Millwall charges fail to take charge of a match they dominated, maybe his planning was premature.

Wigan were such sure pre-season bets for promotion they should have been savouring the smell of Ambre Solaire and sea salt by now. But all the good work of a 25 match unbeaten start to the season was unstitched by a recent slump.

So they will have to do it the hard way, and here they were sweating in south east London. Their response - determined and uncompromising if not exactly the epitome of creativity - gives them the edge for the second leg.

Fear of a traditional Den welcome may have had something to do with the reduced number of travelling Athletic supporters, a few hundred huddled together in a 4,000-seater stand.

They seemed cheerful enough, in spite of Millwall's attempt to put the frighteners on them by introducing that most fearsome of old boys Terry Hurlock to stoke up the locals before kick off. It was deafening. 'No-one likes us,' they bawled at him. He grinned mischievously back and shook a knowing fist. The atmosphere was certainly fruity.

But actually this is a likeable Millwall team. Built around a crop of fresh-faced homegrown talent they played with a zest and verve that ought to have forced a first-half lead. Lucas Neill and Tim Cahill sparked energetically in midfield, and Wigan, for all their experience, struggled to contain the threat of effervescent striker Neil Harris dovetailing well with the rather more direct force of Paul Moody.

His white kit muddied in minutes as proof of his unshakeable commitment, Moody launched himself at everything, including a couple of crosses so nearly converted. Darren Sheridan was handily positioned to clear one off the line while the other ballooned over the crossbar.

The visitors, who included a number of players with Premiership know-how, seldom bothered Tony Warner in the Millwall goal. A Simon Haworth chance that spun dangerously off David Tuttle was about as dangerous as it got until after the hour mark, when Andy Liddell's whipped in crosses became an increasing problem for Millwall.

Liddell continued to grow in influence and when Haworth made the connection on another fizzing centre the best part of 14,000 lions were relieved to see the ball fly narrowly wide.

There's a conspiracy theory going around in Wigan that the players aren't exactly killing themselves for promotion because they fear millionaire chairman Dave Whelan will sell them all to build a new team for a new division. The way they stuck resiliently to the task, and ended up unscathed and in the ascendancy answered that one. For the time being at least.

Let battle recommence in Lancashire, where it may be a case of what goes around comes around. Millwall feel they owe Wigan for inflicting Wembley heartbreak at the Auto Windscreens Final last May. There's still a lot to be settled on Wednesday night.
