fields.headline: It's great to be back
fields.trailText: Ed Giddins reflects on his season with Warwickshire and a certain call from David Graveney on Saturday morning as the first Test approaches.
fields.body:
When the phone goes at 8.15 on a Saturday morning I'm usually not that chuffed, particularly if I'm watching Aerobics Oz Style , but yesterday I didn't mind one little bit.

David Graveney told me I was in the England squad to face Zimbabwe this week and I'm thrilled. He had apparently consulted my county captain, Neil Smith, as well as Bob Woolmer and Allan Donald so obviously a few people feel I'm doing something right. I've now got the chance to play in a Test match at Lord's and it doesn't really get any better than that. I've played in a one-day final at Headquarters and that was special, but a Test appearance there really would be the icing on the cake.

The fact that I have played a Test match before stands me in good stead. First time around I did feel that little bit of extra pressure - I don't think I'd be normal if I didn't - but now that pressure will be much reduced which means I can concentrate solely on the job in hand.

Whenever there is a Test or tour on the horizon there is always plenty of speculation as to who is going to be picked. In the past I always felt on edge, but this past week I have managed to block it all out. The fact that I ignored all the gossip is a sure sign that I'm on an even keel.

With so little meaningful cricket having been played so far this summer the squad will be meeting up at Lord's tomorrow morning and that means we will be able to put in three days' solid practice to prepare ourselves for the game. When the weather was so bad before the Oval Test last summer we headed to Lord's and the facilities there are second to none. I can hardly wait to get my head down and do some hard work with the rest of the England squad.

I'm delighted that my Warwickshire colleague Nick Knight has also been picked. He thoroughly deserves his chance as he has been in wonderful touch so far this season and now has a chance to really cement his place in the England set-up. We've long been aware that he is far more than just a one-day specialist. He doesn't just bring his bat to the game, he is also an outstanding fielder.

The work I put in over the winter has done me the power of good and I'm in no doubt that I'm bowling as well as I've ever done. The wickets have been much flatter this year and that means extra work for the bowlers, so I've been delighted with how I've performed in the early part of the season.

I've often said that batting requires a strong mental approach but bowling is not too different. On flat tracks you have to work the batsmen out and I enjoy nothing better than getting players to select the wrong stroke. It is very satisfying to win the mental battle.

On the county circuit Warwickshire have made a very encouraging start. We got much the better of a draw with Glamorgan in our opening championship match and in this round we've piled up a huge score against Sussex which should see us home fairly comfortably. It's great to see both Dougie Brown and Ashley Giles get big scores.

There has been some pressure on the bowlers since Allan Donald damaged his ribs in that nasty collision with the advertising boards at Southampton but others have stepped up magnificently in his absence. Alan Richardson has bowled very well in this game and is getting better with each appearance he makes for the first XI. Dougie's taking wickets as well as scoring runs so I'm confident we'll be climbing out of Division Two at the first attempt.

Once this game is over my mind will turn completely to England and the task ahead. I've got so many positives to carry into this game, I'm really confident that I'll do very well if I make the side.

Everybody has a bad game once in a while and it does play on your mind, but I've got good recent memories to take to Lord's. The final game before a Test match is hugely important as your form in that particular game is what you carry with you into the Test. My memories of this game at Hove are particularly good since I've bowled well on a very flat wicket.

I was disappointed to be passed over for the trip to South Africa last winter and decided to something about it. All that work at Lilleshall is paying off and I'm a better cricketer for it. I'm perfectly prepared, physically and mentally, for this game and I intend to grab my chance. I would be desperately disappointed to get to the end of my career with only one England cap.

My appetite for the game has never diminished and the thought of a Lord's Test is almost too good to be true.

It is a wonderful feeling to be selected to represent your country and one I hope to experience as many times as possible. This is a very important summer for English cricket both domestically and on the international stage. I'm off to a good start, long may it continue.

fields.headline: Contracted to perform
fields.trailText: Vic Marks reviews the selectors choices for the first Test.
fields.body:
There was joy for an Observer columnist (trust he won't require a pay rise) and a Durham rookie when David Graveney announced the squad of 13 for the Lord's Test, which begins on Thursday. Included for the first time is the lanky 21-year-old pace bowler Steve Harmison, while Ed Giddins, who made his Test debut at The Oval last year, is surprisingly recalled.

Graveney said that the meeting held at Chelmsford on Friday night before the announcement in front of the Channel 4 cameras at Headingley yesterday morning (a nice little Friday night drive for him) had been dominated by the choice of pace bowlers to accompany the seniors, Darren Gough and Andrew Caddick. Old timers Angus Fraser and Martin Bicknell were discussed, so were youngsters Alex Tudor and Matthew Hoggard.

Explaining the selectors' choice Graveney said that the name of Harmison was often 'the first mentioned when I talked to county captains and senior players on the circuit. He is capable of bowling at speed and with hostility'. No one will claim that he is reliable at this stage of his career as a succession of wides in Durham's B&H quarter-final against Lancashire on Tuesday testifies, but he is capable of bowling some serious deliveries and already, after only 37 matches in English domestic cricket, he has a reputation for hitting batsmen (with the ball). It's a bold choice and probably a better move than the recall of an old reliable warhorse like Fraser.

It seems that Giddins' self-financed winter fitness campaign has paid dividends. Graveney said: 'He would have been disappointed at his level of fitness when he played last summer. He needed to work on that and he's done so at his own expense [he spent much of the winter holed up at Lilleshall]. That has to be applauded. He's a very talented, very clever bowler and he may well benefit from [Allan] Donald taking him under his wing at Warwickshire this summer'.

Giddins' ability to swing the ball at a slightly greater pace than Bicknell was crucial. Graveney was conscious of last year's Lord's Test against New Zealand (lost by England) when the ball swung consistently, especially for Dion Nash. Neither Gough, Caddick nor Harmison are considered big swingers of the ball by the selectors so Giddins gives them a 'swinging' option. The final decision over which pacemen are to accompany Gough and Caddick will be left until the morning of the match. None of the squad will be sent home early.

The other non-contracted player selected is Warwickshire's Nick Knight, a double centurion this summer, who will bat at number six. Normally an opener, he has however batted for England at number six before; indeed his solitary Test century at Headingley against Pakistan in 1996 was in that position. Graham Thorpe, in poor form so far this summer was also discussed as were Northamptonshire's David Sales and Somerset's Marcus Trescothick, though Graveney pointed out that these selection meetings were also used for monitoring likely lads for the future as well as the make up of the next Test side.

Of the contracted players Lancashire's Chris Schofield will be the most excited this weekend. Graveney lamented the standard of spin bowling in this country and went on to point out that even at international level finger spinners were in decline. 'There are only Saqlain and Murali, who are unorthodox anyway, and New Zealand's Daniel Vettori'. So England are following the international trend by tossing in a wrist-spinner. It's a huge gamble - before this year Schofield had played only 12 first-class matches. It may be justifiable against Zimbabwe; but the selectors may be warier when the sterner opposition from the Caribbean arrive in this country, especially since Brian Lara, a master against spin if his mind is right, will presumably be taking guard. Graveney wistfully noted that Schofield has also been scoring useful runs this season.

He also conceded that 'it was difficult not to play the contracted players at this stage'. The season has been curtailed by poor weather and 18 May is the earliest a Test has ever been played in this country; so the decisions made in February about the contracted players had to stand. There simply was not enough evidence either way to change course. Hereafter, Graveney admitted there would be an element of trial and error about the system. For example what happens if Knight (non-contracted) scores a century and Michael Vaughan (contracted) returns to fitness and form?

For the moment they are sticking with the plans hatched in the winter, which means that Mike Atherton has a new opening partner in Mark Ramprakash, though they did open up together for the England Under-19 side over a decade ago. Hussain insists that he will bat at three, Hick at four, Stewart five, Knight and then Flintoff; thereafter they must study the skies and the vagaries of the Lord's pitch. Neither openers are in blistering form. Indeed Atherton, ever since he declared that English domestic cricket was rubbish, has barely scored a run for Lancashire.

fields.headline: Stoke first off the blocks
fields.trailText: Gillingham and injury-time goals in the play-offs seem destined to be wedded together. A year after losing to Manchester City at Wembley despite being 2-0 up in the last minute, the Gills player-coach, Andy Hessenthaler, went some way to erasing the memory with a 20-yard goal in the fourth minute of injury time that at least gives his side hope in Wednesday's second leg.
fields.body:
Gillingham and injury-time goals in the play-offs seem destined to be wedded together. A year after losing to Manchester City at Wembley despite being 2-0 up in the last minute, the Gills player-coach, Andy Hessenthaler, went some way to erasing the memory with a 20-yard goal in the fourth minute of injury time that at least gives his side hope in Wednesday's second leg.

Until then it had seemed that three goals from Stoke had sealed their fate. Perhaps it was because Gillingham couldn't quite believe they were back in the play-offs that they were caught stone cold from the kick-off. There were just 25 seconds on the clock when Kyle Lightbourne carved his way down the left and laid the ball into the path of Arnar Gunnlaugsson to hit a shot into the roof of the net. Seven minutes later, Gunnlaugsson, on a loan spell from Leicester, had returned the favour, combining with Brynjar Gunnarsson to set up his Icelandic team-mate. He knocked the ball across for Lightbourne who side-footed a shot past Vince Bartram.

But Gillingham managed to dampen the home-side's premature celebrations when they hit back in the 17th minute to cap an extraordinary opening period. The Stoke defence failed to clear Iffy Onuora's cross and Ty Gooden's scuffed shot bobbled across the line. And, like a boxer knocked down in the first round who has somehow managed to survive and even responded with a couple of punches himself, the longer the match wore on the more Gillingham regained their composure.

Indeed, in the opening 15 minutes of the second half they pummelled Stoke without finding a way through only to fall victim to the classic sucker punch. Gunnlaugsson, reduced largely to peripheral figure following a devastating opening, broke away to put over a cross that Peter Thorne headed against the post. It swung the momentum back towards Stoke and in the 65th minute they restored their two-goal cushion.

Graham Kavanagh swung over a ball James O'Connor met with a powerful header Bartram did well to beat away only to see Thorne follow up for an easy tap in, his 30th goal of the season.

It should have been the knock-out blow for Gillingham's chances but they refused to lie down and Hassenthaler's late effort was no more than they deserved.

fields.headline: Key decisions rock Turner
fields.standfirst: Hartlepool  Darlington Liddle 35, Gabbiadini 76pen att 6,995 :   0 2
fields.trailText: Darlington manager David Hodgson was hit on the head by a missile thrown from the crowd as his team took a significant stride towards the Third Division play-off final.
fields.body:
Darlington manager David Hodgson was hit on the head by a missile thrown from the crowd as his team took a significant stride towards the Third Division play-off final.

Trouble broke out after a controversial second goal - a penalty by Marco Gabbiadini in the 77th minute. Gabbiadini sparked the award with a crossfield pass to Glen Naylor, who looked offside before he was brought down by keeper Martin Hollund, who was sent off, and Hartlepool's Wembley ambitions probably went with him.

Craig Liddle, the former Middlesbrough defender, earned Darlington a crucial advantage near the end of the first half that might have started with his dismissal.

Liddle found space near the penalty spot in the 36th minute to meet Gabbiadini's inviting header with a decisive half volley past keeper Martin Hollund.

Hartlepool's dismay at the setback was only heightened by the knowledge that Liddle had benefited from referee Barry Knight's leniency after five minutes. Liddle brought down James Coppinger as the striker broke forward.

Hartlepool fans demanded a red card; Knight chose to caution Liddle - a decision that was to have a major repercussion with his important goal.

Until Liddle's goal, chances had been rare in a derby of enormous passion. Darlington created only one other clear first-half opportunity when Peter Duffield's 18-yarder was saved by Hollund.

Hartlepool went close after only 10 minutes when Ian Clark's left-foot shot swerved against a post. But they escaped when Gabbiadini later just failed to beat defender Micky Barron on the line.

Chris Turner's team should have levelled in the 56th minute when Craig Midgley shot across goal with substitute Gary Jones unable to get a decisive touch.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Working as Glenys Kinnock's parliamentary aide taught Oona King all about political life - though she never quite mastered diary keeping. Seven years later, Old Labour and New Labour have never been so cosy
fields.trailText: Working as Glenys Kinnock's parliamentary aide taught Oona King all about political life - though she never quite mastered diary keeping. Seven years later, Old Labour and New Labour have never been so cosy
fields.body:
Glenys Kinnock I knew about Oona before I even met her. She's this larger-than-life figure who's impossible not to miss. But we first met in 1993, the year before I was elected to the European Parliament. I'd just arrived in Strasbourg, and because I was a novice, I thought it would be good to work with someone vibrant who knew their way round the European Parliament building as well as round the issues. We hit it off immediately, basically because we made each other laugh. In development, the issues can be quite depressing, so it's good to have someone around who can lighten things up. She's great at laughing at herself, too, and has never had any pomposity. We talk seriously, and she'll confide in me, though not as a mother figure. She assumes she's not perceived as intelligent - but she's actually highly intelligent, perceptive and energetic.

I always said Oona would go on to great things because I could see she had real political acumen. The only thing she wasn't good at was managing a diary, which meant I was never where I should have been. Once, I was heading for a meeting in the wrong direction in a taxi which then crashed, so I had to run to the right address. It was a nightmare, and of course when I told Oona she was terribly apologetic and serious about it. But after a while we both burst out laughing. It was just the thought of this poor taxi driver sitting on the pavement crying because his car was wrecked, and me crying because my life was in ruins.

She sometimes gets herself into pickles. Nothing goes disastrously wrong, but there's a little twist of fate and suddenly all her plans have changed. There's always a slight edge of chaos, yet she's very focused.

I was part of her life when she was preparing for her wedding. Dear, oh dear! What a massive exercise that was! I don't go in for that kind of thing, but the wedding was lovely. Her husband, Tiberio Santomarco, is very long-suffering.

We both have tantrums about things, but never with each other. We never disagree on political issues either. I don't even have to ask her, I just know her views are the same as mine on anything from freedom of information to single parents. She's also deeply caring. She's a very important role model for women. She's also a great asset to the Labour Party - a young black woman who went to the local comprehensive and has her roots in the local community.

People have labelled us as Old Labour and New Labour, but I hate that definition. We're a mixture of both. The main difference is our age and our roots. Oona is a Londoner through and through, whereas I was brought up in north Wales. Also, politically, my family were steeped in the Party, whereas hers was not. However, her dad was a Vietnam draft dodger so she's always had a strong political motivation.

Before she worked with me, she hadn't specialised in development, but it was no surprise to me when she chose to be on the select committee on international development, which monitors Britain's money spent on development and reports back from places such as Mozambique and Rwanda. It was incredible being with Oona in Zambia last month. We went to promote Oxfam's education campaign because the literacy levels and school attendance levels in Zambia are some of the worst in the world. I think we made a great double act. We held meetings with teachers and parents, and because we weren't in competition with each other, we could balance the subject and manage the answers.

Oona King My first impression of Glenys was that she wasn't like a normal politician. By that I mean she hadn't had all the humour entirely squeezed out of her. That's probably why we get on so well. It depends, of course, whether you meet Glenys on or off the record. On the record, she's one of the most accomplished parliamentarians. Off the record, she's one of the funniest people you'd ever wish to have a laugh with. She's quieter than me, because after so many years of being at the very heart of British politics (literally in the belly of the beast) she's learned to be more restrained. But when she's not in public she's far, far more outrageous than I am.

She's not bossy and was never frightening to work for but she's forceful and she usually gets what she wants. When she doesn't, the inside of her office will probably get to hear about it, but never the outside. She's almost demure outside. She's taught me a lot. I remember putting out a press release in which I repeated a joke she'd made about 'such and such' being about as funny as Michael Portillo with a broken hair dryer. I thought it was quite entertaining and astute, but when she saw it she just gave me this withering look. She didn't want people to think she was just there to make jokes. 'That's not the way you change things in politics,' she said. She was right. Five years later, I'm now an MP for Bethnal Green and Bow and I would never do that.

We quarrelled all the time, though never seriously. It was often because Glenys thought she'd given me a piece of paper when I was sure she hadn't. I think I was utterly on top of every aspect of my job, with the exception of the diary, which we continually argued over. I'd send her to the wrong country with a speech I'd prepared on the wrong issue. If you work for a high-profile politician, the diary will probably kill you in the end. I remember Neil Kinnock often ringing me at 11pm wanting to know which country his wife was in.

We share a similar sense of humour, which is quite sarcastic and fairly dry, but you can't use that in public too much because people misunderstand it. I've learned there are times to be serious and times not to be serious.

Many politicians might think, what's the point of a field trip like ours, but Glenys always reminds me that this is the only way of getting to the essence, to the loss and the suffering. You can't imagine the enthusiasm she brought to Zambia. Seeing her with 40 five- to 10-year-olds clapping and singing songs brought joy to everyone's faces. She was a teacher for 30 years and she's got a real talent for it. She arranged for some schools there to twin with schools from her own constituency. We never stopped being shocked: more teachers were dying of Aids than passing through training.

In Brussels, we spent 12 hours a day together, but when I got elected and had my own constituency to look after, I stopped being as close with virtually everyone I'd been close with before - that's the very, very worst thing about being a politician.

 Oxfam's Education Now campaign (01865 313 123)

fields.headline: Wenger boys gunning for glory
fields.trailText: Amy Lawrence takes a long, hard look at Arsenal and finds that Uefa Cup is not enough for the north London club.
fields.byline: But  Amy Lawrence says that the Uefa Cup is not enough
fields.body:
Never, in three-and-a-half compelling years at Arsenal, has Arsène Wenger looked so completely ruined as when his team whimpered out of the Champions League last winter. As Gabriel Batistuta nailed the coffin shut on Arsenal's suicidal European experiment at Wembley, the Frenchman was laid low by a hammer blow of responsibility. There was no light in his eyes. Inside he was as good as empty. Because he is normally a man of logic and calm people don't think he is a winning animal. But he is. And this particular defeat was a wretched wound.

Like Manchester United before them, and Chelsea in recent months, the Champions League has begun to grip Arsenal like some kind of obsession. So fixating is its promise that it overshadowed the build-up to the Uefa Cup Final. Until second place in the Premiership was assured, looking forward to a showpiece against Galatasaray was a waste of valuable energy. Don't mix the icing until you've baked the cake, as they say.

'Today at a club like Arsenal the Uefa Cup is not enough to give you a complete season. The basic thinking is you need to be in the Champions League. If you are not the players feel they are not at the top,' remarks Wenger.

It reveals a lot about where Arsenal are now, and indeed where they want to be, that they can be so apparently blasé about a European final. Come back, if you will, to Copenhagen circa 1994. The red half of north London was delirious that their team made the Cup Winners' Cup Final, a now defunct competition that was ranked below the Uefa Cup in the Euro hierarchy. Even though there was a good chance of getting tonked by a talented Parma side, simply being there was a source of heart-swelling pride. Lee Dixon's reaction come final whistle summed up Arsenal's sense of wonderment. 'How the hell have we won that?' he chuckled.

Only six years ago and yet it feels like a different era. Admittedly four members of the defence that night, those indomitables who famously put the nil into one-nil-to-the-Arsenal, could line up again at the Parken Stadium next week (only the dear departed Steve Bould is missing). Other than that, since 1994 the club has gone through such a radical transformation on and off the field that John Jensen would barely recognise it.

Back then, the boys drank lager tops and now they munch creatine and greens. Back then, they were kicked off the training field at 1pm by the owners and now they regularly choose to stay at the club's complex until teatime to use the gyms and jacuzzis. Back then, the injured had one leg machine at their disposal and now they get sent abroad to continental gurus for a telling tweak of the spine. Back then, tactics meant defending like lions, pumping the ball up to Ian Wright and ignoring midfield (Ian Selley and Stephen Morrow played the games of their lives in Copenhagen but were hardly previous incarnations of Petit and Vieira). Back then, George Graham's job was safe as houses. Back then Arsenal knocked out Paris Saint-Germain and had a right good laugh at the French.

Monsieur Wenger had a monumental impact on Arsenal. 'The way the club has moved on has been quite unbelievable,' says Dixon. 'Every single aspect of the club has changed and I can't emphasise how much Arsène has had to do with that. He has been a massive influence on the club. I don't think it would have been possible to move forward with such pace under anyone else. The team, the facilities, the professionalism, everything is spot-on.'

Last winter though, Wenger's judgment was seriously questioned for the first time since winning the Double in his first full season. His squad were hideously inconsistent, supposedly on the verge of breaking up, and out of every competition except the one that represented their own failings, as Champions League flops, most vividly. They went to Bradford and Middlesbrough and looked completely spineless. 'Speaking to their players afterwards they said we didn't look like we were really up for it,' admits Martin Keown. 'It's very important you get stuck in and show you mean business.'

Business only returned to normal when a host of key players, who had been in and out for most of the campaign, clicked back into the side. For months Tony Adams had been on the treatment table. Marc Overmars was sidelined, Dennis Bergkamp injury prone and fitful, the Petit/Vieira axis off kilter.

Take all those crucial cogs out the Arsenal machine and it's no surprise they struggled. Get them all purring again, et voilà! - a 12-match winning streak. 'It was a big boost to have everybody back, it motivated everybody again,' says Wenger. 'The return of Tony Adams especially was very influential.'

A fruitful Uefa Cup run helped Arsenal's revival too. It brought, in Keown's words, 'light at the end of the tunnel'. It helped kick a few bad habits, by reminding them how to win away games and, for future benefit, convincing them they can win 'home' games against continental opponents. Roll on Barcelona at intense Highbury next season instead of the wide plains of Wembley?

Having learned to appreciate the much-abused Uefa Cup, Arsenal now want to win it. Attracting, and indeed keeping, the highest calibre players is a damn sight easier when you've notched up another honour. It at least gives the likes of Petit and Overmars something to chew on before they get their agents on the case.

The idea they might be so set on leaving they could take the Anelka route invites fighting talk from Wenger: 'The way he left will make other clubs think it is not too easy to take players away from Arsenal Football Club, especially players on long contracts. Although Anelka finally went the clubs had to pay the right price. That might give some clubs something to think about.'

Fortunately for Arsenal, Anelka's sparkling replacement Thierry Henry has the air of a man who has found his natural home at Highbury. So enamoured is he with his new club he dropped in last Friday night to support the youngsters in the FA Youth Cup final.

Arsenal fans who have been whinging about the lack of home-grown talent to emerge over the past decade should soon be placated. An aggressive new policy led by Liam Brady is bearing fruit. The kids now chase a treble, with the under-17s and under-19s in academy finals.

So much promise all over the park: German Moritz Volz is odds-on to soon push for Dixon's spot. Jay Bothroyd has a touch of the Kanus. Jermaine Pennant can do things of which Ray Parlour can only dream. Captain Graham Barrett is not alone hoping this was only the first of many big games he would play for the club.

Students of Arsenal history should recall that the club's last FA Youth Cup triumph came in 1994, the year of Copenhagen.

Marc Overmars was sidelined, Dennis Bergkamp injury prone and fitful, the Petit/Vieira axis off kilter. Take all those crucial cogs out the Arsenal machine and it's no surprise they struggled. Get them all purring again, et voilà! - a 12-match winning streak. 'It was a big boost to have everybody back, it motivated everybody again,' says Wenger. 'The return of Tony Adams especially was very influential.' A fruitful Uefa Cup run helped Arsenal's revival too. It brought, in Keown's words, 'light at the end of the tunnel'. Attracting, and indeed keeping, the highest calibre players is a damn sight easier when you've notched up another honour. It at least gives the likes of Petit and Overmars something to chew on before they get their agents on the case. Fortunately for Arsenal, Anelka's sparkling replacement Thierry Henry has the air of a man who has found his natural home at Highbury. So enamoured is he with his new club he dropped in last Friday night to support the youngsters in the FA Youth Cup final. Arsenal fans who have been whinging about the lack of home-grown talent to emerge over the past decade should soon be placated. An aggressive new policy led by Liam Brady is bearing fruit. The kids now chase a treble, with the under-17s and under-19s in academy finals. So much promise all over the park: German Moritz Volz is odds-on to soon push for Dixon's spot. Jay Bothroyd has a touch of the Kanus. Jermaine Pennant can do things of which Ray Parlour can only dream. Captain Graham Barrett is not alone hoping this was only the first of many big games he would play for the club. Students of Arsenal history should recall that the club's last FA Youth Cup triumph came in 1994, the year of Copenhagen. How they should line up Arsenal David Seaman Lee Dixon Martin Keown Tony Adams Silvinho Ray Parlour Patrick Vieira Emmanuel Petit Marc Overmars Dennis Bergkamp Thierry Henry Galatasaray Claudio Taffarel Carlos de Oliveira Capone Gheorghe Popescu Korkmaz Bulent Umit Davala Gheorghe Hagi Kaya Suat Buruk Okan Hakan Unsal Erdem Arif Hakan Sukur

fields.headline: Godfather of Galatasaray
fields.standfirst: Fatih Terim is, as he tells  Amy Lawrence , a manager, a protector and a Svengali
fields.trailText: Galatasaray manager Fatih Terim is, as he tells Amy Lawrence , also a protector and a Svengali.
fields.body:
Although supporters are banned from Galatasaray's training ground, there's one fanatic, an old eccentric with a faraway gaze in a faded brown suit, who is allowed in to watch practice whenever he likes. He's a poet, and every day he picks his moment to overwhelm the sound of boot thudding against ball by orating stream-of-consciousness verse at the top of his voice. His odes are inspired by his favourite muse. 'Fatih Terim, Fatih Terim,' he starts up melodramatically. 'Emperor of Galatasaray...'

As figureheads go, Terim stands alone in Turkish football. He was already worshiped for breathing new life into the national team before he began casting his spell on the country's most exalted club. Galatasaray currently shine like never before. They are on the verge of their fourth successive championship. With the domestic cup in the bag and a European final next week, they have in their sights a treble that would send the club's 18 million supporters worldwide into unprecedented raptures. Tell him he's probably the most successful coach in the entire continent operating outside the superpower countries of Spain, Italy, England and Germany and he won't disagree. Strutting around in own-label leisurewear embossed by his ornate signature, he's as comfortable with his status as the main man.

It's sunset at the club's luxurious complex in the lush Florya district of Istanbul. Terim is sitting under the trees in the dappled shade sipping tea, his two grinning daughters rush over for a kiss hello, and he contemplates his lot. 'It's a nice life and we have had four years of success but I ask myself what more can I do? That's my way. One of my principles is to go further and further. No limits.'

He is ambitious, out of contract in the summer, and keen to broaden his horizons. AC Milan, among other European heavyweights, are keeping a close eye on developments.

People constantly beg him to stay. He's an icon in these parts. 'He is the soul of the club, his influence is huge, he is simply number one,' gushes Gala's attacker Arif. 'He's like a father to us and a brother to us.' And an uncle, who has been known to pay the players from his own pocket when wages were late. And a godfather, who accepts no messing and no disrespect and acts accordingly if any rules are breached.

He has cracked it with his players. He has managed to get the balance between fear, trust, respect and love. They play for Terim as much as they play for themselves or their shirt. The relationship between players and boss works, he reckons, because he is young enough, at 46, to understand what makes them tick, but also experienced enough to guide them. They talk a lot, about life as well as football matters, and it has created a fantastic bond. Team spirit is one of their major assets.

'All my players know if anything happens they must come and talk to me,' he insists. 'Personal problem, parents problem, wife problem, girlfriend problem, I have seen everything.' His penchant for talking, coupled with his immense confidence and charisma, has kept everyone on track during a bizarre season - on the one hand so thriving on the field, on the other so turbulent off it. In the aftermath of the Leeds incident some have forgotten that Galatasaray bore grief of their own. The Turkish earthquake was incredibly hard to come to terms with. Hakan Sukur's ex-wife was killed and Claudio Taffarel required therapy to overcome anxiety attacks.

The deaths of two Leeds fans in Instanbul dismayed and saddened Terim, an anglophile, because he found it so inexplicable. He has willingly performed the role of spokesman and diplomat and he will continue to do so as long as people demand soundbites, but inwardly he believes it is time to move on. Closing the chapter rather than stoking the fire would have been a better prelude to Copenhagen. 'But,' as he is fond of saying, 'what can you do?'

Mental fortitude, not a characteristic normally associated with Turkish football, has become a Galatsaray hallmark. This is the strongest Cim Bom team Terim, a stylish libero and captain here in his playing days, has seen. With influential foreigners like Hagi enjoying Indian summers and the Turks approaching peak it's the crest of a wave. It seems a summer exodus is on the cards. Sukur, rated by Terim as one of the most dangerous strikers in the world, is hotly coveted, as are Arif and the dynamic young Emre (suspended for the final).

At the moment Terim bullishly argues that anyone who doesn't want to play for Galatasaray can go. 'We'll build another team,' he retorts. 'There's only one type of person I don't like. If somebody says, yeah that's enough for me, I'm very angry. You must always be hungry.'

The other type he's not too keen on are ill-informed critics, who express surprise that his team, who have beaten the likes of Milan, Borussia Dortmund, Real Mallorca and Leeds this season, are so impressive. Surely they deserve more respect: 'Economically we are nothing, organisation is nothing, we have only five foreigners! My five cost maybe the same as one Bergkamp. No, make that one Vieira - Bergkamp is too expensive.

'This is a big success for us, and a good chance to get more money, more foreigners, more success. It's an important time. We have to work hard to maintain this otherwise we'll end up with one final every hundred years, like now.'

They have been waiting for the go-ahead for a $110 million, 48,000 stadium for two years. They are $25 million in debt. Winning the Uefa Cup would bring more than glory.

But what glory if they do lick Arsenal. They are so consumed by the challenge they eased off domestically last Friday and lost at Altay when a point would have guaranteed the title. That has to wait while the romance of being the first Turkish side to grace a European final enthrals Instanbul. 'On the 17th of May life will stop,' predicts Terim, proudly.

And he and his group of professionals might just join the party too. On the plane back from Leeds everyone was mystified to see the players quietly reading or listening to Walkmans. No celebrating yet. 'We were waiting. If we come back from Copenhagen with the cup we can do everything...' Only on the emperor's orders will festivities begin.

fields.headline: Clarke is the difference
fields.trailText: There is little to separate these Third Division clubs. The two managers have been in charge of both sides and Barnet had five former Peterborough players on show.
fields.body:
There is little to separate these Third Division clubs. The two managers have been in charge of both sides and Barnet had five former Peterborough players on show.

But it was a former Barnet man, Andy Clarke, who won this play-off semi final first leg for Peterborough when he scored with 22 minutes to go. The second leg is due to be played at London Road on Wednesday night and Barnet appear to have missed their main chance of promotion.

Peterborough took a sixth minute lead through Jason Lee, the giant striker formerly known as 'pineapple head' thanks to his over-elaborate hairstyle, who could have made it a hat-trick of goals in the next 10 minutes.

But Lee missed his next two chances having used his best effort to power in Peterborough's opening goal with a header from a Richard Scott cross. Both sides defended with passion, although not always with great ability, and there were chances at either end.

Still, it was against the run of play when Mark Arber equalised for Barnet in the 22nd minute. Darren Currie sent a corner to the far post, Greg Heald headed back at the far post and Arber headed the ball in off the crossbar.

An extraordinary incident followed, nine minutes before half time, when Peterborough were denied a second goal over an offside decision. Clarke looked to have scored, but fellow forward Dave Farrell decided to help the ball over the line and was immediately flagged by a linesman. There was an angry exchange of words between Clarke, Farrell and Peterborough manager Barry Fry.

Barnet were the superior side in the second half as they attacked. But they were guilty of wasting goalscoring chances and were made to pay when Clarke scored a second for the visitors in the 68th minute. Clarke stole the ball from the feet of defender Mike Basham and then finished with a left-foot shot.

webTitle: Elite police squad in graft probe

fields.headline: Elite police squad in graft probe
fields.standfirst: Scandal as 52 detectives are removed
fields.trailText: The National Crime Squad - created two years ago as Britain's answer to the FBI - has removed 52 officers from its elite force amid allegations of corruption and malpractice.
fields.byline: John Sweeney, Kamal Ahmed and Martin Bright
fields.body:
The National Crime Squad - created two years ago as Britain's answer to the FBI - has removed 52 officers from its elite force amid allegations of corruption and malpractice.

The latest corruption scandal will come as a huge blow to morale as Home Secretary Jack Straw prepares this week to shift responsibility for the investigation of major corruption cases from the police to other law enforcement agencies.

It is thought likely that a revamped Police Complaints Authority with full investigative powers will include civilians but be dominated by customs officers and the intelligence services. This will end the practice of police forces being used to investigate their colleagues.

The detectives from the NCS have been 'sent back' to their home forces from the squad - which freely admits it is 'under attack from organised crime' - for suspected offences ranging from collaborating with major criminals to losing key evidence and overtime fraud.

The head of the NCS, Ray Penrose, is to step down at the end of the year. 'Penrose is a good cop, but he's had enough,' said one senior law enforcement source. 'Too often, the big players in organised crime know what we are going to do before we do it. The only people in the know are senior police officers. And [the criminals] continue to get away with it.'

The NCS was created in an attempt to break away from the discredited system of regional crime squads, with customs officers openly referring to the corruption-plagued South East Regional Crime Squad 'as the best police force money can buy'.

Concern in Whitehall is greatest about corruption within high profile forces such as the NCS, its sister body, the National Criminal Intelligence Service, and the Metropolitan Police. The latter's anti-corruption squad, CIB3 - The Ghost Squad - has spent £23 million in the last two years, but only eight officers have been convicted.

Corruption was evident in the case of Flying Squad detective Terry McGuinness, 42, jailed last month after admitting burglary, conspiracy to supply cannabis, handling stolen goods and conspiracy to pervert justice. The court was told McGuinness revealed the existence of a 'first-aid kit', which included a balaclava and an imitation gun, used to plant evidence on suspects. McGuinness also described how his unit raided a suspect's home and found £14,000 under a bed. Officers carried off the cash after the criminal invited them to take it with the words: 'Christmas has come early'.

One law enforcement source said: 'The police have lost the Government's trust that it can keep its own house in order. If the NCS isn't clean, then nothing is.'

A huge Customs operation against drug traffickers Brian Charrington and Curtis 'Cocky' Warren, thought to be Britain's richest criminal, was thrown out when two police officers, Det Insp Harry Knaggs and Det Sgt Ian Weedon - then with the North East Regional Crime Squad - came forward, saying that Charrington was their prized informer. After he was released, Customs photographed Knaggs driving a £70,000 BMW, registered in Charrington's name. No one has been prosecuted, as the case is still with the CPS.

Straw will use a speech to the Police Federation on Wednesday to say the police can no longer be left to investigate themselves if public confidence is to be restored in the service. A report drawn up for the Home Office by consultants KPMG recommends that new staff for the body will be taken from Customs and Excise, the Inland Revenue and the Department of Social Services. They will be given sweeping powers of access over police records.

fields.headline: Birmingham buried
fields.trailText: Dave Bassett took a step towards an eighth football-league promotion when Barnsley buried Birmingham City's play-off hopes without recourse to the now superfluous second leg at Oakwell.
fields.body:
Dave Bassett took a step towards an eighth football-league promotion when Barnsley buried Birmingham City's play-off hopes without recourse to the now superfluous second leg at Oakwell.

Two-goal substitute Bruce Dyer was the hero, yet he might not even have figured had Birmingham not fouled Geoff Thomas out of the game. This was definitely not what the home chairman David Gold had in mind when he suggested two goals should be enough to book a place at Wembley.

Whether either of these sides have a realistic chance of beating promotion favourites Ipswich or the Division One form team Bolton is another matter, as is what either could hope to achieve in the Premiership. But at least Bassett and Barnsley did their travelling support proud with a professional and marvellously positive display.

Birmingham, it almost goes without saying, were a huge disappointment to the home fans, who staged a pitch invasion at the final whistle. There were enough blue and white balloons to suggest genuine optimism, but even if the fans were willing to go along with the fiction, the players did not really believe it. Neither did the manager Trevor Francis sound a rallying call, with programme notes reminding everyone that City had done well already in finishing higher than big spenders Wolves, Blackburn and Fulham. In a woeful first half with just a single attempt on Kevin Miller's goal, it took only 11 minutes for the home side's Premiership aspirations to be put into perspective by that one-time terror of the top flight, Neil Shipperley.

The burly striker still looks slow on the turn, but if you give him the time, as Birmingham did when he picked up a loose ball just outside the area, he has no problem hitting the target. As the City defence backed off, Shipperley surprised Thomas Myhre with a low drive that went in off his right upright.

Barnsley could hardly believe their luck. Not only were they off to a dream start without really trying, but St Andrews was silenced and thoroughly demoralised. The visitors lost Robbie van der Laan to practically the first challenge of the game, and then lost his replacement Geoff Thomas to Martin O'Connor's hideously late challenge, but they were still far more composed and organised than their opponents. Bassett's decision to send Dyer on, a bold ploy with Barnsley just one goal in front, was rewarded when the substitute took advantage of square defending to score twice.

Birmingham's Bryan Hughes had managed the solitary shot on target in the first half, a venomous volley from the angle of the area which Miller did well to parry. Obviously realising attacking efforts needed to be stepped up, Francis sent on Peter Ndlovu and Marcelo at the interval, but any half-time reorganisation was negated when Birmingham conceded just four minutes into the second half. Gary Rowett and David Holdsworth both had chances to clear a nondescript ball forward, but dozily left it to each other, allowing Dyer to steal between them and place a shot past a keeper rooted to his line. Myhre is on loan from Everton, and on this evidence needs to improve communication with his defenders, or perhaps Birmingham simply need to improve their defending.

After 59 minutes, Eric Tinkler beat what Birmingham were hoping was an offside trap by prodding the ball forward into the space between Myhre and his back-line, for Dyer to supply an almost identical finish to his first. Apart from a Dyer hat-trick being foiled by an offside flag, the only consolation for the Blues, as Craig Hignett wrapped up the scoring four minutes from the end, is that away goals no longer count double.

webTitle: Outcry over crackdown on model jail

fields.headline: Outcry over crackdown on model jail
fields.trailText: Prison governors and former offenders have joined in condemning the crackdown on a 'model' prison with the lowest rate of drug use, assault and reoffending in the country.
fields.body:
Prison governors and former offenders have joined in condemning the crackdown on a 'model' prison with the lowest rate of drug use, assault and reoffending in the country.

Blantyre House, a resettlement prison for serious offenders on the Isle of Sheppey, Kent, was raided 10 days ago on the orders of Martin Narey, head of the Prison Service, after receiving intelligence of serious breaches of security by prisoners.

In a statement issued this weekend, Narey said: 'The intelligence I received included information to suggest that there were discrepancies with security arrangements and that some prisoners might be involved in criminal activities.'

The raid found unauthorised items, including mobile phones, cash, credit cards and cannabis. It also found evidence of 'large-scale unauthorised cash transactions'.

The governor of Blantyre House, Eoin McLellan-Murray, and his deputy, David Newport, have been moved to other prisons, in a move widely interpreted as a criticism of their progressive methods. The operation is thought to have involved more than 100 prison officers, including members of the control and restraint team. The officers smashed through locked doors 'to ensure contraband was not being hidden'. The Prison Service is conducting an investigation into the security breaches, in collaboration with the police. Five inmates have been sent to other prisons.

The progressive regime at Blantyre was praised in Parliament this year by Shadow Home Secretary Ann Widdecombe and Robin Corbett, the Labour chair of the Home Affairs Select Committee, who described it as a 'model'. In a debate in March, Corbett told Prisons Minister Paul Boateng: 'We must not risk destroying a regime that has demonstrated its success and deserves to continue to do so.'

Widdecombe said: 'There are too few resettlement prisons - Kirklevington and Blantyre - and pretty well no more. Instead of reducing the precious few facilities available, we should seek to expand them.'

Blantyre House is one of only two resettlement prisons designed for prisoners close to release. Inmates are given temporary release to work in the community and save their earnings in bank accounts until release. They are also allowed to use mobile phones outside the prison.

Blantyre House, which houses around 120 prisoners, had the lowest rate of positive random drug-testing in the country last year at 0.7 per cent, and no assaults on staff. Of 16,000 licences given to inmates for temporary release last year, only two prisoners failed to return on time. The reconviction rate at Blantyre is 8 per cent compared with a national average of 54 per cent.

Lynne Bowles, deputy president of the Prison Governors Association, said: 'It is very unusual to have this level of research. This was an extraordinary operation. I am not a party to the intelligence in the possession of the director-general of the Prison Service. But all my information suggests things were going well at the prison.'

Alan Rogers, a former prisoner at the Kent prison with convictions for drugs and firearms offences, said: 'Blantyre House works. It has found a successful way of reintegrating prisoners back into society. Perhaps it is easier and less expensive to destroy one regime that works than it is to expand it across the prison system.'

The experimental regime of McLellan-Murray and Newport was also defended last night by the Rev David Atkins, pastor of Calvary Church in Tunbridge Wells, who has been visiting Blantyre for three years.

Atkins, an ex-Metropolitan Police Flying Squad officer, said: 'They are prison pioneers who have clearly had much success in changing many men's lives for the better. I can't protest too strongly at the action of the authorities in removing these governors from Blantyre.'

Harry Fletcher, spokesman for the National Association of Probation Officers, added: 'Unless the intelligence received by Martin Narey was exceptionally serious, this was an extraordinary response. There needs to be an inquiry because it seems mightily convenient that this search happened when the Prison Service was facing opposition to its plans to change the role of the prison.'

webTitle: Dissent over crash forces chiefs to quit

fields.headline: Dissent over crash forces chiefs to quit
fields.trailText: Two senior RAF officers who blamed the air force's worst peacetime accident on the pilots involved have resigned from the world's most eminent professional aviation body, amid mounting criticism from colleagues over their handling of the inquiry.
fields.body:
Two senior RAF officers who blamed the air force's worst peacetime accident on the pilots involved have resigned from the world's most eminent professional aviation body, amid mounting criticism from colleagues over their handling of the inquiry.

The Observer has learnt that Air Marshals Sir William Wratten and Sir John Day have quit the world-renowned Royal Aeronautical Society after a group of leading members refused to stop publicly attacking their verdict on the crash of a Chinook helicopter in June 1994.

Four aircrew and 25 senior members of the Northern Ireland anti-terrorism community were killed when Chinook Zulu Delta 576 ploughed into the cloud-covered Mull of Kintyre on its way from Belfast to a high-level security conference near Inverness. RAF rules at the time stated that only in cases where there was 'absolutely no doubt whatsoever' could deceased aircrew be blamed and, although the helicopter was not fitted with black box recorders, the RAF's own board of inquiry said an unforeseen technical failure could not be ruled out as the cause.

Wratten, then an air chief marshal, and Day, an air vice- marshal, overruled the board and found the experienced Special Forces pilots, Flight Lieutenants Jonathan Tapper and Rick Cook, guilty of gross negligence. The verdict has been widely condemned as unjust ever since, as evidence has emerged of technical problems with the newly upgraded Chinook fleet, casting serious doubt on the Ministry of Defence's continued insistence that the only possible explanation for the loss of ZD576 was pilot negligence.

Now, in the run-up to the sixth anniversary of the tragedy, the air marshals are embroiled in fresh controversy following an investigation by The Observer and Computer Weekly magazine, which has uncovered allegations that they resigned from the Royal Aeronautical Society after attempting to stifle criticism of their verdict.

The society, whose membership includes the most senior levels of the RAF and MoD as well as civilian pilots, engineers and crash investi gators, is globally recognised for its air safety expertise, and sustained criticism from members of such an esteemed body would have undermined officials' insistence that the negligence verdict was sound. Leading members claim that Wratten and Day, along with other senior RAF officers, put pressure on the society's office-bearers to stop members discussing the issue.

The debate was originally prompted by a small article in the society's newspaper in 1998 detailing widely reported evidence that a software fault in the helicopter's new engine control system could have caused the crash. Wratten and Day were furious that their judgment was being questioned but, over the next six months, the paper continued to publish letters from members on the subject, all but one of them critical.

In July 1998, after complaints from the officers and from another member, Air Chief Marshal Sir Michael Graydon, chief of air staff at the time of the crash, the society made a commitment that it would 'unambiguously draw a line' under the issue. But the rumblings of dissent have continued.

The two men were unavailable to comment last week, but Graydon said they resigned because they were 'fed up to the back teeth' with the refusal of some members to accept the official verdict. He also denied that RAF members had exerted pressure on the society. 'We're getting to the end of our tether on this one. The thing has been gone around so many times by the MoD and every time they reach the same conclusion. And yet this same group of people try to use every trick in the book to have the verdict changed.'

Trevor Truman, the society's president-elect, said: 'There has been interest in this very tragic accident by individual members. But it is not within the remit or the resources of the society to investigate accidents.'

But the episode has angered critics within the society as well as the dead pilots' families. Mike Ramsden, a fellow of the society and a former editor of Flight magazine, said: 'Their actions amount to an abuse of the world's leading professional aviation body.' Rick Cook's father, John, a retired Concorde pilot, said: 'It is disgusting. I would have thought that debating subjects like this is what a learned society is there for, but Wratten and Day cannot handle any dissent whatsoever.'

Six years after the crash, the row over ZD576 is certain to continue. Three members of the society have now produced a report which reveals for the first time that Wratten was one of the officers charged with deciding the verdict on the crash despite the fact that he was also the senior officer responsible for overseeing the upgraded Chinook fleet's transition into operational service.

In the process, he overruled RAF test pilots who suspended flight trials after a series of unexplained software malfunctions in the engine control system.

fields.headline: Digital pests invade Britain
fields.trailText: Pokémon's days are numbered. That is the good news for parents who have resorted to self-help groups as children spend all their pocket money on the Japanese-inspired fad and fall victim to playground muggings.
fields.body:
Pokémon's days are numbered. That is the good news for parents who have resorted to self-help groups as children spend all their pocket money on the Japanese-inspired fad and fall victim to playground muggings.

The bad news is that an even bigger menace is heading our way: the Digimon.

It is the brainchild of Bandai, the world's third biggest toy manufacturer, which created the Tamagotchi virtual pets and the action heroes Power Rangers. The computer games and action figures will reach Britain within a fortnight.

To the jaded adult eye, Digimon (digital monsters) may seem like a Pokémon rip-off. Patamon and his 279 friends are, like Pikachu and his colourful but smaller army of 150, cartoon characters, action figures, cuddly toys and players in hand-held computer games called 'digivices'. They are designed to spawn a myriad of merchandise from shoes to wall hangings.

But to children, Digimons are the next big thing. The toys have swept across America and the Digimon-Pokémon war is shaping up to be the biggest-ever battle for the fickle pre-teenage market.

Digimons have already landed the first significant blow to the £6 billion Pokémon empire, knocking Nintendo's creation off the number one slot in the industry bible's What's Hot toy chart.

Launched in America on a November day proclaimed 'Digiday' by publicity-aware New York mayor Rudi Giuliani, toy sales reached $75 million within six weeks.

Retailers such as Wal-Mart, owner of Asda in the UK, are said to be begging for Digimon branded goods. 'What began as an intriguing property has turned into a white-hot licensing and merchandising explosion,' said Eli Dekel, president of Saban Consumer Products which owns the merchandise licence in America.

Now Digimon has hit Britain, courtesy of Rupert Murdoch's company News Corp which has grabbed the rights to the TV series and all the merchandise for the UK and France. The first of the 54 half-hour cartoons launched on Fox Kids Europe last month and on terrestrial television a fortnight ago. The toys are on their way.

Nintendo and Wizards Of The Coast, the company responsible for the Pokémon trading cards, are publicly sceptical about the impact their rival will make. The British Association of Toy Retailers disagrees: 'I did not believe that anything could challenge Pokémon,' said secretary Moira Dowrie. 'Digimon looks like a second-class Pokémon but the retailers I spoke to last week said it is doing very well in America and it could be neck and neck by Christmas in this country. It will have to be quite something to do that.'

'We believe this game is going to be even more popular than Pokémon, partly because it is going to be more attractive to girls,' said Bandai's spokesman in the UK, Dylan Glover. 'The Digimons are all about teamwork instead of just fighting.'

In the cartoon, seven children at summer camp are transported to a fantasy world, File Island, where they meet the small, digital monsters, the digimons. They have to find their way home by working with the creatures, who must 'digivolve' from monsters-in-training to giant, evil-beating champions.

Digimon comes with interactive 'digivices', which are upgraded Tamagotchis that can be inter-linked by cables. Each Digimon has its own personality corresponding to one of the heroes.

Pokémon trading cards have sold in their millions since they were launched in October and change hands for anything up to £60. The list of card-related crimes carried out by pre-pubescents grows weekly and includes armed robbery and burglary. Parents in Yorkshire have set up a self-help group. More than one million starter packs at £7.25 each have been sold in this country, plus 8 million booster packs and 1.5 million theme decks.

There's worse to come after Pokémon - the dreaded Digimon

Kabuterimon the Insectoid uses electricity to shock his enemies. He has four sets of claws, three sets of teeth and a razor horn, and will soon be available as a cuddly toy.

Greymon is a dinosaur of the 'vaccine' type. He saves the children on the first day of their adventure by destroying the enemy Shellman with a Nova Blast.

He looks like a cactus but Togemon, champion of the Vegetation group, moves at lightning speed to jab opponents with sprays of needles.

webTitle: Sydney counts cost of Olympic ticket fiasco

fields.headline: Sydney counts cost of Olympic ticket fiasco
fields.trailText: As tickets for the Olympics start to go on sale, the hot favourite is a seat to see Cathy Freeman, the 26-year-old Aboriginal runner from Mackay, Queensland, who is the Commonwealth 400 metres title holder.
fields.body:
As tickets for the Olympics start to go on sale, the hot favourite is a seat to see Cathy Freeman, the 26-year-old Aboriginal runner from Mackay, Queensland, who is the Commonwealth 400 metres title holder.

Sydney's sport-mad dashed to buy last Sunday's papers which all had competing Olympic ticket offers. But the day got far more exciting when more than 12,000 tickets for Freeman's first run on 22 September were, by accident, quoted at half-price.

Freeman first grabbed the nation's attention in 1994, when after a win she ran a victory lap draped in both the Australian and Aboriginal flags. So when more than 8,000 A-list tickets (the best seats in the house) for the first round of the women's 400m were priced at A$85 (£34) instead of the correct price of A$165 (£66), the hotlines lit up. The 2,400 B-list seats (at either end of the oval stadium) were selling at £26 rather than £50. The 2,000 category C tickets (upper tiers) were a snip at £18 instead of £42.

The Sydney Olympic organising committee, Socog, could lose up to $1m (£400,000) in the pricing fiasco. Its deputy chief executive, Michael Eyers, confessed his mistake to the Sydney press and promised the organisation would stand by the prices quoted.

'We are bound by that, so the people who ordered them will get the tickets for the price advertised.'

It has not yet emerged how the tickets for Freeman's session came to be mispriced, but to Sydneysiders the fiasco is sweet revenge. There has been much wailing over what many see as steep ticket prices, an unfair return, some say, for the traffic chaos and disruption predicted in the city during the Games.

According to Eyers, tickets had been selling well since the offer was announced at the beginning of last week, but he refused to forecast whether all of the 3.2 million tickets on offer to Australians would be sold.

Even the city's well-off are hesitating at the high prices. A front-row seat for the Opening Ceremony on 15 September is priced at £550. And any Australians desperate to see marathon contestants limp across the finishing line will be charged the same price.

Best seats for the ever popular men's 4x100m relay final are £194, for the women's 200m backstroke final £182, and for the Men's 10m platform diving final £142. Less popular disciplines such as the archery final are selling for £26. Even Greco-Roman wrestling is £22.

The cheapest ticket in town is for the clash between baseball giants South Korea and Cuba on 19 September. These are available for a mere £4.

fields.headline: There's one faun every minute
fields.trailText: The Diaghilev Legacy, Royal Ballet, Royal Opera House, London WC2
fields.body:
The Diaghilev Legacy, Royal Ballet, Royal Opera House, London WC2

Three figures in white pose beneath a soaring skylight at the Royal Opera House; 14 quicksilver bodies slither on metal tables in the vast vault of Tate Modern's turbine hall on Bankside. Dancers now inhabit our cultural cathedrals in a way that Diaghilev could only dream about almost a century ago.

He believed that ballet should reflect the modern world - and he created choreographers who could match the contemporary concerns of artists and composers.

His protégé, Vaslav Nijinsky, devised the first 'high art' ballet, Jeux (1913), to deal with everyday activities - three tennis players enmeshed in games of all sorts in a secluded garden.

A decade later, Vaslav's sister, Bronislava Nijinska, choreographed Les Biches and Le Train bleu , both of which depicted the high jinks of modish Riviera society in the Twenties.

Les Biches and Jeux are part of the Royal Ballet's current Diaghilev Legacy bill (until Saturday), along with Nijinsky's L'Après-midi d'un faune and Fokine's The Firebird . They raise the question of whether these ballets, so much of their time, are worth reviving, or whether today's dancers should be looking to the future.

William Forsythe, whose Ballett Frankfurt company performed at Tate Modern's opening ceremony, is in no doubt. 'The true spirit of Diaghilev lives in choreographers inspiring dancers now,' he said during a rehearsal break. 'It's preposterous to try to go back to the people they were then: creation is what matters, not archaeology.'

Yet his dancers (in extracts from his latest work, The Questioning of Robert Scott ) were being videoed, so a record has been kept. The video could become an installation alongside the other moving images in the Bankside gallery, an instant archive. Choreography can also be notated, like music.

Ballet scores from the Diaghilev era were played in South Bank concerts last week: if we still enjoy the music, why not see the ballets as well, and the original designs?

It's not as easy as that, of course. Although Nijinska herself recreated Les Biches for the Royal Ballet in 1964, Nijinsky's ballets proved as fragile as his sanity. Jeux (1913) was soon lost; Faune (1912) survived, after a fashion, through other dancers and still photographs of Nijinsky in the title role.

fields.headline: Size matters
fields.trailText: When Nicholas Kenyon, as reported by Euan Ferguson, says 'I do regret ... that Classic FM is based so much on the bite-sized culture', he seems to forget that he, in his tenure as Controller of Radio 3, was responsible for its dumbing down into endless programmes of excerpts or single movements from complete works
fields.body:
When Nicholas Kenyon, as reported by Euan Ferguson, says 'I do regret ... that Classic FM is based so much on the bite-sized culture', he seems to forget that he, in his tenure as Controller of Radio 3, was responsible for its dumbing down into endless programmes of excerpts or single movements from complete works. Slowly, it is beginning to recover. He also fails to acknowledge that Classic FM does indeed broadcast complete works. I hope he is not too much of a snob to have noticed that on 11 May, for example, their evening concert consisted of five complete Stravinsky works. Also included this week are Ravel, Britten and Bartok, Salieri, Reicha, Stamitz, Danzi, Vitali and Gade among the other more familiar names. No 'bite' sizes here.


Jack Hearne
London N22

It was refreshing to read Nicholas Kenyon's condemnation of musical snobbery. What a pity then that Sue Arnold was so patronising towards Classic FM listeners in the Arts section.

The BBC is invaluable in promoting live concerts and new work. Classic FM is never going to give us The Silver Tassie or Götterdämmerung from the Met. But why is it assumed that each of us only listens to one radio station? On Sunday morning I listened to Radio 3 over breakfast but then caught part of Natalie Wheen's intelligent afternoon programme on Classic FM before going to the Barbican to hear Anne Sophie Mutter play Rihm and Penderecki.


Miss A.E. Stoddart
Richmond
Surrey

webTitle: Attenborough goes star-hunting for film on De Beauvoir's Left Bank loves

fields.headline: Attenborough goes star-hunting for film on De Beauvoir's Left Bank loves
fields.trailText: She was the arch-intellectual of the Left Bank and an early feminist heroine to generations of women. But now Simone de Beauvoir's softer side is to be exposed to the hard gaze of the world's cinema goers.
fields.body:
She was the arch-intellectual of the Left Bank and an early feminist heroine to generations of women. But now Simone de Beauvoir's softer side is to be exposed to the hard gaze of the world's cinema goers.

Richard Attenborough, one of Britain's best-known directors, is making a film of De Beauvoir's long, passionate and ultimately sad love affair with the American writer Nelson Algren. The details of the affair - De Beauvoir had a long-standing relationship with philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre - were revealed in a set of De Beauvoir's letters to her lover published two years ago, 14 years after the writer's death.

Speaking for the first time about the film to The Observer last week, Attenborough said it had been a long-cherished project. 'I love making movies about people who have a relevance to our own society and the relationship between Sartre, De Beauvoir and Algren is just fabulously fascinating. I am very excited about it.'

Attenborough's production has prompted a fever of speculation among actors as to who is going to be cast in the key roles. The film will be made in Paris and Chicago and involve a host of key literary and artistic figures.

Some have already thrown their hat into the ring. Natascha McElhone, the rising British star who appeared in the surreal thriller Ronin, told reporters after the letters were first published that she would love to play De Beauvoir in a production.

But Attenborough said he wanted a French actress to play her. 'Juliette Binoche would be wonderful or Sophie Marceau,' he said. 'Geoffrey Rush, who did Shine , would be a superb Sartre and someone like George Clooney could do a fabulous Algren.'

Another choice role will be that of Albert Camus, author of a series of classic existentialist novels and favourite of a million student bookshelves with his square-jawed good looks and goalkeeper's build. De Beauvoir's letters refer often to drunken nights with Camus in basement bars in the 4th arrondissement of Paris. One ended with the author of The Outsider threatening Arthur Koestler - author of Darkness at Noon - with his fists. Attenborough said that there would also be roles for Alberto Giacometti, the sculptor, and, fleetingly, Pablo Picasso.

The film is bound to be controversial, whoever is cast. When her letters to Algren were published many were amazed at the new side to De Beauvoir that they revealed.

Many male critics seized gleefully on her offers to do housework for Algren as evidence that the author of The Second Sex , one of the classic texts of feminism, failed to practise what she preached.

Vicki Robinson, director of Women's Studies at Manchester University, said that any film focusing on the relationship between Algren and De Beauvoir alone ran the risk of 'being Hollywoodised'.

'If it is a love biopic, then it could be seen as making a case that underneath every intellectual woman there is merely a sexual woman trying to get out.'

It is a controversy that Attenborough is sensitive to, however. 'She never faced up to these extreme contradictions. It is extraordinary that all such an amazing woman wanted to do was be with [her lover] and knit his socks.'

De Beauvoir, then 39, met Algren, who was a year older, in 1947. The lanky, languid author was still relatively unknown in America and De Beauvoir was already a celebrity. She had also been Sartre's lover and partner - in a famously 'open' relationship - for more than a decade.

Algren, who was later to win awards for his hard-bitten tales of Chicago lowlife and his novel, The Man with the Golden Arm , courted her with a tour of his native city, including heroin addicts and the electric chair, before taking her back to his squalid flat for a night of sex. There, De Beauvoir revealed to a later biographer, she had her first 'complete orgasm'.

For the next 17 years they wrote to each other frequently, sometimes four or five times a week. The letters, all in English, are passionate. Algren is De Beauvoir's 'own big crocodile' and she called herself his 'loving little frog'.

However, it was a fraught relationship. Both lovers refused to sacrifice much of their lifestyles. Simone de Beauvoir remained rooted in the Parisian intellectual milieu that she loved and Algren, who refused even to learn any French, was loath to leave the United States. But they did go for one romantic trip to Latin America together.

Attenborough said that he has discovered the pair actually went through some kind of marriage ceremony in Notre Dame cathedral in Paris.

De Beauvoir told Sartre that she was leaving him permanently to live in Chicago with Algren, but in the end could not bring herself to leave Paris.

Algren, who was repeatedly unfaithful, broke off the relationship in 1964.

He was deeply angered by the way De Beauvoir had used their love affair as material in her books. Though she stayed with Sartre, De Beauvoir died wearing Algren's ring.

For the French, De Beauvoir is still a controversial figure. For decades - as French thought and politics veered away from orthodox Marxist analysis - those tainted by any perceived loyalty to the Left were shunned. Now, however, Sartre is a hero again. His picture adorns cafés and newspaper stalls and contemporary thinkers pay homage to his ideas.

But plans in Paris to rename the square outside Les Deux Magots - the Existentialists' favourite café - as the Place Sartre-De Beauvoir have met with a mixed reaction.

One source at the Institut Français in London, who did not want to be named, was adamant in her opposition to the idea. 'It would be a great pity. It would ignore too many other people. And who reads the Existentialists any more anyway?'

According to Attenborough, American financiers share her attitude. 'It's French and it involves philosophers, so they are terrified. But I'll do what I always do and keep going. Hopefully we'll start filming next year.'

jason.burke@observer.co.uk
