fields.headline: Boom or bust?
fields.standfirst: Britney Spears is an emblem of the times, but only her second album will decide if she's the next Madonna
fields.trailText: Max Martin, a middle-aged Swedish former heavy metal singer, is dressed in a miniskirt, knee-length socks, grey school cardie and white blouse tied halfway up his torso revealing both his soft brown navel and a flash of pubescent cleavage framed by a sports bra. He does a backflip, rearranges his pigtails, pouts seductively at the camera, and sings: 'Oh pretty baby, there's nothing that I wouldn't do...'
fields.body:
Max Martin, a middle-aged Swedish former heavy metal singer, is dressed in a miniskirt, knee-length socks, grey school cardie and white blouse tied halfway up his torso revealing both his soft brown navel and a flash of pubescent cleavage framed by a sports bra. He does a backflip, rearranges his pigtails, pouts seductively at the camera, and sings: 'Oh pretty baby, there's nothing that I wouldn't do...'

It wouldn't have worked, of course. Which is why Martin, probably the most successful songwriter in the world at the moment, offered '... Baby One More Time' to an unknown 16-year-old American girl called Britney Spears. (Actually, he offered it first of all to R&B trio TLC, and then to British boyband Five, but both rejected it, the fools!) The song, allied to that video, was released in November 1998.

Since then, Britney Spears has become one of the most famous brand names - and complex phenomena - in popular culture. Debate still rages as to whether she has had a 'boob job'. Tomorrow she releases her second album, which will ultimately decide whether she is a one-year wonder or a pop legend in the making, and simultaneously publishes her autobiography. In October her world tour reaches Britain. For Christmas, you can buy your child a Britney doll. She has been described as an airhead, but if so she is an emblematic airhead.

So who or what is Britney Spears? Rolling Stone described her as 'the nation's prom queen', and on many levels she is as wholesome as this image suggests: a self-proclaimed smalltown Christian virgin who 'thanks God every day for my parents'. But, as the magazine well knows, having enjoyed its highest sale of last year with a cover shot of Britney posing in bra and knickers on pink satin sheets cuddling a fluffy toy, she has also become a porn icon for paedophiles, her name the eighth-most requested keyword on Internet search engines ('britney spears nude' is 94th). The Net is also where you will find the seething, sarcastic hordes of Britney haters - on websites such as 'bitchney', 'britney spears must die', and 'britney spears just plain sucks'.

Steve Lunt, Britney's A&R man at Jive Records, with whom she signed at the age of 15, says the new album, Oops... I Did It Again , is aimed at 'all the different people who have fallen in love with her', including 'men who think she's a babe'. That will account for Britney's Europop restyling of the Rolling Stones' 'Satisfaction', then.

In recent interviews, however, Britney has suggested she is less than comfortable with this section of her fanbase. 'I don't want to be part of someone's Lolita thing. It kinda freaks me out,' she complained.

This is the same Britney who, according to all those involved, came up with the idea of dressing as a schoolgirl for the '... Baby One More Time' video (the director wanted to dress her as a Power Ranger). As she breathes in the chorus to her current single (a song so similar to '... Baby One More Time' that one wag suggested she should sue herself for plagiarism), 'I'm not that innocent.'

Then again, those words were written not by Britney but by Max Martin. In fact, only one Britney-penned song has made it to record so far. 'Dear Diary', the last song on the new album, is a sugary little ballad decked out with strings, chimes and every sentimental cliché in pop's palette. 'Dear diary, today I saw a boy,' trills Britney, 'And I wondered if he noticed me...' Probably not, Britney. Boys tend to be pretty indifferent to voluptuous vixens in catsuits.

Her voice on this track is almost Bonnie Langford-like: lispy, ickle-girlie, with a whispery upper pitch which can induce fits in dogs and dolphins. On the funkier, more 'adult' tracks, the producers use the now familiar trick of distorting her voice to make her sound more knowing.

Similarly, Britney in pictures can look anything between 12 and 40. On the cover of her debut album, she plays the downhome sweet little Louisiana girl who didn't really go to the Professional Performing Arts School in New York aged nine, or present a TV show ( The Mickey Mouse Club ) at 11, or leave her beloved Kentwood home at 15 because 'I was so bored. I had my boyfriend, and I went to homecoming... but I wanted more.'

In other pictures she seems almost preternaturally mature. Several people have noted this, most memorably the pop-satire duo Supergirly, who do a version of '... Baby One More Time' with the chorus line: 'Britney Spears is 39'. Even Britney's most trusted friend, her on-tour chaperone Felicia Cullotta, says of their first meeting: 'She was seven and she was singing on stage. And I thought: "My, that is a 40-year-old up there!"'

Quite where Britney will be when she really reaches 40 is open to question. She herself has no doubts: 'I want to be a legend like Madonna. That is what I pray for every day.' For every Madonna there are dozens of Tiffanys and Debbie Gibsons, of course, and Oops... lacks the Zeitgeist-defining lyrics of songs like 'Material Girl' and 'Like a Virgin', but you have to respect the self-publicising abilities of someone who can generate so much controversy with a school uniform and a navel ring.

A brief postscript. While I was writing this, a friend sent me an e-mail. It was a picture of Britney with a pump attached to her breasts. If you pumped too much, they exploded. Britney haters should make the most of this: it may be the only way they will get to see her bubble burst in the forseeable future.

fields.headline: Camilla's idea of fun
fields.standfirst: The perfect posh person's party must be planned with proper precision, according to Harpers & Queen social editor Camilla Cecil. But if fish is on the menu, count her out...
fields.trailText: The perfect posh person's party must be planned with proper precision, according to Harpers & Queen social editor Camilla Cecil. But if fish is on the menu, count her out...
fields.body:
As weird jobs go, Camilla's takes the biscuit. Or, rather, the parmesan toast or quail's egg dipped in celery salt. OK, let's play What's My Line? Here comes thirtysomething Camilla in her ice-blue shift dress, looking rather like Fiona Shaw might look if she lived in Fulham and wore Gina mules. A well-to-do Montessori teacher, perhaps, or the director of a small art gallery? Not exactly. Ask a few questions and it emerges that her busiest months are May, June and December, when she's booked solid every night. It's not unknown for her to cram four into a single evening. Overall, she thinks she fits in around 200 a year. What are we talking about? Parties, of course.

As the social editor of Harpers & Queen, the 'Jennifer' of Jennifer's Diary, Camilla Cecil (she's an Hon, naturally) toils doggedly at the coalface of the Season, a miner working a seam rich in Krug and seeded wontons. Because Camilla's water-cooler moments happen at Gloucestershire weddings, or eighteenth-birthday parties in the Highlands, or in the royal enclosure at Ascot, she is ideally qualified to write a guide to party-giving.

The Harpers & Queen Party Book, however, is written for a very particular sort of person who wants to give a very particular sort of party. It's aimed at people who worry about how much space One should allow per wedding guest (four to six square feet for a drinks reception; 10 if there's a sit-down meal), and what sort of flooring is best if One is hosting a dance for 600 (oak parquet). It is a glimpse into an extraordinarily tense parallel universe, in which Fun and Frivolity are attended by a long line of thumb-twiddling, beady-eyed Fates.

Much of the advice is sensible, even obvious. Wedding lists get a big yes ('A list is there as a guideline for the guests, not as an extravagant wish-list from a spoilt couple'); any party snack that comes on a cocktail stick a resounding no ('Where are you supposed to put it?'). In addition, there are lists of tried-and-tested caterers, chair-hire companies and childrens' entertainers.

On the other hand, One does have to wonder about the sort of person who frets about where to store visitors' umbrellas ('A dustbin is OK for this') or lies awake at night dreading the possibility that a guest might bring a bottle of wine to dinner ('You then develop selective amnesia and leave it in the fridge'), rather than hoping, rather desperately, that they will.

Preparation is all. And by preparation, Harpers & Queen does not mean a freezer full of vodka and a bumper tub of Safeway's taramasalata. No, we are talking linen napkins tied with ivy, birch twigs sprayed silver and pats of butter on terracotta tiles. From the host's perspective, entertaining - drinks parties, children's birthday parties, dinner parties - seems to be primarily about fretting over the tiniest of details for months beforehand, and, second, about having a laugh and passing out, with purple teeth, in a pile of coats. Whoops! What I meant to say was: and second, making sure everyone else has a splendid evening and that you treat yourself to a big, medicinal whisky once they've all gone home.

'The best parties,' Camilla tells me over tea in a London hotel, 'are planned with military precision but go off without a hitch, and the ones where you can't see the joins are the ones that most thought has gone into. If people throw it all together and hope it works, most of the time it won't.' Camilla, who seems like a jolly sort of person, says that she has used the book to address the questions that H&Q readers frequently put to her over the phone. They treat her like a social agony aunt, ringing up to ask whether it's U or non-U to serve elderflower pressé this year, or whether you should take your gloves off at mealtimes. She insists that most of the queries are very sensible, but even she must despair when, in the dinner-party section, she is required to answer the question 'How Do I Invite the Guests' ('A quick telephone call is always the simplest'). Surely, this is slightly tragic? 'No, I don't think so,' says Camilla. 'Yes, a lot of it is very obvious. But there's always the hope that someone will find it useful. It's mostly good practical advice.'

So she really never wants to scream: 'Oh, for goodness' sake, just get a life' ?

'If I think that, I say it. And I do say to people, "I'm sure that really doesn't matter." A lot of the time, I don't think it does. It was all very well for our parents and grandparents to live life in a certain way, according to certain rules, but it was awfully time-consuming, and we've all got busy lives. No, I never mind the daffy requests. I'm always surprised that people have the intelligence to ring me in the first place. It's a very easy way of getting information.'

Not that Camilla can help with every social dilemma. 'I did have a bit of a problem with one woman who telephoned me and started shouting because I couldn't give her a ticket to the royal enclosure at Ascot. She said, "But who can give it to me if you can't?" So I said, "The Queen. I can't, I'm so sorry".'

Let's get down to basics. There are some golden rules about party-giving. 'If you're sitting, the seating plan is absolutely paramount,' says Camilla. 'I once went to an absolutely beautiful party and I had two people on either side who didn't speak any English. That, unfortunately for me, was my lasting memory of an otherwise fabulous party. And make sure the alcohol tastes good and flows. It doesn't have to be champagne. Have a nice white wine, or do a cocktail, which can be cheaper. Parties always get going when people have had a few drinks. And relax - have a nice time. It would be a bit of a waste to forget to enjoy yourself. Look good. It helps. If you run upstairs just before people are due to arrive and whip off your sweatshirt, you just don't feel prepared, whereas if you feel scrubbed and brushed up, it makes you feel better.'

I like Camilla and her fresh, confident brand of Mary Poppins correctness. She makes me feel that anything is possible, if you put sufficient effort into it. When she admits that yes, she has been to parties where the alcohol is pooled in a bucket in the kitchen, albeit years ago, I feel able to tell her about my little problem with parties - I hate them. Giving is bad, but taking is even worse. Beforehand, I hover on doorsteps for entire half-hours, plucking up the courage to ring the bell. Once in, I sequester myself in the loo with a pile of old Vogues or National Geographics , ignoring the frantic knockings. Should the loo already be occupied, I loiter at the edge of rooms, either too sober or worse, much worse, too drunk to participate at the appropriate level. How, I ask Camilla, can I overcome my phobia? How can I arrive at a party in the right frame of mind? Camilla has some advice. 'Whenever I'm getting dressed or in the car driving to a party, I'll whack on some Bruce Springsteen to get me in a good mood.'

I'm not quite sure that this will do the trick for me, but Camilla has moved on and is thoughtfully matching my confession with one of her own. She is allergic to fish, but because she was always frightened that hostesses might insist on making her scrambled eggs if she mentioned this at the dining table, 'I used to always eat it and then I'd spend the whole evening rushing off and being sick.'

Then she met the man who is now her husband and he laughed and laughed about it. So now she owns up straight away, but is very firm, insisting she'll be fine with veg and potatoes. 'At that point I realised, life is too short. Parties are supposed to be fun .'

Well, she would say that, wouldn't she?

fields.headline: A cooler shade of grey
fields.standfirst: Tate Modern
fields.trailText: From the cafe on the seventh floor of the Tate Modern, I could see the great greyness of St Paul's Cathedral enveloped by a grey sky which drizzled, greyly, into the grey Thames below. Inside was all sleek grey-black minimalism: clean lines and natural light - dirty grey light. This is probably the best riverside view in London. Better than that offered by the restaurant in the Oxo Tower, which feels a trifle staged and therefore disappointing.
fields.body:
From the cafe on the seventh floor of the Tate Modern, I could see the great greyness of St Paul's Cathedral enveloped by a grey sky which drizzled, greyly, into the grey Thames below. Inside was all sleek grey-black minimalism: clean lines and natural light - dirty grey light. This is probably the best riverside view in London. Better than that offered by the restaurant in the Oxo Tower, which feels a trifle staged and therefore disappointing.

There's a good long bar at which artists, dressed in grey-black, will congregate to get passionately drunk and say outrageous things. The eating area is what any self-respecting modern artist would call an 'interesting space'. It's large and airy and, covering two walls, there are Hamish Fulton artworks, one of which, inspired by a mountain in Japan, is brilliantly grey. Having made my way up past exhibition rooms which are titled in triptych (eg nude/action/body), I rather hoped I'd find a menu divided into food/water/alcohol, but the choice was much more detailed. The wine list is thoughtful and includes some selections that I imagine a modern artist would find interesting.

It's early days on the food front - although it bodes well that Jeremy King of The Ivy and Le Caprice has been offering advice - but the tasters on offer at the preview easily surpass the canteen muck with which most galleries like to insult their visitors. There is also a spacious café on the ground floor, which is called the second floor, but the top floor is the place to head for.

All in all, it's a destination location, somewhere to meet a new date when neither of you can think where to go, or somewhere to take an old date when you've been everywhere else.

And, of course, it's an ideal setting, after slogging around all that difficult modern art stuff, in which to rest up and watch the grey river flow timelessly by.

fields.headline: Industrial light and magic
fields.standfirst:
The transformation of a former power station is a triumph of style and content

Tate Modern
fields.trailText: Tate Modern was meant to make us look at contemporary art in a new way, but its most immediate cultural impact will be on how we see architecture. Herzog and de Meuron have turned a power station of no architectural pretension into a museum that is spectacular enough to be an authentic crowd-pleaser. But at the same time, it will satisfy the most austere artists, wary of being exhibited in galleries in which the architectural ego is too conspicuously on display.
fields.body:
Tate Modern was meant to make us look at contemporary art in a new way, but its most immediate cultural impact will be on how we see architecture. Herzog and de Meuron have turned a power station of no architectural pretension into a museum that is spectacular enough to be an authentic crowd-pleaser. But at the same time, it will satisfy the most austere artists, wary of being exhibited in galleries in which the architectural ego is too conspicuously on display.

Bankside is a defining moment for architecture. Just like Piano and Rogers's Pompidou Centre in the Seventies and James Stirling's Staatsgalerie in the Eighties, it will be the benchmark for gallery architecture for a decade. And that, of course, was by no means an accident. Nicholas Serota is a gallery director with an unusually sophisticated view of architecture and the contribution it can make to a successful museum. He wanted a building that artists would like, but he also wanted a building which would set the architectural agenda, because he knew that if it did both, it would also be popular with the public.

The trick was to pick an architect at just the right moment in their career. They should have done just enough other work to prove that they are capable of handling larger projects, but they should not yet have done that other big project which marks them out as somebody else's discovery or, worse, makes them too busy to concentrate. And it was at exactly this point that Serota found Herzog and de Meuron. Such architects are not exactly in over-abundant supply. It is interesting that the only really tense moment in Serota's six-year relationship with his architects was when Herzog and de Meuron got on to the Museum of Modern Art's shortlist to design an extension in New York.

There are other art galleries that have been carved out of industrial spaces, but they were mainly on the edge of things. The Tate, on the other hand, is at the centre of them, a major national institution that has adopted the same architectural language as what was once regarded as the radical fringe. Tate Modern is a monumental version of Matt's Gallery, the ramshackle collection of sheds in the East End that first showed Richard Wilson, or the Saatchi Gallery. Suddenly, the tidied-up industrial space has become as much the conventional gallery form as the Greek temple used to be. The people who put up those brown, motorway heritage signs will have to rethink the stylised representation of the pediment and columns they use to warn us that there is a museum ahead. The conventional sign for a gallery is now Tate Modern's chimney.

But the Bankside effect will go wider than just the art world. Herzog and de Meuron have demonstrated that austere, serious-minded, grown-up architecture, designed by architects who are neither apologetic about their work, nor who feel the need to ingratiate themselves with their audience, can have real popular appeal.

What makes Tate Modern work is that its architects have had the confidence to do a few, very simple things brilliantly well. The light in the galleries is beautiful. The turbine hall, its proportions intensified by excavating the floor down into what was the basement, is truly heroic. And for what is fundamentally a Swiss building, the timber floors, the expanses of unpretentious concrete, and the bricks make it surprisingly tactile. This kind of thing is much more difficult to do than it looks, as other museums that have struggled to tame relics of the industrial revolution no less imposing than Bankside have discovered. In Madrid, the Reina Sofia, which now holds Picasso's Guernica , has still not managed to shake off the grey, institutional feel of the original hospital. And Gae Aulenti's Busby Berkeley insertions in the Gare d'Orsay crush the impressionists into visual insignificance.

Herzog and de Meuron have accepted the logic of the building, with its sparse finishes and made it into something it never was - a public building. A new entrance has been pierced in the west wall and the old machine hall is set to become London's indoor version of the square in front of the Pompidou. 'We don't want to shock people, or overwhelm them,' says Jacques Herzog. 'You accept the existing building as an artificial landscape. Why should you demolish a mountain? Our strategy was to make it a public building.'

Bankside also represents a significant shift in the way that architects deal with old buildings. The conventional approach has been deliberately to play up the tension between new and old, to contrast mellow brick with glittering, hi-tech insertions that look like jewellery. Herzog and de Meuron don't buy that. They aren't interested in the archaeology of Gilbert Scott's flimsy brickwork. They have just cleaned it up, and integrated it with their own work. There are new window and door openings, but you can't really tell which is old and which is new. The result is that on the exterior, you are not really aware of just how much the building has been changed - it has become all Herzog and de Meuron. Yet despite its architectural Calvinism, Bankside has seduced everyone who has seen it. The light, the river, the space make an immediate impression.

Now that it's finished, complete with the little tip of light on top of the chimney, it's hard to see how else it could have been done. Of course, the Tate should divide its collection between modern and British. Of course, it should move its modern collection away from Millbank. And, of course, it should be in Bankside. It wasn't always that way. The Millennium Commissioners who put up much of the cash needed careful persuasion. At least one of the them, Simon Jenkins, was far from convinced that the old power station would make a plausible art gallery. Better turn it over to nineteenth-century machinery rather than give it to the Tate, 'a place dedicated to presenting dirty underpants as art', he argued while pressing the merits of the Dome.

But the positive response to Bankside will open the doors to a new generation of architects, one to whom the old arguments about the architectural avant garde versus traditional virtues of the Prince of Wales variety will seem like an antediluvian irrelevance.

webTitle: But Bob, how does it feel?

fields.headline: But Bob, how does it feel?
fields.standfirst: He should be at home, impregnating a supermodel. Instead, at 59, Bob Dylan is on tour for the zillionth time, playing all the old songs - though not so you'd recognise them. What is he up to?
fields.trailText: He should be at home, impregnating a supermodel. Instead, at 59, Bob Dylan is on tour for the zillionth time, playing all the old songs - though not so you'd recognise them. What is he up to?
fields.body:
Bob Dylan, Hanns Martin Schleyer Halle, Stuttgart

Germany still boasts more moustaches per capita than any country in the free world, so it was no surprise to find them out in force and twitching expectantly last week for the second day of the latest European leg of Bob Dylan's never-ending mission to visit every town on the planet, a tour that has famously been ongoing since records of blond facial hair began.

Last year he was out there playing 120 shows. This man will be 59 next week. He should be at home getting supermodels pregnant. Whatever happened to the old reclusive, unavailable Dylan?

I remember desperately queuing halfway round London all night to buy a ticket for one of his 1978 shows - the first in the UK since his notorious 1966 stopover when the duffel coat police sent him home with a flea in both ears for playing an electric guitar. What excitement it was to have him back! He packed Earl's Court six times - I couldn't believe my luck at actually being there, four miles from the stage, standing on my seat holding a cigarette lighter in the air, and... yes, OK, sporting a junior moustache of my own.

But who, back then, could have guessed that for the next 20 years Bob would be turning up on the world's doorstep every five minutes like a milkman with amnesia. Having said that, no UK dates have been set for this year, though some are expected to be announced in the autumn. Hence, hello Stuttgart, a city striking for the craftsmanship of its roofing contractors.

Dylan comes shambling on stage like a man wandering into a Las Vegas wedding reception: white suit, cowboy boots, suspicion of a perm (long-gone is the unruly, gravity-defying beehive of Don't Look Back ). The band - a pared-down unit of acoustic guitars, drums, stand-up bass - strap themselves in and roar off with a hootin' country song no one normal has remotely heard of about gamblin', rovin' and skirt-chasin' before plunging into an enthusiastic 'reworking' of 'The Times They Are A-Changin', which gets a roar of approval once the audience realises what on earth it is. A handful of early classics follow in lightning succession - 'Desolation Row', 'Tangled Up In Blue', 'Gates of Eden', 'Girl from the North Country'.

It's an efficient, crowd-pleasing set, consisting almost wholly of old faves, which won't harm sales of his latest 'best of' album, out this week, though it's a pity Bob finds room for only three songs from his last studio release, the bluesily atmospheric Time Out Of Mind (1997), trumpeted by all as his finest since Blood On The Tracks in the mid-Seventies - which admittedly says as much about the poverty of his output in the intervening period as anything else. But songs such as 'Love Sick' and 'Not Dark Yet' were strong evidence of a return to form, as is the pounding acoustic 'Things Have Changed', a track written for the forthcoming Michael Douglas film Wonder Boys, and included on the new compilation - though Dylan doesn't sing that tonight either.

His voice is in good shape, despite the tendency to Waitsian gruffness that he's developed down the years. His stage presence, meanwhile... well, it hasn't got any worse. He prowls around, crouching a bit, waggling his foot occasionally, lurching sideways as if to tease some sign of life from the band, who seem content to spend the evening looking at each other's shoes.

The venue doesn't help - an ugly 6,000-seater velodrome shaped like a set of lower dentures. A lot of people have drifted out of their seats, leaving huge cavities around the rear molar area, to join the crowd in front of the stage and creating the impression of a very popular car boot sale. Still, you don't come to a Bob Dylan concert for drama - though we are quick to show our appreciation when any unsought-for excitement comes our way: a ripple of applause every time the curtains change colour, a thunderous cheer for Bob's harmonica, which is as barmy as ever. Even uninteresting guitar solos are greeted with the kind of enthusiasm usually reserved for ice-dancers executing a difficult jump.

Bob doesn't play any of his stuff from the Eighties, which in itself is enough to get my vote. One of his less smart career moves as a rock legend was to come out as a born-again Christian and devote himself to God, who returned the compliment by removing his talent and making him write Slow Train Coming and the execrable Saved. I don't mind if a chap wants to go to church in his spare time, but you don't need forensic knowledge of Cliff Richard to realise that religion is to rock'n'roll what a bucket of cold water is to sex.

But ultimately how much you can get from a Dylan concert these days depends on how much you mind him boiling down the original melodies to an extemporised version using fewer notes and less time to sing them in; whether it bothers you to hear him rattling through your favourite lines like a cattle auctioneer late for an appointment; whether having to identify songs from the chords is such a terrible thing or all part of the fun; whether the pump still works when the vandals take the handles.

Granted, you might not be disappointed if you'd never heard a Dylan song in your life and had just to come and see the great man in the flesh. And the band rocks through the set, nicely balanced between acoustic and electric - even the lead guitarist eventually manages to make proper use of his long hair, obligingly turning into vintage Bon Jovi during 'Leopard-Skin Pill-Box Hat'. And the bar is open throughout for jugs of beer and those giant varnished pretzel things made of sawdust.

But if one of the highlights of your personal pop history is having the hairs on the back of your neck stand up every time you hear the swirl of organ and the words 'How does it feel...' from 'Like A Rolling Stone' then all you can do is sit here and count the number of times Dylan fails to deliver the genuine article. What is he up to? Maybe the old tunes have wandered out of his vocal range, though that seems unlikely. Perhaps he just doesn't want to go through life jumping through hoops of his own making. Whatever, I can't believe I'm the only one who feels like leaping on stage and singing the bloody thing myself.

So in the end I don't stand on my chair, though I do my share of drinking too much beer and whooping. There is no encore to speak of - Dylan divides his set into 12 songs, followed by a bonus six, and then gets someone to turn the lights on to stop us clamouring for more. Not that anybody does. Perhaps we are pleasantly surprised that there is still some evening left to catch a spot of late supper, followed by a stroll and a lap-dancing show. Dylan, of course, has already left the building and is on the bus to Oberhausen - keeping on keeping on, as he used to say.

webTitle: Should I marry my man to make him happy?

fields.headline: Should I marry my man to make him happy?
fields.trailText: My partner and I have been together for five years and we have a three-year-old son. My partner has never made a secret of the fact that he wishes us to be married   but I have always resisted as I don't see what advantage marriage would have for me. I have my own money and my own house (although we live in his house) and we are very happy together.
fields.body:
My partner and I have been together for five years and we have a three-year-old son. My partner has never made a secret of the fact that he wishes us to be married but I have always resisted as I don't see what advantage marriage would have for me. I have my own money and my own house (although we live in his house) and we are very happy together.

He says he wants us to have the same name and be legally accepted as a couple. I view the partnership as a permanent one and, as neither of us is religious, I don't see the point of getting married. Should I go through with this ceremony just to make him happy?
G.B. of Hampshire

There is every reason not to do something you instinctively resist, and 'just to keep him happy' may sound unselfish but could equally well be apathy and a wish for peace at any price over a thorny issue.

One might observe that it's usually the woman who is anxious to wed while the man resists. Traditionally the mother-to-be wants a stable environment and a biddable man (but a strong defender at the same time) to protect and succour the family at a vulnerable stage.

The man, with a disparate reproductive agenda, avoids being tied down any more than he can help and, in these days of secularity and sexual freedom, puts forward the same arguments against marriage as you do. Why are you different?

There is always a degree of role-reversal within a couple and we don't all slavishly follow gender types. Clearly you are a successful person in your own right, and have less need of the physically protective capacity of your man. Maybe he doesn't even have any!

Perhaps he needs to assert his uncertain dominance by giving you his name, marking you as his property and displaying you thus to the world. Equally he may be from a more recent evolutionary stock, with well-defined inclinations to mate for life. Some men are, they tell me.

Living in small family units can put an intolerable strain on inter-personal relationships, dwelling as we often do in tiny boxes in dense conurbations, imprisoned as often as not by work-time pressures, inadequate services and even the weather. If you feel you need some metaphorical space in order to survive, then follow your instinct.

The wedding ceremony is becoming increasingly outmoded, and rightly too. It has been hijacked by religious establishments as an opportunity for being dictatorial and manipulative, and by commercial interests for making an outrageous profit from joyful life events. Few people can afford the traditional affair done in style with all the extravagant trimmings, but feel pressured by social one-upmanship.

Wise folk are bucking the trend and doing their own thing on a more modest and rational scale. You can devise your own personal and idiosyncratic way of making your commitment to each other.

Maybe the more private the compact, the more durable it will prove.

Readers replies

GB's immediate dilemma is perhaps the least of her concerns and its resolution would still leave a number of issues outstanding. The problem as stated is as interesting for what is omitted as for what is said.

The roots of her partner's desire for a legal form of marriage may lie in some desire for security, possibly indicating past betrayal and the need for some formal statement of commitment.

More ominously, it may be the attribution to his partner of some deeper-seated insecurity or doubt in his own level of commitment.

GB also states that her partner wants them to have the same name, which immediately poses the question 'which name?', although the underlying assumption is that it will be his, perhaps, indicating 'ownership' of his partner.

His wishes seem strange at a time when increasing numbers of women retain their own names after marriage and when the law recognises many aspects of shared lives regardless of marital status.

That GB's partner has persisted with these views for five years suggests that she and her partner should resolve underlying issues about trust and security before contemplating marriage.
R.T. of Cheshire

Since G.B.'s partner is the one who wants both himself and his partner to have the same surname, I assume that he intends to take her surname. If so he can change it by deed-poll. Marriage is not required and if both partners have the same surname, it will be socially assumed.

There are considerable financial advantages to being legally married, providing that both partners are certain that this is the person they want to spend the rest of their lives with: pension rights, inheritance rights and unchallengeable community property rights.

The major advantage of not being legally married is that it makes ending the relationship very much simpler.
J.C. of Reading

Next week's dilemma is from C.A. of Reading

I am a 40-year-old woman and I own my own house. Eighteen months ago I rented a room to a young man. For eight months he has been seeing a married woman whose husband has a history of violence. She has often taken refuge in my house after being severely beaten by him and I have never objected although it has made me uncomfortable.

Recently the husband has been telephoning and making threats and has come to the house brandishing a knife, threatening both my lodger and his girlfriend.

My dilemma is that, although I feel terrible about the way she is being treated, I do not feel I should be risking my own safety. Am I being selfish or should I insist that the lodger moves out?

Write to Observer Review or e-mail margaret.cook@observer.co.uk Views on next week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

fields.headline: Yes, but is it Sartre?
fields.standfirst: A fast-moving thriller of sex, politics and murder- from the pen of France's favourite big thinker
fields.trailText: A fast-moving thriller of sex, politics and murder- from the pen of France's favourite big thinker
fields.body:
The Novice Almeida
Mr Kolpert Royal Court Upstairs
The Comedy of Errors RSC

Richard Eyre, maestro of socially provocative theatre during his spell at the National, has returned to direction after a couple of years' absence from the stage. He has done so tantalisingly, directing his own adaptation of a 1948 play by Jean-Paul Sartre. Les Mains Sales - The Novice in Eyre's version - is a study of political commitment, cast in the form of a thriller.

It's an occasion with a lot of allure and electricity. On the stage of the Almeida a woman - chic, moony and motionless - sits among shadows as the audience enters: the glamorous gloom of film noir seeps into the theatre before a word is said. The action, set in an imaginary land, features a clash between principle and pragmatism in political life: its discussions are perennially applicable to public affairs. The plot has sufficient suspense and twists to propel the play's themes: a young middle-class revolutionary (Jamie Glover, whose lover, Jessica, is played by Natasha Little) is contracted to kill his rough-diamond party chief, who is on the point of forming an alliance with liberals and a right-wing aristocracy; the would-be assassin dithers. And at the centre is a performance by Kenneth Cranham, as the party boss, of such explosive impact - the sandpaper voice, the butting forehead and, most important, the total conviction which surges through each speech - that you almost believe these debates are urgent.

They aren't. This is an interesting snapshot of Sartre's mind in the late Forties, but there are no revelations. The central moral dilemma - should you compromise in order to get power? - though general enough to seem pertinent to current political anxieties, is heavily dependent for its expression on the circumstances and vocabulary - proletarian, bourgeois, intellectual, fascist - of postwar France.

The entwining of this dilemma with a theme of sexual anxiety makes the play not more complex but less condensed: it begins to sound like the anguished musings of a man who can't make up his mind whether to go to bed with a woman or throw a grenade. And there are throughout too many redundant formulations, too many pointlessly repeated words - 'No, Olga, No', 'Why did you come here, why?'. These conversations too often strain for significance. This is a production that makes Sartre look more intriguing, but hardly adds to his stature as a thinker.

The dream of a liberating murder also fills the black and stony heart of Mr Kolpert, the contribution of the German playwright David Gieselmann to the Royal Court's international playwrights' season. But Gieselmann's dream is shorn of any political or social dimension, and stripped of explanation. It is also wired with a sense of humour - David Tushingham's translation must be due some praise here - which switchbacks from the po-faced to the riotous.

Richard Wilson - yes, you do believe it - is soaring as a director. And in this short play he tackles real weirdness. A young couple - whose conversation is artificial to the point of eeriness - invites another couple round for the evening. They announce that they've killed a colleague and stuffed the body in a trunk, which is placed in the middle of the stage. At this point the audience may think they are being thrown a line to Patrick Hamilton's Rope .

Then the couple say they were joking. Then the guests show themselves to be at least as unpredictable and violent as their hosts. Then, in the most deadpan, frightening and funny sequence of the play, all four - enigmatic and sleek Amanda Drew, placid and alarming Adam Godley, meek and terrifying Melanie Ramsay, bovine and raging Darren Boyd - sit around eating pizza and behaving as if they were sipping tea at a vicarage. And then everything goes bananas: Julian McGowan's witty white design ends up spattered with gore.

It's the bold slipping and sliding from one kind of improbability to another which makes Mr Kolpert gripping and unusual. That and the conviction of all its actors - not least Callum Dixon as the unfortunate pizza man, who is persuasively gormless.

The RSC's Stratford season is growing in strength. The cycle of Shakespeare's Histories is indispensable, and last month a hit was added to the repertoire with Lynne Parker's buoyant Forties' production of The Comedy of Errors on the main stage. From its opening moments the evening has both shadowy corners and a spring in its step. Across Blaithin Sheerin's tawny Mediterranean design - which manages to look at once vivid and grimy - a procession of characters glide like mechanical toys. There's a nun with a headdress like a meringue, a jaunty fellow in a panama, a sinister mackintoshed lurker. In this tale of the confusions wrought by two pairs of identical twins, all individuality is precarious - sometimes just a matter of putting on a different hat. This is not a play which will transport an audience with the power of its language. It does, however, have one memorable description of a dissolving identity: 'I to the world am like a drop of water/That in the ocean seeks another drop.'

And it has recurring watery images. The production hints at the wateriness in parodic fashion: a trough stands in the middle of the stage occasionally spouting a miniature fountain.

Parker reasonably plays the action as farce: tragedy at the wrong speed. This series of dire events would normally look bleak but performed in swift succession they seem ludicrous - like a bass dirge hurried up. It draws on music hall, silent movies and slapstick: there are funny walks, collapsing props, virtuoso linguistic displays, tours de force of dance. The verse is well-spoken. There are gifted performances from David Tennant as an elastic-limbed, smooth-tongued Antipholus of Syracuse and from Ian Hughes, who makes Tennant's servant into an Italianate Charlie Chaplin. But most striking is the sense of a group of actors playing together, as if they were puppets tugged by a single pair of hands.

It is also wired with a sense of humour - David Tushingham's translation must be due some praise here - which switchbacks from the po-faced to the riotous. Richard Wilson - yes, you do believe it - is soaring as a director. And in this short play he tackles real weirdness. A young couple - whose conversation is artificial to the point of eeriness - invites another couple round for the evening. They announce that they've killed a colleague and stuffed the body in a trunk, which is placed in the middle of the stage. At this point the audience may think they are being thrown a line to Patrick Hamilton's Rope . Then the couple say they were joking. Then the guests show themselves to be at least as unpredictable and violent as their hosts. Then, in the most deadpan, frightening and funny sequence of the play, all four - enigmatic and sleek Amanda Drew, placid and alarming Adam Godley, meek and terrifying Melanie Ramsay, bovine and raging Darren Boyd - sit around eating pizza and behaving as if they were sipping tea at a vicarage. And then everything goes bananas: Julian McGowan's witty white design ends up spattered with gore. It's the bold slipping and sliding from one kind of improbability to another which makes Mr Kolpert gripping and unusual. That and the conviction of all its actors - not least Callum Dixon as the unfortunate pizza man, who is persuasively gormless. The RSC's Stratford season is growing in strength. The cycle of Shakespeare's Histories is indispensable, and last month a hit was added to the repertoire with Lynne Parker's buoyant Forties' production of The Comedy of Errors on the main stage. From its opening moments the evening has both shadowy corners and a spring in its step. Across Blaithin Sheerin's tawny Mediterranean design - which manages to look at once vivid and grimy - a procession of characters glide like mechanical toys. There's a nun with a headdress like a meringue, a jaunty fellow in a panama, a sinister mackintoshed lurker. In this tale of the confusions wrought by two pairs of identical twins, all individuality is precarious - sometimes just a matter of putting on a different hat. This is not a play which will transport an audience with the power of its language. It does, however, have one memorable description of a dissolving identity: 'I to the world am like a drop of water/That in the ocean seeks another drop.' And it has recurring watery images. The production hints at the wateriness in parodic fashion: a trough stands in the middle of the stage occasionally spouting a miniature fountain. Parker reasonably plays the action as farce: tragedy at the wrong speed. This series of dire events would normally look bleak but performed in swift succession they seem ludicrous - like a bass dirge hurried up. It draws on music hall, silent movies and slapstick: there are funny walks, collapsing props, virtuoso linguistic displays, tours de force of dance. The verse is well-spoken. There are gifted performances from David Tennant as an elastic-limbed, smooth-tongued Antipholus of Syracuse and from Ian Hughes, who makes Tennant's servant into an Italianate Charlie Chaplin. But most striking is the sense of a group of actors playing together, as if they were puppets tugged by a single pair of hands.

webTitle: Get the T-shirt, read the book

fields.headline: Get the T-shirt, read the book
fields.standfirst: Tate Modern
fields.trailText: Walking down the long ramp into Tate Modern, I felt like a plane coming in to land. I was tempted to spread out both my arms and run into the building. The art bookshop flanks the ramp, extends beyond it and contributes to the sense of being in a sublime airport. Situated at the foot of two escalators, it is splendidly and compendiously stocked.
fields.body:
Walking down the long ramp into Tate Modern, I felt like a plane coming in to land. I was tempted to spread out both my arms and run into the building. The art bookshop flanks the ramp, extends beyond it and contributes to the sense of being in a sublime airport. Situated at the foot of two escalators, it is splendidly and compendiously stocked.

Before you get to the books, you're in for Tate Modern's branding: T-shirts carry the single blurred word 'Tate'; mugs (turquoise, mauve, cherry) bear the other salient word: 'Modern'. There are acid-green and silver pens (they need to look cool at £4 each). Then there is edible narcissism aplenty: purse-shaped gingerbread with models of Tate Modern stuck on in what looks like pink and blue plasticine.

If Tate Modern's own label does not please, you can upgrade to Paul Smith. Personally, I think Tate Modern has the edge. Paul Smith contributes an an almost insultingly breezy sketch of the building for his T-shirts, bags and his pompous cufflinks and cigarette lighters. And be warned: by the summer, Tate Modern's staff will all be wearing Paul Smith. The association has not cost the gallery anything - designers have been only too happy to be associated with the gallery. It is, after all, a promotion that works two ways.

You can also buy weird domestic objects (part of last year's collaboration between the Tate and Homebase). I rather fancied Richard Wentworth's plates, marked with gold thumbprints, a nice joke for anyone constitutionally disinclined to wash up.

Look above the bookshelves and you see photographs like unspooled film: an indignant, middle-aged woman in a leopard-print frock who looks as if she has never read a book; the scarlet interior of a take-away joint. The images remind me of Hopper's paintings and they reinforce a sense of transit. There is an intriguing selection of photography books and of videos (Rachel Whiteread's House, for example). The postcards are temptingly idiosyncratic, too, but as an addict, I'd have liked a kingsize postcard department. And one other criticism: too many books are cellophane-wrapped with no 'tester' available. This creates the sense that the books are only for show. In a gallery that knows all about 'show', it is essential that the shop should be for more than display purposes only.

fields.headline: The art of staying silent
fields.trailText:
Art R3
The Reith Lectures R4
Between Ourselves R4
fields.body:
Art R3
The Reith Lectures R4
Between Ourselves R4

If all successful West End plays transferred to radio as seamlessly as Yasmina Rezsa's Art (Radio 3) last Sunday, I'd probably never go to the theatre again.

Admittedly this intimate, intricate, wordy all-male three-hander is ideally suited to radio. It's the sort of play you can afford to watch from a cheap seat with restricted viewing because all the drama is in the words. Since it opened in October 1996, Art has had 14 changes of cast, including some impressive names - Tom Courtenay, Albert Finney Jack Dee. Even so, it is hard to think of any combination of voices as perfectly suited to their characters as Alan Bates, Michael Gambon and Simon Russell Beale.

Art is essentially a play about friendship or male bonding, as it is called these days, in which nuances of tone are crucial. On stage, even from a restricted view seat, small movements, a gesture, a glance might cause you to miss that all-important change of inflection but on the radio, with nothing but the voice, it's an altogether different experience, like a shot of single malt without soda or ice.

Communicating wordlessly on the radio is not easy, but when Serge and Marc (Bates and Gambon) are listening to Ivan's interminable monologue about his wedding invitations you do not need to see their faces to gauge their reaction. Their silence says it all.

What said it all for me in this year's Reith Lectures was not the hifalutin talk from Chris Patten about sustainable development being a development in democracy, or words to that effect, but the Indian farmer who got up at the end of the fifth and final lecture broadcast from New Delhi to ask the speaker, environmentalist Vandana Shiva, about his chances of survival in a world where ruthless multi-nationals are rapidly taking over global agriculture and food distribution.

Biodiversity as practised by small farmers since time began is the way it should be. Native women preparing food at home is the way it should be and the way it was in India before the World Trade Organisation insisted on packaging, processing and all the concomitant horrors of modern junk food.

In India, said Shiva, a farmer could expect to get four dollars for a bushel of corn. Kelloggs gets $125 for a bushel of cornflakes. It does not make sense. No wonder so many Indian farmers are committing suicide. It is one of Shiva's responsibilities to comfort their widows.

Who, I wondered, comforted Pamela, the middle-class, middle-aged mother of three when Jonathan, the prisoner she had been writing to on Death Row in Alabama for eight years, was executed? Jonathan asked her to be present at his death, which she described in chilling detail (the warden was chewing gum as he fitted the lethal injection) in the no-holds-barred Radio 4 series Between Ourselves.

If ever there was a case for banning capital punishment because of its sheer pointlessness, this was surely it. You'd expect an element of stridency when dealing with this sort of issue or, worse, freakiness of the Lord Longford sort. Presenter Olivia O'Leary's motherly no-nonsense tones, combined with Pamela's good sense and sensibility, gave the programme added impact.

She reminded me of woman in the Woman's Hour 's new serial, who keeps having to ask her husband's advice. 'Should I go to Death Row then, Robert?' 'Yes, of course, dear, but now I really must mow the lawn.'

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Hogg Robinson | Abbey National
fields.body:
Watch this space: the trickle - of undervalued, quoted firms succumbing to management buyouts - may turn into a flood.

Last week saw one more - travel agent Hogg Robinson - with another in prospect following news that aerospace engineer McKechnie is in talks with Cinven, one of the UK's biggest buyout firms.

There's certainly a wall of money chasing deals. Last Thursday another of the big players, CVC, raised £2 billion. Nomura is pursuing Associated British Ports and Hyder, the Welsh water and electricity group. And it's only a matter of time before Alchemy pops up again after being snubbed by BMW at Rover.

This column has suggested a few yardsticks, such as price and yield, to help pick undervalued shares likely to recover.

Approaches to the likes of McKechnie remind us of another: where executive share options are so out of the money that incentives are diminished. A bid, of course, also puts them above water.

For now, McKechnie is firmly in play and the shares - at 380p against a mooted 400p offer price - are a buy.

Cheap Abbey
There's nothing the market - and the press - likes better in a quiet, after-Easter period, than a juicy bit of specula tion. And right now racy talk of a Barclays bid for Abbey National fits the bill. Nothing, of course, can be ruled out, especially as Barclays has a racy new chief executive in situ .

But there are good reasons to regard the tale as nonsense. And they have nothing to do with branch-cutting mergers, likely to be frowned on after the Cruickshank report into the banking industry.

First, as senior Barclays insiders confirm, any Barclays bid is likely to be highly dilutive. That would send the share price diving and hit the management, with their extravagant new performance bonuses, right in the pocket.

Second, Abbey chief executive Ian Harley is determined not to be swallowed. Any deal with Barclays would simply trigger a counter-bid from Brian Pitman's Lloyds TSB.

Nervertheless, the talk would not be circulating if Abbey's shares weren't ludicrously cheap. At 831p, they are trading well below the 990p at which they ended last year. Buy for recovery.

Gulping oxygen
Perversely, it has taken the thoroughness - or lethargy, depending which side you're on - of US regulators to save a fine British company from a Franco-American carve-up. As a result of the Federal Trade Commission's refusal to jump to Air Liquide and Air Products' bid timetable, the British Oxygen Company can breathe independence.

It was always a scandal that City institutions were prepared to accept £14.60 a share now rather than reap the benefits of BOC's hefty investment a couple of years down the line. Against that marker, the group's price - 984p now the deal has collapsed - looks extremely cheap. The trouble is that, on the face of it, after a full 10 months of damaging destabilisation since this £7bn bid was announced, BOC looks a far more risky investment than before. It has lost a good chief executive, for starters.

All that, however, looks to be discounted in the price. Analysts still put BOC's value at more than £11 a share. And, like twin Arnie Schwarzeneggers, 'We'll be back', the predators-cum-terminators have already vowed.

Track events
Last week's look at sportswear group Hay & Robertson was timely. On Wednesday, BSkyB's bid for Sports Internet duly arrived and with it an offer for H&R's stake in the firm. H&R shares rose 14p to 257p as a result.

But, as we said, hold for more developments in due course.

webTitle: Soldiers join hooligans to attack Turks in Cup clash

fields.headline: Soldiers join hooligans to attack Turks in Cup clash
fields.trailText: A bloodthirsty alliance of British hooligans - including serving soldiers - is out to avenge last month's murder of two Leeds fans by provoking violence at Wednesday's Uefa Cup Final, say police.
fields.body:
A bloodthirsty alliance of British hooligans - including serving soldiers - is out to avenge last month's murder of two Leeds fans by provoking violence at Wednesday's Uefa Cup Final, say police.

Thugs who are normally bitter rivals have joined forces to plan attacks on fans of Turkish side Galatasaray, who play Arsenal on Wednesday in Copenhagen, following the killing of Kevin Speight and Christopher Loftus in Istanbul last month.

Police say up to 200 troublemakers who follow Leeds, Chelsea, Glasgow Rangers, Cardiff City and Swansea City are travelling to Denmark to help Arsenal hooligans assault Turkish fans. The soldiers are Arsenal fans in a regiment stationed in the South-West and have caused problems at some of the London side's recent European games. They have played a key role in putting together the six-club coalition.

An associate of the soldier gang told The Observer that the invitation to Leeds thugs to join them in Copenhagen was extended after Arsenal beat French side Lens to reach the Uefa Cup Final but Leeds went out to Galatasaray. The soldiers - who call themselves Gooners, the nickname for Arsenal fans - rang the Leeds thugs from a bar in Lens to suggest they help them target Turks in a pan-British revenge mission in Copenhagen.

Since then troublemakers from the other four British clubs, including members of the infamous 'Chelsea headhunters' gang, have agreed to join forces.

Friendships across club boundaries, forged through following England abroad, involvement in extreme right-wing politics and joint criminal enterprises have thus enabled Arsenal thugs to persuade up to 200 others to help them cause mayhem.

One Arsenal hooligan with a history of organising trouble is a close ally of a prominent Chelsea 'headhunter' who has a horrendous record of violence. Although Arsenal fans have a good reputation, the club does have a small hardcore following of around 80 thugs. They have been involved in several outbreaks this season, including fighting at both north London derbies against arch-rivals Tottenham Hotspur. When they played Manchester United at Highbury last August, 20 Arsenal hooligans followed one United fan and beat him senseless at a Tube station.

Huge security will surround this week's match. British police 'spotters' will alert their Danish colleagues to known hooligans, while the Danes have pledged to ban any fan without a ticket from entering the country.

The Ministry of Defence said it would investigate plans by any soldiers to go to Copenhagen. A spokesman said: 'This sounds extremely serious and would not be condoned in any way by either the MoD or the civilian police.' Any soldiers known to be intent on causing trouble would be prevented from travelling, he said.

denis.campbell@observer.co.uk

webTitle: How to save a sarin victim

fields.headline: How to save a sarin victim
fields.standfirst:
Dr Toru Saito (52)
Circulatory specialist at Omori Hospital
fields.trailText: The very first thing that came to mind when I heard what had happened on the subway was poison gas. I thought we had better be prepared to deal with either cyanide or sarin. Up until the Matsumoto incident [an outbreak of sarin poisoning by Aum Shinrikyo the previous June, which killed seven people] I knew virtually nothing about sarin. There was no need for me to be up on such a specialist military weapon. It's a nerve gas that was invented by German scientists in the 1930s as part of Hitler's preparation for World War II and used to lethal effect by Iraq in the 1980s against Iran and the Kurds. Ultimately, it is a gaseous form of the kind of phosphates you find in fertilisers and weedkillers, which people sometimes ingest to commit suicide. It is 26 times more deadly than cyanide but, caught in time, can be treated the same way we treat organophosphate poisoning. It was only thanks to the Matsumoto incident that we discovered this.
fields.body:
The very first thing that came to mind when I heard what had happened on the subway was poison gas. I thought we had better be prepared to deal with either cyanide or sarin. Up until the Matsumoto incident [an outbreak of sarin poisoning by Aum Shinrikyo the previous June, which killed seven people] I knew virtually nothing about sarin. There was no need for me to be up on such a specialist military weapon. It's a nerve gas that was invented by German scientists in the 1930s as part of Hitler's preparation for World War II and used to lethal effect by Iraq in the 1980s against Iran and the Kurds. Ultimately, it is a gaseous form of the kind of phosphates you find in fertilisers and weedkillers, which people sometimes ingest to commit suicide. It is 26 times more deadly than cyanide but, caught in time, can be treated the same way we treat organophosphate poisoning. It was only thanks to the Matsumoto incident that we discovered this.

When they brought in the first patient, his pupils were contracted and he was in a serious comatose state. He'd move if pinched, but otherwise there was no response. If this was cyanide, he would be showing signs of acidosis: blood acidity. Acidosis indicates cyanide, but contracted pupils indicate sarin. That was the critical point of differentiation. Blood tests showed no acidosis, reflexes were way down: all symptoms of sarin poisoning. However, a news bulletin had said that signs of acetonitrile, a cyanide compound, had been detected. I decided to try half the special cyanide kit we'd prepared just to be on the safe side.

After injection, his condition improved dramatically. We don't really understand why. I would guess that the perpetrators had mixed acetonitrile into the sarin in order to slow evaporation, giving them time to escape. Pure sarin would have evaporated much too quickly and in all probability killed them straight away.

By the time we knew for sure it was sarin we'd already begun using the right treatment: atropine. Most of the seriously injured regained consciousness within a day. The ones we couldn't save were those whose heart or lungs had stopped before they got to the hospital. Either that, or they were infibrilated on arrival to restart their heartbeat, but became 'vegetables' as a result.

Most of the seriously injured regained consciousness within a day. The ones we couldn't save were those whose heart or lungs had stopped before they got to the hospital. Either that, or they were infibrilated on arrival to restart their heartbeat, but became 'vegetables' as a result.

webTitle: The Sex Pistols play a blinder while George Best scores an own goal

fields.headline: The Sex Pistols play a blinder while George Best scores an own goal
fields.trailText: Pola X | Hanging Up | Snow Falling on Cedars | The Filth and the Fury | My Life So Far | Best | Sullivan's Travels
fields.body:
Pola X (134 mins, 18) Directed by Leos Carax; starring Catherine Deneuve, Guillaume Depardieu

Hanging Up (94 mins, 15) Directed by Diane Keaton; starring Keaton, Meg Ryan, Lisa Kudrow

Snow Falling on Cedars (127 mins, 15) Directed by Scott Hicks; starring Ethan Hawke, Max von Sydow, Youki Kudoh

The Filth and the Fury (107 mins, 15) Directed by Julien Temple; starring the Sex Pistols

My Life So Far (98 mins, 12) Directed by Hugh Hudson; starring Colin Firth, Robbie Norman

Best (106 mins, 15) Directed by Mary McGuckian; starring John Lynch, Ian Bannen, Patsy Kensit

Sullivan's Travels (91 mins, U) Directed by Preston Sturges; starring Joel McCrea, Veronica Lake

The most interesting thing about Leos Carax's Pola X, which was shown in competition in Cannes exactly a year ago, is its title, 'Pola' being an acronym of the French title of Herman Melville's 1852 novel, Pierre or the Ambiguities.

The significance is twofold. First, this pretentious picture is a transposition of Melville's enormous novel from New England to present-day France. It stars Guillaume Depardieu as a modish novelist who leaves his fashionable girlfriend and the chateau in Normandy he shares with his beautiful mother (Catherine Deneuve) to enter a bizarre, countercultural commune with his newly discovered half-sister, a Balkan refugee.

Second, Carax, in this, his first picture since the disaster of Les Amants du Pont Neuf nine years ago, identifies with Melville, who wrote Pierre as a way of coping with the failure of Moby Dick. Carax believes that Les Amants is a masterpiece that will eventually receive the recognition it deserves.

The sentimental, semi-autobiographical comedy Hanging Up, scripted by Nora and Delia Ephron, is certainly sentimental but rarely funny. It centres on three competitive sisters played by Diane Keaton (who also directs), Lisa Kudrow and Meg Ryan, bitching, bickering and finally reconciling as their 79-year-old divorcé father, a curmudgeonly screenwriter (Walter Matthau), suffers from senile dementia and dies. Matthau has never been so unendearing and his dislikeable daughters spend most of the time gabbing on cellular phones, giving a grisly new meaning to 'la donna mobile'.

Divorced from David Guterson's prose and authorial presence, the film version of Snow Falling on Cedars sinks ponderously between two stools, being neither a satisfactory courtroom drama nor a convincing study of a small community coming to terms with a historic crisis.

The present time, from which there are too many flashbacks, is December 1950, nine years after Pearl Harbor, and a Japanese-American is on trial in a small Washington State community for the murder of a fellow fisherman. The accused was a much decorated infantry officer. His imprisoned parents' land was acquired by his victim's family during the war. Eleventh-hour evidence is produced by a journalist who lost an arm on a Pacific beach and carries a torch for the accused's Japanese wife.

This is factitious stuff that is made watchable by the presence of James Cromwell as the judge and James Rebhorn and Max von Sydow as the competing lawyers. If you want to see a great thriller on this subject, get hold of John Sturges's 1955 Bad Day at Black Rock.

Julien Temple made his name in 1979 with The Great Rock'n'Roll Swindle, a striking film about the two years of the Sex Pistols which had then just ended, before going to direct flat-footed fiction.

With the feature-length documentary, The Filth and the Fury, he returns to the Sex Pistols, but this time the object is to show them not as the puppets of Malcolm McLaren but as both self-creations and products of their chaotic times. The title comes from a Daily Mirror headline of 1978 and the film vividly recreates that curious period when Labour lost control and Thatcher was about to take power. You don't have to take Johnny Rotten at his own valuation to think him shrewd and eloquent. 'We stopped at the right time for the wrong reasons,' Rotten concludes. 'Only the fakers survive.'

Based on the childhood memoirs of TV executive Denis Forman, My Life So Far is a nostalgic look at upper-middle-class Scottish life in the 1920s through the eyes of a precocious, somewhat precious 10-year-old lad living with his mother and eccentric inventor father (Colin Firth) in his grandmother's castle.

Things go wrong when a rich, middle-aged uncle (Malcolm McDowell) brings home his alluring young French fiancée (Iréne Jacob), but the picture is never involving or moving. Produced by David Puttnam, directed by Hugh Hudson and dedicated to Ian Charleson, star of their greatest success, this one might have been called 'Cheviots of Fire', and there's no slow motion.

Apart from a long-forgotten exploitation flick depicting Idi Amin as a genocidal sadist and cannibal, I can't think of a living person as odiously represented as George Best is in Mary McGuckian's dreadful Best. John Lynch, the film's co-writer and producer, plays him as a weak-willed, unreliable, womanising alcoholic, but makes no attempt to reconcile the light-footed Ariel on the football pitch with the staggering Caliban off it.

Possible clues in his Belfast childhood and his early days as an apprentice at Manchester United are ignored or rapidly passed over. Patsy Kensit plays an all-purpose soccer groupie and the late Ian Bannen is given yards of clunking dialogue as Matt Busby. The rest of the supporting cast play household sporting names, and they look as much like the people they impersonate as the work of first-term Madame Tussaud's sculptors resembles their subjects.

Another welcome Preston Sturges season at the NFT highlights the 1941 Hollywood-on-Hollywood comedy Sullivan's Travels. Along with Homer's Odyssey, it's the chief influence on the Coens' Oh Brother, Where Art Thou? (in competition at Cannes this month), the arch title derived from the social protest saga that Sturges's cinematic alter ego never gets to make.

fields.headline: Rome with a view
fields.standfirst: Ridley Scott's exhilarating and ferocious Gladiator brings the epic back to life
fields.trailText: Ridley Scott's exhilarating and ferocious Gladiator brings the epic back to life
fields.body:
Gladiator (150 mins, 15) Directed by Ridley Scott; starring Russell Crowe, Richard Harris, Joaquin Phoenix, Oliver Reed

Britain is a nation that for centuries has dispatched its violently inclined citizens to do their dirty work abroad, in the colonies or, more recently, in Hollywood. Ridley Scott, one of our most gifted directors of commercials and a most impressive exponent of screen violence, has yet to make a movie set in this country.

No one could accuse him of being squeamish and his directorial debut in 1977, The Duellists, featured a succession of brutally painful sabre fights between two French officers in the Napoleonic Wars. The extraterrestrial monster leaping from John Hurt's stomach in Alien is among the most shocking moments in movie history, and now in Gladiator, Scott's best film since Thelma and Louise, he's revived the bloodiest of action genres.

Roman history was the chief topic of the Italian epics before the First World War, while Mussolini encouraged another wave of such pictures in the Thirties to celebrate his own imperial ambitions. Meanwhile, Hollywood got in on the act with the silent Ben-Hur of 1924.

The need to meet the challenge of TV with spectacular entertainments and bigger screens brought about a revival of the costume epic in the Fifties, with new film versions of the Victorian novels Quo Vadis? and Ben-Hur, and pictures based on more recent books such as The Robe and Barabbas, many shot at what became known as Hollywood-on-the-Tiber.

They usually contrasted Roman decadence with Christian spirituality, though for all their piety the selling point was brutal combat in the arena rather than prayers in the catacombs.

In April 1964, the month Anthony Mann's The Fall of the Roman Empire premiered in London, there also opened with less fanfare five dubbed Italian epics of the sort known in Italy as 'peplums' (named for the short tunics the heroes wore) and elsewhere as sword and sandal sagas, among them Caesar the Conqueror, Battles of the Gladiators and Gladiators Seven.

But the glut of such movies and the catastrophic box-office failure of the prestigious, all-star Fall of the Roman Empire brought the cycle to a sudden end. Since then, Christians have been thrown to the lions and Roman legionnaires have marched into battle only for laughs, as in the Asterix comedies and Monty Python's Life of Brian.

So here's Ridley Scott in deadly earnest bringing us the most ferocious picture of its kind since Richard Fleischer's Barabbas. But there is no reference to Christianity in Gladiator. It's about the undoing and attempted restoration of civilised values and covers the very events treated in The Fall of the Roman Empire - the death of the stoic Emperor Marcus Aurelius in AD 180, his failed attempt to appoint a worthy successor and the disastrous 13-year rule of his corrupt son, Commodus, from which point Gibbon charts the imperial decline.

Like Scott, Anthony Mann was a great visual stylist and a master of screen violence. But in The Fall of the Roman Empire, he tried to be too tasteful: before the first blood is shed, there's 45 stately minutes of fancy dialogue between the emperor and his Greek counsellor and beautifully composed shots of a spectacular gathering of regional leaders.

Scott doesn't make this mistake. His picture starts with the Roman army on a muddy battlefield near the Danube, straining like greyhounds in the slips to be unleashed on the howling barbarian hordes by their heroic Spanish-born general, Maximus (Russell Crowe). 'What we do in life echoes in eternity,' he tells his troops, establishing the film's principal theme of confronting death and destiny.

Suddenly, flaming arrows fly through the air, catapults unleash balls of fire that explode above the enemy. The centurions advance accompanied by the cavalry and a hand-to-hand battle ensues, with Maximus in the vanguard. The rapid editing gives way to slow motion and an elegiac soundtrack. This is a final costly victory for tired, tested men and a knock-out overture.

When the battle is over, the effete Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) arrives in a Roman equivalent of a movie star's trailer. 'Have I missed the battle?' he asks his father. 'You have missed the war,' says Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris, who has an uncanny resemblance to Alec Guinness in Mann's picture).

The functional dialogue is pared down and rarely lapses into old-fashioned Hollywood historic or high-flown Christopher Fry poetic. Marcus wants Maximus, a fictitious character, to succeed him and make Rome a republic again. But Commodus kills his ailing father, sentences Maximus to death for treason and becomes Caesar.

From then on, the film pits the decent, civic warrior against the libertine villain, the man who, in Gibbon's words, had 'an aversion to whatever was rational or liberal, and a fond attachment to the amusements of the populace: the sports of the circus and amphitheatre, the combats of gladiators and the hunting of wild beasts'.

After turning the tables on his executioners, Maximus embarks on a long voyage home that is like a cross between the travels of Ulysses after the fall of Troy and the travails of Spartacus as slave and enforced gladiator. It is a journey of revenge that brings him from the dusty eastern fringes of the empire back to a Rome corrupted by Commodus.

The movie is at once gloomy and exciting, oppressive and exhilarating, though at times the plot is somewhat puzzling. Its Rome is as grand as that of past movies, but a harder, harsher place, and the succession of battles in the arena are electrifyingly staged, imaginatively varied and increasingly ferocious. Enthralling and appalling, the gladiatorial combat appeals to much that is primitive and atavistic in us, but we experience it through a true hero who has lost everything except his dignity and his will to survive.

There are attractive performances from Oliver Reed (as an ex-gladiator turned arena impresario), Derek Jacobi (happily back in a toga as an honest senator 25 years after I Claudius) and the statuesque Djimon Hounsou as the hero's resigned African friend.

But the movie is dominated by Russell Crowe's towering Maximus, a man of intelligence, probity and Roman virtue. He's the most virile presence in a film of this kind since Richard Burton commanded the widescreen in The Robe, in 1953. Following on from L.A. Confidential and The Insider, Crowe confirms his position as one of the best star character actors around.

When I read that Ridley Scott's next subject was to be Hannibal I naturally supposed that he was going to celebrate Rome's most formidable enemy, whose defeat is bloodily restaged at the Colosseum in Gladiator like an ancient version of a video game. The hero of his next film, however, is Hannibal Lecter, who'd feel very much at home as Commodus's dinner guest.

webTitle: Summer toys: where's this year's Godzilla?

fields.headline: Summer toys: where's this year's Godzilla?
fields.trailText: Where are the toys? This is the time of year when film journalists are allowed to play at being kids in the privacy of their offices. At the magazine I was working at two years ago we spent our time chasing each other round the office with a rubbery Godzilla hand puppet (we went out of business a few months later, but the two facts aren't necessarily connected).
fields.body:
Where are the toys? This is the time of year when film journalists are allowed to play at being kids in the privacy of their offices. At the magazine I was working at two years ago we spent our time chasing each other round the office with a rubbery Godzilla hand puppet (we went out of business a few months later, but the two facts aren't necessarily connected).

Last year, it was Star Wars Lego. 'The courier will be coming this afternoon,' warned one editor sternly after I had been allowed - strictly for research purposes - to assemble a Tie-Fighter and a Land Cruiser at home.

But so far this year, there's nothing. 'Off the top of my head, I can't think of much,' says the salesperson at London comic book shop Forbidden Planet, which last year was doing a roaring trade in Star Wars action figures. 'It's pretty dead at the moment.' Surely the X-Men merchandising will be big?

'I don't when that's due,' he says dubiously. 'There hasn't been much hype.'

Conventional wisdom has had it that the relationship between films and toys was evolving to the point where the tie-in would come before the movie. And that certainly can happen in kids' films: witness the terrifying phenomenon that is Pokémon: The First Movie.

But it is something of an apocalypse postponed. Video game-based movies - Super Mario Bros, Wing Commander, Mortal Combat - have proved no more threatening to the established order than BMX films. The Tomb Raider film will only change that if it manages to be a half-decent film in its own right. The films that seemed at first glance to be designed simply to sell stuff - Toy Story, Small Soldiers, A Bug's Life - turned out to be smart, excellent movies.

Still, there will be toys around this summer: if it lives up to the legacy of Wallace And Gromit in any way, Nick Parks's feature film debut Chicken Run should keep the shops happy.

And then there's the X-Men, and possibly some even smaller than lifesize Tom Cruises from Mission: Impossible 2. But nothing like a couple of years ago, when things were so out of hand that Armageddon included a scene with Godzilla toys getting destroyed, still less the forecast horrors of a time when My Little Pony would matter more in Hollywood than the biggest A-list star.

Which is good news for people who love movies, and bad news for bored journalists looking for something to replace those broken light-sabres.
