fields.headline: The agony and the irony
fields.standfirst: He's the hottest literary star in America and he's written a best-selling memoir about raising his kid brother after his parents' death. Is Dave Eggers for real?
fields.trailText: He's the hottest literary star in America and he's written a best-selling memoir about raising his kid brother after his parents' death. Is Dave Eggers for real?
fields.body:
Dave Eggers opens the front door of his Brooklyn brownstone into a squall of rain, a phone crunched between ear and shoulder, and waves me upstairs. Then he disappears, leaving me to wait in a front room that is a cross between an Oxbridge don's study and my little brother's bedroom - precarious piles of books everywhere you look, a slew of post and papers covering the floor, and boys' things - balls and frisbees and baseball stuff - scattered over the chairs.

I mooch a bit, examining the books' spines - a mix of the arcane and the newly published - and it doesn't feel at all strange to be here, in Dave Eggers's living room, because, like the thousands of Americans who have bought his memoir, A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, I feel as if I have known Eggers for years.

Certainly I know more about his life and his family than I do about many of my friends. When Eggers was 21, both his parents died of cancer in the space of 32 days, leaving him to bring up his little brother, Toph (pronounced 'Tofe', short for Christopher), who was eight. A heartbreaking tale, to be sure, but what makes AHWOSG (as the author refers to it throughout his preface) different from the legion of personal memoirs currently flooding bookshops is Eggers's style - deliberately knowing and self-conscious, layer upon layer of irony but also vibrant, energetic and, in spite of the subject matter, splutteringly, rib-clutchingly funny, in a self-mocking sort of way.

The book was published in the US in February this year to wildly excited reviews, but its success has largely been through word of mouth; it is still roosting contentedly in the New York Times best-seller lists after 12 weeks and the offers for the film rights are still coming thick and fast. In fact, the person on the other end of the phone when I arrive is a lawyer discussing this very question.

We go to a diner around the corner; Eggers is hungover and tired and wants food. He is smaller than I expected, with exuberant hair and what he describes in the book as 'deeply carved laugh lines'; he wears khaki shorts and a T-shirt that look as if they came from LL Bean or The Gap some years ago. When I check his present age, he says: 'Forty-seven. But I've been telling everyone 30.'

He talks much as he writes - a forceful stream of consciousness, thoughts sprouting in all directions - but I am saved the challenge of taking notes, as Eggers has agreed to see me in New York on the condition that I do not quote anything he says during this meeting, and that the interview proper must be done by e-mail so that he has time to weigh up his answers. He is still sensitive about publicity, he confides, fearful of being misrepresented, easily upset by unfavourable reviews (though these have been almost non-existent). What follows, then, is a kind of fictionalisation of fact, a compression of different events into the same time frame, and Eggers, I hope, can't help but approve, since it's a technique he has employed - and drawn attention to - to great effect himself.

There is an episode in the book in which a well-meaning girl in a bar asks after his brother; Eggers, tired of the same question, replies with an elaborate story about Toph shooting a classmate and then taking off hitch-hiking in the Dakotas, which the unfortunate girl swallows entirely, her shocked sympathy only encouraging Eggers to further fabulation. DE: (leaning confidentially across his waffle with furtive expression) Well... he doesn't actually know about it yet. To tell the truth, I'm afraid to tell him. Where do you start? I don't know what it might do to him.

SM: (baffled) But... how could he not have noticed? With the reading tour and the interviews and everything?

DE: (with an expression at once stoic and sorrowful, tapping his temple) Well, you see - he's in this special school for retarded kids...

SM: (witlessly open-mouthed) And you left that out of the book?!

After watching me flounder for some minutes he says, grinning ruefully, 'you're too easy', and goes on to explain that he won't answer any questions about Toph, who is now 16. 'My talking about him ended, in the book and in public, when he was 13.'

He refuses to answer other questions too, those relating to his private life in the present, often simply referring me to the book or giving jokey responses with a straight face, as if to suggest that we already have everything we could want to know about him between hard covers. This seems a curious stance given the extreme candour of the book, but Eggers is as tricky to interview as the book is to review - not because either are deliberately difficult, but quite the reverse. Every question you could devise has already been pre-empted by Eggers himself in the book, including the obvious problems and contradictions inherent in choosing to lay yourself bare in a memoir. 'Maybe writing about actual events,' he muses in the hilarious Acknowledgements section, 'in the first person, if not from Ireland and before you turned 70, was Bad.'

So why did he choose to write so bluntly about his parents' deaths?

'It's hard to say. I was writing about that winter's events as soon as that spring, while still in college, and I was basically transcribing these scenes straight from my weekends at home. It was creepy. I was creepy. I'm not exactly sure what compelled me to do that, but suffice it to say that I always had the feeling, every day after that winter, that I would someday get it all down.'

It was not, he says, a substitute for therapy - 'I can't really equate it with therapy, never having been in or had much faith in therapy.'

So what did he hope it might achieve? 'I wished it would do what it appears to have already done,' he replies, deadpan. 'Cure tuberculosis and bring democracy to East Africa.'

Eggers grew up in Lake Forest, an affluent town near Chicago (described by a friend in the book as 'a nightmare WASP utopia') with his lawyer father and schoolteacher mother, his two older siblings, Beth and Bill and, later, Toph. His father was an alcoholic, occasionally violent, who determinedly carried on drinking while pretending to his family that he was seeking help: 'The most famous trick was the AA trick, which involved attending AA meetings, in our house even, while a few fingers under.'

At times he could be frightening - 'not that he ever hit us all that hard', Eggers writes - but it was his unpredictability that terrified them as children into hiding from his wrath. Eggers describes locking himself in his room and attempting to escape through the window with a sheet tied to the bed as his father pounded furiously on the door. Despite these episodes, their family life appears on the whole to have been happy, but you get the sense that he feels the loss of his mother more keenly - it is her death, her funeral and her memory that dominate his story, while his father is more shadowy, glimpsed in brief scenes.

Immediately after the deaths (his father from lung cancer, his mother from stomach cancer), they sold the family home, and Eggers and Toph headed west to California, where Bill was working and Beth was starting law school, brimful of exhilaration and a kind of righteous anger, a feeling that the world owed them a huge debt. Eggers was flung into an unorthodox, experimental parenting with no one to explain the rules. Life is full of food-fights, sock-sliding contests, take-out, mess and unwashed laundry. 'I am making our lives a music video, a game show on Nickelodeon - lots of quick cuts, crazy camera angles, fun, fun, fun!'

But behind the fun is an obsessive fear for Toph's safety, an over-compensation that becomes a running joke - this fear that if he lets Toph down in the smallest detail, the boy will grow up 'with an interest in guns and uniforms', or worse. Did the circumstances made him harder on Toph in some ways than his parents might have been?

'Well, fearing for his future, as any parent would, is not the same as being strict, which I wasn't. Much of my parents' strategy had to do with trust, and they created a situation where I wanted to reward that trust, and also a place where rebellion would not find the friction it requires. I remember once, after being ragged on for something minor, complaining that I should never be hassled at all, given that I didn't do drugs, wasn't in a gang, etc. And they said what they always said, which was: 'Go ahead, moron - do drugs, join a gang. It's your stupid life.' Which is, I feel, the perfect way to defuse any run-of-the-mill teenage rebellion. Things were similar with Toph and me, though because we're closer in age, there was - and is - even less need for rebellion or punishment.'

How would his experience with Toph affect him if he had children of his own, I wondered?

Eggers looks serious. He has decided there is something wrong with his bacon. 'Well,' he says, slowly. 'The most important thing I learned is that when your child is eating paint chips, it's almost never healthy. No matter how adorable they look while they're doing it.'

The brothers still live together, having moved from San Francisco to New York two years ago when Eggers's idealistic magazine venture, Might, folded. Toph is at high school and Eggers now edits McSweeney's, a literary journal run on a shoestring and printed in Iceland ('we figured, why not?'), produced from a tiny room in Eggers's flat, no bigger than a cupboard and waist-deep in post. In spite - or perhaps because - of its policy of not paying contributors, McSweeney's has acquired a reputation as an important forum for new writing, including some of the most sought-after names in American fiction: Rick Moody, David Foster Wallace, Jonathan Lethem and George Saunders, among others.

Eggers has been portrayed by the American press as supremely unworldly, largely because of reports that he lives in a bedsit and turned down a $2 million offer for the film rights to AHWOSG because he would find a film too upsetting. (It's not a bedsit, by the way. Under the mess, it's quite a substantial apartment in Park Slope, the nicest part of Brooklyn, a short subway ride from central Manhattan.) These reports were pure surmise, he says. If he were to sell film rights, he says, he would give the money to charity, but won't discuss it any further.

I ask if he has been surprised by his book's extraordinary success.

'Yes, I was surprised. It's a weird book, right? I truly felt, and Toph felt, and most of my friends felt, that it was much too insular and specific and self-indulgent to appeal to anyone outside of our small coterie of friends and family.'

So what is it about his story that has captured the imagination of America?

He does that serious smile again, leaning forward over the table.

'Since it became popular, I've done a lot of thinking about it, and I'm pretty sure the success was due to one factor that no one had kept in mind, though it now seems obvious: my great clothes. I mean, I have really great clothes. And in America, thank God, that counts for something.'

fields.headline: LA goes back to basics
fields.standfirst: Sophistication has been the watchword this year. But summer, says  Andrew Collins,  is no time for intellectual pretensions. As  X-Men shows, size is everything
fields.trailText: Sophistication has been the watchword this year. But summer, says Andrew Collins, is no time for intellectual pretensions. As X-Men shows, size is everything
fields.body:
The Academy Awards are, by their very nature, a backward-looking event - a review rather than a preview - so how come the results are so quickly pressed into service as a divining rod? Spot a common thread among the winners and you've got a map of Hollywood's future. Take the Academy's temperature in March, and you can predict the industry's health for the rest of the year.

If only. Forget everything you read about cinema's 'thinking person's revolution' at the beginning of the year - summer has arrived.

This year the prevailing Oscar mood was sophistication and cleverness, edginess and 'feelbad'. With American Beauty, Being John Malkovich, Boys Don't Cry and even the downbeat The Sixth Sense, things were looking distinctly iffy for Old Hollywood, and the path was cleared, we imagined, for a new wave of smart films, reflecting a smart century. Wishful thinking?

Looking at the summer release schedules, it appears the high-minded dinner party is over, if not for good, then certainly for the holidays. Because summer means bums on seats, not brains in gear. It means sun-addled folks in silly hats looking to get out of the heat and into a nice, dark, air-conditioned cinema. It means restless, off-school kids and bored Euro 2000 widows.

Every summer the studios wheel out the big guns, desperately hoping last year's Speed 2 / Godzilla / Wild Wild West was just a blip on the graph. If a major film like Mission: Impossible 2 isn't ready for Christmas, it's put into a holding pattern for six months. And a costly epic like Gladiator is strategically nudged forward to May to beat the inevitable scrum.

Last year's Blair Witch Project was going to herald a new era of 'guerrilla distribution'. Well, not just yet. This summer it's like Blair Witch never happened. The goods on offer are as old-fashioned as an advert telling you the Golden Temple Tandoori is 'situated within walking distance of this theatre'. So much for all that tea-leaf-reading at the Oscars: we're back with noisy sequels, comic books, cute animals and matinée favourites. And, all intellectual pretensions aside, it sounds like a perfect summer.

Who wants their brain taxed in August by a post-modern, meta-theoretical satire on the nature of celebrity? Who wants to dip out of the midday heat into a cool auditorium, load up on Haagen Dazs and see a psychological ghost story - indeed, anything psychological? Summers were made for Batman and Die Hard and Austin Powers. Last summer, as if you'd forgotten, was made for The Phantom Menace, which duly proved itself critic-proof and ate the world, taking an eventual $430 million in the States and $922m worldwide.

It's almost pointless to say 'Beat that!' this year, but sci-fi action is well-served by Bryan Singer's much-anticipated live-action Marvel adaptation The X-Men, and L. Ron Hubbard's Battlefield Earth with Scientology poster-boy John Travolta in the lead Klingon-esque alien role.

There's also Don Bluth's animated space yarn Titan AE - one for the sort of teenage boy who isn't interested in sport. In short, never underestimate the market for sci-fi in summertime - even with Phantom Menace cleaning up last year, The Matrix still found a huge audience.

In 1996 Tom Cruise sealed his reputation as 'King of Memorial Day' when Mission: Impossible opened big at the start of summer. This year, with the stereotype-busting Eyes Wide Shut and Magnolia under his belt, Cruise returns to blockbusting. Beset by woes it may have been, but Mission: Impossible 2 is by default this season's 'tentpole picture', as they say in Hollywood marketing meetings.

A further octane fix will be found in the Jerry Bruckheimer-produced Gone In 60 Seconds - more offbeat, with Nicolas Cage and Angelina Jolie (and Vinnie Jones!), it's already one of the most exciting trailers in circulation.

The Perfect Storm, a true-life disaster-at-sea spectacle directed by Das Boot 's Wolfgang Petersen, is being touted as a mini-Titanic (they all go down in a trawler). Although it's pure action, George Clooney may throw a line to the ladies. Which is just as well, because if there's an obvious gap in the market this summer it's 'chick flicks'. Where are they?

Romantic comedy-wise, it's pretty much Jim Carrey and Renee Zellwegger in Me, Myself And Irene, or stay at home. (And Carrey is no conventional heart-throb.) There's the winning John Cusack in High Fidelity, Nick Hornby's sad-lad novel transplanted to Chicago, but that's mostly about alphabetising vinyl records, making lists and discussing the merits of Stereolab singles - hardly a 'chick' magnet. It's rare for the studios to overlook an entire section of the cinema-going audience, especially one that proved so profitable with Titanic, but if you're female and you comply with what marketing people think females prefer at the pictures, you're stuffed. Unless the notion of a comedy about fertility treatment (Ben Elton's Maybe Baby) hits the right buttons for you. Let's hope not.

The brats are well-served by two huge, animal-themed kiddyflicks. Stuart Little, a film about a talking mouse, has already done big business in America, putting our own Hugh Laurie at number one in the US box office, and might well be this summer's Babe over here. Then there's Nick Park's eagerly-awaited DreamWorks-backed Chicken Run. A 'chicken flick', if you will, it boasts Mel Gibson and Jane Horrocks in the vocal talent department and will be a test-case: can you sell old-fangled, stop-frame plasticine animation to the Pixar generation?

If Chicken Run succeeds - and the runes are good - it will be the surest sign yet that computer-generated wizardry is not the be-all and end-all of family films. In America - though not over here - Park's clay hens go head to head with the pixellated prehistoric reptiles of Disney's $200m Dinosaur (a sentimental, big-screen Walking With Dinosaurs to you or me). Let the little ones decide.

Perhaps we shouldn't be surprised at this old-fashioned groundswell. The end of the twentieth century was characterised not so much by millennial panic as by overwhelming nostalgia.

Steven Spielberg's Saving Private Ryan tapped in to an international sense of loss, as we realised that the D-Day veterans were an endangered species. The old truism 'They don't make 'em like that any more' stopped being the whine of pensioners and became a back-to-basics clarion call to film-makers blinded by science and studios stung by overspending. And the Private Ryan effect has given us one of this summer's finer blockbusters, U-571, a World War II mission movie so old-fashioned it might have been made 40 years ago. Except for the Dolby sound. If this summer's movies prove anything, it's that they do still make 'em like that. The $922 million question is: will we pay to go and see 'em?

It's rare for the studios to overlook an entire section of the cinema-going audience, especially one that proved so profitable with Titanic, but if you're female and you comply with what marketing people think females prefer at the pictures, you're stuffed. Unless the notion of a comedy about fertility treatment (Ben Elton's Maybe Baby) hits the right buttons for you. Let's hope not. The brats are well-served by two huge, animal-themed kiddyflicks. Stuart Little, a film about a talking mouse, has already done big business in America, putting our own Hugh Laurie at number one in the US box office, and might well be this summer's Babe over here. Then there's Nick Park's eagerly-awaited DreamWorks-backed Chicken Run. A 'chicken flick', if you will, it boasts Mel Gibson and Jane Horrocks in the vocal talent department and will be a test-case: can you sell old-fangled, stop-frame plasticine animation to the Pixar generation? If Chicken Run succeeds - and the runes are good - it will be the surest sign yet that computer-generated wizardry is not the be-all and end-all of family films. In America - though not over here - Park's clay hens go head to head with the pixellated prehistoric reptiles of Disney's $200m Dinosaur (a sentimental, big-screen Walking With Dinosaurs to you or me). Let the little ones decide. Perhaps we shouldn't be surprised at this old-fashioned groundswell. The end of the twentieth century was characterised not so much by millennial panic as by overwhelming nostalgia. Steven Spielberg's Saving Private Ryan tapped in to an international sense of loss, as we realised that the D-Day veterans were an endangered species. The old truism 'They don't make 'em like that any more' stopped being the whine of pensioners and became a back-to-basics clarion call to film-makers blinded by science and studios stung by overspending. And the Private Ryan effect has given us one of this summer's finer blockbusters, U-571, a World War II mission movie so old-fashioned it might have been made 40 years ago. Except for the Dolby sound. If this summer's movies prove anything, it's that they do still make 'em like that. The $922 million question is: will we pay to go and see 'em?

fields.headline: Advertising upstart tops the league
fields.standfirst: Martin Sorrell, once the Saatchis' number cruncher, now the globe's biggest ad man, talks to  Emily Bell
fields.trailText: Martin Sorrell, once the Saatchis' number cruncher, now the globe's biggest ad man, talks to Emily Bell
fields.body:
Sir Martin Sorrell was disappointed not to make the opening party of Tate Modern on Thursday. An old school friend of Nicholas Serota's and a huge fan of the new development, Sorrell was one of the few people in London who really did have something better to do.

The chief executive of WPP was in fact putting the finishing touches to a £3 billion takeover of ad group Y&R, which was duly announced on Friday morning.

The deal puts Sorrell's company at the top of the worldwide advertising league by a sizable margin, with combined annual billings of more than £35 billion, and comes at the end of a month's touch-and-go negotiating. It was a far less chipper Sorrell who a fortnight ago sat in his London office sourly contemplating the fact that his approach was being fought tooth and nail, mostly by Tom Bell, head of Y&R, who attempted to stitch together a white-knight deal with French-based group Publicis in order to keep his company out of Sorrell's clutches.

Sorrell has magnanimously given Bell a chairman's role to help smooth the passage of the merger, although he admits 'it has been a pretty difficult process for both of us'.

He is, however, used to inspiring fear and derision in his takeover targets. When he bought J Walter Thompson in an audacious hostile takeover in 1987, he was still seen as just Saatchi & Saatchi's former finance director, a man of over-arching ambition who lacked the creative flair for really succeeding in the ad business. Two years later when again he won a hostile takeover battle, for Ogilvy and Mather, its illustrious founder described Sorrell as 'an odious little jerk'.

His former colleagues, Charles and Maurice Saatchi, clashed frequently with their upstart accountant as he battled with them for supremacy in the advertising arena.

But Sorrell's triumph against a decade of his peers secretly and publicly willing him to fail is a sign of the industry's maturity.

The days of the start-up superstars, which Saatchi and Saatchi championed in the Eighties, are long gone. So is the mentality that a pair of pink socks and a box of pencils were the only qualifications for success. Agency groupings have become bigger and the kind of hands-on management and concentration on margins and shareholder value for which Sorrell was once lambasted have become the norm.

'I suspect that we will see another round of consolidation in the industry triggered by our deal,' says Sorrell, adding that the move towards larger groupings was not at all out of kilter with the world of the advertising client.

'We are not a conglomerate; we are very focused in what we do. And the world is changing. I would never be relaxed about saying that client conflict is less of an issue - it's still a very sensitive area - but you see alliances in areas of business where previously it would have been unthinkable.'

Sorrell points to the automotive industry, where alliances between manufacturers have taken over from obsessive competition and secrecy. He says that today the idea of owning three different communications networks (he doesn't like the term 'ad agency') is perfectly sensible.

'We can add value and we can improve margins. Y&R's margins are roughly in line with our own and our target to go from 14 per cent margins to 14.5 per cent to 15 per cent by 2002 is entirely achievable. In fact we may accelerate that target. And then the question is, is there life after 15 per cent? I think there is.' Sorrell cites as examples agencies where margins run at 20 per cent.

Although about as unsexy as an Oxo ad, Sorrell's insistence that advertising businesses could produce margins of more than 10 per cent used to send a mass attack of the vapours around the wine bars of Soho, where account directors saw their on-expenses lunches and company 4x4s under direct threat.

'There is an inevitable logic about what we are doing with this deal,' says Sorrell. 'We already have clients shared with Y&R in Ford, Sears, Mattel and Kraft. Y&R has similar strengths to ours in planning and research and the work it does on assessing brand values.'

The sceptics looking at the deal wonder, first, whether the extra size it gives WPP is just being big for the sake of being biggest and, second, whether, given the financial crisis the O&M purchase pushed WPP into, whether it is wise to be once again plunging into acquisitions.

On the first count, Sorrell's argument for the deal is that it moves with industrial logic and globalisation of business. On the second, the deal looks much more comfortable - it is based on paper, not debt, and the industry shows no sign, as it did in 1990, of toppling into recession.

'The outlook is very good indeed,' says Sorrell. 'We have Olympic year and the US presidential election, which boost advertising growth and forecasts and see the overall market growing steadily at between 5 and 7 per cent. So we are confident that, with the savings we have to deliver, the deal will be earnings-enhancing in the first year.'

One wonders, with Sorrell bestriding the planet, what Charles and Maurice Saatchi are up to. 'I don't know. You had better ring them up and ask them,' says Sorrell wryly. At least they would have had time to go to the Tate opening.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Rupert, where did it all go wrong? | Glover misses out
fields.body:
Murdoch listens to the crowds
The comically misnamed biopic Best, produced by Sky TV, suffered one or two glitches during filming. The production team successfully advertised for crowds to turn up at Old Trafford for the reconstructed crowd scenes but, this being well over a year ago, it was in the midst of BSkyB's controversial bid for Manchester United. Dutifully, the packed stand of Man U loyalists chanted 'Murdoch is a Wanker' for a full half hour - leading to several retakes and, even then, a problem with how much of the 'original soundtrack' could be used.

Glover fails to land a catch
Disappointment last week for the talented Spectator columnist Stephen Glover, whose opinions on the media enthrall a nation on a weekly basis. He was 'up for an award' from the Periodical Publishers Association and as great fans of his hilarious column we were obviously upset to hear that Glover's entry had been pipped at the post by a man from The Field - a magazine for country folk which this month carries a 'rod and reel supplement'. In the latest edition Charles Rangeley-Wilson, the victorious candidate, writes fulsomely about 'rod and reels on Test (and Tay)' - which is a fishing joke. Hard luck Stephen, maybe next year - unless someone from Model Railway submits a stonker.

A picture speaks a thousand captions
Picture of the week goes to The Times for printing in its media section a pic of C4 chief executive Michael Jackson perched - somewhat camply it has to be said - on top of a fridge. Why he is sitting on what we assume is the cooler for Pepsis for the cast and crew of Queer as Folk is anyone's guess. But the wicked Times caption writer has accompanied it with the unfortunately punctuated phrase: 'Michael Jackson comes out [new line] against the privatisation of Channel 4.'

'Psycho' Ward recaptured
Enemies of Tina Brown's magazine Talk have been making enough hay to fill a large loft over the appointment of executive editor Vicky Ward. Originally from the UK press, she had latterly been working at the New York Post, where erudite website Salon.com bitchily reported there was 'singing and dancing' among the staff when 'Psycho' Ward's departure was announced. Unreported, but an interesting dynastic fact, is that Ward is married to Matthew Doull, former Telegraph journalist and nephew of eurosceptic Telegraph proprietor Conrad Black. The dominance of the trans-Atlantic media power couple in New York would appear to be almost complete...

Theatrical interruptus
In the Big Apple, it would appear Hillary Clinton may get the mayor's job on a plate after Rudy Giuliani, the standing member for Manhattan, was caught carrying on with another woman. This prompted Mrs G to leave him. It may also explain what Mrs Giuliani was doing taffled up with a profoundly embarrassing theatrical production called the Vagina Monologues . Her quitting the production led Salon.com, the erudite website, to run the glorious headline 'Giuliani's Wife Pulls Out of Vagina'.

After the calm, The Storm
A lovely letter arrived last week - on Friday in fact - from The Storm, a consortium bidding for a radio franchise in the West Midlands. The enthusiastic new chairman of the group chirpily announces that The Storm will be a 'dynamic new radio service for people of Birmingham, Wolverhampton and Coventry'. The enthusiastic entrepreneur who had penned the letter is of course John Towers, the newly minted owner of Rover cars. Nice to know he had to time to worry about other aspects of his portfolio - although the Radio Authority is probably expecting him to offer a bit more than the tenner he paid out for a car factory.

fields.headline: To the victor, the spoiled
fields.standfirst:
Oliver Morgan talks to the 'saviour' of Longbridge
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Oliver Morgan talks to the 'saviour' of Longbridge
fields.body:
The man can yawn. In the space of a 45-minute interview he lets out three tonsil-baring gasps. Perhaps he's simply bored. But he makes no attempt to hide them. It's as though he is saying, 'All this saving the British car industry lark gets a bit tiring, you know.'

Yawns apart, John Towers does his best to be sprightly, and could not be more congenial. So how does he feel about snatching Britain's embattled car maker from under the nose of one of the country's most active venture capitalists? What is it like to return to the business he left five years ago after falling out with its then owner - and now seller - BMW?

'I feel good about it,' he says, and yawns. 'I have been spending an awful lot of time trying to mix the euphoria, with a sense of, "Christ there's a lot of hard work to be done here". And I am also looking forward to a proper night's sleep. The last one I had was three weeks ago.'

There is, as Towers says, an awful lot of work to do. Rover lost BMW £800 million last year - after the German firm invested £3 billion in the years since it bought it from British Aerospace in 1994. Though Longbridge itself does not make up all of either the figure. The only way it has managed to sell cars is by discounting so deeply that it loses around £1,500 a vehicle.

It badly needs new models. But few think Towers has the billions needed to finance them himself. He needs a partner, or he's doomed. So far, despite rumours, there's nothing on the table.

Why did he get into this?

'I knew it was a challenging business plan,' he says. 'But I knew it was do-able. One of the things that helped me was that I had a bunch of people here - the dealers, suppliers and trade unions - who did not make demands that mean Rover has to make huge profits for the sake of them. There is nobody here wanting massive returns on behalf of investors.'

Although 'most people would prefer to believe that there is personal greed in the process', Towers doesn't think there is. He is not prepared to give details of his own financial package. 'I have put quite a lot of my own personal money into this, so I don't want to put any more in,' he says. He promises that the company 'will be run in a very different way'.

Towers, who is 52 and began his career as a student apprentice at Perkins Diesels, met Stephen Byers when the Trade and Industry Secretary visited Longbridge on 17 March, in the aftermath of the Alchemy break-up bid for Rover. 'We had a light discussion about whether anything else could be done.'

Towers wrote a paper over that weekend. He did not offer a solution; instead, he outlined the positions of the other players, and worked out how he might make a better offer to BMW. He wanted to undo Alchemy's 'done deal'.

People were already engaged - dealers such as John Edwards, suppliers and trade unions, led by the Transport and General Workers Union's Tony Woodley.

'We didn't have a cat in hell's chance back then. But one view I held was that Alchemy would pull out. And when they did, I realised the cat had a chance.'

So what could he offer BMW's chief Joachim Milberg that Alchemy's Jon Moulton couldn't? 'Less pain - in cost and public reaction.'

Towers, an engineering graduate who is married with two children, faced scepticism about the lack of money to back his plans. 'I was getting totally cheesed off. We had conversations about the finance package long before. What we didn't do - and this is such 11-plus stuff - was put it in place. There was not the information available to allow us to put it into place. Now we have got all the finances we need. We still have a highly financeable balance sheet. But what was getting on my nerves is that if you are getting railroaded into a financing position at that stage, it is very expensive.'

So can he outline what the position is?

Short answer: no. Towers will not discuss commercially sensitive issues.

However, he concedes that a debt auction - whereby financial institutions will be asked to bid to supply Rover debt - is a likely mechanism for raising working capital to add to a soft £500m BMW loan

So where is Rover heading under Towers?

In 14 months he has promised to turn around cash drainage, and after two years he is looking for profits.

Towers says: 'In two years' you will have a lot of exciting new products.' Some will be modelled around the sports car brands, MG and Austin-Healey, and based on modifications to existing platforms. He says his consortium partner, Nick Stephenson, has plans on the drawing board.

There could also be a supercharged Rover 75 with an upgraded K-series engine. 'That could very quickly become an extremely exotic motor car,' he says. 'In five years' time, the business will be collaborating heavily with someone creating a new platform. The first new platform issue is the 45, then the 25, then the 75.'

He will not take on BMW's new R30 small car.

Towers envisages the development cost of a new model with a partner at between £600m and £700m. Rover would put in some money, and agree to build the car. Effectively, it would become a contracting car development and construc tion company with a partner.

'I would say: if I take this volume and I bring that to the programme, why don't we share our costs on a volume basis. Or, better still: let me give you a margin per car for having the benefit of being part of this programme.'

Has he talked to Honda?

'I've said, "Good idea, good personal relationship", but it does not have to be them. VW have done a job with Seat and Skoda. They would be able to do something here. But I wonder if they have all the capacity in Europe they want.'

Costs have to come out. The engineering and marketing departments have, he believes, considerable opportunities - and about 1,000 redundancies are planned.

'In total terms I would say there is something in the region of £300m to £400m to be saved in this business annually on a £2bn turnover.'

Towers believes Rover's finances look worse than they are because of BMW's German accounting methods. They made the UK firm depreciate assets over shorter periods and wrote off assets over-cautiously.

Reverting to UK methods will help him, but he says his main aim is to make the com pany profitable, rather than worry about the effect of accounting .

'Somebody said the profit and loss account is opinion. The balance sheet and the cash position are fact.'

It's no surprise when Towers says he has meetings to go to. He continues to talk as he packs his bags, visits the lavatory, and leaves the 'Kremlin', Rover's executive building.

Then he jumps into the 'moonstone' green Rover 75 in which he arrived triumphantly last Tuesday, and is off. It is 3.15pm and bedtime is many yawns away.

He continues to talk as he packs his bags, visits the lavatory, and leaves the 'Kremlin', Rover's executive building. Then he jumps into the 'moonstone' green Rover 75 in which he arrived triumphantly last Tuesday, and is off. It is 3.15pm and bedtime is many yawns away.

webTitle: Of old lame ducks and new high-fliers

fields.headline: Of old lame ducks and new high-fliers
fields.standfirst: When industries fail, governments should resist the great temptation to intervene, argues  Geoffrey Owen
fields.trailText: When industries fail, governments should resist the great temptation to intervene, argues Geoffrey Owen
fields.body:
When Michael Heseltine was appointed Trade and Industry Secretary in 1992, he famously declared his willingness to intervene in industry 'before breakfast, before lunch, before dinner - and I'll get up next morning and I'll start all over again'.

In practice, however, this statement was almost wholly rhetorical. By the time Heseltine took office, the era of active industrial intervention, in the sense of selecting specific sectors and companies for government support, was over. This was true not just of Britain, but also of other European countries, France among them, which had been enthusiastic proponents of such policies.

Is the Blair government about to turn the clock back? Faced with crises in cars, shipbuilding and other parts of manufacturing, it is under great pressure to do so. Some recent decisions, notably the offer of help to the coal industry, hark back to the 'lame duck' days of the Sixties and Seventies.

But, quite apart from the need to abide by the European Union rules on state aid, Ministers are aware of the damage that was caused by misguided intervention in those two decades. The general effect, as in the British Leyland rescue of 1975, was to postpone necessary changes and pile up problems which then had to be tackled, under much more difficult circumstances, a few years later.

Some people argue that what was wrong was not the principle of intervention, but the way it was carried out: British politicians and civil servants, unlike their French counterparts, were simply bad at intervening.

But the effectiveness of French industrial policy has been vastly exaggerated. It had a few successes in sectors such as telecommunications, where the government was able to provide its national champion - in this case Alcatel - with a guaranteed market. Where these conditions did not apply, as in computers, the outcome was disastrous. The French steel industry is another example where government intervention in the Sixties and Seventies was at least as unhelpful - and as costly to the taxpayer - as in Britain.

It is now widely recognised that governments can do little to arrest the decline of old industries and that, where they do intervene, they usually make matters worse. In textiles, for example, it is now clear that the creation in the Sixties of large, vertically integrated groups - encouraged, though not directly promoted, by the government - was a serious error.

It could also be argued that, if the shipbuilding industry had not been propped up by the state between the Sixties and the Eighties, yards would have been under greater pressure to make themselves more efficient and to specialise in market sectors where they had a chance of competing with Japanese and Korean shipbuilders.

As for high-technology industries, an OECD economist, Henry Ergas, drew a distinction some years ago between what he called 'mission-oriented' countries, in which he included Britain and France, and 'diffusion-oriented' countries such as Germany and Switzerland. In the former, governments targeted a small number of high-technology enterprises, and supported them with subsidies and preferential procurement. In the latter, technology policy was much more decentralised; the aim was to provide a broadly based capacity for adjusting to technological change throughout the economy.

What has been happening in Britain over the past few years - both under the Tories and under the present government - is a shift in the direction of 'diffusion-oriented' policies. Support for national champions has been largely abandoned. The main objective is to create an environment in which companies of all sorts - British-owned and foreign, small, medium-sized and large - can flourish. This has involved, among other things, seeking to remove obstacles which inhibit entrepreneurial effort (for example, by the provision of venture capital), and increasing public expenditure on basic science.

An interesting example of these policies at work is biotechnology. This is still an emerging industry, and the share prices of the few quoted British biotechnology firms have been extremely volatile. But there is now a cluster of well capitalised companies, led by Celltech, and a host of smaller followers, many of them funded by British or foreign venture capitalists.

This broad spread of activity is a far more promising way forward than the creation, through government-induced mergers, of a national biotechnology champion. The same applies to information technology, where the success of firms such as ARM, Autonomy and Psion suggests at least a partial renaissance in an industry where British companies have done poorly in the past.

The one area where industrial policy in the old sense is still alive is aerospace. The Thatcher government privatised British Aerospace and Rolls-Royce but, somewhat surprisingly, maintained the long-established policy of supporting both companies with 'launch aid' - repayable grants to help finance the development of new airframe and engine projects.

Labour has continued (reluctantly) along the same track: apparently accepting manufacturers' argument that the riskiness and long payback period of these projects justify special treatment.

How long these arrangements will continue remains to be seen. If and when the Airbus consortium is turned into a normal, publicly quoted company, one might expect the need for launch aid for civil airliners to fall away. In any event, it is not easy for Ministers to explain why aerospace is a more deserving case than other industries.

In its 1998 White Paper on competitiveness, the Government stated categorically that it would not resort to the interventionist policies of the past.

'In the industrial policy-making of the Sixties and Seventies,' the White Paper said, 'to be modern meant believing in planning. Now, meeting the requirements of the knowledge-driven economy means making markets work better.'

The next few months will put this commitment to the test. Could there be a U-turn on industrial policy, just as there was in 1972, when rising unemployment forced Edward Heath's Conservative government to retreat from the free-market platform on which it had been elected?

The economy as a whole is much healthier than it was then, but that is not much comfort to hard-pressed manufacturers.

The hope must be that the lessons of the past have been learnt, and that the Government will facilitate the process of structural change - and assist those who suffer from it - instead of attempting to obstruct it.

 Geoffrey Owen, former editor of the Financial Times, is Senior Fellow at the London School of Economics' Institute of Management. His book, 'From Empire to Europe', is published by HarperCollins.

fields.headline: Best footage forward
fields.standfirst: A new Internet service will help freelance cameramen - and TV news editors, writes  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: A new Internet service will help freelance cameramen - and TV news editors, writes Jamie Doward
fields.body:
Suppose you're a freelance camera operator. You're in Freetown, Sierra Leone, and have just shot some dramatic footage of a firefight between rebel factions and government forces. You have risked your life to capture a film which shows the world how dire the situation in the African state has become. It is award-winning stuff.

The chances are you will send the footage to one of the big agencies, who'll then sell it on to other interested newsgathering organisations. But imagine what would happen if there were a dedicated Internet site allowing news editors around the world to view your work. It would create a transparent and instantly accessible market place. Editors hunting for pictures would be able to see immediately where they could pick the best material; freelances could expect to increase their earnings as their pictures were bought by more agencies; and viewers would benefit from the explosion of choice.

Tomorrow the idea of a global news portal for the broadcasting industry becomes a reality. TVnewsweb, a one-year-old company based in Hammersmith, London, launches a service which will allow editors to view footage over the Internet and download it to their bureau at the click of a mouse. The company, which is majority- owned by Tvbus.com, a private incubator fund, predicts that the move will revolutionise a broadcasting market estimated to be worth around £4.6 billion a year.

Not surprisingly the new company, which makes its money from commission, is spearheaded by a former cameraman, Pete Henderson, who worked with Michael Buerk in South Africa before setting up his own business providing news crews and equipment.

'Every time I was in Beirut or some lousy place I was thinking "God, I could be killed for this - just for a day's salary",' he says. 'But TVnewsweb has empowered the freelancer.'

Henderson, who is chairman of TVnewsweb, adds: 'A cameraman just back from Chechnya will go around the BBC, ITV and Sky and try to flog his material. He now has the opportunity to give us the video and we distribute it on a global basis to clients he would previously never have been able to reach.'

He invokes a comparison between TVnewsweb and International Management Group. 'Mark McCormack [IMG's founder] turned sportsmen into the stars that they are because they deserved it as a result of their talents and skills. It's always been a belief of mine that freelancers should enjoy the same opportunities, because they're the chaps who risked their lives, had the skill and intellectual ability to cover the stories and were never paid their due. This gives them an outlet to market their material on a global basis and earn a lot more money from it.'

But the company claims its portal will do more than earn fat fees for freelances. William Hood, the company's managing director, says: 'Currently if you're a small broadcaster, you can't afford to subscribe to Reuters or AP. And if you're a big broadcaster, you've got the logistical nightmare of trawling through 30 minutes of feeds several times a day trying to pluck out what you want.

'With this, you've got an interactive service where you go on to the site and view all the different products, rather than having to trawl through huge amounts of video.'

Such ambitious claims from a little-known company may sound suspect, but TVnewsweb has already signed up the BBC. In an exclusive two-year deal, TVnewsweb will distribute via its web-site all the BBC's news packages .

Henderson says: 'It's a magnificent coup. We have access to the entire BBC news-gathering system from 54 bureaux.

'The Beeb has a sales team and it constantly has people phoning it up saying, "We saw this on News 24. How do we get it?". And they've got no delivery mechanism. Now they've got a way to get it out to a potential client base who they previously couldn't get it out to,' Hood says.

In practice, a news editor will enter the site, look at the different categories (they include everything from sports to entertainment news), click into them and, having been given a password and user name, view the footage.

Special compression techniques mean the user can watch video at a healthy 64 kbits a second - fast enough to give a relatively good quality picture.

Each news agency is equipped with a decoder which receives broadcast- quality pictures via a satellite link. An option to buy a piece of footage triggers an email which TVnewsweb's system receives and then 'reads' to ensure the client is who they say they are.

The system will prevent specific agencies from buying footage if they have been 'banned' by other agencies. The system also understands the concept of the embargo.

Once the purchase is complete, the decoder is instructed to decode the footage ordered so that news agencies can use it instantly. Each video comes with a complete shot-list as well as a script - useful for radio stations looking for copy.

Although distribution will initially be via satellite, the company will switch to the Internet as broadband services are rolled out across the UK.

Other big name broadcasters are likely to sign up for TVnewsweb's service in the near future, Henderson says. CNN has expressed an interest, and more than 30 broadcasters in Asia are in the process of signing up to offer their content.

But why couldn't the big broadcasting names establish their own site and sell their footage direct?

The answer is that they could, but TVnewsweb argues that a site which attempts to bring all the buyers and sellers together is much more attractive to news editors.

Henderson says: 'The more content you have, and the more clients you have, the more viable the service is. This is not the core business of the broadcasters. They're tremendously excited because it gives them a reach and an opportunity that they previously wouldn't have considered.'

If news editors are able to view and order footage online, the entire newsgathering process becomes simplified or, as Henderson puts it, 'democratised'.

'If you are a news editor and somebody says "There's been a flood in Mozambique," you think: how am I going to get these pictures out? Your closest office is in Johannesburg, but they can't get in because they can't land their planes. You go into TVnewsweb and and see that another company has hired a boat, so you opt to take their footage. It's taken the mystery out of newsgathering.'

The site also has the potential for several lucrative spin- offs, providing it can start to attract sufficient numbers of users. Equipment and crew hire, and recruitment advertising, are two revenue sources which will grow with the site's popularity.

Sponsorship offers another income stream. Selling articles and stills photography is being considered and, perhaps inevitably given the media world's addiction to scoops, there are plans for an auction site, allowing freelances to sell footage to the highest bidder.

Expect a large migration of camera crews to a well known Scottish loch soon.

webTitle: Enigma who brought BP in from the cold

fields.headline: Enigma who brought BP in from the cold
fields.standfirst: Oliver Morgan  talks to Sir John Browne who turned the 'two-pipeline' firm into a worldbeater
fields.trailText: Oliver Morgan talks to Sir John Browne who turned the 'two-pipeline' firm into a worldbeater
fields.body:
He presses a button and, like the entrance to Blofeld's HQ in a James Bond movie, a pale wooden panel slides open, revealing a spacious, sunny, well-furnished office.

Sir John Browne, dapper in crisp white shirt and black trousers, militarily polished toe caps on his brogues, walks in and elects to take an armchair by the window. If there are sunlit uplands in British business, these are they.

Last Tuesday Browne announced a record first-quarter profits surge of 256 per cent, from £677 million to £2.7 billion. Last month he finalised one of the hardest-fought regulatory battles of recent memory, when the US Federal Trade Commission passed BP Amoco's takeover of US oil company Arco (Atlantic Richfield). This, combined with the Amoco deal the year before - then the biggest merger ever - has brought him the reputation of one of the world's best deal makers.

Browne is something of an enigma. He has an old-fashioned air of discretion. He collects pre-Columbian art, is a trustee of the British Museum, enjoys reading and theatre, and swims. Apart from that, his life appears to be BP.

Big deals are what this man has built his reputation on, and clearly they are what he likes talking about.

Five years ago he launched a strategy to change BP from a 'two-pipeline company', based in Alaska and the North Sea, with little presence in growth areas and few gas assets, into a world giant. The huge merger with US major Amoco was chapter one.

This deal, says Browne, came from an exhaustive courtship of global oil giants by BP. Last year's takeover of Atlantic Richfield was different. 'It was highly unusual,' he says. 'The CEO rang me and said we have concluded that we want to merge with BP Amoco.'

Arco was driven to BP Amoco because world oil prices had slumped to as low as $10 a barrel last year and, given that its assets were mainly in Alaska, its production costs were high. Its margins were being squeezed so hard it needed a partner to survive.

Timing for that deal was everything, says Browne.

'Shortly afterwards, the price of oil started going up. My conclusion is that had we not done the deal at that time we could not have done it.'

But the Arco deal landed Browne in a year's worth of wrangling with US competition authority the Federal Trade Commission. It was concerned about BP's dominance in Alaska - where it would add Arco assets to its own - and about its position in Californian petrol stations.

Eventually the FTC forced BP Amoco to sell oil and gas assets in the massive Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska to US companies Exxon and Phillips Petroleum. But BP remains an operator in that field.

Browne believes the regulatory environment in the US has changed dramatically recently, and that the situation could not have been resolved outside the US courts.

'The background when we were going through merger approval was changing. We were in an election year; the price of gasoline was very high; and the standing of oil companies generally was probably going down. We then had to spend a lot of time discussing with the FTC what to do, and really we could not have a discussion with them,. So we said go to court, and we could then begin a discussion after that.'

Browne adds that the Arco deal may have been the last of its kind. 'For mergers of scale in the oil industry in the US, the door looks shut.'

Many city analysts were sceptical about the deal Browne emerged with. Combining BP and Arco's Alaskan assets delivered the economies of scale which was the logic of the deal. When he was forced to sell, that logic changed.

Browne points out that a second deal allowed BP Amoco to become the sole operator of Prudhoe Bay, so increasing efficiencies - and that it received a lot for the Arco assets because the oil price was three times higher by that stage than at the beginning of the deal talks.

He says that, strategically, it has delivered what he wanted: more gas and downstream assets in the South-West US sunbelt.

Last week Browne said that now was to be a period of consolidation: no deals were likely in the immediate future. So how does he see the business evolving?

'One key thing is that the rebalancing of assets towards gas, where demand is growing, and away from oil, where it is falling, will continue.' Last week BP said that by the end of next year it would have increased gas output by 50 per cent from last year's levels. 'The world market share in oil and gas must be about the same,' he says.

Then, he says, BP's portfolio of some 29,200 filling stations will be trimmed - although he wants to increase sites in growth areas.

He also wants the performance of the chemicals business to improve, increasing the rates of return on petrochemical plants by making them more efficient. He points to BP Amoco's Grangemouth site as an example.

Much of BP's future rests on this strategy. But not all. Browne believes that Government policy plays an important role in business. He reserves judgment on whether the reported cooling of business's attitude to New Labour lead to a problem: 'These things tend to have an impact after some five years or so, so we'll have to wait to find out.'

But on the issue of measures in the Budget to tighten tax on multinational companies that send profits from low-tax countries to UK headquarters, he is adamant. 'This is very bad for business. It came totally out of the blue. And it should be scrapped,' he says with uncharacteristic bluntness.

But although some companies might pack their bags, Browne says: 'We are not going to leave the UK over this.'

A good thing, too. He'd have to leave behind that Blofeld office behind the sliding door.

But the Arco deal landed Browne in a year's worth of wrangling with US competition authority the Federal Trade Commission. It was concerned about BP's dominance in Alaska - where it would add Arco assets to its own - and about its position in Californian petrol stations. Eventually the FTC forced BP Amoco to sell oil and gas assets in the massive Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska to US companies Exxon and Phillips Petroleum. But BP remains an operator in that field. Browne believes the regulatory environment in the US has changed dramatically recently, and that the situation could not have been resolved outside the US courts. 'The background when we were going through merger approval was changing. We were in an election year; the price of gasoline was very high; and the standing of oil companies generally was probably going down. We then had to spend a lot of time discussing with the FTC what to do, and really we could not have a discussion with them,. So we said go to court, and we could then begin a discussion after that.' Browne adds that the Arco deal may have been the last of its kind. 'For mergers of scale in the oil industry in the US, the door looks shut.' Many city analysts were sceptical about the deal Browne emerged with. Combining BP and Arco's Alaskan assets delivered the economies of scale which was the logic of the deal. When he was forced to sell, that logic changed. Browne points out that a second deal allowed BP Amoco to become the sole operator of Prudhoe Bay, so increasing efficiencies - and that it received a lot for the Arco assets because the oil price was three times higher by that stage than at the beginning of the deal talks. He says that, strategically, it has delivered what he wanted: more gas and downstream assets in the South-West US sunbelt. Last week Browne said that now was to be a period of consolidation: no deals were likely in the immediate future. So how does he see the business evolving? 'One key thing is that the rebalancing of assets towards gas, where demand is growing, and away from oil, where it is falling, will continue.' Last week BP said that by the end of next year it would have increased gas output by 50 per cent from last year's levels. 'The world market share in oil and gas must be about the same,' he says. Then, he says, BP's portfolio of some 29,200 filling stations will be trimmed - although he wants to increase sites in growth areas. He also wants the performance of the chemicals business to improve, increasing the rates of return on petrochemical plants by making them more efficient. He points to BP Amoco's Grangemouth site as an example. Much of BP's future rests on this strategy. But not all. Browne believes that Government policy plays an important role in business. He reserves judgment on whether the reported cooling of business's attitude to New Labour lead to a problem: 'These things tend to have an impact after some five years or so, so we'll have to wait to find out.' But on the issue of measures in the Budget to tighten tax on multinational companies that send profits from low-tax countries to UK headquarters, he is adamant. 'This is very bad for business. It came totally out of the blue. And it should be scrapped,' he says with uncharacteristic bluntness. But although some companies might pack their bags, Browne says: 'We are not going to leave the UK over this.' A good thing, too. He'd have to leave behind that Blofeld office behind the sliding door.

fields.headline: Wickes launches £74m fightback
fields.trailText: Wickes, the do-it-yourself retailer, has stepped up its fight against a £285 million bid from rival Focus Do It All by promising to return £74 million to shareholders if they vote to keep it independent.
fields.body:
Wickes, the do-it-yourself retailer, has stepped up its fight against a £285 million bid from rival Focus Do It All by promising to return £74 million to shareholders if they vote to keep it independent.

Its final defence document, sent to shareholders yesterday, forecasts that profits before interest and tax will jump 33 per cent, to £28.5m, in the year to December. That is after deducting the £6.4m for it is spending on its renewal programme of upgrading its stores.

The £74m, which equates to 100p a share, will be returned through a tender offer after the bid lapses. That will shrink Wickes' share capital by 25 per cent, which is what cement-maker Blue Circle proposed when it fought off an unwelcome bid from French rival Lafarge.

Bill Grimsey, Wickes' chief executive, admits he was encouraged by Blue Circle's escape because it suggested that investors were no longer prepared to accept low offers for 'old-economy' companies. 'I have said before that this bid is ludicrously low. This [defence document] demon strates just how low it is.'

He denied, however, that the buy-back was a bribe, saying the group had been thinking of it anyway. 'We have a healthy balance sheet,' he added. At the end of 1999 the group had £14m in the bank. It is, however, committed to a £150m programme of openings and refurbishments.

The document spells out Wickes' scope for expanding the business, through openings and via alternative sales methods. Its website will be launched in two July, although it will take two years to become fully operational.

The defence paper tries to answer the questions raised by Focus Do It All last week. It argues that a B&Q Warehouse close by does not significantly damage its stores, and sets out the way its renewal programme is producing significant increases in sales.

Analysts do not expect the bid to succeed at this level. Focus is expected to increase its offer from the current 375p before next Sunday's deadline. Most analysts say it will have to pay at least 500p to win, and some put the figure as high as 600p.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Editor to sue TheStreet.co.uk | Boots sinks its teeth in
fields.body:
Standard Life fights back
Standard Life will this week mount Britain's biggest ever campaign against demutualisation with a circular spelling out exactly how much members stand to lose if it becomes a public company. It will warn that flotation may not be as much of a bonanza as carpetbaggers think, pointing to the lacklustre performance of the shares of many former mutuals, such as building societies.

The 20-page circular, being sent to 2.3 million policyholders, sets out Standard Life's case for remaining a mutual insurance company, owned by its members. It will show that its policyholders are around 10 per cent better off than those with companies owned by their shareholders.

Editor to sue TheStreet.co.uk
The former editor-in-chief of online financial newspaper TheStreet.co.uk is to sue the company for unfair dismissal. Martin Baker has decided to launch legal proceedings against his former employer after being sacked last month accused of failing to 'fulfil his editorial remit'.

His dismissal came only three months after the launch of the online paper, owned by ailing US parent company TheStreet, whose backers include the New York Times and Japanese investment firm Softbank.

The news will come as a further blow to TheStreet.co.uk, which has been rocked by the collapse in its parent company's share price and speculation about its long-term future.

Boots sinks its teeth in
Millions of shoppers will soon be able to walk into Boots the Chemist to have their teeth examined. Britain's largest pharmacy chain will this week open the first of 44 new dental practices.

The company is investing £20 million in its latest attempt to establish itself in the lucrative health and beauty services market. The company is taking on more than 150 dentists, 80 hygienists and 230 nurses. Its six trial dental practices have 13,000 registered patients who pay £29.50 for an initial examination including X-rays.

fields.headline: Can Bishop open skies?
fields.standfirst: British Midland boss hopes finally to fly the Atlantic  from Fortress Heathrow.   Joanna Walters  reports
fields.trailText: British Midland boss hopes finally to fly the Atlantic from Fortress Heathrow. Joanna Walters reports
fields.body:
Sir Michael Bishop is not a Branson or a Laker. When, as he hopes, his airline British Midland launches transatlantic flights from Heathrow you will not find him throwing Ivana Trump over his shoulder or hurling himself into swimming pools à la Branson. Nor will he be caught with arms outstretched, asking 'are you ready for Freddie?' à la Freddie Laker, the first US fares-buster with his Seventies Skytrain.

Bishop's will be a quiet revolution, but a revolution nonetheless, as the most genteel of Britain's airline entrepreneurs prepares to break new ground. After almost 10 years of deadlock, all the signs are that the UK and US will sign a historic deal in July to lower the drawbridge at Fortress Heathrow and let new airlines ply the Atlantic.

It could be a big-bang, open skies agreement allowing any carrier the right to fly any combination of cities between the UK and US. What is more probable is that it will be a more modest 'mini-deal' that will committed to total open skies in the future but for the time being, allowing limited extra competition into the market.

The two countries were on the brink of signing a deal just after Christmas, but BA lobbied Tony Blair to block it. This incensed the Americans. They threatened to ban Concorde and spark a trade war.

Bishop told The Observer last week: 'The UK and US are just as close as you can be as trading partners. A dispute like this causes a disproportionate amount of acrimony and it is inconsistent. Each has open skies in their own country and with other trading partners but they cannot do a deal with each other. That holds back the market for everyone.'

If a mini-deal is struck this summer after years of fruitless talks, a handful of airlines will be nominated to launch new routes between specified US cities and Heathrow. In such a case, British Midland would be the new UK player, choosing to fly initially to New York, Washington DC, Boston and Miami. As Britain's second largest scheduled airline it has a growing domestic and European network but has never flown long-haul.

Continental Airlines and Delta are considered the most likely of the US carriers currently confined to Gatwick, to be allowed to move their London flights to Heathrow, serving Houston, Newark and Atlanta.

Both business and tourist passengers will be in the money as a result. At present it costs at least £3,000 return to fly business class from Heathrow to New York and the East coast of the US and upwards of £5,000 to go west to the likes of Los Angeles. But business flights to New York from Frankfurt, Brus sels, Paris, Zurich, Milan, Madrid or Amsterdam range from £1,288 to £2,418 return. There are similar disparities for other major US cities.

Off-season leisure fare giveaways have always produced the winter bargains of £199 and less. But they are always limited in number and dry up when the sun comes out.

Branson's Virgin Atlantic has had a huge impact since it launched from Gatwick in 1984 and battled its way into Heathrow in 1991, especially on the UK-US market, which the Official Airline Guide estimates is the largest in the world at 10.5 million passengers a year. But with only BA and Virgin, and two US airlines, American and United, allowed substantial transatlantic operations from Heathrow, new rivals are desperate to get in.

Bishop is coy about the business and leisure fares he will charge when he actually begins flights next summer but he is bound to cause a stir. 'I think people have been surprised to realise how much extra they are paying to fly from Heathrow,' he said.

But will this be good news for the nation if opening up Heathrow damages flag-carrier BA and Branson's Virgin, which has worked so hard for its slice of the cake?

The UK Government has always protected BA's inherited dominance at Heathrow. Its transatlantic profits prop up the rest of the company. But the airline is about to announce the first annual loss since privatisation, and it could be upwards of a whopping £250m. Surely the Government will not abandon its favourite in its darkest hour, with barbarians at the gate?

Margaret Thatcher let Virgin, American and United into Heathrow in 1991. The then BA chairman Lord King angrily accused the Government of giving away the airline's 'crown jewels', and cut his company's donations to the Conservative Party. BA is a formidable company, however, and learnt to live with the extra competition.

The signs are that Labour will now expect it to do the same again. One industry observer said: 'BA is no longer the only national champion and cannot expect all the attention. Virgin, Midland and the low-cost airlines are growing like mad.'

These aggressive, innovative rivals have contributed to BA's financial travails, exacerbating its problems with high costs, overcapacity and the Asian crisis. Tim Jeans, sales and marketing director of top low-cost airline Ryanair, said: 'No other major carrier in Europe faces the degree of competition in its home market that BA does.

'I think the UK Government no longer sees BA as the only national interest, sending armies of civil servants rushing around the world negotiating on its behalf. These days if BA does not fly on a particular route someone else will.'

BA's new chief executive Rod Eddington does not have a hotline to Tony Blair as did his predecessor, Bob Ayling, a close associate of the Prime Minister. Eddington knows the chill wind of commercial reality is going to whip through more and more of BA's cosy corners over the next few years. He could even use the terrifying prospect of unbridled competition at Heathrow to help force restructuring at the airline, the way George Simpson did at Rover when the Japanese carmakers began manufacturing in the UK more than 10 years ago.

But how will an airline such as British Midland, which has 6,000 staff compared with BA's 60,000, prosper on the cut-throat Atlantic? It will trade on its own strong reputation in Europe and its membership of the Star Alliance. Star is the most effective global airline group so far, led by Midland stake-holders Lufthansa and SAS, United of the US, Singapore Airlines and Air Canada.

Midland will fly the Atlantic with its own aircraft, crew and brand, although it will rename itself once it gets its Atlantic rights, in order to drop the provincial connotations of its identity. But it will rely on United's ubiquitous presence in the US to promote and sell its services as part of a network operation.

Lufthansa, SAS and Midland increasingly think together when planning strategy in Europe. Midland launched flights to Madrid, Rome and Milan earlier this month and is planning other new European services aimed jointly at making money and plugging gaps where the Star network is weak, particularly in southern Europe.

Bishop and senior executives from SAS and Lufthansa shared a platform at a British ambassadorial reception in Madrid last week to celebrate the new flights and their growing partnership.

Midland is already the largest Star player at Heathrow. Transatlantic flights will give it extra clout itself but also help Star mount a formidable challenge in the business travel market to BA and its less-organised Oneworld alliance with American Airlines, Cathay Pacific and others.

Bishop said: 'Two years ago we had to make a very big decision - should we throw all the service off the aircraft and become a low-cost, budget airline at Heathrow? Or should we go into a major alliance?' He decided it would be difficult to have a sufficiently low costbase at a premium airport such as Heathrow. And he would not leave Heathrow because 'if you are playing Monopoly and sitting on Park Lane, you do not give it up for Marylebone Station.'

That decision will shape the future of British Midland and, he hopes, have a major impact on the transatlantic and, one day, the global market.

'I think Star and Oneworld is a Pepsi and Coca-Cola situation,' Bishop said. If two or three airline groupings are to dominate the planet, he wants to be part of one of them.

fields.headline: BMW: 'Where's our tenner?'
fields.trailText: In all the excitement of acquiring Rover, the Phoenix consortium forgot to hand over the tenner it had agreed to pay for the carmaker when it settled terms with BMW on Tuesday
fields.body:
In all the excitement of acquiring Rover, the Phoenix consortium forgot to hand over the tenner it had agreed to pay for the carmaker when it settled terms with BMW on Tuesday, writes Oliver Morgan

It had to be reminded by email on Friday afternoon to pay up. Nick Stephenson at Phoenix received an email from Munich saying it could not trace the payment. He arranged for a cheque to be sent immediately, but by the time it was dispatched the pound had slumped, and Phoenix lost 36p on the purchase price of £10. A reminder of the problems currency fluctuation can bring.

fields.headline: Mirror shares probe widens
fields.standfirst: More about the Mirror share deal scandal
fields.trailText: The inquiry into the share dealings of Mirror editor Piers Morgan by the Department of Trade and Industry is to be widened, The Observer can reveal. It will now cover the newspaper's internal investigation of the affair.
fields.body:
The inquiry into the share dealings of Mirror editor Piers Morgan by the Department of Trade and Industry is to be widened, The Observer can reveal. It will now cover the newspaper's internal investigation of the affair.

The Observer has also established that, in a highly unusual move, the tabloid's owner, Trinity Mirror, asked to see a confidential letter to the Stock Exchange from Viglen Technology, a key firm among those whose shares Morgan bought. The news will provoke new criticism of the media group's handling of the scandal.

The request was made by Paul Vickers, Trinity Mirror's group legal director, and was granted by Viglen's public relations man, Nick Hewer. They met only days before the Mirror completed its internal inquiry, on 18 February. This means it knew Viglen's confidential account of the affair beforehand.

One Stock Exchange source said: 'It is certainly unusual, and not best practice, for a company to show a regulator's letter to a company which is the subject of that letter.'

Hewer could not be contacted. Vickers declined to talk to The Observer directly, but through a spokesman he confirmed that he thought the request proper 'because I believed it would be helpful to our investigation, and it was'.

Last week, the Press Complaints Commission censured Morgan and the two journalists at the centre of the scandal, former Mirror City Slick ers columnists Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell.

Trinity Mirror had already exonerated Morgan, but sacked Bhoyrul and Hipwell.

Morgan bought shares in Viglen in January - on the same day the Slickers tipped the shares. He denies he knew of the Viglen tip at the time; the sacked pair say he did.

A DTI source said: 'With so many versions flying around, it doesn't look as if Trinity Mirror have got their story straight. That is something our inspectors will be looking at in due course.'
