webTitle: The literary lion cubs that failed to roar

fields.headline: The literary lion cubs that failed to roar
fields.trailText: They were the unknowns that publishers put big money on, often bidding against each other for the privilege. If the authors were in their twenties, or even their teens, so much the better. They could be packaged as fresh, contemporary voices, and a writer could buy an inner-city loft with the down-payment on the as yet unwritten book.
fields.body:
They were the unknowns that publishers put big money on, often bidding against each other for the privilege. If the authors were in their twenties, or even their teens, so much the better. They could be packaged as fresh, contemporary voices, and a writer could buy an inner-city loft with the down-payment on the as yet unwritten book.

These writers should have become the new stars of British literature. But where are they now?

In a bonanza of Hollywood-style spending over the past five years, publishing houses have handed out advances of between £50,000 and £300,000 to a fleet of untried writers. Now sales figures show that many will not even qualify as one-hit-wonders.

In 1998 Bo Fowler, author of Scepticism Inc and a graduate of Malcolm Bradbury's creative writing course at the University of East Anglia, was given £140,000 by Jonathan Cape for two books. Richard Mason, then a 19-year-old student, got £200,000 from Michael Joseph for The Drowning People, and journalist John Lanchester was handed around £300,000 in a two-book deal.

Last month mature student Justin Hill accepted £150,000 from Weidenfeld and Nicolson for his incomplete Chinese saga The Drink and Dream Teahouse , and only last week Anselm Audley, a Millfield School A-level student,was offered £50,000 by Simon and Schuster for a work of fantasy fiction called Heresy along with two books to follow.

There is little chance of any of these books making a profit for their publisher. 'It is the triumph of expectation over reality,' said Patrick Janson-Smith, deputy managing director of Transworld, 'and reality only comes into view a year down the line.'

The manuscript-buying frenzy is still going strong, but now the commercial performance of these books can be measured it is clear that few make more than the advance sum - especially when the publicity budget is added to the equation.

According to Whitaker Booktrack , Lanchester's much-hyped novel Mr Phillips , which came out in January and, together with another book, won him an advance of around £300,000 from Faber & Faber on the strength of his previous work, The Debt to Pleasure , has so far sold only 2,786 copies in hardback.

A comic story by opera director John Ramster - Ladies Man - about a gay man who falls for a woman, has sold only 2,727 for Little, Brown who paid more than £100,000 for it last summer.

Mason's thriller The Drowning People was published a year ago and had sold only 3,462 for Michael Joseph by the end of the year.

The 'bonkbuster' - romantic women's fiction - seems to be the only bankable genre. First-time writer Anna Maxted's Getting Over It earned her a six-figure advance payment and has sold a respectable 17,313 copies since publication in April.

Commissioning editors, for some time quietly amazed by the sums bid at auction on unknown writers, are now also worried about the tendency to pay money out on the basis of just a few pages of work. The book business, they believe, is increasingly behaving like the film industry, paying big money for a story idea, or 'pitch', rather than on a full first draft of a novel.

'Books are being sold on just three or four pages,' said Janson-Smith, 'and that seems to be the new thing. It is like a cinematic treatment and makes it very easy for everyone involved. The publisher feels like they have read a book and the writer feels like they have written one. It is perhaps too easy.'

But Amy Jenkins, screenwriter of the cult BBC2 series This Life , sees no reason why the book business should not emulate the film and movie-making process. 'It seems to have worked for me,' she told The Observer last week. Her first novel, Honeymoon , was snapped up by Hodder on the strength of one chapter and, despite critical reviews, is selling well. The first 50,000 print run has sold out. 'It will always be the laws of the market,' Jenkins said . 'Novelists who are offering the kind of work a publisher needs will be able to pick and choose and demand a big advance. Publishing houses have to take a punt early on.'

The emphasis is now on finding and making literary names just as much as it is on finding books that are good commercial bets. If the writer's first book does not make money for the pub lisher, then the second or third may - assuming, of course, that the writer remains loyal to his first publisher. 'Authors do not necessarily feel bound to their first publisher,' points out Janson-Smith. 'In fact they are likely to want just as much if not more for their next book or they will go elsewhere.'

Salvation may lie in the cheaper mass-market editions. These need to be taken into account and are making money for books which had a lukewarm impact at launch. The Drowning People has, for example, sold a more impressive 27,277 copies at £5.99 in paperback,while Ramster's Ladies Man has quickly sold 5,261 copies at the same reduced price.

fields.headline: A car called Günter
fields.standfirst: He's thirsty, stalls a lot and smells of petrol, but Tamsin Blanchard couldn't say no to a BMW 2002
fields.trailText: He's thirsty, stalls a lot and smells of petrol, but Tamsin Blanchard couldn't say no to a BMW 2002
fields.body:
It's not funny, or clever, or kind. But just when it's most unfashionable, I have to confess, I love my BMW. I try not to park near anything bearing a Rover badge, and am happy to let Rovers of all shapes and sizes overtake me. I don't want to get into any trouble. But you see, my BMW is from another era, when the automotive industry was altogether more civilised and friendly - a time when it was not referred to as a 'beamer' but simply by its number, 02 (short for 2002). It is an L-reg from last time around and is three years older than I am, giving it the status of a vintage car - although, typically, it misses tax exemption by one measly year.

I had seen these funny little cars occasionally parked on a street in Soho, or passing on a dual carriageway. They were quite dinky in size, with the sort of headlights and round, rear brake lights you might imagine Noddy's car to have. And they were always in the most off-beat of 70s colours - yellowy orange, leafy green or, sometimes, metallic blue. And every time I saw one, I knew I had to have one. So when an acquaintance announced she was selling hers, I put the battered, reliable old Citroën AX up for sale in the pages of Loot, and before I had even checked to see if it had an engine, agreed to part with £2,000 for a shiny, cream-coloured 2002.

We went on a test drive, and despite the fact the car stalled at every set of traffic lights and consumed £20 of 4-star at the petrol station (just a top up), I was dazzled. The car was in great condition, just 58,000 miles on the clock. It's an automatic, which means that it's great fun, and feels a bit like you're driving a New York cab. Despite its appearance, it has a 2-litre engine which has a really lovely hum to it, and is 'well-pokey'. The car was all original inside, complete with the basic radio which has the advantage that no one will ever want to nick it. It only picks up medium wave and long wave, narrowing the choice of stations to Sunrise for a bit of Bollywood musical, and the ones that only play the sounds of the 70s, which, of course, suits the car perfectly. It even had its original tax disc in the glove compartment, and just needed some work on the carburettor - a bit of tweaking and tuning. The agreement was that I would pick it up from the garage. The bill came to close on £500 for the reconditioned carb; I began to realise why the car was for sale.

When you fall in love with a car, all rational thought goes out through the quarterlight window. Forty pounds for a full tank of petrol was a small price to pay - even if the car could barely make it from one service station to the next on a trip up the motorway. On our first run from London to Liverpool, we refuelled three times, partly because the fuel gauge doesn't work. That was around £100 for a 200-mile journey. But what did 50p per mile matter when, on every petrol forecourt, Günter (yes, that's his name) attracted admiring glances from the cars around him, and comments of approval from the attendants? And although it didn't quite seem to make sense taking the bottles and newspapers to the recycling plant in a car that consumed lead-heavy, polluting gas, fellow recyclers would nod with approval and stop to have a chat. 'I used to have one of those,' the man in the People Carrier would say. 'It was a great little car - it can really go. Bought it new in 1974.'

It's a funny thing, but everyone seems to have owned an 02 at some point in their life. The owner of the garage where I originally picked Günter up from had one. And the owner of the garage he now frequents for his services and his MOT, as well as the time he had to be towed from the Red Route in Islington before the police got there first, informs me that he had one, too. It gives you a feeling of reassurance.

Günter's not like a modern car, and needs a little extra care and attention. Surprisingly, he recently passed his MOT. He just needed a bit of welding and his headlamps had to be adjusted. 'They have the worst headlamps in the world,' the owner tells me, making up my bill. (Just £150 this time.) 'I remember once going to Wales in mine. Driving round those dark lanes, I'd have been better off with a torch out of the window. In the end, d'you know what I did? I got a pair of headlamps from an old Mini, which aren't much better, but they fit. I jammed and glued them in. A great improvement.'

They might not shine too brightly, but the headlamps and the round, Sputnik-like tail lights are part of the car's charm. Some 2002s have square tail-lights. But there is something friendly and inviting about the round ones. Certainly, Günter looked very handsome when we waxed his bonnet and buffed up his chrome to show him off at the BMW 02 register 10th anniversary at Brooklands last summer. This is part of the joy of owning a vintage car. Not only can you wave at other 02s you pass on the road, and get cheap insurance, but you also get to join a club, and your car's registration number is printed in the Welcome column of the register newsletter. I'd been to the odd car rally before, but never actually participated in one.

Unfortunately, by the time we got to the legendary racetrack, we'd missed the chance to drive over the Test Hill. So we just drove around to the steep, curving concrete bank and parked up alongside the other 2002s. The car next to us had its bonnet open, displaying a pristine, steam-cleaned engine. We had only just managed to scrape the mush of dead leaves out from the ledge under the windscreen, and hadn't realised we were supposed to clean the engine as well.

A lot of the cars are owned by real petrolheads. There were cars there that boasted whole rear windows filled with awards. Some were feats of restoration. Others had had their suspension jacked up and really fat wheels added, as though they were in competition to be the new Herbie. The steam-cleaned man next to us sidled over for a chat, and offered us some advice: that we should convert our automatic choke to manual. We nodded knowingly, admired his engine, and continued to unpack our picnic from the boot. (Incidentally, one of the 02's little foibles is that anything you store in the boot comes out smelling of petrol.)

There's something very British about sitting on a stretch of historic Tarmac, eating sandwiches alongside a gathering of a hundred or so other matching cars. After we had wandered around, agreed that we definitely preferred the round rear-lights to the square ones, admired some very cool CSIs that had gathered on a different part of the track, and jumbled through a box of oily bits and pieces on sale at a stall, it was time to go home. Next time, we thought, we'll steam-clean his engine. This year's Brooklands meet is set for 6 August, but, of course, the big one will be in 2002, the year when the market price for the 02 will no doubt double. Even then, it still won't repay the amount I've spent on him. And anyway, Günter is not for sale.

fields.headline: Accidental tourists
fields.standfirst: John has a nasty head wound and Betty's wrist is swollen... but it's only syrup, dough and cochineal. Melanie McFadyean joins the walking wounded of the Casualties Union
fields.trailText: John has a nasty head wound and Betty's wrist is swollen... but it's only syrup, dough and cochineal. Melanie McFadyean joins the walking wounded of the Casualties Union
fields.body:
Marian Kerr, a pretty, middle-aged woman in pink, stirs a tub of blood at the scene of a mock car accident. 'We at the Casualties Union are a happy bunch - we have to laugh, as actually it's very morbid,' she quips. You can say that again. A day out with them is not for ninnies.

The Casualties Union (CU) dates back to the Second World War, when civil defence officials realised it was more effective to use real bodies instead of shop-window dummies during training exercises for the emergency services. 'They moan and groan and you know it's hurting them, so the rescue services can learn from that,' says Marian, deputy regional director of the London CU. Members pose as victims for fire brigade, ambulance and other rescue services, providing practice for catastrophes - train crashes, plane crashes, car accidents, bombings

On the day of this mock pile-up, the CU volunteers started out at a north London fire station. Most were lively sixtysomethings, but there were one or two younger ones. A burly fireman served tea as the 'casualties' rolled up sleeves or rolled down tights to get to the flesh on which they proceeded to make sickeningly realistic simulated wounds. Despite the bloodiness, the atmosphere was polite, restrained, very British, a touch of Ealing comedy.

The six women and two men had their own kit: dough for swellings and wounds, food colouring, blood made of cochineal and golden syrup. There was a hideous leg wound growing in one corner, as its ladylike creator, Jean Irving, slashed at her tights with nail scissors; a wrist swelled grotesquely as Betty Powell applied layers of dough, nylon and colouring to it, before creating a nasty abrasion on her collarbone.

'I've been cut out of more cars than I've had hot dinners,' said Brian Waddingham, 34, as he set about destroying his face. 'You should see him when he does a stomach wound,' said Marian.

Most are St John Ambulance or Red Cross volunteers. They are from all walks of life - secretaries, publishing merchandisers, school technicians, nurses. The creation of wounds is a serious, absorbing business, but this isn't bloodlust territory in the vein of David Cronenberg's Crash, the film which tried to make accidents sexy. None showed any sign of warped obsessions with open wounds or broken bones; they talked about what they do matter of factly so that it all seems as wholesome as a village fête.

It's a way of being useful, of adding to their first aiders' knowledge and, for some, of making friends. But is it a thrill? It's a question that doesn't get much response until someone looms up from blacking an eye and says, 'Ooh yes!' An hour or so after arrival at the fire station, their gruesome injuries complete, they tucked into sandwiches before gathering their blood and dough and boarding a minibus. 'We look like the Addams Family,' one of them said waggishly.

The accident had been set up at a knacker's yard piled high with cars under the M1. The stars of the show dropped into their roles instantly as they got off the bus. Brian looked the goriest: his face was lacerated and shards of glass poked out of swellings on his forehead. He wriggled through the shattered windscreen of a crushed car and sprawled lifelessly across the bonnet. 'Not enough blood - did you bring your own?' Marian said to Brian. 'I've got to get you blooded up.' She poked vigorously at his head wound with a Q-tip and some blood, before taking her position, crumpled and unconscious in an upturned van.

Five fire engines arrived and the firefighters produced wrenches, saws and special boards to lever the wounded out of the wrecks. Doreen Jones, her eyes blacked and a lot of blood on her specs, wandered around playing a loony concussion case. Peggy Cavallo, who had a serious head injury, really cried, and Jean yelped when they began to work her away from the steering wheel over which she was slumped, but there wasn't much moaning and groaning. A firefighter explained: 'We go to the quiet ones first - the more injured you are, the less noise you make' (handy hint, that). Sometimes CU volunteers are taken to hospital to give casualty departments a chance to practise their procedures, and some even end up in the morgue before being reminded they are alive and sent off for a nice cup of tea.

The acting was classy - RSC meets The Bill with a touch of Method thrown in. As one of the fireman said: 'They're a bloody marvel. The help they give us - and you - is inestimable.'

 Dopplarity, Oliver Chanarin and Adam Broomberg's photographs of the Casualties Union, will be exhibited on billboards at Bank Underground station, London, from 16 August to 16 September. In conjunction with the billboards, limited-edition prints will be exhibited at Hiscox Gallery, 1 Great St Helen's, London EC3 (020 7448 6000)

fields.headline: Clean start
fields.standfirst: Lost your fizz? Now winter's finally over, it's time to give your body a boost  with a detox regime that pampers rather than punishes
fields.trailText: Jane Clarke: Lost your fizz? Now winter's finally over, it's time to give your body a boost with a detox regime that pampers rather than punishes
fields.body:
Although the sun has been shining at last, the downside of spring is that the shops are sending me a clear message that I've shrouded myself in my winter woollies for long enough and that it's time to liberate my body. The problem is I'm feeling wintered out and depressed by weeks of rain and grey skies - I've even been comfort-eating further into April than usual. My body's in need of a spring clean. Like many people's routine, however, mine is such that I can't face undergoing a detox programme that will leave me feeling weak and wan, nor do I see the point of depriving myself. I need a pampering regime, not a bullying one. So I've decided to prioritise my body over the next week and boost its nutrient reserves, replenish its batteries and, with luck, rekindle both my outer and inner glow.

Many of my patients find my 'boosting' programme achievable because, with a little resolve, they can eat foods that they enjoy. The resulting invigorating feelings of detoxification and lightness, as well as renewed energy and ability to concentrate, make the exercise worthwhile. I wouldn't recommend embarking on this programme if you have a heavy work schedule, however. And although 10 days is the target length for my body-cleansing programme, if you don't have the necessary window in your diary, give yourself as many days as you can. If you regularly take medication or have a health problem, consult your doctor before starting. If weight loss will cause you problems, consider restricting yourself to a weekend fruit-and-vegetable regime instead. I recommend that anyone starting the programme does so at the weekend.

Some people often abandon a cleansing programme because they haven't prepared themselves. So make sure that you have a 10-day supply of beneficial food, otherwise your craving for munchies will get the better of you and the dial-a-pizza urge will win. Consider buying or resurrecting a blender, juicer or food processor, all of which make creating juices, soups and smoothies child's play. Make sure you have plenty of fresh herbs, lemons, limes and good-quality olive oil with which to make dressings and dishes more appetising.

When cooking, think ahead and make extra portions to enjoy over several days. Grilled or roasted vegetables, for instance, are delicious served cold with some lean charcuterie, chicken, lentils or beans at lunchtime, or when a busy evening dictates a dish that is quick to make. Eating regularly can help you to avoid feeling dizzy and lethargic, and you can eat as many fruits and vegetables as you like.

Over the first weekend of your detox, eat only fruit and vegetables (except potatoes, which are too starchy at this stage). Indulge your body with juices, stirfries, salads, grilled vegetables, fruit salads, poached fruits, comptes, stuffed peppers, tomatoes or sautéed wild mushrooms. Avoiding concentrated carbohydrates (pasta, bread, rice and potatoes) and protein-rich foods (meat, fish, chicken and cheese) will really cleanse your body, as will banishing fatty and sweet foods. As well as making sure that your food is fresh and simple, keep cooking times to a minimum. Because your digestive system doesn't like excess fats (which cause bloating and indigestion) and neither does your circulatory system, use only a little olive oil to make dressings.

Your body may feel strange at the start of the programme. This is not only due to changing your diet and routine but also because the best detox should involve weaning yourself off caffeine, alcohol and any other addictive substances. Hydrate your body with plenty of water (aim to drink at least two litres a day). Although alcohol can be perfectly healthy in moderation, you will feel a lot more energetic and more balanced after spending a week or so off the booze. The physiological benefits of abstinence include giving your liver a rest and helping you to banish baggy, sore and tired-looking eyes and skin.

After your weekend of detoxing, it's time to move on to phase two: introducing two daily helpings of protein into your diet. Stick to sources of lean protein, such as fish, chicken, lean red meat, eggs, seafood, turkey, tofu and pulses. Vegetarians may feel better if they avoid nuts, which contain rather too much fat to cleanse the body properly. Aim to eat the equivalent of a large-sized chicken breast for lunch and supper, which equates to two to three eggs, a medium-sized fillet steak, a large cup of pulses, a dozen langoustines or half a dozen oysters. Maintaining your protein intake will not only provide your body with essential amino acids to feed your muscles, but will also keep your mood sunny, because the amino acids tryptophan and l-phenylalanine produce serotonin and noradrenaline, the endorphins known as 'happy hormones'.

Avoid the richer dairy products, such as cream and cheese, during this week. You can, however, include yoghurt made from cow, sheep or goat's milk in your diet, and I recommend live, full-fat, calcium-rich yoghurts that contain beneficial bacteria, such as bifidus, acidophilus and lactobacillus, which can help replenish your gut flora, alleviate bloating and help build up a strong immune system.

Maintain your energy levels by eating a little often. Healthy snacks include fruit, fruit juices, smoothies and dried fruits (without added sulphur dioxide). Chunks of raw vegetables are also idea.

By the end of your spring clean, you should feel so revitalised that you will feel inspired to keep up many of your newly acquired good habits. Giving food and your body a chance to work harmoniously together will make the prospect of achieving this year's look less daunting.

webTitle: Health report: The agony of acne

fields.headline: Health report: The agony of acne
fields.standfirst: Acne blighted Andrew Smith's adolescence - and the scars it left are more than skin deep
fields.trailText: Acne blighted Andrew Smith's adolescence - and the scars it left are more than skin deep
fields.body:
The memory is shrouded in a dream-like haze, as though it were something I watched on TV. I was sitting in a GP's office and he was saying, 'Of course, we can cure your acne with a shot of oestrogen, but...' He shrugged his shoulder and chuckled at the imagined absurdity of the suggestion, but I scarcely heard him, because my mind was racing forward to images of myself with varying degrees of newly minted breast and bum - and clear skin - and I was thinking, 'Hey, that's not so bad.' It seemed to work for the ladyboys of Bangkok. And, of course, women. Unfortunately, each time I blinked, my imaginary appendages seemed to get bigger, until I was standing there in my mind's eye as Diana Dors. God, how could I wear that lipstick with that eye shadow? I'd rather have acne. But only just. It was at this point that I realised I had a problem.

Adults tend not to take acne seriously, and it's true that the misery it produces is relative. Next to being flattened by a meteorite, or liquidised in a giant blender, or trapped in a lift with Chris Evans, acne is trivial. It goes without saying that there are many more debilitating diseases and afflictions. But it can do damage, nonetheless. In my case, it started suddenly at about the age of 14, as though a little demon came in the night and sprinkled it over my face and back. At first, the angry spots and lumps were itchy and irritating, but over the coming months, they steadily spread and got worse. The statistics say that 85 per cent of people between the ages of 12 and 25 suffer acne to some extent, but a few of us find our faces colonised with serious 'inflammatory' acne to the extent that we become almost unrecognisable. If you're enjoying a pizza lunch right now, you may prefer to return to this later, because there were times when every inch of my face and forehead was covered with glowering pustules and hideous, boil-like mounds, with blackheads and whiteheads and unspeakable growths for which names, to my knowledge, don't even exist.

I tried all kinds of things simply to render the condition manageable. I tried a sun lamp, vitamin E on the skin, various types of wash and commercial products which didn't seem to work and may have done more harm than good. In the hope that an allergy might be involved, I cut out certain foods, drinking only goat's milk for a couple of years, but that didn't help either. The only things which did help were sun and antibiotics, which I was prescribed in increasingly strong forms and dosages, until my skin began to stabilise itself when I was about 20. The damage this did to my immune system has taken years to repair, but I still suspect that, given the same set of options, I would do the same again. David Collins, who runs a website dedicated to the subject, speaks of the 'Porsche test': ask a sufferer if they would rather have a brand-new Porsche or clear skin, he says, and you will always get the same answer. Move around the various sites devoted to the subject, and you're struck by a mood of simmering desperation, backed by a bewildering number of suggestions for remedies. Collins himself advocates (Ro)Accutane, the strong drug of last resort which has been linked to depression, suicide and birth defects. 'Forget the scare stories,' he says. 'You are trading long-term psychological pain for short-term mild discomfort.' Scary, yes, but I know where he's coming from.

The problem is that, while some unlucky adults retain clinical acne, which is recognised as a disease, it hits most of us when we are at our most vulnerable: during adolescence. This is a time when our self-image is coalescing and we're groping, often literally, towards a sexual identity. I remember the mixed feelings I had after returning from my first year at college and hearing a succession of previously uninterested women telling me, 'Wow - you've changed.'

I felt relief, but also a little anger. I hadn't changed. Only my skin had. This would give me pause for thought many times over the years, when I found myself choosing to go out with one person over another partly or primarily because of the way they looked. Those girls from home were being no more fickle or shallow than me - which is perhaps the most painful fact to acknowledge in this story.

No one seems to know precisely what causes Acne vulgaris, as the affliction is undecorously known to the medical profession, but we do know that there is a strong element of heredity involved. It develops when the glands that produce an oily substance called sebum begin to work overtime, possibly due to hormone changes that occur during the teen years. One function of sebum is to carry cells shed by the glands to the surface of the skin. The trouble starts when excess sebum is blocking the gland ducts, causing both cells and sebum to accumulate, forming a plug called a comedo. If this plug stays below the surface of the skin, it becomes a whitehead. If it enlarges and pops out, the tip looks dark (due to a build-up of the pigment melanin, not grease or dirt) and you have a blackhead. If the process continues, a spot emerges. In girls, this process often starts at around the age of 11, in boys at 13. In both cases, research has suggested that a hormone called androgen plays a role, because it stimulates the sebum-producing glands. After puberty, boys produce 10 times as much androgen as girls, which is why far more boys than girls develop severe inflammatory acne. Bacterium, such as Corynebacterium acnes, may also be actively involved, causing skin fats to break down into irritating chemicals.

Things that can make acne worse are picking at it; certain drugs, including some forms of contraceptive pill; exposure to industrial oils, grease and chemicals; some oily cosmetics and - this is a big one - stress and strong emotion, be they triggered by big dates or pressure from exams. There is no evidence that greasy food or oily skin or hair have any direct bearing on the condition - and sex and masturbation certainly don't, though they can mess up your bedroom carpet. At the same time, a healthy, balanced diet can boost the immune system and so reduce inflammation, and there is a suggestion that excess caloric intake can increase production of testosterone - a bad thing. Some people find that reducing their iodine intake (through shellfish, iodized salt and milk) is helpful.

Antibiotics like tetracycline are still prescribed to deal with the problem, but it is now widely recognised that long-term intake of these is extremely unwise. Other drugs, such as the aforementioned Accutane, are also used, but are similarly best avoided if at all possible. These are between you and your doctor, and long before reaching them, there are many naturally based aids that are worth trying. Drinking lots of water helps the body to flush out toxins and relieves the skin from this duty, for instance. Washing should be done no more than two or three times a day, and gently: there is an unconscious tendency to want to punish the skin by scrubbing it, but drying it out, or upsetting its pH balance, will make matters worse.

In addition, some research contends that hormone levels increase when sleep is disturbed, so sleep patterns may be worth looking at and anything which can assist relaxation - exercise, yoga, Grateful Dead albums - can do no harm. Arguably.

Requiring more commitment are regimes of vitamin and mineral supplements. Often suggested are C, E and B complexes, and zinc, all of which must be treated with caution and used only after taking advice on the appropriate dosages. Herbal remedies I've seen recommended include saw palmetto berry extract (for boys), chaste tree berry (for girls), echinacea, alfalfa, burdock root, cayenne, chaparral, dandelion root, red clover, yellow dock root and green tea extract pills... so a quick trip to the herbalist is probably worthwhile.

Exfoliating once or twice a day with distilled white vinegar (dilute until the stinging is tolerable, leave on the skin for 10 minutes, then wash off with cool water), or with lemon or tomato (same procedure), works well for some sufferers, with results taking about 14 days to show. Stranger still are the range of face masks to be found on www.absoluteacneinfo.com, based on egg yolk, honey and oatmeal, milk of magnesia, even strawberries. If they don't work, at least you can eat them or use them to reduce stress through a range of popular sex games.

Does acne come with any blessings? Yes, a few. When I look in the mirror now, I still expect to see something riven with welts and lesions and am surprised when I don't. I suppose this is to be thankful for. Then, the other week, a friend made an unkind comment about someone being overweight and later said that she'd 'watched a sort of cloud' pass over my face. At the time, she thought this was some kind of PC reflex, but it wasn't. I was remembering what it's like to be obscured by, and judged on, your appearance alone; to go through life with the feeling that your true self is unseen. If acne taught me one thing, it is how much looks count for in the world and how suspicious the wise person should be of this.

The five ages of acne

While acne is commonly thought of as the preserve of the teenage skin, it can hit at any age. 'The most common form of acne is caused when the body becomes hypersensitive to the male hormones we all carry,' says Dr Anne Eady from the Skin Research Centre at the University of Leeds. 'This can happen at any age - what varies is the trigger.'

Neonatal acne About 20 per cent of babies develop acne in the few weeks after birth. 'They develop little red spots normally confined to the face,' says Dr Eady. 'It's a reaction to residual hormones transmitted from the mother's blood in pregnancy or through breast milk - it normally clears up after six months.'

Infantile acne Some children develop the more traditional form of acne with blackheads and white spots at the age of one to two. Exactly why is unknown, but it can be treated.

Prepubertal acne Acne that develops in children aged eight to nine is very rare and is normally caused by disorders in the endocrine system.

Adolescent acne All teenagers get acne to some degree. 'It starts just before puberty, when the skin begins to produce sebum (or oil) and the maturation of the sex glands increases this further,' says Dr Eady. 'Cell renewal also speeds up, and this combined with the additional oil in the pores causes blockages in the skin which can get infected.'

Late-onset acne One in five adults develop spots in their twenties, thirties or forties. It's more common in women, as it's often linked to the development of polycystic ovary syndrome. 'Its also often blamed on increased stress aggravating hormone levels,' says Dr Eady.

fields.headline: The perfect... goal
fields.trailText: It has to be Diego Maradona, who, during the course of a quarter-final against England in Mexico 1986, scored not one but two perfect goals. The second was as good as football gets. Maradona picked up the ball in his own half and shimmied past at least half the England team, who failed to even foul him, and Peter Shilton, before placing the ball into an empty net.
fields.body:
It has to be Diego Maradona, who, during the course of a quarter-final against England in Mexico 1986, scored not one but two perfect goals. The second was as good as football gets. Maradona picked up the ball in his own half and shimmied past at least half the England team, who failed to even foul him, and Peter Shilton, before placing the ball into an empty net.

'Gooool,' screamed Argentine commentator Victor Hugo Morales. 'Diegooo Maradooona... The greatest player of all time... Argentina 2, England 0! Diego Armando Maradona... Thank you, God, for football... for Maradona, for these tears, for this... Argentina 2, England 0.'

And he was relatively restrained. You lose a war, you win a football match. It would be a worthy winner had Maradona not scored an even better goal a few minutes earlier. This time, there was no artistry and skill, just chicanery and cheek. The ball comes over and Diego uses sleight of hand to punch it into the net. So quick was the deception that only Shilton, standing alone in front of the England goal, realised he had been had. It was a goal out of nothing, unmerited. To beat England was glorious, to beat them with such a goal... divine.

Those who cavil that, by definition, an illegal goal cannot be perfect are being unduly legalistic. Would they be objecting if Peter Beardsley had pulled off the stunt? If England had gone on to win the World Cup? Of course not.

The fact that tired football writers and old pros still bang on about 'The Hand of God' goal simply reaffirms its worth. Maradona broke the rules and got away with it. That's perfection. Minutes later, he achieved the same end result perfectly legally. That's rubbing it in.

fields.headline: Go see... the Stuckists
fields.trailText: Naming an exhibition The Resignation of Sir Nicholas Serota may not be the best way to endear the Tate director to your cause, but the Stuckist group of painters, whose touring show of expressive figurative work is about to open at the Metropole Arts Centre in Folkestone, are unperturbed. As the founding group of a self-named art movement called Remodernism, they stand on an art ticket that's against clever conceptualism and in favour of a more emotional and spiritual integrity in art via figurative painting.
fields.body:
Naming an exhibition The Resignation of Sir Nicholas Serota may not be the best way to endear the Tate director to your cause, but the Stuckist group of painters, whose touring show of expressive figurative work is about to open at the Metropole Arts Centre in Folkestone, are unperturbed. As the founding group of a self-named art movement called Remodernism, they stand on an art ticket that's against clever conceptualism and in favour of a more emotional and spiritual integrity in art via figurative painting.

Naming themselves after a comment made by Tracey Emin to her ex-partner and Stuckist co-founder Billy Childish that his work was 'stuck, stuck, stuck' played on the Emin connection and gained the group column inches. Their current show continues the publicity campaign with a jokey swipe at Serota's support of current young British conceptual artists, but behind the humour is also a desire for serious debate.

'Serota's admirable achievement with Tate Modern is not in question,' comments Charles Thompson, the main drive behind the Stuckists. 'But while the Tate wants to offer a comprehensive overview of new British art, they only really show and promote Britart and conceptual work. So a lot of disenfranchised artists and art students are made to feel they've failed before they've begun because their work just doesn't fit that mould.'

With interest from artists and galleries in Germany, France, Argentina and Australia, plus a student support group at Camberwell School of art, the movement has definitely struck a chord, but whether a Stuckist painting will ever appear amongst the Bacons, Rothkos and Duchamps in Tate Modern is more doubtful.

 Stuck! Paintings by the Stuckists is showing from 20 May to 4 June at Metropole Arts Centre, The Leas, Folkestone, Kent (01303 255 070; www.stuckism.com)

fields.headline: Topic of cancer
fields.standfirst: The columns, the documentaries, the books, the plays... John Diamond always wanted to be famous. But becoming Mr Celebrity Cancer was never part of the plan. Here, he talks to Nicci Gerrard about his life, his wife and the dying game
fields.trailText: The columns, the documentaries, the books, the plays... John Diamond always wanted to be famous. But becoming Mr Celebrity Cancer was never part of the plan. Here, he talks to Nicci Gerrard about his life, his wife and the dying game
fields.body:
We are all of us dying, of course. In the middle of life, we are in death. But some of us are dying more quickly than others. John Diamond is dying more quickly. Three months, he gives himself; maybe six months; a year, perhaps, even two if he has the luck he hasn't had so far. Who knows, he says with his nice, ironic shrug, the same shrug he gives when you ask him how he is: who knows? Not him.

His cancer was diagnosed three years ago, and since then he's been slithering down the statistical slide, from the 90-something per cent chance of surviving to the going-on 100 per cent chance of not. He's been poisoned, blasted, had bits lopped off him, been in remission, felt lumps grow again, been given shreds of hope, had hope removed. He's lost his tongue, his voice, his middle-aged paunch, his sense of an assumed future. 'I am almost certainly dying,' he says, 'but I live as if I'm not. Not because I've discovered a great truth, but because it is the only possible way to live.' He's not Dennis Potter, rhapsodising over cherry blossom and life's unbearable beauty as he swigged liquid morphine. He's more like Philip Larkin, who said if you were really conscious of your mortality, you wouldn't be able to get out of bed in the morning. Life's not like a supermarket sweep, he says, when you have to frantically throw all the things you don't usually buy into your trolley, cram as much in before that final buzzer goes. He doesn't read the great novels or listen to the great operas he has never quite got round to. He procrastinates more than ever, misses deadlines, reads the same bad detective thrillers he always has, plays poker, cracks jokes, enjoys the things he used to enjoy. For one of the things John Diamond has learned - along with the vocabulary of cancer and the architecture of fear, the way to eat a pear without a tongue - is that you are always in the middle of your own life. In the midst of death, we are in life.

John Diamond is a journalist, a writer and a one-time broadcaster. He used to make much of his living from his voice, 'gabby' he calls the person he used to be, but now has no voice - or not the kind of voice that he can go on radio with, to be witty and opinionated. It's a sparsely consonanted heave of sound from his throat, which family and close friends can understand but others have difficulty with. He is married to the journalist and cookery writer, Nigella Lawson, whose food he can no longer eat. He is not without a sense of irony about all of this, nor about how he has always wanted to be famous and now is famous for his cancer. The painful, funny column he writes about his cancer in The Times, the unsentimental, wry, sad book he wrote about it, the TV documentary that tracked him through diagnoses and operations - all these things have made him, he says, with his sardonic grin, Mr Celebrity Cancer. He sometimes feels as if he's 'landed the cancer franchise for the chattering classes'. One of the tricky things about interviewing John Diamond is that he's already asked himself the questions, made the criticisms, attacked himself in print (a diamond to cut a diamond). He writes about having cancer; he writes about writing about having cancer In the last column I read by him, he wrote about being interviewed and photographed by a Sunday paper - getting his word in first.

I meet him at his lovely house in West London - lovely not just because it's big and light-filled and book-crammed, with a long green garden, but also because it is brimful of life. John Diamond is downstairs in the large kitchen, hub of the house, feeding lunch to his small son, Bruno. There is a fluid crowd of other people - the nanny; Nigella (who's upstairs, filming her latest cookery programme for Channel Four, she wanders in and out); members of the TV team; friends, who enter by way of the garden. 'It's like one of those mad sitcom houses with people popping in and out all the time,' says/writes John Diamond. Most of his side of our conversation is written down, either in his neat italic handwriting, or on his computer up in the study. 'It's like watching a French film with subtitles,' he replies, when I say I'm sure I could follow his speech. 'You're convinced that if there were no subtitles you could still understand it - but you (I) couldn't.'

He is looking pretty good: thinnish in his jeans and silk shirt, pale, hair bleached off-white ('It's my perhaps-David-Irving-had-a-point look'). He keeps his mouth closed much of the time, even when he smiles, and this gives him a kind and secret air. His throat is circled with livid scars - he says that if he'd had all his operations at once, his head would have fallen off - and he lifts his shirt up to show me the puckered ridge running up his back, where he had muscle removed to replace the lower portion of tongue in his jaw. His body is like a battlefield. The Times used to call his diary the 'Diary of Courage', until he asked them to change it. People write to tell him how brave he is. He doesn't think he is brave - his book is titled C: Because Cowards Can Get Cancer Too . 'Courage implies some kind of choice in the way one behaves, and I am behaving the way I behave because that seems to be the way I behave. In any case, when people ask you what you do, you can't say: "Oh, I write the Diary of Courage."'

When you picture a man in his mid-forties, with two small children, who will probably die soon, who's been in and out of hospital under the knife, who has no tongue, can't eat, can't properly talk - well, that sounds pretty grim and scary. But John Diamond isn't grim. There is a feeling of lightness about him, and of zest. His days are spent writing his columns, or his play, or (more rarely) the novel he is working on, tossing coffee or his liquid gloop down his opened throat ('I have to throw it down in one go because without a tongue I can't move food from the front of my mouth to the back and thus down my gullet. I have learned to open my throat - I have no epiglottis to shield my windpipe - and pour it down rather as one might pour it into a bath'), smoking (the doctors agree the reasons for not smoking are irrelevant now, and smoking is the nearest he gets to eating - he tastes the cigarette; he savours it), seeing friends, getting stoned or drunk, not being scared.

'Because most of the time I'm not scared. I get on with life, not because I'm a fatalist, but because that's the most congenial way of dealing with things. Indeed, most of the time, I'm not conscious of dealing with anything. I think of myself as being in remission, and, therefore, as someone with cancer. But whenever I talk about still being cancerous, the doctors affect mock anger and tell me that I don't have it. What they mean is that I have it in such small quantities that it doesn't show up on the scanner, or didn't the last time they looked, at least. But it is remission. The six months' worth of chemo finished about nine months ago, and the average remission in the 25 per cent of people in my condition for whom chemo is useful stay clear for, on average, between three and six months, so to that extent I suppose I am bucking the trend.'

In spite of his clear-eyed sense that his horizons have diminished to the rim of days around him, he has just bought himself a Palm Pilot and has entered dates up to August - when he is going to Edinburgh to direct the one-woman play he is writing for and with Maria McErlane, and to keep in touch with Victoria Coren's one-man play based on his columns. 'The thing is,' he says, 'most of the time I feel just like I ever did, except for the voice and the food. Every so often, though, I do get scared - mainly by the realisation that although I work on the hypothesis that because I feel OK I must be OK, the fact is I'll probably still feel OK on the day they tell me I have three months left. I'll feel like this on the day I go to hospital and hear that it's returned (if you write that, I'll get another million letters and emails telling me I do myself no good by looking on the bad side. But there is no other side to look on.) And I know that the last few weeks will probably be pretty nasty, although I intend spending much of that time as doped up as I can.'

Although he has mostly 'put his affairs in order', and although he writes about his mortality, he never imagines life going on after he has died: never pictures the familiar landscape, but without him in it. 'One of the mad emailers' obsessions is - I quote - who's going to be banging Nigella after I've stopped. It really doesn't worry me. As far as I'm concerned, as long as I'm slightly tepid in the grave I'd hope she'd get round to it as soon as possible - metaphorically and literally.

'Absolutely the most painful thing' about the whole business, 'the one I really can't bear thinking about', is the children. 'Cosima knows that I have cancer but she doesn't know what the prognosis is. She is quite used to my honking self and told me not long ago that she can't remember what I was like before. Bruno still asks me every so often if I am still ill, by which he means will my voice come back, but neither of them is particularly conscious that I'm different from other daddies.'

John Diamond receives thousands of emails and letters every week. He shows me the boxes full of letters - typed and mistyped, handwritten in various colours of ink, with pressed flowers stuck on to their flimsy pages, offering Christian comfort, alternative hopes, words of wisdom and folly and shared sadness. Some treat him as an agony uncle qualified to deal with the griefs of the world ('WHY?'); an agony uncle is the central character in the novel he is working on. Many are from people whose parents/siblings/friends died of cancer in the days when it was thought bad form to talk about it 'and now they say they have some idea of what their loved ones went through'. Many read him and write to him because he is like the scout, going on before us to where we know we will arrive one day; he sends us back dispatches from the last frontier. ('No,' he chastises me, 'I write about living, not dying'; his 'greatest fraud', he says, is pretending to know more about dying than the rest of us.)

But some attack him for writing down all of his illness, dwelling on it, making public what was thought to be private, saying the C-word over and over again, talking of his nausea and his wounds and his phlegm and his fear. He clicks up an email for me: 'dear me diamond,' it begins, 'first I can't believe you have a website devoted to your tongue' and continues at length: 'self-possessed morbid version of eastenders... whingeing ad infinitum... totally middle-class, and you don't really want to know or see the true face of low-income disease... you make me puke... insanely self-indulgent... you're going on like a psychotic, a highly irritating one at that.' And the thing is, says John Diamond then, 'I can see his point.' It's hard not to fall for such a man.

Some journalists have also attacked him for making death into a new sensationalist genre. When the TV cameras followed him on his hospital trolley, Nigella lying beside him, up to the operating theatre; when the camera watched them kiss and maybe that would be goodbye, some critics winced. Surely that was going a bit far? In The Modern Review, Decca Aitkenhead attacked the 'emotional pornography' of writers such as Oscar Moore (now dead), Ruth Picardie (now dead), Martyn Harris (now dead). 'Columns by dying strangers make you cry,' she wrote, 'but if you read a decent porn mag it will probably make you come.' She argued that the difference between love and pornography is the same as the difference between real grief and what she sees as a tourist trip to the profitable theme park of sorrow. These death columnists are colluding in a 'Gotcha!' or Oprah Winfrey style of journalism, where nothing is private, and even dying can be turned into soap opera.

John Diamond cheerfully admits that for many readers he is writing a soap opera, and 'they're hooked, as they may be to The Archers' (except, of course, The Archers goes on and on, and his diary is heading towards brutal narrative closure). And, he agrees, he always wanted to be famous. But he does trenchantly tackle some of the central criticisms. 'Certainly,' he says, 'there are times when I want to forget the whole cancer thing - but which cancer patient doesn't? And there are plenty of times when I could do without being Mr Cancer, the editor's cancerous chum and the man who has cancer for a living. An old git was rounded up to write a knocking piece about me for the Mail a year or so ago, and referred to my "exploiting" my cancer as if I was flogging it by the bottle door to door, but it doesn't really feel like that. I probably get nearer the truth of me than I would the truth of somebody else going through it. Does that sound horribly defensive?' It seems reasonable that a man who makes his living writing about his life (with the supremely arrogant assumption that it stands as a metaphor for life in general) should carry on writing about it when that life gets interesting.

The boundaries, he says, are of good taste and intrusion into the lives of Nigella and the children. And 'while Nigella is naturally a private person who tends to write even the most personal columns in the passive tense, I'm naturally one of those people who you sit next to on the bus who tells you their life story and shows you their appendix scar. This is not affectation: this stuff neither embarrasses me, nor do I regard it as particularly private.'

I ask about the trolley scene on TV, which I had watched with some anxiety myself - is it really all right to spend your possibly last minutes alive being filmed? Is that a way to say goodbye? 'I don't know. Remember, I was medded up to the eyeballs. More to the point, when you're being sent down to undergo an operation which at the unlikely worst might kill you and which at best is going to change your life for the worst forever, it helps if you spend your last few minutes thinking about what the camera is doing rather than what the surgeon's about to do. (Not that I always get it right. The film was due to come out just as my book was coming out, and the publisher had asked me to give it a plug on camera. Rightly enough, the director made it clear that the BBC isn't in the game of product placement. But on the last day of filming, she asked me a question to which the legitimate answer was: "As I say in the book..." I held up the book to read from it, and found myself, for only the second or third time since diagnosis, weeping uncontrollably. But as I wept I found an intrusive thought hovering around: "The book shot is bound to be kept in the final edit. No director of this sort of film ever passes up the opportunity to show a grown man crying." But, good for her, she left it out. It didn't add anything, she said, to the film.)'

When the novelist and journalist Martyn Harris wrote two long features about the death that was hurtling through him, and then began a column about it, it was distressing and terrifying to read. Ruth Picardie's columns in The Observer were almost unbearable - like drawn-out howls of anguish. But John Diamond's writing is not depressing, although it can sting and shock. In its granular, acerbic, self-mocking way, it can be oddly comforting. He nods. 'The thing about Martyn, Ruth, Oscar, et al is that it happened so quickly. I think one of the only differences between me and them is that I've been doing this for three years now.' He grins sardonically. 'They were just dilettantes.' (One of the most unsettling pieces of honesty was when he admitted to being a bit jealous of Ruth, because she was dying more dramatically than him, as if she had somehow stolen his subject.) If he holds out some kind of comfort, he says, it is because he has endured; his approaching death has become familiar. He is no longer gripped by the terror that had hold of him once, and so neither are we. 'But ask me again a few days before I die.'

He seems to have little self-pity and hates the kind of bogus compassion that floods some of the people who look deep into his shrewd eyes with 'that "I do understand, I DO" look'. He hates being regarded as some kind of saint just because he is dying young. He loves being famous but thinks he's got his fame by 'cheating' (after all, he didn't choose the cancer, it chose him). He says that he has not, in any profound way, changed - 'I'm exactly the same person, as far as I'm concerned. I have the same faults, the same worries, the same general inclinations. I'm no kinder or more tolerant, my will power is no greater, and I'm frightened by much the same things as I ever was. People assume that death hanging over my head would allow me to put things into perspective, but that's not how it works. I was driving an old friend to the station the other day. I'd not seen her for years and in the intervening time she'd been beaten up by an abusive husband and was going through the messiest divorce. Halfway through telling me this, she stopped and said "But what am I saying. Compared to your troubles..." But my troubles are - most of the time - as they ever were: why's that idiot driving in two lanes in front of me, why have I run out of clean socks, why have the papers not been delivered yet.'

The most emotional he gets is when he talks about Nigella. He talks about glimpses of her beauty, with a beaming, pride-filled sadness. He talks about the way this is worse for her than for him - she has already been unlucky too many times in her life. Her mother died young of cancer; her sister died of cancer, too. It is as if there is a sniper in the garden, gunning down the people she loves best. 'And after all, she is the one who will be left with the detritus.' She is a reticent person, he says, and only occasionally shows what she is going through. She works as hard as she does so she doesn't have to think too hard about where her life is heading. When he first met Nigella, after his first marriage collapsed ('or rather, imploded'), she was a 'rather shy and introverted literary editor. She's come out so much in the last 10 years. I think it is partly having children, but in many ways I think it was very brave of her to marry me. If I say I was a risk, I don't mean there was a reason for her not to be certain of me. But because I was something of an unknown quantity, as it turned out, we seem to be pretty perfectly matched.' Was she a risk for him, I ask. 'Oh no. No,' he replies at once. He talks about her courage, her talent, her success. He is proud of her, with a pride that lights up his face. They have been together for 11 years.

When I say that it must be surreal, him writing about dying while she (whose subjects include food and make-up, as well as politics) is writing about living, he doesn't agree. 'It doesn't worry me that the life we live is so surreal - actually, most of the time it isn't. We live like any other married couple with kids and a mortgage and the residents' parking to worry about. But then we find ourselves doing the glam media-couple shtick and it does feel odd.' He is quick to say that he is needed by her as much as she by him, and that neither do other friends regard him as a victim. 'Being needed grants me authenticity,' he says. In his gang, he is not the odd one out - though in the pub, when he is tossing alcohol down his open throat, he does look 'like a Russian sailor on leave'.

People write to him offering him the comforts of religion. He is an agnostic, not an atheist, but closeness to death has brought him no nearer to God. He sometimes prays, but he doesn't ask for anything, 'except sometimes the ability to get through something. Usually - this sounds unbearably pious - I give thanks.' He mostly thinks when he goes, that's probably it. Sometimes he worries, in a 'mad and irrational way', about what would happen if he suddenly got cured: 'It would be something of an unsatisfactory ending of the story.' But he knows, of course, that he won't be cured. He knows he is dying; the story is coming to an end. Yet in the middle of death, he is living.

John Diamond wipes his mouth with a handkerchief. 'And in a funny kind of way - call me Cleopatra (Queen of Denial)' - he glances over to see if I get the dreadful pun - 'I've never been happier. I find myself surrounded by a marvellous family, wonderful friends, I have work I enjoy most of the time, and I'm on antidepressants. What more,' he asks, and smiles his sweet, ironic smile, smiles as if he really, truly means it, 'what more could a boy want?'

 To order a copy of John Diamond's book C: Because Cowards Get Cancer Too (Vermillion, £6.99), for £5.99, including UK p&p, freephone 0800 316 8171
