He is looking pretty good: thinnish in his jeans and silk shirt, pale, hair bleached off-white ('It's my perhaps-David-Irving-had-a-point look'). He keeps his mouth closed much of the time, even when he smiles, and this gives him a kind and secret air. His throat is circled with livid scars - he says that if he'd had all his operations at once, his head would have fallen off - and he lifts his shirt up to show me the puckered ridge running up his back, where he had muscle removed to replace the lower portion of tongue in his jaw. His body is like a battlefield. The Times used to call his diary the 'Diary of Courage', until he asked them to change it. People write to tell him how brave he is. He doesn't think he is brave - his book is titled C: Because Cowards Can Get Cancer Too . 'Courage implies some kind of choice in the way one behaves, and I am behaving the way I behave because that seems to be the way I behave. In any case, when people ask you what you do, you can't say: "Oh, I write the Diary of Courage."' When you picture a man in his mid-forties, with two small children, who will probably die soon, who's been in and out of hospital under the knife, who has no tongue, can't eat, can't properly talk - well, that sounds pretty grim and scary. But John Diamond isn't grim. There is a feeling of lightness about him, and of zest. His days are spent writing his columns, or his play, or (more rarely) the novel he is working on, tossing coffee or his liquid gloop down his opened throat ('I have to throw it down in one go because without a tongue I can't move food from the front of my mouth to the back and thus down my gullet. I have learned to open my throat - I have no epiglottis to shield my windpipe - and pour it down rather as one might pour it into a bath'), smoking (the doctors agree the reasons for not smoking are irrelevant now, and smoking is the nearest he gets to eating - he tastes the cigarette; he savours it), seeing friends, getting stoned or drunk, not being scared. 'Because most of the time I'm not scared. I get on with life, not because I'm a fatalist, but because that's the most congenial way of dealing with things. Indeed, most of the time, I'm not conscious of dealing with anything. I think of myself as being in remission, and, therefore, as someone with cancer. But whenever I talk about still being cancerous, the doctors affect mock anger and tell me that I don't have it. What they mean is that I have it in such small quantities that it doesn't show up on the scanner, or didn't the last time they looked, at least. But it is remission. The six months' worth of chemo finished about nine months ago, and the average remission in the 25 per cent of people in my condition for whom chemo is useful stay clear for, on average, between three and six months, so to that extent I suppose I am bucking the trend.' In spite of his clear-eyed sense that his horizons have diminished to the rim of days around him, he has just bought himself a Palm Pilot and has entered dates up to August - when he is going to Edinburgh to direct the one-woman play he is writing for and with Maria McErlane, and to keep in touch with Victoria Coren's one-man play based on his columns. 'The thing is,' he says, 'most of the time I feel just like I ever did, except for the voice and the food. Every so often, though, I do get scared - mainly by the realisation that although I work on the hypothesis that because I feel OK I must be OK, the fact is I'll probably still feel OK on the day they tell me I have three months left. I'll feel like this on the day I go to hospital and hear that it's returned (if you write that, I'll get another million letters and emails telling me I do myself no good by looking on the bad side. But there is no other side to look on.) And I know that the last few weeks will probably be pretty nasty, although I intend spending much of that time as doped up as I can.' Although he has mostly 'put his affairs in order', and although he writes about his mortality, he never imagines life going on after he has died: never pictures the familiar landscape, but without him in it. 'One of the mad emailers' obsessions is - I quote - who's going to be banging Nigella after I've stopped. It really doesn't worry me. As far as I'm concerned, as long as I'm slightly tepid in the grave I'd hope she'd get round to it as soon as possible - metaphorically and literally. 'Absolutely the most painful thing' about the whole business, 'the one I really can't bear thinking about', is the children. 'Cosima knows that I have cancer but she doesn't know what the prognosis is. She is quite used to my honking self and told me not long ago that she can't remember what I was like before. Bruno still asks me every so often if I am still ill, by which he means will my voice come back, but neither of them is particularly conscious that I'm different from other daddies.' John Diamond receives thousands of emails and letters every week. He shows me the boxes full of letters - typed and mistyped, handwritten in various colours of ink, with pressed flowers stuck on to their flimsy pages, offering Christian comfort, alternative hopes, words of wisdom and folly and shared sadness. Some treat him as an agony uncle qualified to deal with the griefs of the world ('WHY?'); an agony uncle is the central character in the novel he is working on. Many are from people whose parents/siblings/friends died of cancer in the days when it was thought bad form to talk about it 'and now they say they have some idea of what their loved ones went through'. Many read him and write to him because he is like the scout, going on before us to where we know we will arrive one day; he sends us back dispatches from the last frontier. ('No,' he chastises me, 'I write about living, not dying'; his 'greatest fraud', he says, is pretending to know more about dying than the rest of us.) But some attack him for writing down all of his illness, dwelling on it, making public what was thought to be private, saying the C-word over and over again, talking of his nausea and his wounds and his phlegm and his fear. He clicks up an email for me: 'dear me diamond,' it begins, 'first I can't believe you have a website devoted to your tongue' and continues at length: 'self-possessed morbid version of eastenders... whingeing ad infinitum... totally middle-class, and you don't really want to know or see the true face of low-income disease... you make me puke... insanely self-indulgent... you're going on like a psychotic, a highly irritating one at that.' And the thing is, says John Diamond then, 'I can see his point.' It's hard not to fall for such a man. Some journalists have also attacked him for making death into a new sensationalist genre. When the TV cameras followed him on his hospital trolley, Nigella lying beside him, up to the operating theatre; when the camera watched them kiss and maybe that would be goodbye, some critics winced. Surely that was going a bit far? In The Modern Review, Decca Aitkenhead attacked the 'emotional pornography' of writers such as Oscar Moore (now dead), Ruth Picardie (now dead), Martyn Harris (now dead). 'Columns by dying strangers make you cry,' she wrote, 'but if you read a decent porn mag it will probably make you come.' She argued that the difference between love and pornography is the same as the difference between real grief and what she sees as a tourist trip to the profitable theme park of sorrow. These death columnists are colluding in a 'Gotcha!' or Oprah Winfrey style of journalism, where nothing is private, and even dying can be turned into soap opera. John Diamond cheerfully admits that for many readers he is writing a soap opera, and 'they're hooked, as they may be to The Archers' (except, of course, The Archers goes on and on, and his diary is heading towards brutal narrative closure). And, he agrees, he always wanted to be famous. But he does trenchantly tackle some of the central criticisms. 'Certainly,' he says, 'there are times when I want to forget the whole cancer thing - but which cancer patient doesn't? And there are plenty of times when I could do without being Mr Cancer, the editor's cancerous chum and the man who has cancer for a living. An old git was rounded up to write a knocking piece about me for the Mail a year or so ago, and referred to my "exploiting" my cancer as if I was flogging it by the bottle door to door, but it doesn't really feel like that. I probably get nearer the truth of me than I would the truth of somebody else going through it. Does that sound horribly defensive?' It seems reasonable that a man who makes his living writing about his life (with the supremely arrogant assumption that it stands as a metaphor for life in general) should carry on writing about it when that life gets interesting. The boundaries, he says, are of good taste and intrusion into the lives of Nigella and the children. And 'while Nigella is naturally a private person who tends to write even the most personal columns in the passive tense, I'm naturally one of those people who you sit next to on the bus who tells you their life story and shows you their appendix scar. This is not affectation: this stuff neither embarrasses me, nor do I regard it as particularly private.' I ask about the trolley scene on TV, which I had watched with some anxiety myself - is it really all right to spend your possibly last minutes alive being filmed? Is that a way to say goodbye? 'I don't know. Remember, I was medded up to the eyeballs. More to the point, when you're being sent down to undergo an operation which at the unlikely worst might kill you and which at best is going to change your life for the worst forever, it helps if you spend your last few minutes thinking about what the camera is doing rather than what the surgeon's about to do. (Not that I always get it right. The film was due to come out just as my book was coming out, and the publisher had asked me to give it a plug on camera. Rightly enough, the director made it clear that the BBC isn't in the game of product placement. But on the last day of filming, she asked me a question to which the legitimate answer was: "As I say in the book..." I held up the book to read from it, and found myself, for only the second or third time since diagnosis, weeping uncontrollably. But as I wept I found an intrusive thought hovering around: "The book shot is bound to be kept in the final edit. No director of this sort of film ever passes up the opportunity to show a grown man crying." But, good for her, she left it out. It didn't add anything, she said, to the film.)' When the novelist and journalist Martyn Harris wrote two long features about the death that was hurtling through him, and then began a column about it, it was distressing and terrifying to read. Ruth Picardie's columns in The Observer were almost unbearable - like drawn-out howls of anguish. But John Diamond's writing is not depressing, although it can sting and shock. In its granular, acerbic, self-mocking way, it can be oddly comforting. He nods. 'The thing about Martyn, Ruth, Oscar, et al is that it happened so quickly. I think one of the only differences between me and them is that I've been doing this for three years now.' He grins sardonically. 'They were just dilettantes.' (One of the most unsettling pieces of honesty was when he admitted to being a bit jealous of Ruth, because she was dying more dramatically than him, as if she had somehow stolen his subject.) If he holds out some kind of comfort, he says, it is because he has endured; his approaching death has become familiar. He is no longer gripped by the terror that had hold of him once, and so neither are we. 'But ask me again a few days before I die.' He seems to have little self-pity and hates the kind of bogus compassion that floods some of the people who look deep into his shrewd eyes with 'that "I do understand, I DO" look'. He hates being regarded as some kind of saint just because he is dying young. He loves being famous but thinks he's got his fame by 'cheating' (after all, he didn't choose the cancer, it chose him). He says that he has not, in any profound way, changed - 'I'm exactly the same person, as far as I'm concerned. I have the same faults, the same worries, the same general inclinations. I'm no kinder or more tolerant, my will power is no greater, and I'm frightened by much the same things as I ever was. People assume that death hanging over my head would allow me to put things into perspective, but that's not how it works. I was driving an old friend to the station the other day. I'd not seen her for years and in the intervening time she'd been beaten up by an abusive husband and was going through the messiest divorce. Halfway through telling me this, she stopped and said "But what am I saying. Compared to your troubles..." But my troubles are - most of the time - as they ever were: why's that idiot driving in two lanes in front of me, why have I run out of clean socks, why have the papers not been delivered yet.' The most emotional he gets is when he talks about Nigella. He talks about glimpses of her beauty, with a beaming, pride-filled sadness. He talks about the way this is worse for her than for him - she has already been unlucky too many times in her life. Her mother died young of cancer; her sister died of cancer, too. It is as if there is a sniper in the garden, gunning down the people she loves best. 'And after all, she is the one who will be left with the detritus.' She is a reticent person, he says, and only occasionally shows what she is going through. She works as hard as she does so she doesn't have to think too hard about where her life is heading. When he first met Nigella, after his first marriage collapsed ('or rather, imploded'), she was a 'rather shy and introverted literary editor. She's come out so much in the last 10 years. I think it is partly having children, but in many ways I think it was very brave of her to marry me. If I say I was a risk, I don't mean there was a reason for her not to be certain of me. But because I was something of an unknown quantity, as it turned out, we seem to be pretty perfectly matched.' Was she a risk for him, I ask. 'Oh no. No,' he replies at once. He talks about her courage, her talent, her success. He is proud of her, with a pride that lights up his face. They have been together for 11 years. When I say that it must be surreal, him writing about dying while she (whose subjects include food and make-up, as well as politics) is writing about living, he doesn't agree. 'It doesn't worry me that the life we live is so surreal - actually, most of the time it isn't. We live like any other married couple with kids and a mortgage and the residents' parking to worry about. But then we find ourselves doing the glam media-couple shtick and it does feel odd.' He is quick to say that he is needed by her as much as she by him, and that neither do other friends regard him as a victim. 'Being needed grants me authenticity,' he says. In his gang, he is not the odd one out - though in the pub, when he is tossing alcohol down his open throat, he does look 'like a Russian sailor on leave'. People write to him offering him the comforts of religion. He is an agnostic, not an atheist, but closeness to death has brought him no nearer to God. He sometimes prays, but he doesn't ask for anything, 'except sometimes the ability to get through something. Usually - this sounds unbearably pious - I give thanks.' He mostly thinks when he goes, that's probably it. Sometimes he worries, in a 'mad and irrational way', about what would happen if he suddenly got cured: 'It would be something of an unsatisfactory ending of the story.' But he knows, of course, that he won't be cured. He knows he is dying; the story is coming to an end. Yet in the middle of death, he is living. John Diamond wipes his mouth with a handkerchief. 'And in a funny kind of way - call me Cleopatra (Queen of Denial)' - he glances over to see if I get the dreadful pun - 'I've never been happier. I find myself surrounded by a marvellous family, wonderful friends, I have work I enjoy most of the time, and I'm on antidepressants. What more,' he asks, and smiles his sweet, ironic smile, smiles as if he really, truly means it, 'what more could a boy want?'  To order a copy of John Diamond's book C: Because Cowards Get Cancer Too (Vermillion, £6.99), for £5.99, including UK p&p, freephone 0800 316 8171

webTitle: The cost of... changing your identity

fields.headline: The cost of... changing your identity
fields.trailText: The good news is that you can obtain a new identity quite cheaply. The bad news is that it will take time, patience and guile.
fields.body:
The good news is that you can obtain a new identity quite cheaply. The bad news is that it will take time, patience and guile.

Anybody can change their name by Deed Poll for £100, but an indelible link with your old name will remain. The only way to obtain a mint-condition identity, rather than an alias, is to build it from scratch. The most obvious method is to buy a dodgy passport from a man in a pub (£300-£500). One problem with this is that you probably don't know any members of the criminal underworld, and if you do, you know better than to trust them. A forged passport will not withstand close scrutiny; a stolen passport is useless. In 1998, more than 400 forged UK passports were discovered, and almost 150 were found in the hands of impostors.

To get a new passport (£28), you will need a birth certificate (£11 from the Family Records Centre or your local register office) and a few photographs of yourself (avoid using mug shots). It is legal to send off for anybody's birth certificate, but it is a criminal offence to use it fraudulently. You will need to know the date of birth, name and locale of your new namesake. There is no system to cross-reference births and deaths, but you will want to minimise the chances of bumping into your alter ego, so it helps if they are deceased. One technique, popular with criminals in the 70s, was 'paper chasing'. This involved searching cemeteries for the gravestone of an infant born roughly at the same time you were.

Once you have a birth certificate, other documents are easier to come by. A driving licence will be £23.50, although you will have to brush up on your mirror-signal manoeuvring.

Unfortunately, it is essential to pay off all your debts. This might defy the point of a new identity, but debt collectors are a persistent sort.

With valid paperwork, cosmetic changes are unnecessary, unless you plan to continue living in the same area. Invest in a new hairstyle (£20) or coloured contact lenses (£240 per year).

If you are abroad, then you might consider a foreign identity. A Costa Rican driving licence can be obtained for £10 (plus £3 for a medical) within a day or two. Of course the Holy Grail of international identities is Swiss - while it will open certain doors for you, other doors will be closed on anyone investigating you.

Cost of a new identity

Birth certificate £11
Passport photos £3
First passport £28
First driving licence £23.50
Clear all your debts £??

Total (excluding debts) £65.50

fields.headline: Mind the gap
fields.standfirst: Cherie and Tony Blair's baby will be 16 years younger than Euan, their eldest child. What impact will the age difference have? Marina Cantacuzino talks to three sets of siblings about rivalry, rage and the generation gap
fields.trailText: Cherie and Tony Blair's baby will be 16 years younger than Euan, their eldest child. What impact will the age difference have? Marina Cantacuzino talks to three sets of siblings about rivalry, rage and the generation gap
fields.body:
Sibling relationships are fuelled by competition and riven by comparison. While a great deal may rest on personality, circumstances and gender, the nearer you are in age to your brother or sister, the more acute the sibling rivalry is likely to be.

When Cherie Blair gives birth to her baby, due at the end of this month, there will be a gap of 16 years between her first, Euan, and her last child. Her daughter Kathryn will be 12 and her second son Nicholas, 14. The relationship this youngest child has with its older brothers and sister will be entirely different from the relationship they have with each other. The Blair baby will be cossetted, adored and treated like a very special person, not only by its parents but probably by its siblings, as rivalry usually loses its potency as the age gap widens.

'Sibling rivalry is usually for parents' affection, and in my clinical experience if there's a big gap they're still competing but they've got some distinction,' says David Spellman, a consultant psychologist who works with families. 'Possibly it's more tricky for the parents because there are so many facets to the task of parenting, but with the younger one, at least they've got experience to draw on and are probably better resourced financially.'

The Blair baby will also feel in many ways like an only child. Everything it has will be new, since suitable clothes and toys will have been thrown out long ago. Just as the other three children are learning to exercise their independence, it will be locked into its parents' lives for many years to come - living, eating, holidaying alone with a mother and father old enough to be grandparents.

Cherie Blair's pregnancy has invited copious comment, but once there was nothing unusual about late motherhood. In the late 19th century, sibling births spanned a generation, with new mothers often already grandmothers. American research shows that in the 20s, the average age at which women had their last child was 42, whereas now only 12 per cent of babies are born to women over 35. However, according to the Office of National Statistics, the most noticeable change in fertility over the past 20 years has been a shift towards later child-bearing. Significantly, since 1992 the number of 30- to 34-year-olds giving birth has exceeded the number of 20- to 24-year-olds giving birth. About 11,000 babies a year are born to women over 40, almost double the number 10 years ago, although still less than in the earlier part of the century.

Thirty years ago, having a child in your forties was looked upon as a little weird - if not a little disgusting - but now, in an era where 55-year-old women can use IVF and egg donation to become pregnant, it isn't that unusual, especially among women who have held off having children for career purposes. Another reason why gaps between brothers and sisters are growing wider can be put down to the high level of divorce and remarriage. But what is less common is when children born to the same parents span a 10-, 15- or 20-year age gap.

There are advantages and disadvantages to spreading your children out across the decades. For the mother and father, it can mean as many as 30 years of child-rearing, being bound at the hip to a toddler when your friends are rediscovering their freedom (not to mention the physical wear and tear on a body not designed for young children in middle age). On the other hand, there is nothing more likely to stop parents in their sixties from sinking into old age than having teenage children.

For the youngest child, it can mean feeling isolated and spotlighted as 'special'; for the older child, a blurring of edges between parent and sibling.

'As long as the older children have the message that they'll still be special and there's emotional preparation for the new arrival, there's no evidence to suggest that anyone should suffer,' says Barry Mason, director of the Institute for Family Therapy. 'In fact, often a newborn baby can make a difference to a child who's been difficult because they find themselves giving a lot of affection to the new child.

'I know of no research that says having children a good few years apart is somehow bad.'

David Spellman agrees. 'Older children can be nurturing of their younger brothers or sisters in a way that is actively supportive of their parents. Some parents even come to count on them. It can be a very enriching experience for all concerned.'

 Singer/songwriter Alissa Scott, 28, and her sister Sophie Scott, 15, live within two miles of each other in north London. Alissa is best known for her song 'Only Human', written for Dina Carroll; recently her debut single 'Easy For You to Say' won widespread acclaim. Sophie lives with her father and will be taking her GCSEs next year. Two months ago, their mother died after a 10-year battle with cancer.

Alissa As a child I remember always being on at my parents because I desperately wanted a brother or sister. I would plague them every day. But by the time I was 11, I'd given up. So I was completely shocked, at the age of 12, when my mother told me she was expecting another baby.

Sophie and I are just like best friends nowadays, but I remember for the first two years of her life I was a bit jealous because suddenly all the attention went on to this beautiful little fair-haired thing. Even up until the age of eight she was a bit bossy because with Mum not being well it meant she wasn't able to discipline Sophie as much as she'd have liked to. My mum was 39 when she had Sophie and my Dad was 45, so they weren't that old, but when she got ill afterwards it obviously stopped them from having any more. Mum was very much a homemaker and loved having children round the house, but because of her illness it physically exhausted her.

Our relationship has got closer as Sophie has got older because it's more equal now. I think this closeness is actually largely due to the age gap because there's nothing threatening about our relationship and no jealousy.

We're so similar inside and view the world in exactly the same way. It's like a having a soulmate. We'll often go out together and our friends get on really well.

Although I'm 13 years older, I don't feel the age difference at all. Perhaps because, being a musician, I'm not a conventional person, and also Sophie is incredibly streetwise and far more trendy than I ever was at that age.

Since Mum died, I've tried to be a support to Sophie. I've wanted to be, so I've never felt weighed down by the responsibility, and we've both been able to comfort each other. Having a mother who was ill for so long and a much older sister has made Sophie very mature. She's a wise old soul.

Mum's illness and death hasn't made our relationship closer, because we've always been close, but having a shared experience has definitely deepened our connection. Thank God we do have this closeness and thank God Sophie isn't an only child having to deal with the impact of her mother's death all on her own.

At the moment I'm going home a lot more than before because we're all still trying to register what's happened. I need to be there for Sophie, and over Easter I took time out to make sure she had the school things she needed - Mum would have done that before. In the future, I'll have to integrate that kind of thing more into my life.

I'm certain that having this age difference between us and being like a second mother to Sophie has taken away the broodiness other people seem to feel around my age. I know from direct experience the responsibility of bringing up a child, and therefore I don't want to get into it for at least another five years. I'm sure if it wasn't for Sophie, I'd probably be wanting babies by now.

Sophie I think my parents wanted the big age gap because they didn't want to be left without a child in the house. Alissa was like a second mum to me - she'd change my nappies, pick me up and throw me around. When I was five, she left home and I missed her terribly.

I never wished that she was younger, but I did wish that she still lived with us. Now the gap has narrowed and we're closer than ever. We talk all the time and during these last few weeks, since our mother died, we've leant on each other a lot.

I don't feel the age gap, because Alissa is very young at heart and when you love someone so much, the age doesn't make a difference. I find it quite cool having an older sister, especially one like Alissa. I'm just so proud of her. I've watched her music achievements over the years, seen her on TV and heard her on the radio. I've even asked her if one day she'll write a song about me.

Perhaps our relationship is different to normal sibling relationships because Alissa has watched me grow up and blossom more in the way that a parent would than a sister. She's very young, 28, and so that's not really like a mother, but she's also a very motherly figure in my life and cares for me in a practical way.

Mum was diagnosed with breast cancer when I was five, so Alissa has always helped out and been there for me. Perhaps knowing that Mum had this critical illness and could die one day made us closer as sisters, but I think we would have been very close anyway. At the moment I don't know what I'd do without her. I know it was a great comfort for Mum knowing we had each other. She used to say that by having us two girls she'd given each of us the perfect gift.

 Cherry Payne, 53, is 21 years older than her brother, Paul Shearing, 34. They have always lived in the village of Herstmonceux in East Sussex. Cherry is a PCV coach driver and has two children, Karen, 34, and Kevin, 32. Paul is a company director, married with two small children.

Cherry After I was born my mother was told she couldn't have any more children, but when I was 15 she suddenly discovered she was expecting my first brother, David in fact she found out practically on her due date! I was absolutely disgusted because I didn't think my parents did things like that.

I knew my dad had always wanted a son and I felt very, very jealous. David was born at home, but I wouldn't look at him for the first 24 hours. I was just coming into puberty and this was the first time that anything had rocked my life.

It was different when Paul came along five years later. By then I had moved out and I wasn't shocked or jealous. Ten months after Paul was born, I had my daughter, Karen, and they were brought up like brother and sister.

The older Paul has got the closer we've become. We're two of a kind. He's always looked out for me, even though I'm the older one. When I was ill three years ago, he visited me in hospital every day and was there for me whenever I needed him. He'll still ring up to see how I am. Our lives are very much linked, and it was Paul who introduced me to my present husband.

But it's never been a mother/son relationship. I think of Paul as my younger brother. Sometimes I feel the generation gap, but mostly having two younger brothers makes me feel younger than my age. In other ways, I think I lost out on a lot when I was a child. I feel envious of people who've got brothers and sisters closer in age because I was always on my own. I was treated like an only child and I felt like one, and sometimes it was difficult for me to mix with people because until David came along I was thoroughly spoilt.

For Mum and Dad, having two little boys in their forties made their life as parents much longer and meant they didn't have much time together. I went the opposite way and had two children in my early twenties and within two years of each other. I didn't want a big age gap because I wanted to have some life of my own at the end of it.

I've always been there for Paul, and when I lived alone before remarrying, he'd come and spend the evening with me and my children. He was a teenager, and he'd prefer to come to my house than spend it at home with our mum and dad. We'd go around like a little gang - I used to help look after David and Paul, and when Mum and Dad came to live near me, we'd mind all the kids together.

Paul and I have the same interests. People must think we're quite weird sometimes because we look a different age, but they'll see us feeding the ponies or hanging the garden gate together. But I don't think it looks like an old lady with a young lad. In fact, only the other day I was mistaken for Paul's wife!

It's only lately that I've thought of her more as a sister. That's come about with age and since becoming more of an equal to her than I was as a child.

fields.bodyText: Sibling relationships are fuelled by competition and riven by comparison. While a great deal may rest on personality, circumstances and gender, the nearer you are in age to your brother or sister, the more acute the sibling rivalry is likely to be. When Cherie Blair gives birth to her baby, due at the end of this month, there will be a gap of 16 years between her first, Euan, and her last child. Her daughter Kathryn will be 12 and her second son Nicholas, 14. The relationship this youngest child has with its older brothers and sister will be entirely different from the relationship they have with each other. The Blair baby will be cossetted, adored and treated like a very special person, not only by its parents but probably by its siblings, as rivalry usually loses its potency as the age gap widens. 'Sibling rivalry is usually for parents' affection, and in my clinical experience if there's a big gap they're still competing but they've got some distinction,' says David Spellman, a consultant psychologist who works with families. 'Possibly it's more tricky for the parents because there are so many facets to the task of parenting, but with the younger one, at least they've got experience to draw on and are probably better resourced financially.' The Blair baby will also feel in many ways like an only child. Everything it has will be new, since suitable clothes and toys will have been thrown out long ago. Just as the other three children are learning to exercise their independence, it will be locked into its parents' lives for many years to come - living, eating, holidaying alone with a mother and father old enough to be grandparents. Cherie Blair's pregnancy has invited copious comment, but once there was nothing unusual about late motherhood. In the late 19th century, sibling births spanned a generation, with new mothers often already grandmothers. American research shows that in the 20s, the average age at which women had their last child was 42, whereas now only 12 per cent of babies are born to women over 35. However, according to the Office of National Statistics, the most noticeable change in fertility over the past 20 years has been a shift towards later child-bearing. Significantly, since 1992 the number of 30- to 34-year-olds giving birth has exceeded the number of 20- to 24-year-olds giving birth. About 11,000 babies a year are born to women over 40, almost double the number 10 years ago, although still less than in the earlier part of the century. Thirty years ago, having a child in your forties was looked upon as a little weird - if not a little disgusting - but now, in an era where 55-year-old women can use IVF and egg donation to become pregnant, it isn't that unusual, especially among women who have held off having children for career purposes. Another reason why gaps between brothers and sisters are growing wider can be put down to the high level of divorce and remarriage. But what is less common is when children born to the same parents span a 10-, 15- or 20-year age gap. There are advantages and disadvantages to spreading your children out across the decades. For the mother and father, it can mean as many as 30 years of child-rearing, being bound at the hip to a toddler when your friends are rediscovering their freedom (not to mention the physical wear and tear on a body not designed for young children in middle age). On the other hand, there is nothing more likely to stop parents in their sixties from sinking into old age than having teenage children. For the youngest child, it can mean feeling isolated and spotlighted as 'special'; for the older child, a blurring of edges between parent and sibling. 'As long as the older children have the message that they'll still be special and there's emotional preparation for the new arrival, there's no evidence to suggest that anyone should suffer,' says Barry Mason, director of the Institute for Family Therapy. 'In fact, often a newborn baby can make a difference to a child who's been difficult because they find themselves giving a lot of affection to the new child. 'I know of no research that says having children a good few years apart is somehow bad.' David Spellman agrees. 'Older children can be nurturing of their younger brothers or sisters in a way that is actively supportive of their parents. Some parents even come to count on them. It can be a very enriching experience for all concerned.'  Singer/songwriter Alissa Scott, 28, and her sister Sophie Scott, 15, live within two miles of each other in north London. Alissa is best known for her song 'Only Human', written for Dina Carroll; recently her debut single 'Easy For You to Say' won widespread acclaim. Sophie lives with her father and will be taking her GCSEs next year. Two months ago, their mother died after a 10-year battle with cancer. Sophie and I are just like best friends nowadays, but I remember for the first two years of her life I was a bit jealous because suddenly all the attention went on to this beautiful little fair-haired thing. Even up until the age of eight she was a bit bossy because with Mum not being well it meant she wasn't able to discipline Sophie as much as she'd have liked to. My mum was 39 when she had Sophie and my Dad was 45, so they weren't that old, but when she got ill afterwards it obviously stopped them from having any more. Mum was very much a homemaker and loved having children round the house, but because of her illness it physically exhausted her. webTitle: The future isn't orange for Sunny D

fields.headline: The future isn't orange for Sunny D
fields.trailText: In the past couple of years, a curious phenomenon has been occurring in the chiller cabinets of our supermarkets. The Just Juices, smoothies and cordials have been usurped by a newcomer that's changed the face of the soft-drink brandscape. Last year, Sunny Delight stormed to third place in the UK 'pop' chart with annual sales of £160m, putting it streaks ahead of venerable brands such as Robinson's and challenging Pepsi - only £30m in front - for supremacy.
fields.body:
In the past couple of years, a curious phenomenon has been occurring in the chiller cabinets of our supermarkets. The Just Juices, smoothies and cordials have been usurped by a newcomer that's changed the face of the soft-drink brandscape. Last year, Sunny Delight stormed to third place in the UK 'pop' chart with annual sales of £160m, putting it streaks ahead of venerable brands such as Robinson's and challenging Pepsi - only £30m in front - for supremacy.

For Sunny Delight - or to use its 'street' name, Sunny D - is not a juice. Fruit derivatives - a cocktail of orange, lime, grapefruit and tangerine juices - make up only 5 per cent of its content. The rest is a riot of preservatives, flavourings and vegetable oil, plus, according to the watchdogs the Food Commission, 10-teaspoons-worth of sugar in each half-litre bottle. Sunny D, however, makes much of its 'enrichment' with beta-carotene and vitamins B and C - and therein lies a rub that could put the brakes on the brand's world domination.

Sunny D was initially marketed by its parent company, Proctor & Gamble, as a healthier alternative to the colas and Tangos. (In this, it was following an illustrious precedent; Coke itself was pushed as an 'esteemed brain tonic' on its launch a century ago). Its £7m Saatchi & Saatchi ad campaign - 'the great stuff kids go for!' - featured rosy outward-bound children watched over by complacent mums, secure in the knowledge that their offspring were vitamin-enhanced. It even supported Child Health Day in the US. 'It arrived at a time when there had been a lot of food scares, and the public were susceptible to optimistic messages,' says Tom Blackett, chairman at brand consultants Interbrand. 'The vitamin stuff gave it a white-coated credibility.'

P&G, having sold Sunny D in the US for 20 years and road-tested it in Carlisle for two years prior to its launch, wanted to ensure maximum visibility for the product, and set about wooing the supermarkets. 'Their clout ensured that it was given very high shelvage,' says an industry insider at a leading supermarket chain. 'Don't forget that P&G's main business is detergent; they know how to pile stuff high and sell it cheap.' They also employed data from loyalty-card schemes to direct-mail lower income families, offering Sunny D discounts.

However, the honeymoon period came to an abrupt end in August last year, when a report on the BBC's Watchdog urged parents to take a closer look at the stuff their kids were demanding and lapping up. The Food Commission also weighed in, accusing P&G of bandying phrases like 'California Style' and 'orange taste' to mislead punters into thinking they were being sold pure fruit juice. 'The initial trust gave way to scepticism,' says the supermarket insider. 'Mums came up to me, saying things like, "At least with Coke we know we're basically feeding our kids junk. If you looked at the ingredients of Sunny D, it sounded like a chemistry set."'

There was a certain inevitability to the subsequent rash of Sunny D scare stories-cum-playground myths: the grapefruit juice in it reacted badly with prescription hay fever medicine (false; too little to make any difference); it contains chalk (a 'fact' reported earnestly by a dentist acquaintance that's, regrettably, false); a girl turned orange after drinking it (true, her face and hands went tangerine, but only after consuming 1.5 litres in a single day); it needn't be in the chiller cabinet at all - false, insists John Bennett, marketing director at Proctor & Gamble. 'It's not a marketing con,' he says. 'It's in the cabinet to ensure that its vitamin levels are maintained.'

There's no doubt, however, that the adverse publicity recently dealt out to Sunny D has given P&G pause for thought. The more recent TV ads put less stress on health and more on gratification, and while John Bennett thinks the brand's 'core values' remain unaffected - 'it's a compromise between fizzy drinks and juices, with the vitamin content giving it that something extra' - he admits to mistakes in the way it was initially presented. 'I don't think we made it clear enough that Sunny D was a different brand of drink.'

To that end, P&G are experimenting with new Sunny D formats. Mango and orange and raspberry flavours will shortly be joined by a Five Alive-style Caribbean cocktail flavour, aimed at older teens; miniatures are also planned (to go alongside snap-boxes for Pringles, another P&G triumph), and calcium has recently been added to Sunny D in the US. Bennett says P&G are in it for the long-term, but for some it may be a case of stable doors and bolting horses. 'It doesn't matter what they put in it,' one mother told me. 'If they add vitamin C to tobacco, does that make it healthy?' 'May be it peaked too early,' says the industry insider. 'You'll see the displays getting smaller as it finds its natural level.'

Sunny D could be embattled on another front. 'It had huge success exploiting this gap in the market,' says Tom Blackett, 'so you can expect supermarkets to launch their own versions anytime soon.' Hmm - Cloudless Elation, anyone?

The rest is a riot of preservatives, flavourings and vegetable oil, plus, according to the watchdogs the Food Commission, 10-teaspoons-worth of sugar in each half-litre bottle. Sunny D, however, makes much of its 'enrichment' with beta-carotene and vitamins B and C - and therein lies a rub that could put the brakes on the brand's world domination. Sunny D was initially marketed by its parent company, Proctor & Gamble, as a healthier alternative to the colas and Tangos. (In this, it was following an illustrious precedent; Coke itself was pushed as an 'esteemed brain tonic' on its launch a century ago). Its £7m Saatchi & Saatchi ad campaign - 'the great stuff kids go for!' - featured rosy outward-bound children watched over by complacent mums, secure in the knowledge that their offspring were vitamin-enhanced. It even supported Child Health Day in the US. 'It arrived at a time when there had been a lot of food scares, and the public were susceptible to optimistic messages,' says Tom Blackett, chairman at brand consultants Interbrand. 'The vitamin stuff gave it a white-coated credibility.' P&G, having sold Sunny D in the US for 20 years and road-tested it in Carlisle for two years prior to its launch, wanted to ensure maximum visibility for the product, and set about wooing the supermarkets. 'Their clout ensured that it was given very high shelvage,' says an industry insider at a leading supermarket chain. 'Don't forget that P&G's main business is detergent; they know how to pile stuff high and sell it cheap.' They also employed data from loyalty-card schemes to direct-mail lower income families, offering Sunny D discounts. However, the honeymoon period came to an abrupt end in August last year, when a report on the BBC's Watchdog urged parents to take a closer look at the stuff their kids were demanding and lapping up. The Food Commission also weighed in, accusing P&G of bandying phrases like 'California Style' and 'orange taste' to mislead punters into thinking they were being sold pure fruit juice. 'The initial trust gave way to scepticism,' says the supermarket insider. 'Mums came up to me, saying things like, "At least with Coke we know we're basically feeding our kids junk. If you looked at the ingredients of Sunny D, it sounded like a chemistry set."' There was a certain inevitability to the subsequent rash of Sunny D scare stories-cum-playground myths: the grapefruit juice in it reacted badly with prescription hay fever medicine (false; too little to make any difference); it contains chalk (a 'fact' reported earnestly by a dentist acquaintance that's, regrettably, false); a girl turned orange after drinking it (true, her face and hands went tangerine, but only after consuming 1.5 litres in a single day); it needn't be in the chiller cabinet at all - false, insists John Bennett, marketing director at Proctor & Gamble. 'It's not a marketing con,' he says. 'It's in the cabinet to ensure that its vitamin levels are maintained.' There's no doubt, however, that the adverse publicity recently dealt out to Sunny D has given P&G pause for thought. The more recent TV ads put less stress on health and more on gratification, and while John Bennett thinks the brand's 'core values' remain unaffected - 'it's a compromise between fizzy drinks and juices, with the vitamin content giving it that something extra' - he admits to mistakes in the way it was initially presented. 'I don't think we made it clear enough that Sunny D was a different brand of drink.' To that end, P&G are experimenting with new Sunny D formats. Mango and orange and raspberry flavours will shortly be joined by a Five Alive-style Caribbean cocktail flavour, aimed at older teens; miniatures are also planned (to go alongside snap-boxes for Pringles, another P&G triumph), and calcium has recently been added to Sunny D in the US. Bennett says P&G are in it for the long-term, but for some it may be a case of stable doors and bolting horses. 'It doesn't matter what they put in it,' one mother told me. 'If they add vitamin C to tobacco, does that make it healthy?' 'May be it peaked too early,' says the industry insider. 'You'll see the displays getting smaller as it finds its natural level.' Sunny D could be embattled on another front. 'It had huge success exploiting this gap in the market,' says Tom Blackett, 'so you can expect supermarkets to launch their own versions anytime soon.' Hmm - Cloudless Elation, anyone?

fields.headline: Fast Forward
fields.standfirst: The loafer's guide to popular culture. This week: Laurie Anderson
fields.trailText: The loafer's guide to popular culture. This week: Laurie Anderson
fields.body:
Remember her? Of course you do - she's best known for her eight-minute pop hit 'Oh Superman' and more recently as Lou Reed's other half. Sweetly, life for Mr and Mrs Avant-garde revolves around a terrier, Lola Belle. 'Neither of us ever had kids,' Laurie explains. But we digress. Her new work is an opera about a whale, Songs and Stories From Moby Dick, which will be at London's Barbican Centre later this month.

Tell us more. Based on Herman Melville's 19th-century tale of obsession and destruction aboard the whaling ship Pequod, the opera came about when she was asked to create a monologue on her favourite book for a TV show. It fell through, but Anderson re-created Moby Dick as an avant-garde opera. Not all 720 pages of it - 10 per cent is down to Melville, the rest is Laurie's 'meditations and reflections on this powerful book'.

What? You mean she just made most of it up? Look, she's a techno-artist given to wild inspiration. Or as she puts it: 'In the spirit of Melville's digressions, I invented and added whatever I felt like adding.' OK, she made it up. At least at 96 minutes, it's a tad shorter than her eight-hour opus United States - a multi-media epic with synth songs, projected images and stories about 'people's attempts to live in the electronic world'.

Talking of which, isn't Moby Dick a little old-fashioned for such a technophile? Well, according to Laurie, the 21st century is all about being 'obsessive, technological, voluble and in search of the transcendent', which is obviously also a pretty accurate description of Melville's existential floating whale factory. Add in his multi-layered narrative style and his musings on history, philosophy, science, religion and whales, and you have something that just screams multi-media. In fact, it's so NOW that she's even invented a new instrument for the show, the Talking Stick. It's described by Laurie as 'a physical representation of the disembodied voice, as well as a physical digital descendant of turntables'.

Eh? Basically, it's a long paddle, packed with software that emits pre-recorded sounds - seagull cries, ships creaks, bagpipes - at a touch. And, of course, if it doesn't catch on, it will still come in handy.

How so? As a toy for Lou and Laurie's dog. Fetch, Lola Belle, fetch.

fields.headline: From arthouse to  funhouse
fields.standfirst: French actress Irene Jacob rose to fame guided by her mentor - the late Krzysztof Kieslowski. But the star of  Three Colours: Red, tired of playing 'tragic' women, had fun with her new film,  My Life So Far
fields.trailText: French actress Irene Jacob rose to fame guided by her mentor - the late Krzysztof Kieslowski. But the star of Three Colours: Red, tired of playing 'tragic' women, had fun with her new film, My Life So Far
fields.body:
Because Irène Jacob is three-quarters of an hour late for our interview in Paris (it is not her fault but a cross-channel PR mix-up), the French-based photographer and I have plenty of time to discuss our subject. She's one of 'those types', he says. She makes the kind of French arthouse fare he's dragged to by his partner: precious little dialogue, pensive expressions and ambiguous endings. Ah, that sort.

Jacob is, after all, one of the darlings of European cinema. She has worked with three of the undisputed heavyweights - Kieslowski, Malle and Antonioni - and won the best actress award at the Cannes film festival when she was just 25. One imagines small talk and bouts of frivolity will not be on the menu today.

But Jacob arrives with a ready smile and an instant handshake. During the interview she laughs frequently and talks quickly and passionately without apparent guile. At times her voice rings with girlish glee.

She explains that her early roles were often 'unsatisfied' women. 'I was constantly offered parts that were very interiorised and things that were slightly tragic. I don't know why. I enjoyed doing those big, probing parts but that wasn't who I was at the time. I also really like comedy and recently I've got to do some different parts.'

It was her two films with the late Krzysztof Kieslowski, the Polish existentialist, that set the standard. Both films, The Double Life of Veronique (1991) and Three Colours: Red (1994) explored themes of destiny and loneliness and saw the birth of the original Jacob persona: the chic, independent young woman prone to soul searching with an innate desire to connect. They were profoundly intimate performances. According to Jacob, though, there was no Method secret to the intensity of her speech and gaze.

'The camera was really like a microscope. Krzysztof was always very close and very precise in his directions. It was not something he talked about beforehand; he would only work on the set. He liked to rehearse just before a take, if at all.'

Her latest role in My Life So Far, starring Colin Firth and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, is definitely Jacob post-Kieslowski. In this amiable yet hardly substantive family drama set in the inter-war years, Jacob plays the elegant, spirited Gallic fiancée who sets pulses racing amid a mildly eccentric Scottish gentry family.

'I thought the character was very inspiring and liked the way she interacted very honestly with all the children,' she says. 'It reminded me of Au Revoir Les Enfants when I was the piano teacher and all the boys were inspired by me as the only woman in the place.'

Her role in Louis Malle's heartfelt memoir about anti-Semitism came while she was still in drama school in 1987. Jacob had partially impressed Malle by telling him she could play the piano. On set, his direction was succinct. 'He told me to file my nails, yawn a bit and look into the distance and immediately the character was there,' she recalls.

She was born in Paris but raised in Geneva by strict parents. 'I think we are in a generation where people talk to their children a lot and explain things to them but it wasn't like that then. The most important thing was having a good education.' So was Jacob's decision to leave home for Paris and drama school at 18 an act of rebellion? 'There are many reasons why I wanted to act but perhaps it's true that was one of them.' She gets more animated. 'You have to want to be an actor in spite of everything.'

Her conversation is peppered with reference to Kieslowski. She speaks of him with great affection but denies being his confidante. He moulded her early career but he often kept her in the dark about the process. The actress initially felt little affinity with her character in Red and she found plenty of The Double Life of Veronique mystifying until she saw the finished film.

'He didn't like talking about a role,' she says. 'He felt that would impose a direction and not allow you to follow your instincts. If I asked him a question, he would say "Well, you know it's more interesting for me to know what you think about it, or how would you answer it."'

Afterwards, Hollywood came calling, but she turned down the lead role in Indecent Proposal because she didn't 'feel comfortable with the film's sensibility'. Her rare Hollywood excursions have been in small films (Incognito) or small roles in big films (US Marshals). Instead, she entered her 'English period'; an alluring performance as Desdemona in Othello (1995) and she was good in Mark Peploe's version of Conrad's Victory in the same year.

Then there was Antonioni's Beyond the Clouds. The director had suffered a severe stroke but he still coaxed a beatific performance from Jacob as a rather austere young woman pursued on foot by a handsome suitor. And his most telling direction? 'He would just ask me to do bigger steps?' Excuse me? 'It sounds quite odd but you see by doing bigger steps you have a different energy,' she explains.

She only appeared in one of the four vignettes in Antonioni's film, and it's clear Jacob still hankers for those 'big, probing parts'. At 34 she is well respected, works around the world and is undoubtedly a directors' favourite. But she is unwilling to make the choices and calculations that would lead to greater fame. Post-Kieslowski, kudos counts, but having fun is important too. She likes to play with her image and confound audiences. 'If I choose a part, it's because I'm moved by it and I like the director. It's only for that reason now. I have to be curious about the part whether it's nice, not nice, mean, jealous, generous, aggressive. Who cares? If it moves me, I'll do it.'

 My Life So Far opens on 12 May

fields.headline: O unhappy man
fields.standfirst: Lindsay Anderson was a stranger to serenity, as Gavin Lambert tells in Mainly About Lindsay Anderson
fields.trailText: Lindsay Anderson was a stranger to serenity, as Gavin Lambert tells in Mainly About Lindsay Anderson
fields.body:
Mainly About Lindsay Anderson: A Memoir
Gavin Lambert
Faber £20, pp302
Buy it at BOL

The French movie critics on Cahiers du Cinema - Chabrol, Truffaut, Godard, Rivette, Rohmer - who became world famous as the Nouvelle Vague have received more publicity than their gifted British contemporaries, Lindsay Anderson, Gavin Lambert, Tony Richardson and Karel Reisz.

But a case could be made out for the equal importance of this Oxbridge quartet, who emerged as critics on the influential short-lived Sequence and the British Film Institute's quarterly Sight and Sound, which they transformed in the early Fifties into a magazine of world importance, before themselves becoming moviemakers.

They wrote with greater lucidity, their best films survive impressively and they operated in a culture much less sympathetic to the cinema than that of their French confrères.

Richardson was from a Yorkshire working-class background. Reisz came to England as a pre-war refugee from Czechoslovakia. Lambert and Anderson were products of the British upper-middle-class who met in 1939 at Cheltenham College, the setting 30 years later of Anderson's surreal satire If...

They became lifelong friends, and Lambert's affectionate but sharply unsentimental memoir deals with a close personal and professional relationship that lasted for more than half a century until Anderson's death in 1995 at the age of 72.

Two things brought them together - a passion for the cinema and a rebellious attitude towards the Establishment in all its manifestations. Their first joint act of defiance was to perform a Noël Coward sketch in drag to outrage their headmaster.

Lambert's title alludes to his friend's 1982 monograph About John Ford and is as much about the author as his subject and this is what makes it so fascinating. The book is in effect about the different responses of two sensitive, intelligent artists to British life and their sexuality during a period of rapid social change, and Lambert brings to it the skills he has honed as screenwriter and novelist.

Both Lambert and Anderson hated the snobbish, blinkered, unimaginative Britain into which they were born. But Lambert turned his back on it in 1956, resigning from the editorship of Sight and Sound to settle in America, embark on a successful career as a writer and become a confident cosmopolitan.

Anderson remained at home, engaging as a polemicist, theatre director, and moviemaker with a society that he wanted to influence and change.

From the age of 11 the precocious Lambert was a guilt-free practising homosexual. He became the lover and cinematic collaborator of Peter Brook at Oxford, was taken to Hollywood as an assistant to another lover, Nicholas Ray, and writes frankly of his cruising days in Los Angeles and the 12-year affair with a working-class Arab in Tangier.

He had 'always wanted Lindsay as a best friend' and they never became lovers. But Anderson, by Lambert's account, never came to terms with his gay nature. Born in India, Anderson was the guilt-ridden son of a domineering mother, who left her rigid military husband for another Army officer, and his unceasing struggles with a puritanical conscience were recorded in an eloquent journal of which Lambert makes good use.

'It seems then I'm homosexual,' he reluctantly noted at the age of 20, though he never formed a permanent relationship and endlessly complicated his life by falling in love with heterosexual married men, usually actors. Most notable among these inaccessible objects of desire were Serge Reggiani, and three stars from Britain whose careers Anderson helped launch: Albert Finney, Richard Harris and Frank Grimes.

Lambert, you infer, is at peace with himself. Anderson, on the other hand, was a stranger to serenity, a spiky man whose every activity involved severe moral challenges to himself and others. His refusal to compromise limited the amount of work he accomplished but was central to his important achievements, most notably This Sporting Life, If... and O Lucky Man.

Capable of being 'totally irrational,' according to his long-time time collaborator David Storey, Anderson was as complex a mixture of kindness and cruelty as John Ford, one of the triumvirate of cinematic poets he idolised, the others being Jean Vigo and Humphrey Jennings. The last two died young, leaving even smaller bodies of work than Anderson's, but every item a gem. Ford was an idealist whose belief in communities, large and small, became increasingly attenuated, until only the business of making films with friends sustained it. Something of the same happened to Anderson and his last film, the autobiographical TV essay Is That All There Is? concluded with a boat trip down the Thames accompanied by a party of friends to scatter the ashes of Jill Bennett and Rachel Roberts on the waters.

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Hilary Spurling gets behind the dull image of a painter who shaped the visual language of the 20th century
fields.body:
The Unknown Matisse: Man of the North 1869-1908
Hilary Spurling
Penguin £12.99, pp423
Buy it at BOL

Matisse's paintings are among the best-loved and most joyful artistic creations but unlike other modernists, in particular his younger contemporary, Picasso, he has suffered from a matt and unsexy profile. Indeed, little had been written about him until Spurling's text first appeared in hardback last year.

She gets behind the dull image to present a painter who shaped the visual imagination of the last century by the way he met its horrors. She writes: 'His intimate acquaintance with violence and destruction, a sense of human misery sharpened by years of humiliation could be neutralised only by the serene power and stable weight of art.'

As a boy, Matisse dreamed of being an acrobat, knowing that, in fact, he would end up lugging around sacks in the family business. Kidney problems saved him from this fate and he turned to law. He discovered his vocation during a brief spell in hospital when a fellow patient, copying a Swiss landscape from a coloured reproduction, urged him to do the same.

He took off for Paris with a small allowance from his father, but was later made to feel he had brought disgrace on his family. Spurling invigorates the tale with details of his affairs and friends.

It is well known that Matisse suffered public mockery and financial insecurity, but neither the degree of misery he endured nor its different causes have ever been uncovered - until now. For Matisse's harmonies of colour and design were hard won, crafted in the face of discord and disorder. This is truly the 'unknown Matisse'.

He took off for Paris with a small allowance from his father, but was later made to feel he had brought disgrace on his family. Spurling invigorates the tale with details of his affairs and friends. It is well known that Matisse suffered public mockery and financial insecurity, but neither the degree of misery he endured nor its different causes have ever been uncovered - until now. For Matisse's harmonies of colour and design were hard won, crafted in the face of discord and disorder. This is truly the 'unknown Matisse'.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: James Macpherson delivers a taut abridgement, whilst The Hanging Garden is allowed space to flourish in a full-length version
fields.body:
Set In Darkness
Ian Rankin
Read by James Macpherson
Running time 6hrs 20mins Orion Audio £12.99
Buy it at BOL

A decayed corpse is uncovered by workmen setting up the offices for the new Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh. Days later, a prospective MSP is found dead, a tramp throws himself through the roof of Waverley station, leaving £40,000.

So the scene is set for Rankin's eleventh D.I. Rebus investigation. The cracking pace of the narration and the speed of the dialogue sharpen the story's harsh mood, while the abridgement tautens the dramatic force.

The Hanging Garden
Ian Rankin
Read by Joe Dunlop
Running time 12hrs 30mins
Isis £18.99
Mail order details: 0800 731 5637
Buy it at BOL

This is one of three unabridged Rankin titles on Isis. Rebus breaks down a lavatory door to find a Bosnian girl, who has been forced into prostitution, choking to death on a piece of paper she has stuffed into her mouth. Rebus pulls it out, saving her life, and starting a complex inquiry involving the exploitation of Balkan refugees.

The mood is mellowed by Dunlop's reading, which is less hectic than Macpherson's, his accent softened for the narrative voice and a broader Scots reserved for the dialogue. In the unabridged reading, relationships, like the growing trust between the Bosnian girl and Rebus, have time to develop convincingly, and the insights into Rebus's remorse for his failed marriage deepen the listener's sympathy with him. The result is a more leisurely listening experience.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Elmore Leonard on top form, plus Starcrossed, The Tulip, For the Relief of Unbearable Urges and Genome
fields.body:
Be Cool
Elmore Leonard
Penguin, £6.99, pp292
Buy it at BOL

Chili Palmer, Leonard's laid-back protagonist, approaches his profession of film-making much as his creator constructs his novel: assemble a gaggle of idiosyncratic characters, weave a plot to incorporate them all, give the impression that the story is writing itself effortlessly.

Against the backdrop of shallow Los Angeles, Leonard rustles up a plot that, while bordering on the incredible, certainly showcases his expert ear for dialogue. The assassination of Tommy Athens, an acquaintance of Chili, in broad daylight jumps the latter's imagination.

Juxtapose the lives and aspirations of a honey-toned beauty, a good black cop, a big gay Samoan bodyguard and a few unsavoury characters plucked from the music industry, stir in a few members of the Russian mafia for flavour and a great novel, slick as oil, is born.

Starcrossed
AA Gill

Black Swan, £6.99, pp349
Buy it at BOL

Gill was justifiably awarded the Literary Review 's Bad Sex Prize for this prize example of pap. Quotes from the pornographic manuscript penned by the vile Clive (friend of the hero) are particularly worthy of that accolade.

The plot is a tired rehash of Notting Hill: Lee Montana, archetypal American glamourpuss celebrity, plucks John Dart, aimless poet, Oxford graduate, bookshop assistant from obscurity. Sex, shopping and dining at fancy restaurants frequented by the likes of Joan Collins ensues with John equally discomfited and hypnotised by this new world of riches and fame. Cue musings on life, love and self, padded out with acidic attacks on hoi polloi at every possible opportunity as this laughably awful novel lurches towards its half-cocked happy ending.

The Tulip
Anna Pavord
Bloomsbury, £8.99,pp295

Buy it at BOL

Delicate Coquette, Matchless Pearl and Those That Burn the Heart are but a fraction of the fancy names given to the myriad varieties of a flower that has bewitched men for centuries. In her erudite, enthusiastic study, Pavord chronicles man's obsession with the tulip from the Turkish Era in Constantinople under Sultan Ahmed III to the 'Tulipomania' of seventeenth-century Holland to the present day.

Colour illustrations complement Pavord's passages on changing perceptions of the bloom while the odd anecdote injects humour. Though the popularity of the tulip may wax and wane, though the advent of horticulture has robbed the bloom of some of its mystery, its magic endures - underlined by the export of two million flowers from the Netherlands every year.

For the Relief of Unbearable Urges
Nathan Englander
Faber & Faber, £6.99, pp205
Buy it at BOL

Englander's collection of short stories united by Jewish themes is an impressive, confident debut threaded with wry humour and evocative detail.

The action moves from Stalin's Russia through New York to contemporary Israel with Englander's focus tight on his characters' lives, from the hirsute Gitta Floog as desperate to rid herself of her husband as she is to banish the hair from her upper lip, to Charles, a Gentile, whose epiphany in the back of a cab that he is Jewish reveals also the prejudice of those dearest to him. The final story is the most powerful, the setting the aftermath of a bomb in Jerusalem, the mood serious, an overview of the Jewish people, effecting a neat conclusion to this sympathetic, eloquent examination of individual lives.

Genome
Matt Ridley
4th Estate, £8.99, 344pp
Buy it at BOL

'Seaweed is your distant cousin and anthrax one of your advanced relatives,' reveals Ridley in this history of mankind, informed by advances in genetics, written with spirit and passion.

Expanding on this statement in the 23 chapters of his thorough, complex autobiography of the human species, each one relating to the pairs of chromosomes in each individual, Ridley aims, for the most part successfully, to elucidate scientific phenomena for the layman.

The genome, (the collective noun for our approximately 100,000 genes) can be read as the dictionary of all life from plant to animal, bug to blob, explaining our place in the world and the processes of evolution, even allowing Ridley to make the provocative claim that there may exist a gene responsible for free will.

webTitle: Remembrance of sex and mashed spuds

fields.headline: Remembrance of sex and mashed spuds
fields.standfirst: William C Carter tells the story of a hero's life in Marcel Proust: A Life
fields.trailText: William C Carter tells the story of a hero's life in Marcel Proust: A Life
fields.body:
Marcel Proust: A Life
William C Carter
Yale £22.50, pp961
Buy it at BOL

Proust shared some of Oscar Wilde's fatal foibles. They both adored duchesses and had sex with the hired help. But Proust avoided Wilde's gravest tactical error, which was - as Wilde himself admitted - to put his genius into his life, leaving only his talent for his works.

Preparing to write his own great work of self-analysis and retrospection, Proust in effect retired from life. He took to his bed for 15 years to write In Search of Lost Time. Inside his cork-lined hermitage, he lived vicariously, reading seven newspapers a day and quizzing servants about the habits of the beau monde. Having completed the book, and wrecked his health in the process, he announced to his housekeeper that he was ready to die, and promptly did so.

It is, as William C Carter makes clear, a hero's life, even though most of it was spent in a horizontal position. The recurring motif of this sympathetic and assiduous biography is the triumph of Proust's will. No one who knew him as an asthmatic, mother-fixated boy or a swishy, dandyfied young man credited him, as his classmate Daniel Halevy said, with 'the will to power to ever achieve a masterpiece'.

The doubters were wrong. Despite his neurasthenia, Proust relished the year he spent in the army as a conscript, fought a duel when his literary achievements were impugned, and later took pride in the military daring of homosexual friends who fought in the 1914-18 war; he even compared the novelist - meaning himself - with a general who plots strategy and mobilises multitudes. The ferocity of his ambition was positively Napoleonic.

Napoleon had himself painted by David in a curtained office at three in the morning, demonstrating that the all-seeing dictator must be a night worker. The insomniac Proust maintained a similar routine, and wilfully obliged others to accommodate themselves to the bizarre hours he kept. If he wanted to hear a string quartet, there was no question of going out in the evening to a concert. The players must come to him after midnight; more than once he drove through Paris in a carriage - swaddled in an eiderdown and scoffing mashed potatoes - to rouse them from their beds, extorting encores as dawn approached by stuffing their pockets with money.

In 1917 military exigencies deferred to his whim as he corrected his proofs. He was in the habit of eating a nocturnal breakfast at the Ritz, but the blackout compelled them to switch off the lights at 9.30pm; Proust took his custom to the Hotel Crillon, next to the American embassy, where the use of electricity was permitted until 2am.

His publisher called Proust 'the most complicated man in Paris'. Those who invited him to dinner were barraged in advance with a list of demands, mostly involving the prevention of draughts or the provision of Evian water and hot-water bottles. His world collapsed if he could not locate a certain safety pin which he fastened to his underpants: he believed that it 'kept his abdomen in and prevented stomach aches'. His fear of germs - and his ritualised retreat from the soiling transactions of the real world - meant that he would read letters only if they had been disinfected by formaldehyde for two hours.

But there was method in this fussy, infuriating madness. Proust was creating the conditions necessary for his artistic work, turning disabilities to advantage. Take, for instance, his visits to the male brothel which he supposedly bankrolled. One young man he often chose from the line-up was asked to undress, stand by the door and masturbate while Proust, tucked in bed with the sheet prudishly drawn up to his chin, did likewise. It sounds commendably safe, but more than that it served the purpose of research: for Proust the novelist was an observer, not a participant. His fascination with the will made him curious about sado-masochism, which is a theatre of power. For an extra fee, the brothel keeper allowed him to watch through a concealed window while a nobleman from the provinces was chained to the wall and flogged.

Martyred to his art, Proust accepted the self-denials it enjoined. But what fuelled his sessions of nocturnal work? Carter horrifyingly documents the drug abuse which for Proust was a vocational necessity. He insisted on medicating himself for imaginary ailments, and 'consumed huge quantities of caffeine in pill form, laced with bromide as a corrective to coffee's stimulation properties'. Once he carelessly swallowed 70 times the prescribed quantity of Veronal.

Towards the end of his life, he overdosed on dry adrenaline, and scorched his digestive tract. After this, he subsisted on ice cream and cold beer, ferried to his sickbed from the Ritz. Like all hypochondriacs, he was an eager amateur physician, and diagnosed a brain disorder which he thought could be relieved by drilling holes into his skull. Luckily the neurologist he consulted refused to operate.

Without suspending this suicidal regime, Proust found the energy, when the serial publication of In Search of Lost Time finally began, for a shrewd promotional campaign. He treated critics to bedside interviews, dispatched his servants to ensure that his books were available in the shops, harried his publisher without mercy and even paid a menacing late-night call on Maurice Barres to order his own immediate election to the Academie française.

He likened the painter Elstir in his novel to Michelangelo, 'strapped to his scaffold' just below the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel; he compared himself to the prophet Nehemiah, who called to the groundlings from his vertiginous perch on a ladder: 'I cannot come down, I am finishing a great task'.

Carter, who considers Proust's epic of introspection to be 'the most remarkable example of a sustained narrative in the history of literature', demonstrates that he had every right to his fanatical solipsism. His book was a search for lost time and also a race against elapsing time, which he gloriously won - and, because he believed that neurotics are altruists, pondering and resolving problems of existence which the healthy and well-adjusted can afford to ignore, the victory is ours as well as his.

fields.headline: Alzheimer Fruit
fields.trailText:
In that underworld you ambled off to

On your own, you must have drunk or eaten

Something prohibited so that your memory

Of this life faded. But where could that place

Have been? And what was the fruit? If we knew,
fields.body:
In that underworld you ambled off to

On your own, you must have drunk or eaten

Something prohibited so that your memory

Of this life faded. But where could that place

Have been? And what was the fruit? If we knew,

We'd go there with you, or for you, and put it back:

Whatever it was you ate or drank or brought away.

I dreamt I came upon you in the early hours

In your pyjamas, scoring a sheet of paper

Over and over with a highlighter pen.

'This pen's gone dry,' you said. 'I'm trying my best

To make it orange up this paragraph.'
